-- MacBain, Alexander
-- An Etymological Dictionary of the Gaelic Language
-- 1st edition - 1896
-- 2nd edition (revised) - 1911
--
-- Photolitho Reprint of 1911 edition - 1982
-- Gairm Publications, 29 Waterloo Street, Glasgow G2 6BZ
-- Tel. 041-221 1971
-- Printed by Clark Constable (1982) Let, Edinburgh
-- ISBN 0 901771 68 6
--
-- Lines beginning, like this one, with two hyphens are not part of the
-- original text, but contain added documentation, page numbers, etc.
--
-- The UTF-8 character set is used throughout this document.
--
-- The following formatting conventions are used:-
--   {...}   italics
--   <...>   bold
--   ^       superscript - the following single character is a superscript
--
-- The following markup tags are also used:
--   @Ref    a reference to another headword (as in @Ref<tàbh> or @Ref{ceò})
--           may contain sense id (as in @Ref<an.4>)
--   @ExtRef an external reference (as in @ExtRef{title;vol;page})
--
-- Greek alphabet encoding
--  The range of Greek characters in Unicode is from:
--    0300-0367  Combining Diacritical Marks - http://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U0300.pdf
--    0370-03FF  Greek and Coptic - http://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U0370.pdf
--    1F00-1FFF  Greek Extended - http://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U1F00.pdf
--  The following characters are used from this range to encode Greek characters:
--   α  03B1      a    alpha
--   ά  03AC      a/   alpha with tonos  (REVIEW: should be 1F71 alpha with oxia)
--   ᾱ  1FB1      a@-  alpha with macron
--   ἀ  1F00      a@'  alpha with psili (comma above)
--   ἁ  1F01      a@`  alpha with dasia (backward comma above)
--   ἂ  1F02      a@'\ alpha with psili and varia
--   ἄ  1F04      a@'/ alpha with psili and oxia
--   ἅ  1F05      a@`/ alpha with psili and dasia
--   ᾶ  1FB6      a@n  alpha with perispomeni (wavy dash above)
--   β  03B2      b    beta
--   γ  03B3      g    gamma
--   δ  03B4      d    delta
--   Δ  0394      D    delta (capital)
--   ε  03B5      e    epsilon
--   έ  03AD      e/   epsilon with tonos (REVIEW: should be 1F73 epsilon with oxia)
--   ἐ  1F10      e@'  epsilon with psili
--   ἑ  1F11      e@`  epsilon with dasia
--   ε̑  03B5 0311 e@n  epsilon with inverted breve
--   ἒ  1F12      e@'/ (REVIEW: should be 1F14 epsilon with psili and oxia)
--   ἕ  1F15      e@`/ epsilon with dasia and oxia
--   ἔ  1F14      e@'\ (REVIEW: should be 1F12 epsilon with psili and varia)
--   ἓ  1F13      e@`\ epsilon with dasia and varia
--   ε῏ 03B5 1FCF e@'@n
--   ζ  03B6      z  eta
--   Ζ  0396      Z  eta (capital)
--   η  03B7      c    eta
--   ή  1F75      c/   eta with oxia
--   ἠ  1F20      c@'  eta with psili
--   ἡ  1F21      c@`  eta with dasia
--   ῆ  1FC6      c@n  eta with perispomeni (REVIEW: should be 03B7+0311 eta with inverted breve)
--   ἤ  1F24      c@'/ eta with psili and oxia
--   θ  03B8      q    theta
--   ι  03B9      i    iota
--   í  00ED      í    REVIEW: non-greek char, replace with iota
--   î  00EE      î    REVIEW: non-greek char
--   ΐ  0390      ï/
--   ἰ  1F30      i@'  
--   ἱ  1F31      i@`
--   ῖ  1FD6      i@n  REVIEW use inverted breve
--   ἲ  1F32      i@'/ 
--   ἵ  1F35      i@`/ 
--   ἶ  1F36      i@'@n 
--   κ  03BA      k    kappa
--   λ  03BB      l    lambda
--   Λ  039B      L 
--   μ  03BC      m    mu
--   ν  03BD      n    nu
--   ξ  03BE      x    xi
--   ο  03BF      o    omicron
--   ό  03CC      ó 
--   ὀ  1F40      o@' 
--   ὁ  1F41      o@` 
--   ο῀  03BF+1FC0 o@n REVIEW
--   ὄ  1F44      o@'/ 
--   ὅ  1F45      o@`/ 
--   π  03C0      p    pi
--   ρ  03C1      r    rho
--   ῥ  1FE5      r@` 
--   ς  03C2      s    sigma (final)
--   σ  03C3      s    sigma
--   τ  03C4      t    tau
--   υ  03C5      u    upsilon
--   ύ  03CD      ú 
--   ῡ́  1FE1+0301 ū́ 
--   ὐ  1F50      u@' 
--   ὑ  1F51      u@` 
--   ῦ  1FE6      u@n 
--   ὔ  1F54      u@'/ 
--   ὕ  1F55      u@`/ 
--   ὗ  1F57      u@`@n 
--   ὖ  1F56      u@'@n 
--   φ  03C6      f    phi
--   χ  03C7      h    chi
--   ψ  03C8      y    psi
--   ω  03C9      w    omega
--   ώ  1F7D      w/ 
--   ὠ  1F60      w@' 
--   ῶ  1FF6      w@n 
--   ὤ  1F64      w@'/ 
--   ὦ  1F66      w@'@n 
--   ϝ  03DD      F    digamma
--   v  0076  v    REVIEW greek letter
-- Fixup Greek: use inverted breve instead of perispomeni
--              use oxia instead of tonos for consistency *** TODO ***
--
-- Lines of the text are strictly adhered to, except that words split
-- across successive lines by a hyphen are recombined and inserted
-- on the first line.
-- Punctuation is moved out of quotes where the logic of parsing dictates this,
-- e.g. "sharp bush or tree"; where the book has "sharp bush or tree;".
-- If a word referred to (i.e. an italicised word) has a capital letter 
-- purely because it is at the beginning of the sentence, I have changed
-- the capital letter to lower case.
-- Punctuation is corrected in the relatively small number of instances where
-- it is obviously incorrect according to the conventions used elsewhere in
-- the dictionary.
--
-- Comments added to the original text have put put on separate lines,
-- beginning with three dashes and the initials of the commentator.  e.g.
--         ---KPD: More likely to be from ...
-- Initials used:
--   KPD  Kevin P. Donnelly
--   gjk  Gary J. Kacmarcik
--   JTM  John T. MacCranie
--
-- Suggestions for future modernisations:
--   - Change "aspirate" to "lenite"
--   - Change "small" to "slender"
--   - Put dictionary in correct alphabetical order throughout
--   - Place inserted entries in proper place (currently at end of doc)
--   - Review all Greek f/phi
--   - Make accent reference table
-- Questions:
--   - "g." (in addition to "G.") is used as a language title.
--       Is this a typo (used sporatically throughout the document) for "G."?
--       If not, what does it correspond to?
--
-- Notes:
--   - The cross-reference tags (@Ref) are currently overgenerated since they have
--      been automatically inserted whenever a highlighted word matches a headword.
--      Thus, foreign words that are orthographically coincident with a headword
--      will be (incorrectly) noted as a cross-reference.
--
-- Suggestions for parsing:
--   - Some tags appear across line breaks (e.g., {áirneis no spréidh} in <eudail>).
--       Collapsing each entry to a single line (using a single space to replace
--       the line break and indent) can make it easier to match tags correctly.
--   - The {}s do not nest, so when the { is found you can search forward until the 
--       } is found without concern.
--
-- Air a chur air a' choimpiutair le Caoimhín Pádraig Ó Donnaíle
-- Earraid House, Biggar Road, Dùn Éideann, EH10 7DX, Alba
-- A' tòiseachadh 1990-03-14; deiseil 1990-10-10
-- 140 uairean a thìde de dh'obair.
--
-- While numerous corrections and updates have been made to this text,
-- it has only been keyed in one time. There are undoubtedly many other
-- mistakes which have not yet been corrected. Before any serious work is
-- done with it, it needs to be keyed in again to verify it and correct
-- typing mistakes.
--
-- 2007-01-21 1.16  (gjk)  Use {...} for italics to eliminate ambiguous markup
--                         Fixup Greek: use inverted breve instead of perispomeni
--                                      use oxia instead of tonos for consistency *** TODO ***
--                         Replace @G with language tag (@Gr, @Dor, ...) or remove as appropriate
--                         Add language tags for many languages
--                         Move asterisks outside {}s for consistency with cross-references
--                         Fix typos, markup errors
-- 2007-01-15 1.15  (gjk/  Merge JTM's 1.11b changes with 1.14
--                   JTM)  Revert Armenian (to be reviewed later)
-- 2005-02-11 1.14  (gjk)  Add numeric suffix to distinguish each sense (when multiple entries exist)
--                         Add @Ref to mark internal headword cross-references
--                         Change accents in cross-refs to be consistent with headword (these changes
--                           are always marked with a comment)
--                         Change "see next word" et al. to explicit cross-reference
--                         Added over 1500 new headwords from alternates given in existing entries
-- 2005-01-10 1.13  (gjk)  Convert more accents sequences to UTF-8 & fix lots of typos
-- 2005-01-07 1.12  (gjk)  Direct conversion of 1.11 from Latin-1 to UTF-8
-- 2004-??-?? 1.11b (JTM)  Convert from Latin-1 into UTF-8
--                         Fix language abbreviations and numerous other typos.
--                         Convert Greek, Russian, Bulgarian and Armenian transliterated characters
--                           into appropriate UTF-8 chars.
--                         Replace '?' accents with correct forms
-- 2000-04-11 1.11  (KPD)  Na ceann-fhaclan air an dearbhadh.  Mearachdan
--                           an-siud 's an-seo air an ceartachadh.
-- 2000-04-08 1.10  (KPD)  Air a thiondadh bho ASCII gu Latin-1, cho fad 's
--                           a b'urrainn

--page xiii
ABBREVIATIONS

1. LANGUAGE TITLES

-- Note that multiple language identifiers can be placed around a single word (e.g.: @Ir@OIr{an-}).
--  When there are multiple identifiers, they should occur in alphabetical order.
-- Note that the process of marking up all words with language ids is not yet complete.

Ag.S.           Anglo Saxon

2. BOOKS AND AUTHORITIES

A.M`D           Alexander Macdonald's {Gaelic Songs}, with vocabulary
Atk.            Atkinson's Dictionary to the {Passions and Homilies
                     from the Leabhar Breac}, 1887
Arm.,Arms.      Armstrong's {Gaelic Dictionary}, 1825
B.of Deer       Book of Deer, edited by Stokes in {Goidelica}, 1872
Bez.Beit.       Bezzenberger's {Beiträge zur Kunde der Idg. Sprachen},
                     a German periodical still proceeding
C.S.            Common Speech, not yet recorded in literature
Celt.Mag        The {Celtic Magazine}, 13 vols., stopped in 1888
Con.            Coneys' {Irish-English Dictionary}, 1849
--page xiv
Corm.           Cormac's Glossary, published in 1862 and 1868, edited
                     by Dr Whitely Stokes
D.of L.         {The Dean of Lismore's Book}, edited in 1862, 1892
Four Mast.      Annals of the Four Masters, published in 1848, 1851
Fol.            Foley's {English-Irish Dictionary}, 1855
Hend.           Dr George Henderson, Lecturer in Celtic Languages
                     and Literature in the University of Glasgow
H.S.D.          The Highland Society's {Dictionary of the Gaelic
                     Language}, 1828
Inv.Gael.Soc.Tr Transactions of the Gaelic Society of Inverness, still
                     proceeding
L.na  H.        {Lebor na h-uidre}, or the Book of the Dun Cow, an
                     Irish MS of 1100
Lh.             Lhuyd's {Archaeologia Brittanica}, 1707
Lib.Leinster    Book of Leinster, an Irish MS of 1150
M`A.            Macalpine's {Gaelic Dictionary}, 1832
M`D.            Alexander Macdonald's {Gaelick and English Vocabulary},
                     1741
M`E.            M`Eachan's {Faclair}, 1862
M`F.            M`Farlane's {Focalair} or Gaelic Vocabulary, 1815
M`L.            M`Leod and Dewar's {Dictionary of the Gaelic Language},
                     1831
Nich.           Sheriff Nicholson's Gaelic Proverbs
O'B.            O'Brien's {Irish-English Dictionary}, 1768 and 1832
O'Br.           O'Brien's {Irish-English Dictionary}, 1768 and 1832
---JTM: O'B. is the more common abbrev., I assume they are the same
O'Cl.           O'Clery's Glossary, republished in {Revue Celtique},
                     Vols. IV, V, date 1643
O'R.            O'Reilly's {Irish English Dictionary}, 1823
Rev.Celt.       {Revue Celtique}, a periodical published at Paris, now in
                     its 17th vol.
R.D.            Rob Donn, the Reay Bard; sometimes given as (Suth.)
Rob.            Rev. Chas M. Robertson, author of pamphlets on
                     certain dialects of the Scottish Highlands
S.C.R.          The {Scottish Celtic Review}, 1 vol., edited by Dr
                     Cameron, 1885
S.D.            {Sean Dana}, Ossianic Poems by the Rev Donald Smith
Sh.             Shaw's {Gaelic and English Dictionary}, 1780
St.             Dr Whitley Stokes; see "Authors quoted"
Stew.           Vocabulary at the end of Stewart's Gaelic Collection
Wh.             John Whyte, Inverness; sometimes entered as (Arg.)
Zeit.           Kuhn's {Zeitschrift f. vergl. Sprachforschung}, a German
                     periodical still proceeding

   An asterisk (*) denotes always a hypothetical word; the sign (†) denotes
   that the word is obsolete.  The numeral above the line denotes the number
   of the edition or the number of the volume.
--page 1
<a.1>, vocative particle, Ir. @Ir{a}, O.Ir. @OIr{á}, @OIr{a}; W., Corn., Br. @Br@Corn@W{a}; Lat. @Lat{o};
  Gr. @Gr{ὦ}.
<a.2>, his, her, Ir. @Ir{a}, O.Ir. @OIr{á}, @OIr{ái} (accented), W. @W{ei}, Br. @Br{e}, Celtic {esjo},
  {esjâs}; Skr. gen. {asyá}, {asyâs}.  The gen. pl. is @Ref<an.4>, their, O.Ir.
  @OIr{a n-}, Celtic {esjon} (Stokes gives {esan}=Skr. gem. gen. pl. {âsâm}).
<a.3>, who, that (rel. pron.). In G. this is merely the verbal particle
  @Ref{do.2} of past time, used also to explain the aspiration of the
  future rel. sentence.  Oblique cases are done by {an}, {am} (for {san},
  {sam}, O.Ir. @OIr{san}, @OIr{sam}), the neut. of art. used as rel. (cf. Eng.
  @Eng{that}).  The rel. locative is sometimes done by the prep. {an},
  {am}: "An coire am bi na caoraich" (1776 Collection, p112).
<a.4>, out of, ex: see @Ref<as>.
<a.5>, from, in the adverbs @Ref<a nall>, @Ref<a nìos>, @Ref<a nuas>, @Ref<a null>; Ir., O.Ir.
  @Ir@OIr{an-}, as {anuas}, etc.; Celtic {a(p)ona}, a derivative from I.E.
  @IE{apo}, whence Lat. {ab}, Gr. @Gr{ἀπό}; Ger. {von}, from, is the exact
  equivalent of the Celtic.  The @Ref<a.5> before @Ref{sìos} and @Ref{suas} is due
  to analogy with @Ref{a nìos}, @Ref{a nuas}.
<a.6>, in to, as in @Ref<a bhàn>, @Ref<a bhos>, @Ref<a nis>, @Ref<a stigh>, @Ref<a steach>, is the
  prep. @Ref<an.2>, in, into, q.v.
<a.7>, as in @Ref<a rìs>, &c., and before verbs, is the prep. @Ref<do.2>, q.v.
<a'>, the, at; see @Ref{an.1}, the, and @Ref{ag.1}, at.
<ab>, or @Ref<ab ab>, fie!  The Ir. @Ir{ab ab}, M.Ir. @MIr{abb} is an interjection of
  defiance, {obo}, of wonder; cf. Lat. {babæ}, Gr. @Gr{βαβαí}.  Hence
  doubtless M`A.'s {abab}, dirt.
<aba>, abbot, Ir. @Ir{ab}, O.Ir. @OIr{abb}, W. @W{abad}; from Lat. {abbas}, {abbatis},
  whence also Eng. @Eng{abbot}.  Hence {abaid}, abbey.  M.Ir.
  {apdaine}, abbacy, in M.G. "abbey lands", whence placenames
  Appin, older Abbathania (1310), Abthein (1220), "abbey lands".
--page 2
<abadh>, syllable, utterance; E.Ir. @EIr{apad}, proclamation: {ad-ba-},
  Celtic {ba}, speak; Lat. {fatur}, {fama}, Eng. fame.
<abaich>, ripe, Ir. @Ir{abaidh}, M.Ir. @MIr{abaid}, E.Ir. @EIr{apaig}, *{ad-bagi},
  O.Ir. @OIr{apchugud}, autumnatio; *{ad-bog-}, Celtic root {bug}, as in
  @Ref{bog}, q.v.; {ad-bach}, root of Eng. @Eng{bake}; Gr. @Gr{φώγω}.  The W.
  @W{addfed} is from a root {met}.
<abaideal>, colic (M`A.):
<abair>, say, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{epiur}, Celtic {ád-berô}; Lat. {re-fero};
  see root in @Ref{beir}.
<abaisd>, a brat, trifling, impudent person:
<abalt>, expert (M`A.); from Sc. {apert}?  See @Ref{aparr}.
<abar>, confluence; only in Pictish place names: O.Gaelic (B.of
  Deer) {abbor}; W. @W{aber}, O.W. @OW{aper}, Celtic {ad-bero-}, root {ber};
  see @Ref{beir}.  Modern Gaelic pronounces it @Ref<obair.2> (so in 17th
  cent.), which agrees with the O.W. @OW{oper}; this suggests
  {od-bero-}, "out flow", as against the "to flow" of {ad-bero-}.
  The @Ref{od} is for @Ref{ud}, allied to Eng. @Eng{out}.  Aporicum: *{ati-boro-n}
  (Holden).
<abarach>, bold; see @Ref{abair} above.
<abardair>, dictionary (Shaw); from @Ref{abair}, q.v.
<abartach>, talkative, bold; from @Ref{abair} q.v.
<àbh>, hand net; from Norse {háfr}, pock-net.  Also @Ref<tàbh>, q.v.
  Spelt less correctly @Ref<àmh> and @Ref<àbhadh>.
<abh>, bark of dog; an onomatopaetic word.
<abhainn>, river, Ir. @Ir{abhann} (gen. {abhann}, now {aibhne}), O.Ir. @OIr{abann},
  W. @W{afon}, Br. @Br{auon}, Gallo-Brit. {Abona}; Lat. {amnis} (*{ab-nis}).
  Root {abh}; Skr. {ambhas}, water; Gr. @Gr{ἀφρος} (@Gr{ὄμβρος}, imber)
  (Zim. @ExtRef{Neu.;;270}).
<àbhacas>, sport, irony; see @Ref{àbhachd}.
<àbhachd>, humour, sport, Ir. @Ir{adhbhachd}:
<abhag>, terrier, Ir. @Ir{abhach}; from @Ref{abh}, q.v.  Cf. E.Ir. @EIr{abacc},
  dwarf; W. @W{afanc}.
<abhagas>, rumour, false suspicion:
<àbhaist>, custom, Manx {oaysh}, Ir. @Ir{abhest} (O'R.), {abaise} (O'B.),
  {ad-beus}? M.Ir. @MIr{ábaisi} (pl.).  See @Ref{beus}, custom.  Ascoli
  compares the O.Ir. @OIr{-abais} of @OIr{duabais}, teter, and {suabais},
  suavis.  Meyer suggests from N. {avist}, abode : unlikely.
<abhall>, an orchard, apple-tree, M.Ir. @MIr{aball}, apple-tree.  See @Ref{ubhal}.
<abharr>, silly jest (M`A.):
<abharsair>, Satan, Ir. @Ir{aidhbherseóir}, E.Ir. @EIr{adbirseoir}; from Lat.
  @Lat{adversarius} (Eng. {adversary}).  Also @Ref<aibhistear>.
<abhcaid>, a jest; @Ref{àbhachd}.
<abhlan>, wafer, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{obla}, g. {oblann}; from Lat. {oblationem},
  an oblation.
--page 3
<abhra>, eyelid; see @Ref{fabhra}.
<abhras>, spinning, produce of distaff, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr@Ir{abhras}, O.Ir.
  @OIr{abras}, gestus, E.Ir. @EIr{abras}, handiwork, spinning, {abairsech},
  needlewoman.  Corm. (B) {abras}, who derives it from L.Lat.
  {abra}, ancilla.
<abhsadh>, the slackening of a sail, hoisting sail (N.H.); from
  Norse {hálsa}, clew up sail, from {hâls}, neck, allied to Lat.
  @Lat{collum}.  Eng. @Eng{hawser} is also hence.  Also @Ref<allsadh>.
<abhsporag>, a cow's stomach, tripe (H.S.D.), @Ref<allsporag>, cow's
  throttle (M`A.); borrowed evidently from a Scandinavian
  compound of {háls}, neck.  Cf. @Ref{abhsadh} above.
<ablach>, a mangled carcase, Ir. @Ir{ablach}, carcase: *{ád-bal-ac-}, from
  root {bal}, {bel}, die, I.E. {gel}, whence Eng. @Eng{quell}.  Irish has
---JTM: changed Eng, to Eng.
  @Ir{abailt}, death, O.Ir. @OIr{epeltu}, @OIr{atbail}, perit, from the same root
  and prefix; the first of them appears in our Gaelic dictionaries
  through Shaw.  From Gaelic comes Scotch {ablach}.
<àbran>, @Ref<abran> (M`A. and H.S.D.), an oar-patch on a boat's gunwale;
  see @Ref{aparan}.
<Abraon>, April, so Ir.; founded on Lat. {Aprilis} (Eng. @Eng{April}).
  The form is due to folk-etymology, which relates it to @Ref{braon}.
<abstol>, apostle, Ir. @Ir{absdal}, O.Ir. @OIr{apstal}, W. @W{apostol}; from Lat.
  @Lat{apostolus}, whence Eng. @Eng{apostle}.
<acaid>, a pain, stitch; *{ád-conti-}; see @Ref{urchoid}.
<acain>, sigh, complaint, E.Ir. @EIr{accáine}, W. @W{achwyn}; {ád+caoin}; see
  @Ref{caoin.3}, weep.
<acair.1>, anchor, Ir. @Ir{ancaire}, O.Ir. @OIr{ingor}; from N. {akkeri}:
  @Ref<acairsaid>, anchorage, from N. {akkarsaeti}, "anchor-seat".
  From Lat. {ancora}, whence Eng. @Eng{anchor}.
<acair.2>, acre, Ir. @Ir{acra}; from Eng. @Eng{acre}; Lat. {ager}.
<acarach>, gentle; Ir. @Ir{acarach}, obliging, convenient, which shades
  off into @Ref{acartha}, profit; W. @W{achar}, affectionate; {ád-car-}; see
  @Ref{càr}, friendly.  M`A. has @Ref<acarra>, moderate in price, indulgence,
  which belongs to @Ref<acartha>.
<acaran>, lumber.
<acartha>, profit, so Ir.; see @Ref{ocar}, interest.
<acastair>, axle-tree; borrowed word from Sc. {ax-tree} of like meaning
  - Eng. @Eng{axle}, &c.
<ach.1>, but, Ir. @Ir{achd}, O.G. (B.of Deer) {act}, O.Ir. @OIr{act}, @OIr{acht}, *{ekstos},
  possibly, from {eks}={ex}; cf. Gr. @Gr{ἐκτός}, without.  For the
  change of vowel, cf. @Ref{as}, from {eks}.  The Welsh for "but" is
  {eithr}, from {ekster}; Lat. {exter-}.
<ach.2>, interjection of objection and impatience; founded on @Ref{ach.1}
  with leaning upon @Ref{och}, q.v.
<achadh>, a field, so Ir., O.G. {achad}, O.Ir. @OIr{ached} (locative?)
  campu lus (Adamnan), *{acoto-}; Lat. {acies}, {acnua}, field.
--page 4
<achain>, prayer; dialect for @Ref{achuinge}, q.v.
<acharradh>, dwarf, sprite.
<achd.1>, statute, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{acht}; from Lat. {actum}, Eng. @Eng{act}.
<achd.2>, manner, condition, Ir. @Ir{achd}; same as @Ref{achd.1}.  There may be
  a native {aktu-} (*{ag-tu}, *{pag-tu}?) underlying some meanings
  of the word, especially in Irish.
<achdarr>, @Ref<achdartha>, methodical, expert (H.S.D.):
<achlaid>, chase, pursuit, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{acclaid}, fishing, E.Ir. @EIr{atclaid},
  fishes, hunts, pursues: {ad-claidim}; see @Ref{claoidh}.
<achlais>, arm-pit, Ir. @Ir{ascall}, M.Ir. @MIr{ochsal}, W. @W{cesail}.  The
  divergence from regular philologic equivalence here proves
  borrowing - from the Lat. {axilla}; Norse {öxl}, Ger. {achsel},
  Sc. {oxter}.
<achlan>, lamentation (M`L.); for {och-lan}? from @Ref{och}.
<achmhasan>, a rebuke, Ir. @Ir{achmhusán}, E.Ir. @EIr{athchomsán}; cf. @Ref{aithis}
  for root.
<achuinge>, supplication; also @Ref<athchuinge>, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr@Ir{athchuingid};
  {ath+cuinge}; O.Ir. @OIr{cuintgim}, peto, {con-tek-}; Eng. @Eng{thig}.  See
  @Ref{atach.1}.
<acras>, hunger, Ir. @Ir{ocrus}, E.Ir. @EIr{accorus}, {occorus}: *{ad-co-restu-},
  possibly the root {pres} of Lat. {premo}: *{careo} (@ExtRef{F.;4;422}).
<acuinn>, @Ref<acfhuinn>, apparatus, accoutrements, Ir. @Ir{acfuinn}, E.Ir.
  @EIr{accmaing}, means, apparatus: {ad-cumang}, O.Ir. @OIr{cumang},
  potentia; see further under @Ref{cumhachd}.
<ad>, hat, M.Ir. @MIr{at}, W. @W{het}; from Eng. @Eng{hat}, N. {hattr}.
<ad->, @Ref<adh->, inseparable prefix, in force and origin the same as Lat.
  @Lat{ad}.  It is to be separated, though with difficulty, from the
  {ad-} arising from @Ref{aith-} or @Ref{ath-}, q.v.
<adag.1>, shock of corn, Ir. @Ir{adag}; cf. Sc. {hat}, {hot}, {hut}, "to put up
  grain in the field, a small stack built in the field"; M.Eng.
  @MEng{hutte}, heap.
<adag.2>, a haddock; from the English @Eng{haddock}.
<adamant>, adamant, so Ir.; from the English @Eng{adamant}.
<adha>, @Ref<ae>, liver, Ir. @Ir{aeghe}, g. @Ref{ae}, O.Ir. @OIr{óa}, @OIr{ae}, W. @W{afu}, Br. @Br{avu},
  root {av}.  Cf. {adha} for @Ref{ae}, @Ref{cadha} for {cae}.
<adhan>, proverb (M`A.); rather @Ref<aghan>, root {agh}, Lat. {ajo}, {adagio},
  adage; Skr. {ah}, say.
<adhal>, flesh hook (Sh.), so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{áel}, tridens: *{pavelo-}, Lat.
  @Lat{pavire}?  But cf. Eng. @Eng{awl}, M.E. and Ag.S. {awel}, awl, flesh-hook.
<adhaltrach>, adulterous, Ir. @Ir{adhaltranach}, E.Ir. @EIr{adaltrach}; from
  Lat. {adulter}, whence Eng. @Eng{adulterous}.
<adharc>, horn, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{adarc}: {ad-arc}; root {arq}, defend, as in
  @Ref{teasairg}, q.v.; Lat. {areceo}, &c.
--page 5
<adharcan>, lapwing, "horned bird"; from @Ref{adharc}; Dial. @Ref<dhaoireagan>.
  Ir. @Ir{adaircín} (P.O'C).
<adhart.1>, pillow, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{adart}: {ad-art}; {art}, stone?  See
  @Ref{airtein}.
<adhart.2>, @Ref<aghart>, "progress" (Dict.).  This is a ghost-word, made
  from the adverbial phrase {air adhart}, which in M.Ir. is
  {araird}, forward, bring forward; in O.Ir. @OIr{arairt}, prorsum.
  Hence it is {air+àrd}, q.v.
<adhastar>, halter, Manx {eistyr}, Ir. @Ir{aghastor}, M.Ir. @MIr{adastar}; cf. W.
  {eddestl}, steed.
<adhbhal>, vast, awful, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{adbul}: *{ad-bol-}; I.E. root
  {bhel}, swell, as in Eng. @Eng{bloom}, etc.  Zimmer compares it with
  Skr. {bala}, strength.  Stokes and Osthoff give root {bel}, {bol},
  strong, big, Skr. {balam}, strength, Gr. @Gr{βέλτερος}, better, Lat.
  {de-bilis}, weak, Ch.Sl. {bolijĭ}, greater; whence @Ref<bailceach>
  (Osthoff) and @Ref<bail>, @Ref<buil>.
<adhlac>, burial, Ir. @Ir{adhlacadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{adnacul}, sepulcrum: {ad-nank-otlo}
  (*{ad-nagtlo-}, Zim.): root verb {nankô}, I bring; Lat.
  {nanciscor}; further I.E. {nenk}, {enk}, as in @Ref{thig}, q.v.
<adhna>, an advocate (Macd.): H.S.D. cfs. Heb. {adhon}, sustentator.
<ag.1>, at, with inf. only; see @Ref{aig}.
<ag.2>, @Ref<agadh.2>, refusal, doubt; E.Ir. @EIr{ac}, refusal, O.Ir. @OIr{acc}, no!
  W. @W{acom}, to deny.  It is onomatopoetic?  See @Ref{agadh}.
<agadh.1>, hesitancy in speech, Br. @Br{hak},{hakal}; cf. Skr. {ac}, speak
  indistinctly.  See @Ref{ag.2}, @Ref{agadh.2}.
<agadh.2>, see @Ref{ag.2}.

<agair>, plead, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{acre} (n.), from {ad-gar-}; root {gar}, cry;

<agallamh>, conversation, Ir. @Ir{agallamh}, O.Ir. @OIr{acaldam}, for {ad-glád-},

<àgh>, also @Ref<àdh>, happiness, luck, Manx {aigh}, Ir. @Ir{ágh}, M.Ir. @MIr{ada},

  contest; Gr. @Gr{ἀγώv}, Eng. @Eng{antagonist}.
<aghaib>, essay (M`A); see @Ref{oidheirp}.
<aghaidh>, face, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aged}, *{agitâ}; I.E. root {ag}, lead.  It
  is usually referred to the root {oq}, Lat. {oculus}, etc., but the
  phonetics are unsatisfactory.
<aghann>, pan, so Ir., O.Ir., @OIr{aigen}, Celtic {aginâ}; Skr. {aga}, water
  jar; Gr. @Gr{ἄγγος}, a vessel.
<agus>, and so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{acus}, @OIr{ocus}, B.of Deer {acus}, O.W. @OW{ac}, Br.
  {hag}; allied is @Ref{fagus}, near, O.Ir. @OIr{ocus}, W. @W{agos}, Br. @Br{hogoz}:
--page 6
  *{aggostu-}, {ad-gos-}; root {ges}, {gos}, carry; Lat. {gero}, {aggestu-s},
  mound (Zimmer).  Stokes refers it to the root {angh}, choke,
  narrow; Celtic {aggúst-}, from pre-Celtic {aghnústu-} (Lat.
  {angustus}), with accent on syllable after the root - {gn} with
  the accent on the following vowel being supposed, as in
  Teutonic, to produce {gg}.  The derivation from root {onk}, {enk},
  as in @Ref{thig}, is not tenable in view of the Welsh.
<ai>, sheep, swan (Carm.):
<aibheil>, huge (M`E.).  See @Ref{adhbhal}.
<aibheis.1>, sea, the deep; Ir. @Ir{aibheis}, sea, abyss; E.Ir. @EIr{aibéis}, sea.
  This Stokes refers to a Celtic {abensi-s}, {abhent-ti-s}; root {abh},
  as in @Ref{abhainn}.  But cf. O.Ir. @OIr{abis}, from Lat. {abyssus}: W.
  {affwys}, bottomless pit.
<aibheis.2>, boasting; @Ref<aibhsich>, exaggerate; Ir. @Ir{aibhseach}, boasting:
  from @Ref{aibheis.2}?  Another form of @Ref{aibhsich} is @Ref<aillsich>.
<aibhist>, an old ruin (Stew.):
<aibhistear>, the Devil; another form of @Ref{abharsair}, q.v.
<aibhse>, spectre, so Ir.: see @Ref{taibhse}.
<aibidil>, alphabet, Ir. @Ir{aibghitir}, O.Ir. @OIr{abbgitir}, from L.Lat.
  {abgetorium}, {abecedarium}, the {a}, {b}, {c}, {d}, ar alphabet.  A
  dialectic form, @Ref<aibirsidh>, comes from the old learning system,
  beginning "A per se", {a} by itself={a}, Eng. @Eng{apersie}.  Analogised
  to {caibideal} (Meyer).
<aice.1>, proximity, Ir. @Ir{aice}; see @Ref{taic}.
<aice.2>, a lobster's burrow, also @Ref{faiche.2}.
<àicheadh>, deny, Ir. @Ir{aithcheo}, contradicting, M.Ir. @MIr{aithceód}: *{ati-ceud-}(?),
  "go back on"; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{atchuaid}, exposui, which
  Stokes refers to the root of @Ref{chaidh}, went, q.v.
<aicheamhail>, reprisal; cf. Ir. @Ir{athghabháil}; {ath+gabhail}.
†<aicme>, race, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aicme}, W. @W{ach}, pedigree, *{akk-}, from {ak},

  property.
<aidheam>, joyous carol:

<aig>, at, Ir. @Ir{ag}, O.Ir. @OIr{oc}; for root, see @Ref{agus}.
<àigeach>, young or entire horse; also @Ref<òigeach>={òg+each}, q.v.
  M.Ir. @MIr{óc-ech}, young steed (@ExtRef{Eriu;2;11}).
<aigeann>, the deep, Ir. @Ir{àigeun}, E.Ir. @EIr{oician}, W. @W{eigion}: from Lat.
  {oceanus}, Eng. @Eng{ocean}.  There is also a by-form @Ref<aigeal>.
<aigeannach>, spirited, E.Ir. @EIr{aignech}; see @Ref{aigneadh}.  Ir. @Ir{aigeanta},
  meditative.
--page 7
<aighear>, mirth, Manx {aigher}; *{ati-gar-}; see @Ref{gàirdeachas} for root.
  Yet Ir. @Ir{aiereach}, merry, aerial, from {aier}, air, from Lat. {aer},
  makes the matter doubtful.  Ir. @Ir{aerach} (Hyde), merry, airy.
  Evidently the G. is borrowed from the Lat.
<aigilean>, ear-ring, tassel; cf. Sc. {aiglet}, tagged point, jewel in
  one's cap; {eglie}, needlework, from Fr. {aiguille}, needle; Lat.
  {acus}.
<aigne.1>, the swift, anything quick (Carm.):
<aigne.2>, @Ref<aigneadh>, mind, so Ir., O.Ir., @OIr{aicned}: {ád-gn-eto-}, root {gnā},
  know, Gr. @Gr{γιγνώσκω}, Eng. @Eng{know}.  Stokes refers it to the root
  of @Ref{aicme}, as he gives it.  Ascoli makes the root {cen}, as in
  @Ref{cineal}.  The Gaelic {g} is against any root with {c}.
<àil>, will; better @Ref<àill>, q.v.
<ail.1>, @Ref<aileadh>, @Ref<ailt>, a mark, impression, Ir. @Ir{oil}, mark (O'R), M.
  and E.Ir. @EIr{aile}, fence, boundary (Meyer).  A {t} stem: {oiledaib},
  *{al-et}.
†<ail.2>, rock, Ir. and O.Ir. @OIr{ail}, *{alek-}, allied to Ger. {fels}; see further
  under @Ref{mac-talla}.
<ailbheag>, ring; see @Ref{failbhe}.
<ailbhinn>, flint, precipice; from @Ref{ail.2}, rock.
<àile>, air, scent, E.Ir. @EIr{aél}, {ahél}; W. @W{avel}, C., Br., {awel}, wind; Gr.
  @Gr{ἀέλλα} (St. Lec.), storm; *{avel-}, root {ave}, {ve}, wind; Lat.

  borrowed from Lat. {ulmus}, Norse {álmr}, Eng. @Eng{elm}.

<ailt>, stately, high; Ir. @Ir{ailt}, Lat. {altus}, {àilt} (H.S.D.).
<aim->, @Ref<aimh->, privative prefix; see @Ref{am-}, @Ref{amh-}.  See its use in
  @Ref<aimhleas> (={am-leas}), hurt, @Ref<aimhrea>, @Ref<aimhreidh>, confusion
  (={am-réidh}), @Ref<aimbeart>, distress, etc. (={am-bert}).  The
  vowel in the root is "small", and hence affects the {a} of @Ref{am}.
<aimheal>, grief, Ir. @Ir{aithmhéal}, repentance; {aith+méala}, grief,
  E.Ir. @EIr{méla}, sorrow, reproach; *{meblo-}, a shorter form of O.Ir.
  {mebul}, dedecus; Gr. @Gr{μέμφομαι}

<aimhfheoil>, @Ref<ainfheoil>, proud flesh; from @Ref{aimh-} and @Ref{feòil}, q.v.

<aimsir>, time, so Ir.; O.Ir. @OIr{amser}, W. @W{amser}, Br. @Br{amzer}, possibly a
  Celtic {ammesserâ}; either a compound of @Ref{am}, time ({ammensîrâ},

<àin>, heat (Dict.), light (H.M`Lean), O.Ir. @OIr{áne}, fulgor, from {án},

  {ignis}, Skr. {agní}, fire.

<ainmhide>, a rash fool; see @Ref{òinid}.

  *{anem-}, life, soul; Lat. {animal}, etc.  Ir. is also {ainmhinte},
  "animans".
<ainmig>, rare; {an-minig}, q.v.
<ainneamh>, rare; see @Ref{annamh}.
<ainneart>, force; @Ref{ain-}, excess (see @Ref{an-}), and @Ref{neart}.
<ainnighte>, tame, from {ainneadh}, patience (Sh.); possibly from
  {an-dam}, root {dam}, tame.
<ainnir>, virgin, E.Ir. @EIr{ander}, W. @W{anner}, heifer, M.Br. @MBr{annoer} (do.),
  *{anderâ}; cf. Gr. @Gr{ανθηρός}, blooming, @Gr{ἀθάριοι}, virgins (Hes.),
  *@Gr{νθαρ-}.
<ainnis>, @Ref<ainniseach>, needy: {an+dìth}, want?
<ainstil>, fury, over-fizzing: {an+steall}.
<air>, on, upon.  This prep. represents three Irish ones:
  (a) <air>=O.Ir. @OIr{ar}, @OIr{air}, ante, propter, W. @W{ar}, @W{er}, Br. @Br{er}, Gaul. {are-},
      Celtic {ari}, {arei}, Gr. @Gr{παρά}, @Gr{παραí}, by, before; Lat. {prae}; Eng.
      {fore}, {for}.  This prep. aspirates in Irish, and in Gaelic idioms
      it still does so, e.g. {air chionn}.
  (b) <air>=O.Ir. @OIr{for}, "super", O.W. and O.Br. @OBr@OW{guor}, Br. @Br{voar}, @Br{oar},
      Gaul. {ver-}; Gr. @Gr{ὑπέρ}; Lat. {s-uper}; Eng. @Eng{over}.  This prep.
      did not aspirate;  it ended originally in {r} in Gaelic; as an
      inseperable prefix ({vero-}, {viro-} in Gaul.) it aspirated, as in the
      modern form of old names like {Fergus}, now {Fearghuis} or
      {Fear'uis} (gen. case).
  (c) <air>=O.Ir. @OIr{iar n-}, after, pre-Celtic {epron}; Skr. {aparám},
      afterwards, {aparena}, after; Got. {afar}, after, Eng. @Eng{af-ter}.
      Further come Gr. @Gr{ὀπι-}, behind, {e@'pí-}, to, Lat. {ob-}, {op-}.  See @Ref{iar.1}.
--page 10
      This is the prep. that is used with the inf. to represent a
      perfect or past participle in Gaelic - {Tha mi air bualadh}; "I
      have struck".
<airbhinneach>, honourable; {air+beann}?
<airc>, distress, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aircur}, pressure; cf. Lat. {parcus},
  sparing.
<àirc>, the Ark, Ir. @Ir{airc}; from Lat. {arca}.
<airchios>, pity, clemency (Hend.): see @Ref{oircheas}.
<aircill>, to watch, listen, Ir. @Ir{aircill}; see @Ref{faircill}.
<aircleach>, a cripple; *{airc-lach}, from @Ref{airc}, q.v.
<àird.1>, point (of the compass), Ir. @Ir{áird}, E.Ir. @EIr{aird}, Gr. @Gr{ἄρδις}, a
  point.  Hence Sc. {airt}.
<àird.2>, preparation, activity.
<àirde>, height, Ir. @Ir{áirde}, E.Ir. @EIr{arde}; see @Ref{àrd}.
<àirdeil>, ingenious:
<aire>, heed, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aire}, Old.Brit. {Areanos}, native watchers who
  gave intimation to the Romans (Ammianus), pre-Celtic {parjâ},
  {par}, seek; Gr. @Gr{πεîρα}, trial; Lat. {ex-perior}, Eng. @Eng{experiment}.
<àireach>, keeper of cattle.  There is confusion in Gaelc between
  {àireach} and O.Ir. @OIr{aire(ch)}, lord; the {bó-aire}, cow-lord, was
  the free tenant of ancient Ireland.  For O.Ir. @OIr{aire}, see
  @Ref{airidh}.  G. {àireach} owes its long vowel to a confusion with
  {àraich}, rear.  See @Ref{àiridh} for root.
<àireamh>, number, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{áram}, W. @W{eirif}, *{ad-rîm-}, Celtic
  {rîmâ}, number; Ag.S. {rîm}, number, Eng. @Eng{rhyme}; Gr.
  @Gr{ἀριθμός}, number.
<airean>, ploughman, herdsman; Ir. @Ir{oireamh}, g. {oiramhan}, ploughman,
  the mythic {Eremon}, {Airem(on)}, *{arjamon-}, Skr.
  {Arjaman}, further {Aryan}(?); root {ar}, plough; see @Ref{àr.1}.
†<airfid>, music, harmony; {oirfid}.
<airgiod>, silver, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{arget}, W. @W{ariant}, Br. @Br{arc'hant}, Gail.
  {Argento-}, {Argento-coxus} (a Caledonian prince): Lat. {argentum};
  Gr. @Gr{ἄργυρος}.  Eng. @Eng{argent} is from the Lat.
<àiridh>, better @Ref<àirigh>, hill pasture, sheiling (@Ref<airghe>, in Lh. for
  Gaelic); cf. E.Ir. @EIr{airge}, {áirge}, place where cows are, dairy,
  herd of cattle; E.Ir. @EIr{airgech}, herdswoman {of Brigit}; Ir.
  @Ir{airghe}, pl. @Ir{áiríghe} (O'B.), a herd of cattle; @Ir{airgheach}, one
  who has many herds; *{ar-egia}; Lat. {armentum}?  But see
  {àraich}, rear.  Norse or Danish {erg} from Gaelic equals Norse
  {setr} (Ork. Sag.).  This Norse form proves the identity of
  Gaelic with E.Ir. @EIr{airge}; {airge}={ar-agio}, *{agio}, herd.
<airidh>, worthy, Ir. @Ir{airigh} (Ulster), {airigh}, nobleman (O'B.), O.Ir.
  {aire(ch)}, primas, lard; Skr. {árya}, good, a lord; {ârya}, Aryan,
  {âryaka}, honourable man.  *{parei}?
--page 11
<airilleach>, a sleepy person; from †{aireal}, bed, M.Ir. @MIr{aired} (O'C.):
<airleag>, leng, Ir. @Ir{airligim}, O.Ir. @OIr{airliciud}, lending; from @Ref{leig}, let,
  which is allied to Eng. @Eng{loan}, Got. {leihvan}, Ger. {leihen}.  See
  @Ref{leig}.
<airleas>, pledge, earnest, arles; from Sc. {arles}, older {erles}, which,
  through Old French, comes from Lat. *{arrhula}, dim. of {arrha},
  pledge.  Eng. @Eng{earnest}, whence W. @W{ernes}, is probably from the
  same origin.  See @Ref{eàrlas}.
<airleig>, a strait:
<airmis>, hit; see @Ref{eirmis}.
<àirne>, a sloe, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{arni}, sloes, W. @W{eirin}, plums, Br. @Br{irinenn},
  sloe, Celtic {arjanio-} (Stokes); Skr. {araṇi}, tinder-stick
  "premna spinosa", {araṇka}, forest.
<àirneach>, murrain in cattle:
<airneis>, @Ref<àirneis> (M`L. & D.), furniture; Ir. @Ir{áirneis}, cattle, goods,
  etc., M.Ir. @MIr{airnis}, tools, furniture.  The word can hardly
  be separated from the Romance {arnese}, accotrements,
  armour, whence Eng. @Eng{harness}, armour for man or horse.  The
  word is originally of Brittonic origin (Br. {harnez}, armour),
  from *{eisarno-}, iron; see @Ref{iarunn}.
<airtein>, a pebble, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{arteini} (pl.), O.Ir. @OIr{art}; possibly
  Gaul. {arto-} ({Arto-briga}), {Artemia}, name of a rock.
<airtneal>, @Ref<airsneal>, weariness:
<àis.1>, milk (Carm.), M.Ir. @MIr{as} (O'Dav.).
<àis.2>, wisdom (Carm.), @Ref{ais} (O'Cl.)  See @Ref{cnoc} (Carm.).
<ais>, back, backwards; so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{aiss}, {daraaiss}, backwards; Gaelic
  @Ref<air ais>.  The forms {ais}, @Ref{rithisd} ({rìs}), @Ref{thairis}, seem compounds
  from the root {sta}, {sto}, stand; cf. @Ref{fois}, @Ref{bhos}, @Ref{ros.2}; <ais> may be
  for {ati-sta-}, or {ati-sti-}.  Ascoli refers {ais} to an unaccented
  form of @Ref{éis}, track, which is used after {tar} and {di} ({di a éis}, post
  eum; see @Ref{déis}) for "after, @Ref{post}", but not for "back", as is
  {air ais}, with verbs of rest or motion.
<aisead>, delivery (obstetrical), E.Ir. @EIr{asait}, vb. {ad-saiter}, is delivered;
  *{ad-sizd-}; Lat. {sīdo}, {assīdere}, a reduplication of the root
  {sed}, of @Ref{suidhe}, q.v.  From {ad-sem-t}, root {sem} as in @Ref{taom.1}
  (Stokes).
<aiseag>, a ferry, Ir. @Ir{aiseog} (Fol.):
<aiseal.1>, axle; it seems borrowed from Eng. @Eng{axle}, Norse {öxull}, but
  the W. @W{echel}, Br. @Br{ahel}, *{aksila}, makes its native origin
  possible, despite the absence of the word in Irish.
<aiseal.2>, jollity (Sh., Arms.); see @Ref{aisteach}.
<aisean>, rib, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr@Ir{asna}, W. @W{eisen}, {asen}, Corn. @Corn{asen}; cf. Lat.
  {assula}, splinter, {asser}, beam (Stokes).  Formerly it was
  referred to the same origin as Lat. {os}, {ossis}, bone, Gr. @Gr{ὀστέον},
--page 12
  but the root vowel and meaning are both unfavourable to
  this etymology.
<aisearan>, weanling (Argyle); from @Ref{ais}?
<aisg>, a request (Sh.), E.Ir. @EIr{ascid}; *{ad-skv-}, root {seq}., as in @Ref{sgeul},
  q.v.
<aisgeir>, a ridge of high mountains, Ir. @Ir{eiscir}, {aisgeir} (Lh. for
  latter); *{ad-sker-}(?), as in Eng. @Eng{skerry}, G. {sgeir}, q.v.  Cf. W.
  {esgair} (Meyer).
<aisig>, restore, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{assec}; possibly=*{as-ic}, "out-bring",
  @Ref{ic}={enl}; see @Ref{thig}, come.
<aisir>, @Ref<aisridh>, path; see @Ref{astar}.
<aisith>, strife; {as-sìth}, @Ref{as-}, privative, and @Ref{sìth.1}, q.v.
<aisling>, a vision, dream, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aislinge}; possibly *{ex-líng-ia},
  "a jump out of one-self, ec-stasy", the root being {leng} of
  @Ref{leum}, q.v.  Nigra suggested the root {sil}, or {sell} of @Ref{seall}, see,
  q.v.;  he divided the word as {as-sil-inge}, Stokes as {ad-sell-angia}
  (Beiträge, Vol. VIII)
<aisneis>, rehearsing, tattle, E.Ir. @EIr{aisneis}, O.Ir. @OIr{áisndís}; @OIr{aisnédim}, I
  relate; ({as-ind-fiad-im}, O.Ir. @OIr{in-fiadim}, I relate); {fiad}={veid},
  know; see @Ref{innis.2}; root {vet}, Lat. {veto} (Stokes), but this does
  not account for {í} of O.Ir. @OIr{aisndís}.
<aisteach>, a diverting fellow, Ir. @Ir{aisdeach}, witty:
<ait>, glad, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ait}, O.Ir. @OIr{ait}, euge! adverbium optantis:
<àite>, a place, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{áit}.  Possibly Celtic {pōd-ti}, *{panti}? root
  {pōd}, {ped}, Lat. {oppidum}, Gr. @Gr{πέδον}, ground, Skr. {padám}, place;
  as in @Ref{eadh.2}, q.v.  Stokes has referred {áit} to the root that
  appears in Ger. {ort}, place, Norse {oddr}, O.Eng. {ord}, point,
  Teutonic {uzd-}, I.E. {uzdh-}; but this in Gaelic would give @Ref{ud}
  or @Ref{od}.
<àiteag>, a shy girl, see @Ref{faiteach}.
<aiteal>, breeze, ray, small portion.  In the sense of "ray", cf. Gr.
  @Gr{ἀκτíς}, ray; in the sense of "quantulum", it may be divided
  as {ad-tel}, O.Br. @OBr{attal}, an equivalent, root {tel}, weight, money;
  see @Ref{tuarasdal}.  {actualis}?
<aiteam>, a people, a tribe (Arms.):
<aiteamh>, a thaw; *{aith-tā-m}, W. @W{toddi}, melt; Lat. {tabes}; Gr.
  @Gr{τήκω}, melt; Eng. @Eng{thaw}.  The Ir. word is {tionadh} (O.Ir.
  {tinaid}, evanescit), Manx {tennue}, the root of which is {ten}, Lat.
  {tener}, Eng. @Eng{thin}.
<aith->, "re-"; see @Ref{ath-}.
<aitheamh>, fathom, O.W. @OW{atem}, filum; *{(p)etemâ}; Eng. @Eng{fathom};
  I.E. {pet}, extend, Lat. {pateo}, etc.
<aithinne>, fire-brand, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aithinne}: *{aith-tén-io-}?  Root of
  @Ref{teine}?  The root {and}, kindle, as in O.Ir. @OIr{andud}, accendere,
--page 13
  {adandad}, lighting up, is also possible, *{aith-and-io-} being the
  form in that case.  @Ref{amhailte} (Glen-moriston).
<aithis>, a reproach, affront, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{athiss}; *{ati-vid-tu-}; Got.
  {idveit}, Eng. @Eng{twit}; root {vid}, wit, know.
<aithlis>, a disgrace; cf. @Ref{leas} in {leas-mhac}.
<aithne>, knowledge, so Ir., O.Ir., @OIr{aithgne}, W. @W{adwaen}: {ati-gn-io-} for
  Ir.; I.E. {gen}, {gnā}, {gnō}, to know; Lat. {cognosco}; Gr. @Gr{γιγνώσκω};
  Eng. @Eng{know}.
<àithne>, command, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aithne}, depositum, command; {immánim},
  delego, assign; W. @W{adne}, custody; the root seems to be {ān}
  or {an}, judging from verbal forms, though these scarcely
  agree with the noun forms.  See @Ref{tiomnadh} further.
<aithreach>, repentant, so Ir., O.Ir. @Ir@OIr{aithrech}, Corn. @Corn{edreck}, repentance,
  Br. @Br{azrec} (do.), *{ati-(p)reko-}, *{ati-(p)rekiâ}; root, {prek},
  Lat. {precor}, Ger. {fragen}, ask, etc.  Ascoli makes the root {reg},
  come (see @Ref{rach}).
<aithris>, tell so Ir. *{ati-ris}, E.Ir. @EIr{ris}, a story, *{rt-ti}, {rat}, {rēt},
  Ger. {rede}, speech, Got. {rathjo}, speak, Lat. {ratio}.  Cf. O.Ir.
  {airissim}, from {iss}.
<àitidh>, damp:
<aitionn>, juniper, Ir. @Ir{aiteann}, O.Ir. @OIr{aitenn}, W. @W{aith}, @W{eithin}, Corn.
  @Corn{eythinen}, O.Br. @OBr{ethin} (gl. rusco), *{akto-}, I.E. root {ak}, sharp,
  Lat. {acidus}, Eng. @Eng{acid}, {edge}, Gr. @Gr{ἄκρος}, extreme, etc.  The
  nearest words are Lit. {ákstinas}, sting, Ch.Sl. {ostinu}.  Also
  @Ref<aiteal>.  *{at-tenn-}, "sharp bush or tree"; from root {at}, sharp,
  E.Ir. @EIr{aith}, sharp, *{atti-}, {atto-}.  For {-tenn}, see @Ref{caorrunn}.  Cf.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {caorunn}
  Ir. @Ir{teine}, furze.
<aitreabh>, a building, Ir. @Ref<aitreibh>, E.Ir. @EIr{aittreb}, W. @W{adref}, homewards,
  Gaul. {Atrebates}; *{ad-treb-}, the Celtic root {treb} corresponding
  to Lat. {tribus}, Eng. @Eng{thorpe}.
<àl>, brood, Ir. @Ir{ál}, W. @W{ael}, @W{al}: *{(p)aglo-}; cf. Lat. {propâgo}, Eng.
  {propogate}.  Hence @Ref<àlaire>, brood mare.  Ger. {adel}, nobility.
<àlach.1>, a brood, set, bank of oars (M`E.):
<àlach.2>, nails: *{āl-lach}, {āl-}, from {(p)agl-}, Lat. {pālus}, stake; root
  {pag}, {pāg}, fasten, whence Gr. @Gr{πήγνυμι}, Lat. {pango}, fix, Eng.
  {page}.
<alachag>, @Ref<alachuin>, see @Ref{ealachainn}.
<àlainn>, beautiful, Ir. @Ir{áluin}, O.Ir. @OIr{álaind}; *{ad-lainn}; see @Ref{loinn.1}.
  Stokes prefers referring it to {áil}, pleasant, *{pagli-}, Eng. @Eng{fair},
  root {pag}.  But {ra-laind}, pleasant, *{ad-pland} (Holden).
<all->, over; see @Ref{thall}.
<allaban>, wandering:
<alladh>, fame (either good or bad), Ir. @Ir{alladh}, excellency, fame,
  E.Ir. @EIr{allud}; see @Ref{allail}.
--page 14
<allaidh>, fierce, wild, Ir. @Ir{allta}, O.Ir. @OIr{allaid}; possibly from @Ref{all-},
  over, the idea being "foreign, barbarous, fierce";, cf. W.
  {allaidd} of like meanings, from W. @W{all}, other.  See @Ref{allmharach}.
<allail>, noble, M.Ir. @MIr{all}, {aill}, *{al-no-s}, root {al}, as in Lat. {altus}.
---gjk (1.14) moved entry. originally located between <allaban> and <alladh>.
<allmharach>, a foreigner, foreign, fierce; Ir. @Ir{allmharach}, foreigner,
  transmarine; E.Ir. @EIr{allmarach}.  From @Ref{all-}, beyond, and
  @Ref{muir}, sea, "transmarine" (K.Meyer).
<allsadh>, a jerk, suspending, leaning to one side; see @Ref{abhsadh}.
<allsmuain>, a float, great buoy:
<allsporag>, cow's throttle (M`A.); see @Ref{abhsporag}.
<allt>, a stream, Ir. @Ir{alt}, height , (topographically) glen-side or cliff,
  O.Ir. @OIr{alt}, shore, cliff, O.W. @OW{allt}, cliff, Corn. @Corn{als}, Br. @Br{aot}, shore;
  all allied to Lat. {altus}.  The Gaelic form and meaning are
  are plssibly of Pictish origin.
<all-tapadh>, mishap, ill-luck (Wh.); mischance: from @Ref{all-} and
  {tapadh}.
<alm>, alum; from the English.
<almsadh>, charity (Hend.), M.Ir. @MIr{almsain}.
<alp>, also @Ref<ealp> (Wh.), ingraft, join closely together: {alp} in tinkers'
  Ir., a job of work, hill; @Ref{ealp}=Sc. {imper}, graft.
<alt>, joint, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{alt}, *{(p)alto-s}; root {pel}, whence Eng. @Eng{fold},
  Norse {faldr}, Ger. {falz}, groove; Gr. @Gr{-πλάσιος}, doubled, for
  {plátios}.  "air alt"= in order that (Wh.).
<altach>, a grace (at food), Ir. @Ir{altughadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{attlugud}, rendering
  thanks, {atluchur bude}, I give thanks: *{ad-tlukôr}, root, tluq;
  Lit. {tulkas}, interpreter; Lat. {loquor} for {tloquor}.
<altair>, altar, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{altóir}, W. @W{allor}, Corn. @Corn{altor}, Br.  {auter}; from
  Lat. {altare}, altar, "high place".
<altrum>, fostering, Ir. @Ir{altrom}, O.Ir. @OIr{altram}, W. @W{alltraw}, sponsor;
  root {al}, nourish, whence Lat. {alo}, Got. {alan}, grow, Eng. @Eng{old}.
<àm>, time Ir. @Ir{am}, pl. {amanna}, E.Ir. @EIr{am}, *{ammen-}, from *{at-s-men-},
  root {at}, Got. {aþn}, year; possibly Lat. {annus} ({at-s-no}).
<am->, privative prefix; this is the labialised form of @Ref{an-}, q.v.; and
  being labialised, it is also aspirated into @Ref<amh->.  The forms
  before "small" vowels in the subsequent syllable are @Ref<aim->,
  @Ref<aimh->.
<amach>, vulture, so Ir.:
<amadan>, fool, Ir. @Ir{amadán}: {am+ment-}, "non-minded", Celtic root
  {ment} (@Ref{dearmad}, @Ref{farmad}, etc.), mind; Lat. {mens}, {menti-s}, Eng.
  {mind}, etc.  The shorter root {men} is found in @Ref{meanmna}.
<amail.1>, mischief; E.Ir. @EIr{admillim}, I destroy: {ad+mill}, q.v.
<amail.2>, hindrance: {ad+mall}; q.v.  But Norse {hamla}, hinder.
<amal>, swingle-tree; *{ad-mol}; {mol}, a beam, especially "a mill
  shaft", E.Ir. @EIr{mol}.  Cf. Norse {hamla}, oar-loop.
<amar>, channel, mill lead; E.Ir. @EIr{ammor}, {ammbur}, a trough,
  *{amb-or-}; Gaul. {ambes}, rivos, rivers, {Ambris}, river name;
--page 15
  Lat. {imber}; Gr. @Gr{ὄμβος}, rain; Skr. {ambu}, water.  Zimmer
  considers the Ir. borrowed from Ag.S. {ámber}, amphora, Ger.
  {eimer}; but the Gaelic meaning is distinctly against his
  theory.  A borrowing from Lat. {amphora} is liable to the same
  objection.
<amarlaich>, blustering (M`A.):
<amarlaid>, blustering female; not @Ref{amarlaich}.
<amart>, need (Hend.).  Hend. now questions it, {aimbeairt}.
<amhailte>, large ember of wood (Glen-moriston).
<amas>, hitting, O.Ir. @OIr{ammus}, an aim: *{ad-mes-}; see @Ref{eirmis}.
<amasguidh>, @Ref<aimsgith>, profane, impure: *{ad-mesc-id-}, "mixed";
  see @Ref{measg.2}.
<amh>, raw, Ir. @Ir{amh}, E.Ir. @EIr{om}, W. @W{of}; root {om}, {ōm}, whence Gr.
  @Gr{ὠμός}; Got. {amsa}; Skr. {amsas}.
<amhach>, neck: *{om-âk-â}; Lat. {humerus}, shoulder (*om-es-os);
  Gr. @Gr{ὦμός}; Got. {amsa}; Skr. {amsas}.
<amhain>, entanglement by the neck (M`A.); from @Ref{amhach}.
<a mhàin>, only, Ir. @Ir{amháin}, E.Ir. @EIr{amáin}; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{nammá} (W.
  {namyn}, but?) = {nan-n-má} "ut non sit major" (?).  The main
  root is {má} or {mó}, more, with the negative, but the exact
  explanation is not easy; "no more than"(?).  {amháin} ={a-(a[p]o)+màin},
  *{mani}; Gr. @Gr{μάνος}, spärlich, @Gr{μονος} (St.Z.).
<amhainn>, river; better @Ref{abhainn}, q.v.
<amhaltach>, vexing; see @Ref{aimheil}.
<amhan>, a marsh, or @Ref{lòn.2} (Glen-moriston).
<amharc>, looking, seeing; so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{amarc}, {amharc} ={a-(apo)+marc},
  Ger. {merken}, perhaps Lit. {mérkti}, wink, blink (St.).
  Roots @Ref{marc}, @Ref{marg}.
<amhartan>, luck, Ir. @Ir{amhantur}, {abhantur}, from Fr. {aventure}, Eng.
  {adventure}.
<amharus>, suspicion, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{amairess}, infidelitas, {am+iress},
  the latter meaning "faith"; O.Ir. @OIr{iress}={air-ess}, and *{ess} is
  from *{sistâ}, standing, root {stâ}, stand, reduplicated; cf. Lat.
  {sisto}, etc.  The whole word, were it formed at once, would
  look like *{am-(p)are-sistâ}, or *{am-are-sistâ}.
<amhas>, @Ref<amhusg>, wild man, beast man; Ir. @Ir{amhas}, a wild man,
  madman; E.Ir. @EIr{amos}, {amsach}, a mercenary soldier, servant.
  Conchobar's {amsaig}, or mercenaries, in the E.Ir. saga of
  Deirdre, appear misunderstood as our {amhusgan}, monsters;
  there is probably a reminiscence of the Norse "bear-sarks".
  Borrowed from Gaul. Lat. {ambactus} (={servus}, Festus), through
  *{ambaxus}; Cæsar says of the Gaulish princes: "Circum se
  {ambactos} clientesque habent".  The roots are {ambi-} (see @Ref{mu})
  and {ag}, go lead (see @Ref{aghaidh}).  Hence many words, as Eng.
--page 16
  {ambassador}, Ger. {amt}, official position, etc. Ir.J., 154, 156,
  has {amhas}, in G. force.
<àmhghar>, affliction, Ir. @Ir{amhgar}; @Ref{am-}(not) {+gar}; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{ingir},
  tristia, from {gáire}, risus.  See @Ref{gàir.2}, laughter, for root.
  E.Ir. @EIr{so-gar}, {do-gar}, *@Gr{χαρα} (St.).
<amhladh>, distress, dismay (Hend.).  See @Ref{amhluadh}.
<amhlair>, fool, boor, silly talker or behaver (Arg.); Ir. @Ir{amhlóir},
  O.Ir. @OIr{amlabar}, mute; from @Ref{am-} (not) and {labair}, speak,
  q.v.  Cf. @Ref{suilbhir}.
<amhlaisg>, bad beer, taplash:
<amhluadh>, confusion, distress:
<amhra>, wonderful; *{am-porios} (St.), @Gr{ἄπειρος}.
<amhran>, song, Ir. @Ir{amhrán}, {abhrán}, M.Ir. @MIr{ambrán}, Manx {arrane};
  see @Ref{òran}.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{amhra}, eulogy, especially in verse; @Ref{amhra},
  famous (Lec. 69).
<amhsan> (@Ref<ansan>), Dial @Ref<osan>, solan goose; from Lat. {anser}?
<amhuil>, like, as, Ir. @Ir{amhluidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{amail}, @OIr{amal}, O.W. @OW{amal},
  W. @W{mal}, Br. @Br{evel}; from a Celtic {samali-}, which appears in
  @Ref{samhail}, q.v.
<amhuilt>, a trick, deceit (H.S.D., M`E. @Ref<àmhuilt>):  Cf. {aith-méla}.
<àmhuinn>, oven, Ir. @Ir{òigheann}; borrowed from Eng. @Eng{oven}.
<amlach>, curled, @Ref<amlag>, a curl, M.Ir. @MIr{amlach}, from the prep.
  {ambi-}, as in @Ref{mu}, q.v.
<amraidh>, @Ref<àmraidh> (M`E.), cupboard, Ir. @Ir{amri} (O'B.), W. @W{almari};
  all borrowed from Eng. (Gaelic from Sc. {aumrie}?) {ambry} and
  M.E. {almarie}, from O.Fr. {almarie}, from Lat. {armarium},
  place of tools or arms, from {arma}.
<an.1>, @Ref<a'>, the, Ir. @Ir{an}, O.Ir. @OIr{in} (mas. and fem.), {a n-} (neut.); a {t-}
  appears before vowels in the nom. masc. ({an t-athair}), and it
  is part of the article stem; a Celtic {sendo-s} (m.), {sendâ} (f.),
  {san} (n.).  {Sendo-s} is composed of two pronominal roots,
  dividing into {sen-do-}; {sen}, judging by the neuter {san}, is a
  fixed neuter nom. or acc. from the Celtic root {se} (I.E. {sjo},
  beside @Ref{so-}, allied to Ag.S. {se}, the, {seó}, now {she}.  The {-do-} of
  {sendo-s} has been referred by Thurneysen and Brugmann to
  the pron. root {to-} (Eng. {tha-t}, Gr. @Gr{τό}); it is suggested that {to-}
  may have degenerated into {do-} before it was stuck to the
  fixed form {sen}.  {Sen-to-} could not, on any principle otherwise,
  whether of accentuation or what not, produce the historical
  forms.  It is best to revert to the older etymology, and
  refer {do-} to the pronominal root appearing in the Latin fixed
  cases (enclitic) {-dam}, {-dem}, (qui{-dam}, {i-dem}, etc.), the Gr. @Gr{δέ},
  @Gr{-δε} (as in @Gr{ὅ-δε}, this), Ch.Sl. {da}, he.  The difference, then,
  between Gr. @Gr{ὅ-δε} and Gaelic {sen-do-s} is this: the Gr. inflects
--page 17
  the first element (@Gr{ὁ}=@Ref{so}) and keeps the @Gr{δε} fixed, whereas
  Gaelic reverses the matter by fixing the {sen} and inflecting the
  {do-}; otherwise the roots are the same ultimately, and used
  for almost similar purposes.
<an.2>, in, Ir. @Ir{a n-} (eclipsing), O.Ir. @OIr{i}, @OIr{i n-}, W. @W{yn}, Br. @Br{en}; Lat. {in};
  Gr. @Gr{ἐν}; Eng. @Eng{in}, etc.  Generally it appears in the longer form
  @Ref{ann.2}, or even as {ann an}; see @Ref{ann.2}.
<an.3>, interrogative particle, Ir. @Ir{an}, O.Ir. @OIr{in}; Lat. {an}; Got. {an}.
<an.4>, their, gen. pl. of @Ref<a.2>.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<an.5>, breath, see @Ref<àinich>, @Ref<anail>.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<an->, negative prefix, Ir. @Ir{an-}, O.Ir., @OIr{an-}, {in-}; W., Corn., Br. @Br@Corn@W{an-};
  Celtic {an}, I.E. {ṇ-}, Lat. {in-}, Gr. @Gr{ἀ-}, @Gr{ἀν-}, Eng. @Eng{un-}, Skr. {a-}, {an-},
  etc.  It appears before labials and liquids (save {n}) as @Ref<am->,
  aspirated to @Ref<amh->; with consequent "small" vowels, it
  becomes @Ref<ain->, @Ref<aim->, @Ref<aimh->.  Before {g}, it becomes @Ref{ion-}, as in
  {iongantas}.  Before {c}, {t}, {s}, the {an-} becomes @Ref{eu-} and the {t} and {c}
  become medials (as in @Ref{beud}, @Ref{breug}, @Ref{feusag}).  See also @Ref{ana-.1}.
<ana-.1>, negative prefix, O.Ir. @OIr{an-}, sometimes aspirating; G.
  @Ref<ana-creidimh>, disbelief, O.Ir. @OIr{ancretem}, but {ainfhior}, untrue;
  M.Ir. @MIr{ainfhír}.  This suggests a Celtic {anas-} for the first, and
  {ana-} for the second, extensions of the previous @Ref{an-}; cognate
  are Gr. @Gr{ἂνις}, @Gr{ἂνευ}, without; Ger. {ohne}, Got. {inu}, without.
<ana-.2>, @Ref<an->, @Ref<ain->, prefix of excess; Ir. @Ir{an-}, @Ref{ain-}, M.Ir. @MIr{an-}; Ir.
  aspirates where possible (not {t}, {d}, {g}), Gaelic does so rarely.
  Allied are Gr. @Gr{ἀνα}, up, Got. {ana}, Eng. @Eng{on}.  Hence @Ref<ana-barr>,
  excess; @Ref<ain-neart>, violence; @Ref<ain-teas>, excessive heat, etc.
<anabas>, dregs, refuse, also green, unripe stuff cut; from {an-abaich}.
<anabhiorach>, centipede, whitlow:
<anacail>, defend, save; Ir. @Ir{anacail}, protection, E.Ir. @EIr{anacul} (do.).
  This Ascoli refers to the same origin as {adnacul}; see @Ref{adhlac}.
<anacair>, sickness, affliction, so Ir., {an-shocair}. Ir. Jl. 156.  See
  @Ref{acarach}.
<anadas>, regret (M`D):
<anagna>, irregularity, unusualness (Hend.), {ana-gnáth}.
<anail>, breath, Ir. and O.Ir. @OIr{anál}, W. @W{anadl}, {anal}, Corn. @Corn{anal}, Br.
  {alan}, Celtic {anatlâ}; @Ref{an.5}, breathe, Got. {anan}, to breathe,
  Skr. {anila}, wind.  See @Ref{anam} also.
<anainn>, eaves, top of house wall:
<anam>, soul, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{anim} (d. anmin), Corn. @Corn{enef}, M.Br. @MBr{eneff},
  Br. @Br{ene}, Celtic {animon-} (Stokes); Lat. {animus}, {anima}; Gr.
  @Gr{ἄνεμος}, wind.
<anamaint>, lust, perversity (Hend.), {ana+mèin}.
<anart>, linen, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{anairt}, O.Ir. @OIr{annart}, *{an-arto-}; root {pan},
  {pān}; Lat. {pannus}, cloth; Gr. @Gr{πενός}, thread on the bobbin;
  Got. {fana}, cloth, Ag.S. {fana}, small flag, Eng. @Eng{vane}, {fane}.
--page 18
<ànart>, pride:
<anasta>, stormy; *{an-fadh_asta}; see @Ref{anfadh}, storm.
<ancachd>, adversity (Hend.):
<an dràsta>, now; for {an-trâth-sa}, "the time here", q.v.
†<anfadh>, storm; proper G. is @Ref{onfhadh}, q.v.
<anfhann>, weak, Ir. @Ir{anbhfann}, M.Ir. @MIr{anbfann}, {anband}; {an+fann},
  "excessive faint".  See @Ref{fann}.
<anlamh>, @Ref<annlamh>, misfortune; @Ref{an-}(not)+@Ref{lamh}; see @Ref{ullamh} for
  @Ref{lamh}.
<ann.1>, there, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{and}, *{anda} (Stokes); Cyprian Gr. @Gr{ἄνδα}
  (=@Gr{ἄυτη}, this, she); Lit. {àndai}, newly, {àns}, {anà}, ille, illa;
  Ch.Sl. {onŭ}, that; Skr. {ana}, this (he).
<ann.2>, @Ref<ann an>, in, Ir. @Ir{ann}, E.Ir. @EIr{ind}, O.Ir. @OIr{ind-ium} (in me), Celtic
  {endo} (Stokes); Lat. {endo}, {indu}, into, in; Gr. @Gr{ἒνδον}, within,
  @Gr{ἒνδοθεν}; Eng. @Eng{indo}.  The roots are {en} (see @Ref{an.2}), in, and {do}
  (see @Ref{do.1}), to.  In @Ref<ann an>, the two prepositions @Ref{ann.2} and @Ref{an.2}
  are used.  The form @Ref<anns> is used before the article and
  relative; the {-s} properly belongs to the article; {anns an},
  in the, is for {ann san}.
†<annaid>, @Ref<annoid>, a church, M.Ir. @MIr{annóit}, O.Ir. @OIr{andoóit}, mother-church.
  Stokes refers it to L.Lat. {antitas}, for {antiquitas},
  "ancient church".  In Scottish place-names it appears as
  {Annet}, {Clach na h-Annaid}, etc.  Cf. {annone}, church (O'Dav.),
  from Hebrew.
<annaladh>, era, calendar, Ir. @Ir{analach}, chronicle; from Lat. {annalia}.
<annamh>, rare, M.Ir. @MIr{annam}, E.Ir. @EIr{andam}; *{an-dam-}, "non-tame";
  root {dam}, home, home, etc.; Eng. @Eng{domestic}, {tame}.  Hence
  @Ref<annas>, rarity.
<annlamh>, vexation, etc.; see @Ref{anlamh}.
<annlan>, condiment, E.Ir. @EIr{annland}, W. @W{enllyn}; possibly {an+leann}.
<annrach>, @Ref<ànrach>, wanderer, stranger; either from *{ann-reth-ach},
  root {reth}, run (see @Ref{ruith}, @Ref{faondradh}), or from *{an-rath-ach},
  "unfortunate", root {rath}, luck, q.v.
<annrath>, distress, Ir. @Ir{anrath}; {an-rath}; see @Ref{rath}, luck.  The
  E.Ir. @EIr{andró} appears to be of a different origin.
<annsa>, dearer, better liked, so Ir., M.Ir. @Ir@MIr{andsa}, preferable:
<ao->, privative prefix; for @Ref{eu-}, this is for @Ref{an-} (not), before {c} and {t}.
  See @Ref{an-}
<aobhach>, joyous; see @Ref{aoibhinn}.
<aobhar>, cause, Ir. @Ir{adhbhar}, O.Ir. @OIr{adbar}, *{ad-bero-n}; root {ber}, I.E.
  {bher}, whence Lat. {fero}, Eng. @Eng{bear}, etc.
<aobharrach>, a young person or beast of good promise, hobble-dehoy;
  from @Ref{aobhar}, material.
<aobrann>, ankle, O.Ir. @OIr{odbrann}, W. @W{uffarn}: *{od-bronn}, *{ud-brunn-},
  "out-bulge"; {ud-}=Eng. {out}, and {brunn-}, see @Ref{brù}, belly.

  Stokes ({Academy}, June, 1892) makes {od-} to be for {pod}, foot,

<aodach>, clothes, Ir. @Ir{eudach}, O.Ir. @OIr{étach}, *{ant-ac-os}; root {pan}, as
  in @Ref{anart}, q.v.  Cf. Lit. {pinti}, plait, twine, Ch.Sl. {pęti}, wind,
  Lat. {pannus}, etc. Strachan cfs. Alban. {ent}, {int}, weave, Gr.
  @Gr{ἄττομαι}, weave.
<aodann>, face, Ir. @Ir{éadan}, O.Ir. @OIr{étan}, Celtic {antano-} (Stokes); Lat.
  {ante}; Gr. @Gr{ἀvτí}, against; Eng. @Eng{and}; Skr. {ánti}, opposite.
<aodraman>, bladder, Ir. @Ir{éadromán}; see @Ref{aotrom}.
<aog>, death; see @Ref{eug}.
<aogas>, @Ref<aogasg>, face, appearance, M.Ir. @MIr{écosg} (O'Cl), O.Ir. @OIr{écosc},
  habitus, expression, *{in-cosc}; see @Ref{casg}, check.  Cf. O.Ir.
  {in-cho-sig}, significat.
<aoghaire>, shepherd, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{aegaire}, O.Ir. @OIr{augaire}, *{ovi-gar-};
  for {ovi-}, sheep, see @Ref{òisg}.  The {-gar-} is allied to Gr. @Gr{ἀγεíρω},
  @Gr{ἀγορά}, meeting place, market.

<aoibh>, civil look, cheerful face, Ir. @Ir{aoibh}, pleasant, humour, E.Ir.
  {áeb}, O.Ir. @OIr{óiph}, beauty, appearance, *{aibâ} (Thurneysen),
  mien, look, Prov. Fr. {aib}, good manners.  Ascoli refers it to
  the root of @Ref{éibheall} (q.v.), a live coal, the underlying idea
  being "shining, sheen".  This would agree as to the original
  force with @Ref{taitinn}, please, {taitneach}, pleasant.
<aoibhinn>, pleasant, joyful, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{áibind}, {óibind}.  See @Ref{aoibh}
  for root.
<aoideag>, hair-lace, fillet, from root of @Ref{aodach}.
<aoigh.1>, guest, Ir. @Ir{aoidhe}, pl. {aoidheadha}, O.Ir. @OIr{óegi}, pl. {óegid},
  *{(p)oig-it}; cf. the Teutonic *{faig-iþ-}, whence Norse {feigr},
  doomed to die, Ag.S. {fáege}, doomed, Eng. @Eng{fey} (Schräder).
  Stokes gives the Celtic as {(p)oik-it}, {poik}, whence Eng. @Eng{foe}
  (cf. Lat. {hostis}, {hospes}); but the Gaelic {gh} of {aoigh} is against
  this otherwise satisfactory derivation.  As against Schräder's
  etymology, might be put a reference to the form found in
  Gr. @Gr{οἲχομαι}, go, Lit. {eigà}, going, gurther root {ei}, go; the idea
  being "journey-taker".  Commonly misspelt @Ref<aoidh>.
<aoigh.2>, pleasant countenance, Ir. @Ir{aoibh}.
<aoine>, fast, @Ref<Di-haoine>, Friday, Ir. @Ir{aoine}, Friday, O.Ir. @OIr{oine}, fast,
  Br. @Br{iun}; from Lat. {jejunium}, a fast, fast-day, Eng. @Eng{jejune}.
  Stokes suggests Gr. @Gr{πεινάω}, hunger, as cognate, making it
  native: *{poin-io-}.  Unlikely.
<aoineadh>, a steep brae with rocks, Manx {eaynee}, steep place:
<aoir.1>, a satire, Ir. @Ir{aor}, E.Ir. @EIr{áer}, O.Ir. @OIr{áir}.  *{aigrâ}, @Gr{ἀισχος}, Got.
  {aiviski}: {aigh} (St.).  Prellwitz gives Gr. and Got. and root.

  Ir. has also {arrach}, contour, spectre.

  (Sh.):

<arral>, foolish pride:

<àrrusg>, awkwardness, indecency, @Ref<arusg> (M`A.):
<ars>, @Ref<arsa>, quoth, Ir. @Ir{ar}, E.Ir. @EIr{ar}.  The {s} of the Gaelic really belongs
  to the pronoun {sé} or @Ref{sì}, said he, said she, "ar sé, ar sì".  Cf.
  M.G. "ar san tres ughdar glic" - said the third wise author
  ({san} being the full art.; now {ars an}.  The E.Ir. forms {bar}
  and {for}, inquit, point to the root {sver}, say, Eng. @Eng{swear},
  {answer}.  Stokes refers it to the root {ver}, {verdh}, Eng. @Eng{word},
  adducing E.Ir. @EIr{fordat}, {ordat}, {oldat}, inquiunt, for the {verdh}
  root.  Thurneysen objects that {ol} or {for} is a preposition, the
  {-dat} being the verb @Ref{ta} on analogy with other forms {indás},
  {oldáte}.  The original is {al}, propter, "further" (see "thall"),
  like Lat. {tum} ("tum ille" - then he), later {or} or {for}, and
  later still {ar} - all prepositions, denoting "further".
<àrsaidh>, old, Ir. @Ir{ársaidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{arsid}: *{ar-sta-}; {sta}, stand.  It was
  not observed that Stokes had the word; but the same conclusion
  is reached.  His stem is *{(p)arostât}, from {paros},
  before, and {stât}, Skr. {purástât}, erst.
<arsnaig>, arsenic; from the Eng.
<arspag>, large species of sea-gull, larus major:
<artan> a stone; see @Ref{airtein}.
<artlaich>, baffle; see @Ref{fairtlich}.
<àruinn>, a forest; *{ag-ro-ni-}, root {ag}, Gr. @Gr{ἄγρα}, the chase.
--page 23
<as>, @Ref<a.4>, out of, from, Ir. @Ir{as}, O.Ir. @OIr{ass}, @OIr{a}, W. @W{a}, @W{oc}, Br. @Br{a}, @Br{ag}, Gaul.
  @Gaul{ex-}; Lat. {ex}; Gr. @Gr{ἐξ}, etc.  @Ref<as-> is also used as a privative
  particle.
<asaid>, delivery; see @Ref{aisead}.
<asair.1>, also @Ref<fasair>, the herb "asara bacca"; borrowed from Latin
  name.
<asair.2>, harness, shoemaker, Ir. @Ir{asaire}, shoemaker, {assain}, greaves,
  etc., O.Ir. @OIr{assa}, soccus; Gr. @Gr{παξ}, sandal (Hes.), Lat. {baxea};
  root {pāg}, fit, Gr. @Gr{πήγνυμι} (Stokes).
<asal>, an ass, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{assal}, W. @W{asyn}, Corn. @Corn{asen}.  G. and Ir.
  are borrowed from Lat. {assellus}, the W. and Corn. from Lat.
  {asinus}.
<asbhuain>, stubble; *{as-buain}, "out-reaping", q.v.
<ascaoin>, unkind, wrong side of cloth ({caoin is ascaoin}); @Ref{as-},
  privative, and @Ref{caoin.1}, @Ref{caoin.2}, q.v.
<ascart>, tow, Ir. @Ir{asgartach}, M.Ir. @MIr{escart}, W. @W{carth}, Br. @Br{skarz},
  *{ex-skarto-}, *{skarto-}, dividing, root {sker}, separate; Gr. @Gr{σκώρ},
  dung; Eng. @Eng{sharn}; etc.
<asgaidh>, present, boon, E.Ir. @EIr{ascad}, O.Ir. @OIr{ascid} (Meyer); for
  root, see @Ref{taisg}.
<asgailt>, a retreat, shelter; see @Ref{fasgadh}, @Ref{sgàil}: *{ad-scath-}, {ascaid}.
<asgall>, bosom, armpit, so Ir., Br. @Br{askle}, W. @W{asgre}, bosom.  The
  same as @Ref{achlais} (q.v.) be metathesis of the {s}.
<asgan>, a grig, merry creature, dwarf (Arm.).  See @Ref{aisteach}.
<asgnadh>, ascending, so Ir.; *{ad-sqendô-}; Lat. {scando}, etc.
<aslach>, request, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{aslach}, persuasio, {adslig}, persuades; for
  root, see @Ref{slighe}, way.
<aslonnach>, prone to tell (Arm.), E.Ir. @EIr{asluindim}, I request; *{ad-sloinn},
  q.v.
<asp>, an asp, W. @W{asp}, from the Eng.
<àsran>, a forlorn object, Ir. @Ir{asránnach}, {astrannach}, a stranger: from
  @Ref{astar}?
<astail.1>, a dwelling; see @Ref{fasdail}.
<astail.2>, a contemptible fellow (M`A.):
<astar>, a journey, Ir. @Ir{asdar}, {astar}, E.Ir. @EIr{astur}; *{ad-sod-ro-n}, root
  {sod}, {sed}, go; Gr. @Gr{ὁδός}, way, Ch.Sl. {choditi}, go; Eng. @Eng{ex-odus}.
  Stokes (@ExtRef{Bez. Beit.;21;1134}) now gives its Celtic form as
  *{adsîtro-}, root {sai} of {saothar}, toil.
<àsuing>, @Ref<àsuinn>, @Ref<àsuig>, apparatus, weapon; see @Ref{asair.2}(?).
<at>, swell, Ir. @Ir{at}, O.Ir. @OIr{att}, *{(p)at-to-}, root {pat}, extend, as in
  @Ref{aitheamh}, q.v.  Stokes gives Celtic as {azdo-} (Got. {asts}, twig,
  etc.); but this would be Gaelic {ad}.
†<atach.1>, request, B.of Deer {attác}, E.Ir. @EIr{atach}, O.Ir. @OIr{ateoch}, I
  pray, *{ad-tek-}; Eng. @Eng{thig}.
--page 24
<atach.2>, cast-off clothes (Uist, etc.)={ath-aodach}.
<ataig>, @Ref<atuinn>, a palisade, stake:
<atamach>, fondling, caressing (M`A):
<ath.1>, next, again: see @Ref{ath-}.
<ath.2>, flinch; from @Ref{ath-}, back. Hence @Ref<athach.3>, modest.
<ath->, @Ref<aith>, re-, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ath-}, @Ref{aith-}, @Ref{ad-}, *{ati}, W. @W{ad-}, Br. @Br{at-},
  {az-}; Gaul. {ate}: Lat. @Ref{at}, but, {at-} ({atavus}); Lit. {at-}, {ata-}, back,
  Slav. {otŭ}; Skr. {ati}, over.  Stokes divides Celtic {ati-} into two,
  meaning respectively "over" and "re-"; but this seems
  unnecessary.
<àth.1>, a ford, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{áth}, *{jâtu-}; Skr.{yâ}, to go; Lit. {jóti}, ride
  (Stokes).  @Ref<Beul-àth>:
<àth.2>, a kiln, Ir. @Ir{áith}, W. @W{odyn}.  Stokes refers this to a pre-Celtic
  {apati-}, {apatino-}, parallel to Eng. @Eng{oven}, Got. {auhns}, Gr. @Gr{ἰπνός}.
  Bezzenberger suggests the Zend. {âtar}, fire, as related.
<athach.1>, a giant, Ir. @Ir{fathach}, {athach}; root {pat}, extend?
†<athach.2>, a breeze, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{athach}; Gr. @Gr{ἀτμός}, vapour, Eng.
  {atmosphere}; Ger. {atem}, breath; etc.
<athach.3>, modest. See @Ref{ath.2}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<athainne>, embers, so Ir.; *{ath-teine}(?)  See @Ref{aithinne}.
<athailt>, a scar; {ath-ail}; see @Ref{ail.1}, mark.
<athair>, father, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{athir}; Lat. {pater}; Gr. @Gr{πατήρ}; Skr.
  {pitár}; Eng. @Eng{father}.
<athair-neimh>, serpent, Br. @Br{aer}, {azr}; for {nathair-neimh}, q.v.
<athair-thalmhainn>, yarrow, milfoil, Ir. and M.Ir. @MIr{athair talman};
  "pater-telluris!"  Also {earr-thalmhainn}, which suggests
  borrowing from Eng. @Eng{yarrow}.
<athair-thalmhuinn>, see @Ref{athair-thalmhainn}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<athais>, leisure; {ath-fois} = delay, q.v.
<athar.1>, evil effect, consequence (M`A., Whyte), *{at-ro-n} from @Ref{ath-},
  "re-".  See @Ref{comharradh}.  Sc. {aur} = @Ref{athailt}.
<athar.2>, sky, air, Ir. @Ir{aiéur}, air, sky, O.Ir. @OIr{aér}, {aier}, W. @W{awyr}; from
  Lat. {aer}, whence Eng. @Eng{air}.  See St. for {aér}, *{aver}?  Cf.
  @Ref{padhal}, {ataidhir}, @Ref{adhal}.
---gjk (1.14) @Ref{ataidhir} doesn't exist
<atharla>, heifer; possibly {ath-ar-laogh}, "ex-calf".  Cf. E.Ir.
  {aithirni}, calf.
<atharnach>, second crop, ground cropped and ready for ploughing
  (N.H.) {ath-eòrn-ach}? *{ath-ar-nach}, root {ar}, plough.
  See @Ref{àr.1}.
---gjk (1.14) added ref to {àr.1}
<atharrach>, alteration, Ir. @Ir{atharrach}, O.Ir. @OIr{aitherrach}, Br. @Br{adarre},
  afresh, {arre}, *{ati-ar-reg-}, rrot {reg} of {èirich}.  Stokes analyses
  it into {ati-ex-regô}, that is {ath-éirich}.
<atharrais>, mocking, imitating (M`K.); (Dial. @Ref{ailis.2}): {ath-aithris},
  "re-say", Ir. @Ir{aithris}, tell, imitation.  See @Ref{aithris}.
--page 25
<ba!>, part of lullaby; onomatopoetic.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{baby}, Ger. {bube},
  etc.
<bà>, @Ref<bàth.2>, foolish, Fernaig MS. {bah}: "deadly", (talky?), root {bā-},
  kill (speak?); see @Ref{bàs}.  Cf. Lat. {fatuus}.
<babag>, tassle; see @Ref{pab}.
<babhd>, a surmise (M`A.), a quirk; from Lat. {faut}.
<babhsganta>, @Ref<baosganta>, cowardly; see @Ref{bodhbh}; {babhsgadh}, fright,
  shock (Hend.).
<bàbhun>, bulwark, enclosure for cattle, Ir. @Ir{bábhún}, whence Eng.
  {bawn}, M.Ir. @MIr{bódhún} (Annals of Loch Cé, 1199); from @Ref{bó} and
  @Ref{dùn}, q.v.
<bac.1>, hindrance, Ir. @Ir{bac}, M.Ir. @MIr{bacaim} (vb.).  See @Ref{bacag}.
<bac.2>, a crook, Ir. @Ir{bac}, O.Ir. @OIr{bacc}, W. @W{bach}, Br. @Br{bac'h}, Celtic {bakko-s};
  *{bag-ko-}, Norse {bak}, Eng. @Eng{back}.  Hence @Ref<bacach>, lame, E.Ir.
  @Ref{bacach}, W. @W{bachog}, crooked.
<bacag>, a fall, tripping; from @Ref{bac.1}, q.v.
<bac-mòine>, tuf-pit or bank (N.H.); from Norse {bakki}, a bank,
  Eng. @Eng{bank}.  Hence also place-name {Back}.
<bacaid>, ash holder, backet; from Sc. {backet}, from Fr. {baquet}
<bacastair>, baker, @Ref<bacaladh>, oven, Ir. @Ir{bacail}, baker; all from the
  Eng. @Eng{bake}, {baxter}.
<bacan>, stake, hinge, Ir. and E.Ir. @EIr{bacán}.  From @Ref{bac.1}.
<bach>, drunkenness, Ir. @Ir{bach}: from Lat. {Bacchus}.
<bachall>, shepherd's crook, crozier, Ir. @Ir{bachul}, O.Ir. @OIr{bachall}, W.
  {bagl}, crutch; from Lat. {baculum}, staff; Gr. @Gr{βακτηριά}, Eng.
  {bacteria}.  {Bachull gille}, slovenly fellow (M`D.).
<bachar>, acorn, "Molucca bean", Ir. @Ir{bachar}; forrowed from or
  allied to Lat. {baccar}, Gr. @Gr{βάκκαρις}, nard.
<bachlag>, a shoot, a curl, Ir. @Ir{bachlóg}; from @Ref{bachall} (Thurneysen).
<bachoid>, the boss of a shield, Ir. @Ir{bocoide}, bosses of shields; from
  L.Lat. {buccatus}, Lat. {bucca}, cheek.  See @Ref{bucaid}.
<bad>, a cluster, thicket; cf. Br. @Br{bot}, {bod}, bunch of grapes, thicket;
  common in Breton and Scotch place names; probably a
  Pictish word.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{bud}, earlier {bodde}.  Cf. Lat. {fascis}
  (*{fað-scis}), *{fað-sk-}, Norse, Eng. @Eng{bast}?
<badhal>, a wandering, @Ref<bàdharan>; possibly from the root {ba}, go,
  as in @Ref{bothar}, q.v.  H.S.D. suggests {bà+dol}.
<bàdhan>, a churchyard (Sutherland), i.e. "enclosure", same as
  @Ref{bàbhun}.
<bàdhar> (H.S.D.), @Ref<badhar> (Carm.), placenta of cow:
<bag>, a bag; from the Eng.
<bagaid>, a cluster, troop, W. @W{bagad}, Br. @Br{bogod}; from Lat. {bacca}
  (Thurneysen, Ernault).
--page 26
<bagaire>, a glutton; from @Ref{bag} in the sence of "belly".
<bagair>, threaten, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bacur}, a threat.  The W. @W{bygwl}, a
  threat, etc., is scarcely allied, for it comes from {bwg}, a spectre,
  bogie, whence possibly the English words {bogie}, {boggle}, etc.
  G. {bagair} may be allied with the root underlying @Ref{bac.2}; possibly
  {bag-gar-}, "cry-back".
<bagaisde>, baggage, lumber (of a person) (Wh.), from {baggage}.
<bàgh>, a bay, Ir. @Ir{bádh}; from Eng. @Eng{bay}, Romance {baja}.
<baghan>, a stomach (@Ref{baoghan}, with {ao} short).  Dial. @Ref<maghan>
  (Sutherland); cf. Eng. @Eng{maw}, Ger. {magen}, Norse {magi}.
<baibeil>, lying, given to fables; from Eng. @Eng{babble}.
<baideal>, tower, battlement, ensign, @Ref<badealach>, bannered; from
  M.Eng. {battle}, {battlement}, which is of the same origin as
  {battlement}.
<bàidh>, love, Ir. @Ir{báidhe}, M.Ir. @MIr{báide}, {báde}, *{bâdi-s} (Stokes).  Cf.
  Gr. @Gr{φώτιον}, friendly (Hes.), for @Gr{φώθιον}; root {bhā}, whence
  Gr. @Gr{φώς}, man.
<baidreag>, a ragged garment; see @Ref{paidreag}.
<bàidse>, musician's fee; from the Eng. @Eng{batch}?
<baigeir>, a beggar; from Eng.
<baigileis>, looe lumber or baggage (Argyle); from {baggage}.
<bail>, thrift, Ir. @Ir{bail}, success, careful collection, M.Ir. @MIr{bail}, goodness,
  E.Ir. @EIr{bulid}: @Gr{φυλλα}; I.E. root {bhel}, swell, increase.
  See @Ref{buil}, @Ref{bile}.  Hence @Ref<baileach>.  Cf. @Ref{adhbhal}, @Gr{βέλτερος}.
<bailbheag>, a corn poppy; also @Ref<beilbheag>, @Ref<mealbhag>, @Ref<meilbheag>.
<bailc.1>, a ridge, beam, W. @W{balc}, from Eng. @Eng{balk}.
<bailc.2>, seasonable rain, showers:
<bailceach>, strong, a strong man, E.Ir. @EIr{balc}, strong, W. @W{balch},
  (Stokes).  Likely a Celtic {bal-ko-}, root {bal}, as in @Ref{bail}.  So
  Ost.; Skr. {balam}, strength (@Ref{adhbhal}), Gr. @Gr{βέλτερος}; Wh. St.
  {bolijĭ}, greater; Lat. {debilis}.
<baile>, town, township, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{baile}, *{balio-s}, a pre-Celtic
  {bhv-alio-}, root {bhu-}, be; Gr. @Gr{φωλεός}, a lair; Norse {ból}, a
  "bally", further Eng. @Eng{build}, {booth}.
<baileach>, excessive; see @Ref{bail}.  Also @Ref<buileach>.
<bàilisdeir>, babbler, founded on Eng. Scandinavian {balderdash}.
<bàillidh>, a magistrate, balie; from Sc. {bailzie} (Eng. {bailiff}), Fr.
  {bailli}.
<baineasag>, a ferret, Ir. @Ir{baineasóg}; {bán+neas}, "white weasel", q.v.
<bàinidh>, madness, fury, Ir. @Ir{báinidhe}; Ir. @Ir{mainigh} (O'Br.), from
  Lat. {mania}; see @Ref{bà}.
<bainisg>, a little old woman, female satirist (Carm.) = {ban=éisg};
  from {ban}, @Ref{bean.1}, q.v.
<bainne>, milk, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{bainne}; also @Ref<boinne>, milk (Sutherland),
  a drop, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{bainne}, milk. O.Ir. @OIr{banne}, drop
--page 27
  Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{banne}, gutta; root {bha}; O.Slav. {banja}, bath; Eng.
  {bath}, etc.
<bàir>, a game, goal, Ir. @Ir{báire}, hurling match, goal, M.Ir. @MIr{báire}:
  *{bag-ro-}, root {bāg-}, strive; see @Ref{arabhaig}.  @Ref<bàireach>, a ball.
<baircinn>, side timbers of a house (Sh.):
<baireachd>, quarrelling (Carm.); cf. @Ref{bàirseag}.
†<bairghin>, bread, cake, Ir. @Ir{bairghean}, E.Ir. @EIr{bargen}, W., Corn., and
  Br. @Br@Corn@W{bara}, panis, *{bargo-}; Lat. {ferctum}, oblation cake; Ag.S.
  {byrgan}, to taste, Norse {bergja}, taste.
<bàirich>, lowing; root of @Ref{bó}, cow.  Cf. @Ref{bùirich}.
<bàirig>, bestow; from Eng. @Eng{ware}, as also @Ref{bathar}.
<bàirleigeadh>, @Ref<bàirneigeadh>, warning, summonsl; from the Eng.
  {warning}.
<bàirlinn>, rooling wave, billow; {bàir-linn}, from †@Ref<bàir>, wave, borrowed
  from Norse {bára}, wave, billow.  For @Ref{linne}, see that
  word.
<bàirneach>, a limpet, Ir. @Ir{báirneach} (Fol.), W. @W{brenig}, Corn. @Corn{brennic}:
  from M.Eng. {bernekke}, now {barnacle}, from Med.Lat. {bernaca}.
  Stokes takes {bàirnech} from {barenn}, rock, as Gr. @Gr{λεπάς}, limpet,
  is allied to {lépas}, rock.
<bàirneachd>, judgment (Sh.), Ir., W., Br. @Br@Ir@W{barn}, root {ber} in @Ref{bràth},
  q.v.
<bàirseag>, a scold (Sh.), Ir. @Ir{bairseach}, M.Ir. @MIr{bairsecha}, foolish
  talk, @Ref{bara}, wrath, W. @W{bâr}, wrath.  Stokes refers @Ref{bara} to the
  same origin as Lat. {ferio}, I strike, Norse {berja}, smite, etc.
<baisceall>, a wild person (Sh.); M.Ir. @MIr{basgell} (i. {geltan}, {boiscell};
  root in @Ref{bà}, foolish? {+ciall}.
<baiseach>, a heavy shower, Ir. @Ir{báisdeach}, rain, {bais}, water; cf. O.Ir.
  {baithis}, baptism, which may be borrowed from Lat. {baptisma}
  (Windish).  The root here is @Ref{bad}, of @Ref{bàth.1}, drown.  Ir.
  {baiseach}, raining (Clare), from {baisteadh}, Lat. {baptisma} (Zim.).
<baist>, baptise, Ir. @Ir{baisd}, O.Ir. @OIr{baitsim}, from Lat. {baptizo}, which
  is from Gr. @Gr{βαπτíζω}, dip.
<baiteal>, a battle; from Eng. @Eng{battle}.
<balach>, clown, lad, Ir. @Ir{balach}, clown, churl; cf. Skr. {bālakas}, a
  little boy, from {bāla}, young.  But cf. W. @W{bala}, budding, root
  {bhel}.  Rathlin Ir. @Ir{bachlach}.
<balaiste>, ballast; from the Eng.
<balbh>, dumb, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{balb}; borrowed from Lat. {balbus}.
<balc.1>, ridge, etc.; see @Ref{bailc.1}.  Also "calf of leg" (Wh.).
<balc.2>, misdeed:
<balcach>, splay-footed (H.S.D.).  Cf. Gr. @Gr{φολκός}, bandy-legged(?).
<balg>, belly, bag, Ir. @Ir{bolg}, O.Ir. @OIr{bolc}, W. @W{bol}, @W{boly}, belly, Corn. @Corn{bol},
  Gaulish {bulga} (Festus), sacculus; Got. {balgs}, wine-skin,
  Norse {belgr}, skin, bellows, Eng. @Eng{belly}.
--page 28
<balgair>, a fox:
<balgum>, mouthful, M.G. {bolgama} (pl.), Ir. @Ir{blogam}; from @Ref{balg}.  Cf.
  O.Ir. @OIr{bolc uisce}, a bubble.
<ball.1>, a member, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ball}; Gr. @Gr{φαλλός}; Eng. @Eng{phallus}; root
  {bhel}, swell.
<ball.2>, a spot, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{ball}, white-spotted on forehead (of a horse),
  Br. @Br{bal} (do.).  The Gaelic suggests a stem {bal-no-}, Celtic root
  {bal}, white, Gr. @Gr{φαλός}, shining, {fálaros} (phalāros), white-spotted
  (of animals); I.E. {bhēl}: {bhale}, shine; whence Eng.
  {bale}-fire.  Stokes says the Irish {ball} seems allied to the
  Romance {balla}, a ball, Eng. @Eng{bale} and {ball}(?).  Hence @Ref<ballach>,
  spotted.  W. @W{bal}, spotted on forehead.
<ball.3>, a ball; from Eng.
<balla>, wall, Ir. @Ir{balla} (Four Masters), {fala} (Munster); from
  M.Eng. {bailly}, an outer castle wall, now in Old Bailey, from
  Med.Lat. {ballium}.
<ballaire>, a cormorant; from @Ref{ball.2}, spot.
<ballan>, a vessel, tub, Ir. @Ir{ballán}, E.Ir. @EIr{ballan}.  Stokes cfs. Norse
  {bolli}, bowl, Eng. @Eng{bowl}, and says that the Gaelic is probably
  borrowed.
<ballart>, boasting, clamour; probably from Norse {ballra}, strepere,
  {baldrast}, make a clatter (Eng. {balderdash}), Ger. {poltern}.
<balt>, a welt: see @Ref{bolt}.
<bàn>, white, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bán}; I.E. root {bhā}, shine; Gr. @Gr{φανός} ({α}
  long), bright; Skr. {bhânù}, light; further away is Eng. @Eng{bale}
  ({bale}-fire).
<ban->, @Ref<bana->, she-, female-; see @Ref{bean.1}.
<banabachadh>, worse for wear (M`D):
<banachag>, dairymaid:
<banachdach>, vaccination:
<banair>, sheep fold; see rather @Ref{mainnir}.
<banais>, a wedding, wedding feast, Ir. @Ir{bainfheis}, wedding feast,
  M.Ir. @MIr{banais}, g. {baindse}; from {ban+féisd}?
<banarach>, dairymaidl from @Ref{ban-} and @Ref{àireach}.
†<banbh>, a pig, Ir. @Ir{banbh}, E.Ir. @EIr{banb}, W. @W{banw}, Br. @Br{banv}, {bano},
  *{banvo-s}.  The word appears as {Banba}, a name for Ireland,
  and, in Scotland, as Banff.  M`L. and D. gives the further
  meaning of "land unploughed for a year".
<banc>, a bank; from the Eng.
<bànchuir>, squeamishness at sea (H.S.D., which derives it from
  @Ref{bàn} and @Ref{cuir}).
<bangadh>, a binding, promise (Sh., H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{bangadh}.  (H.S.D.
  suggests Lat. {pango}, whence it may have come.
<bangaid>, a banquet, christening feastl from Eng. @Eng{banquet}.
--page 29
<bann>, a belt, band; from Eng. @Eng{band}.  It also means a "hinge".
  Dialectic @Ref<spann.2>.
<bannag.1>, a Christmas cake; from the Sc. {bannock}.  See @Ref{bonnach}.
<bannag.2>, corn-fan; from Lat. {vannus}, Eng. @Eng{fan}.
<bannal>, a troop, gang, Ir. @Ir{banna}; from Eng. @Eng{band}.  Cf. E.Ir.
  {ban-dál}, assembly of ladies.  Also @Ref<pannail>.
<bansgal> (Dial. {banasgal}), a female, a hussy, Ir. @Ir{bansgal}, E.Ir.
  {banscál}, O.Ir. @OIr{banscala}, servae; root of @Ref{sgalag}.
<bantrach>, a widow, E.Ir. @EIr{bantrebthach}, landlady: {ban+trebthach},
  farmer, from {treb} in {treabhadh}, @Ref{aitreabh}.
<baobh>, a wicked woman, witch, Ir. @Ir{badhbh}, hoodie crow, a fairy, a
  scold, E.Ir. @EIr{badb}, crow, demon, {Badba}, the Ir. war-goddess,
  W. @W{bod}, kite, Gaul. {Bodv-}, {Bodvo-gnatus}, W. @W{Bodnod}; Norse
  {böð}, g. {boðvar}, war, Ag.S. {beadu}, g. {beadwe}, *{badwa-} (Rhys.).
  In Stokes' Dict. the Skr. {bádhate}, oppress, Lit. {bádas}, famine,
  are alone given.  Also @Ref<baogh>.
<baodhaiste>, ill usage from the weather:
<baoghal>, danger, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{baigul}, {baegul}; cf. Lit. {bai-mė}, fear,
  {bai-gus}, shy, Skr. {bhayate}, fear.
<baoghan>, a calf, anything jolly; from @Ref{baoth}.
<baogram>, a flighty emotion (Dialectic); founded on @Ref<baogadh>, a dialectic
  form of @Ref{biog}, q.v.
<baoileag>, blaeberry; cf. Eng. @Eng{bil}berry, Dan. {bölle}bær.
<baoireadh>, foolish talk; founded on {baothaire}, fool, from @Ref{baoth}, q.v.
†<baois.1>, lust, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{baes}, *{baisso-} (Stokes); compared by
  Bezzenberger to Gr. @Gr{φαιδρός}, shining, and by Strachan to the
  root {gheidh}, desire, Lit. {geidu}, desire, Ch.Sl. {żida}, expetere,
  Got. {gaidw}, a want.  Possibly allied to Lat. {foedus}, foul.
<baois.2>, madness, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{báis}; from @Ref{baoth} (Zim. @ExtRef{Z;32;229})
  = {báithas}.  Cf. @Ref{sgìth}, {sgìos}.
<baoisg>, shine forth: see @Ref{boillsg}.
<baoiteag>, a small wite maggot; see @Ref{boiteag}.
<baol>, nearness of doing anything (M`A.); @Ref{baoghal}?  Cf. its use
  in Fern. MS.
<baoth>, foolish, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{báith}, {baeth}; root {bai}, fear, as in
