  @Ref{baoghal}; Corn. @Corn{bad}, Br. @Br{bad}, stupidity, are not allied, nor is
  Got. {bauths}, dumb, as some suggest.  Hence @Ref<baothair>, fool.
<bara>, a barrow, Ir. @Ir{bara}, E.Ir. @EIr{bara}; from M.Eng. {barowe}, Eng.
  {barrow}.
<barail>, opinion, Ir. @Ir{baramhuil}, M.Ir. @MIr{baramail}: {bar+samhail};
  for {bar-}, see @Ref{bàirneachd}, @Ref{bràth}.
<baraill>, a barrel, Ir. @Ir{báirille}, E.Ir. @EIr{barille}, W. @W{baril}; from M.E.
  {barel}, from O.Fr. {baril}.
<baraisd>, @Ref<barraisd>, borage; Ir. @Ir{barraist}; from the Eng. @Eng{borage}.
<baran>, a baron; Ir. @Ir{barún}, W. @W{barwn}; from the Eng.
--page 30
<barant>, surety, warrant, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{baránta}, W. @W{gwarant}; from
  M.Eng. {warant}, now {warrant}.  So St.
<barbair>, a barber, Ir. @Ir{bearrbóir} (Fol.), W. @W{barfwr}; from the Eng.
<barbarra>, barbarous, Ir. @Ir{barbartha}; from Lat. {barbarus}, Eng.
  {barbarous}.
<bar-bhrigein>, silver-weed (Arm.); also @Ref<brisgean> (from @Ref{brisg.1}):
<barbrag>, tangle tops, barberry; from Eng. @Eng{barberry}.  In Lewis,
  the former is called @Ref<bragaire>.
<bàrc.1>, a bark, boat, Ir. @Ir{bárc}, E.Ir. @EIr{barc}, W. @W{barg}, Br. @Br{barc}.  These
  words are all ultimately from the Late Latin {barca}, whence
  through Fr. comes Eng. @Eng{bark}.
<bàrc.2>, rush (as water), Ir. @Ir{bárcaim}, break out; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{barc},
  multitude; Lat. {farcio}, cram, {frequens}, numerous.
<bàrd.1>, a poet, Ir. @Ir{bárd}, E.Ir. @EIr{bard}, W. @W{bardd}, Br. @Br{barz}, Gaul.
  {bardos}, *{bardo-s}; Gr. @Gr{φράζω} (@Gr{φραδ-}), speak (Eng. {phrase}.
<bàrd.2>, dyke, inclosure, meadow, Ir. @Ir{bárd}, a guard, garrison; from
  Eng. @Eng{ward}, enclosed pasture land (Liddell 35).
<bargan>, a bargain, W. @W{bargen}; from the Eng. @Eng{bargain}.
<bàrlag>, a rag, tatter-demalion; cf. Ir. @Ir{barlín}, sheet, for {braith-lín},
  q.v.
<bàrluadh>, a term in pipe music; from Eng. @Eng{bar} + G. {luath}.
<bàrnaig>, a summons; from the Eng. @Eng{warning}.
<barpa>, barrow, cairn (H.S.D., a Skye word).  Cape Wrath is
  {Am Parph} in Gaelic ({An Carbh}, Lewis); from Norse {Hvarf},
  a turning, rounding, Eng. @Eng{wharf}.
<bàrr>, top, Ir. @Ir{bárr}, O.Ir. @OIr{barr}, W., Corn. @Corn@W{bar}, Br. @Br{barr}, *{barso-};
  Norse {barr}, pine needles, Ag.S. {byrst}, Eng. @Eng{bristle}, {burr}; Lat.
  {fastiguim} (for {farstigium}, top; Skr. {bhṛshti}, a point.  Hence
  @Ref<barrachd>, overplus.  @Ref<bàrrlach>, refuse, flotsam (Wh.).
<barra>, a spike, bar, Ir. @Ir{bárra}, W. @W{bar}, nail, etc.; all from the Eng.
  {bar}.
<barra-gùg>, potato bloom, bud.  See @Ref{gucag}.  Also {barr-guc}.
<bàrraisg>, boasting, brag, @Ref<bàrsaich>, vain, prating; see @Ref{bàirseag}.
<barramhaise>, a cornice (A.M`D.); {barr+maise}.  Also @Ref<barr-maisich>
  (verb), ornament (M`A.).
<barrlait>, a check (Carm.):
<bas>, palm of the hand, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bas}, {bass}, {boss}, Br. @Br{boz}, *{bostâ};
  Gr. @Gr{ἀγοστός}.
<bàs>, death, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bás}; Celtic root {bā}, {ba}, hit, slay, whence
  Gaul. Lat. {batuere} (Eng. {battls}, etc.); Ag.S. {beadu}, war.
<basaidh>, a basin; from Sc. {bassie}, Eng. @Eng{basin}.
<bascaid>, a basket, Ir. @Ir{basgaod}, W. @W{basged}; from the Eng. @Eng{basket}.
<basdal>, noise, gaiety; from Norse {bastle}, turmoil.
<basdard>, a bastard, so Ir. and M.Ir. @Ir@MIr{basdard}, W. @W{basdardd}; all from the
  Eng. @Eng{bastard}.
--page 31
<basgaire>, mourning, Ir. @Ir{bascarrach}, lamentation, clapping with
  the hands, M.Ir. @MIr{basgaire}; {bas+gaire}, "palm-noise"; for
  {baire}, see @Ref{goir}.  Also @Ref<basraich>.
<basganta>, melodious:
<basg-luath>, vermilion; from the obsolete adg. {basg}, red, E.Ir.
  {basc}, and @Ref{luath.1}, ashes, q.v.  Stokes cfs. {basc} to Lat. {bacca}
  (for {bat-ca}), berry.
<bat>, @Ref<bata>, a stick, Ir. @Ir{bata}; from M.Eng. {batte}, stick, now {bat},
  which comes from O.Fr. {batte}, from Gaul. Lat. {battuere}, as
  under @Ref{bàs}, q.v.  The Br. @Br{baz} seems borrowed from the Fr.
  thought it may be native.
<bàta>, a boat, Ir. @Ir{bád}, M.Ir. @MIr{bát}, W. @W{bâd}; all from Ag.S. {bât}, Eng.
  {boat}, Norse {bátr} (Stokes).  K. Meyer takes Ir. and G. from
  the Norse.
<batail>, a fight; see @Ref{baiteal}.
<bàth.1>, drown, Ir. @Ir{báthaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{bádud} (inf.), W. @W{boddi}, Br. @Br{beuzi};
  I.E. {ℊādh}, sink, Gr. @Gr{βαθύς}, deep, @Gr{-βδύω}, sink, Skr. {gāhas}, the
  deep.  Gl. {fodio} (Ern.).
<bàth.2>, vain, foolish (Hend.); see @Ref<bà>.  Skye.
<bàthaich>, a byre, Ir. @Ir{bothigh}, W. @W{beudy}; {bó+tigh}, "cow-house".
<bathais>, forehead, Ir. @Ir{baithis}, pate, E.Ir. @EIr{baithes}, crown of the
  forehead; *{bat-esti-}, from @Ref{bat}, I.E. {bhā}, shine, Gr. @Gr{φάσις},
  appearance, {phase}.  See @Ref{bàn} further.  Lat. {facies}, face,
  appearance, may be allied, though the latest authorities
  connect it with {facio}, make.
<bathar>, wares; from the Eng. @Eng{wares}.
†<beabhar>, beaver, Ir. @Ir{beabhar} (Lh.), Corn. @Corn{befer}, Br. @Br{bieuzr}, Gaul.
  {Bibrax}; Lat. {fiber}; Eng. @Eng{beaver}, Ag.S. {béofor}.  Gaelic and
  Ir. are doubtful.
<beach>, a bee, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bech}, W. @W{begegyr}, drone, *{biko-s}; a root
  {bi-} appears in Eng. @Eng{bee}, Ag.S. {beó} (=*{bija}), Ger. {biene}
  (=*{bi-nja}), Lit. {bitis}.  Stokes makes the Celtic stem {beko-s},
  but does not compare it with any other language.
<beachd>, opinion, notice, Ir. @Ir{beacht}, certain, E.Ir. @EIr{becht}, {bechtaim}, I
  certify; *{bhig-to-}; Lat. {figo} (St. Z.C.P. 71).
<beadaidh>, impudent, fastidious, Ir. @Ir{béadaidh}, {beadaidh}, sweet-mouthed,
  scoffing; E.Ir. @EIr{bet}, talking, shameless girl (Corm.):
  *{beddo-}, *{bez-do-}, root {bet}, {ℊet}, as in @Ref{beul}.
<beadradh>, fondling, caressing, @Ref<beadarrach>, pampered:
<beag>, little, Ir. @Ir{beag}, O.Ir. @OIr{becc}, W. @W{bach}, Corn. @Corn{bechan}, Br. @Br{bic'han},
  @Ref{bian}, *{bezgo-}; Lat. {vescus} (={gvesgus})?  Some have connected
  it with Gr. @Gr{μικρός}, Dor. Gr. @Dor{μικκός}, and Dr Cameron suggested
  Lat. {vix}, scarcely.
<beairt>, engine, loom: see @Ref{beart}.
<beairtean>, shrouds, rigging; see @Ref{beart}.
--page 32
<bealach>, a pass, Ir. @Ir{bealach}, pass, road, E.Ir. @EIr{belach}, cf. Skr.
  {bíla}, gap, mouth; {bilako-n} (C.RR. 174).  Cf. W. @W{bwlch}, pass,
  etc?  See @Ref{bile}.
<bealaidh>, broom, Ir. @Ir{beallýi} (Lh. {Comp. Voc.}); cf. Br. @Br{balan},
  M.Br. @MBr{balazn}, O.Fr. {balain}; also Fr. {balai}, older {balain}, a
  broom.  This might be referred to the common root {bhel},
  bloom (prolific as a root, like the corresponding root of {broom},
  as in W. @W{balannu}, to bud), but the W. for "broom" is {banadl},
  Corn. @Corn{banathel}, which M. Ernault has compared with Lat.
  {genista}, broom (root {gen}, beget?).  Jub. gives Br. as {banadlon}
  (@ExtRef{R.C.;18;106}).  The Br. might be a metathesis of W. @W{banadl}
  (cf. Br. @Br{alan} v. @Ref{anail}).  It is possible that Gaelic is borrowed
  from the Pictish; the word does not appear in the Ir.
  Dictionaries, save in Lh.'s Celt. part, which perhaps proves
  nothing.
<bealbhan-ruadh>, a species of hawk (Sh., O'R.); for {bealbhan}, cf.
  †@Ref<bealbhach>, a bit, from @Ref{beul}, mouth?
<bealltuinn>, May-day, Ir. @Ir{béalteine}, E.Ir. @EIr{beltene}, {belltaine}, *{belo-te(p)niâ}
  (Stokes), "bright-fire", where {belo-} is allied to Eng.
  {bale} ("bale-fire"), Ag.S. {bael}, Lit. {baltas}, white.  The Gaul.
  god-names {Belenos} and {Belisama} are also hence, and Shakespeare's
  {Cym-beline}.  Two needfires were lighted on Beltane
  among the Gael, between which they drove their cattle for
  purification and luck; hence the proverb: "Eadar dà theine
  Bhealltuinn" - Between two Beltane fires.
<bean.1>, wife, so Ir. @Ir{ben}, W. @W{bun}, {benyw}, Corn. @Corn{benen}, sponsa,
  Celtic {benâ}, g. {bnâs}, pl.n. {bnâs}; Gr. @Gr{γυνή}, Bœot. Gr. @Boeot{βανά};
  Got. {ginô}, Eng. @Eng{queen}, Sc. {queyn}; Skr. {gnâ}.
<bean.2>, touch, Ir. @Ir{beanaim}, beat, touch, appertain to, O.Ir. @OIr{benim},
  pulso, ferio, Br. @Br{bena}, to cut, M.Br. @MBr{benaff}, hit; *{bina}, root
  {bin}, {bi} (O.Ir. @OIr{ro bi}, percussit, {bithe}, perculsus), from I.E. {bhi},
  {bhei}, hit; Ch.Sl. {bija}, {biti}, strike; O.H.G. {bîhal}, axe; Gr.
  @Gr{φιτρός}, log.  Further is root {bheid}, split, Eng. @Eng{bite}.  Usually
  {bean} has been referred to I.E. {ℊhen}, {ℊhon}, hit, slay; Gr. @Gr{φεν-},
  slay, @Gr{επεφνον}, slew, @Gr{φόνος}, slaughter, @Gr{θεíνω}, strike; Skr. {han},
  hit; but {ℊh} = G. {b} is doubtful.
<beann>, top, horn, peak, Ir. @Ir{beann}, O.Ir. @OIr{benn}, pinna, W. @W{ban},
  height, peak, M.Br. @MBr{ban}, also {benny}, horn, pipe (music),
  Gaul. {canto-bennicus} mons, "white peak" mount; proto-Gaelic
  {bennâ}; root {ℊen-}, {ℊn-}, as in Eng. @Eng{knoll}, Sc. {knowe}.  In Scotch
  Gaelic, the oblique form @Ref<beinn> has usurped the place of
  {beann}, save in the gen.pl.
<beannachd>, blessing, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bendacht}, W. @W{bendith}l from Lat.
  {bendictio}, whence Eng. @Eng{benediction}.
--page 33
<beannag>, a skirt, corner, coif, Ir. @Ir{beannóg}; from @Ref{beann}.
<beantag>, a corn-fan; see @Ref<bannag.2>.
<bearach>, dog-fish (M`A.); O.Ir. @OIr{berach}, verutus, from @Ref{bior}; cf.
  Eng. "picked or horned dogfish"; "bone-dog".
<bearachd>, judgement (Sh., O'R.); root {bera}, {brâ}, as in @Ref{bràth}, q.v.
<bearbhain>, vervain; from Eng. @Eng{vervain}, Lat. {verbena}.
<bearn>, a breach, cleft, Ir. @Ir{bearna}, E.Ir. @EIr{berna}; I.E. {bher}, cut,
  bore;  Lat. {forare}, bore; Gr. @Gr{φάρος}, a plough, @Gr{φαρω}, split;
  Arm. {beran}, mouth; Ch.Sl. {bar}, clip; Eng. @Eng{bore}.  Also {bern},
  fen in E.Ir.
<beàrr>, shear, Ir. @Ir{béarraim}, O.Ir. @OIr{berraim}, O.W. @OW{byrr}, short, Corn.
  @Corn{ber}, Br. @Br{berr}, short, *{berso-}; Gr. @Gr{φάρσος}, any piece cut off;
  root {bhera}, as in @Ref{bearn}.
<bearraideach>, flighty, nimble; from @Ref{beàrr}?
<beart>, a deed, Ir. @Ir{beárt}, load, action, E.Ir. @EIr{bert}, bundle, birth; Gr.
  @Gr{φόρτος}, burden; root, {bher}, in @Ref{beir}, q.v.  Also @Ref<beairt>, engine,
  loom.  It is used in many compounds in the sense of "gear",
  as in @Ref<cais-bheart>, foot-gear, shoes; @Ref<ceann-bheart>, head-gear,
  helmet, etc.
<beartach>, rich; from @Ref{beart}; W. @W{berth}, rich, {berthedd}, riches.
<beatha>, life, so Ir.  O.Ir. @OIr{bethu}, g. {bethad}, Celtic stem {bitât-},
  divided into {bi-tât}; see @Ref{bith.2} (i.e. {bi-tu-}) for root.  It is usual
  for philologists to represent the stem of {beatha} as {bivotât}, that
  is {bi-vo-tât-}, the {bi-vo-} part being the same as the stem {bivo}
  of @Ref{beò}.  While the root {bi} is common to both {beatha} and @Ref{beò},
  the former does not contain {-vo-}; it is the O.Ir. nom. {beothu}
  (*{bi-tûs}) that has set philologists wrong.  Hence G. and Ir.
  @Ref<beathach>, animal.  Ir. @Ir{beathadhach}, dial. of @Ref{beathach}.
<beic>, a curtesy; from Sc. {beck}, curtesy, a dialectic use of Eng.
  {beck}, {beckon}.  Hence @Ref<beiceis>, bobbing, etc. (M`A.).
<beil.1>, grind; a very common form of @Ref{meil}, q.v.
<beil.2>, is; see @Ref{bheil}.
<beilbheag>, corn-poppy; see @Ref{mealbhag}.  Also @Ref<bailbheag>.
<béileach>, a muzzle, Ir. @Ir{beulmhach}, a bridle, bit, {-mhach} for @Ref{bach}
  termination from {bongim}, beat; from @Ref{beul}.
<béilleach>, blubber-lipped, @Ref<béileach> (H.S.D.); from @Ref{beul}.  The first
  form suggests a stem {bél-nac-}.  Cf. @Ref<béilean>, a prating mouth.
  Also @Ref<méilleach>.
<beilleag>, outer coating of birch, rind; also @Ref<méilleag>, q.v.
<beince>, @Ref<being> (H.S.D.), a bench; from Sc. {bink}; Eng. @Eng{bench}.
  Cf. Ir. @Ir{beinse}, W. @W{mainc}, Br. @Br{menk}.
<beinn>, hill, ben; oblique form of @Ref{beann} (f.n.), used as a fem.nom.,
  for @Ref{beann} sounds masculine beside @Ref{ceann}, etc.  See @Ref{beann}.
--page 34
<beinneal>, binding of a sheaf of corn, bundle; from Sc. {bindle}, a
  cord of straw or other for binding, Eng. @Eng{bundle}; from {bind}.
<beir>, catch, bring forth, Ir. @Ir{beirim}, O.Ir. @OIr{berim}, W. @W{cymmeryd}, to
  take, accept, Br. @Br{kemeret} (={com-ber-}); I.E. {bher}, whence
  Lat. {fero}, Gr. @Gr{φέρω}, Eng. @Eng{bear}, Skr. {bharami}.
<beirm>, @Ref<bairm>, (Hend.), barm, yeast; from Sc. {barm} (pronounced
  {berm}, Eng. @Eng{barm}; Lat. {fermentum}.
<beisear>, plate-rack on dresser (Rob.).
<béist>, a beast, Ir. @Ir{bíast}, {péist}, O.Ir. @OIr{béist}, W.  {bwystfil}; from Lat.
  {bestia} (Eng. {beast}).  Also @Ref<biast>.
<beith>, birch, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bethe}, W. @W{bedw}, Br. @Br{bezuenn}, Celtic {betvâ},
  Lat. {betula}, Fr. {boule}.
<beithir>, a serpent, any wild beast, monster, a huge skate,
  Ir. @Ir{beithir}, wild beast, bear, E.Ir. @EIr{beithir}, G. {bethrach}.  In
  the sense of "bear", the word is, doubtless, borrowed; but
  there seems a genuine Celtic word {betrix} behind the other
  meanings, and the {beithir} or {beithir béimneach} is famed in
  myth.  Cf. Lat. {bēstia}, for {bet-tia}?  Norse {bera}, bear (fem.),
  {beirfhall}, bearskin, Eng. @Eng{bear} (Zim. @ExtRef{K.B.;1;286}).
<beitir>, neat, clean (M`F.):
<beò>, living, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{beó}, W. @W{byw}, Br. @Br{beu}, *{bivo-s}; Lat. {vîvus},
  living, {vîta}; Gr. @Gr{βíοτος}, a living; Eng. @Eng{quick}; Skr. {jîvá},
  living; I.E. {ℊei-}, {ℊi-}, live.  See also @Ref{beatha}, @Ref{bith.2}.
<beòir>, beer, Ir. @Ir{beór}; from Ag.S. {beór}, Norse {bjórr} (Eng. {beer}).
<beòlach>, ashes with hot embers (M`A.); from @Ref{beò} + {luathach},
  "live-ashes".  Another <beòlach>, lively youth, hero, stands
  for {beò-lach}; for {-lach}, see @Ref{òglach}.
<beuban>, anything, mangled:
<beuc>, roar, Ir. @Ir{béic}, O.Ir. @OIr{béccim}, W. @W{beichio}, {baich}, *{beikkiô}; Corn.
  @Corn{begy}, Br. @Br{begiat}, squeal, {baeguel}, bleat, *{baikiô} (Stokes).  The
  difficulty of the vowels as between G. and W. ({é} should give
  {wy}) suggests comparison with @Ref{creuchd}, W. @W{craith}, *{crempt-}
  (Strachan).  Thus {beuc}, {baich} suggests {benk-ko-}, further
  {gṇk-ko-}, root {ℊem}, Lat. {gemo}, etc.  The same result can be
  derived from the root {geng-} of @Ref{geum}, q.v.
<beud>, mischief, hurt, Ir. @Ir{béad}, E.Ir. @EIr{bét}, *{bento-n}; allied to Eng.
  {bane}.
<beul>, mouth, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bél}, *{bet-lo-}, I.E. {ℊet-}, whence Eng.
  {quoth}, Got. {qithan}.  The idea is the "speaker".  Some
  connect W. @W{gwefl} (={vo-bel}), but this is probably *{vo-byl}, {byl},
  edge (Ernault).
<beulaobh>, front, E.Ir. @EIr{ar-bélaib}, O.Ir. @OIr{bélib}; dat.pl. of @Ref{beul}; also
  mixed with this is the O.Ir. acc.pl. {béulu}.
--page 35
<beum>, a stroke, cut, taunt, Ir. and O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{béim}, nom.pl. {bémen},
  blow, from the root {beng}, {bong}, which appears in @Ref{buain}; cf. @Ref{ceum}
  from {ceng-men}, @Ref{leum} from {leng-men}.  This agrees with Corn.
  @Corn{bom}, blow.  Some suggest {beid-men} or {beids-men}, root {bheid},
  Eng. @Eng{bite}, which suits G. best as to meaning.  The favourite
  derivation has been *{ben-s-men}, root {ben} of @Ref{bean.2}.
<beur>, @Ref<beurra>, @Ref<beurtha>, sharp, pointed, clear; gibe, jeer (Hend.);
  cf. Ir. @Ir{béarrtha}, clipped, from @Ref{beàrr}; from {berr-tio-s}, with @Ref{i}
  regressive into {berr}, giving {beirr}.
<beurla>, English, language, Ir. @Ir{beurla}, speech, language, especially
  English; O.Ir. @OIr{bélre}; {bél}+{re}, {bél}, mouth, and the abstract
  termination {-re} (as in {luibhre}, {buidhre}, etc.).
<beus>, conduct, habit, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bés}, Br. @Br{boaz}, *{beissu-}, {beid-tu-},
  root {beid}, I.E. {bheidh}, Gr. @Gr{πειθω}, persuade, Lat. {fides}, English
  {faith}.  Others derive it from {bhend}, bind, giving {bhend-tu-} as
  the oldest stem.  Windisch suggests connection with Got.
  {bansts}, barn, Skr. {bhâsa}, cowstall.  The Breton {oa} seems against these
  derivations.
<bha>, @Ref<bhà>, was, Ir. @Ir{do bhámar}, we were ({bhá-}), {do bhí}, was, M.Ir.
  {ro bói}, was, O.Ir., @OIr{bói}, @OIr{bái}, @OIr{búi}, a perfect tense, *{bove(t)}, for
  {bebove}; Skr. {babhūva};  Gr. @Gr{πέφυ-κε}; I.E. {bheu}, to be, as
  in Lat. {fui}, was (an aorist form), Eng. @Eng{be}.
<bhàn>, @Ref<a bhàn>, down; by eclipsis for {a(n) bh-fàn}, "into declivity",
  from @Ref{fàn}, a declivity, Ir., O.Ir., @OIr{fán}, proclive, W. @W{gwaen}, a
  plain, planities montana, *{vag-no-}, root, {vag}, bow, etc., Lat.
  {vagor}, wander, Ger. {wackeln}, wobble.  Ir. has also {fán}, a
  wandering, which comes near the Lat. sense.  In Sutherlandshire,
  the adj. @Ref<fàn>, prone, is still used.
<bheil>, is, Ir. @Ir{fuil}, {bh-fuil}, O.Ir. @OIr{fail}, @OIr{fel}, @OIr{fil}, root {vel} ({val}), wish,
  prevail, Lat. {volo}, {valeo}, Eng. @Eng{will}.
<bho>, @Ref<o.2>, from Ir. @Ir{ó}, @Ref{ua}, O.Ir., @OIr{ó}, @OIr{úa}, *{ava}; Lat. {au}-fero, "away"-take;
  Ch.Sl. {u-}; Skr. {ava}, from.
<bhos>, @Ref<a bhos>, on this side; from the eclipsed form {a(n) bh-fos},
  "in station", in rest, Ir. @Ir{abhus}, O.Ir. @OIr{i foss}, here, O.Ir. @OIr{foss},
  remaining, staying, rest.  See @Ref{fois}, rest, for root.
<bhur>, @Ref<bhur n->, your, Ir. @Ir{bhar n-}, O.Ir. @OIr{bar n-}, {far n-}, *{svaron}
  (Stokes), *{s-ves-ro-n}.  For {sves-}, see @Ref{sibh}.  Cf. for form Got.
  {izvara}, Lat. {nostrum} (nos{-tero-}, where {-tero-} is a fuller comparitive
  form than Celtic {-(e)ro-}, {-ro-} of {sves-ro-n}, {svaron}).
<bi.1>, @Ref<bì>, be Ir. @Ir{bí}, be thou, O.Ir. @OIr{bíu}, sum, {bí} be thou, O.W. @OW{bit},
  sit, {bwyf}, sim, M.Br. @MBr{bezaff}.  Proto-Celtic {bhv-ijô}, for O.Ir.
  {bíu}, I am; Lat. {fio}; Eng. @Eng{be}; I.E. root {bheu}, be.  See @Ref{bha}.
  Stokes differs from other authorities in referring {bíu}, {bí} to
  Celtic {beiô}, root {bei}, {bi}, live, as in @Ref{bith.2}, @Ref{beatha}, Lat. {vivo}, etc.
--page 36
<bi.2>, @Ref<bigh>, doorpost, threshold (Hend.), E.Ir. @EIr{di bí} = two posts.
  M`A. has @Ref{bìgh}, post, pillar.
<biadh>, food, so Ir., O.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{biad}, *{bivoto-n}, whence W. @W{bywyd}, vita,
  Corn. @Corn{buit}, cibus, Br. @Br{boed}, food.  {bivoto-n} is a derivative from
  {bivo-} of @Ref{beò}, living, q.v.
<bian>, a hide, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bían}, *{beino-}; root {bhei-}, as in Eng. @Eng{bite},
  Lat. {findo}.  For force, cf. Gr. @Gr{δέρμα}, skin, from {der}, split,
  Eng. @Eng{tear}.  Cf., for root, @Ref{bean.2}, hit.
<biasgach>, niggardly; from @Ref{biast}.  In some parts @Ref{biast} is applied
  to a niggardly person.  H.S.D. refers it to @Ref{biadh}+{sgathach},
  catching at morsels.
<biast>, a beast, worthless person; see @Ref{béist}.  The word <biast>,
  abuse, is a metaphoric use of {biast}.
<biatach>, a raven (Sh.); cf. {biatach}, {biadhtach}, a provider, farmer,
  from @Ref{biadh}.
<biatas>, betony, beet, Ir. @Ir{biatuis}, W. @W{betys}; from Lat. {bētis}, {bēta},
  Eng. @Eng{beet}.  Also @Ref<biotais>.
<biathainne>, earth-worm, hook-bait, @Ref<biathaidh> (Dialectic); from
  @Ref{biadh}.  Cf. Lat. {esca}, bait, for {ed-sca}, {ed}={eat}.  The word
  @Ref<biathadh> in many places means "to entice".
<biatsadh>, provisions for a journey, {viaticum}; formed from @Ref{biadh},
  with, possibly, a leaning on {viaticum}.
<bicas>, viscount (Arm.).  Founded on the Eng., and badly spelt by
  Armstrong: either @Ref<biceas> or @Ref<biocas>.
<bicein>, a single grain (Arg.).  From {bioc}, @Ref{pioc}? (Wh.)
<biceir>, a wooden dish; from Sc. {bicker}, Eng. @Eng{beaker}.  Also @Ref<bigeir>,
  @Ref<bigein>.
<bìd>, a very small portion, a nip, a chirp.  In the sense of "small
  portion", the word is from the Sc. {bite}, {bit}, Eng. @Eng{bite}, {bit}.  In
  the sense of "chirp, a small sound", O'R. has an Ir. word
  {bíd}, "song of birds".  See @Ref<bìog>.  Hence @Ref<bìdein>, diminutive
  person or thing.  Cf. W. @W{bidan}, of like force.
<bìdeag>, a bit, bittie; from Sc. {bittock}, dim. of Eng. @Eng{bit}.
<bidean>, a fence (Stew.), @Ref<bid> (Sh.), Ir. @Ir{bíd}, {bídeán} (O'R.), W. @W{bid},
  quickset hedge, {bidan}, a twig; *{bid-do-}, root {bheid}, split?
<bidhis>, a vice, screw, so Ir.; from Eng. @Eng{vice}.
<bidse>, a bitch; from the English.
<bìgh>, @Ref<bigh>, pith of wood, gum.  See @Ref<bìth.1>.
<bil>, @Ref<bile>, edge, lip, Ir. @Ir{bil}, mouth, E.Ir., {bil}, @Ref{bile}, W. @W{byl}, *{bili-},
  {bilio-}.  Root {bhi}, {bhei}, split; cf. Skr. {bíla}, a hole, mouth of a
  vessel, etc.; {vil}, edge : W. also {myl}.
<bileag>, @Ref<bile>, a leaf, blade, Ir. @Ir{billeóg}, {bileóg}, *{biliâ}, I.E. root {bhela},
  {bhale}, {bhlē}, {bhlō}, as in @Ref{blàth.1}; Lat. {folium}; Gr. @Gr{φύλλον}, a
  leaf; further, Eng. @Eng{blade}.
--page 37
<bilearach>, @Ref<bileanach>, sea-grass, sweet-grass; from @Ref{bile}.
<bileid>, a billet; from the Eng.
<bilistear>, a mean, sorry fellow, a glutton, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bille}, mean,
  paltry.  In the Heb. it means, "rancid butter" (H.S.D.).
<binid>, also @Ref<minid> (Arg.), cheese, rennet, bag that holds the rennet,
  stomach, Ir. @Ir{binid}, O.Ir. @OIr{binit}, rennet; *{binenti-}, "biter",
  root of @Ref{bean.2}?  Cf. @Ref{muinne}, stomach.
<binn.1>, melodious, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bind}, *{bendi}, *{bydi-}; O.Br. @OBr{bann}
  (St.); Skr. {bhandate}, joyful, {bhand}, receive loud praise,
  {bhandána}, shouting (Stokes, who adds Lat. {fides}, lyre).  The
  idea may, however, be "high", root of @Ref{beann}, peak, {binneach},
  high-headed.  See @Ref{binn.2} also.
<binn.2>, sentence, verdict; *{bendi-}, *{benni-}; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{atboind},
  proclaims, *{bonnô}, I ban.  Cf. Skr. {bhan}, speak, Eng. @Eng{ban}.
  It is clear that Gaelic has an ablaut in {e:o} connected with
  the root {bha}, speak.
<binndich>, curdle; from @Ref{binid}, q.v.
<binnein>, pinnacle; from @Ref{beann}, q.v.
<bìoball>, @Ref<pìoball>, Bible, Ir. @Ir{biobla}, W. @W{bebil}; from Lat. {biblia},
  Eng. @Eng{bible}.
<bìobull>, see @Ref{bìoball}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<biod>, pointed top; root in @Ref{biodag}, @Ref{bidean}.
<biodag>, a daggar, Ir. @Ir{bideóg} (O'R.), {miodóg}, W. @W{bidog}, O.Br. @OBr{bitat},
  resicaret, *{biddo-}, {bid-do-}, Celtic root {bid}, {beid}, I.E. {bhid},
  {bheid}, Lat. {findo}, Eng. @Eng{bite}, Skr. {bhid}, split.  Hence Eng.
  {bodkin}, possibly.
<biog>, @Ref<bìog>, a start, Ir. @Ir{bíodhg}, E.Ir. @EIr{bedg}, O.Ir. @OIr{du-bidcet},
  jaculantur, *{bizgo-}, root {bis}, {ℊis}, root {ℊi-} of @Ref{beò}.  Consider
  @Ref<bìogail>, lively, {quick}.
<bìog>, @Ref<biog>, chirp; onomatopetic; cf. Lat. {pipe}, chirp, Eng. @Eng{pipe};
  also Eng. @Eng{cheep}.  Also @Ref<bìd>, q.v.
<bìogarra>, churlish; "cheepish", from @Ref{bìog}, cheep.
<biolagach>, melodious (M`F.); from †@Ref<biol>, violin; from Eng. @Eng{viol},
  Fr. {viole}, violin.
<biolaire>, water-cresses, Ir. @Ir{biolar}, E.Ir. @EIr{biror}, W. @W{berwr}, Corn., Br.
  @Br@Corn{beler}, *{beruro-}, Lat. {berula} (Marcellus), Fr. {berle}, Sp. {berro}.
  Possibly allied to the root of Celtic {bervô}, seethe, O.Ir. @OIr{tipra},
  well, G. {tobar}, Eng. @Eng{burn}.  Cf. Ger. {brunnen kresse}, water-cress,
  i.e. "well" cress.  The dictionaries and old glossaries
  (Cormac, etc.) give {bir}, @Ref{bior}, as water or well.
<biolar>, dainty, spruce (Sh.); for {bior-ar}, from @Ref{bior}, "sharp"?
<biolasgach>, prattling, so Ir. (Lh., O'B.); from @Ref{bil}, lip.
<bionn>, symmetrical (Carm.): Sc {bien}.
<bior>, stake, spit, Ir. @Ir{bior}, O.Ir. @OIr{bir}, W. @W{bêr}, Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{ber}, Celtic
  {beru-}; Lat. {veru}; Gr. @Gr{βαρύες}, trees (Hes.); Lit. {gìrė}, forest.
  Hence @Ref<biorach>, sharp.
--page 38
<biorach>, a heifer, colt, Ir. @Ir{biorach}, cow-calf:
<bioras>, water-lily; same origin as @Ref{biolar}, q.v.
<biorg>, gush, twich, tingle; from the roots of @Ref{biolar} ({bior-}) and
  @Ref{bior}.
<biorraid>, a helmet, cap, Ir. @Ir{birreud}, cap; from Eng. @Eng{biretta}, from
  Late Lat. {birretum}.
<biorsadh>, a keen impatience: "groading"; from @Ref{bior}.
<biorsamaid>, a balance; from Sc. {bismar}, Norse {bismari}.
<bior-snaois>, bowsprit of a sailing boat (N. Lochaber), forepart of
  vessel:
<biota>, a churn, vessel; from Norse {bytta}, a pail, tub, Ag.S. {bytt},
  Latin {buttis}, Eng. @Eng{butt}.
<biotailt>, victuals, E.Ir. @EIr{bitáill}, W. @W{bitel}, M.Br. @MBr{bitaill}; from O.Fr.
  {vitaille}, from Lat. {victualia}.  Eng. @Eng{victuals} is from the French.
<birlinn>, a galley, bark, M.Ir. @MIr{beirling}; formed from the Norse
  {byrðingr}, a ship of burthen, from {byrðr}, burden, vb. {bera},
  Eng. @Eng{bear}.  The Sc. {bierling}, {birlinn} is from the Gaelic.  Cf.
  @Ref{feòirlig}={fjórðungr}.
<birtich>, stir up; from @Ref{bior}, goad.
<biseach>, luck; see @Ref{piseach}.
<bith.1>, the world, existence, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bith}, W. @W{byd}, Br. @Br{bed}, Gaul.
  {bitu-}, *{bitu-s}; root {bi}, {bei}, live, I.E. {ℊei}, {ℊi}, whence Lat.
  {vivo}, Eng. @Eng{be}, etc.  Hence @Ref{beatha}, @Ref{beò}, @Ref{biadh}, q.v.
<bith.2>, being (inf. of @Ref{bì}, be), Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{beith}, O.Ir. @OIr{buith}.  The O.Ir.
  is from the root {bhu} (Eng. {be}, Lat. {fui}) = *{buti-s}, Gr. @Gr{φύσις}.
  The forms {bith} and @Ref{beith}, if derived from {bhu}, have been
  influenced by @Ref{bith.1}, world, existence; but it is possible that
  they are of the same root {ℊi} as {bith}.  Stokes, in his treatise
  on the {Neo-Celtic Verb Substantive}, takes {bith} and @Ref{beith} from
  the root {ga}, go, Gr. @Gr{βάσις} (Eng. {base}), a root to which he
  still refers the O.Ir. aorist {bá}, fui (see @Ref{bu}).
<bìth.1>, resin, gum, birdlime, Ir. @Ir{bigh}, O.Ir. @OIr{bí}, pix, adj. {bíde}, *{geis-},
  a longer form of {gis-}, the root of @Ref{giuthas}, fir (Schräder).
  Otherwise we must regard it as borrowed from Lat. {pix}, {picis},
  whence W. @W{pyg}, Eng. @Eng{pitch}, against which {b} and {í} (@Ref{i} long)
  militate.
<bìth.2>, quiet (Arm.):
<bith->, prefix denoting "ever", Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bith-}, W. @W{byth-}; from
  @Ref{bith.1}, world.
<biùc>, difficult utterance:
<biùthaidh>, foe, Ir. @Ir{bíodhbha}, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bidbe}, {bidbid} (gen.),
  culprit, enemy.
<biùthas>, fame, @Ref<biùthaidh>, hero; see @Ref{fiù}, @Ref{fiùbhaidh}.
--page 39
<blabaran>, stammerer, Ir. @Ir{blabarán}, from the Eng. @Eng{blabber}, speak
  inarticulately.  It is of onomatopetic origin.  Cf. Eng.
  {babble}.
<bladair>, a wide mouth, a flatterer, Ir. @Ir{bladaire}, flatterer; from
  the Eng. @Eng{blatterer}, bletherer, blusterer, {blatter}, prate; from
  Lat. {blaterare}, prate.  Also @Ref<blad> a wide mouth (M`F.).
<bladh>, fame, Ir. @Ir{bládh}, E.Ir. @EIr{blad}; root {blad-}, {blat-}, speak, as in
  Lat. {blatero}, babble, Norse {blaðr}, nonsense, Sc. {blether}.  See
  @Ref{bladair}.  Cf. @Ref{glaodh.1}, shout.  Hence @Ref<bladhair>, expressive,
  a boaster.
<bladhail>, strong, from @Ref<bladh>, pith, W. @W{blawdd}, active; *{blâd-};
  root {blā}, swell, bloom, as in @Ref{blàth.1}, q.v.
<bladhm>, a boast, etc.; see @Ref{blaomadh}.
<blad-shronach>, @Ref<blad-spàgach>, flat-nosed, flat-footed; {blad-} is from
  Eng. @Eng{flat}.
<blaisbheum>, blasphemy; from Lat. {blasphemia}, Eng. @Eng{blasphemy}.
<blanndaidh>, rotten, stale; from Norse {blanda}, whey "blend".
<blanndar>, flattery, dissimulation, so Ir.; from Lat. {blandiri},
  Sc. {blander}, Eng. @Eng{blandish}.
†<blaodh>, a shout, noise, Ir. @Ir{blaodh}, M.Ir. @MIr{blaeded}, W. @W{bloedd}.
  Hence @Ref<blaodhag>, noisy girl, @Ref<boaghan>, calf's cry, etc.
<blaomadh>, loud talking, Ir. @Ir{blaodhmanach}, noisy person; from
  *{blaid-s-men}; see @Ref{blaodh}.
†<blaosg>, a shell, Ir. @Ir{blaosc}, M.Ir. @MIr{blaesc}, testa, W. @W{blisg}; see
  @Ref{plaosg}.
<blàr.1>, a field, battle, peat-moss; from @Ref{blàr.2}, spotted, the idea being
  a "spot".  See @Ref{blàr.2}.
<blàr.2>, having a white face, or white spot on the face (of an animal);
  {blāro-s}, root {blā}, from I.E. {bhale}, shine, {bhā}; Gr. @Gr{φαλαρός}
  (second {α} long), having a white patch (on the head, as on a
  dog's head).  Cf. Du. {blaar}, a white spot on the forehead
  (Whence Fr. {blaireau}, badger), M.Du. {blaer}, bald.  See
  for roots @Ref{bealltuinn}, @Ref{bàn}.  Welsh has {blawr}, grey, iron-grey,
  which seems allied.  This word enters largely into Pictish
  topography.  It is not so used in Argyle (M`K.) nor in Ireland.
<blas>, taste, Ir. @Ir{blas}, O.Ir. @OIr{mlas}, W. @W{blâs}, Br. @Br{blas}, *{mlasto-}; Czech
  {mlasti}, lick, be sweet-toothed, Russ. {молсатй}, suck (Bezzenberger).
  Ultimately the root seems to be {mel}, as in {meli-},
  honey, G. {mil}, and even @Ref{meil}, grind.  Hence Fr. {blasé}?
<blas-bheumnaich>, blaspheme (Hend.).  See @Ref<blaisbheum>.
<blàth.1>, bloom, blossom, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{blàth}, W. @W{blawd}, {blodau}, Corn.
  @Corn{blodon}, M.Br. @MBr{bleuzenn}, *{blâto-n}; I.E. root {blela}: {bhlo},
  blossom forth; Lat. {flōs}, flower; Eng. @Eng{bloom}, etc.
--page 40
<blàth.2>, warm, kind, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bláith}, soft, smooth, {mláith}, *{mlâti};
  root {mela}, {mlâ}, to grind.  The original idea is "ground soft".
  Cf. W. @W{blawd}, meal.
<blàthach>, buttermilk, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{bláthach}; {blā-tac-}, root {mel}, {mlâ},
  as in @Ref{blàth.2}.  The idea is "pounded, soured".  Cf. @Ref{braich},
  from {mrac-}, "soured", and Eng. @Eng{malt}, "soured", from {melt}.
  Hence Sc. {bladach}.
<bleachdair>, a soothing, flattering fellow, Ir. @Ir{bleachdaire}, flatterer,
  cow-milker; a metaphoric use of @Ref{blàthach}, "cow-milker",
  from @Ref{bliochd}, milk, q.v.
<bleagh>, milk (vb.), Ir. @Ir{blighim}; see @Ref{bleoghainn}.
<bleaghan>, a dibble for digging up shell-fish, a worthless tool;
<bleid>, impertinence, solicitation, Ir. @Ir{bleid}, cajolery, impertinence.
  This seems another word formed on the word @Ref{bladair}, @Ref{blad},
  just like Eng. @Eng{blatant}, {blate} (talk, prate).
<bleideir>, coward; from Norse {bleyði}, cowardice, and Sc. {blate}(?).
<bleith>, grind, Ir. @Ir{bleithim}, E.Ir. @EIr{bleith}, inf. to O.Ir. @OIr{melim}, I
  grind, W. @W{malu}, Br. @Br{malaff}; root {mel}, grind, Lat. {molo}, Eng.
  @Ref{meal}, etc.
<bleoghainn>, milking, E.Ir. @EIr{blegon}, inf. to {bligim}, {mligim}; Lat.
  {mulgeo}; Gr. @Gr{ἀ-μέλγω}; Eng. @Eng{milk}; Lit. {mélżu}.
<bliadhna>, year, Ir. @Ir{bliadhain}, O.Ir. @OIr{bliadain}, W. @W{blydd}, {blwyddyn},
  Br. @Br{bloaz}, {blizen}, *{bleidni-}, *{bleido-}; I.E. {ℊhleidh}, whence
  Eng. @Eng{glide}: "labuntur anni" (Stokes).  It is doubtful if
  I.E. {ℊh} becomes Celtic {b}.
<blialum>, jargon; from the Sc. {blellum}.
<blian.1>, the flank, groin, Ir. @Ir{bléin}, E.Ir. @EIr{blén}, O.Ir. @OIr{melen}, for {mleen},
  *{mlakno-}; Gr. @Gr{μαλακός}, soft (Strachan, Stokes).  The meaning,
  if not the phonetics, is not quite satisfactory.
<blian.2>, lean, insipid, @Ref<blianach>, lean flesh; cf. W. @W{blin}, tired, O.Br.
  {blinion}, inertes.  These may be referred to *{ℊleghno-}, Lit.
  {gleżnus}, tender, weak, Gr. @Gr{βληχρός}, languid.  See, however,
  the derivation suggested for @Ref{blian.1}, above.  For the Brittonic
  words, Stokes has suggested the stem {blêno-}; Skr. {glána},
  tired.
<bligh>, milk; see @Ref{bleagh}.
<bliochan>, yellow marsh, asphodel, Ir. @Ir{bliochan}; from *{blioch} =
  *{melgos-}, milk.  For phonetics, cf. @Ref{teach}, from {tegos-}.
<bliochd>, milk, Ir. @Ir{bleachd}, E.Ir. @EIr{blicht}, W. @W{blith}, *{mḷctu-}, root
  {melg}, milk.  See @Ref{bleoghainn}.
<blìonadh>, basking (Islands): "softening"?  See @Ref{blian.2}.
<bliosan>, artichoke (Sh., O'B., O'R.), Ir. @Ir{bliosán}: *{blig-s-ān-}, "milk-curdler"?
  Its florets were used for curdling.
--page 41
<blob>, blubber-lipped (Sh.); from Eng. @Eng{blub}, puffed, protruding,
  {blubber}, etc.
<blocan>, a little block, @Ref<blog>, block (Dialectic), Ir. @Ir{bloc}, {blocán}; from
  Eng. @Eng{block}.
<bloigh>, fragment, half, Ir. @Ir{blogh}, {blógh}, fragment, E.Ir. @EIr{blog}, pre-Celtic
  {bhlog}; Eng. @Eng{block}, further away Eng. @Eng{balk}, Gr.
  @Gr{φάλαγξ}.  Stokes refers it to the root of Eng. @Eng{pluck}.  (St.
  now Eng. @Eng{blough}, Ger. {pflug}).
<bloin'gein>, any plant with crisped leaves, Ir. @Ir{bloinigain} (O'R.);
  G. and Ir. @Ref<bloinigean gàrraidh> is "spinage".  Cameron
  refers the word to @Ref{blonag}, fat.
<blomas>, ostentation (Sh.). Ir. @Ir{blomas}; see @Ref{bladhm}.  Ir. @Ir{blamaire},
  means "boaster".
<blonag>, fat, Ir. @Ir{blonóg}, {blainic}, {blunag}, M.Ir. @MIr{blonac}, W. @W{bloneg}, Br.
  {blonek}, *{blon-}, *{blen-}, root {bhle}, {bhel}, swell; a very prolific
  root.  Rhys says W. is borrowed. [@ExtRef{R.C.;17;102}]
†<blosg>, sound a horn, Ir. @Ir{blosgaidhim}, resound, sound a horn,
  M.Ir. @MIr{blosc}, voice; W. @W{bloedd}, a shout, from *{blogðo-}, for
  {bloðgo-}; cf. @Ref{mèag}, W. @W{maidd}. [@ExtRef{Zeit;34;502}.]  Cf. Gr. @Gr{φλοῖσβος},
  din (= @Gr{φλοσ-γος}), Lit. {blázgu}, roar.
<bó>, a cow, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bó}, W. @W{buw}, O.Br. @OBr{bou-}, *{bov-s}; I.E. {ℊôus},
  whence Lat. {bos}, Gr. @Gr{βοῦς}, Eng. @Eng{cow}, Skr. {go}.
<boban.1>, @Ref<bobug>, a term of affection for a boy; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{boban}, calf,
  {bóban}, from @Ref{bó}.  Eng. @Eng{babe}, earlier, {baban}, of uncertain origin,
  may be compared.
<boban.2>, a bobbin; from the Eng. @Eng{bobbin}
<boc>, a buck, Ir. @Ir{boc}, he-goat, O.Ir. @OIr{bocc}, W. @W{bwch}, Corn. @Corn{boch}, Br.
  {bouc'h}, *{bukko-s}; Skr. {bukka}, goat.  These may be analysed
  into {bug-ko-}, root {bug}, Zend. {bûza}, buck, Arm. {buc}, lamb, Eng.
  {buck}, Ger. {bock}.
<bòc>, swell, Ir. @Ir{bócaim}; cf. W. @W{boch}, cheek, from Lat. {bucca}, puffed
  cheek (Eng. {debouch}, {rebuke}).
<bòcan>, hobgoblin, Ir. @Ir{bocán}, E.Ir. @EIr{boccánach}.  With these are
  connected W. @W{bwg} ({bwci}, Corn. @Corn{bucca}, borrowed from M.E.?),
  Eng. @Eng{bug}, {bugbear}, {bogie}; the relationship is not clear (Murray).
  For Gadelic a stem {bukko-}, from {bug-ko-}, would do, allied
  possibly to Norse {púki}, a Puck, Ag.S. {puca}, larbula. {boc-sithe},
  apparition, ghost (Perth: Wh.).
<bochail>, proud, nimble; cf. the interjection †@Ref<boch>, Ir. @Ir{boch},
  heyday! "O festum diem".
<bochuin>, swelling, the sea (Carm.), {boch-thonn} (H.S.D.):
--page 42
<bochd>, poor, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bocht}; *{bog-to-}, a participle from the vb.
  (Irish) {bongaim}, break, reap, Celtic {bongô}, break; Skr. {bhanj},
  break, Lit. {banga}, breaker (wave).  See @Ref{buain}.
<bocsa>, a box, so Ir., pronounced in Ir. @Ir{bosca} also, W. @W{bocys}; from
  Eng. @Eng{box}.  Hence @Ref<bocsaid>, a thump, Eng. @Eng{box}.
<bodach>, an old man, a carle, Ir. @Ir{bodach}, a rustic, carle; *{bodd-aco-},
  "pēnitus", from @Ref<bod>, mentula, M.G. {bod} (D.of Lismore
  passim), M.Ir. @MIr{bod}, @Ref{bot}, *{boddo-}, *{bozdo-}; Gr. @Gr{πόσθη}, mentula.
  Stokes suggests the alternative form {butto-s}, Gr. @Gr{βύττος},
  vulva, but the G. {d} is against this.  He also suggests that
  {bodach} is formed on the O.Fr. {botte}, a clod.
<bodha>, a rock over which waves break; from Norse {boði}, a
  breaker, over sunken rocks especially.
<bòdhag>, a sea-lark.
<bodhaig>, body, corpus; from the Sc. {bouk}, body, trunk, Norse
  {búkr}, trunk, Ger. {bauch}, belly.  The G. word has been compared
  by Fick with Eng. @Eng{body}, Ag.S. {bodig}, and Murray says it is
  thence derived, but the {d} would scarcely disappear and leave
  the soft {g} ending now so hard.
<bòdhan>, ham, breech, breast: *{boud-āno}, *{boud}, {bhud-}; cf. Eng.
  {butt}, {buttock}.
<bodhar>, deaf, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bodar}, W. @W{byddar}, Corn. @Corn{bodhar}, Br.
  {bouzar}; Skr. {badhirá}.
<bodhbh>, @Ref<bobh>, a fright (Perthshire), E.Ir. @EIr{bodba}, dangerous,
  *{bodv-io-s}; from {bodvo-} in @Ref{baobh}, q.v.
<bodht>, swampy ground:
<bog>, soft, Ir. @Ir{bog}, O.Ir. @OIr{bocc}, Br. @Br{bouk}, O.Br. @OBr{buc}, putris; *{boggo-},
  *{bug-go-}; I.E. {bhuℊ}, bend, Skr. {bhugna}, bent, Got. {biugan},
  Eng. @Eng{bow}, from Ag.S. {boga}.
<bogha>, a bow, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{boga}; from Ag.S. {boga}, Eng. @Eng{bow}.
  For root, see under @Ref{bog}.
<bògus>, a timber moth, bug; from Eng. @Eng{bug}, Sc. {bōg}.
<boicineach>, small-pox; root in @Ref{bucaid}, q.v.
<boicionn>, a goat skin, skin; *{boc-cionn}, "buck-skin"; the word
  †@Ref<cionn> is in O.Ir. @OIr{cenni}, scamae, W. @W{cen}, skin, Corn. @Corn{cennen},
  Br. @Br{kenn-}, pellis; Eng. @Eng{skinn}, Norse {skinn}.  {-cionn}, skin,
  Norse {hinna}, film (Leiden) @ExtRef{I.F.;5A;127}.
<bóid>, vow, Ir. @Ir{móid}, M.Ir. @MIr{móit}, *{monti-}, root {mon}, {men}, think.
  A borrowing from, or leaning on Lat. {vōtum} seems possible
  in view of the Gaelic form.  M.Ir. @MIr{in uóit}; from Lat. {vôtum},
  as is also @Ref{móid} (Stokes).
<bòidheach>, pretty; for {buaidheach}, "having virtues", from @Ref{buaidh},
  q.v.
<bòidheam>, flattery (H.S.D.):
<bòigear>, puffin, ducker; also @Ref{budhaigir}, q.v.
--page 43
<boil>, @Ref<boile>, madness, Ir. @Ir{buile}, E.Ir. @EIr{baile}:
<bòilich>, tall talk, boasting; cf. Eng. @Eng{bawl}, cry like cows (@Ref{bó}).
<boillsg>, gleam; *{bolg-s-cio-}; Lat. {fulgeo}, shine, Eng. @Eng{effulgent}, Lit.
  {blizgù}, glance, shine, Eng. @Eng{blink}, I.E. {bhleg}, *{fulgeo}.
<boineid>, a bonnet, Ir. @Ir{boineud}; from Eng. @Eng{bonnet}.
<boinne>, a drop, Ir. @Ir{bain} (d.pl {bainnibh}), O.Ir. @OIr{banne}, Corn., Br.
  {banne}; Celt. {bannjâ} (Stokes.  See @Ref{bainne}.  Hence @Ref<boinneanta>,
  healthy, well-built.
<boirche>, a buffalo (Sh., Lh.), so Ir.; perhaps allied to Lat. {ferus},
  Eng. @Eng{bear}.
<boireal>, a small auger (M`F.); founded on Eng. @Eng{bore}.
<boiriche>, rising ground, bank (M`D.); same root as Ger. {berg},
  mountain, Eng. ice-{berg}.
<boirionn>, female, feminine, Ir. @Ir{bainionn}, {boinionn}; *{bani-}, from
  the word @Ref{bean.1}, {ban}, q.v.  Hence @Ref<biorionnach>, a female, which
  is masc. in gender, having been originally neuter.  Cf.
  @Ref{doirionn} for @Ref{doinionn} (Arg.).
<bois>, the palm; see @Ref{bas}.
<boiseag>, slap in the face, palmful, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{boiseóg}, buffet.
<boiseid>, a belt, budget; from the English
<boisg>, gleam; @Ref{boillsg}.
<boiteadh>, boiled food for horses (H.S.D.), Eng. @Eng{bait}:
<boiteag>, a maggot; see @Ref{botus}.
<boitean>, a bundle of hay or straw; for {boiteal}, from Sc. {buttle},
  Eng. @Eng{bottle}, bundle of hay, from O.Fr. {botte}.
<boitidh>, the call to pig, @Ref<boit>, a taste for (Dialectic):
<bòl>, a bowl; from the English.
<boladh>, smell, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bolad}, *{bulato-}; Lit. {bu'ls}, dusty air
  (Bezzenberger).  Stokes has compared Lit. {bulis}, buttock,
  Skr. {buli}, vulva.
<bolanta>, excellent; root {bol}, as in @Ref{adhbhal}, q.v.
<bolla>, a boll; from Sc., Eng. @Eng{boll}.  Hence also <bolla>, a buoy.
<bolt>, a welt, Ir. @Ir{balta}, welt, border; from the Lat. {balteus}, girdle,
  Eng. @Eng{belt}.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{welt}, W. @W{gwald}.
<boma>, a bomb; from the English.
<bonn.1>, foundation, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bond}; Lat. {fundus}; Skr. {budhná};
  Eng. @Eng{bottom}.
<bonn.2>, a coin, so Ir.; possibly from Lat. {pondo}.
<bonnach>, cake, bannock, Ir. @Ir{boinneóg}, oaten cake.  This word, like
  the Sc., {bannock}, appears to be founded on Lat. {pānicum},
  {pānis}, bread.
<bonnanach>, a strapping fellow (Mrs M`Ph.), {bonnanaich}, active
  young men (Skye):
<borb>, fierce, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{borp}; allied to, or, more probably,
  borrowed from, Lat. {barbarus}.
--page 44
<borbhan>, a purling sound; *{borvo-}, a stem identical with {bervo-},
  seethe, Fr. {Bourbon}, Lat. {fervo}, etc.  Hence @Ref<borbhanach>,
  base, deep.
<bòrc>, sprout, swell; see @Ref{bàrc.2}.
<bòrc-lunn>, swell-wave (Hend.):
<bòrd>, a table, Ir., M.Ir., {bord}, W. @W{bwrdd}; from Ag.S., Norse
  {bord}.
<bòrlanachd>, @Ref<mòrlanachd>, compulsory labour for the proprietor;
  from Eng. @Eng{bordland}, as under @Ref{bòrlum.1}.  Hence M`Morland.
  The @Ref{cairiste}, done for proprietor (M`K. and Carm.).
<bòrlum.1>, a strip of arable land (Hebridees); a frequent place namel
  from M.Eng. {bordland}, mensal land, especially the royal
  castle lands in the Highlands.
<bòrlum.2>, a sudden flux or vomiting, a flux; for {bòrc-lum}; see @Ref{bòrc}.
†<borr>, knob, pride, greatness, great, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{borr}, *{borso-},
  {bhorso-}; Lat. {fastus} (for {farstus}), pride; O.H.G. {parrunga},
  superbia; allied to @Ref{bàrr}, q.v.  Hence @Ref<borrach>, a haughty
  man, a protruding bank, a mountain grass.
<bòsd>, a boast, Ir. @Ir{bóst} (O'R.), W., Corn. @Corn@W{bost}; all from Eng. @Eng{boast},
  itself of unknown origin.
<bòsdan>, a little box, Br. @Br{bouist}; the G. is from early Sc. {boyst},
  M.Eng. {boiste}, from O.Fr. {boiste}, Med.Lat. {buxida} ({bossida}),
  which is the Gr. @Gr{πύξιδα}.  Hence also Eng. @Eng{box}, G. {bosca}.
<bosgaire>, applause (Sh.); @Ref{bas}+@Ref{gaire}, q.v. "palm-noise".
<bot>, a mound, river bank; cf. {bught}, {botach}, a reedy bog.
<bòt>, a boot; from M.E. {bote}, Eng. @Eng{boot}.  Also @Ref<bòtuinn>, from Sc.
  {booting}, Fr. {bottine}, half-boot.
<botaidh>, a wooden vessel (size, half anker); formed from M.E.
  {butte}, Eng. @Eng{butt}, Fr. {botte}.
<both.1>, perturbation, a plash; see @Ref{bodhbh}.
<both.2>, @Ref<bothan>, a hut, bothie, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{bothán}, {both}, W. @W{bod},
  residence, Corn. @Corn{bod}, {bos}, *{buto-}; Lit. {bùtas}, house; Eng. @Eng{booth},
  Norse {búð}, Ger. {bude}; root {bhu}, be.  Hence Eng. @Eng{bothie}.
<bothar>, a lane, street (A.M`D.), Ir. @Ir{bothar} (Con.), {bóthar}, E.Ir.
  {bóthar}, *{bâtro-}, *{bâtro-}, root {bā}, go; Gr. @Gr{ἒβην}, went, @Gr{βαíνυ},
  go; Skr. {gâ}, go; Eng. @Eng{path}.
<botrumaid>, a slattern, (M`F.); see @Ref{butrais}.
<botul>, bottle, Ir. @Ir{buideul}, W. @W{potel}; from Eng. @Eng{bottle}.
<botunn> (Lewis), deep water pool (in moors); Norse {botn}.
<botus>, a belly-worm; from M.E. {bottes}, pl. of @Ref{bot}, {bott}, of like
  meaning; Sc. {batts}.  Origin unknown (Murray).
<brà>, @Ref<bràth>, a quern, Ir. @Ir{bró}, g. {brón}, E.Ir. @EIr{bró}, g. {broon}, mill-stone,
  *{brevon-}, *{bravon-}; Skr. {grâvan-}; Lit. {gìrnos}; Eng. @Eng{quern}.
<brabhd-chasach>, bow-legged.
--page 45
<brabhdadh>, bravado, idle talk, @Ref<brabhtalachd>, haughtiness
  (A.M`D.); from Eng. @Eng{bravado}?
<bràc>, curve as of waves before breaking, a bellow, branch or deer-horn
  (Carm.), reindeer (Carm.):
<bracach>, grayish, @Ref<braclach>, brake: see words in {broc-ach}, {-lach}.
<brachag>, pustule; from @Ref<brach>, rot (vb.); see @Ref{braich}, malt.
  Also @Ref<brachan>, putrefaction.
<bràchd>, putrescence, fat, rich.
<bradach>, thievish, @Ref<braid>, theft, Ir. @Ir{bradach}, thievish, roguish,
  E.Ir. @EIr{broit}, g. {braite}: *{mraddo-}, allied to @Ref{brath}, betray?
  Scarcely braom {bṛ-ont-}, root {bher}, carry, Lat. {fur}, etc.
<bradan.1>, salmon, Ir. @Ir{bradán}, E.Ir. @EIr{bratan}.  Cf. Lit. {bradà}, water,
  Ch.Sl. {brożdą}, wade through.
<bradan.2>, a ridgy tumour on the surface of the body (H.S.D.);
  metaphorically from @Ref{bradan.1}?
<bradhadair>, a blazing fire, kindling of a fire (Hebrides).  Possibly
  {braghadair}, from @Ref{bragh}, q.v.  Cf. @Ref<braghadaich>, crackling.
<brag> (Lewis), a sudden creeking noise, Norse {brak}.
<bragaireachd>, vain boasting, Ir. @Ir{bragáireachd}, from @Ref{bragaire},
  boaster; from the Eng. @Eng{brag}.
<bragh>, an explosion, peal, O.Ir. @OIr{braigim}, pedo; Lat. {fragor}, crash,
  {fragare}, Eng. @Eng{fragrant}.  See @Ref{bram}.
<bràghad>, neck, throat, Ir. @Ir{bráighid}, O.Ir. @OIr{bráge}, g. {brágat}, W.
  {breuant}, O.Br. @OBr{brehant}, *{brâgṇt-}; Eng. @Eng{craw}, Ger. {kragen},
  collar, M.H.G. {krage}, neck; Gr. @Gr{βρόγχος}, windpipe, Eng.
  {bronchitis}.  Bezzenberger (Stokes' Dict.), refers it ot the root
  of Norse {barki}, weazand, Gr. @Gr{φάρυγξ}, Eng. @Eng{pharynx}.  {bràghad}
  is really the gen. of @Ref{bràighe}.
<bragsaidh>, braxy; from Sc., Eng. @Eng{braxy}.
<braich>, malt, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{mraich}, W., Corn. @Corn{brag}, Br. @Br{bragezi},
  germinate, Gaul. {brace} (Plin.), genus farris: *{mraki}; Lit.
  {mèrkti}, macerate, {márka}, flax-hole for steeping; Lat. {marcere},
  fade, {marcidus}, decayed, rotten.  From W. @W{bragod}, comes
  Eng. @Eng{bragget}.
<braid>, theft; see @Ref{bradach}.
<bràid>, horse-collar; see @Ref{bràighdeach}.
<bràighde>, captives, pledges, Ir. @Ir{bráighe}, pl. {bráighde}, E.Ir. @EIr{braga},
  g. {bragat}, hostage, prisoner, {braig}, a chain; Gr. @Gr{γρόχος},
  noose; Eng. @Eng{crank}, Ger. {kringel}; I.E. {ℊregh}, possibly allied
  to I.E. {ℊrēgh}, neck, as in {brághad}.  Hence @Ref<braighdeanas>,
  captivity, also dialectic @Ref<braigh>, hostage, pledge.
<bràighdeach>, horse-collar, M.Ir. @MIr{braigdech}, older {bráigtech}; from
  @Ref{bràghad}.  Also @Ref<bràid>.
--page 46
<bràighe>, upper part (of places): this is the nom. case of @Ref{bràghad},
  which also appears in place names, as {Bra'id-Albainn}, Braidalbane.
<braile.1>, a heavy rain (Sh.):
<braile.2>, @Ref<braighlish>, a rattling noise (Perth).  Sc. {bruilze}, Fr.
  {brouille}.  See @Ref<braodhlach>.
<brailis>, wort of ale, Ir. @Ir{braithlis}, M.Ir. @MIr{braichlis}, from @Ref{braich}.
<braim>, @Ref<bram>, crepitus ventris, Ir. @Ir{broim}, O.Ir. @OIr{braigim}, pedo, W.,
  Corn., Br. @Br@Corn@W{bram}, *{bragsmen}, root {brag}, I.E. {bhrag}; Lat.
  {fragor}, crash, {fragrare}, etc.  Hence @Ref<bramaire>, a noisy fellow.
<braisleach>, full-formed, bulky man, M.Ir. @MIr{bras}, great, W., Corn.,
  Br. @Br@Corn@W{bras}, grossus, *{brasso-}; Lat. {grossus}, Fr. {gros}, bulky.
<bràist>, a brooch; from the Eng.
<braithlìn>, linen sheet, so Ir.: *{brath+lìn}; but @Ref{brath}?  M`E.
  suggests {plài-linn}.
<braman>, misadventure, the Devil; also dialectic @Ref<broman>.  M.Ir.
  {bromán} means a "boor", {brománach}, impertinent.  The root
  seems to be {breg}, @Ref{brog}, @Ref{brag} of @Ref{breun}, @Ref{braim}.
<bramasag>, a clott-burr, the prickly head of a thistle (H.S.D.):
†<bran.1>, a raven, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bran}, W. @W{brân}, crow, Br. @Br{bran}, crow;
  *{branâ}, for {gvranâ}, with which cf. O.Slav. {gavranŭ}, raven,
  but not {vrana} (do.), as is usually done.  The further root is
  {ℊra}, {ℊera}, cry, whence Eng. @Eng{crane}, Gr. @Gr{γέρανος}, crane, W. and
  Corn. @Corn@W{garan}.  Used much in personal and river names.
<bran.2>, bran, Ir., W. @W{bran}, Br. @Br{brenn}; G., Ir., and W. are from Eng.
  {bran}, from O.Fr. {bren}, {bran}, whence Br.
<brang> a slip of wood in the head-stall of a horse's halter, resting
  on the jaw; horse's collar; @Ref<brangas>, a pillory; from the Sc.
  {branks}, a head pillory (for tongue and mouth), a bridle with
  two wooden side pieces, {brank}, to bridle; allied to Ger.
  {pranger}, pillory, Du. {prang}, fetter.
<branndaidh>, brandy; from Eng. @Eng{brandy}, that is "brand or burnt
  wine".
<branndair>, a gridiron; from Sc. {brander}, from {brand}, {burn}, etc.
<braodag>, a huff (Hend.), also (Perth):
<braodhlach>, brawling, @Ref<braoileadh>, loud noise, Ir. @Ir{braóilleadh},
  rattling; a borrowed word, seemingly from Sc., Eng. @Eng{brawl},
  confused with Sc. {brulye}, Eng. @Eng{broil}.
<braoileag>, a whortleberry, Ir. @Ir{broileóg}, {breileóg}.  Sc. {brawlins},
  {brylocks}, comes from the Gaelic.
<braoisg>, a grin, Ir. @Ir{braos}:
<braolaid>, raving, dreaming; from @Ref{breathal}?
<braon>, a drop, rain, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{broen}; cf. Eng. @Eng{brine}.  The
  attempt to connect it with Gr. @Gr{βρέχω}, or with Lat. {rigare},
--page 47
  Eng. @Eng{rain}, is unsatisfactory.  Stokes derives it from root
  {ver} (see @Ref{fearthuinn}), *{vroen}, but unlikely.
<braonan>, @Ref<praonan>, an earth-nut, bunium flexuosum.  Perhaps
  from @Ref{braon}, a drop - "a bead, nut".
<bras>, @Ref<brais>, active, rash, Ir. @Ir{bras}, E.Ir. @EIr{bras}, W. @W{brys}, haste:
  *{bṛsto-}, I.E. {ℊredh-}, as in @Ref{greas}, q.v.?  See also @Ref{brisg.2}, active.
<brasailt> a panegyric (M`A.); E.Ir. @EIr{bras-scélach}, panegyrical;
  from O.Ir. @OIr{bras}, great, W. and Br. @Br{bras}; cf. Lat. {grossus},
  Eng. @Eng{gross}.  See @Ref{braisleach}.
<brat>, a mantle, Ir. @Ir{brat}, O.Ir. @OIr{bratt}, W. @W{brethyn}, woolen cloth, Br.
  {broz}, petticoat, *{bratto-}, *{brat-to-}.  For root {brat}, {brant}, see
  @Ref{bréid}.  Ag.S. {bratt}, pallium, is borrowed from the Celtic.
  Hence @Ref<bratach>, flag.
<bratag>, the furry or grass caterpillar, Ir. @Ir{bratóg}, "the mantled
  one", from @Ref{brat}.  Cf. {caterpillar} = "downy cat", by derivation.
<brath>, information, betrayal, Ir. @Ir{brath}, E.Ir. @EIr{brath}, treason, and
  {mrath} also, W. @W{brad}, treachery, Corn. @Corn{bras}, Br. @Br{barat}, O.Br.
  {brat}, *{mrato-}; Gr. @Gr{ἁμαρτάνω}(@Gr{-μαρτ-}), sin, miss, @Gr{ἒμβροτον} (past
  tense).  Cf. @Ref{mearachd}.  M.Ir. @MIr{mairned}, treachery.
<bràth>, judgement, @Ref<gu bràth>, for ever (pron. {gu bràch}) "till Judgment",
  so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bráth}, judgment, W. @W{brawd}, M.Br. @MBr{breut},
  Gaul. {bratu-}, *{brâtu-}; *{brâ}, *{bera}, judge, decide, from I.E.
  {bher}, in the sense of "say", as in @Ref{abair}.  The Ir. @Ir{barn}, judge,
  and W. @W{barn}, judgment, are hence, and may be compared
  to Gr. @Gr{φρήν}, @Gr{φρήνες}, soul, {phrenology}.  Hence also @Ref<breath.2>, or
  @Ref<breith> (*{bṛt-}), q.v.  The sense "conflagration" given in the
  Dict. is due to "Druidic" theorisings, and is imaginary.
<bràthair>, brother, Ir. @Ir{bráthair}, O.Ir. @OIr{bráthir}, W. @W{brawd}, pl. {brodyr},
  Corn. @Corn{broder}, pl. {bredereth}, Br. @Br{breur}, {breuzr}, pl. {breudeur},
  *{brâtêr}; Lat. {frâter}; Eng. @Eng{brother}; Skr. {bhrā́ta}; etc.
<breab>, a kick, Ir. @Ir{preab}, M.Ir. @MIr{prebach}, kicking; perhaps from the
  root form of @Ref{breaban}.
<breaban>, a patch of leather, Ir. @Ir{preabán}, parcel, piece, patch;
  from, or allied to, O.Fr. {bribe}, a piece of bread, alms, Sp.
  {briba}, alms; also O.Fr. {bribeur}, mendicant, {briberesse}, female
  vagabondage and harloting; cf. Ir. @Ir{preabóg}, a wenching jade
  (O'B.).  Eng. @Eng{bribe} is from the French.
<breac>, speckled, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{brecc}, W. @W{brych}, Br. @Br{brec'h}, smallpox,
  *{mṛkko-s}, *{mṛg-ko-}, root {mṛℊ}; Lit. {márgas}, speckled, pied;
  Gr. @Gr{ἀμαρύσσω}, twinkle.  There is an O.Ir. @OIr{mrecht}, W. @W{brith},
  of like meaning and origin, viz. {mṛk-to}, from {mṛg-to-}.  Hence
  <breac>, smallpox, W. @W{brech}, and <breac>, trout, W. @W{brithyll}.
<breacan>, plaid, Ir. @Ir{breacán}, W. @W{brecan}, rug; from @Ref{breac}.  Rhys
  regards W. as borrowed from Irish.
<breac-shianain>, freckles:
--page 48
<breacag>, a pancake, W. @W{brechdan}, slice of bread and butter,
  {bṛg-ko-}, {bṛg}, as in @Ref{bairghin}, bread? (@ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;17;102}).  See
  @Ref{breachdan}.
<breachd>, seizing ={beireachd}.
<breachdan>, custard (Lh.), M.Ir. @MIr{brechtán}, a roll, W. @W{brithog}; from
  {mṛg-to-}, Ir. @Ir{brecht}, W. @W{brith}, motley, mixed.  See under @Ref{breac}.
<brèagh>, fine, Ir. @Ir{breágh}, M.Ir. @MIr{breagha} (O'Cl.), *{breigavo-s}, root
  {breig}, {brîg}, as in @Ref{brìgh}, q.v.?  Ir. @Ir{breagh} or {breaghda} = {Bregian},
  Tir Breg. (Ir.J. No.119).
†<breall>, knob, glens mentulæ, D.of Lismore {breyl}, Ir. @Ir{breall},
  {bṛs-lo-}, root {bers}, {bors}, as in G. {borr}, {bàrr}, Eng. @Eng{bristle}.  Hence
  @Ref{brilleanach}, lewd, q.v.  {breall}=@Ref{bod} (Glenmoriston).
<breaman>, tail of sheep or goat, podex; cf. Ir. @Ir{breim}, by-form of
  @Ref{braim}, q.v.
<breamas>, mischief, mishap, the Devil; an {e} vowel form of @Ref{braman}?
<breanan>, dunghill (Sh.); from @Ref{breun}, q.v.
<breath.1>, row, layer: *{bṛtâ}, a slice, root {bher} of {beàrn}.
<breath.2>, judgment, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{breth}, *{bṛtâ}, W. @W{bryd}, Gaul. vergo-{bretus},
  *{bṛto-s}.  For root, see @Ref{bràth}.  Spelt also @Ref{breith}.
<breathas>, frenzy (M`A.); see @Ref{breisleach}.
<bréid>, a kerchief, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bréit}, *{brenti-}, roots {brent}, @Ref{brat};
  Skr. {granth}, tie, knot, {grathnâti}; Ger. {kranz}, garland, Eng.
  {crants} (Rhys).  The Skr. being allied to Gr. @Gr{γρόνθος}, fist,
  seems against this derivation (Stokes), not to mention the
  difficulty of Gr. {θ} and Skr. {th} corresponding to Celtic {t}.
  Possibly from root {bhera}, cut, Gr. @Gr{φᾶρος}, cloth (Windisch).
  Cf. W. @W{brwyd}, braid.
<breisleach>, confusion, delirium, nightmare, Ir. @Ir{breisleach} (O'R.,
  Fol.), {breaghaslach} (Lh.) from {breith-}, *{bret}, *{bhre-t}; {bhre},
  mind, as in Gr. @Gr{φρέν}, mind?  Cf. E.Ir. @EIr{Breslech} Mór
  Murtheimme; {brislech}, "overthrow".
<breith>, bearing, birth, so Ir. and E.Ir., {bṛtí-s}; Skr. {bhṛti-}; Eng.
  {birth}; etc.: root {bher}, bear; see @Ref{beir}.
<breitheal>, confusion of mind; from {breith-}, as in @Ref{breisleach}.  Also
  @Ref<breathal> and @Ref<preathal>.
<breitheanas>, judgment, Ir. @Ir{breitheamhnus}, E.Ir. @EIr{britheamnas}; from
  {brithem}, a judge, stem {britheman}, to which is added the
  abstract termination {-as} (={astu-}).  From @Ref{britheamh}, q.v.
<breo>, @Ref<breoth>, rot, putrefy:
<breochaid>, any tender or fragile thing (M`A.); from @Ref{breo}.
<breòcladh>, clumsy patching, @Ref<breòclaid>, sickly person: {breódh}+
  {clad} (= {cail} of {buachail}).  See @Ref{breòite}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {breóite}
<breòite>, infirm, Ir. @Ir{breóite}, {breódhaim}, I enfeeble (Keat.), *{brivod-};
  cf. W. @W{briw}, break, *{brîvo-}, possibly allied to Lat. {frivolus}.
<breolaid>, dotage, delirium; cf. @Ref{breitheal}, etc.
--page 49
<breug>, @Ref<briag>, a lie, Ir. @Ir{breug}, {bréag}, O.Ir. @OIr{bréc}, {brenkâ}; Skr.
  {bhramça}, loss, deviation.
<breun>, putrid, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{brén}, W. @W{braen}, Br. @Br{brein}; *{bregno-},
  {bragno-}, foul, from root, {breg}, @Ref{brag}, of @Ref{braim}.  Strachan takes
  it from *{mrak-no-}; Lat. {marcidus}, rancid, as in @Ref{braich}, q.v.
<briagail>, prattling:
<briathar>, a word, so Ir. and O.Ir. *{brêtrâ} (O.Ir. is fem.; G. is
  mas., by analogy?), *{brê}, ablaut to {brâ-} of @Ref{bràth}, q.v.  Bezzenberger
  would refer it to O.H.G. {chrâjan}, Eng. @Eng{crow}.
<brìb>, a bribe, Ir. @Ir{bríb}; from the Eng.
<bricein->, a prefix to certain animal names; from @Ref{breac}.
†<brìdeach>, a dwarf (Arm., Sh.), Ir. @Ir{brideach} (Lh., O'B.).  See
  @Ref{brìdeag}, little woman.  Shaw also gives it the meaning of
  "bride", which is due to Eng. influences.
<brìdeag>, a little woman, Ir. @Ir{brídeag}, a figure of St. Bridget made
  on the Saint's eve by maidens for divination purposes.  See
  {Brighid} in the list of Proper Names.  Shaw gives @Ref<bridag>,
  part of the jaw, which H.S.D. reproduces as <brìdeag>.
<brìdeun>, a little bird, sea-piet (M`A. for latter meaning): seemingly
  formed on the analogy of @Ref{brìdeag} and @Ref{brìdeach}.
<brìg>, a heap (H.S.D., M`A.): "brìg mhòine", a pile of peats; cf.
  Norse {brík}, square tablet, piece, Eng. @Eng{brick}.
<brìgh>, pith, pwer, Ir. @Ir{brígh}, O.Ir. @OIr{bríg}, W. @W{bri}, dignity, rank,
  Corn. @Corn{bry}, Br. @Br{bri}, respect, *{brîga}, *{brîgo-}; Gr. @Gr{βρῖ}=@Gr{βριαρός},
  strong, mighty, @Gr{βρíμη} (@Ref{i} long), strength, anger; Skr. {jri},
  overpower, {jrayas}, extent; an I.E. {ℊri-}, {ℊrī-}, {ℊrei-}.  Bezzenberger
  suggests Ger. {krieg}, war, striving: *{ℊreigh}?  This may be from the root
  {brî} above.
<brilleanach>, lewd, @Ref<briollair>, @Ref<briollan>, from @Ref{breall}, q.v.
<brìm>, pickle (Arg.); from Eng. @Eng{brine}.
<brimin bodaich>, a shabby carle; for {breimein}, a side form of
  @Ref{braman}; root {breg}, @Ref{brag}?  But cf. Norse {brimill}, phoca
  fetida mas.
<brìobadh>, bribing; see @Ref{brìb}, which also has the spelling @Ref<brìob>.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {bríb}
<brìodal>, lovers' language, caressing, flattery; also @Ref<brionnda>,
  caressing, @Ref<brionnal>, flattery; possibly from {brionn}, a lie,
  dream (Ir.), as in {brionglaid}, q.v.  M.Ir. @MIr{brinneal} means a
  beautiful young maid or a matron.  Cf. {briagadh}.  Arran
  {brìd}, whisper.
<briog>, thrust, Ir. @Ir{priocam}; from the Eng. @Eng{prick}.
<briogach>, mean-spirited:
<brìoghas>, fervour of passion; cf. W. @W{brywus}, {bryw}, vigorous.
<briogais>, breeches, Ir. @Ir{brigis}; from the Eng. @Eng{breeks}, {breeches}.
--page 50
<briollag>, an illusion (Sh.); Ir. @Ir{brionn}, dream, reverie.  The G.
  seems for {brion-lag}.  See @Ref{brionglaìd}.
<brionglaìd>, a confusion, dream, Ir. @Ir{brionnglóid}, a dream; from
  {brionn}, a dream, a lie.  In the sense of "wrangling",
  {brionglaid} is purely a Scotch Gaelic word, from S., Eng.
  {brangle}, of like force.
<brionnach.1>, pretty (M`F.), fair (Sh.), glittering, Ir. @Ir{brinneall}, a
  beautiful young woman, a matron.
<brionnach.2>, brindled, striped; from the Eng. @Eng{brinded}, now {brindled}.
<brìos>, mockery (A.M`D.), half-intoxication (M`A.):
<briosaid>, a girdle (Arm.), from Eng. @Eng{brace}?
<briosg>, start, jerk, so Ir.; from @Ref{brisg.2}, active, q.v.
<briosgaid>, a biscuit, M.Ir. @MIr{brisca} (F.M.); founded on Eng. @Eng{biscuit},
  but by folk-etymology made to agree with @Ref{brisg.1}, brittle
  (Gaidoz).
<briosuirneach>, ludicrous; cf. @Ref{brìos}, mockery, etc.
<briot>, @Ref<briotal>, chit-chat, Ir. †{briot}, chatter, {briotach}, a stammerer:
  {bṛt-t-}, {bṛ-t}, root {bar}, {ber}, as in Lat. {barbarus}, Gr. @Gr{βάρβαρος},
  {berberízu}, I stammer.  The reference of {briot} to the name
  {Breatnaich} or Briotons as foreigners and stammerers is scarcely
  happy.
<bris>, break, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{brissim}, *{brestô}, I break, root {bres}, {bhres};
  O.H.G. {brestan}, Ag.S. {berstan}, Eng. @Eng{burst}, Fr. {briser},
  break.  Distantly allied to *{berso-s}, short, G. {beàrr}.  Brugmann
  has compared the Gaelic to Gr. @Gr{πέρθω}, destroy, from
  {bherdho-}, giving a Celtic stem {bṛd-to-}, and {bṛd-co-} for @Ref{brisg.1}.
<brisg.1>, brittle, Ir. @Ir{briosg}, E.Ir. @EIr{brisc}, Br. @Br{bresq}: *{bres-co-}; root {bres}
  of @Ref{bris} above.
<brisg.2>, lively, Ir. @Ir{brisc}, W. @W{brysg}; all from the Eng. @Eng{brisk}, of
  Scandinavian origin (Johansson, Zeit. xxx.).
<brisgein.1>, cartilage; from Norse {brjósk}, cartilage, @Ref{bris}, Sw. and
  Dan. {brusk}; Ger. {brausche}, a lump (from a bruise).
<brisgein.2>, @Ref<brislein>, white tansy; from @Ref{brisg.1}, brittle.
<britheamh>, a judge, Ir. @Ir{breitheamh}, O.Ir. @OIr{brithem}, g. {britheman};
  root {bṛt}, of @Ref{breath.2}, judgment, q.v.
<broc>, a badger, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr@Ir{brocc}, W., Corn., @Corn@W{broch}, Br. @Br{broc'h},
  *{brokko-s}: *{bork-ko-}, "grey one"; root {bherk}, {bhork}, bright,
  Gr. @Gr{φορκός}, grey, Lit. {berszti}, Eng. @Eng{bright}?  Thurneysen cfs.
  the Lat. {broccus}, having projecting teeth, whence Fr. {broche}
  (from Lat. *{brocca}, a spike, etc.), a spit, Eng. @Eng{broach}, {brooch};
  he thinks the badger was named {broccos} from his snout, and
  he instances the Fr. {brochet}, pike, as parallet by derivation
  and analogy.  If Gr. @Gr{βρύκω}, bite, is allied to Lat. {broccus}, the
  underlying idea of {broc} may rather be the "biter", "gripper".
--page 51
  Bezzenberger suggests Russ. {барсӯкў}, Turk. {porsuk}, Magyar
  {borz}; or *{brokko-s}, from *{bhrod-ko-s}, Skr. {bradhná}, dun.
<brocach>, greyish in the face, speckled, Ir. @Ir{brocach}, @Ref{broc}, W. @W{broc},
  grizzled, roan; from @Ref{broc}.
<brochan>, gruel, porridge, Ir. @Ir{brochán}, O.Ir. @OIr{brothchán}; {broth-chán},
  *{broti-}, cookery; root {bru}, I.E. {bhru}, whence Eng. @Eng{broth},
  Lat. {defrutum}, must.  See @Ref{bruith}.
<bròchlaid>, trash, farrago; root {bhreu}, {bhru}, as in @Ref{brochan}; {bhreu}
  varies with {bhrou}, G. {brò}.
<bròcladh>, spoiling, mangling; see @Ref{breòclaid}.
<brod.1>, a lid; from Sc. {brod}, side form of Eng. @Eng{board}.
<brod.2>, a goad, prickle, Ir. @Ir{brod}, E.Ir. @EIr{brott}, W. @W{brath}, Corn. @Corn{broz}, Br.
  @Br{brout}, *{broddos}, from {broz-do-}; O.H.G. {brort}, edge, Norse
  {broddr}, sting, Eng. @Eng{brod}, {brad}, Ag.S. {brord}, sting.
<brod.3>, the choice of anything; from @Ref{brod.2}, in the sense of
  "excess".  Cf. @Ref{corr}.
<bròd.1>, pride, @Ref<bròdail>, proud, Ir. @Ir{bród}, etc.  In Arran (Sc.) we find
  @Ref<pròtail>, which is a step nearer the origin.  From the Eng.
  {proud}.
<bròd.2>, a crowd, brood, @Ref<bròdach>, in crowds; from the Eng. @Eng{brood}?
†<brodan>, mastiff, E.Ir. @EIr{brotchu}, W. @W{brathgi}; from {brod}, "good".
---gjk (1.14) moved entry. originally located between <bròd.1> and <bròd.2>.
---gjk (1.14) @Ref{brod} doesn't have a sense that means "good"
<bròg>, a shoe, Ir. @Ir{bróg}, M.Ir. @MIr{brócc}, E.Ir. @EIr{bróc}, pl. {bróca}, used in
  compounds for various nether garments; from Norse {brókr},
  Ag.S. {bróc}, pl. {bréc}, Eng. @Eng{breech}, {breeks} (Zimmer, Zeit. xxx.).
  See @Ref{briogais}.
<brog>, stimulate, an awl; from Sc. {brog}, {prog}.  Cf. W. @W{procio},
  thrust, poke, from M.E. {prokien}, stimulare.  Thurneysen
  takes Sc. and G. from Fr. {broche}, Lat. *{brocca} (see @Ref{broc}).
  Hence @Ref<brogail>, "active", "in good form".
<brogach>, a boy, young lad, from @Ref{brog}?
<broidneireachd>, embroidery, Ir. @Ir{broidineireachd}; from the Eng.
  {broider}, {embroidery}.
†<broigheal>, cormorant, Ir. @Ir{broighioll}:
<broighleadh>, bustle; from Sc. {brulye} (Eng. {broil}), Fr. {brouiller},
  Ital. {broglio}.  See @Ref{braodhlach}.
<broighleag>, whortleberry; see @Ref{braoileag}.
<broigileineach>, substantial; from {broigeil}, a by-form of @Ref{brogail};
  see @Ref{brogach}.
<broilein>, king's hood; pig's snout (Badenoch): root {bhru}, brow?
<broilleach>, a breast, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{brollach}: *{bron-lach}; for *{bron},
  see @Ref{bruinne}.
<broineag>, a rag, ill-clad female, @Ref<bronag>, a crum (Dialectic); possibly
  from the root of @Ref{bronn}, distribute.  Shaw spells it
  {broinneag}, M`F. as above.
--page 52
<broinn>, belly (Dialectic); the dat. of @Ref{brù} used dialectically as
  nom.; see @Ref{brù}.
<broit>, the bosom; properly the breast covering (H.S.D., for latter
  meaning); cf. G. @Ref{brot.2}, O.Ir. @OIr{broiténe}, palliolum.  The word
  appears to be from @Ref{brat}, mantle, with a leaning for meaning
  on @Ref{bruinne}, breast.
<brolaich>, incoherent talk (as in sleep), @Ref<brolasg>, garrulity, Ir.
  {brolasgach}, prattling; cf. W. @W{brawl}, {brol}, boasting, Eng.
  {brawl}, Du. {brallen}, boast.
<brolamas>, a mess (D.C.Mc.Ph.) (Glenmoriston); same root as
  @Ref{brollach}.
<broluinn>, @Ref<brothluinn>, boiling, "æstus", tide-boiling; from @Ref{broth.2},
  boiling, as in @Ref{brollach}, etc.
<brollach>, a mess; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{brothlach}, the Fénian cooking pit, from
  @Ref{broth.2}, as in @Ref{brochan}, q.v.
<bromach>, a colt, Ir. @Ir{bromach}: *{brusmo-}, *{brud-}, *{bru}, as in
  Eng. em-{bryo}?
<bròn>, grief, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{brón}, W. @W{brwyn}, smarting, sorrow, *{brugno-s};
  Gr. @Gr{βρύχω} ({υ} long), gnash the teeth; Lit. {gráużiu}, gnaw,
  Pol. {zgryzota}, sorrow.
†<bronn>, grant, distribute, M.G. {bronnagh} (1408 charter), Ir.
  {bronnaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{bronnaim}, {brondaim}, bestow, spend: *{brundo-},
  *{bhrud-no-}, I.E. root {bhrud}; Ag.S. {bryttian}, deal out, Norse
  {bryti}, a steward (cf. Gr. @Gr{ταμíας}, steward, "cutter"), {brytja},
  chop, Eng. @Eng{brittle}, Teut. {brut}, chop; perhaps Lat. {frustum},
  bit.
<brosdaich>, stir up, Ir. @Ir{brosduighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{brostugud}, inciting.  The
  word is from the root {bros-}, in {brosdo-} of @Ref{brod.2}, q.v., being here
  {bros-to-}, which become {brosso-}, and later reverts to {brost},
  {brosd}, or remains as in @Ref<brosnaich>.  Stokes says it is founded
  on Low Lat. {brosdus}, {brusdus}, broidery, "done by a needle",
  or {brosd}, which is of Teutonic origin and cognate with G.
  {brod}, already given as the root.  Hence @Ref<brosgadh>, stimulation,
  etc.  The Ir. @Ir{brosna}, O.Ir. @OIr{brosne}, faggot, may be hence;
  the root {bhrud}, discussed under @Ref{bronn}, has also been suggested.
<brosgul>, flattery, fawning (especially of a dog); possibly from the
  root form {brost}, in @Ref{brosdaich}, @Ref{brosgadh}.
<brosnaich>, incite; see @Ref{brosdaich}.  This is the best G. form;
  @Ref{brosdaich} is rather literary and Irish.
<brot.1>, broth; from the Eng. @Eng{broth}.
<brot.2>, a veil, upper garment, O.Ir. @OIr{broiténe}, palliolum; G. is a by-form
  of @Ref{brat}.
<broth.1>, itch, Ir. @Ir{broth}, *{bruto-}; see @Ref{bruthainn} for root.  Also
  (rarely) @Ref<bruth>.
--page 53
<broth.2>, lunar halo (Arg.), or @Ref<brogh>; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{bruth}, heat, under
  @Ref{bruthainn}.  Sc. {broch}, Ulster Ir. @Ir{broth}.
<brothag>, the bosom, a fold of the breast clothes; *{broso-}, root
  {brus} of @Ref{bruinne}, breast.
<brothas>, farrago, brose, Ir. @Ir{brothus}, from M.E. {brewis}, Sc. {brose}
  See @Ref{bruthaist}, the best G. form.
<brù>, g. @Ref<bronn>, belly, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{brú}, {brond}; W. @W{bru}: *{brûs},
  *{brus-nos}, root {brus}, I.E. {bhrus}, {bhreus}; Teut. {breust-}, Norse
  {bfjóst}, Eng. @Eng{breast}, Ger. {brust}.  Stokes refers it to the root
  {bru}, to swell, Gr. @Gr{βρύω}, am full, @Gr{ἐμ-βρυον}, embryo (whence
  Eng. @Eng{embryo}), or to Skr. {bhrûṇá}, embryo.  See @Ref{bruinne}.
<bruach>, a bank, brink, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bruach}: *{brou-ko-}, I.E. {bhrû},
  brow, Gr. @Gr{ὀφρύς}, eybrow, Eng. @Eng{brow}, Lit. {bruvis}, O.Ir. @OIr{brúad},
  (dual).  Also E.Ir. @EIr{brú}, bank, border.  Stokes suggests
  either the root of @Ref{brùth}, bruise, or Lit. {briau-nà}, edge.
<bruachaire>, a surly fellow, one that hovers about, Ir. @Ir{bruachaireachd},
  hovering about; @Ref{bruach}.
<bruadar>, @Ref<bruadal>, a dream, Ir. @Ir{bruadair}, W. @W{breuddwyd}: *{braud}
  or *{brav-}: {fraus}, {fraud}?
<bruaillean>, @Ref<bruaidlean>, trouble, grief; from @Ref{bruadal}, above.
<bruais>, crush to peices, gnash (Dialectic): *{bhraud-so-}, Lat. {fraus},
  Eng. @Eng{brittle}.
<bruan.1>, thrust, wound; from the root of @Ref{brùth}.
<bruan.2>, a fragment; *{bhroud-no-}, from *{bhroud}, break, Ag.S.
  {bréostan}, break, Eng. @Eng{brittle}, etc., as under @Ref{bronn}.  Strachan
  also suggests *{bhroucno-}, Lett. {brukt}, crumple, and Stokes the
  root of @Ref{brùth}.
<brùc>, seaweed cast ashore (Lewis); Norse {brúk}, drid heaps of
  seaweed.
<brucach>, spotted in the face, smutted, Ir. @Ir{brocach}: "badger like";
  see @Ref{broc}.  The Sc. {broukit}, {brooked}, is of uncertain origin
  (Murray).  Hence @Ref<brucadhadh>, irregular digging, @Ref<brucaniach>,
  the peep of dawn (M`A.), etc.
<brucag>, @Ref<bruchag>, a chink, eylet (Sh.), dim candle light (H.S.D.).
  Sh. gives @Ref{bruchag}, H.S.D. {brucag}, which appears only to apply
  to the "dim candle light"; from @Ref{brucach}.
<brùchd>, belch, burst out, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{brúchtaim}, eructo, vomo,
  W. @W{brytheiro} (vb.), {brythar} (n.).
<bruchlag>, a hovel; from @Ref{brugh}, q.v.
<bruchlas>, the fluttering of birds going to rest (Sh.):
<bruchorcan>, stool bent, heath rush; said to be derived from †{brú},
  a hind, and {corc-an}, oats, "deer's oats".  Also @Ref<bruth-chorcan>.
<brudhach>, a brae; see @Ref{bruthach}.
<brudhaist>, brose; see @Ref{bruthaist}.
--page 54
<brugh>, large house, a tumulus, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{brug}, {mrug}, land,
  holding, mark, W. @W{bro}, country, region, land, {Cym-mro}, a
  Welshman, pl. {Cymmry} (*{com-mroges}), Br. @Br{bro}, country, Gaul.
  {Brogi-}: *{mrogi} (for Gadelic); Lat. {margo}; Got. {marka},
  border-country, Ag.S. {mearc}, border, Eng. @Eng{mark}, {march}.
<bruich>, boil, cook; gutturalised form of @Ref{bruith} (cf. @Ref{bràth}, {bràch}).
  See @Ref{bruith}.  The Ir. @Ir{bruighim} appears in O'R., and has been
  compared to Lat. {frîgo}, Gr. @Gr{φρύγω}, roast; but it is evidently
  a bad spelling of @Ref{bruith}.
<bruid.1>, captivity, Ir. @Ir{bruid}, M.Ir. *{brat}, g. {braite}, E.Ir. acc. @Ref{broit},
  *{braddâ}.  For root, see @Ref{bradach}.
<bruid.2>, @Ref<bruidich>, stab, goad, Ir. @Ir{bruidighim}: the verb from @Ref{brod.2},
  a goad.
<brùid>, a brute, Ir. @Ir{brúid}; from Eng. @Eng{brute}.
<bruidheann>, @Ref<bruidhinn>, talk, conversation, Ir. @Ir{bruíghinn}, scolding
  speech, a brawl (also {bruitheann}), O.Ir. @OIr{fris-brudi}, renuit, W.
  {cyfrau}, song, O.Br. @OBr{co-brouol}, verbialia, *{mru}, say; Skr. {brû},
  {bravati}, says, Zend {mrû}, speak.  O'Grady (S. Gad. xvi.)
  connects E.Ir. @EIr{brudin}, hospitium; says meaning really is "quarrel".  He
  gives Ir. as {bruidhen}.  Stokes E.Ir. @EIr{brudin},
  *{brodìna}, Eng. @Eng{board} (Z. 33).
<bruidlich>, stir up; see @Ref{bruid.2}, stab, goad.
<brùill>, bruise, thump; a derivative from @Ref{brùth}, q.v.
<brùillig>, a person of clumsy figure and gait (H.S.D., which refers
  the word to @Ref{brù}, belly); from @Ref{brù}?
<bruim-fheur>, switch grass, so Ir.: from {braim-fheur}, a term to
  denote its worthlessness.
<Brùinidh>, the Brownie; from Sc. {Brownie}, the benevolent farmhouse
  goblin, from Eng. @Eng{brown}.  Cf. the Norse {Svart-álfr} or
  dark elves.
<bruinne>, breast, O.Ir. @OIr{bruinne}, W. @W{bron}, Corn. and M.Br. @Corn@MBr{bronn},
  *{brus-no}, root {bhrus}, {bhreus}; Norse {brjóst}, Ger. {brust}, Eng.
  {breast}.  Stokes gives the root as {brend}, from I.E. {ℊrendh},
  swell, be haughty, Gr. @Gr{βρένθύομαι}, strut, bear oneself loftily,
  Lat. {grandis}, Ch.Sl. {grądĭ}, breast.  Usually correlated with
  Got. {brunjô}, breastplate, M.H.G. {brünne}, N. {brynja}, coat of
  mail,  M.Eng. {brynie}, Sc. {byrnie}: a satisfactory enough derivation,
  and ultimatley from the same root as the first one
  given above (I.E. {bhru}).  Indeed Stokes says the Teut. is
  borrowed from the Celtic.
<bruinneadh>, the from (Dialectic), O.Ir. @OIr{bruinech}, prow, Corn.
  @Corn{brenniat}, prow, *{bronjo-}, to which Bex. compares Ger. {grans},
  prow (I.E. {ℊh} = G. {b}?).  From root of @Ref{bruinne}.
<bruis>, a brush, Ir. @Ir{bruis} (vulg.); from the Eng. @Eng{brush}.
--page 55
<bruiteach>, warm; from *{bruth}, heat; see @Ref{bruthainn}.
<bruith>, boil, cook, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bruith}, cooking, *{brot-}, from the
  root {bru}, I.E. {bhru}; Eng. @Eng{broth} (Teut. {broþo-}, I.E. {bhruto-},
  and {brew} (I.E. {bhreu}); Lat. {defrutum}, must; Thrac. Gr.
  @Gr{βρῦτον}, beer.
<brunsgal>, rumbling noise; @Ref{bronn}+@Ref{sgal}?  From @Ref{brù}, in any case.
<brusg>, a crumb, particle of food, Ir. @Ir{bruscán}, {brusgar}, broken ware,
  useless fragments, {brus}, refuse of corn: from *{brus}, short
  form of *{brûs} in @Ref{brùth}.
<brutach>, digging, the act of digging (N.H. according to H.S.D.):
  *{brutto-}, *{bhrud-to-}, root {bhrud}, break?  See @Ref{bronn}.
<brùth>, bruise, pound, Ir. @Ir{brúighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{brúim}, *{brûs}, strike,
  graze, pound; Pre. Celt. {bhreus}; Ag.S. {brýsan}, bruise, Eng.
  {bruise} (influenced by Fr.); perhaps O.Slav. {brŭsnąti}, corrumpere,
  radere.
<bruthach>, a brae: *{brut-acos}, root {bru}, from {bhru}, brow; see
  @Ref{bruach}.  Sc. {brae} is of a similar origin, founded on Norse
  {brá}, eyelid, brow (Murray).
<bruthainn>, sultriness, heat, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bruth}, fervour, W. @W{brwd}, hot,
  Br. @Br{brout}, hot (fire), O.Br. @OBr{brot}: *{brutu-}.  For further root see
  @Ref{bruith}.  Wider are Lat. {ferveo}, {fervor}, Eng. @Eng{burn}, etc.
<bruthaist>, brose; from early Sc., Eng. @Eng{browes}, Sc. {brose}; from the
  Fr., but allied to Eng. @Eng{broth}.
<bu>, was, Ir. @Ir{budh}, O.Ir. @OIr{by}: Proto-Gaelic *{bu} for a Celtic {bu-t};
  Gr. @Gr{ἕφυ} ({υ} long), aorist tense; Lat. {fuit}; Skr. {ábhût}, was;
  I.E. {é-bhû-t}.  The root is {bheu}, {bhu}; Eng. @Eng{be}, etc.  Both G.
  and Ir. @Ir{aspirate}, which shows the {t} of the 3rd sing.
  disappeared early.
<buabhall.1>, unicorn, buffalo, M.Ir. @MIr{buabhall}, W. @W{bual}; from Lat.
  {bubalus}, buffalo, gazelle, whence ({būfalus}) Eng. @Eng{fuggalo}.
<buabhall.2>, a trumpet, Ir. @Ir{bubhall}, {buadhbhall}, M.Ir. @MIr{buaball}, W.
  {bual}, bugle; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{buabhall}, horn, W. @W{bual}, buffalo horn,
  M.Ir. @MIr{corn buabhaill}; whence the further force of "trumpet".
<buachaill>, a herdsman, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{bóchaill}, {buachaill}, W. @W{bugail},
  Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{bugel}; Gr. @Gr{βουκόλος}, cowherd (Lat. {bucolicus}, Eng.
  {bucolic}, @Gr{βου-}, cow, and @Gr{-κολος}, attendant, Lat. {colo}, {cult}ivate.
<buachar>, cow-dung, Ir. @Ir{buacar}, {buachar} (Con.), Br. @Br{beuzel}; for the
  stem before the suffix {-ar}, cf. W. @W{buwch} (*{boukkâ}), though
  {bou-cor-} or {bouk-cor-}, "cow-offcast", may properly be the derivation for
  the Gadelic.  See @Ref{bó} and, possibly, @Ref{cuir}.  Cf.
  {salchar}.
<buadhghallan>, @Ref<buaghallan>, ragwort, Ir. <buadhghallan>, M.Ir.
  {buathbhallan}, {buathfallan}: "virtue bearing wort"?  More
  probably it is {buaf-bhallan}, "toad-wort", brom {buaf}, toad,
--page 56
  reptile, from Lat. {bûfo}.  The Welsh call it "serpent's weed",
  {llysiau'r nedir}.  Ir. @Ir{baufanau} is "mugwort"; {buadharlann}
  (Hend.).
<buaic.1>, a wick, Ir. @Ir{buaic}; from Eng. @Eng{wick}, Ag.S. {weoca}?
<buaic.2>, bleaching lees, Ir. @Ir{buac}; from M.E. {bouken}, steep in lye,
  Eng. @Eng{buck}, Ger. {bauchen}; Fr. {buer}, from a Lat. type *{bûcare}.
  See @Ref{fùcadh}.
<buaicneach>, smallpox (Suth.); founded on a later form of Lat.
  {bucca}, as in @Ref{bucaid}, q.v.
<buaidh>, victory, virtue, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{buaid}, W. @W{budd}, O.Br. @OBr{bud},
  Gaul. {boud-}, in many personal names, whether as the only
  root (cf. Boudicca, "Victrix") or in compounds, either initial
  or as second part: *{boudi-}; Norse {býti}, exchange, Ger. {beute},
  booty, Eng. @Eng{booty}, Fr. {butin} (do.).
<buaidheam>, fits of inconstancy; cf. @Ref{buathadh}.
<buail>, strike, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bualaim}: *{budlo-}, or *{boudlo-}, *{boud},
  Pre-Celt. {bhoud}, {bheud}; Ag.S. {béatan}, Eng. @Eng{beat}, {beetle}, Ger.
  {beutel}, beetle (Strachan).  See @Ref{buille}.  Stokes gives the form
  *{buglaô}, root {bug}, {bhug}, as in Ger. {pochen}, Eng. @Eng{poke}.
<buaile>, a fold, pen, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{buale}; Lat. {bovile}; from *{bov-}, cow.
<buaill>, place for resting and milking (Lewis).  Cf. Norse {ból}.
<buain>, reap, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{buain}, inf. of {bongaim}, reap, break: *{bogni-}
  or *{bongni-}?  For root, see @Ref{bochd}.
<buair>, tempt, vex, Ir. @Ir{buaidhirim}, E.Ir. @EIr{buadraim}, O.Ir. @OIr{buadartha},
  turbulentus: *{boud-ro-}; possibly from {bhoud}, strike, the idea
  coming from a form *{boudro-}, a goad, goading?  G. has
  @Ref<buaireadh>, <buair>, a rage.
<bual-chòmhla>, sluice (M`L.) ({an fhamh bhual}, water vole); M.Ir.
  {bual}, flowing sluice water, E.Ir. @EIr{roth-búali}, water-wheel,
  *{bogla}, Eng. @Eng{beck}, Ger. @Ref{bach} (St.) (Zim.).
<bualtrach>, cow-dung, so Ir. @Ir{buartlach} (Dial. Ir.); from @Ref{buar}, cattle.
<buamastair>, a blockhead.
<buan>, lasging, Ir. @Ir{buan}, lasting, fixed, E.Ir. @EIr{buan}: "being,
  during", from *{bu}, be, I.E. {bhu}, be; Lit. {butinas}, being,
  during, from {buti}, be; Norse {búa}, dwell, Got. {bauan}, etc.
  Stokes gives the G. stem as {buvano-s}, and cfs. Skr. {bhûvana},
  existence.  Hence @Ref<buanaich>, persevere.
<buana>, an idle person who lives on the best his heighbours can
  afford (Lewis) (M`A.):
†<buanna>, a mercenary, a billeted soldier, so Ir.:
<buannachd>, profit; from @Ref{buain}, reap, with irregularly doubled {n}
  (see @Ref{cinne}, @Ref{linne}, {seann}, {bann-} for @Ref{ban-}, @Ref{miann}?  Cf. Ir.
  {buannacht}, soldiers billeting from a tenant (Joyce).
<buar>, cattle, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{búar}, cattle of the cow kind; from @Ref{bó},
  cow: *{bovâro-}; cf. Lat. {boarius}.
--page 57
<buarach>, cow-fetter, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{buarach}: for {bó-árach}, "cow-fetter",
  {árach} being for {ad-rig-os}, root {rig} of @Ref{cuibhreach}, q.v.
<buathadh>, a rushing, a mad fit:
<bùb>, roar, Ir. @Ir{bub}: onomatopoetic.  Cf. Lat. {baubor}, bay, Gr.
  @Gr{βαύζω}, bark, Lit. {bubauti}, roar.
<bùban>, coxcomb, Ir. @Ir{bubán}; cf. Eng. @Eng{booby}.
<bucach>, a boy (dial.): "growing one"; founded on Lat. {bucca} as
  in @Ref{bucaid}.
<bucaid>, a pustule, Ir. @Ir{bucóoid}, a spot, E.Ir. @EIr{boccóit}; from Brittonic
  Lat. {buccâtus}, from {bucca}, puffed cheek (Eng. {debouch}, {rebuke}).
<bucall>, a buckle, Ir. @Ir{buccla}, W. @W{bwel}; from M.Eng. {bukyll}, Eng.
  {buckle}, from Fr. {boucle}, from Lat. {bucula}, cheek-strap, from
  {bucca}, cheek.
<bùchd>, size {buc} (Sh.); from Sc. {bouk}, i.e. {bulk}.
