<buchainn>, melodious (A.M`D.):
<buchallach>, nestling (adj.): *{buth-chal}, "house tending"?
  {buchallach} (M`L. Teachd.Gaidh.):
<budach>, poult (Suth.): see @Ref{pùt.1}.
<budagochd>, snipe (M`L.), woodcock (H.S.D.).  It seems a reminiscence
  of Eng. @Eng{woodcock}.
<budhaigir>, the puffin, @Ref<buigire>, (M`A., for St. Kilda), Sc. {bowger}, the
  coulter-neb; somehow from Norse {bugr}, curve, "bent-bill"?
<budhailt>, a window-like recess in a wall; from Sc. {bowall}, {boal},
  {bole}.  Origin unknown (Murray).
<budhag>, a bundle of straw: root {bud}, which underlies Fr. {botte},
  bundle?  See @Ref{boitean}.
<bugha>, a green spot by a stream (Skye), @Ref{bogha} (Rob.).
<buideal>, a bottle, cask, Ir. @Ir{buideul}, W. @W{potel}; from Eng. @Eng{bottle}.
  See @Ref{botul}.
<buidealaich>, a conflagration, Ir. @Ir{buite}, fire, {buitealach} (Lh.†, O'Cl.,
  O'B.), {bott} (O'Cl.): *{bud-do-}, root {bhud} (Lat. {fustis}, {bhud-tis},
  Eng. @Eng{beetle}), giving the idea of "faggot", "firewood"?
<buidhe.1>, yellow, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{buide}; Lat. {badius}, Eng. @Eng{bay}.
<buidhe.2>, now @Ref<buidheachas>, thanks, Ir. @Ir{buidhe}, O.Ir. @OIr{buide} (W.
  {boddaw}, please, {bodd}, will?), *{budo-}, I.E. {bhudh}, {bheudh}; Gr.
  @Gr{πεύθομαι}, learn by inquiry; Ag.S. {béodan}, command, Eng.
  for-@Ref{bid}.
<buidhe.3>, glad to, had to, O.Ir. @OIr{buithi}, participle of necessity, from
  the verb {bí}, be: "Is amlid is buithi do chách" - Thus ought
  it to be with every one (9th Cent. glosses); G. "Is buidhe do
  gach neach".
<buidheann>, a company, Ir. @Ir{buidhean}, O.Ir. @OIr{buden}, W. @W{byddin},
  O.Br. @OBr{bodin}, manus, *{bodînâ}; O.H.G. {chutti}, troop, band,
  O.Fris. {kedde}, Ger. {kette}, covey; I.E. {gô}: {go}, drive; cf. Lit.
---JTM: normalized to Fris.
  {gůtas}, herd.
--page 58
<buidhinn>, gain,win, @Ref<buinnig>, act of gaining, gain; from the Eng.
  {win}, {winning}.
<buil>, effect, use, Ir. @Ir{boil}, *{bol}, *{bel}: Pre-Celt. {bhel}, {bhol}; Gr.
  @Gr{ὄφελος}, advantage, @Gr{ὠφέλέω}, help.
<buileach>, total, entirely; another form of @Ref{baileach}.  E.Ir. has
  {bulid}, blooming.
<buileastair>, a bullace or sloe (M`D., Sh.); from M.E. {bolaster} =
  {bullace-tree}, from {bolace}, now {bullace}.
<builionn>, a loaf, Ir. @Ir{builín}; from O.Fr. {boulange}, ball-shaped
  loaf (?), which Diez suggests as the basis of Fr. {boulanger},
  baker.
<buille>, a blow, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bulle}, {buille} = {bollia} = {bus-liâ} + {bhud-s-liâ};
  root {bhud}, beat, as in @Ref{buail}, q.v.  Stokes gives the stem as
  *{boldja}, allied to Lit. {béldżiu}, {belsti}, give a blow, {baldas}, a
  beetle; Ger. {poltern}.
<buillsgean>, centre, Ir. @Ir{boilsceán}, M.Ir. @MIr{bolscén}, middle, midriff =
  {bolgán}, from @Ref{balg}, {bolg}, belly.
<buin>, belong to, Ir. @Ir{beanaim}.  The Ir. is from the verb @Ref{bean.2},
  touch; the G., which has the idea of relationship or origin
  ({Cha bhuin e dhomh}: he is not related to me), seems to
  confuse @Ref{bean.2} and @Ref{bun}, stock.
<buinne>, a cataract, tide, Ir. @Ir{buinne}, a spout, tap, E.Ir. @EIr{buinne},
  wave, rush of water: G. @Ref<buinneach>, flux, diarrhœa, so Ir.;
  see @Ref{boinne}.  Also {puinne} (Suth.) (W.Ross).
<buinneag>, a twig, sprout, Ir. @Ir{buinneán}, E.Ir. @EIr{buinne}: *{bus-niâ};
  root {bus}, as in Eng. @Eng{bush}, {boosky}, Ger. {busch}, etc.
<buinnig>, winning; see @Ref{buidhinn}.
†<buinnire>, a footman, so Ir.; from @Ref{bonn.1}, sole of the foot.
<bùir>, @Ref<bùirich>, roar, bellow (as a bull), Ir. @Ir{búireadh}, roaring; E.Ir.
  {búraim}; *{bû-ro-}, I.E. root {ℊevo}, {ℊû}, cry; Gr. @Gr{βοάω}, shout;
  Lit. {gauju}, howl; Skr. @Ref{gu}, cry.  Strachan gives as G. stem
  {bucro-}, root {buq} as in Lat. {buccina}, horn, Gr. @Gr{βύκτης}, howling,
  Skr. {bukkāras}, lion's roar, Nor. {bura}, to bellow, Shet.
---JTM: normalized to Nor.
  {boorik}, cow.
<buirdeiseach>, a free man, burgess, Ir. @Ir{buirgéiseach}; from the Eng.
  {burgess}.
<buirleadh>, language of folly and ridicule; from the Romance
  {burla}, to jest, etc.  See @Ref{burraidh}.
<bùirseach>, a deluge of rain; a rousing fire (Heb.):
<buiseal>, a bhshel, Ir. @Ir{buiseul}; from Eng. @Eng{bushel}.
<bùit>, bashful (Badenoch): "fugy", as a fowl; see @Ref{pùt.1}
<bùiteach>, a threat (Suth.): a form of {bòidich}?
<buitseach>, a witch, so Ir.; from Eng. @Eng{witch}; "buidseach agus
  raitseach".
--page 59
<bùlas>, pot hook; from the Sc. {bools}, a pot hook in two parts or
  "bools", M.Eng. {bool}, a pail handle, round part of a key,
  Ger. {bügel}, arc: from Teut. {beugan}, bend, Eng. @Eng{bow}.  Dialectic
  @Ref<pùlas>.
<bumailear>, bungler; from Sc. {bummeler}, from {bummil}, bungle,
  Eng. @Eng{bumble}; of onomatopoetic origin (Murray).  Cf. Ger.
  {bummler}, a lounger.
<bun>, root, stock, bottom, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bun}, W. @W{bon}, stem, trunk,
  O.W. @OW{boned}; Arm. {bun}; N.Pers. {bun}, Zd. {buna-} (Bugge).
  Rhys has suggested a comnection with Ger. {bühne}, a stage,
  boards.  Ag.S. {bune}, "stalk, reed", may be allied.  It cannot
  be connected with @Ref{bonn.1}, for the stem there is {bhuadh-no-}, root
  {bhudh}.  The ultimate root of {bun}, in any case, is simply {bhu},
  {bhû}, grow, swell, Gr. @Gr{φύω}, @Gr{φῦλον},a tribe, Eng. @Eng{boil} (n.), Ger.
  {bheule}, a swelling, Skr. {bhumis}, earth; {bhû}, grow, is identical
  with {bhu}, be.
<bunach>, coarse tow, refuse of flax, so Ir.; from @Ref{bun}.
<bunait>, foundation, Ir. @Ir{bunáit}: @Ref{bun}+{áit}, q.v.
<bungaìd>, a hussy (Dial.); from Sc. {bungy}, pettish.
<bunnlum>, steadiness, @Ref<bunntam>, @Ref<bunntamas>, solidity, shrewdness;
  from @Ref{bun}, foundation.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{buntomhas}, well founded
  opinion: @Ref{bun}+@Ref{tomhas}, q.v.
<bunnsach.1>, a twig, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{bunsach}; see @Ref{buinneag}.
<bunnsach.2>, a sudden rush; from @Ref{buinne}.
<bunntam>, solidity; see @Ref{bunnlum}.
<buntàta>, potato, Ir. @Ir{potáta}, {fataidhe}; from the English.  It contains
  a piece of folk-etymologising in the syllable {bun-}, root.
<buntuinn>, belonging; see @Ref{buin}.
<bùrach>, turning up of the earth, digging; from the Sc. {bourie},
  Eng. @Eng{burrow}.  The Sc. {bourach}, enclosure, cluster, knoll,
  heap, etc., is the Eng. @Eng{bower}.
<burgaid>, a purge, @Ref<Burgadoir>, Purgatory; see @Ref{purgaid}, {Purgadoir}.
<bùrlam>, a flood, rush of water (Arg.); see @Ref{bòrlum.2}.
<burmaid>, wormwood; from the Eng.  M.Ir. @MIr{in uormoint}.
<bùrn>, water; from Sc. {burn}, water, spring-water, Eng. @Eng{bourne},
  {burn}, a stream, Teut. {brunnon-}, a spring, Norse {brunnr}, well,
  Ger. {brunnen}.
<burrachdadh>, raging:
<burraidh>, ablockhead, Ir. @Ir{búrraidh}; from Sc. {burrio} (1535), Fr.
  {bourrieau}, Lat. {burræ}, nonsense, Eng. @Eng{burlesque}, etc.
<burral>, a howl, lamentation, so Ir.; for the root, which is here
  short (*{bur-ro-}?), see @Ref{bùir}.  Cf. @Ref{bururus}, however.
<burras>, a caterpillar:
--page 60
<burr->, as in @Ref<burr'caid>, clumsy person, @Ref<burr'ghlas>, a torrent of
  rage, etc, seems from @Ref{borr}, great, excessive, q.v.  @Ref<burr'sgadh>,
  a burst of passion, may be from Eng. @Eng{borasco}, squall of wind.
<bùrt>, mockery; from Sc. {bourd}, M.Eng. {bourd}, jest, Fr. {bourde},
  a lie.
<bururus>, infant lisping, warbling, purling; cf. Eng. @Eng{purr} and {purl}
  (Skeat).  Evidently onomatopoetic.
<bus>, a mouth, kiss, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{bus}, *{bussu-}; Pre-Celt. {ℊuss-}; Teut.
  {kuss}, Ger. {küssen}, kiss, Eng. @Eng{kiss} (Kluge).  Bezzenberger cfs.
  Lit {buczúti}, kiss; others give {buc-sa}, allied to Lat. {bucca},
  cheek.
<busgadh>, dressing; from the Sc., Eng. @Eng{busk}.
<busgaid>, a bustle (M`D.); formed from Eng. @Eng{busy}; cf. Ag.S.
  {bysgy}, business.
<bustail>, puffing, blowing (Heb.); from @Ref{bus}.
<butadh>, a push; see @Ref{putadh}.
<butag>, oar pin; see @Ref{putag.1}.
<bùth>, a shop; from the Eng. @Eng{booth}, Norse {búð}, shop, root {bhu}, be.
  See @Ref{bothan}.
<buthainnich>, thump, thrash, bang; from the root {bhud}, beat
  (Eng. {beat})?  See @Ref{buthuinn}.
<buthuinn>, long straw for thatch; cf. @Ref<sputhainn>, straw not
  threshed, but seedless (Arg.), which seems from @Ref{spoth}.
<butrais>, @Ref<butarrais>, a mess:
<c'>, for @Ref{co.1}, @Ref{cia}, who, what, q.v.
<cà>, @Ref<ca>, where, Ir. @Ir{cá}, how, where, who; a by-form to @Ref{cia}, {cè}, q.v.
---gjk (1.14) which sense of {cè} is this referring to?
<cab>, a gap, indentation, mouth, Ir. @Ir{cab}, mouth, head, gap, @Ref{cabach},
  babbling, indented.  The word is borrowed from two English
  words - {gap} and @Ref{gab} (M.E. {gabben}, chatter); G. has also @Ref{gab},
  directly from @Ref{gab} of the Sc.  Hence @Ref<cabach>, gap-toothed.
<càbag>, a cheese; Sc. {cabback}, {kebbock}.  The latter form ({kebbock})
  is probably from a G. {ceapag}, {cepag}, obsolete in G. in the sense
  of "a cheese", but still used for the thick wooden wheel of
  wheel-barrows; it is from G. {ceap}.  Sc. {cabback} is a side form
  of {kebbock}, and it seems to have been re-borrowed into G. as
  {càbag}.  the real G. word for "a cheese" is now @Ref{mulachag}.
<cabaist>, cabbage, Ir. @Ir{gabáisde}; from the Eng.
<càball>, a cable, Ir. @Ir{cabla}; from Eng. @Eng{cable}, which, through Fr.,
  comes from Lat. {capulum}.
<cabar>, a rafter, caber, deer's horn, Ir. @Ir{cabar}, W. @W{ceibr}, rafters,
  O.Br. @OBr{cepriou}, beams; from a Med.Lat. *{caprio}, a rafter,
  {capro}, {caprones} (which exists as a genuine 8th century word),
--page 61
  Fr. {chevron}, rafter.  {caprio} is from {caper}, goat; Lat. {capreoli},
  goat-lets, was used for two beams meeting to support something,
  props, stays.
<cabasdar>, @Ref<cabstar>, a bit, curb, W. @W{cebystr}, Br. @Br{kabestr}; from Lat.
  {capistrum}, halter, "head-holder", from {caput}.
<cabhag>, hurry:
<cabhlach>, a fleet, Ir. @Ir{cobhlach}, {cabhlach}, E.Ir. @EIr{coblach}; *{cob-lach};
  from {kub}, *{quℊ}, curve, root of Lat. {cymba}, boat, Gr. @Gr{κύμβη},
  boat, cup, especially Lat. {cybaea}, a transport (*{kubaía}.
<cabhladh>, ship's tackle, Ir. @Ir{cábhluighe}; cf. @Ref{cabhlach} and Eng.
  {cable}.
<càbhruich>, sowens, flummery, Ir. @Ir{cáthbhruith}; from {cáth} and
  @Ref{bruith}, q.v.
<cabhsair>, causeway, Ir. @Ir{cabhsa}; from Eng. @Eng{causey}, {causeway}, from
  O.Fr. {caucie}, from Lat. {calciata} (via).
<cabhsanta>, dry, snug; from Sc. {cosie}, {colsie}, Eng. @Eng{cosy}, whose
  origin is unknown.
<cabhtair>, an issue, drain in the body (M`D., who, as {cautair},
  explains it as "an issue or cauter"); from Eng. @Eng{cauter}.
<cabhuil>, a conical basket for catching fish; from M.Eng. {cawell},
  a fish basket, still used in Cornwall, Ag.S. {cawl}.  Cf. Br.
  {kavell}, bow-net, O.Br. @OBr{cauell}, basket, cradle; from Lat.
  {cauuella}, a vat, etc. (Loth, Ernault).
<càblaid>, turmoil, hindrance, trouble (Wh.): See @Ref{càpraid}.
<cabon>, capon (M`D.), Ir. @Ir{cabún}; from Eng. @Eng{capon}.
<cac>, excrement, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cacc}, Corn. @Corn{caugh}, Br. @Br{kac'k}, *{kakko-};
  Lat. {caco}; Gr. @Gr{κάκκη}; Skr. {çáka}, g. {çaknás}.
<càch>, the rest, others, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cách}, quivis, W. @W{pawb}, all, Br. @Br{pep},
  *{qáqe}; root {qō}, {qo}, {qe} of @Ref{co.1} and @Ref{gach}, q.v.
<cachdan>, vexation, Ir. @Ir{cacht}, distress, prioner, E.Ir. @EIr{cachtaim}, I
  capture, W. @W{caeth}, slave, confined: *{kapto-}, caught; Lat.
  {capio}, {captus}; Got. {haban}, Eng. @Eng{have}.
<cachliadh> (Arm.), @Ref<cachaleith> (H.S.D.), a gate; {co-cliath}, "co-hurdle";
  see @Ref{cliath.1}, @Ref{cleath}, hurdle, wattle.  Also @Ref<cachliag>,
  (C.S.).  It has also been explained as {cadha-chliath}, "hurdle-pass".
  Carmichael gives alternate {cliath-na-cadha}.
<cadadh>, tartan cloth, hose tartan, Manx {cadee}, cotton; Eng.
  {caddow} (16th cent.), an Irish quilt or cloak; doubtless from
  Eng. @Eng{caddis}, worsted, crewel work, etc., Fr. {cadis}, woolen
  serge.  See also @Ref{catas}.
<cadal>, sleep, Ir. @Ir{codladh}, O.Ir. @OIr{cotlud}, vb. {contulim}: *{con-tul-}, root
  {tol}; Ch.Sl. {toliti}, appease, placare, Lit. {tilas}, quiet (Persson).
  The root {tol}, {tel}, appears in @Ref{tràth}, gentle, Lat. {tolerare}, Sc.
  {thole}.
--page 62
<cadan>, cotton (Sh.); from Eng. @Eng{cotton}.  Properly @Ref<codan>, which is
  the usual dialect form.  See @Ref{cotan}.  For Ir. @Ir{cadás}, cotton,
  see @Ref{catas}.
<cadha>, a pass, narrow pass, entry; cf. Ir. @Ir{caoi}, way, road, E.Ir.
  {cái}, which Stokes, however, refers to the root {ci} as in Lat.
  {cio}, move, Gr. @Gr{κíω}, go, a derivation which does not suit the
  G. phonetically.  {cae} (Meyer).
<cadhag.1>, jackdaw, Ir. @Ir{cabhóg}, M.Ir. @MIr{caog}; *{ca-óg}, the @Ref{ca}-er or
  crier of @Ref{ca}, {caw}; on onomatopoetic origin.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{caw};
  also {chough}, from a West Teut. {kâwa-}.
<cadhag.2>, a wedge (M`A. for Skye):
<cadhan>, wild goose, barnacle goose, so Ir.; cf. Eng. @Eng{caw}, for possibly
  the name is onomatopoetic.  Corm. (B) @Ref{cadan}.
<cadh-luibh>, the cud-weed (Sh. gives @Ref<cad-luibh>, and O'B.), Ir.
  {cadh-luibh}; from M.Eng. {code}, a cud.  M`A. omits the word;
  it is clearly Irish.  The G. is @Ref<cnàmh lus>, which is its Lat.
  name of {gnaphalium} in folk etymology.
<cadhmus>, a mould for casting bullets; from Sc. {cawmys}, {calmes}
  (16th century), {caums}, Eng. @Eng{calm}, {came}.
<cagailt>, a hearth, Ir. @Ir{cagailt}, raking of the fire (O'R.):
<cagar>, a whisper, Ir. @Ir{cogar}, M.Ir. @MIr{coccur}; {cechras}, qui canet,
  {cairche}, sound; root {kar}, of Lat. {carmet}, Gr. @Gr{κῆρυξ}, herald
  (Stokes).
<cagaran>, darling: *{con-car-}; root {car}, dear, as in @Ref{caraid}.
<caglachan>, something ground to pulp or dust (M`D.):
<cagnadh>, chewing, Ir. @Ir{cognadh}, M.Ir. @MIr{cocnum}, O.Ir. @OIr{cocnom}:
  *{con-cnámh}; see @Ref{cnàmh}.
<caibe>, a spade, turf cutter, Ir. @Ir{coibe}, {cuibe} (O'R., Fol.), W. @W{caib},
  O.Corn. {cep}.
<caibeal>, a chapel (M`D.); from Lat. {capella}.  The G. really is
  @Ref{seipeal}, q.v.
<caibheis>, giggling, laughing:
<caibideil>, @Ref<caibdeil>, a chapter, Ir. @Ir{caibidil}, E.Ir. @EIr{caiptel}, W.
  {cabidwl}; from Lat. {capitulum}, whence O.Fr. {chapitre}, Eng.
  {chapter}.
<caidir>, cherish, so Ir.  See @Ref{caidreabh}.
<caidreabh>, fellowship, affection, vicinity, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{caidrebh},
  Celtiberian {Contrebia}: *{con-treb-}; see @Ref{aitreabh}, @Ref{treabh}.
<caig>, conversation, claque (Arg.); teaze (Perth):
<caigeann.1>, a couple (of animals), coupling: *{con-ceann}; from
  @Ref{ceann}, q.v.
<caigeann.2>, a winding pass through rocks and brushwood, a rough
  mountani pass (Dial. = {cadha-éiginn}).
<caigeann.3>, scrimmage (M`D.):
--page 63
<càil>, condition, vigour, appetite, anything ({càileigin}), Ir. @Ir{cáil}, W.
  {cael}, to have, get, enjoy, *{kapli-}, *{kapelo-}: root {qap}; Lat.
  {capio}, Eng. @Eng{have}.
<cailbhe>, a partition wall (of wattle or clay, etc.); from {calbh}, q.v.
---gjk (1.14) which sense of {calbh} is this referring to?
<cailc>, chalk, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cailc}, W. @W{calch}; from Lat. {calx}, {calcis},
  whence also Eng. @Eng{chalk}.
<caile>, girl, wench, Ir. @Ir{caile}, hussy, E.Ir. @EIr{caile}; cf. Br. @Br{plac'h}, girl;
  Gr. @Gr{παλλακή}, concubine, Lat. {pellex}.  Usually @Ref<caileag>, girl.
<càileach>, husks, Ir. @Ir{cáithleach}: {cáith-lach}; see @Ref{càth}.  From @Ref{càth}
  comes also @Ref<càilean>, a husk.
<caileadair>, philosopher, star-gazer; from the Eng. @Eng{calender}, a
  mendicant dervish, from Pers. {qalander}.
<cailidear>, snot, rheum (M`F., @Ref<cailidhir> in Sh.).  O'R. improves
  this into {cailidéar}.
<cailis>, chalice, Ir. @Ir{cailís}; from Lat. {calix}, cup, Eng. @Eng{chalice}.
<cailise>, kails, ninepins (M`D.); from Eng. @Eng{kails}, M.Eng. {cailis},
  from {keyle}, a peg, Ger. {kegel}, a cane, ninepin.
<cailleach>, old wife, nun, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{caillech}, "veiled one"; from
  {caille}, veil, which is from the Lat. {pallium}, cloak, Eng. @Eng{pall}.
<caillteanach>, eunuch, so Ir.; from {caill}, lose.  See @Ref{call}.
<càimein>, a mote, Ir. @Ir{cáim}, a stain, blemish; from {càm}.
<caimeineach>, saving (Carm.):
<caimhleachadh>, @Ref<caingleachadh>, restraining (Carm.).
<caimir>, a fold:
<caimleid>, camlet; from the Eng.
<càin.1>, a tax, a tribute, Ir. @Ir{cáin}, E.Ir. @EIr{cáin}, statute, law: *{kap-ni-},
  root {qap}, as in @Ref{càil}?  Stokes refers it to the root {kâs}, order,
  Skr. {çâs} (do.), Lat. {castigare}, {castus}, Got. {hazjan}, praise.
  Hence Sc. {cain}.
<càin.2>, white: from Lat. {cānus}.
<càin.3>, scold, revile, Ir. @Ir{cáin}, M.Ir. @MIr{cáined}, scolding: *{kag-niô} or
  {kakniô}(?); Gr. @Gr{καχάζω}, laugh, @Gr{καγχάζω}, Lat. {cachinnus};
  O.H.G. {huohôn}, mock; Skr. {kakhati}, laugh.
<cainb>, hemp, Ir. @Ir{cnáib}, M.Br. @MBr{canap}; from Lat. {cannabis}, allied to
  Eng. @Eng{hemp}.
<caineal>, cinnamon; from Sc. and obsolete Eng. @Eng{cannel}, {canel},
  cinnamon, from O.Fr. {canelle}, from Lat. {canella}, dim. of
  @Ref{canna}, cane.
<caingeann>, a fine (Heb.), Ir. @Ir{caingean}, a rule, case, compact, etc.:
<Caingis>, Pentecost, Ir. @Ir{cingcis}, E.Ir. @EIr{Cingcigais}; from the Lat.
  {quinquagesima} (dies, 50th day from the Passover).
<cainneag.1>, a mote:
<cainneag.2>, a hamper (Skye):
--page 64
<cainnt>, speech, Ir. @Ir{caint}; from @Ref{can}, say, q.v.  Stokes gives the
  stem as *{kan(s)ti}, root {kans}, Skr {çasti}, prise, from {çams},
  speak, Lat. {censeo}.
<caiptean>, a captain, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{caiptín}; from M.Eng. {capitain},
  from O.Fr. {capitaine}, Lat. {capitaneus}, {caput}, head.
<càir.1>, a blaze, sea foam, etc.; see rather @Ref{caoir}.
<càir.2>, the gum, Ir. @Ir{cáir} ({cairib}, Fol.):
<càir.3>, a peat moss, dry part of the peat moss (Dial.); from Eng.
  @Ref{carr}, boggy ground, Norse {kjarr}, brushwood.  Also @Ref{càthar},
  q.v.
<cairb>, the bent ridge of a cart saddle @Ref{srathair}.  Shaw gives
  further the meanings "plank, ship, fusec ({cairb a' ghunna})
  (Rob), chariot"; Ir. @Ir{corb}, coach.  The word is the primary
  stem from which @Ref{carbad.1}, chariot, springs; see @Ref{carbad.1}.  As
  "fusee" or "fisil", i.e., "musket", it seems a curtailed form
  of @Ref{cairbinn}.
<cairbh>, a carcase, carrion; also @Ref<cairb> (Dial.); allied to {corpus}?
<cairbhist>, carriage, tenants' rent service; from M.Eng. {cariage},
  in all senses (Cf. the charter terms - "Areage and cariage
  and all due service"), now {carriage}.
<cairbinn>, a carabine; from the Eng.
<cairbinneach>, a toothless person (Sh.); from †@Ref<cairb>, a jaw, gum,
  Ir. @Ir{cairb}.  See @Ref{cairb} above.
<cairc>, flesh, person:
<càird>, a delay, respite, Ir. @Ir{cáirde}; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{cairde}, pactum.  A
  special legal use of a word which originally means "friendship".
  See @Ref{càirdeas}.
<càirdeas>, friendship, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cairdes}; from @Ref{caraid}, q.v.
<càireag>, a prating girl (Sh., who gives {caireog}); probably from
  @Ref{càir.2}, gum: "having jaw".
<caireal>, noise; see @Ref{coirioll}.
†<cairfhiadh>, a hart or stag, Ir. @Ir{cáirrfhiadh}: *{carbh-fhiadh}.  For
  *{carbh}, a deer; cf. W. @W{carw}, hart, stag, Corn. @Corn{caruu}, Br. @Br{caru};
  Lat. {carvus}; Gr. @Gr{κεραός}, horned.
<càirich>, mend, Ir. @Ir{cóirighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{córaigim}, arrange, from {cóir}, q.v.
  Cf. {cairim}, sutor, Z. 775.
<cairidh>, a weir, Ir. @Ir{cora}, M.Ir. @MIr{coraidh} for {cora}, g. {corad}, W.
  {cored}, O.W. and O.Br. @OBr{coret}, from Celtic {korjô}, I set, put.
  See @Ref{cuir}.
<cairgein>, sea moss, Ir. moss, Eng {carrageen}, so named from
  Carragheen (Waterford), in Ireland.  This place name is a
  dim. of @Ref{carraig}, rock.
<cairis>, corpse, carcase; founded on M.Eng. {cors}, Sc. {corrssys} (pl.
  in Blind Harry), now {corse}.
<cairmeal>, wild liquorice; see @Ref{carra-meille}.
--page 65
<cairnean>, an egg-shell:
<cairt.1>, bark (of a tree), Ir. @Ir{cairt}; Lat. {cortex}; root {qert}, cut, Lit.
  {kertù}, cut, Eng. @Eng{rend}.
<cairt.2>, a cart, so Ir., W. @W{cart}; from the Eng. @Eng{cart}.
<cairt.3>, a card, so Ir.; G. is from Sc. {carte}, which is direct from
  the Fr. {carte}.  The Eng. modifies the latter form into {card}.
  The are all from Lat. {charta}, paper.  E.Ir. @EIr{cairt} meant
  "parchment".
<cairt>, cleanse, Ir. @Ir{cartaighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{cartaim}, W. @W{carthu}, purge,
  {kar-to-}.  The root idea is a "clearing out"; the root {ker}, {kar},
  separate, is allied to {sker} in @Ref{ascart}, and especially in @Ref{sgar}.
<cairteal>, a quarter; from Late Lat. {quartellus}, Norse {kvartill},
  Lat. {quartus}, fourth.
<caisbheart>, @Ref<cais'eart>, foot gear (shoes or boots), Ir. @Ir{coisbheart};
  from @Ref{cas.1}+{bheart} (@Ref{beart}), q.v.
<caisd>, listen, Ir. @Ir{coisteacht}, listening, E.Ir. @EIr{coistim}, O.Ir. @OIr{coitsea},
  auscultet: {co-étsim}, @Ref{co.2} and @Ref{éisd}, listen, q.v.  O'R. gives the
  modern Ir. @Ir{cóisdeacht} with {o} long, which would seem the
  most natural result from {co-éisd}.
<càise>, chese, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cáise}, W. @W{caws}, Br. @Br{kaouz}; from Lat.
  {cāseus}, whence Eng. @Eng{cheese}.
<caiseal>, bulwark, castle, Ir. @Ir{caiseal}, E.Ir. @EIr{caisel}, {caissle}; from Lat.
  {castellum}.
<caisean>, anything curled, etc.; from @Ref{cas.3}, curled, q.v.
<caisg>, check, stop, Ir. @Ir{coisgim}, O.Ir. @OIr{cosc}, castigare, W. @W{cosp}, *{kon-sqo-},
  *{seqô}, I say; Lat. {inseque}; Gr. @Gr{ἒννεπε}, say, @Gr{ἒνι-σπε}, dixit;
  Eng. @Eng{say}, Ger. {sagen}.
<Càisg>, Easter, Ir. @Ir{Cáisg}, O.Ir. @OIr{cásc}, W. @W{pasc}; from Lat. {pascha},
  Eng. @Eng{paschal}.
<caisil-chrò>, a bier, bed of blood, M.Ir. @MIr{cosair chró}, bed of blood -
  to denote a violent death, E.Ir. @EIr{cosair}, bed.  the expression
  appears in the Ossianic Ballads, and folk-etymology is
  responsible for making G. {casair} into {caisil}, bulwark.  The
  word {cosair} has been explained as {co-ster-}, root {ster}, strew,
  Lat. {sternere}, Eng. @Eng{strew}.
<caisleach>, a ford, footpath; from {cas-lach}, rather than {cas-slighe},
  foot-way.
<caislich>, stir up, @Ref<caisleachadh>, shaking up, etc.; from @Ref{cas.2}, sudden.
<caismeachd>, an alarm (of battle), signal, march tune.  The corresponding
  Ir. is {caismirt}, alarm, battle, M.Ir. @MIr{caismert}, E.Ir.
  {cosmert}.
<caisrig>, consecrate; see @Ref{coisrig}.
<caisteal>, a castle, M.Ir. @MIr{castél}, E.Ir. @EIr{castíall}; from Lat. {castellum},
  whence Eng. @Eng{castle}.
--page 66
<càiteach>, a rush mat for measuring corn, Ir. @Ir{cáiteach}, winnowing
  sheet; from {càite}, winnowed, from @Ref{càth}.
<caiteag>, a small bit (H.S.D.), a basket for trouts (M`A. for
  Islands), basket (Sh.), a place to hold barley in (M`L.).  For
  the first sense, cf. W. @W{cat}, a piece, Sc. @Ref{cat}, a rag.  In Irish
  Lat. the trout was called {catus} (Giraldus).
<caiteas>, scraped linen, applied for the stoppage of wounds (M`F.);
  from Sc. {caddis}, lint for wounds, M.Eng. {cadas}, {caddis}, cotton
  wool, floss silk for padding, from O.Fr. {cadas}.  See G. @Ref{catas}.
  {caiteas} = sawdust, scrapings (M`D.).
<caitein>, nap of cloth, shag, Ir. @Ir{caitín}, catkin of the osier, little
  cat.  The Eng. words {caddis}, {catkin}, and {cotton} seem to be
  mixed up as the basis of the G. and Ir. words.  Cf. W. @W{ceden},
  shaggy hair.
<caith>, spend, cast, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{caithim}, *{katjô}, I consume, castaway;
  Skr. {çâtayati}, sever, cast down, destroy, {çât-ana}, causing to
  fall, wearing out, root {çat}.  Allied to the root of @Ref{cath}, war.
<caithear>, just, right, Ir. @Ir{caithear} (Lh.), {caithfidh}, it behoves,
  M.Ir. @MIr{caithfid}; from @Ref{caith}, doubtless (Atk.).
<caithream>, shout of joy, triumph, Ir. @Ir{caithréim}; from @Ref{cath}, battle,
  and @Ref{réim.3}, a shout, E.Ir. @EIr{rém}.  This last word Strachan
  refers to the root {req} (*{rec-m} or *{rec-s-m}), Ch.Sl. {reką}, speak,
  Lit. {rėkiù}.
<caithris>, night-watching:
<càl>, kail, cabbage, Ir. @Ir{cál}, W. @W{cawl}, Corn. @Corn{caul}, Br. @Br{kaol}; from Lat.
  {caulis}, a stalk, whence likewise Eng. @Eng{cole} ({cole}wort) and Sc.
  {kail}.
<cala>, @Ref<caladh>, a harbour, Ir. @Ir{caladh}, M.Ir. @MIr{calad}.  It is usual to
  correlate this with Ital. {cala}, Fr. {cale}, bay, cove (Diez, Thurneysen,
  Windisch), and Stokes even says the G. and Ir. words
  are borrowed from a Romance *{calatum}, Ital. {calata}, {cala}, Fr.
  {cale}, cove.  More probably the Celtic root is {qel}, {qal}, hide, as
  in Eng. @Eng{hollow}, M.Eng. {holh}, hollow, cave, also Eng. @Eng{hole},
  possibly.  the root of @Ref{cladh}, has also been suggested.
<caladair>, calendar, Ir. @Ir{calaindéir}; from M.Eng. {kalendar},
  through Fr. from Lat. {calendarium}, an account-book, from
  {calendæ}, the Calends or first of the month.
<calaman>, a dove; the common form of the literary @Ref{columan}, q.v.
<calanas>, spinning of wool; seemingly founded on Lat. {colus},
  distaff.  See @Ref{cuigeal}.
†<calbh.1>, head, pate, bald, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{calb}; from Lat. {calva},
  scalp, {calvus}, bald.  H.S.D. gives as a meaning "promontory",
  and instances "Aoineadh a' Chailbh Mhuilich", which surely
  must be the Calf of Mull; and Calf is a common name for
--page 67
  such subsidiary isles - from Norse {kálfr}, Eng. @Eng{calf}.  Cognate
  with Lat. {calva}, {calvaria} (St. Lec.).
<calbh.2>, a shoot, osier, twig, Ir. @Ir{colbha}, plant stalk, sceptre, hazel
  tree, E.Ir. @EIr{colba}, wand; see @Ref{colbh}.
<calbh.3>, gushing of water or blood (H.S.D.) from @Ref{calbh.2}?
<calbhair>, greedy of food (Suth.); from @Ref{càil}?
<calc>, drive, ram, caulk, Ir. @Ir{calcaim}; from Lat. {calco}, {calx}, the heel,
  Eng. @Eng{in-culcate}.
<caldach>, sharp, pointed (Sh., M`L.):
<calg>, awn, beard of corn, bristles, Ir. @Ir{calg}, {colg}, E.Ir. @EIr{colg}, a
  sword, O.W. @OW{colginn}, aristam, W. @W{cola}, beard of corn, sting,
  {caly}, penis, Br. @Br{calc'h} (do.), {kalgo-}, *{kolgo-}; Gr. @Gr{κολοβός},
  stunted; Got. {halks}, poor; further is Lat. {cellere}, hit, {culter},
  knife; etc.  The main root is {qel}, {qlâ}, hit, break; see
  @Ref{claidheamh}, @Ref{cladh}.  The Caledonian hero {Calgocos} derives
  his name hence.  Hence @Ref<calg-dhìreach>, direct, "sword-straight"
  to a place.
<call>, loss, Ir. @Ir{caill}, E.Ir. @EIr{coll}, W. @W{coll}, Corn. @Corn{colled}, jactura, M.Br.
  {coll}, *{koldo-}; Eng. @Eng{halt}, Got. {halts}, O.H.G. {halz}, lame; root
  {qel}, as above in @Ref{calg}, q.v.
<calla>, @Ref<callda>, tame, @Ref<callaidh> (M`A., also Sh., who gives the
  meaning "active" to the last form); cf. W. @W{call}, wise; from
  Lat. {callidus}?
<callag>, @Ref<calltag>, the black guillemot, diver; compare Eng. @Eng{quail},
  Fr. {caille}.
<callaid.1>, a partition, fence; the same as @Ref{tallaid}, q.v.?
<callaid.2>, a wig, cap (M`F.); from Eng. @Eng{calott}, skull-cap.
<callan>, a noise, Ir. @Ir{callán}, {callóich}; from Eng. @Eng{call}?
<calltuinn>, hazel, Ir. E.Ir. @EIr{coll}, W. @W{collen}, Corn. @Corn{coll-widen}. M.Br.
  {quel-vezenn}, *{koslo-}; Lat. {corylus}; Norse {hasl}, Eng. @Eng{hazel}.
  *{coll}+{tann}.
<Calluinn>, New Year's Day, Ir. @Ir{calláin}, Calends, or first day of the
  month, E.Ir. @EIr{callaind}, the Calends, particularly the first
  Jan., W. @W{calan}, Calends; from Lat. {calendæ} (Eng. {Calends}).
<calm.1>, a pillar (M`A.), Ir. @Ir{columhan}, @Ref{colbh}; from Lat. {columna}, etc.
<calm.2>, @Ref<calma>, brave, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{calma}.  Cf. W. @W{celf}, skill, art,
  {celfydd}, skilled, O.Br. @OBr{celmed}, efficax.  The root {cal} is to be
  compared with that in Ger. {held}, hero, *{haleth} or *{calet}.  The
  I.E. root is {qel}, as in Lat. {celsus}, high, {columna}, column, Eng.
  {excel}.
<calman>, dove; see @Ref{calaman}.
<calmarra>, the pike (Wh.)?
<calpa.1>, the calf of the leg, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{calpda}, bonus pes (Corm.),
  {colpa}, tibia; from the Norse {kálfi}, whence also Eng. @Eng{calf}.
--page 68
<calpa.2>, principal set to interest, Sc. {calpa}, dath-duty payable to
  the landlord, from N. {kaup}, stipulation, pay.
<calum>, hardness on the skin (H.S.D.; @Ref<cathlum> in M`D.); from
  Lat. {callum}, {callus}.  It is not the obsolete @Ref<caladh>, hard,
  E.Ir. @EIr{calad}, W. @W{caled}, O.Br. @OBr{calat}, *{kaleto-}, root {kal}, hard;
  Got. {hallus}, stone, Norse {helle}, {hallr}; Skr. {çilâ}, stone.
<cam>, crooked, one-eyed, Ir. @Ir{cam}, O.Ir. @OIr{camm}, W. @W{cam}, Br. @Br{kam},
  Gaul. {cambo-}, root {kemb}, wind; Gr. @Gr{κόμβος}, a band, bond; Lit.
  {kingė}, door-bar.  It has been refered to the root of Gr.
  @Gr{σκαμβός}, crooked (se @Ref{ceum}), and to Lat. {camera}, whence Eng.
  {chamber}.  Hence @Ref<camag>, club, @Ref<camas>, bay.
<camag-gharuidh>, hoow above the eye, Ir. @Ir{camóg-ara}, "the bend
  of the {ara}", O.Ir. @OIr{aire}, G. {arach}, tempus; Gr. @Gr{παρειά}, cheek.
<camart>, wry-neck:
<camastrang>, quarrelsome disputation (M`D.):
<camhach>, talkative; *{com-ag-ach}, root {ag} in @Ref{adhan}?
<camhal>, a camel, Ir. @Ir{camhall}, E.Ir. @EIr{camail}, W. @W{camyll}; from Lat.
  {camelus}.
<camhan>, a hollow plain, Ir. @Ir{cabhán} (County {Cavan}); from the
  Lat. {cavus}.
<camhanaich>, break of day, twilight, Ir. @Ir{camhaoir}; (M`A. {sgamhanaich},
  "lights"):
<camlag>, a curl:
<camp>, @Ref<campa>, a camp, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{campa}; from the Eng. @Eng{camp}.
<campar>, vexation, grief; from Sc. {cummar}, Eng. @Eng{cumber}.
<can>, say, sing, Ir. @Ir{canaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{canim}, W. @W{cana}, sing. Br. @Br{kana};
  Lat. {cano}, sing; Gr. @Gr{κανάζω}; Eng. @Eng{hen}.
<cana>, porpoise, young whale, Ir. @Ir{cana} (O'R.), {cána} (O'B.), whelp,
  pup, M.Ir. @MIr{cana} (do.); from Lat. {canis}?
<canach>, mountain down, cotton Ir. @Ir{canach}, O.Ir. @OIr{canach}, lanugo;
  Gr. @Gr{κνῆκος}, thistle, @Gr{κνεκός}, yellow; Skr. {kāncanas}, golden, a
  plant; *{qonak-}.  Stokes refers it to *{casnaka}, Lat. {cânus},
  white (*{casno-}), Ag.S. {hasu}, grey, Eng. @Eng{hare}.
<cànain>, language, Ir. @Ir{cánamhuin}.  Seemingly a long-vowel form
  of the root {qan}, cry.  See @Ref{cainnt}.
<canal>, cinnamon; see @Ref{caineal}.
<canan>, a cannon; from the Eng.
<canastair>, a canister; from the Eng.
<cangaruich>, fret; from Sc. {canker}, fret, Eng. @Eng{canker}.
<cangluinn>, trouble, vexation; from Sc. {cangle}.
<canna>, a can, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cann}; from Eng. @Eng{can}.
<cannach>, pretty, kind; *{cas-no-}, root, {qas}, Lat. {cānus}, white ({casnus}),
  Ag.S. {hasu}, grey, Eng. @Eng{haze}?  Or it may be allied to
  Lat. {candidus}, white, Skr. {cand}, shine.
--page 69
<canntaireachd>, articulate music, chanting, Ir. @Ir{cantaireachd}, singing,
  {cántaire}, a singer; from Lat. {cantor}, {cano}, I sing.
<cànran>, wrangling, grumbling, muttering, Ir. @Ir{cannrán}; from @Ref{can},
  say, sing.
<cantal>, grief, weeping (Sh., M`L.), Ir. @Ir{cantlamh}:
<caob>, a clod, a bite, Ir. @Ir{caob}, clod, M.Ir. @MIr{coep}, E.Ir. @EIr{caip}, {cáep},
  clot, lump, O.Ir. @OIr{caebb oo}, jecur.
<caoch.1>, empty (as a nut), blind, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{caech}, W. @W{coeg}, foolish,
  Corn. @Corn{cuic}, *{kaiko-s}; Lat. {caecus}; Got. {haihs}, one-eyed.
<caoch.2>, @Ref<caothach>, rage; see @Ref{cuthach}.
<caochan>, a streamlet; from {caoth}, blind?
<caochail>, change, die, @Ref<caochladh>, a change, Ir. @Ir{caochluighim},
  O.Ir. @OIr{caoimchláim cóem-chlóim}: {imchloud}, {imchlóad}, inversio;
  for {co-imm-clóim}; from {clóim}, muto: see @Ref{claoidh}.  The aspiration
  of the {mn} of {imb} is unusual, but the history of the word
  is also unusual, for it actually appears as {claemchlód} in E.Ir.
  oftener than once, and Ir. @Ir{claochlódh}, {claochladh}.
<caod Chaluim-chille>, St John's wort (Sh.):
<caog>, wink; apparently from Eng. @Eng{cock} (the eye).  Cf. Norse
  {kaga}, keek; Sc. {keek}; Shet. {caog}, peep slily.
<caogad>, fifty, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cóica(t)}, *{qenqekont}; Lat. {quinquaginta};
  Gr. @Gr{πεντήκοντα}.  See @Ref{cóig}.
<caoidh>, lamentation, Ir. @Ir{caoi}, {caoidh}, E.Ir. @EIr{cói}, {cái}, inf. to {cíim},
  ploro, *{keiô}, root {qei}, which appears in @Ref{caoin.1}, q.v., and in
  Eng. @Eng{whine}, {whisper}, etc.  Bezzenberger suggests *{keipô}, and
  compares Lit. szëptis, grimace, Ch.Sl. {o-sipnąti}, raucescere.
  A former derivation of Stokes' is repeated by Rhys (@ExtRef{Manx.Pray.;2;26}):
  *{qesi}, root {qes} as in Lat. {questus}.
<caoillean>, a twig or osier for wicker, M.Ir. @MIr{cóelach}; from @Ref{caol},
  slender.
<caoimheach>, a bedfellow (Sh.), Ir. @Ir{caoimhthech}, E.Ir. @EIr{com-aithech},
  neighbour; see {aitheach}.  Also @Ref<caomhach>, friend, bedfellow.
  The latter seems from, or influenced by, @Ref{caomh}.
---gjk (1.14) @Ref{aitheach} doesn't exist
<caoimhneas>, kindness.  This word is supposed by folk etymology
  to be from @Ref{caomh}, kind, whereas it is really allied to O.Ir.
  {coibnes}, affionitas, *{co-ven-estu-}, root {ven} of @Ref{fine}, q.v.
<caoin.1>, kind, mild, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{càin}, kind, beautiful [W. {cain}?]:
  *{koini-}, root {koi}, {kei} of @Ref{caomh}, q.v.  Stokes gives base as
  {kaini-}, and Bezzenberger compares Gr. @Gr{καíνυσθαι}, excel, Ch.Sl.
  {sinąti}, gleam forth.  If the base idea were "beauty", Eng.
  {shine} might be compared.
<caoin.2>, the exterior surface of cloth, right side, rind, sward; from
  @Ref{caoin.1}, gentle, polished?
--page 70
<caoin.3>, weep, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cóinim}, {cáinim}, O.W. @OW{cuinhaunt},
  deflebunt, Br. @Br{couen}, {queiniff}, *{koiniô}; {qein}, {qîn}; Eng. @Eng{whine},
  Norse {hvína}, whirr; Gr. @Gr{κινυρός}, wailing.  See @Ref{caoidh}.
<caoinich>, dry, make dry (as hay by the sun), @Ref<caoin.1>, seasoned;
  from the adj. @Ref{caoin.1}?
<caoir>, a blaze, stream of sparks, a coal, Ir. @Ir{caor}, E.Ir. @EIr{cáer}, *{kairo},
  Eng. @Eng{hoar} (*{kairo-}), Teut. root {hai} in Norse {heið}, atmospheric
  clearness, O.H.G. {hei}, heat, Eng. @Eng{heat}; Skr. {kêtus}, light.
  More near are Gr. @Gr{κíρις} (lamp, Hes.), Skr. {kiráṇa}, a ray,
  clear, has been also suggested.  @Ref<caoran>, a peat ember.
<caoirean>, a plaintive song; also @Ref<caoi-ràn>, moaning (H.S.D.).  The
  root word is @Ref{caoidh}; possibly {ràn}, roar, forms the latter part.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {rán}
<caoirnean>, a drop of sheep or goats' dung, a drop or globule; cf.
  Ir. @Ir{caoirín}, a little berry, little sheep, from @Ref{caor}, berry, @Ref{caora},
  sheep.  The two ideas seem confused in Gaelic.  In Argyle,
  {gaoirnean}; (Arg. {ao} here is northern {ao}).  From {skar}, {sharn}?
<caol>, slender, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cóil}, W., Corn. @Corn{cul}, O.Br. @OBr{culed}, macies,
  *{koilo-}; Lett. {káils}, naked; Lat. {caelebs}, single?  Gr. @Gr{κο῀ιλος},
  hollow?  Hence <caol>; @Ref<caolas>, a firth or Kyle.
<caolan>, gut, intestine, Ir. @Ir{caolán}, E.Ir. @EIr{coelán}, O.W. @OW{coilion}, exta;
  from @Ref{caol}.
<caomh>, tender, kind, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{coem}, O.Ir. @OIr{cóim}, W. @W{cu}, O.W.
  @Ref{cum}, Br. @Br{cuff}, {cun}, debonnaire, *{koimo-}, root {kei}, lie; Gr.
  @Gr{κοιμάω}, put to rest, @Gr{κε̑ιμαι}, lie; Got. {háims}, a village, Ag.S.
  {hám}.  Eng. @Eng{home}.  The idea is "restful".
<caomhach>, bedfellow, friend, Ir. @Ir{caomthach}, friend; see @Ref{caoimheach},
  and cf. Ir. @Ir{caomhaighim}, I protect, cherish, from @Ref{caomh}.
<caomhain>, spare, save, @Ref<caomhnadh>, sparing, Ir. @Ir{caoimhnaim},
  preserve, keep, protect, {caomhaighim}, {caomhnuighim}, preserve.
  The last form seems the most original, if we refer the root to
  O.Ir. @OIr{anich}, protegit, {aingim}, I protect ({a-nak}), root {nak} and
  {nank}, as in @Ref{adhlac}, @Ref{thig}, etc.  The form {nak} is more particularly
  allied to Skr. {náçati}, reach, Lit. {neszù}, draw.  The G.
  verb may have been *{com-anich-}.  It is possible to derive it
  from @Ref{caomh} with {caomhuin} as an inf. form which usurped the
  place of the present stem.
<caonnag>, strife, tumult, Ir. @Ir{caonnóg}, strife, a nest of wild bees:
  *{cais-no-}, root {kais}, {kai}, heat, Eng. @Eng{heat}, G. {caoir}?
<caor>, berry of the rowan, a mountain berry, Ir. @Ir{caor}, O.Ir. @OIr{cáer},
  bacca, W. @W{cair}, berries, {ceirion}, berry *{kairâ}.  It is seemingly
  the same word as @Ref{caoir}, blaze, the idea arising probably from
  the {red} rowan berries.
--page 71
<caora>, a sheep, Ir. @Ir{caora}, g. {caorach}, O.Ir. @OIr{câer}, *{cairax}, from
  *{ka(p)erax}, alliet to Lat. {caper}, a goat, Gr. @Gr{κάπρος}, a boar,
  Eng. @Eng{heifer}.  Cf. W. @W{caeriwrch}, roebuck.
<caorrunn>, the rowan tree, Ir. @Ir{caorthann}, E.Ir. @EIr{caerthann}, W.
  {cerddin}, Br. @Br{kerzin}, *{cairo-tann}, from @Ref{caor}, berry, and *{tann},
  tree, Br. @Br{tann}, oak, Corn. @Corn{glas-tannen}.  The connection with
  O.H.G. {tanna}, fir, oak, M.H.G. {tan}, wood, Ger. {tanne}, fir,
  Eng. @Eng{tan}, {tanner} (Gr. @Gr{θάμνος}, bush?) is doubtful; it would
  necessitate the idea of borrowing, or that the Celtic word was
  {dann}.  Ogam {Maqui Cairatini}, McCaorthainn.  Rhys says
  W. is borrowed from Gadelic (C.F.L. 292).
<càpa>, a capl from the Eng. @Eng{cap}.
<càpraid>, drunken riotousness (Dial.); from Lat. *{crâpula}.
<capull>, a horse, mare (more commonly), so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{capall}, Br.
  {caval}; from Lat. {capallus}, whence Eng. @Eng{cavalry}, etc., {caple} (M.Eng.
  {capil}, from Celt.)  Norse {kapall}, nag, seems borrowed
  from Gaelic.  The W. is {ceffyl}, with remarkable vocalisation.
  {capal-coille}?
<car>, turn, twist, Ir. @Ir{cor}, M.Ir. @MIr{cor} (=@Ref{cuairt}, (O'Cl.)), O.Ir. @OIr{curu},
  gyros, W. @W{cor-wynt}, turbo, M.Br. @MBr{coruent}, *{kuro-}; Lat. {curvus};
  Gr. @Gr{κυρτός}, curved.  See @Ref{cruinn}.
<càr>, friendly, related to, Ir. @Ir{cára(d)}, a friend.  See @Ref{caraid} for the
  usual root.
<càradh>, condition, usage; from @Ref{càirich}, mend.
<caraich>, move, stir, Ir. @Ir{corruighim}, from @Ref{corrach}, unsteady.  The
  G. confuses this with @Ref{car}, turn.
<caraid>, a friend, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cara}, g. {carat}, *{karant-}; O.Ir. verb
  {carim}, {caraim}, I love, W. @W{caraf}, amo, Br. @Br{quaret}, amare, Gaul.
  {carantus}, {Caractacus}, etc.; Lat. {cârus}, dear, Eng. @Eng{charity}, etc.;
  Got. {hôrs}, meretrix.
<càraid>, a pair, couple, Ir. @Ir{córaid}, E.Ir. @EIr{córait}:
<carainnean>, refuse of threshed barley, Ir. @Ir{carra}, bran; see
  @Ref{carthuinnich}.
<caraist>, catechism; from Sc. {carritch}, a corruption of {catechise}.
<caramasg>, contest, confusion (Arm. M`F.): from @Ref{car} and @Ref{measg.2}?
<caramh>, beside; see @Ref{caruibh}.
<càramh>, @Ref<càradh>, condition, treatment:
<carathaist>, compulsory labour, @Ref<cairiste>, @Ref<cairbhist>, which last see.
<carbad.1>, a chariot, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{carpat}, W. @W{cerbyd}, O.Br. @OBr{cerpit},
  Gaul. {carpentoracte}, {Carbantia}, *{karbanto-}; Lat. {corbis}, a
  basket; Norse {hrip}, pannier for peats on horse-back.  Lat.
  {carpentum} (Eng. {carpenter}, etc.), seems borrowed from Gaulish.
  The root idea is "wicker", referring to the basket character
  of the body of these chariots.
--page 72
<carbad.2>, jaw, jaw-bone, so Ir., W. @W{car yr ên} (car of the mouth), Br.
  {karvan}.  The idea is "mouth chariot", from the resemblance
  between the lower jaw and the old wicker chariots.  Loth
  cfs. W. @W{carfan}, beam, rail, row.
<carbh.1>, engrave, carve; from the English.
<carbh.2>, a particular kind of ship or boat (Islay); from Norse
  {karfi}, a galley for the fiords.
<carbhaidh>, carraway-seed; from the English.
<carbhanach>, a carp, Ir. @Ir{carbhán}, Manx {caroo}; from Norse {karfi},
  Eng. @Eng{carp}.
<carcair>, a prison, sewer in a cow-house, Ir. @Ir{carcar}, prison, E.Ir.
  {carcair} (do.); from Lat. {carcer}, prison, barrier.  {cacair} in
  Glenmoriston.
<carcais> a carcase; from the English.
<càrd>, card wool, Ir. @Ir{cardaighim}; from the Eng. @Eng{card}.
<cargo>, a cargo, load; from the English.
<Carghus>, Lent, torment, Ir. @Ir{Corghas}, M.Ir. @MIr{corgus}, W. @W{garawys};
  from Lat. {quadragessima}.
<càrlàg>, a lock of wool (Sh., H.S.D.), @Ref<carla>, a wool-card (Sh. Coneys
  for Ir.); *{card-la-}, from {card} of Eng.  For phonetics, cf.
  @Ref{òirleach}.
<càrlas>, excellence, Ir. @Ir{carlamh}, excellent, *{co-er-lam-}, {erlam},
  clever, *{air-lam}?  For {lam}, see @Ref{ullamh}.
<càrn.1>, heap of stones, cairn, Ir. @Ir{carn}, E.Ir., W. @W{carn}, Br. @Br{karn},
  *{kar-no-}, root {kar}, be hard; Gr. @Gr{κραναός}, rock (@Gr{κρα-}, @Gr{καρ});
  further Eng. @Eng{hard}, {harsh}.  See @Ref{carraig}.
<càrn.2>, a horning.  The G. seems a confusion between @Ref{còrn}, horn,
  Eng. @Eng{horn}, put to the {horn}, and @Ref{càrn.1}.  M`F. gives @Ref<àir chàrn>
  for "outlawed", @Ref<càrn-eaglais>, excommunication.
<càrn.3>, a sledge, cart, peat cart, Ir. @Ir{carr}, dray, waggon, E.Ir. @EIr{carr},
  biga, W. @W{carr}, biga, O.Br. @OBr{carr}, vehiculum (gl.), Gaul.
  {carros}, Latinised into {carrus} (whence, through Fr., Eng.
  {chariot}, {career}, {carry}, @Ref{cargo}, {charge}); from Celt. {karso-}; Lat.
  {currus} ({quors-}), from {qṛs}; Eng. @Eng{horse}, {hurry}.
<carnaid>, red; from Eng. @Eng{carnation}.
<càrnag>, (1) a she-terrier, (2) a small fish found in stony shores at
  ebb-tide.  From @Ref{càrn.1}, cairn.  Terriers were
  used for cairn hunting.
<carr>, the flesh of the seal and whale (Heb.; Carmichael); founded
  on obsolete {carn}, flesh?
<càrr>, the itch, mange, superficial roughness, Ir. @Ir{carr}; @Ref<carrach>,
  scabby, M.Ir. @MIr{carrach}, *{karsâko-}, from {kars}, be rough, hard;
  cf. Eng. @Eng{harsh} (*{horsqs}), and {hard}, Lit. {krasta}, the itch
  (*{kors-ta-}); further root {kar}, to be hard, rough.  For <càrr>,
  rocky shelf, Ir. @Ir{carr}, rock, see @Ref{carraig}.
--page 73
<carrachan>, a frog-fish, called "cobler", Ir. @Ir{carrachán}, the rock
  fish called cobler (Coneys).  From @Ref{carr}, a rock.  Also the
  word means "the wild liquorice root" - @Ref{carra-meille}, q.v.
<carragh>, a pillar stone, Ir. @Ir{carrthadh}, {cartha}, E.Ir. @EIr{corthe}.  The
  root, despite the vocalic difficulty caused by the E.Ir. form,
  is likely the same as in @Ref{carraig}; yet cf. {kor} of @Ref{cuir}, set.
<carraid>, conflict; from the root {kars} in @Ref{càrr}, "rough-work"?
<carraig>, rock, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{carric}, W. @W{careg}, O.W. @OW{carrecc}, Br.
  {karrek}, *{karsekki-} (so Rhys, @ExtRef{R.C.;17;102}, who thinks W.
  borrowed), from root {kars}, hard, rough; Nor. {herren},
  hard, stiff, {harren}, hard, Eng. @Eng{harsh}, {hard} (root {kar}).  See
  @Ref{càrr}.
<carra-meille>, wild liquorice, wood pease, Ir. @Ir{carra-mhilis}.  The
  name is explained as "knots of honey", the {carra} being the
  same as @Ref{càrr}, and {meille} the gen. of @Ref{mil}.  Hence Sc. {carmele}, etc.
<carran>, spurrey, spergula arvensis, Ir. @Ir{carrán}, scurvy grass.  From
  the root {kars} of @Ref{càrr}.  <carran> also means a "shrimp", and is
  of the same origin.
<carran-creige>, the conger; see @Ref{carran} above.
<carrasan>, hoarseness, wheezing, Ir. @Ir{carsán}; from the root {kars}, be
  rough.  See @Ref{càrr}.  Cf. @Gr{κόρνζα}, catarrh, {rotz}.
<càrt>, a quart, Ir. @Ir{cárt}; from the Eng. @Eng{quart}, Lat. {quartus}.
<cartan>, a small brown insect that eats into the flesh, Ir. @Ir{cartán}, a
  small brown insect that eats into the flesh, a crab.  A
  Gadelicised form of @Ref{partan}, q.v.
<carthannach>, affectionate, charitable, Ir. @Ir{carthannach}; from Lat.
  {caritas}.
<carthuinnich>, dwell apart as in a cave, separate (M`F.).  Cf.
  @Ref<caruinnean>, refuse of threshed corn, @Ref<caruinnich>, winnow.
  Possibly from the root {kar}, separate, a form of the root of
  @Ref{sgar}, q.v.
<caruibh>, @Ref<an caruibh>, beside, near.  This is the dat.pl. of @Ref{car}.
<cas.1>, foot, leg, Ir. @Ir{cos}, O.Ir. @OIr{coss}, W. @W{coes}, *{koksâ}; Lat. {coxa}, hip;
  M.H.G. {hahse}, bend of the knee; Skr. {kákshas}, armpit.
<cas.2>, steep, sudden, Ir. @Ir{casach}, an ascent, M.Ir. @MIr{cass}, rapid, *{kasto-};
  Eng. @Eng{haste}.
<cas.3>, curled, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{cas}, curly, {casaim}, flecto; *{qasto-}, root {qas};
  Norse {haddr} ({has-da-}), hair, Eng. @Eng{hair}; Lit. {kasa}, hair-plait,
  Ch.Sl. {kosa}, hair (Kluge).  Stokes compares it with Lat.
  {quasillum}, a basket, root {quas}.
<cas.4>, gnash the teeth, Ir. @Ir{cais}, hate, W. @W{câs}, hate, Br. @Br{cas}, *{cad-s-to-};
  Eng. @Eng{hate}, Ger. {hass}, Got. {hatis}.  Of the same ultimate origin
  as @Ref{cas.2}, sudden (Strachan).
--page 74
<cas.5>, fire (as a stone) (Suth.), seemingly founded on Eng. @Eng{cast}.
  Cf. {casadh ar a chéile} = met (Ir.).
<càs>, a difficulty, Ir. @Ir{cás}; from Lat. {casus} (Eng. {case}).
<casach>, fishing tackle (part attached to hook): from @Ref{cas.3}.
<casad>, <casad>, a cough, Ir. @Ir{casachdach}, W. @W{pâs}, {peswch}, Br. @Br{pas},
  *{qasto-}; Eng. @Eng{host}, Ag.S. {hvósta}, Ger. {husten}; Lit. {kósiu};
  Skr. {kâsate}, coughs.
<casag>, cassock, Ir. @Ir{casóg}; from the Eng.  The E.Ir. word is
  {casal}, from Lat. {casula}.
<casaid>, a complaint, accusation, Ir. @Ir{casoid}, O.Ir. @OIr{cossóit}.  The
  word is a compound, beginning with {con}, and seemingly of
  the same origin as @Ref{faosaid}, q.v.  Stokes thinks that the word
  is borrowed from the Lat. {causatio}; this is not likely, however.
  Root {sen}, W. @W{cynhenn}, quarrel.
<casair>, sea drift, Ir. @Ir{casair}, a shower, E.Ir. @EIr{casair}, hail, W. @W{cesair}
  (do.), Br. @Br{kazerc'h} (do.), *{kassri-}, *{kad-tri-}; from root {cad} as
  in Lat. {cado}, fall.  The Ir. and G. (?) {casáir}, phosphorescence,
  seems to be the same word.
<casan.1>, a path, Ir. @Ir{casán}; from @Ref{cas.1}, foot.
<casan.2>, a rafter, roof-tree; from @Ref{cas.1}?
<casg>, see @Ref{caisg}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<casgair>, slay, butcher, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{coscar}, victory, destruction;
  *{co-scar}; see @Ref{sgar}.
<casgairt>, see @Ref{casgair}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<casnaid>, chips of wood (Arm.), Ir. @Ir{casnaidh}; *{co-}+@Ref{snaidh}, q.v.
<caspanach>, parallel (Sh.), Ir. @Ir{cospanach} (O'R.); *{co-spann}; see
  @Ref{spann.1}.
<castan>, a chestnut; from Lat. {castanea}, through M.Eng. {castane},
  {chestnut}.
<castaran>, a measure for butter (quarter stone); from the Eng. @Eng{castor}.
<castreaghainn>, the straw on a kiln below the grain (Arm., not
  H.S.D.):
<cat>, a cat, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{catt}, W. @W{cath}, Corn. @Corn{kat}, Br. @Br{kaz}, Gaul.
  {Cattos}; Lat. {catta}, perhaps also {catulus}; Eng. @Eng{cat}, Ger. {katze},
  etc.  It is a word of doubtful origin; possibly, however,
  Celtic, and applied first to the wild cat, then to the tame
  Egyptian cat introduced in the early centuries of the Christian
  era.
<cata>, @Ref<càta>, sheep-cot, pen; from Eng. @Eng{cot}.
<catadh>, @Ref<catachadh>, taming, @Ref<càtadh> (M`F.); cf. {tataich}.
<catag>, potatoe cellar (Dialectic); see @Ref{cata}.
<catas>, refuse at carding of wool, Ir. @Ir{cadás}, cotton, scraping of
  linen rags; from Eng. @Eng{caddis}.  See further under @Ref{caiteas}.
<cath>, battle, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cath}, W. @W{cad}, O.W. @OW{cat}, Corn. @Corn{cas}, Gaul.
  {catu-}; O.H.G. {hadu-}, fight, Ag.S. {heaðo-}, Ger. {hader}, contention;
  Skr. {çatru}, enemy; Gr. @Gr{κότος}, wrath.
--page 75
<càth>, chaff, husks of corn, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cáith}, W. @W{codem}, a bag, husk,
  pod (?), *{kûti-}, root {kât}, {kat}, as in @Ref{caith}, spend, cast.
<cathachadh>, provoking, accusing, fighting, Ir. @Ir{cathaighim}; from
  @Ref{cath}, fight.
<cathadh>, snow-drift, Ir. @Ir{cáthadh}, snow-drift, sea-drift; cf. M.Ir.
  {cúa}, gen. {cúadh}, W. @W{cawod}, O.Corn. {cowes}, nimbus, Br. @Br{kaouad},
  *{kavat} (Stokes); allied to Eng. @Eng{shower}.  It is possible to
  refer the G. word to the root of @Ref{caith}, @Ref{càth}.
<cathair.1>, a city, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cathair}, O.Ir. @OIr{cathir} (*{kastrex}), W.
  {caer}, Br. @Br{kaer}, *{kastro-}; Lat. {castrum}, fort (Stokes).  The
  root seems to be @Ref{cat}, {cats}; the phonetics are the same as in
  @Ref{piuthar}, for the final part of the word.
<cathair.2>, a chair, Ir. @Ir{cathaoir}, E.Ir. @EIr{catháir}, W. @W{cadair}, Br. @Br{kador};
  from Lat. {cathedra}, whence also, through Fr., Eng. @Eng{chair}.
<cathan>, a wild goose with black bill (Heb.); see @Ref{cadhan}.
<cathan-aodaich>, a web (M`D.):
<càthar>, mossy ground; see @Ref{càir.3}.
<cathlunn>, a corn (Sh.; not in H.S.D.); formed on Lat. {callum}.
  See @Ref{calum}.
<catluibh>, cudwort; see @Ref{cadh-luibh}.
<cè.1>, @Ref<cèath>, cream, M.Ir. @MIr{ceó}, milk; cf. Br. @Br{koavenn}, which suggests
  a form {keivo-} (cf. @Ref{glé} from {gleivo-}), root {kei}, {skei}, shade, cover,
  as in Gr. @Gr{σκιά}, shadow, Ger. {schemen} (do.)?  The Br. @Br{koavenn}
  has been refered to *{co+hufen}, W. @W{hufen}, cream.  Cf. @Ref{ceò},
  mist, "covering".
<cè.2>, give?
<cè.3>, spouse (Carm.), Ir. @Ir{cé}:
<cé>, the earth, used only in the phrase @Ref<an cruinne cé>, the (round)
  earth, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cé}, {for bith ché}, on this earth.  The {cé} is
  supposed to be for "this", from the pronomial {kei}, Gr.
  @Gr{κεῖνος}, he, Lat. {ce}, {cis}, Eng. @Eng{he}.  The root {kei}, go, move (Lat.
  {cio}, Gr. @Gr{κíω}), has also been suggested.
---gjk (1.14) moved entry. originally located between <cè.1> and <cè.2>.
<ceaba>, @Ref<ceibe>, the iron part of a spade or other delving instrument;
  see @Ref{caibe}.
<cèabhar>, a fine breeze (Heb.):
<ceabhar> (Carm.), sky, (Prov.) {ci'ar}:
<ceach>, an interjection of dislike; see the next word.
<ceacharra>, dirty, mean, obstreperous (Carm.), Ir. @Ir{ceachair}, dirt,
  M.Ir. @MIr{cecharda}, *{kekari-}; from {kek}, the @Ref{e} form of the root
  {kak} seen in @Ref{cac}, q.v.
<ceachladh>, digging, Ir. @Ir{ceachlaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{ro-cechladatar}, suffoderunt,
  *{ce-clad-}, a reduplicated or perfect form of the root {clad} of G.
  @Ref{cladh}, q.v.
<cead>, permission, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cet}, *{ces-do-}; Lat. {cēdo}, I yield (for
  {ces-dô}).
--page 76
<ceadan>, bunch of wool, Ir. @Ir{ceadach}, cloth, coarse cloth, W. @W{cadach},
  clout.  Rhys regards W. as borrowed from Ir.  For all, cf.
  @Ref{cadadh}, @Ref{caiteas}.
<ceadha>, the part of the plough on which the share is fixed.  Also
  @Ref<ceidhe>.  Both words are used for Eng. @Eng{quay}.
<ceafan>, a frivolous person (Dialectic):
<ceàird>, a trade, E.Ir. @EIr{cerd}; see @Ref{ceàrd}.
<ceal.1>, stupor, forgetfulness, Ir. @Ir{ceal}, forgetfulness; from the root
  {qel} of @Ref{ceil}, conceal.  Cf. E.Ir. @EIr{cel}, death.  {ceal}, end (Carm.).
†<ceal.2>, same, similar hue (Carm.):
<cealaich.1>, the fire-place of a kiln:
<cealaich.2>, eat (Kirk), Ir. @Ir{cealaim}; root {qel} as in Lat. {colo}?
<cealair>, a virago (Badenoch):
<cealg>, guile, treachery, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{celg}, *{kelgâ}; Arm. {keλch^c},
  hypocrisy.  The further root is {qel} of @Ref{ceil}.
<ceall>, g. @Ref<cille>, a church, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cell}; from Lat. {cella}, a cell,
  a hermit's cell especially, whence the Gadelic use.  Hence
  @Ref<cealloir>, superior of a cell, and the name Mackellar.  "A
  retired spot" (Hend.).
<cealtar>, broad-cloth, Ir. @Ir{cealtair}, clothes, E.Ir. @EIr{celtar}, {celt}, raiment;
  from {qel}, cover, as in @Ref{ceil}, q.v.
<ceana>, whither, for @Ref{c'iona}, @Ref{c'ionadh}?  Cf. Ir. @Ir{cá h-ionad}.  See
  @Ref{ionadh}.
<ceanalta>, mild, kind, so Ir.; from *{cen}, as in @Ref{cion.2}, †{cean}, love,
  desire.  See @Ref{cion.2}.
<ceangal>, a tie, binding, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cengal}, W. @W{cengl}; from Lat.
  {cingulum}, vb. {cingo}, I bind, Eng. @Eng{cincture}.
<ceann>, head, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cend}, {cenn}, W., Br. @Br{penn}, Gaul. {Penno-},
---JTM: changed Gaul, to Gaul.
  *{qenno}.  Perhaps for {qen-no-}, root {qen} (labialised), begin,
  Ch.Sl. {koni}, beginning, as in @Ref{ceud.1}, first.  The difficulty is
  that the other labialising languages and the Britonic branch
  otherwise show no trace of labialisation for {qen}.  Windisch,
  followed by Brugmann, suggested a stem {kvindo-}, I.E. root
  {kvi}, Skr. {çvi}, swell, Gr. @Gr{Píνδος}, Pindus Mount; but the root
  vowel is not @Ref{i}, even granting the possible labialisation of {kvi},
  which does not really take place in Greek.  Hence @Ref<ceannag>,
  a bottle of hay, @Ref<ceannaich>, buy (="heading" or reckoning
  by the head; cf. Dial. <ceann>, sum up), @Ref<ceannaich>, head-wind
  (Hend.), @Ref<ceannas>, vaunting (Hend.).
<ceannach>, a purchasing, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cennaigim}, I buy, O.Ir.
  {cennige}, lixa, {caingen}, negotium.
<ceannairc>, rebellion, turbulence, so Ir.; *{ceann+arc}; for root
  @Ref{arc}, see @Ref{adharc}.  For meaning cf. Eng. @Eng{head}strong, W.
  {pen}ffest (do.).
--page 77
<ceannard>, commander, chief, Ir. @Ir{ceannárd}, arrogant, commanding,
  "high-headed", from @Ref{ceann} and @Ref{àrd}; Manx {kinnoort}, Ir. @Ir{ceannphort},
  commander, authority, head post or city: @Ref{ceann}+@Ref{port.1}.
<ceannrach>, @Ref<ceannraig>, (Cam.), a brindle or horse's head-gear, Ir.
  {ceannrach}; from @Ref{ceann}+@Ref{rach}.  For @Ref{rach} (root {rig}), see
  @Ref{cuibhreach}, @Ref{àrachas}.
<ceannsaich>, subdue, tame, Ir. @Ir{ceannsaighim}; from @Ref{ceannas}, superiority,
  "head-ness", from @Ref{ceann} and the abst. termination @Ref{as}.
  Similarly {ceannsal}, rule.
<ceap.1>, a block, shoemaker's last, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cepp}, W. @W{cyff}, Br. @Br{kef};
  from Lat. {cippus}.
<ceap.2>, catch, stop.  This word seems borrowed from the Sc. {kep}, of
  like meaning, a bye-form of Eng. @Eng{keep}.  The Ir. @Ir{ceap}, bound,
  bind, stop (?), seems from @Ref{ceap.1} above.
†<ceapach>, a tillage plot, Ir. @Ir{ceapach}.  This Stokes refers to a
  Celtic {keppo-}, garden, root {kep}, {kā}, Lat. {campus}, Gr. @Gr{κῆπος},
  garden, Ger. {hube}, piece of land.  Satisfactory though the
  meaning be, the derivation is doubtful as involving the preservation
  of {p}, even though flanked by a second {p} (or {-nó},
  i.e. {kep-nó-}, which is still more doubtful).  Hence the common
  place name @Ref<Keppock>.
<ceapag>, a verse, an impromptu verse, carelessly sung verse, E.Ir.
  {cepóc}, a chorus song: a rare word in Ir., and said to be Sc.
  Gaelic for Ir. @Ir{aidbsi}, great chorus.  From @Ref{ceap.2}, catch?  cf.
  Eng. @Eng{catch}, a chorus verse.  Zimmer suggests that it stands
  {Ce Póc}, "kiss here", (?) sung by the girls as a refrain at
  gatherings!
<ceapaire>, bread covered with butter, etc. Ir. @Ir{ceapaire}; from @Ref{ceap.1},
  a block.  Cf. @Ref<ceapag>, a wheel-barrow wheel.
<cearb>, piece, article of clothing, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cerp}, cutting, {cerbaim};
  *{kṛbh}, {skṛbh}; Gr. @Gr{κάρφος}, twig, Eng. @Eng{shrub}; *{(s)ker}, cut,
  divide.  Cf. W. @W{carp}, rag, cerpyn.  Bezzenberger cfs. M.H.G.
  {herb}, asper.  St. now {skerb}, Eng. @Eng{sharp}.
<cearc>, a hen, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{cerc}, *{cercâ}; from I.E. {qerqo}, to sound,
  hence "a noise-making bird"; Gr. @Gr{κέρκος}, a cock, @Gr{κρέξ}, a
  fowl; Lat. {querquedula}, a teal, O.Pruss. {kerko}, a diver; Skr.
  {kṛka-vâkus}, a cock.
<cearcall>, a hoop, so Ir.; from L.Lat. {circulus}, {circullus}, a hoop,
  from {circulus}, a circle.
<ceàrd>, a craftsman, Ir. @Ir{céard}, E.Ir. @EIr{cerd}, W. @W{cerdd}, art; Lat. {cerdo},
  craftsman; Gr. @Gr{κέρδος}, gain.
<ceàrdach>, a smithy, Ir. @Ir{céardcha}, O.Ir. @OIr{cerddchae}; from {cerd}+{cae},
  the latter word {cae} meaning a house in Ir., a Celtic {kaio-n},
  allied to Eng. @Eng{home}.
--page 78
<ceard-dubhan>, scarabæbus, dung-beetle, hornet (H.S.D. for form),
  @Ref<ceardaman> (M`A.); see @Ref{cearnabhan}.  {cearr-dubhan} (Carm.),
  "wrong-sided little black one".
<cearmanta>, tidy (Arm.); {cearmanaich}, make tidy (Perth):
<ceàrn>, a corner, quarter, Ir. @Ir{cearn}, {cearna}, angle, corner, E.Ir. @EIr{cern};
  evidently an @Ref{e} form of the stem found in {corn}, horn, q.v.
<cearnabhan>, a hornet, Ir. @Ir{cearnabhán}; from *{cerno-}.  Cf. Eng.
  {hornet} (*{kṛs-en-}), Lat. {crabro}.
<ceàrr>, wrong, left (hand), E.Ir. @EIr{cerr}, *{kerso-}; Lat. {cerritus}, crazed;
  Gr. @Gr{ἐγκάρσιος}, slantwise; Lit. {skersas}, crooked.
<ceàrrach>, a gamester, Ir. @Ir{cearrbhach}, a gamester, dexterous
  gambler.  Cf. G. @Ref<ceàrrbhag>, @Ref<cearrag>, the left-hand, the use
  of which was considered in plays of chance as "sinister".
<ceart>, right, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cert}; Lat. {certus}, certain, sure, {cerno},
  discern; Gr. @Gr{κρíνω}, judge, @Gr{κριτές}, a judge, Eng. @Eng{critic}.
<ceasad>, a complaint (M`F.), Ir. @Ir{ceasacht}, grumbling, M.Ir.
  {cesnaighim}, complain, {ces}, sorrow, *{qes-to-}; Lat. {questus},
  {queror}, I complain, {querela}, Eng. @Eng{quarrel}.
†<ceasg>, floss (Carm.), animal with long flossy hair or wool, Ir.
  {ceaslach}, long hair or wool on fleece legs.  See @Ref{ceus.2}.
<ceasnaich>, examine, catechise, Ir. @Ir{ceasnuighim}; from Lat. {quæstio},
  {quæstionis}, Eng. @Eng{question}.  Stokes (Bk.of Lis.) has suggested
  that the Lat. and Gadelic are cognate; though possible ({qais},
  {qis} may become by umlaut {ces} in G.), it is improbable from
  the stem form in {n} persisting in the G. verb.
<ceathach>, mist; this is really the old stem of @Ref{ceò}, mist, E.Ir.
  {ciach}, q.v.  Ir. @Ir{ceathach}, showery, is from @Ref{cith.1}, a shower.
<ceathairne>, yeomanry, the portion of a population fit for warfare;
  see @Ref{ceatharn}.
<ceatharn>, a troop, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ceithern}, *{keternâ}; Lat. {caterua},
  troop, {catêna}, a chain; O.Sl. {ceta}, company (Stokes).  It
  has also been regarded as borrowed from Lat. {quaternio},
  which in the Vulg. means a "body of four soldiers", quaternion.
  Hence Eng. @Eng{cateran}, {kern}.
<ceidhe>, quay, coulter-place, Ir. @Ir{ceigh}, quay.  See @Ref{ceadha}.
<ceig.1>, a mass of shag, clot, @Ref<ceigein>, a tuft, a fat man.  From
  Scandinavian {kagge}, round mass, {keg}, corpulent man or
  animal, whence Eng. @Eng{keg}; Norse {kaggi}, cask, Nor.
  {kagge}, round mass.
<ceig.2>, a kick; from the Eng.
<ceil>, conceal, Ir., {ceilim}, O.Ir. @OIr{celim}, W. @W{celu}, I.E. {qel}; Lat. {cêle},
  Eng. con-{ceal}; Ag.S. {helan}, hide, Eng. @Eng{Hell}; Gr. @Gr{καλύπτω},
  hide; Skr. {kála}, darkness.
<céile>, spouse, fellow, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{céle}, socius, W. @W{cilydd} ({y gilydd}
  = {a chéile} of G. = {eguille} of Br.), *{keiljo-}, "way-farer", from
--page 79
  {kei}, go (Lat. {cio}, move, Gr. @Gr{κíω}, go, {kínéw}, move, {kinetics}.
  The idea is the same as in Ir. @Ir{sétig}, wife, from {sét}, way.
  Strachan thinks that G. and W. demand a stem {ceglio-}; and
  Dr Stokes thinks that, if {céle}, servus, is different from {céle},
  fellow, it must come from {kak-lio-} (better {keklio-}), and be
  allied to Lat. {cacula}, a servant.  Hence @Ref<céilidh>, a gossiping
  visit or meeting.
<ceileach>, martial (H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{ceallach}, war, M.Ir. @MIr{cellach}, war;
  Teut. {hildi-}, war, Lat. {per-cellere}, hit.
<ceileir>, chirping of birds, Ir. @Ir{ceileabhar}, {ceileabhrach}, musical,
  M.Ir. @MIr{ceilebradh eoin} singing of birds, E.Ir. @EIr{celebrad}, a
  celebrating or observance, a welcome of joy; from Lat.
  {celebratio}.
<céillidh>, wise, sover, Ir. @Ir{céillidhe}; from @Ref{ciall}.
<ceilp>, kelp; from Eng.
<céin>, remote; really the oblique form of @Ref{cian}, q.v.
<céir.1>, wax, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{céir}, W. @W{cwyr}, O.W. @OW{kuyr}, Corn. @Corn{coir}, Br. @Br{coar};
  from Lat. {cêra}, wax.
<céir.2>, @Ref<céire>, the buttock; see @Ref{péire}.
<ceireanaich>, fondle, make much of (Perth); cf. @Ref{ceirein}, plaster.
<ceirein>, a plaster, a "clout", Ir., M.Ir., {céirín}, a plaster; from
  @Ref{céir.1}, wax.  Eng. @Eng{cerate}.
<ceirtle>, a clew, ball of yarn, Ir. @Ir{ceirsle} (so G. too), {ceirtlín}, O.Ir.
  {certle}, glomus, *{kertilliâ}; from I.E. {qert}, wind, bend; Skr.
  {kart}, spin; Lat. {cartilago}, Eng. @Eng{cartilage}; Gr. @Gr{κάρταλος},
  basket; Eng. @Eng{hurdle}.
<céis>, a case, hamper; from Eng. @Eng{case}. Ir. @Ir{ceis}, basket, M.Ir. @MIr{ceiss},
  is a different word, possibly allied to, if not borrowed from,
  Lat. {cista} (Stokes).  From Ir. @Ir{ceis} comes @Ref<ceis-chrann>, polypody,
  given in H.S.D. from O'R.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{cass}, basket,
  Lat. {quasillus}.
<ceisd>, a question, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ceist}; from Lat. {quæstio}.  Hence
  @Ref<ceisdein>, a sweetheart, founded on "ceisd mo chridhe" -
  darling (i.e., question, anxiety) of my heart.
<céiseach>, large, corpulent woman; see @Ref{ceòs}.
<Céitein>, May, O.Ir. @OIr{cétam} (g. {cétaman}), {cetsoman} ({cetshaman}) in
  Corn.Gl., where it is explained as {cét-sam-sín}, the first weather-motion
  of {sam} or summer.  The word means the "first of
  summer" - {cét+sam-}, the {sam} of @Ref{samhradh}, q.v.  The termination
  is possibly influenced by other time words.  See
  {Samhainn}.
<ceithir>, four, Ir. @Ir{ceathair} (n.), {ceithre} (adj.), O.Ir. @OIr{cethir}, W.
  {pedwar}, Corn. @Corn{peswar}, Br. @Br{pevar}, Gaul. {petor-}, *{qetveres}, I.E.
  {qetvôr}; Lat. {quatuor}; Gr. @Gr{τέτταρες}; Got. {fidvôr}, Eng. @Eng{four};
  Lit. {keturi}; Skr. {catvâras}.
--page 80
<ceò>, mist, Ir. @Ir{ceó}, E.Ir. @EIr{ceó}, g. {ciach}, *{cevox}, g. *{gevocos}, I.E.
  {sqevo-}, Lat. {obscūrus}, Norse {ský}, cloud, Eng. @Eng{sky}.  The idea
  is "covering".
<ceòb>, a dark nook, corner:
<ceòban>, small drizzle; @Ref{ceò}+@Ref{boinne} or {-bainne}, "mist-drop".  The
  Ir. is {ceóbhrán}, for @Ref{ceò}+@Ref{braon}.  This last is G. @Ref<ciùran>, q.v.
  Hence @Ref<ceòpach> (for @Ref<ceòbnach>?).  Also @Ref<ceòpan>.  Ir. @Ir{ciabhrán},
  drizzle, fog, M.Ir. @MIr{ciabor}, mist.
<ceòl>, music, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ceól}, g. {ciúil}, *{kipolo-}, a Gadelicised form of
  *{pipolo}; onomatopoetic root {pīp}, Lat. {pîpilo}, chirp, {pipilum},
  outcry, {pîpo}, chirp, Ag.S. {pípe} , Eng. @Eng{pipe} (hence W. @W{pib}, G.
  @Ref{pìob}, etc.).  Stokes and Rhys have given a Celtic {qeqlo-} for
  stem, allied to W. @W{pib}, pipe.  For phonetics, see @Ref{feòil}.  Stokes
  now suggests alliance with Ger. {heulen}, hoot, howl, O.H.G.
  {hiuwilôn}.
<ceòs>, the hip, podex; see @Ref{ceus.1}, poples.  Hence @Ref<ceòsach>, broad-skirted,
  bulky, clumsy.
<ceòsan>, burr or light down of feathers; see @Ref{ceus.2}, wool of legs, etc.
<ceud.1>, first, Ir. @Ir{céad}, O.Ir. @OIr{cét}, W. @W{cynt}, formerly, {cyntaf}, first, Br.
  {kent}, {kenta} (do.), Gaul. {Cintu-}, *{kentu-}; allied to W. @W{cann},
  with Gr. @Gr{κατά}, down, against (={kṇta}); Lat. {contra}.  Further
  allied is possibly ({and this is the usual derivation}) I.E. {qen},
  begin, Lat. {re-cens}), Eng. @Eng{recent}; Gr. @Gr{καινός} (=@Gr{κανιός}), new;
  Skr. {kaná}, young; Ch.Sl. {koni}, beginning.  Some again have
  compared Teut. {hind} as in Eng. @Eng{hindmost}.
<ceud.2>, a hundred, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cét}, W. @W{cant}, Corn. @Corn{cans}, Br. @Br{kant},
  *{kṇto-n}; Lat. {centum}; Gr. @Gr{ἑκατόν} (={se-kṇton}); Got. {hund},
  Eng. @Eng{hund}-red; Lit. {szìmtas}; Skr. {çatám}.
<ceudfadh>, sense, Ir. @Ir{céadfadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{cétbaid}, W. @W{canfod}, to perceive,
  *{cant-buti-}, "with-being", from @Ref{ceud.1}, with first, and @Ref{bu}, be.
<ceudna>, the same, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cétna}, *{centinio-s}; from @Ref{ceud.1}, first.
<ceum>, a step, Ir. @Ir{céim}, O.Ir. @OIr{ceimm}, W., Corn. @Corn{cam}, O.W. @OW{cemmein},
  gradibus, Br. @Br{kam}, *{kṇgmen-}, verb *{kengô}, I go, Ir. @Ir{cingim},
  Gaul. {Cingeto}-rix, "king of marching men" - of warriors:
  I.E. {khenℊ}, limp; Ger. {hinken}, limp; Skr. {khañj}, limp.
<ceus.1>, ham, polpes: *{cencso-}; Lit. {kenkle}, hough, bend of the knee,
  {kinka}, knee joint; Ag.S. {hóh} (={hanχ}), Eng. @Eng{hough} (Strachan
  for Lit.).  The gen. is @Ref<ceòis>, whence @Ref{ceòs}, etc.
<ceus.2>, the coarse part of the wool on sheep's legs (Heb.), M.Ir.
  {céslach}; from @Ref{ceus.1}, ham.
<ceus.3>, crucify, Ir. @Ir{céasaim}, {ceusaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{céssaim}, suffer, *{kentsô},
  suffer: I.E. {qentho}; Gr. @Gr{πένθος}, @Gr{πάθος}, suffering, Eng. @Eng{pathos};
  Lit. {kenczù}, suffering
<ceutach>, becoming; see @Ref{ciatach}.
--page 81
<cha>, @Ref<cha'n>, not, Ir. @Ir{nocha n-}, O.Ir. @OIr{ní con} aspirating.  The
  particle @Ref{no} or {nu} is no part of this negative: only {ní} and {con},
  "non quod", {con} being the same as @Ref{gu'n}.  Aspirating power
  of it is as yet unexplained.  Ulster Ir. @Ir{cha}.
<chaidh>, went, ivit, Ir. @Ir{cochuaidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{dochóid}, he went, *{coud-};
  Skr. {codati}, make haste, {codayati}, drive, {códa}, a goad; Eng.
  {shoot}.  See @Ref{deach}.
<chaoidh>, for ever, Ir. @Ir{choidhche}, E.Ir. @EIr{chaidche}, {coidchi}; for {co-aidche},
  {gu oidhche}, "till night".
<cheana>, already, Ir. @Ir{cheana}, E.Ir. @EIr{chena}, in sooth, quidem, jam,
  {ol chena}, {ar chena}, O.Ir. @OIr{cene}, {olchene}; from {cen-é}, "without
  this", root in @Ref{gun}, without, @Ref{cion.1}, want.
<chì>, will see, Ir. @Ir{chidhim}, {chím}, O.Ir. @OIr{atchí}, videt, *{ad-cesiô},
  *{kesiô}; Skr. {caksh}, see, for *{ca-kas}; Lat. {canus} (*{cas-no-}?),
  grey; Ag.S. {hasu}, grey, Eng. @Eng{hare}.  See @Ref{chunnaic}, @Ref{faic}.  The
  aspiration of {chì} is due to the lost @Ref{ad-} initial, which is
  confused with the verbal particle @Ref{do.2}, @Ref{a.7}.
---gjk (1.13) original headword: <chi>
<cho>, @Ref<co.2>, as, so, Ir. @Ir{comh}, W. @W{cyn}; from {com}, with.  See @Ref{comh-}.
  Gaelic "Cho dubh ri feannaig" = Welsh "Cyn ddued a'r frân".
<chon>, to; dialectic form of @Ref{gu}.  The {n} belongs to the article.
  Also @Ref{thun}; q.v.  Compare @Ref{chugad} and @Ref{thugad} to {chon} and
  @Ref{thun} in phonetics.
<chuala>, heard, Ir. @Ir{do chuala}, O.Ir. @OIr{rochúala}, W. @W{cigleu}, *{kuklova};
  root {kleu} as in @Ref{cluinn}, q.v.
<chugad>, towards thee, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{chucut}, *{cu-cu-t}, where the
  prep. {cu} or @Ref{gu}, to, is reduplicated.  See @Ref{gu}.  The {t} or {-ut} is
  for @Ref{tu}, q.v.  So with @Ref<chuga>, @Ref<chuige>, etc.
<chum>, @Ref<chùm>, @Ref<a chum>, to, for, in order to, Ir. @Ir{chum}, {do chum}, O.Ir.
  {dochum n-}, {dochom n-}; an idiomatic use of {com}, side?  Cf.
  Eng. @Eng{side}, {beside}.
<chun>, to, until; see @Ref{chon}.
<chunnaic>, saw, Ir. @Ir{chonacadar}, they saw, O.Ir. @OIr{conaca}, vidi; from
  {con}+@Ref{faic}; for {con}, see @Ref{comh-}, and see @Ref{faic}.  The old past was
  @Ref<chunnairc>, still used in Ir. as {chonnairc}, from {con}+@Ref{dearc.4}, q.v.
<cia>, who, what, Ir. @Ir{cia}, O.Ir. @OIr{cía}, W. @W{pwy}, Corn. @Corn{pyu}, Br. @Br{piu}, *{qei};
  Lat. {qui} (Old Lat. {quei}).  See further under @Ref{co.1}.
<ciabh>, a lock of hair, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ciab}: *{kes-abu-}, {kes} of @Ref{cas.3}?
<Ciadaoin>, @Ref<Di-ciadaoin>, Wednesday, Ir. @Ir{Céadaoin}, O.Ir. @OIr{cétáin},
  first fast, "Day of the First Fast".  The first weekly fast
  was the latter half of Wednesday, the next was Friday -
  {Di-h-aoine}.  Thursday is the day "Between two fasts" -
  @Ref{Diardaoin}, q.v.  See further under @Ref{Di-}.
<ciagach>, sly-jumoured (Dialectic):
<cial>, side or brim of a vessel; see @Ref{ciobhull}.
--page 82
<ciall>, sense, understanding, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ciall}, W. @W{pwyll}, Corn. @Corn{pull},
  Br. @Br{poell}, *{qeislâ}: I.E. {qei}, observe, see, shine; Gr. @Gr{πινυτός},
  wise; Skr. {cetati}, perceive, {cittam}, thought, {cinōti}, discover;
  further Ger. {heiter}, clear.
<ciamhair>, sad (Sh., Arm.), Ir. @Ir{ciamhair}, {ciamhaire} (O'Cl., O'Br.):
<cian>, remote, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cían}, *{keino-}; from the pronominal
  root {kei}, there, Gr. @Gr{κε̑ινος}, ille, Lat. {cis}, {citra}, Eng. @Eng{he}.  Others
  have referred it to root {qei}, {qi}, Skr. {ciras}, long, Got. {hveila},
  time, Eng. @Eng{while}.  Hence @Ref<cianail>, sad, lonesome, Ir. @Ir{cianamhuil}.
<cianog>, a small measure of arable land (Heb.: H.S.D.); see @Ref{cionag}.
<ciar>, dusky, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cíar}, *{keiro-s}, "shadowy"; root {sqhei}, Gr.
  @Gr{σκιερός}, shady, @Gr{σκιά}, shadow, Skr. {châyā́}, shadow, Ag.S.
  {scimo} (do.).  It has been compared to Eng. @Eng{hoar}, Norse {hárr},
  but the vowels do not suit.
<cias>, g. @Ref<ceòis>, border, skirt, fringe:
<ciatach>, @Ref<ciatfach>, elegant, becoming, Ir. @Ir{céadfadhach}, discreet,
  belonging to the senses; from {deudfadh}, q.v.
<cibein>, rump (of a bird, M`D.), Ir. @Ir{cibín}, the rump (Con.).  Cf. Ir.
  {giob}, a tail.
<cìbeir>, a shepherd; from Sc., Eng. @Eng{keeper}.
<cibhearg>, a rag, a little ragged woman (Sh.):
<cidhis>, a mask, vizard (M`D.), @Ref<luchd cidhis>, masqueraders; from
  Sc. {gyis}, a mask, {gysars}, masqueraders, M.Eng. {gīsen}, to
  dress, Eng. @Eng{guise}, {disguise}; all from O.Fr. {guise}, modus,
  {desguiser}, disguise.  The Sc. was directly borrowed in the
  Stuart period.
<cigil>, tickle (Sh.); see @Ref{ciogail}.
<cìleag>, a diminutive, weakly person (Arg.):
<cìlean>, a large codfish; from Norse {keila}, gadus longus or "long
  cod".  Also @Ref<cilig> (Sutherland).
<cill>, a church; locative case of @Ref{ceall}, q.v., used for the most part
  in place-names.
<cillein>, a concealed heap, repository, Ir. @Ir{cillín}, a purse or store of
  hoarded cash (O'B.), dim of @Ref{ceall}, cell, church, q.v.
<cineal> offspring, clan, Ir. @Ir{cineul}, O.Ir. @OIr{cenél}, W. @W{cenedl}, O.W.
  {cenetl}, Corn. @Corn{kinethel}, *{kenetlo-n}: I.E. {qen}, begin; Gr. @Gr{καινός},
  new (@Gr{κανjός}); Lat. re-{cens}, Eng. @Eng{recent}; Ch.Sl. {koni}, beginning;
  Skr. {kaná}, young.
<cinn>, grow, increase, spring from, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cinim}, spring from,
  descend of; root {qen} of @Ref{cineal}, q.v.  Also @Ref<cinnich>, grow,
  increase.
<cinneadh>, @Ref<cinne>, tribe, clan, Ir. @Ir{cineadh}, {cine}, E.Ir. @EIr{ciniud}
  (g. {cineda}); from root {qen} in @Ref{cineal}, q.v.  Hence @Ref<cinnich>,
  gentiles, Ir. @Ir{cineadhach}, a gentile.
--page 83
<cinneag>, a spindle (Sutherland):
<cinnseal>, need, desire (Arm.), contact, origin (M`A.).  In the first
  sense, the word is from @Ref{cion.1}, want; in the second, from @Ref{cinn}.
  In the sense of "contact", as exemplified by M`A., the Sc.
  {kinches}, correspondence, etc. ("to kep kinches wi' one"), has
  to be remembered, a word apparently from {kin}.
<cinnte>, certain, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cinnim}, definio, {écintech}, infinitus;
  from @Ref{ceann}, head, q.v.
<cìob.1>, bite, wound (Bib. Gl.); see @Ref{caob}.  {cìbidh} (Hend.).
<cìob.2>, coarse mountain grass, tow, Ir. @Ir{cíob}, coarse mountain grass,
  scirpus cæspitosus.  Club rush, flaky peat (Carm.).
<ciobhull>, the jaw (M`D., who writes "na cíobhuill"), @Ref<ciobhal>
  (Sh.), more properly @Ref<giall.1> (Arm.), q.v.  H.S.D. gives the
  pl. as @Ref<cibhlean>.
<cìoch>, a woman's breast, Ir. @Ir{cíoch}, E.Ir. @EIr{cích}; cf. W. @W{cig}, flesh,
  M.Br. @MBr{quic} (do.), *{kîkâ} ({kêkâ}?).  Bez. suggests (with query)
  connection with Bulg. {цица}, teat, Polish {cyc}.
<cìocras>, hunger, longing, Ir. @Ir{cíocras}, hunger, greed, ravenousness:
<ciod>, what, Ir. @Ir{cad}, O.Ir. @OIr{cate}, {cote}, lit. "quid est", @Ref{co.1}+@Ref{ta}, q.v.
  Ir. @Ir{caidé} (North {goidé}, O.Ir. @OIr{caté}, what is it, O.Ir. @OIr{ité}, it is.
<ciogail>, tickle, Ir. @Ir{giglim}; see @Ref{diogail}.  In the Heb. @Ref<ciogailt>,
  tickling, also signifies terror, a crisis of timerous determination
  (H.S.D.).
<ciom>, a comb, wool-card, Ir. @Ir{ciomam}, I comb (O'B., Sh.); from
  M.Eng. {kemb}, to comb.  H.S.D. has not the word.
<ciomach>, a prisoner, Ir. @Ir{cimidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{cimbid}, *{kṃbiti-} (Stokes),
  root {kemb}, wind; Lat. {cingo}, surround; Gr. @Gr{κόμβος}, band,
  Nor. {hempa} (do.).  See @Ref{ceangal}, from the same I.E.
  root {qenℊ}.
<ciombal>, bell, cymbal, so Ir.,; from Lat. {cymbalum}, Eng. @Eng{cymbal}.
<ciomboll>, a bundle of hay or straw (Heb.); from Norse {kimbill}, a
  bundle {kimbla}, to truss, Sc. {kemple}, fory bottles of hay or
  straw, {kimple}, a piece (Banffshire).
<cion.1>, want; from the root {ken} of @Ref{gun}, without.
<cion.2>, love, esteem, Ir. @Ir{cion}, {cean}, M.Ir. @MIr{cen}, O.Ir. @OIr{fochen}, welcome;
  root {qino-}, {qi}, I.E. {qei}, notice, as in @Ref{ciall}.  Further, Gr. @Gr{τιμή},
  honour, @Gr{τíω}, honour, @Gr{τíνω}, pay penalty.  The sense of honour
  and punishment is combined in the same word.  See @Ref{ciont}.
<cionag>, a small portion of land, one-fourth of a @Ref{cleitig} or one-eighth
  of a "farthing" land (Heb.), Ir. @Ir{cionóg}, a small coin, a
  kernel; cf. W. @W{ceiniog}, a penny.
<cionar>, music (Arm.; Sh. has @Ref<cionthar>; H.S.D. has @Ref<cion'thar>
  from A.M`D., querulous music):
<cionn>, @Ref<os cionn>, etc.; this is the old dat. of @Ref{ceann}, head (*{qennō}).
--page 84
<cionnarra>, identical, idem; Ir. @Ir{cionda} (dial. Gaelic @Ref<cìonda>), for
  @Ref{ceudna}, by metathesis of the {n}.  The G. {-arra} is an adjectival
  form of the {-ar} in {aon-ar}, etc.
<cionnas>, how, Ir. @Ir{cionnus}, O.Ir. @OIr{cindas} = {co}+{indas}; see @Ref{co.2} and
  @Ref{ionnas}.
<ciont>, guilt, Ir. @Ir{cionnta}, O.Ir. @OIr{cintach}, injustice, {cin}, guilt
  (*{cin-at-}), dat.pl. {cintaib}; also G. †<cion>; I.E. {qin}, Gr.
  @Gr{τíνυμαι}, punish, @Gr{ποινή}, punishment, Lat. {pœna}, punishment,
  Eng. @Eng{pain}.  See @Ref{cion.2}.
<ciora>, a pet lamb or sheep, @Ref<cireag>, a petted sheep, @Ref<ciridh>, the
  call to a sheep to come to one: all from a shorter form of
  the root {ka'er} or {kair} (i.e. {kir}) of @Ref{caora}, q.v.
<cioralta>, cheerful, @Ref<ciorbail>, snug; from Eng. @Eng{cheerful}.  Cf. @Ref{tìorail}.
<ciorram>, hurt, damage, wounding, Ir. @Ir{cíorrbhadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{cirriud},
  {cirud}, *{cir-thu-}, root {ker}, destroy, Lat. {caries}, decay, Gr. @Gr{κήρ},
  death, Skr. {çṛnâtí}, smash.  {ro cirrad}, was mutilated.
<cìosaich>, subdue: "make tributary"; from @Ref{cìs}, tribute, tax.
<ciosan>, a bread basket, corn-skep (M`D.), Ir. @Ir{cisean}, {cis}, basket,
  M.Ir. @MIr{ceiss}, possibly allied to (if not borrowed from) Lat. {cista}
  (Stokes).  See @Ref{céis}.  Sc. {cassie}.
<ciotach>, left-handed, sinister, so Ir., W. @W{chwith}, *{sqîttu-} (Stokes),
  *{sqit-tu-}, and {sqit} is an extension of {sqi}, {sqai} in Gr. @Gr{σκαιός},
  Lat. {scaevas} (*{sqai-vo-}), left.
<ciotag>, a little plaid, shawl, O.Ir. @OIr{cétaig}, acc. case (Bk.of Armagh);
<cìr.1>, a comb, Ir. @Ir{cìor}, O.Ir. @OIr{cír}, *{kensrâ}; cf. Gr. @Gr{κτέις}, g. @Gr{κτενός},
  (from {skens}), Ch.Sl. {ceslŭ}, Lit. {kasýti}, scratch (Stokes,
  Strachan), root {qes}, shave, scratch; cf. Gr. @Gr{ξέω}, @Gr{ξυρόν}.  Zimmer
  refers it to the root {qers}, to furrow, Skr. {karsha}, a scratch,
  etc.; but {qers} would give a G. {cerr}.  A Celtic {cêra} would be
  the ideal form, suggesting Lat. {cêra}, wax, "honey-{comb}".
<cìr.2>, cud, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cír}, Manx {keeil}, W. @W{cil}, Br. @Br{das-kiriat}, ruminer.
  Perhaps identical with @Ref{cìr.1} (Windisch).  {cir}, @Ref{ciridh},
  sheep (Carm.).
<cìs>, tribute, tax, Ir. @Ir{cíos}, O.Ir. @OIr{cís}; from Lat. {census}, whence Eng.
  {census}.
<cisd>, @Ref<cist>, a chest, Ir. @Ir{cisde}, M.Ir. @MIr{ciste}, W. @W{cist}; from Lat. {cista},
  Ir. @Ir{cis}, piece of basket work of osiers.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{cass}, basket,
  Lat. {quasillus}.
<cìsean>, hamper (Islay); from {cèis}.
<ciseart>, a light tweed (N.Lochaber).
<cistin>, a kitchen; from the Eng.
<cith.1>, a shower, Ir. @Ir{cith}, {cioth}, g. {ceatha}, E.Ir. @EIr{cith}, O.Ir. @OIr{cithech},
  flebilium; *{citu-}:
