<cithris-chaithris>, confusion (M`L.): "hurly-burly"; an onomatopoetic
  word.
<ciùbhran>, @Ref<ciùran>, @Ref<ciùrach>, small rain, drizzle, Ir. @Ir{ceóbhrán}.  See
  @Ref{ceòban}.  M.Ir. @MIr{ciabor}, mist.
<ciuchair>, beautiful, dimpling (Sh., Arm.; not H.S.D.):
<ciùcharan>, @Ref<ciùcran>, a low-voiced plaint: from Norse {kjökra},
  whine, {kjökr}, a voice stifled with tears.
<ciùin>, mild, Ir. @Ir{ciúin}, *{kivo-ni-}, I.E., {kivo-}, {keivo-}, akin, dear; Lat.
  {civis}, Eng. @Eng{civil}; Norse {hýrr}, mild, Ag.S. {heóre}, Ger. {ge-heuer},
  safe; Ch.Sl. {po-çivŭ}, benignus; Skr. {çivá}, friendly.
<ciùrr>, hurt, Ir. @Ir{cíorrbhaigim}, I maim, wound: see @Ref{ciorram}.  Cf.,
  however, O.Ir. @OIr{dufiurrsa}, adteram, {du-furr}, attriveris,
  {iúrthund}, to hurt, root {org} as in {tuargan}.
<clab>, an open mouth, Ir. @Ir{clab}; from Eng. @Eng{clap}, a clap, noise, the
  human tongue.  Hence @Ref<claban>, a mill-clapper.
<claban>, top of the head, brain-pan (H.S.D.); cf. W. @W{clopen}, G.
  @Ref{claigionn}, q.v.  Possibly Pictish?
<clàbar>, filth, mire, clay, Ir. @Ir{clábar} (whence Eng. @Eng{clabber}); cf. @Ref{làban}.
<clabar-nasg>, the clasp of wooden cow collar (Arg.):
<clabog>, a good bargain, great pennyworth:
<clach>, a stone, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cloch}, W. @W{clwg}, a rock, detached rock,
  @Ref{clog}, a rock, {clogan}, a large stone, *{klukâ}; root {kal}, {kl-}, hard;
  Got. {hallus}, stone, Norse {hella}, flat stone, Skr. {çilâ}, a stone.
  Usually correlated with Lat. {calculus}, a pebble, Eng. @Eng{calculate}.
<clachan>, kirk or kirk town, Ir. @Ir{clochán}, monastic stone-cells singly
  or in group; also G. and Ir. "stepping stones".
<clàd>, comb wool, <clàd>, a wool comb; from Sc. {claut}, {clauts}, wool
  comb, also a "clutching hand, a hoe or scraper"; from {claw}.
<cladach>, a shore, beach, so Ir., *{claddo-}, "a score, shore"; from
  {clad} of @Ref{cladh}, q.v.
<clàdan>, a burr, a thing that sticks, Ir. @Ir{cladán}, burr, flake; from
  @Ref{clàd}.
<cladh>, churchyard, Ir. @Ir{cladh}, a bank, ditch, E.Ir. @EIr{clad}, a ditch,
  W. @W{cladd}, {clawdd}, fossa, Corn. @Corn{cledh} (do.), Br. @Br{cleuz} (do.),
  *{klado-}, *{klâdo}; root {kela}, {kla}, break, split, hit; Gr.
  @Gr{κλαδαρός}, easily broken; Lat. {clâdes}; Russ. {кладу}, cut.  See
  further @Ref{claidheamh}, sword.  Hence @Ref<cladhaich>, dig.
<cladhaire>, a poltroon, so Ir.; "digger, clod-hopper", from @Ref{cladh}?
<clag>, a bell, Ir. @Ir{clog}, O.Ir. @OIr{clocc}, W., Corn. @Corn{cloch}, Br. @Br{kloc'h}, *{klokko-},
  *{kloggo-}; root, {klog}, {klag}, sound; Lat. {clango}, Eng. @Eng{clang};
  Gr. @Gr{κλάζω}, @Gr{κλαγγή}, clang; Lit. {klagėti}, cackle.  Bez. suggests
--page 86
  Bulg. {клўцам}, hit, giving the stem of {clag} as *{klukko-}.  Hence
  Eng. @Eng{clock}, etc.
<clàideag>, a lock, ringlet; see @Ref{clàd}, @Ref{clàdan}.
<claidheag>, the last handful of corn cut on the farm, the "maiden"
  (Badenoch); Sc. {claaik-sheaf} (Aberdeen, etc.), from {claaick},
  the harvest home; the state of having all the corn in.
<claidheamh>, a sword, Ir. @Ir{clóidheamh}, O.Ir. @OIr{claideb}, W. @W{cleddyf},
  Corn. @Corn{cledhe}, Br. @Br{kleze}, *{kladebo-s}; root {klad}, Skr. {kladga}:
  Gr. @Gr{κλάδος}, a twig; Ch.Sl. {kladivo}, a hammer.  Further root
  {kela}, {klâ}, hit, split; Lat. {culter}, per-{cellere}, etc.  See @Ref{cladh}.
<claidhean>, better @Ref<clàidhean>, the bolt of a door, Ir. @Ir{claibín}; from
  the same source as @Ref{claidheamh}.  H.S.D. gives it in supp. as
  {clàimhean}.
<claidreach>, a damaging, shattering: *{claddo-}; root {clad} of @Ref{claidheamh}.
<claigionn>, a skull, Ir. @Ir{cloigionn}, M.Ir. @MIr{cloicend}, W. @W{clopen}, Br.
  {klopenn}, *{cloc-cenn}, from @Ref{clag} and @Ref{ceann}, "bell-head, dome-head".
  Stokes considers the Ir. borrowed from the Welsh.
  Cf. @Ref{claban}.
<clais>, a furrow, ditch, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{class}, W. @W{clais}, *{clad-s-ti-}; from
  *{clad} of @Ref{cladh}.  Br. @Br{kleus}, pit.
<clàistinn>, hearing, listening; from *{clôstâ}, ear; see @Ref{cluas}.
<clàiteachd>, gentle rain (Arran):
<clambar>, wrangling, Ir. @Ir{clampar}; from Lat. {clamor}.
<clamhan>, a buzzard:
<clamhradh>, a scratching, so Ir.: *{clam-rad}; see @Ref{cloimh}, itch.
<clamhsa>, an alley, close, so Ir.,; from Eng. @Eng{close}.
<clàmhuinn>, sleet:
<clann>, children, clan, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cland}, W. @W{plant}, *{qlanatâ}: I.E.
  root {qel}; Gr. @Gr{τέλος}, company; O.Slav. {celjadĭ}, family, Lit.
  {kiltis} = Lett. {zilts}, race, stock; Skr. {kúla}, race.  Some have
  added Lat. {populus}.  Usually regarded as borrowed from
  Lat. {planta}, a sprout, Eng. @Eng{plant}, whence G. @Ref<clannach>,
  comatus.
<claoidh>, vex, oppress, Ir. @Ir{claoidhim}, O.Ir. @OIr{clóim}, W. @W{cluddio}, overwhelm,
  *{cloid}; I.E. {klei}, incline, as in @Ref{claon}, q.v.  Windisch
  and Stokes refer it to *{cloviô}, root {qlov}, {qlav}, {qlu}, shut in,
  Lat. {claudo}, close, {claudus}, lame, Gr. @Gr{κλεíς}, @Gr{κλειδός}, key.
<claon>, inclining, squint, oblique, Ir. @Ir{claon}, O.Ir. @OIr{clóin}: *{kloino-};
  Lat. {clīno}, {acclīnis}, leaning, Eng. @Eng{incline}; Gr. @Gr{κλíνω} ({ι} long),
  incline; Eng. @Eng{lean}; Lit. {szlë́ti}, incline; Skr. {çrayati} (do.).
<clap>, @Ref<clapartaich>, clap, clapping; from the Eng. @Eng{clap}.
<clàr>, a board, tablet, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{clár}, W. @W{claur}, O.W. @OW{claur}; Gr.
  @Gr{κλήρος} (for @Gr{κλᾶρος}), a lot, @Gr{κλάω}, break; root {qela}, {qlâ}, break,
--page 87
  etc., as in @Ref{claidheamh}, @Ref{coille}, q.v.  Hence, {inter alia}, @Ref<clàrach>,
  a woman of clumsy figure, "board-built".
<clàrsach>, a harp, Ir. @Ir{cláirseach}; from {clár}.  Cf. for meaning
  @Ref{fiodhcheall}, chess-play, "wood-intelligence".
<clasp>, @Ref<claspa>, a clasp, Ir. @Ir{clasba}; from the Eng.
<clàtar>, mire (Dial.); from Sc. {clart}.
<clathnàire>, bashfulness (M`D., who writes @Ref<clàthnàire>.  H.S.D.
  gives the form in the text): {clath}+@Ref{nàire}; see @Ref{nàire}.  {clath}
  seems from the root {qel}, hide, as in @Ref{ceil}, q.v. (H.S.D.).
<cleachd.1>, a practice, custom, Ir. @Ir{cleachdadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{clechtaim}, I am
  wont, *{kḷcto-}, root {qel}, as in Lat. {colo}, Eng. @Eng{cultivate}, Gr.

  {klek}, {klok}, as in @Ref{cluich}, q.v.
<cleath>, concealment, hiding; also @Ref<cleith.2> (*{kleti-s}); inf. to @Ref{ceil},
  hide, q.v.
<cleibe>, an instrument for laying hold of fish, or of sea-fowls, Ir.
  @Ref{clipe}; from Eng. @Eng{clip}, a gaff or cleek, a fastener, Norse {klýpa},
  to pinch, O.H.G. {chluppa}, tongs.
<cléir>, the clergy, Ir. @Ir{cléir}; from Lat. {clêrus}.  See @Ref{cléireach}.
<cléireach>, a clerk, a cleric, O.G. {clérec} (Bk.of Deer), Ir. @Ir{cléireach},
  E.Ir. @EIr{clérech}, Br. @Br{kloarek}; from Lat. {clēricus}, a clerk, cleric,
  from Gr. @Gr{κληρικός} (do.), from @Gr{κλῆρος}, a lot, office: "the lot
  (@Gr{κλῆρον}) of this ministry" (Acts i. 17).
<cleit.1>, a quill, feather, down, Ir. @Ir{cleite}:
<cleit.2>, a rocky eminence; from Norse {klettr}, rock, cliff.  Common
  in Northern place-names.
<cleit.3>, bar, ridge (Carm.).
<cleith.1>, a stake, wattle, Ir. @Ir{cleith}, @Ref{cleath}, E.Ir. @EIr{cleth}, tignum, W.
  {clyd}, sheltering, M.Br. @MBr{clet}, warm (place); root {qleit}, {qlit},
  O.Sax.  {hhlîdan}, cover, Got. {hleiðra}, hut, Ch.Sl. {kleti}, house.
  Hence @Ref<cleith.3>, roof; the E.Ir. @EIr{cléthe}, roof, roof-pole, appears
  to be for {kleitio-}, the same root in its full vocalic form
  (Schräder).

<cleith.3>, roof. See @Ref{cleith.1}.

<cleitig>, @Ref<clitig>, a measure of land - an 8th of the "penny" land:

<cliabh>, a basket, hamper, the chest (of a man), Ir. @Ir{clíabh}, O.Ir.
  {cliab}, corbis, *{cleibo-}.  Root {klei} as in @Ref{cliath.1}.
<cliadan>, a burr; cf. @Ref{clàdan}.
<cliamhuinn>, son-in-law, Ir. @Ir{cliamhuin}, G. and Ir. @Ref<cleamhnas>,
  affinity; root {klei}, lean, Lat. {cliens}, Eng. @Eng{client}, in-{cline}, @Ref{lean}.
<cliar>, a poet, hero or heroes, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{clíar}, society, train, clergy;
  from Lat. {clérus}, as in @Ref{cléir}, q.v.  Hence @Ref<cliaranach>, a bard,
  swordsman.  The @Ref<Cliar Sheanachain>, (Senchan's Lot) was
  the mythic bardic company, especially on its rounds (Gaelic
  Folk Tales).  Hence @Ref<cliarachd>, singing, feats.
<cliatan>, a level plot of ground: *{cliath-t-an}, a participial formation
  from @Ref{cliath.1}, harrow - "harrowed, level".
<cliath.1>, harrow, hurdle, Ir. @Ir{clíath}, E.Ir. @EIr{cliath}, O.Ir. Vadum {clied}
  (Adamnan), Dublin, W. @W{clwyd}, hurdle, Corn. @Corn{cluit}, Br. @Br{kloned},
  Gaul.  {8clêta}, whence Fr. {claie}, hurdle, *{kleitâ}; root {klei},
  lean; Lett. {slita}, wood fence, Lit {szlité}, a rack (of a waggon).
<cliath.2>, tread hens, as cock:
<cliathach>, side, the side of the ribs, Ir. @Ir{cliathán}, side, breast,
  *{kleito-}, "slope", root {klei}, incline; Norse {klíð}, a slope,
  mountain side, Gr. @Gr{κλιτύς} (@Ref{i} long), a slope, hill-side.
<clibeag>, a trick, wile (H.S.D.); from @Ref{cleibe}, @Ref{clip}, as @Ref{clìchd.2} from
  {cleek}.
<clibist>, a misadventure; see @Ref{cliob.1}.
<clic>, a hook, gaff: see @Ref{clìchd.1}.
<clìchd.1>, an iron hook; from Sc. {cleik}, Eng. @Eng{cleek}, {click}.
<clìchd.2>, a cunning trick; from @Ref{clìchd.1}.  Sc. {cleiky}, ready to take
  the advantage, tricky, {cleek}, inclination to cheat: "There's a
  {cleek} in 'im" (Banffshire).
<cliob.1>, to stumble, @Ref<cliobach>, stumbling, awkward.  Cf. Sc. @Ref<clypock>,
  a fall.  See next.
<cliob.2>, anything dangling, excrescence, @Ref<cliobain>, a dew-lap, Ir.
  {cliob}, {clibín}; also Ir. @Ir{cliobach}, hairy, shaggy, {clibóg}, a
  (shaggy) colt, etc.  Cf. Sc. {clype}, an ugly, ill-shaped fellow:
  origin unknown (Murray); @Ref{clip}, a colt, Ger. {klepper}, palfrey.
  Root {qḷℊ}, stumpy, Gr. @Gr{κολοβός}.
<cliopach>, halt in speech (H.S.D.): cf. Eng. @Eng{clip} words.
<cliostar>, a clyster; from the Eng.
<clip>, a hook, clip, Ir. @Ir{clipe}, a gaff; from the Eng. @Eng{clip}.  See @Ref{cleibe}.
<clipe>, deceit (H.S.D.); see @Ref{clibeag}.
<clis>, active, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{cliste}, ready, quick.  Cf. W. @W{clys}, impulse:
  *{cḷ-sto-}; root {kel}, as in Lat. {celer}, swift, etc.?  "@Ref<Na fir chlis>",
  the Merry Dancers.  From @Ref{cleas}.  Cf. Ir. and E.Ir. @EIr{deil-clis},
  staff-sling.
<clisbeach>, unsteady of foot, cripple; from @Ref{clis}.  Also @Ref<clisneach.3>.

<clisneach.1>, the human body, carcase, outward appearance (Arm.;
  not H.S.D.):
<clisneach.2>, a bar-gate (H.S.D.), a rib (Wh.):
<clisneach.3>, see @Ref{clisbeach}.

<cliù>, renown, praise, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{clú}, W. @W{clyw}, sense of hearing, @Ref{clod},
  praise; Gr. @Gr{κλέος}, fame; Skr. {çravás}, I.E. {kleu}, hear.  See
  further under @Ref{cluinn}.
<cliùchd>, mend nets:
<cliùd.1>, a slap with the fingers; from the Sc. {clout}, Eng. @Eng{clout}, a
  cuff, "clout".
<cliùd.2>, a small or disabled hand; from Sc. {cloot}, hoof, half-hoof?
<clò.1>, @Ref<clòth>, broad-cloth; from Eng. @Eng{cloth}, {clothing}, etc.
<clò.2>, a print, printing press, M.G. {cló} (Carswell), Ir. @Ir{cló}, {clódh}
  ({clodhuighim}, Coneys; E.Ir. @EIr{clod}, mark?); cf. @Ref{clò.1}.

†<clò.3>, a nail, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{clò}, W. @W{clo}, key, Br. @Br{klao}, tool, *{klavo-};
  Lat. {clâvus}, nail, {clavis}, key; Gr. @Gr{κλεíς}, key, etc.  See @Ref{claoidh}.
<clò-chadail>, slumber; see @Ref{clòth}.
<clobha>, a pair of tongs; from Norse {klofi}, a fork (of a river), a
  forked mast, snuffers, {klof}, fork of the legs, "cloven, cleft".
  The Ir. @Ir{clobh(a)} in Con. and Fol., and the @Ref{clomh} of Lh., seems
  a Scottish importation, for Coneys says the vernacular is
  {tlobh}.  In fact, the Ir. word is {tlú}, {tlúgh}: "lifter"; root {tḷ-}
  as in Lat. {tollo}?
<clobhsa>, a close, lane, farm-yard, Ir. @Ir{clamhsa}, W. @W{claws}; from Eng.
  {close}.  Also, @Ref{clamhsa}, q.v.
<clochranaich>, wheezing in the throat (M`F.; Sh. has @Ref<clochar>, and
  @Ref<clochan>, respire); from Sc. {clocher}, wheezing, {cloch}, cough
  feebly.  It is an onomatopoetic word, like Eng. @Eng{cluck}, {clock}.
<clod>, a clod, turf; from the Eng.

<clogais>, a wooden clog; from Eng. @Eng{clogs}.

<cnuasaich>, ponder, collect, Ir. @Ir{cnuasuighim}, @Ref{cnuas}, a collection,
  scraping together, G. and Ir. @Ref<cnuasachd>, reflection, collection,
  *{knousto-}; root {knu}, {knevo}, scrape, Gr. @Gr{κνύω}, scratch, Norse
  {hnöggr}, niggard, Eng. niggard, Ag.S. {hneáw}, sparing.  The
  idea is "scraping together": a {niggard} is "one who scrapes".
  Stokes (Dict.) gives the root as {knup}, and compares Lit.
  {knupsyti}, oppress.  St. now, possibly, *{knoud-to}, Norse
  {knúðr}, ball.  Cf. {cruinnich}, for force.

†<Coimhde>, God, Ir. @Ir{Cóimhdhe}, God, the Trinity, O.Ir. @OIr{comdiu},

<coinne.3>, @Ref<coinneamh>, a meeting, Ir. @Ir{coinne}, E.Ir. @EIr{conne}, *{con-nesiâ};
  root {nes}, come, dwell, Gr. @Gr{νέμοι}, go, @Gr{ναíω}, dwell; Skr. {nas},
  join some one.  Stokes seems to think that {kon-dê-} is the
  ultimate form here, {dê} being the I.E. {dhê}, set, Gr. @Gr{τíθημι}, etc.
  @Ref<coinneamh>, when used as adverb = {coinnibh}, dat.pl.?

  from {vêro-}, now {fíor}, q.v.  Hence <còir>, justice, right, share.

<conn>, sense, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cond}: *{cos-no-}, root {kos}, {kes}, as in G. @Ref{chì},
  see; Gr. @Gr{κοννέω}, understand, @Gr{κόσμος}, array ("what is seen"),
  world.  See further under @Ref{chì} for {kes}.  Stokes equates {cond}
  with Got. {handngs}, wise; but this is merely the Eng. @Eng{handy}.
  It has been suggested as an ablaut form to @Ref{ceann}, head.  Got.
  {hugs}, sense, has also been compared; *{cug-s-no-} is possible.

  appears in Lat. {Ceres}, Eng. @Eng{cereal}, Gr. @Gr{κόρος}, satiety, Lit.

<corcur>, crimson, Ir. @Ir{corcur}, scarlet, O.Ir. @OIr{corcur}, purple, W.

<còrd.1>, a rope, Ir. @Ir{corda}; from Eng. @Eng{cord}, Lat. {corda}.
<còrd.2>, agree, Ir. @Ir{cord}; from obsolete Eng. @Eng{cord}, agree, bring to an
  agreement, from Lat. {cord-}, the stem of @Ref{cor}, heart, whence
  Eng. @Eng{cordial}, etc.  The Sc. has the part. as {cordyt}, agreed.
<cordaidhe>, spasms (Sh.): "twistings", from @Ref{còrd.1}.
<còrlach>, bran, refuse of grain (M`D.; O'R has {corlach}), @Ref<còrrlach>,
  coarsly ground meal, over-plus.  A compound of @Ref{còrr},
  "what is over"?
<còrn>, a drinking horn, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{corn}, W. @W{corn}, Br. @Br{korn}, *{korno-};
  Lat. {cornu}; Eng. @Eng{horn}; Gr. @Gr{κέρας}, horn.
<còrnuil>, retching, violent coughing: *{kors-no-}?  For {kors}, see
  @Ref{carrasan}.
<coron>, a crown, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{coróin}, {corón}, W. @W{coron}; from Lat.
  {corona} (Eng. {crown}).
<corp>, a body, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{corp}, W. @W{corff}, Br. @Br{korf}; from Lat. {corpus}
  (Eng. {corpse}, Sc. {corp}).
<corpag>, tiptoe (Arm.); seemingly founded on @Ref{corr} of @Ref{corrag}.
<corr>, a crane, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{corr}, W. @W{crychydd}, Corn. @Corn{cherhit}, O.Br.
  {corcid}, ardea, *{korgsâ}, {korgjo-s}; Gr. @Gr{κέρχω}, be hoarse, @Gr{κερχνη},
  a hawk, O.Sl. {kraguj}, sparrow-hawk.  Cf. W. @W{cregyr}, heron,
  "screamer", from {cregu}, be hoarse; Ag.S. {hrágra}, Ger.
  {reiher}, heron, Gr. @Gr{κρíζω}, @Gr{κρíκε}, screech.
<còrr>, excess, overplus, Ir. @Ir{corr}; G. @Ref<corr>, odd, Ir. @Ir{cor}, @Ref{corr}, odd;
  also Ir. @Ir{corr}, snout, corner, point, E.Ir. @EIr{corr}, rostrum, corner.
  The E.Ir. @EIr{corr}, rostrum, has been referred by Zimmer and
  Thurneysen to @Ref{corr}, crane - the name of "beaked" bird doing
  duty for "beak".  The modern meanings of "excess,
  odd" (cf. {odd} of Eng., which really means "point, end")
  makes the comparison doubtful.  Refer it rather to {kors-}, stick
  out, point, head; Gr. @Gr{κόρση}, head; stem {keras-}; Lat. {crista},
  Eng. @Eng{crest}; further is Gr. @Gr{κέρας}, horn, Lat. {cerebrum}, Norse
  {hjarsi}, crown of the head; and also {corn}, horn, q.v.  Hence
  @Ref<corran.2>, headland.
<corra-biod>, an attitude of readiness to start; from @Ref{còrr}, point,
  and @Ref{biod} = @Ref{biog}, start.  @Ref<corra-beaga> (M`A.).
<corrach>, abrupt, steep, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{corrach}, unsteady, wavering;
  "on a point", from @Ref{corr}, point, odd?
<corra-chagailt>, glow-worm-like figures from raked embers, Ir.
  {corrchagailt}; from @Ref{còrr}, a point, and @Ref{cagailt}.
--page 102
<corradhuil>, first effor of an infant to articulate.  An onomatopoetic
  word.
<corrag>, a forefinger, finger; from @Ref{còrr}, point, etc.
<corra-ghriodhach>, a heron, crane, Ir. @Ir{corr-ghrian}, heron; from
  @Ref{còrr}, and (E.Ir.) {grith}, a cry, scream, *{gṛtu-}, root {gar}, of
  @Ref{goir}, q.v.
<corran.1>, a sickle, Ir. @Ir{corrán}, {carrán}, M.Ir. @MIr{corrán}, *{korso-}, root
  {kors}, {kers}, an extension of I.E. {qero}, Gr. @Gr{κεíρω}, etc., as in @Ref{corc.2},
  q.v.  Cf. I.E. {qerpo}, cut, from the same root, which gives
  Lat. {carpo}, cull, Gr. @Gr{καρπός}, fruit (Eng. harvest), Lit. {kerpu},
  cut, Skr. {kṛpana}, sword.  G. may be from a {korpso-}, {korso-}.
  The Gaelic has also been referred to the root {kur}, round, as
  in @Ref{cruinn}, Ir. @Ir{cor}, circuit (O'Cl.).
<corran.2>, headland; see @Ref{còrr}.
<corran.3>, a spear, barbed arrow (Ossianic Poems); from @Ref{corr}, a
  point, q.v.
<corranach>, loud weeping, "coronach", Ir. @Ir{coránach}, a funeral cry,
  dirge: {co}+{ràn-ach}, "co-weeping"; see @Ref{ràn}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {rán}
<corrghuil>, a murmur, chirping (Heb.); see @Ref{corradhuil}.
<còrrlach>, coarsely ground meal, overplus; see @Ref{còrlach}.
<corruich>, anger, rage, Ir. @Ir{corruighe}, vb. {corruighim}, stir, shake;
  from @Ref{corrach}.  The striking resemblance to M.Eng. {couroux},
  O.Fr. {couroux} (from Lat. {corruptus}), has been remarked by
  Dr Cameron (Rel.Celt. II, 625).
<còrsa>, a coast; from the Eng. @Eng{course}.  Cf. @Ref<còrsair>, a cruiser.
<cor-shìomain>, thraw-crook; from @Ref{cor} or @Ref{car}, q.v., and @Ref{sìoman}, q.v.
<cos>, a foot, leg; see @Ref{cas.1}.
<còs>, a cave, Ir. @Ir{cuas}, topographically {Coos}, {Coose}, M.Ir. @MIr{cuas}, a
  cave, hollow: *{cavosto-}, from {cavo-}, hollow; Lat. {cavus}.  It is
  possible to refer it to *{coud-to}, {koudh}, hide, Gr. @Gr{κεύθω}, Eng.
  {hide}, {hut}.  The Norse {kjós}, a deep or hollow place, is not
  allied, but it appears in Lewis in the place-name {Keose}.
<cosanta>, industrious; see @Ref{cosnadh}.
<cosd>, cost, Ir. @Ir{cosdus} (n.), M.Ir. @MIr{costus}, W. @W{cost}; from O.Fr. {cost},
  Eng. @Eng{cost}.
<cosgairt>, slaughtering; see @Ref{casgairt}.
<cosgaradh>, valuation of the sheep and cattle which a crofter is
  entitled to; Norse {kost-gorð}, state of affairs (Lewis).
<cosgus>, cost; a by-form of {cost}.
<coslach>, like, @Ref<coslas>, likeness, Ir. @Ir{cosmhuil}, like, O.Ir. @OIr{cosmail},
  {cosmailius} (n.): {con}+@Ref{samhail}, q.v.
<cosmhail>, like; see @Ref{coslach}.
<cosmal>, rubbish, refuse of meat, etc. (M`A.):
--page 103
<cosnadh>, earning, winning, Ir. @Ir{cosnamh}, defence, O.Ir. @OIr{cosnam},
  contentio, *{co-sen-}, root {sen}, Skr. {san}, win, {sangias}, more
  profitable, Gr. @Gr{ἔναρα}, booty.  M.Ir. @MIr{aisne}, gain, *{ad-senia},
  Skr. {sanati}, Gr. @Gr{ἄνυμι}.
<costag>, costmary; from the Eng.
<cot>, a cottage; from Eng. @Eng{cot}.
<còta>, a coat; Ir. @Ir{cóta}; from the Eng.
<cota-bàn>, a groat:

<cothaich>, contend, strive; from @Ref{cath}, battle?
<cothan>, pulp, froth; see @Ref{omhan}.
<cothar>, a coffer, Ir. @Ir{cófra}; from the Eng.
<cothlamadh>, things of a different nature mixed together:
<cothrom>, fairplay, justice, Ir. @Ir{cómhthrom}, equilibrium, E.Ir.
  {comthrom}, par: {com}+@Ref{trom}, q.v.
<cràbhach>, devout, Ir. @Ir{crábhach}, O.Ir. @OIr{cráibdech}, {crabud}, fides, W.
  {crefydd}, *{krab}, religion; Skr. {vi-çrambh}, trust.
<crabhat>, a cravat, Ir. @Ir{carabhat}; from the Eng.
<cracas>, conversation; from Sc., Eng. @Eng{crack}.
<cràdh>, torment, Ir. @Ir{crádh}, E.Ir. @EIr{crád}, {cráidim} (vb.).  Ascoli has
  compared O.Ir. @OIr{tacráth}, exacerbatione, which he refers to a
  stem {acrad-}, derived from Lat. {acritas}.  This will not suit the
  {à} of {cràdh}.  Possibly it has arisen from the root {ker}, cut,
  hurt ({ker}, {krâ}).
<crà-dhearg>, blood-red, E.Ir. @EIr{cró-derg}; see @Ref{crò.3}.
<crag.1>, @Ref<crac>, a fissure; from the Eng. @Eng{crack}.
<crag.2>, knock; from the Eng. @Eng{crack}
<craicionn>, skin, Ir. @Ir{croiceann}, O.Ir. @OIr{crocenn}, tergus, Corn. @Corn{crohen},
  Br. @Br{kroc'hen}, *{krokkenno-}, W. @W{croen}, *{krokno-} (?)  From
  *{krok-kenn}: {krok} is allied to Ger. {rücken}, back, Eng. @Eng{ridge},
  Norse {hryggr}; and {kenn} is allied to Eng. @Eng{skin}.  For it, see
  @Ref{boicionn}.
<craidhneach>, a skeleton, a gaunt figure, @Ref<craidhneag>, a dried peat;
  for root, see @Ref{creathach}, @Ref{crìon} (*{krat-ni-}).
<cràigean>, a frog, from {cràg}, @Ref{cròg}, q.v.: "the well-pawed one".
<craimhinn>, cancer, Ir. @Ir{cnamhuinn}; from @Ref{cnàmh}, q.v.
<cràin>, a sow, Ir. @Ir{cráin}, M.Ir. @MIr{cránai} (gen. case): *{crācnix},
  "grunter", root {qreq}, as in Lat. {crōcio}, croak, Lit. {krõkti},
  grunt.
<cràiteag>, a niggard woman; likely from @Ref{cràdh}.
<cràlad>, torment; from {cràdh-lot}, @Ref{cràdh} and @Ref{lot.1}, q.v.
<cramaist>, a crease by folding (Skye):
--page 104
<cramb>, a cramp-iron, Ir. @Ir{crampa}; from the Eng.
<crambadh>, @Ref<crampadh>, a quarrel:
<cràlaidh>, crawl, crawling; from the Eng.
<crann>, tree, a plough, Ir. @Ir{crann}, a tree, lot, O.Ir. @OIr{crann}, W. and
  Br. @Br{prenn}: *{qrenn-}; cf. Gr. @Gr{κράνον}, cornel, Lat. {cornus}, Lit.
  {kéras}, tree stump, O.Pruss. {kirno}, shrub (Bezzenberger).
  Windisch correlated Lat. {quernus}, oaken, but this form,
  satisfactory as it is in view of the Welsh, rather stands for
  {quercnus}, from {quercus}, oak.
<crannadh>, withering, shrivelling, Ir. @Ir{crannda}, decrepit; from
  @Ref{crann}: "running to wood".
<crannag>, a pulpit, a wooden frame to hold the fir candles, Ir.
  {crannóg}, a hamper or basket, M.Ir. @MIr{crannoc}, a wooden vessel,
  a wooden structure, especially the "crannogs" in Irish lakes.
  From @Ref{crann}; the word means many kinds of wooden
  structures in Gadelic lands.
<crannchur>, lot, casting lots, Ir. @Ir{crannchar}, O.Ir. @OIr{crannchur}; from
  @Ref{crann} and {cuiir}.
<crannlach>, the teal, red-breasted merganser; from @Ref{crann} and @Ref{lach.1},
  duck, q.v.
<craobh>, tree, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cróeb}, {cráeb}, *{croib}? "the splittable",
  root {krei}, {kri}, separate; as {tree} of Eng. and its numerous
  congeners in other languages is from the root {der}, split; and
  som other tree words are from roots meaning violence of
  rending or splitting ({kládos}, {twig}, e.g.).  For root {kri}, see
  @Ref{criathar}.
<craoiseach>, a spear, E.Ir. @EIr{cróisech}; from @Ref{craobh}?
<craoit>, a croft; see @Ref{croit.2}.
<craos>, a wide, open mouth, gluttony, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cróes}, {cráes},
  O.Ir. @OIr{crois}, gula, gluttony.  Zimmer cfs. W. @W{croesan}, buffoon.
  Possibly a Celtic {krapesty-}, allied to Lat. {crāpula}, or to Gr.
  @Gr{κραιπάλη}, headache from intoxication.
<crasgach.1>, cross-ways, @Ref<crasg>, an across place; for {crosg}, from {cros}
  of @Ref{crois}, a cross, q.v.
<crasgach.2>, corpulent (Sh.; H.S.D. for C.S.); from obsolete {cras},
  body (O'Cl.), Ir. @Ir{cras}, for *{crapso-}, *{kṛps}, root {kṛp} of Lat.
  {corpus}?
<cratach>, back of person, side (Skye): {crot}?
<crath>, shake, Ir. @Ir{crathadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{crothim}, *{kṛto-}; perhaps allied to
  Lit. {kresti}, {kratýi}, shake.  But it may be allied to @Ref{crith}, q.v.
  It has been compared to Gr. @Gr{κραδάω}, brandish, which may be
  for @Gr{σκαρδάω}, root {sker} in @Gr{σκαíρω}, spring, Ger. {scherz}, joke.
  This would suit G. {crith}, W. @W{cryd} and {ysgryd}.
--page 105
<crè.1>, clay, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cré}, g. {criad}, W. @W{pridd}, Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{pry}.  Its
  relation to Lat. {crêta}, which Wharton explains as from {crêtus},
  "sifted", from {cerno}, is doubtful.  If {cerno} be for *{crino}, Gr.
  @Gr{κρíνω}, we should have the root {kri}, {krei}, separate, as in
  @Ref{criathar}, and it is not labialised in any language (not {qrei}).
  The Celtic phonetics are not easily explained, however.
  Stokes gives the stem as {qreid-}, but the modern G. has the
  peculiar {è} sound which we find in @Ref{gnè}, {cè}.  This points to a
  stem {qrē-jâ}, root {qrê}, which is in agreement with Lat. {crêta}
  without doing the violence of supposing {crino} to give {cerno},
  and this again {crêtus}.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{clé}, left.
---gjk (1.14) which sense of {cè} is this referring to?
<crè.2>, @Ref<creubh.1>, body; see @Ref{creubh.1}.
<crèabag>, a ball for playing, fir cone:
<creach>, plunder, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{crech}, plundering, hosting; cf. Br.
  {kregi}, seize, bite, catch (as fire).  From the root {ker}, cut,
  ultimately.  See @Ref{corc.2}, knife, and @Ref{creuchd}.
<creachag>, a cockle, Ir. @Ir{creach}, scollop shell (O'R.); cf. W. @W{cragen},
  a shell, Corn. @Corn{crogen}, Br. @Br{krog}.
<creachan.1>, @Ref<creachann>, bare summit of a hill wanting foliage, a
  mountain: "bared", from @Ref{creach}?
<creachan.2>, pudding made with a calf's entrails (M`L.):
<creadhonadh>, a twitching, piercing pain (Heb.); possibly for
  {cneadh-ghonadh}, "wound-piercing".
<creag>, a rock, so Ir.; a curtailed form of @Ref{carraig}.  Also (Dialectically)
  @Ref<craig>.  Hence Eng. @Eng{crag}.
<creamh>, garlic, Ir. @Ir{creamh}, earlier {crem}, W. @W{craf}; Gr. @Gr{κρόμυον},
  onion; Ag.S. {hramse}, Eng. @Eng{ramsons}; Lit. {kermúszė}, wild
  garlic.
<crean>, @Ref<crion>, quake, tear up (Carm.):
<creanair>, sedition (Arm.; not H.S.D.), so Ir. (O'R.):
<creanas>, whetting or hacking of sticks (M`F.; H.S.D. considers it
  Dialectic), neat-handed (M`L.):
<creapall.1>, entanglin, hindering, so Ir.; it is an Ir. word evidently,
  from Lh.; founded on Eng. @Eng{cripple}.
<creapall.2>, a garter, @Ref<crepailld> (Skye); @Ref<creapull> (Arm.):

<creathach>, (faded) underwood, firewood, Ir. @Ir{creathach}, hurdle,
  brushwood, faggots (O'R.): *{kṛto-}; cf. @Ref{crìon}.
<creathall.1>, cradle, from Northern M.Eng. {credil}, Sc. {creddle}, Eng.
  {cradle}, Ag.S. {cradol}.  Further derivation at present uncertain
  (Murray).
<creathall.2>, a lamprey:
<creatrach>, a wilderness, so Ir. (Lh., etc.); M`A. gives the word,
  but it is clearly Ir.  Cf. @Ref{creathach}.

<creic>, sell, M.Ir. @MIr{creicc}, sale, E.Ir. @EIr{creic}, buying, O.Ir. @OIr{crenim}, I
  buy, W. @W{prynn}, buy; Skr. {krînami} (do.).  There seems a
  confusion in G. and E.Ir.with the word @Ref{reic}, sell, q.v.
<creid>, believe, Ir. @Ir{creidim}, O.Ir. @OIr{cretim}, W. @W{credu}, Corn. @Corn{cresy}, Br.
  {cridiff}, *{kreddiô}, O.Ir. @OIr{cretim}, W. @W{credu}, Corn. @Corn{cresy}, Br.
  {cridiff}, *{kreddiô}; Lat. {cred}; Skr. {çrad-dadhâmi}.  From
  {cred-dô}, "I give heart to".
<creigeir>, a grapple (M`D.); from some derivative of Norse {krækja},
  to hook, {krækill}, a crooked stick, Eng. @Eng{crook}?
<creim>, @Ref<creidhm>, gnaw, chew, nibble, Ir. @Ir{creimim}, {creidhmim}, M.Ir.
  {créim}.  Ir. is also {creinim}, W. @W{cnithio}, {cnoi} (which also means
  "gnaw"):  from {knet}, {knen}, {knō}, {ken}, bite, scratch, as in
  @Ref{cnàmh}, q.v.  The {n} of {kn} early becomes {r} because of the {m}
  or {n} after the first vowel.
<crein>, suffer for (W. H.)  Allied to the O.Ir. @OIr{crenim}, buy:
  "You will {buy} for it!"  See under @Ref{creic}.
<créis>, grease; from Sc. {creische}, from O.Fr. {craisse}, {cress}, from
  Lat. {crass}, {crassus}, thick.  Eng. @Eng{grease} is of like origin.
<creithleag>, a gadful, so Ir. (Fol.), M.Ir. @MIr{crebar}, W. @W{crëyr}, root
  {creb}, scratch?  Cf. Lett. {kribinát}, gnaw off.  Ir. @Ir{creabhar},
  horse-fly.
<creòth>, wound, hurt (Dialectic), Ir. @Ir{creo}, a wound (O'R.); @Ref<creonadh>,
  being pained: *{krevo-} as in @Ref{crò.3}, blood.
<creubh.1>, @Ref<creubhag>, @Ref<crè.2>, the body; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{crí}, *{kreivio-}, flesh,
  body; Got. {hraiva-}, Norse {hrae}, body, O.H.G. {hreô}, corpse.
  It is possible to refer {crí}, {cré} to *{krepi-}, Lat. {corpus}, O.H.G.
  {href}, Ag.S. {hrif}, body, Eng. mod-{riff}.  Stokes: {crí}, {kṛpes}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to <cré>
<creubh.2>, dun, crave; from the Eng. @Eng{crave}.
<creubhaidh>, tender in health; seemingly from @Ref{creubh.1}.
<creuchd>, wound, Ir. @Ir{créachd}, O.Ir. @OIr{crécht}, W. @W{craith}, scar, {creithen},
  M.Br. @MBr{creizenn} (do.), *{crempto-}; root {kerp}, {ker}, Lit. {kerpù},
  cut, Skr. {kṛpana}, sword (Strachan).  Stokes gives the Celtic
  as {krekto-s}, and Bez. cfs. Norse {hrekja}, worry.  This neglects
  the {é} of Gadelic.
<creud.1>, what, Ir. @Ir{creud}, {créad}, E.Ir. @EIr{crét}; for {ce rét}.  See @Ref{co.2} and
  @Ref{rud}.
<creud.2>, creed, Ir. @Ir{créidh}, M.Ir. @MIr{credo}, W. @W{credo}; from Lat. {credo}, I
  believe; the first word of the Apostles' {Creed} in Lat.
<creutair>, creature, Ir. @Ir{créatúr}, W. @W{creadwr}; from Lat. {creatura}.
<criadh>, clay, so Ir.  Really the oblique form of @Ref{cré}, q.v.
<criathar>, a sieve, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{criathar}, O.W. @OW{cruitr}, Corn. @Corn{croider},
  M.Br. @MBr{croezr}, *{kreitro-}; Ag.S. {hridder}, {hriddel}, Eng. @Eng{riddle},
  Ger. {reiter}; further Lat. {crîbrum} (*{kri-θro-n}); root {kri}, {krei},
  separate, whence Gr. @Gr{κρíνω}, Eng. @Eng{critic}, etc.
<criachadh>, proposing to oneself; from @Ref{crìoch}, end.  Cf. Eng.
  de@Ref{fine}, from {finis} and {end}, used for "purpose".
--page 107
<cridhe>, heart, Ir. @Ir{croidhe}, O.Ir. @OIr{cride}, W. @W{craidd}, Br. @Br{kreis}, middle,
  *{krdjo-n}; Gr. @Gr{κραδíα}, @Gr{καρδíα}; Lat. @Ref{cor}, {cordis}; Eng. @Eng{heart},
  Ger. {herz}; Lit. {szirdis}.
<crìlein>, a small creel (M`E.), a box, small coffer (H.S.D.), @Ref<crilein>
  (Arm., M`L.), a box, Ir. @Ir{crilín}, E.Ir. @EIr{criol}, coffer, *{krêpolo}.
  @Ref<criol> (Arran, Perth).  Stokes gives the stem as {krêpo-},
  and Bez. adds Skr. {çū́rpa}, winnowing basket (Cf. for
  phonetics @Ref{lìon.3}, and Skr. {pûrna}, full).  Sc., Eng. @Eng{creel}, which
  appears about 1400, is usually derived hence; but as the
  G. form itself is doubtful, and, from all appearance, taken
  from Lh., it is best to look elsewhere for an etymology for
  {creel}, as, through Fr., from Lat. {craticula}.  The G. {criol}
  exists only in Sh., who found it in Lh.  See @Ref{croidhleag}.
<crìoch>, end, Ir. @Ir{críoch}, O.Ir. @OIr{crích}, *{krîka},from the root {krei},
  separate, as in @Ref{criathar}, q.v.  Stokes and Bezzenberger join
  W. @W{crip}, a comb, and compare Lit. {kreikti}, strew, and, for
  sense, appeal to the Ger., Eng. @Eng{strand}, "the strewed",
  O.Slav. {strana}, side.  It has also been referred to the root
  of Lat. {circus}, circle, Gr. @Gr{κρíκος}.
<criom>, nibbling, @Ref<criomag>, a bit; see @Ref{creim}.
<crìon>, little, withered, Ir. @Ir{críon}, E.Ir. @EIr{crín}, W. @W{crin}, fragile, dry,
  Br. @Br{krin}, *{krēno-s}; the root {krē} appears to belong to root {kēr},
  {kera}, destroy, Skr. {çṛṇā́mi}, break, rend, Lat. {caries}, decay,
  Gr. @Gr{ἀκήρατος}, pure, untouched, Got. {hairus}, sword.  Stokes
  allies it to Skr. {çrâṇa}, cooked, {çrâ}, cook, possibly a form of
  the root {kera}, mix, Gr. @Gr{κέραμαι}, mix.
<crioncanachd>, a strife, quarrelsomeness, Ir. @Ir{críoncánachd}: an Ir.
  word from Lh., apparently.  Perhaps {críon-cán}, "small
  reviling".
<crionna>, attentive to small things, prudent, so Ir. ({críonna}, Con.);
  also dialectic @Ref<crìonda>, which shows its connection with @Ref{crìon}.
  Cf. W. @W{crintach}, sordid.
<criopag>, a wrinkle, Ir. @Ir{criopóg}; founded on Eng. @Eng{crimp}, {crumple}.
  M`A. has <criopag>, a clew of yarn.
<crios>, a belt, girdle, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{criss}, {fo-chridigedar}, accingat, W.
  {crys}, shirt, E.W. {crys}, belt, M.Br. @MBr{crisaff}, succingere, Br.
  {kreis}, middle.  Bez. suggests comparison with Lit. {skritulýs},
  circle, knee-cap, {skreistė}, mantle.  It has been referred also
  to the root {krid} of @Ref{cridhe}, heart.
<Crìosdaidh>, a Christian, Ir. @Ir{Criosduighe}, M.Ir. @MIr{cristaige}; from
  the G. {Crìosd}, Ir. @Ir{Críosda}, Christ; from Lat. {Christus}, Gr.
  @Gr{Hριοστός}, the Anointed One.
<criostal>, a crystal, so Ir; from the Eng.
<criot>, an earthen vessel (Dialect, H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{criotamhail}, earthen,
  made of clay (O'B.), {criot}, an earthen vessel (O'R.):
--page 108
<criotaich>, caress; see @Ref<cniadaich>.
<criplich>, a cripple; from the Eng. @Eng{cripple}.
<crith>, shake, quiver, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{crith}, W. @W{cryd}, O.W. @OW{crit}, *{kritu-};
  Ag.S. {hriða}, fever, Ger. {ritten}, fever.  See @Ref{crath}, to which
  {crith} has been suggested as cognate (root {kṛt}, {krot}, {kret}.
<critheann>, @Ref<critheach>, the aspen tree, Ir. @Ir{crann-critheach}; from
  @Ref{crith}.
<crò.1>, a sheep cot, pen, Ir. @Ir{cró}, M.Ir. @MIr{cró caerach}, ovile, {crò na muice},
  pig-stye, W. @W{craw}, hovel, pig-stye, Br. @Br{kraou}, {crou}, stable,
  *{krâpo-s}, a stye, roof; Ag.S. {hróf}, Eng. @Eng{roof}, Norse {hróf}, a
  shed (Stokes).  The Norse {kró}, small pen, Sc. {croo}, seem
  borrowed.
<crò.2>, the eye of a needle, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cró}, W. @W{crau}, M.Br. @MBr{cräo}, Br.
  {kraouenn}.
†<crò.3>, blood, E.Ir. @EIr{cró}, {crú}, W. @W{crau}, Corn. @Corn{crow}, *{krovo-s}; Lat.
  {cruor}, gore; Lit. {kraújas}, blood; Skr. {kravis}, raw flesh; Gr.
  @Gr{κρέας}, flesh; Eng. @Eng{raw}.
†<crò.4>, death, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cró}.  From the same origin as @Ref{crò.3}, blood.
  This is the Sc. {cro}, the weregild of the various individuals in
  the Scoto-Celtic Kingdom, from the king downwards.
<cròc.1>, beat, pound (Dialectic, H.S.D.):
<cròc.2>, a branch of a deer's horn; cf. Norse {krókr}, Eng. @Eng{crook}.
<cròcan>, a crook; from the Norse {krókr}, Eng. @Eng{crook}.
<croch>, hang, Ir. @Ir{crochaim}, {croch}, a cross, gallows, E.Ir. @EIr{croch}, cross,
  W. @W{crog}; from the Lat. {crux}, {crucis}.
<cròch>, saffron, Ir. @Ir{cróch}; from Lat. {crocus}, from Gr. @Gr{κρόκος}, {crocus},
  and its product saffron.
<crodh>, cattle, Ir. @Ir{crodh}, a dowry, cattle, M.Ir. @MIr{crod}, wealth
  (cattle): *{krodo-}, I.E. {qordh}, {qerdh}; Eng. @Eng{herd}, Ger. {herde};
  Lit. {kerdżus}, herd (man), Ch.Sl. {creda}, a herd; Skr. {çardhas},
  a troop.
<cròdha>, valiant, Ir. @Ir{cródha}, E.Ir. @EIr{cróda}, valiant, cruel, *{croudavo-s},
  "hardy";  root {croud} of @Ref{cruaidh}, q.v.
<crodhan>, hoof, parted hoof, Ir. @Ir{crobhán}, a little hoof or paw,  See
  @Ref{crubh}.
<crog.1>, an earthen vessel, @Ref<crogan>, a pitcher, Ir. @Ir{crogán}, pitcher,
  E.Ir. @EIr{crocann}, olla, W. @W{crochan}, *{krokko-}; Gr. @Gr{κρωσσός},
  pitcher (*@Gr{κρωκjος}); to which are allied, by borrowing somehow,
  Eng. @Eng{crock}, Ag.S. {crocca}, Norse {krukka}, Ger. {krug}.  G.
  and W. phonetics (G. {g} = W. @W{ch}.) are unsatisfactory.  Schrader
  derives these words from O.Ir. @OIr{crocenn}, skin - a "skin"
  vessel being the original.
<crog.2>, an aged ewe; from the Sc. {crock}; cf. Nor. {krake}, a sickly
  beast, Fris. {krakke}, broken-down horse, etc.
---JTM: normalized to Fris.
--page 109
<cròg>, large hand, hand in paw form, *@Ref<crobhag>, Ir. @Ir{crobh}, hand
  from wrist to fingers, paw, hoof, O.Ir. @OIr{crob}, hand.  See @Ref{crubh}.
<crogaid>, a beast with small horns (M`A.); from @Ref{crog.2}?
<crogan>, a gnarled tree (Arg.); cf. @Ref{cròcan}.
<crògan>, thornbush (Arg.), from @Ref{cròg}, W. @W{crafanc}, claw.
<cròic>, foam on spirits, rage, difficulty, cast sea-weed:
<croich>, gallows, Ir. @Ir{croch}, gallows, cross, E.Ir. @EIr{croch}, cross, W.
  {crogbren}, gallows; from Lat. {crux}, {crucis}.
<cròid>, a sumptuous present (Heb.); see @Ref{cnòid}.
<cròidh>, pen cattle, house corn; from @Ref{crò.1}.  Dialectic for latter
  meaning is @Ref<cródhadh>.
<croidhleag>, a basket, small creel; see @Ref{crìlein}.
<cròilean>, a little fold, a group; from @Ref{crò.1}.
<crois>, a cross, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cross}, W. @W{croes}; from Lat. {crux}.
<croistara>, @Ref<cranntara>, also @Ref<croistàra>, @Ref<croistarra>, @Ref<cranntàra>, @Ref<cranntarra> the fiery cross: @Ref{crois}+{tara};
  see @Ref{crois} above.  As to {tara}, cf. the Norse {tara}, war
  (Cam.).
---gjk (1.16) expanded <-tàra>, <-tarra> into full entries with <crois-> and <crann->
<croit.1>, a hump, hillock, Ir. @Ir{croit}, W. @W{crwth}, a hunch, harp, {croth}, a
  protuberant part (as calf of leg), *{crotti-}; from {krot}, {kurt},
  root {kur}, round, as in @Ref{cruinn}, @Ref{cruit}, q.v.
<croit.2>, a croft; from the Eng. @Eng{croft}.  In the sense of "vulva", cf.
  W. @W{croth}, Br. @Br{courz}, which Stokes refers to @Ref{cruit}, harp; but
  the G. may be simply a metaphorical use of {croit}, croft.
<cròlot>, wound dangerously; @Ref{crò.3}+@Ref{lot.1}, q.v.
<cròm>, bent, Ir. E.Ir. @EIr{crom}, O.Ir. @OIr{cromm}, W. @W{crwm}, Br. @Br{krom},
  O.Br. @OBr{crum}, {krumbo-}; from the same root as @Ref{cruinn}?  The
  Ag.S. {crumb}, crooked, Eng. @Eng{crumple}, Ger. {krumm}, have been
  compared, and borrowing alleged, some holding that the
  Teutons borrowed from the Celts, and {vice versa}.  Dr Stokes
  holds that the Celts are the borrowers.  The Teutonic and
  Celtic words do not seem to be connected at all in reality.
  It is an accidental coincidence, which is bound to happen
  sometimes, and the wonder is it does not happen oftener.
<cromadh>, measure the length of the middle finger, Ir. @Ir{cruma},
  {cromadh}; from {crom}.
<croman>, kite, hawk, from {crom}.
<cron>, fault, harm, Ir. @Ir{cronaim}, I bewitch; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{cron}, rebuking.
  The idea is that of being "fore-spoken" by witchcraft.  See
  @Ref{cronaich}.
<cronaich>, rebuke, Ir. @Ir{cronuighim}, M.Ir. @MIr{cronaigim}, @Ref{cron}, rebuking,
  E.Ir. @EIr{air-chron} (do.), *{kruno-}; cf. Teut. {hru}, noise, Norse
  {rómr}, shouting, Ag.S. {hréam}, a din.
<crònan>, a dirge, croon, purring, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cronán}.  O'Curry
  (Mann. and Cust. III., 246) writes the Ir. as {crónán}, and
  defines it as the low murmuring or chorus to each verse of
--page 110
  the {aidbsi} or choral singing.  Sc. {croon}, {croyn} (15th century),
  corresponds to Du. {kreunen}, groan, M.Du. {krönon}, lament,
  M.Low G. {kronen}, growl, O.H.G. {chrônan}, M.L.G. {kroenen},
  chatter (Murray, who thinks the Sc. came from Low Ger.
  in M.Eng. period).  It seems clear that the Gadelic and
  Teutonic are related to each other by borrowing; seemingly
  the Gadelic is borrowed.
<cropan>, deformed person (Suth.); from Norse {kroppinn}, deformed.
  See under @Ref{crùb.1}.
<crosach>, crossing, thwarting, Ir. @Ir{crosanta}; also G. @Ref<crosan> (and
  @Ref<crostan>), a peevish man; all from {cros}, the basis of @Ref{crois},
  cross, q.v.
<crosanachd>, from @Ref{crosan}, poet, chorister.
<crosda>, perverse, irascible, so Ir.; from the G. base {cros} of @Ref{crois},
  cross.
<crotal>, lichen, especially for dyeing, cudbear: *{crottal}; *{crot-to-},
  from {krot}, cf. Gr. @Gr{κροτώνη}, an excrescence on a tree.  Hence
  Sc. {crottle}.  M.Ir. @MIr{crotal} means "husk" (which may be G.
  <crotal> above), "kernel, cymbal".  In the last two senses the
  word is from the Lat. {crotalum}, a rattle; the Irish used a
  small pear-shaped bell or rattle, whence the Ir.Eng. {crotal}
  (Murray).
<cruach>, a pile, heap, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cruach}, W. @W{crug}, Corn. @Corn{cruc}, O.Br.
  {cruc}, *{kroukâ}; Lit. {kráuti}, to pile, {krúvi}, heap; Norse {krúga},
  heap.  Others have compared the Norse {hraukr}, a small
  stack, Ag.S. {hreác}, Eng. @Eng{rick}.
<cruachan>, @Ref<cruachainn>, hip, upper part of the hip, E.Ir. @EIr{cruachait};
  from @Ref{cruach}, heap, hump.  Stokes translates the Ir. as
  "chine", and considers it like the corresponding Ger. {kreuz},
  derived from Lat. {crûcem}, cross.  The Gaelic meaning is
  distinctly against this.
<cruaidh>, hard, Ir. @Ir{cruaidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{cruaid}, *{kroudi-s}; root {kreva}, to
  be blood, raw, whence @Ref{crò.3}, blood, q.v.; Lat. {crûdus}, Eng.
  {crude}.  Hence @Ref<cruailinn>, hard, rocky.
<crùb.1>, squat, crouch, Ir. @Ir{crúbadh}, to bend, crook; also G. @Ref<crùbach>,
  cripple, Ir. do.; from Norse {krjúpa}, to creep, kneel (Eng.
  {creep}, etc.), {kroppinn}, crippled, root {kreup}, {krup}, as in Eng.
  {cripple}, Sc. {cruppen thegether}, contracted, bowed.  Cf. W.
  {crwb}, bent.
<crùb.2>, bed recess (Carm.):
<crùban>, the crab-fish, Ir. @Ir{crúban}, W. @W{crwban}.  From @Ref{crùb.1} above.
<crubh>, a horse's hoof, Ir. @Ir{crobh}, paw, hoof, E.Ir. @EIr{crù}, *{kruvo-},
  hoof; Zend {çrva}, {çruva}, nail, horn; further Gr. @Gr{κέρας}, horn,
  and {corn}, q.v. (Stokes).
<crudha>, horse shoe, Ir. @Ir{crúdh}: seemingly from @Ref{crubh}.
--page 111
<crùidein>, the king-fisher, Ir. @Ir{cruidín}:
<cruidhean>, paw (Arm.) = {crùibhean}.
<cruimh>, a worm, Ir. @Ir{cnuimh}, O.Ir. @OIr{cruinn}, W., Corn. @Corn{pryf}, Br. @Br{prenv},
  *{qṛmi-}; Lit. {kırmis}, Lett. {sérms}; Skr. {kṛmis}, {krímis}.
<cruinn>, round, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cruind}, W. @W{crwn}, Br. @Br{krenn}, *{krundi-s};
  root {kuro-}, circle, turn, as in @Ref{car}, q.v.  Cf. Lat. {curvus}; Gr.
  @Gr{κυρτός}, bunt, @Gr{κορώνη}, ring, Lat. {corona}, Eng. @Eng{crown}.  Bezzenberger
  cfs. the form {crundi-} from {kur} to Lat. {rotundus} from
  {rota}.
<crùisgein>, a lamp, jug, Ir. @Ir{crúisgín}; from M.Eng. {cruskyn}, from
  O.Fr. {creusequin}, from Teut. {krûs}, whence Eng. @Eng{cruse}.
<crùisle>, @Ref<crùidse>, mausoleum, hollow vault of a church; from
  M.Eng. {cruddes}, vault, crypt, {crowd}, by-form of Eng. @Eng{crypt}.
<cruit>, a harp, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{crot}, W. @W{crwth}, fidicula, Late Lat. (600
  A.D.) {chrotta}, *{krotta}: {krot-ta-}, from {krot}, {kurt}, root {kur}, as in
  G. @Ref{cruinn}, round, q.v., Gr. @Gr{κυρτός} (do.): "the curved
  instrument".  Stokes refers it to the root {krot}, strike, as in
  Gr. @Gr{κροτέω}, rattle, clap.  Hence Eng. @Eng{crowd}.
<cruithneachd>, @Ref<cruineachd>, wheat, Ir. @Ir{cruithneachd}, O.Ir. @OIr{cruithnecht}:
  *{kṛt-on-}, root {kert}, {ker}, cut, "that which is cut"; Lit.
  {kertù}, cut; Gr. @Gr{κεíρω}, Lat. {curtus}, etc. (Rhys).  It has been
  compared to the Lat. {Ceres}, Eng. @Eng{cereal}, and Lat. {cresco}, {creo},
  as in @Ref{cruth}.
<crùlaist>, a rocky hill (H.S.D., from MSS.); from @Ref{cruaidh}?  Cf.
  @Ref{cruailinn}.
<crumag>, the plant skirret; Sc. {crummock}.  From Gaelic {crom}
  (Cameron).
<cruman>, the hip bone, Ir. @Ir{crumán}, hip bone, crooked surgical
  instrument; from {crom}.
<crùn>, crown, Ir. @Ir{crún}; from M.Eng. {crune}, from O.Fr. {coronne},
  from Lat. {corona}.
<crunnluadh>, a quick measure in pipe music: @Ref{cruinn}+@Ref{luath.2}.
<crup>, crouch, contract, Ir. @Ir{crupaim}; founded on the M.Eng.
  {cruppel}, cripple, a root {crup}, appearing in Sc. {cruppen},
  contracted.  See @Ref{crùbach}.
<crùsbal>, crucible (Hend.).
<cruscladh>, wrinkling:
<cruth>, form, figure, O.Ir. @OIr{cruth}, W. @W{pryd}, *{qṛtu-s}, root {qer},
  make; Lat. {cerus}, creator, {creo}, Eng. @Eng{create}; Lit. {kuriù}, build;
  Skr. {kar}, make, {kṛtas}, made.
<cruthach>, placenta of mare:
<cù>, a dog, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cú}, g. {con}, W. @W{ci}, pl. {cwn}, Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{ki}, pl. Br.
  {koun}, *{kuô}, g. *{kunos}; Gr. @Gr{κύων}; Lat. {canis}; Eng. @Eng{hound};
  Skr. {çvâ}, g. {çúnas}.

<cuach.1>, a cup, bowl, Ir. @Ir{cuachóg}, O.Ir. @OIr{cúach}: Lat. {caucus}, Gr.
  @Gr{καῦκα}; Skr. {koça}.  It is generally held that {cuach} is borrowed
  from the Lat., though phonetically they may be cognate.
  Thw W. @W{cawg} is certainly borrowed.
<cuach.2>, curl, so Ir.; from the above.
<cuag>, an awkward curve, kink, an excrescence on the heel; also
  @Ref<guag.2> (Dialectic): *{kouggâ}, *{kouk-gâ}; root {qeuq}, bend; Skr.
  {kuc}, bend.  Lit. {kuku}, hook?
<cu'ag>, @Ref<cubhag>, cuckoo, Ir. @Ir{cuach}, O.Ir. @OIr{cúach}, W. @W{côg}, of onomatopoetic
  origin - from the cuckoo's cry of {kuku}, whence Eng.
  {cuckoo}, Lat. {cucûlus}, Gr. @Gr{κόκκυξ}, Skr. {kôkilas}, {koka}.
<cuailean>, the hair, a lock, curl, Ir. @Ir{cuailen} (Stokes).  This Stokes
  refers to a stem *{koglenno-}, and cfs. Gr. @Gr{κόχλος}, a spiral-shelled
  shell-fish, @Gr{κοχλíας}, spiral-shelled snail, Lat. {cochlea}.
  As the Gr. may be for @Gr{χόχλος}, the derivation is uncertain.
  Ir. @Ir{cuailín}, a bundle, faggot, suggests that a similar derivation
  from @Ref{cual} was used metaphorically for a "bundle or cord of
  hair".
<cuaille>, a club, bludgeon, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cuaille}, *{kaullio-}; Gr. @Gr{καυλός},
  stalk; Lat. {caulis}, stalk; Lit. {káulas}, a bone (Stokes).  It
  may, however, be for *{coud-s-lio-}, from {qoud}, Lat. {cûdo}, strike.
<cuairsg>, roll, wreathe, so Ir.; from @Ref{cuairt}, with the termination
  {-sqô}.
<cuairt>, circuit, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cúairt}.  Stokes gives the stem as
  {kukṛti}, from {kur}, circle, as in @Ref{cruinn}.
<cual>, a faggot, burden of sticks, Ir. @Ir{cual}, M.Ir. @MIr{cual}, heap, *{kuglo-},
  root {kug}, {qeuℊ}; Eng. @Eng{heap}; Lat. {cumulus} (={cub-lus}?); Lit.
  {kúgis}, heap.
<cuallach.1>, herding or tending cattle:
<cuallach.2>, society, family, Ir. @Ir{cuallaidheachd}, society, {cuallaidhe}, a
  companion:
<cuan>, the ocean, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{cuan}, harbour, {copno-}; Norse {köfn},
  Ger. {hafen}, Eng. @Eng{haven}.
<cuanal>, @Ref<cuantal>, a company, a band of singers, flocks (Carm.),
  E.Ir. @EIr{cúan}, host, *{koupn-}, Lit. {kupa}, heap, Eng. @Eng{heap}(?).
<cuanna>, @Ref<cuannar>, handsome, fine, Ir. @Ir{cuanna}; also @Ref<cuanta>, robust,
  neat: *{kaun-navos}, from {kaun}, {skaun}; Ger. {schön}.
†<cuar>, crooked, Ir. @Ir{cuar}, E.Ir. @EIr{cúar}, *{kukro-}, root {kuc}, bend; Skr.
  {kucati}, bend, Lit. {kukŭ}, hook (Strachan).  But cf. @Ref{cuairt}.
<cuaradh>, paining, tormenting; cf. W. @W{cur}, pain, care, {curio}, beat.
  The Dictionaries refer the word to @Ref{ciùrr}, as a Dialectic form.
<cuaran>, a brogue, sock, Ir. @Ir{cuaróg}, M.Ir. @MIr{cúarán}, W. @W{curan}, a
  covering for the foot and leg *{kourano-}, "mocassin": *{keu-ro-};
  root {keu}, {ku}, as in Lat. {cu-tis}, skin, Eng. @Eng{hide}, Ag.S.
  {hýd} (*{kûtí-}).

  probably the same as Eng. @Eng{coop}, basket.  Dialectic @Ref<coba>.
<cùb.2>, crouch, Ir. @Ir{cúbaim}; founded on Lat. {cubo}, lie

<cùbhraidh>, fragrant, Ir. @Ir{cumhra}, {cúmhra}, M.Ir. @MIr{cumra}, {cumrae},
  E.Ir. @EIr{cumrai} (i n-aballgort chumrai); *{com-rae}:
<cubhraig>, @Ref<cubhrainn>, a coverlet; founded on the Eng. @Eng{cover},
  {coverlet}.  Dialectic @Ref<cuibhlig>.
<cuchailte>, a residence (Arm.; not H.S.D.), Ir., {cuclaidhe}; *{concladh-};
  from @Ref{cladh}, q.v.
<cudaig>, the fish cuddy, young of the coalfish, Ir. @Ir{cudóg}, {códog},
  haddock, *{cod-do-}; Eng. @Eng{haddock}?  Sc. {cuddy}, {cudden}, may
  be of G. origin (Murray).  A.so @Ref<cudainn>.
<cùdainn>, a large bushel or tub; cf. Norse {kútr}, cask, Sc. {coodie},
  {quiddie}, small tub.  M.Ir. @MIr{cuidin}, {coithin}, catînus, is
  probably from a Celt. {kotîno-}, Gr. @Gr{κοτύλη}, cup, Lat. {catînus},
  a dep vessel.
<cudrom>, @Ref<cudthrom>, weight: *{con-trom-}, "co-heavy"; O.Ir.
  {cutrumme}, similis.  See @Ref{trom}.  Dialectic @Ref<cuideam>.
<cugann>, delicacy, "kitchen", E.Ir. @EIr{cuicen}; from Lat. {coquina}.
<cugan>, food (Carm.):
<cugar>, mab, or wild cat (Carm.):
<cugullach>, precarious, unstable (Carm.):
<cuibheas>, sufficiency:
<cuibheasach>, tolerable, middling, Ir. @Ir{cuibheasach}, decent, pretty
  good, fairly good (in health), @Ref{cuibheas}, decency, {cuibhe}, decent.
  See @Ref{cubhaidh} for stem.  The Ir. @Ir{cuibhe} shows that it is
  possible to derive the word from *{con-vesu-}, root {vesu} of
  @Ref{feabhas}.
<cuibhle>, @Ref<cuibhill>, a wheel; from Eng. @Eng{wheel}.
<cuìbhne>, deer's horn (Arm., M`L.), deer's tibia (H.S.D.):
<cuibhreach>, a bond, chain, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cuimrech}, vb. {conriug}, ligo,
  W. @W{rhwym}, vinculum, Br. @Br{rum}, {kevre}, *{kom-rigo-n}; {rigo-}, a
  bond; Lat. {corrigia}, shoe-lace; M.H.G. {ric}, band, string.
--page 114
  Stokes (rightly) now gives root is {rek}, bind, Skr. {raçana},
  cord, rope, {raçmi} (do.).
<cuibhrig>, cover, coverlet; see @Ref{cubhraig}.
<cuibhrionn>, portion, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cuibrend}, W. @W{cyfran}: *{com-rann};
  see @Ref{rann.1}.
<cuicheineach>, coquetting, secretly hobnobbing (Arg.): {co-ceann}.
<cuid>, share, part, Ir. @Ir{cuid}, g. {coda}, O.Ir. @OIr{cuit}, W. @W{peth}, res, pars,
  Corn. @Corn{peth}, Br. @Br{pez}, *{qezdi-}, *{qozdi-}; {qes}, {qos}, seemingly from the
  pron. root {qo}, {qe} (see @Ref{co.1}).  Cf. Lat. {quotidie}, {quota}, Br. @Br{ped},
  how much.  Bezzenberger compares Lit. {kedėti}, burst, Sl.
  {cęsti}, part; root {qed}.  Hence Eng. @Eng{piece}.  Some have
  suggested comparison with Lat. {costa}, rib, Eng. @Eng{coast}.
<cuideachd>, company, Ir. @Ir{cuideachda}, O.Ir. @OIr{cotecht}, coitio, conventus:
  *{con-techt}; see @Ref{teacht}.
<cuideag>, a spider (H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{cuideog} (O'R.):
<cuideal>, pride (Arm.), @Ref<cuidealas> (M`A.); from @Ref{cuid}?
<cuideam>, weight; see @Ref{cudrom}.
<cuidh>, @Ref<cuith>, inclosure (Barra); from Norse {kué}, Orkney {quoy}, a
  pen, Orkney and Shetland {quey}, {quay}, enclosed land.
<cuidhe>, wreath of snow; see @Ref{cuith}.
<cuidhtich>, quit, requite, Ir. @Ir{cúitighim}; from Eng. @Eng{quit}?
<cuidich>, assist, Ir. @Ir{cuidighim}, M.Ir. @MIr{cuitigim}, share; from @Ref{cuid}.
<cuidridh>, common (Sh.; not H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{cuidri(dh)}, entertainment,
  commons: *{con-trebi-}, as in @Ref{caidreabh}?
<cuifein>, the wadding of a gun; from Sc. {colfin}.
<cuigeal>, a distaff, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{cuigel}, W. @W{cogail}, Corn. @Corn{cigel}, Br.
  {kegel}; from M.Lat. {conucula}, for {colucula}, from {colus}.  From
  Lat. {conucula} comes Ger. {kunkel}, Fr. {quenouille}.
<cùil>, corner, recess, Ir. @Ir{cúil}, O.Ir. @OIr{cuil}, W. @W{cil}, *{kûli-}.  See @Ref{cùl}
<cuilbheart>, a wile, trick; from @Ref{cùil}+@Ref{beart}.
<cuilbheir>, a gun; from the Eng. @Eng{culverin}.
<cuilc>, reed, cane, Ir. @Ir{cuilc}, *{kolki-}; root {kol}, as in Lat. {culmus},
  stalk, Gr. @Gr{κάλαμος}, reed, Eng. @Eng{haulm}.
<cuile>, an apartment where stores are kept, O.Ir. @OIr{cuile fínda},
  vinaria, *{koliâ}; Gr. @Gr{καλíα}, hut, Skr. {kulā́ya}, hut, nest
  (Stokes); from *{kol-io-}, root {qel} of @Ref{ceil}.
<cuileag>, a fly, Ir. and E.Ir. @EIr{cuil}, W. @W{cylion}, flies, Corn. @Corn{kelionen}, Br.
  {quelyenen}, *{kuli-s}, {kuliâno-s}; Lat. {culex}.
<cùileagan>, feast (in a corner) (Carm.).
<cuilean>, a whelp, Ir. @Ir{cuileán} (O'B.), {cuileann} (O'R.), E.Ir. @EIr{culén},
  W. @W{colwyn}, Corn. @Corn{coloin}, catulus, Br. @Br{kolenn}, young of quadrupeds;
  Gr. @Gr{κύλλα}=@Gr{σκύλαζ}, whelp (Bez.).  It may be from @Ref{cù},
  *{kun}, dog.  Ernault, *{culenos}: root of @Gr{κύος}; M.Br. @MBr{colen}, so
  D'Arbois.  Rhys says W. borrowed.

<cuilidh>, cellar, secret place, treasury; see @Ref{cuile}.

  {kelenn} (pl.), *{kolenno-}; Eng. @Eng{holly}, Ag.S. {holegn}
<cuilm>, a feast; Dialectic for @Ref{cuirm}, q.v.
<cuimein>, the plant cumin, Ir. @Ir{cumín}; from Lat. {cuminum}, Eng.

<cuimhne>, rememberance, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cuman}, {cuimnech}, memor, W.

  {memini}, I remember, Eng. @Eng{mention}, {mind}, etc.
<cuimir>, brief, handsome, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cumbair}, *{com-berro-}; for
  {berr}, see @Ref{beàrr}.

<cuimrig>, trouble; see @Ref{coimrig}.
<cuimse>, a mark, aim, moderation, Ir. @Ir{cuimse}; from {com}+{meas};
  see @Ref{meas.2}.  Cf. @Ref{eirmis}.
<cuin>, when, E.Ir. @EIr{cuin}, W., Br. @Br{pan}; Lat. {quum}; Eng. @Eng{when}; see
  @Ref{co.1}.  The Ir. @Ir{can} (O'Cl.) is allied to Lat. {quando}, and more
  nearly than {cuin} to W., Br. @Br{pan}.
<cuing>, a yoke, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cuing}: *{con-jungi-}, root {jung}, {jug}, as in
  Lat. {jungo}, Eng. @Eng{joke}.  For phonetics, see @Ref{cuinge}.  Stokes
  since gives the stem as {ko-jungi-}.
<cuinge>, narrowness, O.Ir. @OIr{cumce}; see @Ref{cumhang}.
<cùinn>, coin; from the Eng.
<cuinneag>, a pail, milk pail, Ir. @Ir{cuinneóg}, M.Ir. @MIr{cuindeog}, W.
  {cunnog}, {cynnog}; cf. Lat. {congius}, a quart.
<cuinnean>, a nostril:
<cuinnlein>, a stalk of corn, a nostril; for the first meaning, see
  @Ref{connlach}; for the second, @Ref{cuinnean} above.
<cuinnse>, a quince; from the Eng.
<cuinnsear>, a dagger, sword; from the Eng. @Eng{whinger}.
<cuip>, a whip; from Eng. @Eng{whip}.
<cuir>, put, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cuirim}, O.Ir. @OIr{cuiriur}, W. @W{hebgor}, put aside,
  *{koriô}, I put.  The root is likely {ker}, {kor}, of @Ref{cruth}, q.v.
  For meaning cf. Lat. {facio} and Gr. @Gr{τíθημι}.  Bezzenberger
  compares it to Skr. {kaláyati}, drive, bear, do, Lit. {karta},
  position, lie.
<cuircinn>, a particular kind of head-dress for women, Ir. @Ir{cuircín},
  head, crest, comb (O'R.); from @Ref{currachd}?  Sc. {courche}, {curges}
  (pl.), a covering for a woman's head, Eng. @Eng{kerchief}.  E.Ir.
  {cuirce}, bow, knot; which makes the Sc. and Eng. comparison
  doubtful.
<cuireadh>, an invitation, so Ir.; from @Ref{cuir}, q.v.
<cuireall>, a kind of pack-saddle (H.S.D. from MSS.):
<cuireid>, @Ref<cuirein>, turn, wile; from @Ref{car}, q.v.
<cuirinnein>, the white water-lily (H.S.D., which quotes only O'R.),
  Ir. @Ir{cuirinín} (O'R.):

<cuirm>, a feast, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{coirm}, {cuirm}, M.W. @MW{cwrwf}, W. @W{cwrw},

  broth (Eng. {cream}; Gr. @Gr{κεράννυμι}, mix; Skr. {çrâ}, {çṛ}, cook;
  I.E. {kera}, {kra}, mix.
<cuirnean>, a small heap of stones, dew-drop, ringlet, Ir. @Ir{cuirneán},
  head of a pin, brooch, ringlet.  In the first sense, it is from
  {cárn}, and possibly also in the other two senses, the idea
  being "cluster, heap".
<cuirpidh>, wicked, corrupt; see {coirbte}, @Ref{coirb}.

<cùirt>, court, Ir. @Ir{cúirt}; from the Eng.

<cuisdeag>, the little finger (Sh., H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{cuisdeog} (O'R.):
<cuiseag>, a stalk, kind of grass, Ir. @Ir{coisín}, a stem, stalk, little foot;
  from @Ref{cas.1}, foot.  But see @Ref{cuisle}.  {di fetchoisig}, "by piping".
<cuisle>, pulse, vein, pipe, Ir. @Ir{cuisle}, E.Ir. @EIr{cuisli}, g.pl. {cuislend}, a
  pipe for music, O.Ir. @OIr{cusle}, g. {cuslen}, {cuislennach}, a piper.  It
  has no connection with Lat. {pulsus}, and its etymology is
  obscure (Stokes).  Cf. Eng. @Eng{hose}.
<cuiste>, a couch, Ir. @Ir{cúiste}, {cuiste} (O'B.); from Eng. @Eng{couch}.

  {cûlus}.  Hence {cùlaist}, recess.
<culadh>, a good condition of the body, @Ref<culach>, fat, sleek: "well-covered",
  from {cul} of @Ref{culaidh.1}?
<culaidh.1>, apparel, so Ir.; root {qel}, {qol}, cover; Ger. {hülle}, a
  covering, Lat. {occulo}.  See @Ref{ceil}.
<culaidh.2>, boat (Suth.):
<cùlag>, turf for the back of the fire, sitting behind another on
  horseback, a collop; all from @Ref{cùl}.
<cùlan>, tresses, hair; from @Ref{cùl}.
<cùlaobh>, behind, the back; E.Ir. @EIr{cúlaib} (dat.pl.), {cúlu} (acc.pl.);
  from @Ref{cùl}.  The dat. (and acc.) pl. of @Ref{cùl} used locatively - for
  rest (and motion).  Compare @Ref{beulaobh}.
<cularan>, a cucumber, Ir. @Ir{cularán}, W. @W{cylor}, earth nuts, Br. @Br{coloren},
  earth nut.  Ernault makes the Celtic word to be *{carul-an-},
  and compares Gr. @Gr{κάρνον}, nut.
<cullach>, a boar, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cullach}, O.Ir. @OIr{callach}, {cullach}, {caullach},
  Br. @Br{kalloc'h}, "entire", {qellecq}, epithet for stallions and boars,
  *{kalluâko-s}, from *{kalljo-}, testicle, W. @W{caill}, testiculus, M.Br.
--page 117
  {quell}; root {kal}, hard, as in @Ref{clach}, q.v., Norse {hella}, flat stone,
  etc.  (Bezzenberger).  Cf. Lat. {cuelleus}, bag, scrotum, whence
  O.Fr. {couillon}, Eng. @Eng{cullion}, testicles, Sc. {culls}.  Hence
  @Ref<cullbhoc>, wether-goat, Ir. @Ir{culbhoc}.
<cullachas>, impotence, @Ref<cullach>, eunuch; from {coll}, {call}; see @Ref{call}.
<culraoìnidh>, goal-keeper (Suth.); from @Ref{cùl} and @Ref{raon}?
<culuran>, birth-wort, cucumber; see @Ref{cularan}.
<cum>, keep, hold, Ir. @Ir{congbhaighim}, inf. {congmhail}, O.Ir. @OIr{congabin};
  from {con} and @Ref{gabh}, take.  The G. {cum} is for {congv} or {congbh},
  and the {gv} becomes {m} as in @Ref{ìm}, @Ref{ciomach}, @Ref{tum}, etc.
<cuma>, @Ref<cumadh>, shape, form, Ir. @Ir{cuma}, E.Ir. @EIr{cumma}, vb. {cummaim}:
<cumail>, keeping, Ir. @Ir{cumail}, {congmhail}; inf.to @Ref{cum}, i.e., {cum-gabhail}.
<cuman>, a milking pail; Gr. @Gr{κύμβη}, @Gr{κύμβος}, cup; Ger. {humpen},
  bowl.
<cumanta>, common, Ir. @Ir{cumann}; from the Eng. @Eng{common}.
<cumha.1>, mourning, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{cuma}: I.E. root {qem}, {qom}; Eng.
  {hum}, Ger. {hummen}.
<cumha.2>, a stipulation, Ir. @Ir{cumha}, E.Ir. @EIr{coma}, bribe, gift, condition:
  *{com-ajo-}, "co-saying", O.Ir. @OIr{ái}, a saying, Lat. {ajo}?  See
  @Ref{adhan}.  Cf. @Ref{cunnradh}.
<cumhachd>, power, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{cumachte}, W. @W{cyfoeth}, power, riches,
  *{kom-akto}, root {ag}, drive, carry, Lat. {ago}, Gr. @Gr{ἄγω}, Eng. @Eng{act},
  etc. (Stokes).  The O.Ir. @OIr{cumang}, potestas, is doubtless a
  nasalised form of the root {ag} (={ang}); it has been referred
  to the root {ang}, Lat. {angere}, etc., as in @Ref{cumhang} below, but
  the meaning is unsatisfactory.  The word {cumhachd} has also
  been analysed as {co-mag-tu-}, where {mag} has been bariously
  referred to I.E. {meg}, great (G. @Gr{μέγας}, Eng. @Eng{much}), or I.E.
  {mēgh} (Eng. {may}, Lat. {machina}, {machine}).
<cumhang>, narrow, Ir. @Ir{cúmhang}, O.Ir. @OIr{cumang}, W. @W{cyfang}, *{kom-ango-s};
  root {ang}; Gr. @Gr{ἂγω}, choke, @Gr{ἄγχι}, near; Lat. {ango},
  {angustus}; Ger. {eng}.
<cùmhlaidean>, stipulations (Hend.):
<cùmhnant>, covenant; from M.Eng., Sc. {conand}, {couenant}, Eng.
  {covenant}, from O.Fr. {convenant}, Lat. {convenire}.  M.Br. has
  {comanant}, W. @W{cyfammod}.  Dial. plurals are @Ref<cùmhlaichean>
  and @Ref<cùmhlaidean>.

<cur>, a placing, setting; inf. to @Ref{cuir}, q.v.
<curach>, a boat, coracle, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{curach}, Irish Lat. {curucis}, dat.pl.
  (Adamnan), W. @W{corwc}, {cwrwg}, {cwrwgl}, *{kuruko-} (Stokes);

  {carina} has been compared, but the vowels are unsuitable.
  Hence Eng. @Eng{coracle}.
<cùradh>, affliction, obstacle, @Ref<curabh> (Lh.), obstacle.  In the sense
  of affliction, cf. @Ref{cuaradh}.
<curaideach>, frisky, cunning; see @Ref{cuireid}.

  *{kauaro-s}, a hero, mighty, root {keva}, {kû}, be strong; Skr.
  {çavîra}, mighty, {çū́ra}, hero; Gr. @Gr{κύριος}, lord, @Gr{κῦρος}, might.
<cùraing>, @Ref<cùrainn>, a coverlet (Dialectic, H.S.D.); founded on Eng.

<cùram>, care, Ir. @Ir{cúram}; from Lat. {cura}.

  O.W. @OW{cors}, cannulos, W. @W{corsen}, reed, Br. @Br{corsenn}, reed,

  Ag.S. {pearroc}, Fr. {parc} (St.), Lat. {cursus}.  Perhaps Eng.

  {hurst} (St.).

  W. @W{cwr}, corner.
<curracag>, a bubble on the surface of liquids; see @Ref{currachd}.
