<currachd>, hood, cap, night-cap, Ir. @Ir{currach} (O'R.), M.Ir. @MIr{curracach},
  cuculatus (Stokes, Ir. Gl. 598, who suggested connection
  with W. @W{pyrchwyn}, crest of a helmet).  Sc. {curch}, {courchie},
  Eng. @Eng{kerchief}, seem to be the origin of the G. word.
<currachdag>, peat-heap (M`A.); cf. @Ref{gurracag}.
<curradh>, a crowding together (Macpherson's {Ossian}):
<curraidh>, exhausted (H.S.D.), @Ref<currtha> (Sh., O'B.), Ir. @Ir{currtha}; cf.
  @Ref{ciùrr}.
<curran.1>, @Ref<curral.1>, a carrot, root, radish, Ir. @Ir{currán}, any kind of tap-rooted
  plant (O'R., Sh.): *{cors}, head, as in @Ref{corr}?  Cf. Eng.
  {carrot}, ultimately from Gr. @Gr{καρωτόν}, carrot, from @Gr{κάρα}, head,
  top; *{cors} and {kar} of @Gr{κάρα} are ultimately from the same
  source.
<curran.2>, @Ref<curral.2>, horse-panniers for heavy loads; cf. Sc. {currack},
  {corrack} (do.), Eng. @Eng{crooks}.
<currucadh>, cooing of pigeons, Ir. @Ir{currúcadh} (O'R.), Sc., Eng. @Eng{curr},
  {curring}.  The word is onomatopoetic.
<currucag>, the lapwing: see @Ref{curcag}.
<currusan>, a milk-pail:
<cùrsa>, course, manner, Ir. @Ir{cúrsa}, from the Eng. @Eng{course}.
<curta>, bad (Sh.; not H.S.D.), {curtsa} (O'R.); from Eng. @Eng{curst},
  {cursed}.
<cus>, sufficiency, overplus:
<cusag>, a wild mustard (Sh., Arm.; not H.S.D.):
<cusp>, a kibe:
<cuspair>, an object, mark, Ir. @Ir{cuspóir}, M.Ir. @MIr{cuspóir} (Keat., @ExtRef{Oss.;3;296}).
  Dialectic <cuspair>, a customer (see @Ref{cuspunn}).
<cuspunn>, custom, tribute, also @Ref<cusmunn>; founded on Eng. @Eng{custom}.
<cut.1>, hank of yarn, Ir. @Ir{cuta}, one-twelfth of a hank of yarn; from
  Eng. @Eng{cut}.
<cut.2>, to gut (fish); from Eng. @Eng{gut}.
<cutach>, bobtailed, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{do-chotta}, they cut short, W. @W{cwta}.
  The relationship, if any, existing between @Ref{cut.1}, {cutach}, and
  Eng. @Eng{cut}, is one of borrowing; the history of Eng. @Eng{cut} is
  obscure, and the Celtic words mean "short, shorten", not "to
  cut" with a knife.  Besides, the E.Ir. appears a century and
  a half earler than the Eng. (1139 {v}. 1275).  Stokes has
  suggested a borrowing from Fr. {couteau} (= {cultellus}, knife) for
  the E.Ir. form.  Rhys says W. is Eng. @Eng{cutty}, borrowed.
<cuthach>, @Ref<caothach>, rage, Ir. @Ir{cuthach}, *{koti-aca-}; root {kot}, Gr.
  @Gr{κότος}, wrath.  See @Ref{cath}.  Stokes says Pict.  Skr. {kváthati},
  seethe, Got. {hvapjan}, foam.
--page 120
<dà>, two, Ir. @Ir{dá}, O.Ir. @OIr{dá} (m.), {dí} (f.), {da n-} (n.), W. @W{dau} (m.),
  {dwy} (f.), Corn. @Corn{dou}, @Ref{diu}, Br. @Br{daou}, {diou}, (f.), *{dvâ}, *{dvâu} (m.), {dvei}
  (f.), {dvabin} (dat.); Skr. {dvau}, {dvâ}, {dve} (f., n.); Gr. @Gr{δύω}; Lat.
  {duô}: Got. {tuai}, Eng. @Eng{two}.
<dabhach>, a vat, a measure of land (either one or four ploughgates,
  according to locality and land), O.G. {dabach} (Bk.of
  Deer), Ir. @Ir{dabhach}, a vat, *{dabâkâ}; Gr. @Gr{θάπτω}, bury, @Gr{τάφος},
  grave; root {dhabh}, {dhôbh}, deepen, dig out.  Cf. Lit. {důbiú},
  hollow out.  Bezzenberger suggests alliance with Eng. @Eng{top},
  Ger. {topf}.  Eng. @Eng{tub}, if allied to the Ger. {zuber}, is from the
  root of {two}, "a two-eared" vessel.  Also @Ref<dabhoch>, and in
  place-names @Ref<Doch->.
<dàcha>, more likely; see @Ref{dòcha}.
<dachaidh>, home (adverb), a home, Ir. @Ir{do thigh}, M.Ir. @MIr{dia tig},
  home, E.Ir. @EIr{dia thaig}; from @Ref{do.1} and @Ref{tigh}.  In Ir. the phrase
  is a prepositional adverb; in Gaelic it ceases to be a phrase
  and becomes a welded noun.
<dad>, anything, aught, tittle, M.G. {dad}, mote (in sunbeam), Ir.
  {dadadh}, {dadamh}, aught, a jot, etc., *{da-z-dho-}, root {da}, divide,
  Lit. {dalìs}, part, Gr. @Gr{δασμός}, division?  See †@Ref{dàil.3}.  Hence
  @Ref<dadmun>, a mote, and @Ref<dadum> = {dad}.
<dag>, a pistol; from M.Eng. {dag}, a pistol, from Fr. {dague}, a
  dagger, whence Br. @Br{dag}.  The change of meaning from
  "dagger" to "pistol" is one which occurs in the history of
  "pistol" itself, for it originally meant "dagger".  Eng.
  {dagger} is allied.
<daibhir>, poor, Ir. @Ir{daidhbhir}, M.Ir. @MIr{daidber}: *{do-adberi-}, from @Ref{do-.1}
  and {adber}, *{ád-bherô}, Lat. {adfero}.  See @Ref{saoibhir}.
<dàicheil>, handsome, Ir. @Ir{dóigheamhuil}, well appointed, decent; see
  {dácha}, {dócha}, @Ref{dòigh}.
<daidein>, daddy, Ir. @Ir{daidín}, {daid}, M.Ir. @MIr{datán},  foster-father, {datnait},
  foster-mother, W. @W{tad}, Corn. @Corn{tat}; Lat. {tata}; Gr. @Gr{τέττα}; Lit.
  {tetýtis}, Ch.Sl. {teta}; Skr. {tatás}.  Eng. @Eng{dad} is borrowed from
  the Welsh (Skeat).
<daigeil>, firm or well-built (of a man) - Arg.  Cf. @Ref{daingean}.
<dail.1>, a wooden collar for cattle; cf. W. @W{dal}, a hold, catch, Br. @Br{dal},
  a holding; root {dhê}, {dhô}, set?  Cf. Gr. @Gr{θήκη}, repository,
  @Gr{τíθημι}, place, Lat. {facîo}, etc.  But see @Ref{dàil.1}, delay.
<dail.2>, a dale, meadow, from Norse {dalr}, Eng. @Eng{dale}.
<dàil.1>, delay, credit, Ir. @Ir{dáil}, M.Ir. @MIr{dál}, gen. {dála}, respite, *{dâli-};
  from {dvôl}, {dvel}, whence Eng. @Eng{dwell}, Norse {dvöl}, delay.
--page 121
<dàil.2>, a meeting, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{dál}, O.W. @OW{datl}, forum, W. @W{dadl},
  sermo, O.Br. @OBr{dadlou}, curiæ, Br. @Br{dael}, *{datlâ}, root {dha}, {dhê},
  set, as in @Ref{dail.1} (Ernault).  Stokes suggests connection with
  O.Sl. {dê}, dicere.
†<dàil.3>, †@Ref<dàl>, portion, tribe, Ir. and O.Ir. @OIr{dáil}, {dál}, Bede {daal} =
  part, {Dalreudini}, later {Dál-riata}, {Dalriada}, the early Scotic
  kingdom of Argyle, etc: *{dâlo-}, root {dâ}, divide, Gr. @Gr{δατέομαι},
  divide, @Gr{δασμός}, division, Lit. {dalis}, a part, Skr. {dā́ti}, cut off,
  {dalas}, part.  The verb @Ref<dailich>, distribute, is given in H.S.D.
  as a dialectic form; the Ir. is {dáilim}.  Zimmer thinks {dáil},
  meeting, and {dáil}, part, are originally the same.
<dailgneachd>, prophetic vision.  See @Ref{tairgneachd}.
<dàimh>, relationship, Ir. @Ir{dámh}, tribe, family, E.Ir. @EIr{dám}: *{dâmâ},
  tribe, company; Gr. @Gr{δῆμος}, Dor. @Dor{δᾶμος}, people, tribe, Eng.
  {demo}cracy.  It is usual to compare O.W. @OW{dauu}, cliens, W.
  {daw} ({dawf}), son-in-law, M.Br. @MBr{deuff}, Br. @Br{den} (do.); but these
  words may be allied to Gr. @Gr{δάμαρ}, spouse, and be from the
  root {dam}, @Ref{dom}, house.
<daingean>, strong, firm, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{daingen}, W. @W{dengyn}, barbarous,
  *{dangeno-}, firm, hard, verb *{dengô}, E.Ir. @EIr{dingim}, press.
  Bezzenberger compares Norse {tengja}, fasten, tie together,
  Ag.S. {tengan}, press, O.H.G. {gi-zengi}, conjunctus.  Thurneysen
  compares W. @W{tengyn}, obstinate, and Fr. {tangoner}, press. It
  is possible to connect {daingean} with Norse {dyngja}, heap,
  women's apartment, Ag.S. {ding}, carcer, Lit. {dengiu}, cover;
  perhaps O.H.G. {tunc}, earth-house, Eng. @Eng{dung}.
<dàir>, inire vaccam, Ir. @Ir{dáir}, M.Ir. @MIr{dair}, *{dârô}, root {dhṝ-}, {dhoro},
  Gr. @Gr{θρώσκω}, spring, @Gr{θορός}, semen viri, Skr. {dhā́ra}, stream,
  seed.
<dairireach>, rattling noise, E.Ir. @EIr{der-drethar}, cries, W. @W{dâr}, noise,
  {daredd}, tumultuous noise, root {der}, {dher}, as in Gr. @Gr{θρῆνος},
  dirge, Skr. {dhraṇ}, sound, Eng. @Eng{drone}.  See @Ref{dùrd} and
  @Ref{stairirich}.
<dais.1>, a heap of hay or peats, O.Ir. @OIr{ais}, a heap, W. @W{dâs}, O.W.
  {das}, M.Br. @MBr{dastum}, to mass, *{dasti-} (for G. and W.); Ag.S.
  {tass} (whence Fr. {tas}).  Bezzenberger and Stokes correlate it
  with Norse {des}, hay heap, Sc. {dass}.
<dais.2>, @Ref<dois>, a blockhead (H.S.D.), @Ref<daiseachan>, insipid rhymer
  (Arm.); seemingly borrowed from the Sc. {dawsie}, stupid,
  {dase} stupefy.  For root, see @Ref{dàsachd}.  Norse {dasi}, lazy fellow.
<dais.3>, a musical instrument:
<daithead>, a diet; from the Eng.  See @Ref{dìot}.
<dala>, one of two; see under @Ref{dara}.
--page 122
<dall>, blind, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{dall}, W., Br. @Br{dall}, Corn. @Corn{dal}, *{dvalno-}, I.E.
  {dhvḷ-no-}; Got. {dvals}, foolish, Eng. @Eng{dull}; Lat. {fallo}, cheat
  (= {dhalnó}); Gr. @Gr{θολερός}, turbid.  Hence {inter alia}, @Ref<dallag>,
  a field shrew, a mole, Ir. @Ir{dallóg}.
<dallanach>, a winnowing fan; from @Ref{dall}.
<dalma>, bold, forward, obstinate: "vigorous"?, root {dhḷ} in @Ref{duille}.
<dalta>, foster-son, god-son, O.G. {dalta} (Bk.of Deer), Ir. @Ir{dalta},
  O.Ir. @OIr{dalte}, *{daltaio-s}, root {dhê}, {dhêl}, suck; Gr. @Gr{θῆλυς},
  female; Lat. {fêlo}, suck, femina; etc. (Stokes, Strachan).  See
  @Ref{deoghail}.  It has been usual to refer {dalta} to the root {al} of
  {altram}, the {d} being considered as the remains of @Ref{de}, the
  prepositional prefix (*{de-altjo-s}).
<dàm>, a dam; from the Eng.
<dàmais>, draughts, @Ref<bord dàmais>, draught board; from the Sc.
  {dams}, {dambrod}, Ger. {dambrett}, from Fr. {dame}, dame, draughts,
  Lat. {domina}.
<damh>, ox, stag, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{dam}, Corn. @Corn{da}, dama, M.Br. @MBr{dauat},
  sheep, Br. @Br{danvad}, sheep, {demm}, roe, *{damo-s}; Lat. {dâma},
  {damma}, deer; Gr. @Gr{δαμάλης}, a stier, @Gr{δάμαλις}, a calf; Skr.
  {damya}, untamed stier.  Allied is Eng. @Eng{tame}, Lat. {domare},
  Eng. @Eng{domestic}, etc.
<dàmhair.1>, rutting time; for {damh-dhàir}, from @Ref{damh} and @Ref{dàir}
  (H.S.D.).
<dàmhair.2> (H.S.D.), @Ref<damhair> (Sh., Arm.), earnest, keen:
<damhan-allaidh>, spider, Ir. @Ir{damhán-alla}, O.Ir. @OIr{damán n-allaid}
  (g.pl.), "wild little deer"; see @Ref{damh} and @Ref{allaidh}.
<damnadh>, cursing, condemnation, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{damnad}; from
  Lat. {damnatio}.
<dàn.1>, fate, destiny, Ir. @Ir{dán}; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{dán}, gift, W. @W{dawn}, gift,
  talent, Lat. {dônum}, root {dó}, Gr. @Gr{δíδωμι}, give, Skr. {dâ}, give.
<dàn.2>, a poem, Ir. @Ir{dán}, song, O.Ir. @OIr{dán}, g. {dáno}, ars. *{dâsnu-}, root
  {dâs}, know; Gr. @Gr{δήνεα}, plans, arts, @Gr{δαήμον}, skilful; Ch.Sl.
  {danhanh}, wisdom; Skr. {damsána}, miracle (Stokes).
<dàn.3>, bold, Ir. @Ir{dána}, O.Ir. @OIr{dáne}, {dána}, *{dâsnavo-s}, from the root
  of {dán} above (Stokes).
<danns>, dance (thou), @Ref<dannsa>, @Ref<damhsa>, a dance, Ir. @Ir{damhsa}, W.
  {dawns}; from the Eng.
<dao>, obstinate, O.Ir. @OIr{doe}, g. {doi}, tardus, *{dausio-s}; Ag.S. {dysig},
  foolish, Eng. @Eng{dizzy}, O.H.G. {tusîc}, stultus, Ger. {thor}, foolish
  (Stokes, Windisch).
<daobhaidh>, wicked, perverse (Heb.); see @Ref{dao}.
<daoch>, strong dislike, horror, @Ref<daochan>, anger (Sh.):
<daoi>, wicked, a wicked man, Ir. @Ir{daoi}, a wicked or foolish person;
  opposite of @Ref{saoi} (with @Ref{do-.1}, *@Ref{du-}), which see for root.
--page 123
<daoimean>, a diamond; from the Eng.
<daol>, @Ref<daolag>, a beetle, Ir. @Ir{daol}, E.Ir. @EIr{dael}, {doel}, {dail}: *{daoilo-}, root
  {dei}, {di}, as in @Ref{dian}, q.v.  Stokes connects with M.Ir. @MIr{dael},
  grightsomeness, root {dvei}, fright, Gr. @Gr{δέος}, a fright, Skr.
  {dvis}, hate.
<daolair>, a lazy man, a niggard, Ir. @Ir{daol}, lazy (O'R.):
<daonnan>, @Ref<daondan>, continually, always *{d'aon-tan} (?), "from one
  time".  Cf. @Ref{greis.2}.
<daor.1>, enslaved, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{dóir}; opposite of @Ref{saor.1} (with negative
  (do), *@Ref{du-}), which see for root.
<daor.2>, dear, Ir. @Ir{daor}, {daoradh}, making dear (Four Masters); from
  M.Eng. {deere}, {deore}, dear (Stokes).
<daorach>, intoxication; cf. Sc. {deray}, mirthful noise at a banquet,
  M.Eng. {derai}, disorder, from Fr. {desroi}, dis-{array}.
<dar>, when (conj.), Northern form for @Ref<'n uair>; probably {d'uair} =
  {do-uair}.
<dara>, second, so Ir.; M.G. {darle} (Oss. Ballad, Fernaig MS),
  *{ind-araile}, "the other", from {ind} = @Ref{an.1}, the, and O.Ir. @OIr{araile},
  alius = {ar}+{aile}, @Ref{air}+@Ref{eile}, q.v., {alalijos}, Br. @Br{arall}.  Also @Ref<an dala>,
  the one of two, O.Ir., @OIr{indala}, from {ind} and {aile}, that
  is @Ref{an.1} and @Ref{eile}.  Further, @Ref<dàrna> (= @Ref{dala}), E.Ir. @EIr{indarna},
  *{ind-araile n-ai}, the one of them (two), O.Ir. @OIr{indala n-ai},
  where {ái}, eorum, is the pl. of @Ref{a.2}, his.
<darach>, oak, Ir. @Ir{dair}, {darach}, E.Ir. @EIr{dair}, gen. {darach}, W., Corn.
  @Ref{dar}, *{darik-}; Lat. {larix}, Eng. @Eng{larch}; Gr. (Maced.) @Maced{δάρυλλος},
  oak, @Gr{δρῦς} (do.), {dóru}, spear; Eng. @Eng{tree}, etc.  Hence <darach>,
  body of a boat.
<darcan.1>, the hollow of the hand (Dialectic, H.S.D.); cf. @Ref{deàrna}.
<darcan.2>, a teal:
<dàrna>, one of two; see under @Ref{dara}.
<darnaig>, darn, darning; from the Eng. @Eng{darning}, which is itself
  from W. @W{darn}, piece, patch (root {dera}, split, Eng. @Eng{tear}).
<dàsachd>, rage, madness, M.G. {dásacht} (M`V.), Ir. @Ir{dásachd}, O.Ir.
  {dásacht}, insania; Ag.S. {dwáes}, foolish, Sc. {dawsie}, Du. {dwaas},
  senseless (Strachan).
<dath>, colour, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{dath}, *{datu-}; from the root {dha}, {dhê},
  place, as in @Ref{dail.1}, etc.?
<dàth>, singe, Ir. @Ir{doghaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{dóthim}, inf. {dóud}, {daif} (n.), Br.
  {deuiff}, to burn, *{daviô}, I burn; Gr. @Gr{δαíω}, burn; Skr. {du},
  {dunóti}, burn, {davas}, a brand.
<dathas>, fallow deer; @Ref<damhasg>, @Ref<dabhasg>; from @Ref{damh}+@Ref{seasg} (?).
<de>, of, Ir. @Ir{de}, O.Ir. @OIr{de}, {di}, O.W. @OW{di}, W. @W{y}, Corn. @Corn{the}, Br. @Br{di}, *{de},
  *{di}, *{dê}; Lat. {dê}; from {dvê}, a case-form from {dvô}, two.
  Gaelic and Irish confuse this prep. with @Ref{do.1}, to; a confusion
--page 124
  which even extends to O.Ir. in pre-accentual {de} compounds.
  Hence <do> of the past tenses: {do chaidh}, went, i.e., @Ref{deach}; {do rinn},
  did, from {do-gníu}, I do, etc.
<dé.1>, what; also @Ref<gu dé>; a curtailed form of {ciod è}, "what is it";
  from @Ref{ciod} and @Ref{è}, q.v.  Ir. @Ir{caidé}, Galway {godé}.
<dé.2>, @Ref<an dé>, yesterday, Ir. @Ir{ané}, ({andé}), O.Ir. @OIr{indhé}, W. @W{y ddoe}, Br.
  {deac'h}, M.Br. @MBr{dech}, *{sendi-gesi}, art. {an} and *{gesi}; Lat. {heri}
  (= *{hesî}); Gr. @Gr{χθές}; Eng. @Eng{yesterday}.  The Celtic forms are
  all influenced by the word for "to-day", G. {an diu}, O.Ir.
  {indiu}, W. @W{heddyw}, {dyw}; from @Ref{diu}, *{divo}, day, q.v.  Zimmer
  in fact refers the word to the root of @Ref{diu} (@ExtRef{Zeit.;30;17}).  *{jesi},
  {ghjesi}, {heri}, etc. (St.).
<dé.3>: @Ref<teine dé>, M.Ir. @MIr{tene díait}, lightning; *{deia}, shine with {-anti}
  or {-anta} (n.) (St.).
<dèabh>, drain, dry up, @Ref<dèabhadh> (pronounced {dè-u}, shrinking (as
  the staves of a wooden vessel), Dialectic @Ref<deò>; I.E. {dhevo-},
  run, Eng. @Eng{dew}, Gr. @Gr{θέω}, run, Skr. {dhav}, run, flow.
<deacaid>, boddice, jacket; from Eng. @Eng{jacket}.
<deacair>, difficult, surly, Ir. @Ir{deacair}, O.Ir. @OIr{deccair}; for {di-acar}:
  prep. @Ref{de} and {acar}, as in @Ref{socair}, q.v.
<deach>, went; the post-particicle or enclitic form of {do chaidh}, q.v.
  Ir. @Ir{deachaidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{dechud}.
<deachd>, dictate, so Ir., {deachdadh} (n.); from Lat. {dicto}, {dictatio},
  whence Eng. @Eng{dictation}.
<deadhan>, a dean; from the Eng.
<deagh>, good, Ir. @Ir{deagh}, O.Ir. @OIr{deg-}, {dag-}, W. @W{da}, Corn. @Corn{da}, bonum
  (gl.), Gaul. {Dago-}, *{dago-}, *{dego-}, "good, acceptable"; Gr.
  @Gr{δέχεσθαι}, receive.  Further allied to Gr. @Gr{δεξιός}, right, @Gr{δέκομαι}
  receive; Lat. {dexter}, right, {decus}, {doceo}; Gaelic @Ref{deas}, O.Ir.
  {dech}, best (superlative to {deagh} or @Ref{maith.1}).
<deaghad>, living, diet, morals (Uist); see @Ref{dìot}.
<deaghaidh>: see @Ref{déidh.2}.
<deal.1>, friendly (H.S.D., M`E.); see @Ref{dìleas}.
<deal.2>, @Ref<deala>, a leech, Ir. @Ir{deal}, a blood-sucker (O'R.); from I.E.
  root {dhê}, suck, as in @Ref{deoghail}, q.v.  Cf. Lit. {dėlė}, leech; also
  Ir. (and G. in Dict. therefrom) @Ref<deala>, teat, E.Ir. @EIr{del}.
<dealaich>, separate, Ir. @Ir{dealuighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{deligim}, {deil}, separation;
  I.E. {delo-}, to split, Skr. {dalítas}, split, Gr. @Gr{δέλτος}, tablet, Lit.
  {dalis}, part.  Cf. †@Ref{dàil.3}, part.
<dealan>, @Ref<dealanach>, lightning, Ir. @Ir{dealán}, spark, flaming coal,
  *{dilo-}: root {di}, {dei} ({dêi}), {deya} (Fick), shine; Gr. @Gr{δέελος}
  (= @Gr{δέj-ελος}), conspicuous, @Gr{δῆλος}, clear; Skr. {dî}, shine; further
  is *{dei-vo-s}, whence G. @Ref{dia}, etc. M.Ir. @MIr{tene-gelain}, "lightning",
  now "will o' the wisp"; {tene-gelan}, fireflaught.
--page 125
<dealan-dé>, butterfly, Ir. @Ir{dalán-dé}, {dealán-dé}.  The G. also means
  the phenomenon observed by shirling a stick lighted at
  the end.  Apparently the meaning is "God's fire".  For
  {dé}, see @Ref{dia}.
<dealan-doruis>, door-bolt (Sh., O'R.); see @Ref{deil.1}.
<dealas>, zeal, @Ref<dealasach>, zealous; from the Eng. @Eng{zeal}, {zealous}.
<dealbh>, form, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{delb}, W. @W{delw}, Br. @Br{-delu}, *{delvo-}, root
  {del}; Lat. {dolare}, hew, {dolo}, a pike; Gr. @Gr{δαιδάλλω}, embellish,
  work cunningly; O.H.G. {zol}, log; Ch.Sl. {dely}, vat.
<dealg>, a pin, skewer, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{delg}, M.W. @MW{dala}, sting, fang,
  W. @W{dal}, a catch, Corn. @Corn{delc}, monile, *{delgos}; Ag.S. {telgan}
  virgultum, twig, Du. {telg}, M.H.G. {zelge}, Norse {tjálgr}, a
  prong; Lit. {dalgís}, scythe (?).  Bezzenberger compares Norse
  {dálkr}, a cloak pin; cf. Ag.S. {dalc}, buckle.
<dealradh>, brightness, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{dellrad}, jubar; from {deal-}, as
  in @Ref{dealan}, q.v.
<dealt>, dew, Ir. @Ir{dealt}, M.Br., Br. @Br{delt}, moist, damp:
<dealunn>, loud barking (H.S.D.); see @Ref{deileann}.
<deamhan>, a demon, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{demon}; from Lat. {daemon}, from
  Gr. @Gr{δαíμων}, Eng. @Eng{demon}.
<deamhais>, @Ref<deimheis>, shears, Ir. @Ir{deimheas} (pronounced {díos}), E.Ir.
  {demess}, *{di-mess}, "two-edged"; from {di} of {da}, two, and E.Ir.
  {mess}, edge (Cormac's Gl.), "cutter", from root {met}, mow, cut,
  as in @Ref{meath}, {meith}, cut, prune, Lat. {meto}.  Cf. Gaul. {mataris}.
---JTM: changed Gaul, to Gaul.
<dèan>, do, Ir. @Ir{déan} (imper.), O.Ir. @OIr{dén}, {dénim}: enclitic or post-particle
  form of O.Ir. @OIr{dogníu}, G. @Ref{nì.2}, I do; from @Ref{de}, of, and
  {gnî} of @Ref{gnìomh}, q.v.  Inf. @Ref<dèanamh> (= {de-gnîmu-}).
<deann>, haste, speed; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{denmne}, haste, which Cormac
  explains as {di-ainmne}, "non-patience", from {ainmne}, patience;
  root {men}, wait (Lat. {maneo}, etc.).
<deannag>, a small pinch, a grain, @Ref<deannach>, mill dust, Ir. @Ir{deanóg},
  a pinch, grain:
<deannal>, conflict, stir, so Ir. (O'R.); from @Ref{deann}.  In the sense of
  "flash" (H.S.D.), <deannal> seems a metathetical form of
  @Ref{dealan}.
<deanntag>, a nettle, Ir. @Ir{neantóg}, M.Ir. @MIr{nenntóg}, E.Ir. @EIr{nenaid},
  *{nenadi-}, for *{ne-nadi}, a reduplicated form; Ag.S. {netele},
  Eng. @Eng{nettle}; Lit. {néndrė}, pipe, tube.  The {t} of G. and Ir. is
  due to the same phonetic law that gives @Ref{teine} the pl. {teintean}.
<dearail>, poor, wretched, Ir. @Ir{dearóil}, E.Ir. @EIr{deróil}, feeble, O.Ir.
  {deróil}, penuria, from {der-}, privative prefix (see @Ref{deàrgnaidh}),
  and {óil}, abundance, which Windisch has referred to *{pâli-}, a
  form of the root {pḷ}, {pel}, full, as in {lán}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {deargnaidh}
<dearbadan>, @Ref<dearbadan-dé>, butterfuly (M`D., H.S.D.):
--page 126
<dearbh>, certain, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{derb}, *{dervo-}; I.E. {drevo-}, whence
  Ag.S. {treówe}, Eng. @Eng{true}, Ger. {treu}.
<dearc.1>, @Ref<dearcag>, a berry, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{derc}, *{derkes-}, Skr. {drâkshâ},
  grape, vine (Stokes); root {derk}, see, the idea being "conspicuous".
  Cf. Gr. @Gr{δράκων}, dragon, @Gr{δορκάς}, gazelle, from the
  root {derk}, see.  See @Ref{dearc.4}, behold.  The O.Ir. @OIr{derucc}, g.
  {dercon}, glans, is, like Ger. {eichel}, glans (from {eiche}, oak), from
  the root of @Ref{darach}, oak (Zimmer).
<dearc.2>, @Ref<dearc-luachrach>, a lizard, Ir. @Ir{earcluachra}, the "@Ref{earc} of the
  rashes", M.Ir. @MIr{erc}, speckled, red, Ir. @Ir{earc}, salmon, W. @W{erch},
  fuscus, darkish, *{erko-s}, for {perko-}; Gr. @Gr{περκνός}, dark-blue,
  @Gr{πέρκη}, a perch; Skr. {pṛçnis}, speckled; Ger. {forelle}, a trout,
  O.H.G. {forhanna}.  For meaning, cf. @Ref{breac}, a trout, "the
  speckled one".  The {d} of G. {dearc} belongs to the article.
†<dearc.3>, an eye, a cave, hole, Ir. @Ir{dearc} (do.), O.Ir. @OIr{derc} (do.); from
  the root {derk}, behold.  See verb @Ref{dearc.4}: "eye-pit" gives the
  meaning "cave".  Shaw has {deirc} for "pit" in Engl.Gael.
  section.
<dearc.4>, behold, see, Ir. @Ir{dearcaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{dercaim}, video, {derc}, eye,
  *{derkô}, I see, perfect *{dedorka} (cf. @Ref{chunnairc} = {con-darc}
  I.E. {derk}, see; Gr. @Gr{δέρκομαι}, @Gr{δέδορκα}, have seen; O.H.G.
  {zoraht}, bright; Skr. {darç}, see.
<dearg>, red, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{derg}, *{dhergo-s}; Eng. @Eng{dark}, Ag.S. {deorc}.
<deargad>, @Ref<deargant>, a flea, Ir. @Ir{deargán}, {dreancuid}, {deargnuid}, E.Ir.
  {dergnat}: *{derg-nat}, "reddener", from @Ref{dearg}, red?
<deàrgnaidh>, unlearned (Arm.; M`A. says "Irish"), Ir. @Ir{deargnaidh},
  *{der-gnadi-}; from {der-}, privative prefix ({di}+@Ref{air}, see @Ref{de} and
  @Ref{air}), and root {gnâ}, {gen}, know, as in @Ref{aithne}.
<deàrlan>, brimful; *{der-lán}; from intensive prefix {der} (= @Ref{de}+@Ref{ro})
  and @Ref{làn}, full.
<dearmad>, neglect, forgetfulness, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{dermet}, *{der-mét};
  from {der-}, priv. particle (see @Ref{deàrgnaidh}) and {mét}, *{mento-},
  mind; root {men}, think; Lat. {mens}, {mentio}, {commentum}; Eng.
  {mind}; etc.
<dearmail>, anxiety (M`D.), anxious (H.S.D.):
<deàrn>, do, Ir. @Ir{deárnaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{derninn}, facerem, *{di-ro-gnî-}, a side
  form of @Ref{dèan} with infixed @Ref{ro}.  See @Ref{dèan}.
<deàrna>, the palm of the hand, Ir. @Ir{déarna}, E.Ir. @EIr{derna}; cf. Gr.
  @Gr{δῶρον}, palm, handbreadth, @Gr{δάρις}, the distance between the
  thumb and little finger, a span (Hes.), @Gr{δαρεἱρ}, the distance
  between the big and little fingers (Hes.).  It is further
  referred to the I.E. root {der}, split, open (Fick, Prellwitz).
<dearras>, keenness, obstinacy; see @Ref{diarras}.

<deàrrsach>, a swig of liquor (Wh.):
<deàrrsadh>, radiance, effulgence, Ir. @Ir{dearsgaim}, {dearsgnaim}, I

  *{de-ro-sec-}, root {sec}, see, Eng. @Eng{see}?  Hence @Ref<deàrrsgnuìdh>
  burnished, brilliant.  The word †@Ref<deàrsgnaidh>, excellent, is
  allied to O.Ir. @OIr{dersigem}, præcellimus, {dirósci}, excels, {doroscai},

<deasbud>, a dispute; from the Eng. @Eng{dispute}, Lat. {disputo}.
<deasgainn>, rennet, barm, @Ref<deasgadh>, lees, yeast, Ir. @Ir{deasgadh}, lees,

<deat>, an unshorn year-old sheep or wedder, @Ref<deathaid>, *{det-anti-},
  "sucking one"; from {det}, @Ref{de}, suck.  See @Ref{deoghail}.
<deatam>, anxiety; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{dethitiu}, {dethiden}, care.  For root, see
  @Ref{dìdean}.  M`A. has also @Ref<deatamach>, necessary, which seems
  allied.
<deathach>, @Ref<deatach>, smoke, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{deatach}, O.Ir. @OIr{dé}, g. {diad},
  E.Ir. @EIr{dethach}, {detfadach}, smoky, W. @W{dywy}, vapour.  From
  I.E. root {dhêu}, {dheu}, {dhu}, {dhve}, smoke, air; Lat. {fûmus},
  smoke; Gr. @Gr{θυμιάω}, to smoke; Ch.Sl. {dymŭ} (n.); Skr.
  {dhûmas}.  Ir. @Ir{dé} is for {dīvâ}, from {dhêu}, or {dhêv}; the gen. {diad}
  is phonetically like the nom. {biad}, food (*{bivoto-n}).  The
  form @Ref{deatach} is probably for *{dett-acos}, {dett} being from {dhve}
  (cf. Gr. @Gr{θεός}, for @Gr{θεσ-ός}, from {dhve-s-}).  The {t} (= {tt}) of @Ref{deatach}
  is difficult to account for.  For phonetics cf. @Ref{beathach}.
<déibhleid>, a feeble or awkward person, M.Ir. @MIr{déblén}, E.Ir. @EIr{dedblén},
  weakling, from {dedbul}, weak; the opposite of @Ref{adhbhal}, q.v.
  ({di-adbul}).  Stokes allows the alternate possibility of it
  being from Lat. {dêbilis}; see @Ref{dìblidh}.

<déidh.1>, desire; a noun formed from the adverbial phrase {an déidh},

<déidh.2>, @Ref<an déidh>, after, Ir. @Ir{a n-diaigh}, O.Ir. @OIr{i n-dead}, post, E.Ir.
  {i n-diaid}, from O.Ir. @OIr{déad}, finis, W. @W{diwedd}, finis, Corn. @Corn{deweth},
  Br. @Br{diuez}, *{dê-ved-on} (Stokes); from the root {ved}, lead, as in
  @Ref{toiseach}, q.v. (Stokes prefers {ved} of @Ref{feadhainn}.  Also @Ref<deidh>,
  @Ref<déigh>, the latter a bad form etymologically.  The O.Ir. had
  also the form {degaid} (= {di-agaid}), the opposite of {i n-agid},
  now {an aghaidh}, against, adversus.
<deidhinn>, @Ref<mu dheidhinn>, concerning, of; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{dágin}, {daigind},

  because (prep. and conj.), O.Ir. @OIr{dég}, quia.  See @Ref{dòigh}.

<deigh>, ice, Ir. @Ir{oighear}, snow, {leac-oighir}, ice, O.Ir. @OIr{aig}, g. {ega},

<deir>, @Ref<a deir>, says (said), inquit, Ir. @Ir{deirim}, O.Ir. @OIr{adbeir}, dicit; {deir}
  is the root-accented fort (*{ad-bérô}) of @Ref{abair} (the prepositional

  belongs to the @Ref{ad-}, while the {d} of it takes the place of
  {b} in the root ({ber}).

  *{der-vedo-n}, root {ved} as in @Ref{déidh.2}, q.v.?  Ascoli suggests that
  {der} is the basis, the opposite of {er}, front, from the proposition
  @Ref{air} (*{pare}).  Hence @Ref<deireas>, injury.
<déis>, @Ref<an déis>, after, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{di éis}, retro, O.G. {daneis}, after

<deòidh>, @Ref<fa dheòidh>, at last, finally, Ir. @Ir{fá dheoidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{fo diud},
  postremo; dat. case of O.Ir. @OIr{déad}, end.  See @Ref{déidh.2} for

<deòin>, assent, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{deóin}, *{degni-}; I.E. root {deg}, {degh}; Gr.
  @Gr{δοκέω}, seem, @Gr{δόξα}, opinion, @Gr{διδαχή}, teaching, Lat. {doceo},
  {doctrina}, etc.  See @Ref{deagh}, good.
<deòradh>, an alien, Ir. @Ir{deóraidh}, a stranger, exile, M.Ir. @MIr{deorad}.
  Stokes thinks the word is borrowed from Brittonic - Br.
  {devroet}, depaysé, "dis-countrified" ({di-brog-}, see @Ref{brugh}), Corn.
  {diures}, exul.  {deòradh}: opposite of @Ref{urradh}, guarantor, = {di-urradh}
  (Jub.).  {air-rad} (Meyer).  Hence the name {Dewar}.
<detheine>, a heated boring iron: *{déthéine}, the accent being on
  the second portion @Ref{teine}, fire.  For {dé}, see @Ref{dealan-dé}.
<detheoda>, henbane (M`D.):
<detìach>, @Ref<deteigheach>, the gullet, weasand (M`D., Sh., etc.):
  peculiar as accented on {iach}, properly {det-íach}; Dial. @Ref<it-ioch>,
  epiglottis (Arg.).
<deubh>, shrink; see @Ref{dèabh}.
<deubhann>, a fetter for a horse:

<deud>, a tooth, Ir. @Ir{déad}, O.Ir. @OIr{dét}, W. @W{dant}, Corn. @Corn{dans}, Br. @Br{dant}.
  {dṇtâ} (Stokes); Lat. {dens} ({dentis}); Gr. @Gr{ὀδούς} (g. @Gr{ὀδόντος}); Eng.
  {tooth}, Got. {tunþus}; Lit. {dantìs}; Skr. {dant-}.
<deug>, @Ref<diag>, -teen, e.g., @Ref<cóig-deug>, fif-teen, Ir. @Ir{déag}, O.Ir. @OIr{déc},
  {deac}, W. @W{deng}, ten (?).  The exact relationship of {deug} to
  @Ref{deich} is difficult to decide.  The other I.E. languages, as
  a rule, make 13 to 19 by combining the unit numeral
  with 10, as Ger. {drei-zehn}, Ag.S. {ðríténe}, Lat. {tridecim}.
  *{dvei-penge} (St.).
<deur>, @Ref<diar>, a tear, drop, Ir. @Ir{déar}, {deór}, O.Ir. @OIr{dér}, W., Corn., {dagr},
  O.Br. @OBr{dacr}, M.Br. @MBr{dazrou}, tears, *{dakru}; Gr. @Gr{δάκρυ}; Lat.
  {lacrima}, for {dacrima}; Eng. @Eng{tear}, Got. {tagr}.
<Di->, {-day}; the prefix in the names of the days of the week, Ir.,
  O.Ir. @OIr{dia}, {die} (O.Ir.), W. @W{dydd}, Corn. @Corn{det} (for {dedh}), Br. @Br{dez},
--page 131
  {dijas} (*dejes-?); Lat. {diês}; Skr. {dyáús}, day, sky; Gr. @Gr{Zεύς},
  @Gr{Διός}, Jove.  Allied to @Ref{dia}, god.  @Ref<Di-dòmhnuich>, Sunday, Ir.
  {Domhnach}, E.Ir. @EIr{domnach}, from Lat. (dies) {dominica}, Lard's
  day - {dominus}, lord; @Ref<Di-luain>, Monday, Ir. @Ir{Dia-luain}, M.Ir.
  @Ref{luan}, W. @W{Dydd Llun}, from Lat. dies {Lunæ}, "day of the
  moon"; @Ref<Di-màirt>, Tuesday, Ir. @Ir{Dia-mairt}, E.Ir. @EIr{máirt}, W.
  {Dydd mawrth}, from Lat. dies {Martis}, "day of Mars"; @Ref<Di-ciaduinn>,
  @Ref<Di-ciadaoin>, Wednesday, Ir. @Ir{Dia-céadaoine}, O.Ir.
  {cétáin}, {cétóin}, {de cétain} (@Ref{de} = @Ref{dia} = Lat. {die}), {dia cetáíne}, from
  @Ref{ceud.1}, first, and {aone}, fast, q.v., E.Ir. @EIr{áine}: "day of the first
  fast", Friday being the second and chief day; @Ref<Diardaoin>,
  Thursday, Ir. @Ir{Dia-dhardaoin}, E.Ir. @EIr{dardóen} = {etar dá óin},
  "between two fasts" - the day between the two fasts of
  Wednesday and Friday; @Ref<Di-haoine>, Friday, Ir. @Ir{Dia-aoine},
  {Dia-haoine}, E.Ir. @EIr{áine}, {dia áine}, O.Ir. @OIr{dia oine dídine} (day
  of the last fast): "day of the fast", from {aoin}, fast, q.v.;
  @Ref<Di-sathuirn>, Saturday, Ir. @Ir{Dia-sathuirn}, M.Ir. @MIr{satharn}, {dia sathairn},
  from Lat. dies {Saturni}, day of Saturn.  The days
  of the week were originally named (in Egypt) after the seven
  planets of the ancients - Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jove, Jove,
  Venus, Saturn.
<di->, negative prefix, Ir. @Ir{dí}, {dío-}, O.Ir. @OIr{dí}, W. @W{di}, *{dê}; Lat. {dê},
  of.  See @Ref{de}.  Also @Ref<dim>, @Ref<diom-> (@Ref{dìmeas}, @Ref{dimbrigh}, @Ref{diombuaidh},
  {diomal}).
<dia>, a god, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{día}, W. @W{duw}, O.W. @OW{duiu}, Corn. @Corn{duy}, Br.
  {doe}, Gaul. {dêvo}, @Gr{Δειουονα} = Dîvona, *{deiuo-s}; Lat. {dîvus} (for
  {deiuos}), deified one, {deus}; Gr. @Gr{δῖος}, divine; Norse {tívar}, gods,
  Eng. @Eng{Tues}-day, "day of {Tiw}", the war-god; Lit. {dë́vas}, Pruss.
  {deiwas}; Skr. {devá}.  Hence @Ref<diadhaidh>, pious, Ir. @Ir{diadha},
  O.Ir. @OIr{diade}, divinus.

<Diardaoin>, Thursday; see @Ref{Di-}.

<diarras>, @Ref<dìorras>, stubbornness, vehemence, Ir. @Ir{díorruisg}, fierceness,

  root {steip}, stiff, Lat. {stipes}, stake, stipula, Eng. @Eng{stiff}?  Cf.

<dibhirceach>, diligent (Sh.; H.S.D., which refers to C.S., but
  neither in M`A. nor M`E.), Ir. @Ir{dibhirceach}, diligent, violent
  (O'B., etc.):
<dìbir>, forsake; see @Ref{dìobair}.
<dibith>, @Ref<dimbith>, luckless, lifeless (Carm.):
<dìblidh>, abject, vile, Ir. @Ir{díbligh}, O.Ir. @OIr{diblide}, senium; seemingly
  from Lat. {dêbilis}, weak, feeble (Eng. {debilitate}, etc.).  Zim.
  (@ExtRef{Zeit.;24;}) has suggested *{dí-adbul}, "un-great", from {adbul},
  i.e. @Ref{adhbhal}, q.v.
<dìbrigh>, @Ref<dimbrigh>, contempt, Ir. @Ir{dimbrigh}; from {dim-}, {dí-}, and
  @Ref{brìgh}, q.v.
<dìchioll>, diligence, Ir. @Ir{díthchioll}: *{dícell-}; for {cell}, see @Ref{timchioll}.
  Or from @Ref{ciall}, sense; "attention to"?
<Di-ciadaoin>, Wednesday; see @Ref{Di-}.
<dìd>, a peep; an onomatopoetic word.
<dìdean>, protection, a fort, Ir. @Ir{dídean}, O.Ir. @OIr{dítiu}, g. {díten}, *{di-jemtion-}
  (Stokes); root {jem}, cover, protect, Lett. {ju'mju}, {ju'mt},
  cover a roof.  The O.Ir. verb is {do-emim} tueor.  Ascoli
  makes the root {em}, as in Lat. {emo}, buy.  Cf. @Ref{eiridinn}.
<Di-dòmhnuich>, Sunday; see @Ref{Di-}.
<difir>, difference, Ir. @Ir{difir}, {dithfir}, M.Ir. @MIr{dethbir}; from Lat. {differo},
  Eng. @Eng{differ}.
<dìg>, a wall of loose stones, a dike; from the Sc. {dike}, Eng. @Eng{dike}.
<dil>, eager, keen.  See @Ref{deil.2}.
<dìl>, @Ref<dìle>, @Ref<dìlinn>, a flood, Ir. @Ir{díle}, pl. {díleanna}, E.Ir. @EIr{díli}, g. {dílenn},
  diluvium; from Lat. {diluvium} (Stokes), whence Eng. @Eng{deluge}.
<dile>, dill (M`D.); from the Eng.
<dìleab>, a legacy, Ir. @Ir{dilb} (O'R.):
<dileag>, a small drop; from @Ref{dìle}, flood.
--page 133
<dìleas>, dear, faithful, Ir. @Ir{díleas}, O.Ir. @OIr{díles}, proprius, own, *{dêlesto-},
  {dêl}, I.E. {dhêl}, {dhê}, suck, Lat. {filius}, {femina}, etc.  See @Ref{deoghal}.
  Zeuss has suggested {di+leas}, from @Ref{leas}, advantage.
<dìleigh>, digest, @Ref<dìleaghadh>, digesting, Ir. @Ir{dìleaghadh}, from
  {di-leagh}, root of @Ref{leagh}, melt.
<dileum> (accent on @Ref{leum}), a shackle; {di+leum}, q.v.
<dìlinn>, @Ref<leac dhìlinn>, a stone {in situ}, a rock appearing above
  ground: "natural", from {dìl-} as in @Ref{dìleas}.
<dìlleachdan>, an orphan, Ir. @Ir{dílleachda}, O.Ir. @OIr{dilechtu}, orfani:
  "de{re}lict", from @Ref{di-} and @Ref{leig}, let go ({di-lēc-}, let go).

<dìmeas>, contempt, Ir. @Ir{dímheas}, O.Ir. @OIr{dímess}; from {dí-}, {dím-}, and

<dinn>, press, force down, squeeze, Ir. @Ir{dingim}, {ding}, a wedge, E.Ir.
  {dingim}, perf. {dedaig}, *{dengô}; Ag.S. {tengan}, press, Norse
  {tengja}, fasten (Bezzenberger).  See @Ref{daingean}.  Brugmann
  refers it to *{dhinghô}, Lat. {fingo}, mould, feign, I.E. {dheigh},
  Eng. @Eng{dough}.
<dinnein>, a small heap, Ir. @Ir{dinn}, a hill, fortified hill, E.Ir. @EIr{dinn}

  pinnacle, Eng. @Eng{tine}.  But cf. Gr. @Gr{θíς}, @Gr{θινός} ({ι} long), a heap,
  Skr. {dhanvan}.

<dinnsear>, ginger, Ir. @Ir{gingsear}, M.Ir. @MIr{sinnsar}; from M.Eng.
  {ginger}, Lat. {zingiber}.
<dìobair>, forsake, Ir. @Ir{dìbirim}; for {dì}+{ìobair}, q.v.  {di-ud-ber} (St.).
<dìobhail>, loss, Ir. @Ir{díoghabhail}, O.Ir. @OIr{dígbail}, deminutio; {dì-} and
  {gabhail}, q.v.
<dìobhargadh>, persecution, @Ref<dìobhargach>, fierce, keen, Ir. @Ir{dibheargach},
  vindictive; see @Ref{dibhfhearg}.
<dìobhuir>, vomit: *{de+beir}, Lat. {defero}; from @Ref{de} and @Ref{beir}.
<diocail>, lower, diminish (H.S.D., which quotes MSS. only);
  {dí}+{ad-cal}; from @Ref{càil}?
<dìochain>, forgetfulness; Dialectic for {dichuimhne}, that is @Ref{di-} and

<diod>, @Ref<diodag>, a drop; from the Eng. @Eng{jet}? {jot}?
<diog>, a syllable, Ir. @Ir{digim}, {diugam}, cluck as a hen: G. @Ref<diug>, the
  call to hens.  Onomatopoetic.
<diogail>, tickle, Ir. @Ir{giglim}, O.Ir. @OIr{fogitled} (for {fogicled}?).  The G.
  seems borrowed from the Eng. @Eng{tickle}, {kittle}; and possibly all
  are onomatopoetic, and reshaped in later times.  Cf. Eng.
  {giggle}, Lat. {cachinnus}.
<diogair>, eager, Ir. @Ir{díogar} (O'R.), E.Ir. @EIr{dígar} (?):
<dìogan>, revenge, Ir. @Ir{díogan} (O'B., etc.); the word is Irish (not in
  M`A.; M`E. marks it doubtful.):

<diùlt>, refuse, Ir. @Ir{diúltaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{díultaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{díltuch}, refusing,
  {doríltiset}, negaverunt, *{di-îlt} (Thu.).  Zimmer suggests the
  root of Lat. {lateo}, lurk, Stokes gives *{de-laudi} ("Celt. Dec."),
  and Ascoli hesitates between *{di-la-} ({la}, throw, Gr. @Gr{ἐλαύνω})
  and *{di-shlond}.  Possibly an active form of @Ref{till}, return.
  {díltud}, v.n. of {do-sluindi}.

<do.1>, to, Ir. @Ir{do}, O.Ir. @OIr{do}, {du}, Corn. @Corn{dhe}, O.Br. @OBr{do}, Br. @Br{da}; Eng. @Eng{to},
  Ag.S. {tó}, Ger. {zu}; Lat. {-do} ({endo}, {indu}); Gr. @Gr{-δε}.  Stokes
  derives the prep {do} from the verbal particle @Ref{do.2}, {to}.  See

<do.2>, a verbal particle denoting "to, ad", Ir. @Ir{do}, O.Ir. @OIr{do-}, {du-}, also
  @Ref{to-}, when it carries the accent (e.g. {dobiur}, I give, *{do-bérô},

  prep. and prefix, for *{þu}?
<do.3>, thy, Ir. @Ir{do}, O.Ir. @OIr{do}, {du}, W. @W{dy}, E.W. {teu}, Corn. @Corn{dhe}, Br.{da},
  *{tovo}; Lat. {tuus}; Skr. {táva}, etc.  See @Ref{tu}.
<do-.1>, @Ref<du->, prefix of negative quality, Ir. @Ir{do-}, {dó-}, O.Ir. @OIr{do-}, @Ref{du-},
  *{dus-}; Skr. {dus-}; Gr. @Gr{δυσ-}; Got. {taz-}, Ger. {zer-}.  Its opposite
  is @Ref{so}, q.v.  Following the analogy of @Ref{so}, it aspirates the
  consonants though originally it ended in {s}.
<do-.2>, see @Ref{do.2}, @Ref{to-}.

†<dobhar>, water, Ir. @Ir{dobhar}, E.Ir. @EIr{dobur}, W. @W{dwfr}, Corn. @Corn{dofer}, Br.
  {dour}, Gaul. {dubrum}, *{dubro-n}, *{dub-ro-}, root {dub}, deep, as in

  place in flowing or standing water.  Hence @Ref<dobharchu>

<docair>, grievous, hard, trouble, E.Ir. @EIr{doccair}, uneasiness, trouble.
<docha>, preferable, @Ref<is docha>, prefer; see @Ref{toigh}.
<dòcha>, more likely, Ir. @Ir{dócha}, O.Ir. @OIr{dochu}; comparative of {dóigh},
  O.Ir. @OIr{dóig}, likely, *{dougi-}, *{douki-}; Gr. @Gr{δεύκει}, thinks,
  @Gr{ἀδευκής}, unseemly; Ger. {zeuge}, witness; further allied is Lat.
  {dûco}.  Connection with Gr. @Gr{δοκέω} has been suggested, and
  Zimmer has analysed it into *{do-ech}, *{do-sech}, root {sec}, say
  (as in {casg}, etc.: Cam.), citing the by-form {toich} (G. @Ref<toigh>),
  which is a different word.  Hence @Ref<dòchas>, @Ref<dòigh>.
<dochair>, @Ref<dochar>, hurt, damage, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{dochor}; from @Ref{do-.1} and

<dòid.1>, the hand, grasp, Ir. @Ir{dóid}, E.Ir. @EIr{dóit}, O.Ir. @OIr{inna n-doat},
  lacertorum, *{dousenti-}; Skr @Ref{dos} (*{daus}), {doshan}, fore-arm,
  Zend {daosha}, shoulder.  Strachan, who cites the meanings

  (move violently), comparing Gr. @Gr{καρπός}, wrist, from {qṛp}, turn.

  @Ref<dòideach>, firmly grasping.

<dol>, going, Ir. @Ir{dul}, O.Ir. @OIr{dul}, inf. to {doluid}, {dolluid}, ivit, from

--page 139
<dòlas>, grief, Ir. @Ir{dólas}: formed from @Ref{sòlas}, consolation on the
  analogy of other @Ref{do-.1} and @Ref{so-} words.  See @Ref{sòlas}.
<dòlum>, mean, surly, wretchedness, poverty.  Cf. @Ref{dòlach}.
<dom>, the gall, gall-bladder; see @Ref{domblas}.
<domail>, damage; apparently founded on Lat. {damnum}.
<domblas>, gall, bile, Ir. @Ir{comblas}, M.Ir. @MIr{domblas ae}, i.e., "bitterness
  of the liver"; from M.Ir. @MIr{domblas}, ill-taste; from {do-mlas}.
  See @Ref{blas}.
<domhach>, a savage; see @Ref{doimh.2}.
<dòmhail>, bulky: M.Ir. @MIr{derg-domla}, pl., from *{domail}, root of
  @Ref{meall.1}: *{do-fo-mell}?
<domhain>, deep, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{domain}, W. @W{dwfn}, Br. @Br{don}, *{dubni-s},
  *{dubno-s}; Eng. @Eng{deep}, Got. {diups}; Lit. {dubùs}, deep {dumburýs},
  a hole in the ground filled with water, {dauba}, ravine, Ch.Sl.
  {dŭbrĭ}, ravine: I.E. {dheub}.  See also @Ref{dobhar}.
<domhan>, the Universe, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{domun}, Gaul. {Dubno-}, {Dumno-}
  (in many proper names, as {Dubnotalus}, {Dumnorix}, "World-king",
  Gaelic @Ref{Domhnall}, *{Dumno-valo-s}, W. @W{Dyfnual}, Celtic
  *{dubno-}, the world, the "deep"; another form of @Ref{domhain}
  above.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{deep} for the "sea".  D'Arbois de Jubainville
  explains {Dubno-} of Gaulish names as "deep", {Dumnorix},
  "deep king", "high king"; and he has similarly to explain
  {Biturix} as "king for aye", not "world king": all which
  seems a little forced.
<Dòmhnach>, Sunday, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{domnach}; from Lat. {dominica},
  "the Lord's".  See under @Ref{Di-}.
<don>, evil, defect, Ir. @Ir{don}; see @Ref{dona}.
<dona>, bad, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{donae}, {dona}, wretched, bad; opposite to
  @Ref{sona}, @Ref{son}, happy.  See @Ref{sona}.
<dongaidh>, moist, humid; from the Sc. {donk}, Eng. @Eng{dank}.
<donn>, brown, Ir. O.Ir. @OIr{donn}, W. @W{dwn}, Gaul. {Donnus}, {Donno-};
  *{donno-s}, *{dus-no-}; Lat. {fuscus}; Eng. @Eng{dusk}, {dust}.  Eng. @Eng{dun}
  may be hence.
<donnal>, a howl, complaint; *{don-no-}, I.E. {dhven}, whence Eng. @Eng{din},
  Skr. {dhvana}, sound.  Meyer says: "Better {donal}, fem."  G.
  is masc.
<dorbh>, @Ref<dorgh>, a hand-line, Ir. @Ir{dorubha}; also @Ref<drogha>, q.v.
<dorc>, a piece (Dialectic): *{dorco-}, root {der}, split, Eng. @Eng{tear}; N. {dorg}.
<dorch>, dark, Ir. @Ir{dorcha}, O.Ir. @OIr{dorche}; opposed to @Ref{sorcha}, bright,
  *{do-reg-io-}, root {reg}, see, Lit. {regiù}, I see.  See @Ref{rosg.1}.  The
  root {reg}, colour, Gr. @Gr{ῥέξω}, colour, @Gr{ἒρεβος}, Erebus, Norse {rökr},
  darkness, {Ragna-rökr}, twilight of the gods, is allied.  Ascoli
  and Zimmer refer it to the Gadelic root {rich}, shine, O.Ir.
  @OIr{richis}, coal, Br. @Br{regez}, glowing embers, Skr. {ric}, {ṛc}, shine.
---JTM: normalized to Br.
--page 140
<dòrlach>, a handful, quantity: *{dorn-lach}, from @Ref{dòrn}, a fist.
<dòrn>, a fist, Ir. @Ir{dorn}, O.Ir. @OIr{dorn}, W. @W{dwrn}, Corn. @Corn{dorn}, O.Br. @OBr{dorn},
  Br. @Br{dourn}, hand, Gaul. {Durnacos}, *{durno-}; Gr. @Gr{δῶρον}, palm,
  @Gr{δάρειρ}, @Gr{δάριν}, a span; Lettic {dúrc}, fist; I.E. root {der} split.
  *{dver}, *{dur}, strong.
<dorra>, more difficult, Ir. @Ir{dorrach}, harsh, M.Ir. @MIr{dorr}, rough,
  *{dorso-}; Czech {drsen}, rough (Stokes, Strachan).
<dorran>, vexation, anger, Ir. @Ir{dorrán}, M.Ir. @MIr{dorr}, *{dorso-}; see
  @Ref{dorra}.
<dòruinn>, pain, anguish, Ir. @Ir{dóghruing}.  Cf. E.Ir. @EIr{dogra}, {dógra},
  lamenting, anguish, {dogar}, sad, from @Ref{do-.1} and @Ref{gar.1}, q.v.
<dorus>, a door, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{dorus}, W. @W{drws}, Corn. @Corn{daras}, O.Corn. {dor},
  Br. @Br{dor}, *{dvorestu-}; Lat. {fores}; Gr. @Gr{θύρα}; Eng. @Eng{door}; Lit.
  {dùrys}; Skr {dvā́r}.
<dos>, a bush, tuft, Ir. @Ir{dos}, O.Ir. @OIr{doss}, *{dosto-}, root {dus}; Lat. {dumus}
  (= {dus-mus}), thicket; Eng. @Eng{tease}, {teasel}.
<dosdan>, a kind of food given to horses; from Eng. @Eng{dust}.
<dosgadh>, @Ref<dosgainn>, misfortune; cf. Ir. @Ir{dósgathach}, improvident.
  From @Ref{do-.1} and @Ref{sgath.1}, q.v.  Ir. @Ir{dosguidhtheach}, morose,
  extravagant.
<dotarra>, sulky; see @Ref{dod}.
<doth>, a doating on one; cf. Sc. {daut}, dote, M.Eng. {doten}.
<dràbach>, dirty slovenly, Ir. @Ir{drabaire}, {drabóg}, slut, {drab}, a stain;
  from Eng. @Eng{drab}.  See @Ref{drabh}.  Hence @Ref<drabasda>, obscene.
<drabh>, dissolve, @Ref<drabhag>, dregs, @Ref<drabhas>, filth, E.Ir. @EIr{drabar-slog},
  rabble; from Eng. @Eng{draff}, allied to Ger. {treber}, Norse {draf}.
  Stokes thinks that the G. is allied to, not derived from, the
  Eng.  The Eng. word {drab} is allied to {draff}, and so is {dregs}.
<dràbh>, scatter, dissolve (M`A., Arg.), not @Ref<drabh> (H.S.D., which,
  however, has @Ref<drabhach>, rifted).  @Ref<dràbhach>, wide-sutured,
  rifted (Arg.):
<dràc>, a drake; from the Eng.  See @Ref{ràc.2}.
<dragh.1>, trouble, O.Ir. g. {mor-draige}, roughness: *{drago-}, I.E.
  {dregho-}, Ag.S. {trega}, vexation, Norse {tregr}, dragging,
  slovenly, {trega}, grieve; Skr. {drâgh}, pain; Gr. *@Gr{ταραχή},
  @Gr{τρᾱχύς} (St.).
<dragh.2>, pull, draw, Ir. @Ir{dragáil}; from the Eng. @Eng{drag}, {draw}, Norse
  {drega}.
<dràgon>, a dragon, Ir. @Ir{dragún}, E.Ir. @EIr{drac}, g. {dracon}; from Lat.
  {draco(n)}, Eng. @Eng{dragon}.
<dràichd>, a slattern (Arm.):
<draighlichd>, a trollop, draggle-tail (Arg.); from Eng. @Eng{draggle-tail}?
  Cf. @Ref{draghlainn} under @Ref{draoluinn}.
<draillsein>, a sparkling light (Sh., H.S.D.); see @Ref{drillsean}.
--page 141
<draimheas>, a foul mouth; cf. Ir. @Ir{drabhas}, a wry mouth, {dramhaim},
  I grin.  The G. seems from @Ref{drabh} above.
<draing>, a snarl, grin; see @Ref{dranndan}.
<dràm>, @Ref<dram>, a dram, Ir. @Ir{dram}; from the Eng.
<dramaig>, a foul mixture, crowdie (Sh., H.S.D.); from the Sc.
  {dramock}.
<drannd>, @Ref<dranndan>, a hum, snarl, Ir. @Ir{draint}, {dranntán}, M.Ir.
  {drantaigim}, I snarl; from a Celtic *{dran}, I.E. {dhreno-},
  sound, drone; Eng. @Eng{drone}; Gr. @Gr{θρῆνος}, dirge; Skr. {dhraṇ},
  sound, murmur.
<drann>, @Ref<dranna>, a word (M`A., Arg.); same as @Ref{drannd}.
<draoch>, a fretful or ghastly look, hair standing on end, Ir. @Ir{driuch},
  fretfulness, angry look: root {dhrigh}; Gr. @Gr{θρíξ}, @Gr{τριχός}, hair.
  For meaning, cf. @Ref{snuadh}, hue, hair.
<draoi>, @Ref<draoidh>, @Ref<druidh>, a magician, druid, Ir. @Ir{draoi}, gen. pl.
  {druadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{drai}, {drui}, g. {druad}, Gaul. {druides} (Eng.
  {druid}).  Its etymology is obscure.  Stokes suggests relationship
  with Eng. @Eng{true}, G. @Ref{dearbh}, q.v., or with Gr. @Gr{θρέομαι}, cry,
  (as in @Ref{drannd}, @Ref{dùrd}), or Gr. @Gr{ἄθρέω}, look sharp, Pruss. {dereis},
  see.  Thurneysen analyses the word as {dru}, high, strong,
  see @Ref{truaill.2}.  Brugmann and Windisch have also suggested
  the root {dru}, oak, as Pliny did too, because of the Druids'
  reverence for the oak tree.  Ag.S. {drý}, magus, is borrowed
  from the Celtic.  {draoineach}, {druineach}, artisan, "eident"
  person (Carm.); {draoneach}, "any person that practices an
  art" (Grant), agriculturist; {druinneach}, artist (Lh.).  Ir.
  {druine}, art needlework; @Gr{θρόνα}, flowers in embroidery
  drugs.
<draoluinn>, delay, tediousness, drawling; from the Eng. @Eng{drawling},
  Sc. {drawl}, to be slow in action, {drawlie}, slow and slovenly.
  Dialectic @Ref<draghlainn>, a slovenly person, a mess.
<drapuinn>, tape; from the Eng. @Eng{drape}.
<draos>, trash, filth, Ir. @Ir{draos}.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{dross}.
<dràsda>, @Ref<an dràsda>, now, Ir. @Ir{drásda}, M.Ir. @MIr{trasta}, for {an tràth sa},
  this time.
<drathais>, drawers; from the Eng.
<dreach>, aspect, Ir. @Ir{dreach}, E.Ir. @EIr{drech}, W. @W{drych}, M.Br. @MBr{derch},
  *{dṛkâ}, *{dṛkko-}, root {derk} as in @Ref{dearc.1}, q.v.
<drèachd>, @Ref<dreuchd>, duty, office, Ir. @Ir{dréacht}, song, O.Ir. @OIr{drécht},
  portio, *{drempto-}, root {drep}, Gr. @Gr{δρέπω}, pluck, cull (Strachan).
<dreag>, @Ref<drèag>, a meteor or portent; from the Ag.S. {dréag},
  apparition, Norse {draugr}, ghost.  Also @Ref<driug>.
<dreall>, @Ref<dreoll>, door-bar, @Ref<dreallag>, a swingle-tree: {dṛs-lo-}, root {der},
  split, Eng. @Eng{tree}?  Cf. W. @W{dryll}, *{dhruslo}, @Gr{θραυω}.
--page 142
<dreallaire>, an idler; see @Ref{drollaire}.
<dreallsach>, a blazing fire; see @Ref{drillsean}.
<dream>, a tribe, people, Ir. @Ir{dream}, E.Ir. @EIr{dremm}; from <dream>,
  bundle, handful, manipulus, Br. @Br{dramm}, a sheaf, *{dregsmo-};
  Gr. @Gr{δράγμα}, a handful, @Gr{δράσσομαι}; Ch.Sl. {drazhaiti},
  grasps; Skr. {darh}, make fast, I.E. {dergho-}, fasten.  Hence
  @Ref<dreamsgal>, a heterogeneous mass.  {dreg}: {dreng}, tramp?
  Cf. @Ref{drong}.
<dreamach>, peevish, @Ref<dream>, snarl; cf. Ir. @Ir{dreamhnach}, perverse,
  E.Ir. @EIr{dremne}, fierceness, from {dreamh}, surly, *{dremo-}, from
  {drem}, {drom}, rush, Gr. @Gr{δρόμος}, a race.  G. {dreamach} may be
  for *{dregsmo-}, root {dreg} as in @Ref{dreangan}.
<dreangan>, a snarler, Ir. @Ir{drainceanta}, snarling, {drainc}, a snarl, also
  {draint}, W. @W{drengyn}, a surly chap, {dreng}, morose, *{drengo-},
  root {dreg}, from {dhre} of @Ref{dranndan}.
<dreas>, bramble, bramble-bush, Ir. @Ir{dreas}; see @Ref{dris}.
<dreasair>, a dresser (house-furniture).
<dreathan>, see @Ref{dreathan-donn}.

<dreathan-donn>, wren, Ir. @Ir{dreaán}, {drean}, W. @W{dryw}, *{drivo-}, *{dṛ-vo-},
  root {der}, {dher}, jump?  See @Ref{dàir}.  Cf. for sense Gr. @Gr{τρόχιλος}.
  or from {dhrevo}, cry, Gr. @Gr{θρέομαι}, G. @Ref{drannd}, q.v.
<dreigeas>, a grin, peevish face, E.Ir. @EIr{dric}, wrathful; *{dreggo-}, root
  {dreg} as in @Ref{dreangan}.
<dreimire>, a ladder, Ir. @Ir{dréimire}, E.Ir. @EIr{dréimm}, ascent, vb. {dringim},
  W. @W{dringo}, scandere, *{drengô}.  Bezzenberger compares the
  Norse {drangr}, an up-standing rock (cf. {cliff} and {climb}.  The
  root {dreg} of {dreimire} has also been compared to Ger. {treppe},
  staircase, Eng. @Eng{tramp}.  See @Ref{dream}, people, "goers".  Ir. @Ir{ag dreim},
  advancing.
<dréin>, a grin: *{dreg-ni-}, root {dreg} of @Ref{dreangan}.
<dreòchdam>, the crying of the deer; from {dhrevo}, {dhre}, cry.
<dreòlan.1>, a wren, Ir. @Ir{dreólán}: *{drivolo-}; see @Ref{dreathan}.
<dreòlan.2>, a silly person, Ir. @Ir{dreólán}, W. @W{drel}, a clown; from Eng.
  {droll}?  Thurneysen prefers to consider these words borrowed
  from Eng. @Eng{thrall}, Norse {þrœl}.  The word appears as @Ref<dreòlan.2>,
  @Ref<dreallaire>, @Ref<drollaire>.  In the sense of "loiterer", these words
  are from the Norse {drolla}, loiter, Eng. @Eng{droil}.
<dreòs>, a blaze:
<dreugan>, a dragon (Dialectic); see @Ref{dràgon}.
<driachan>, plodding, obstinacy, Ir. @Ir{driachaireachd}: *{dreiqo-}; cf.
  Eng. @Eng{drive}, from {dhreip}.
<driamlach>, a fishing line, Manx {rimlagh}, E.Ir. @EIr{ríamnach}:
  *{reimmen-}; see @Ref{réim.2}.
<driceachan>, tricks (M`D.).
<drifeag>, hurry (Heb.); see @Ref{drip}.

<dril>, a spark, sparkle, Ir. @Ir{dril}, {drithle}, pl. {drithleanna}, M.Ir.
  {drithle}, dat. {drithlinn}, also {drithre}, *{drith-renn-} (for {-renn-},
  see @Ref{reannag}), *{drith}.  Hence @Ref<drillsean>, sparkles, from
  {drithlis}, a spark.  {drìllsean}, rushlight, rush used as wick.
<driodar>, dregs, lees, Ir. @Ir{dríodar}, gore, dregs: *{driddo-}, *{dṛd-do-},
  root {der}, Eng. @Eng{tear}.  Cf. Sc. {driddle}.
<driog>, a drop, Ir. @Ir{driog} ({dríog}, Con.), {driogaire}, a distiller; seemingly
  borrowed from Norse {dregg}, M.Eng. {dreg}, dregs.
<driongan>, slowness, Ir. @Ir{driongán}, a plaything, worthless pastime:
<drip>, hurry, confusion, Ir. @Ir{drip}, bustle, snare: *{drippi-}, *{dhribh},
  Eng. @Eng{drive}?  N. {drepa}, hit.
<dris>, a bramble, brier, Ir. @Ir{dris}, O.Ir. @OIr{driss}, O.W. @OW{drissi}, W.
  {dryssien}, Corn. @Corn{dreis}, Br. @Br{drezen}, *{dressi-}.  Bezzenberger
  suggests a stem *{drepso}, M.H.G. {trefs}, Ger. {trespe}, darnel,
  M.Eng. {drauk} (= {dravick} of Du.), zizanium.  It must be
  kept separate from {droighionn}, O.Ir. @OIr{draigen}, Celtic root
  {dṛg}, thought G. {dris} might be for *{dṛg-si-}, for the W. would
  be in {ch}, not {s}.  See @Ref{droighionn}.
<drithlean>, a rivet:
<drithleann>, a sparkle, Ir. @Ir{drithlinn}; oblique form of @Ref{dril}.
<driubhlach>, a cowl, so Ir. (O'R.); Sh. has {dribhlach}.
<driùcan>, a beak, Ir. @Ir{driuch}.  M`A. gives also the meaning, "an
  incision under one of the toes".  See @Ref{draoch}.
<driuch>activity (M`A.):
<driuchan>, a stripe, as in cloth (M`A.):
<driug>, a meteor, portent; see @Ref{dreag}.
<dròbh>, a drove; from the Eng.
<drobhlas>, profusion, so Ir.:
<droch>, evil, bad, Ir. @Ir{droch}, O.Ir. @OIr{droch}, {drog}, W. @W{drwg}, Corn. @Corn{drog},
  malum, M.Br. @MBr{drouc}, *{druko-}.  Usually compared to Skr.
  {druh}, injure, Ger. {trug}, deception.  Stokes has suggested
  {dhruk}, whence Eng. @Eng{dry}, and Bezzenberger compares Norse
  {trega}, grieve, {tregr}, unwilling (see @Ref{dragh.1}).
<drochaid>, a bridge, Ir. @Ir{droichiod}, O.Ir. @OIr{drochet}:
<drog>, a sea-swell at its impact on a rock (Arg.):
<drogaid>, drugget, Ir. @Ir{drogáid} (O'R.); from the Eng.
<drogha>, a nad fishing line; also @Ref<dorgh>, @Ref<dorbh>, Ir. @Ir{dorubha},
  {drubha}; Norse {dorg}, an angler's tackle.
<droich>, a dwarf, Ir. @Ir{droich}, *{drogi-}, allied to Teut. {dwergo-}, Ger.
  {zwerg}, Norse {dvergr}, Eng. @Eng{dwarf}.
<droigheann>, bramble, thorn, Ir. @Ir{droigheann}, O.Ir. @OIr{draigen}, W.
  {draen}, Corn. @Corn{drain}, {drein}, Br. @Br{drean}, *{dragino-}: cf. Gr. @Gr{τραχύς},
  rough, @Gr{θράσσω}, confuse, Eng. @Eng{dregs}.  Bezzenberger compares
  Lit. {drìgnės}, black henbane, Gr. @Gr{δράβη}.  Ebel referred

  it to the same origin as Gr. @Gr{τέρχνος}, twig.  Also @Ref<droighneach>,
  (1) thorn, (2) lumber, "entanglement".

<droinip>, tackle:

<droman>, the alder tree; see @Ref{troman}.
<drong>, @Ref<droing>, people, tribe, Ir. @Ir{drong}, E.Ir. @EIr{drong}, O.Br. @OBr{drogn},
  @Ref{drog}, factio, Gaul. {drungus}, whence Lat. {drungus}, a troop
  (4th century), *{drungo-}; Got. {driugan}, serve as a soldier,
  Ag.S. {dryht}, people, Norse {drótt}, household, people.
<drongair>, a drunkard; from the Eng.
<dronn>, the back, Ir. @Ir{dronnóg}: *{dros-no-}, root {dros} of @Ref{druim}, q.v.
<dronng>, a trunk; from the Eng.
<drothan>, a breeze (M`D.):
<druabag>, a small drop, @Ref<druablas>, muddy water, @Ref<druaip>, dregs,
  lees.  The first is from Eng. @Eng{drop}; @Ref{druablas} is from M.Eng.
  {drubli}, turbid, Sc. {droubly}; and @Ref{druaip} is from Norse
  {drjúpa}, drip.  {drubhag} and {drùigean} (Wh.).
<drùb>, a wink of sleep, a mouthful of liquid; from Norse {drjúpa},
  drip.  See the above words.
<drùchd>, dew, Ir. @Ir{drúchd}, E.Ir. @EIr{drúcht}, *{drūb-bu}, root {dhreub};
  Ag.S. {dréapian}, trickle, Eng. @Eng{drip}, {drop}, Norse {drjúpa}, drip,
  Ger. {triefen}.
<drùdh>, penetrate, pierce, @Ref<drùidh>; see @Ref{drùdhadh}.
<drùdhadh>, oozing, soaking; cf. Skr. {dru}, {dráva}, melt, run, Got.
  {ufar-trusian}, besprinkle.  Cf. Gaul. {Druentia} (Gaelic {Druie},
  a river in Strathspey).
<drugair>, a drudge, Ir. @Ir{drugaire}; from M.Eng. {druggar}, a dragger,
  Eng. @Eng{drudge}.
<druid.1>, close, Ir. @Ir{druidim}, E.Ir. @EIr{druit}, close, firm, trustworthy:
  *{druzdo-}, *{drus}, W. @W{drws}.  See @Ref{dorus}.  Stokes now
  refers *{druzdi-} to the same source as Eng. @Eng{trust}.
<druid.2>, a starling, Ir. @Ir{druid}, E.Ir. @EIr{truid}, Manx {truitling}, W. @W{drudwy},
  Br. @Br{dred}, {dret}: *{struzdi}; Lat. {turdus}, thrush; Lit. {stázdas}
  (Bohemian {drazd}), thrush, Eng. @Eng{throstle}.
<druidh>, a magician; see @Ref{draoi}.
<drùidh>, penetrate; see @Ref{drùdh}.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{treidhim}; {treaghaim} (Sh.).
<druim>, back, ridge, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{druimm}, pl. {dromand}, W. @W{trum},
  *{drosmen-}; Lat. {dorsum}.
<drùis>, lust, @Ref<drùiseach>, @Ref<drùth>, lecherous, Ir. @Ir{drúis}, adultery, E.Ir.
  {drúth}, lewd, a harlot, *{drūto-}.  Cf. M.Eng. {drüð}, darling,
--page 145
  O.Fr. {drud} (do.), {druerie}, love, whence M.Eng. {druerie}, Sc.
  {drouery}, illicit love.  Mayhew refers the Fr. and Eng. to
  O.H.G. {drút} dear (also {trút}, {drúd}): a Teut. {dreuð}?  Cf.
  Ger. {traut}, beloved (Kludge).
<druma>, a drum, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{druma}; from the Eng.
<druman>, elder; see @Ref{troman}.
<drumlagan>, a cramp in back, wrists, etc. (M`D.):
<dù>, meet, proper, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{dú}.  This Stokes regards as borrowed
  from O.Fr. {dû} (= {debntus}), whence Eng. @Eng{due}.  But see
  @Ref{dùthaich}, @Ref{dual.2}.
<du->, @Ref<do-.1>, prefix denoting badness of quality, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{du-}, {do-},
  *{dus}; Gr. @Gr{δυσ-}; Got. {tuz-}, Norse {tor-}; Skr. {dus-}.  See @Ref{do-.1}.
---gjk (1.15) originally δυς-, changed to be consistent with other Greek prefixes
<duaichnidh>, gloomy, ugly, Ir. @Ir{duaichniúghadh}, to disfigure.  See
  @Ref{suaicheantas}.
<duaidh>, a horrid scene, a fight, Ir. @Ir{dúaidh}, evil (O'B.): *{du-vid}?
<duairc>, uncivil, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{duairc}: opposite of @Ref{suairc}, q.v.

<duairidh>, @Ref<dubharaidh>, a dowry; from the Eng.

  give (= {douénai}): Lit. {důti} (do.), {dovanà}, a gift; Lat. {duint}
  (= {dent}).  Root {dô}, give.
<dual.1>, a lock of hair, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{dual}, *{doklo-}; Got. {tagl}, hair,
  Ag.S. {taegl}, Eng. @Eng{tail}, Norse {tagl}, horse's tail.
<dual.2>, hereditary right, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{dúal}, *{dutlo-}; see @Ref{dùthaich}.
  Stokes refers it to Fr. {dû}, as he does @Ref{dù}, q.v.  Ir. @Ir{dúal}, just,
  proper, might come from *{duglo-}, root {dhugh}, fashion, Gr.
  @Gr{τεύχειν}, Got. {dugan}, Eng. @Eng{do}.

<dùdlachd>, depth of winter:
<duìdseag>, a plump woman of low stature (Perth); "My old
  Dutch"; {dùitseach} (Arm.).  {Dutch}man, docked cock.
<dùil.1>, expectation, hope, Ir. @Ir{dúil}, *{dûli-}, root {du}, strive, Gr. @Gr{θυμός},
  soul; Lit {dumas}, thought (Stokes for Gr.).
<dùil.2>, an element, Ir. @Ir{dúil}, O.Ir. @OIr{dúil}, {dúl}, *{dûli-}; Skr. {dhûli-},
  dust; Lit. {dulkės} (do.); Lat. {fuligo}, soot.  Stokes (Dict.)
  refers it to *{dukli-}, root {duk}, fashion; Ger. {zeugen}, engender;
  further Lat. {duco}.  Hence dialectic @Ref<Na dùil>, poor creatures!
  Ir. @Ir{dúil} means "creature" also.  Hence also @Ref<dùileag>, a term
  of affection for a girl.
<duileasg>, dulse, Ir. @Ir{duileasg}, M.Ir. @MIr{duilesc}, W. @W{dylusg}, what is
  drifted on shore by floods.  Hence Sc. {dulse}.  Jamieson
  suggests that the G. stands for {duill' uisge}, "water-leaf".
<duilich>, difficult, sorry, Ir. @Ir{doiligh}, E.Ir. @EIr{dolig}; cf. Lat. {dolor},
  grief.
<duille>, a leaf, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{duille}, W. @W{dalen}, M.Br. @MBr{del}; Gr. @Gr{θύλλα},

  bloom, sprout.  Gaul. @Gaul{πεμπε-δουλα}, "five leaved", is allied.
<duillinnean>, customs, taxes (M`D.):
<dùin>, shut, Ir. @Ir{dúnaim} "barricading"; from @Ref{dùn}, q.v.

<èaladh>, @Ref<euladh>, a creeping along (as to catch game), Ir. @Ir{euloighim}

<eanghlas>, gruel, milk and water, Ir. @Ir{eanghlais}, E.Ir. @EIr{englas} (fem.
  {a} stem), milk and water, green water (Corm.), from {in} and
  M.Ir. @MIr{glas}, milk, *{glagsa}; Gr. @Gr{γλάγος}, @Gr{γάλα(κτος)}, milk,
  Lat. {lac} (= *{glak-t}).  Cormac says it is from {en}, water, and
  @Ref{glas.2}, grey.  {en} = water, *{pino} (St.).
<eanntag>, nettles; see @Ref{deanntag}.
<eanraich>, @Ref<eanbhruith>, soup, juice of boiled flesh, Ir. @Ir{eanbhruithe},
  E.Ir. @EIr{enbruthe}, from {in} and @Ref{bruith}, boil.  Corm. and O'Cl.
  have an obsolete {broth}, {bruithe}, flesh, and explain it as "water
  of flesh".  For {en}, water, see @Ref{eanghlas}.  Most dialects make
  it "chicken-soup", as from @Ref{eun}+@Ref{bruith}.
<ear>, @Ref<an ear>, the east, from the east, Ir. @Ir{soir}, eastern, {anoir}, from
  the east, O.Ir. @OIr{an-air}, ab oriente; really "from before", the
  prep. @Ref{an.2} (*{apona}) of {a nall} (see @Ref{a.5}, from), and @Ref{air} (= *{ari}),
  before.  The observer is supposed to face the sun.  The
  opposite is @Ref<iar.2>, @Ref<an iar>, from @Ref{iar.1}, behind, q.v.
<earail>, an exhortation, O.Ir. @OIr{eráil}, {iráil}, *{air-áil}; from @Ref{àill},
  desire.  Hence @Ref<earal>, provision, caution.
<earar>, @Ref<an earar>, the day after to-morrow, Ir. @Ir{oirthior}, eastern,
  day following, day after to-morrow, O.Ir. @OIr{airther}, eastern,
  *{ariteros} *{pareiteros} (Gr. @Gr{παροíτερος}), comparative of @Ref{air},
  before.
<eararadh>, a parching of corn in a pot before grinding: *{air-aradh},
  root {ar}, as in Lat. {aridus}, arid?
<earasaid>, a square of tartan worn over the shoulders by females
  and fastened by a brooch, a tartan shawl: *{air-asaid}?  Cf.
  @Ref{asair.2} for root.
<earb.1>, a roe, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{erb}, O.Ir. @OIr{heirp}, *{erbi-s}, Gr. @Gr{ἒριφος}.
<earb.2>, trust (vb.), @Ref<earbsa> (n.), Ir. @Ir{earbaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{erbaim}, {nomerpimm},

<earball>, a tail, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{erball}, *{áir-ball}; from @Ref{air} (= *{ari})
  and @Ref{ball.1}, q.v.  {urball} in Arran and the West.
<earc>, heifer (Carm.), cow, Ir. @Ir{earc}, E.Ir. @EIr{erc}, cow (Corm.):
<earchall>, @Ref<earachall>, misfortune: *{air-cáll}; from @Ref{air} and @Ref{call}, q.v.
<earghalt>, arable land; @Ref{air}+@Ref{geadhail}, which see.
<eargnaich>, inflame, enrage: *{áir-gon-}; from @Ref{air} and @Ref{gon}?  Also
  {feargnaich}, which suggests @Ref{fearg} as root.
<earlachadh>, preparing food (Suth.); from old adj. {erlam}, ready.
  See @Ref{ullamh}.
<eàrlaid>, expectation, trust: *{ari-lanti-}, root {lam} of @Ref{lamh}.

--page 152
<eàrr>, end, tail, Ir. @Ir{earr}, E.Ir. @EIr{err}, *{ersâ}; Gr. @Gr{ὄρρος}, rump; Ag.S.
  {ears}, Eng.
<earr>, scar (Lewis); Norse {örr}, {arr} (do.).
<earrach>, spring, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{errech} *{persâko-}, from {pers}, which is
  from {per}, as {eks}, (= {ex}) is from {ek}; {per}, before, Lat. {per}, {prœ},
  Eng. @Eng{for}, {fore}; as in @Ref{air}, (= {ari}).  The idea is the "first of
  the year".  Cf. Ger. {fru"hling}, spring, of like descent.  Such
  is Stokes' derivation.  Another view is that {earrach} is from
  @Ref{eàrr}, end (cf. for form @Ref{tòs} and @Ref{toiseach}, and {earrach}, lower
  extremity) meaning the "end of the year', the {céitein},
  May, "first of summer", being the beginning of the year.
  Not allied to Lat. {ver}.
<earradh>, clothes, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{earrad}, {eirred}, *{áir-rêd}, *{ari-reido-n};
  from {reid} of @Ref{réidh}.  Eng. @Eng{array} comes from the Gaul.
  equivalent (*{ad-rêdare}), and Eng. @Eng{ready} is allied.  Hence
  <earradh>, wares.
<earradhubh>, the wane, the wane of the moon: *{earr}+@Ref{dubh}?
<earrag.1>, a taunt (a blow, Arms.):
<earrag.2>, a shift, refuge, attempt (H.S.D., from MSS.):
<earraghlòir>, vain glory: *{er-glòir}; the {er} is the intensie particle;
  Lat. {per}.
<earraid>, a tip-staff, @Ref<tearraid>, @Ref<tarraid> (Dial.): form Eng. @Eng{herald}?
<earraigh>, a captain (H.S.D.); see @Ref{urra}.
<earrann>, a portion, Ir. @Ir{earrunn}, M.Ir. @MIr{errand}, *{áir-rann}; from
  @Ref{rann.1}, portion.
<earras>, wealth; see @Ref{earradh}.
<earrlait>, ground manured one year and productive next (Carm.):
<earr-thalmhainn>, see {eàrr-thalmhuinn}.

<fabhra>, @Ref<fabhrad>, @Ref<abhra>, eyelid, eyebrow, Ir. @Ir{abhra}, {fabhra}, eyelid,
  E.Ir. @EIr{abra}, n.pl. {abrait}, Corn. @Corn{abrans}, Br. @Br{abrant}, eyebrow,
  Mac. Gr. @Maced{ἀβροῦτες}; further @Gr{ὀφρύς}, brow, Eng. @Eng{brow}.  There is
  an E.Ir. @EIr{bra}, pl. {brói}, dual {brúad}, *{bruvat-}.  The phonetics
  are not clear.  Stokes has suggested Lat. {frons}, {frontis}, as
  allied, *{bhront-} with the prep. {a(p)o} (= E.Ir. @EIr{-a-}), ab.
--page 158
<fabhradh>, swirl, eddy (Carm.).  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{fobar} (St.).
<facal>, @Ref<focal>, word, Ir. @Ir{focal}, O.Ir. @OIr{focul}, from Lat. {vocabulum}
  (through *{focvul}, Güterbock).  Stokes and Wind. take it
  from Lat. {vocula}.
<fachach>, the puffin - a water fowl (Sh.); root {va}, blow?  Onomatopoetic:
  {f-ah-ah}, call of bird?
<fachail>, strife (Sh.; H.S.D. marks it Dialectic); cf. Ir. @Ir{fachain},
  striving.
<fachant>, puny (H.S.D. for N.High.):
<fachaint>, ridicule, scoffing; from {fo-cainnt}, "sub-speaking".  Cf.
  W. @W{gogan}, satire, Br. @Br{goge}, *{vo-can}, root {can}, sing, say.
<fad>, <fad>, long, Ir. @Ir{fad}, O.Ir. @OIr{fota}, longus, {fot}, length, *{vad-dho-}
  or {vaz-dho-}, Lat. {vastus}, vast?  Hence @Ref<fadal>, delay, desiderium,
  {faddáil} (Keat.), "long delay", from {fad} and {dáil}.
---JTM: normalized reference
<fàdadh>, @Ref<fadadh>, kindling, Ir. @Ir{fadadh}, {fadaghadh}, {fadógh} (Keat.),
  M.Ir. @MIr{fatód}, E.Ir. @EIr{átúd}, which Zimmer analyses as
  *{ad-soud} ({soud} of @Ref{iompaidh}), but unsatisfactorily; E.Ir.
  {adsúi} tenid, kindles, {adsúithe}, kindled (Meyer).  Cf. @Ref{fód}.
<fadharsach>, trifling, paltry, @Ref<fagharsach>:
<fadhbhag>, cuttle-fish:
<fafan>, a breeze:
<fàg>, leave, Ir. @Ir{fágaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{foacbaim}, {fácbaim}, *{fo-ad-gab-}; root
  @Ref{gab} of @Ref{gabh}, q.v.
<fagus>, @Ref<faisg.2>, near, Ir. @Ir{fogus}, E.Ir. @EIr{focus}, {ocus}, O.Ir. @OIr{accus}, W.
  {agos}, Br. @Br{hôgoz}, *{aggostu-}.  See @Ref{agus}.
<faic>, see, Ir. @Ir{faic}, O.Ir. @OIr{im-aci}, vides-ne, *{ád-cî}, see @Ref{chì}.  The {f} is
  prothetic.
<faich>, @Ref<faiche.1>, a green (by the house), Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{faithche}, the field
  nearest the house, E.Ir. @EIr{faidche}, *{ad-cáio-}, "by the house",
  Celtic {kaio-n}, house; see @Ref{ceàrdach}.  Ascoli refers it to O.Ir.
  @Ref{aith}, area (an imaginary word), and Jubainville allies it with
  W. @W{gwaen}, plain, Ger. {weide} (see @Ref{bhàn} for W.).

<faichd>, hiding place, den, mole's burrow; see @Ref{aice.2}.

<faicill>, caution, guard, E.Ir. @EIr{accill}, preparation, watch: *{ád-ciall};
  from @Ref{ciall}, sense?  CF. @Ref{dìchioll}.
<fàidh>, a prophet, Ir. @Ir{fáidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{fáith}, *{vâti-s}; Lat. {vates}; Norse
  {óðr}, sense, song, M.Eng. {wood}, Sc. {wud} (= mad), Ger. {with},
  rage.  W. has {gwawd}, carmen: *{vâto-}.
<faidhbhile>, a beech, Ir. @Ir{feagha}, {fagh-vile} (Lh., {Comp.Voc.}), W.
  {ffawydden}, Br. @Br{fao}; from Lat. @Ref{fagus}.  G. adds the old word
  @Ref{bile}, a tree, which is the same in origin as @Ref{bile}, leaf.

<faidhir>, a fair, Ir. @Ir{faidhrín}; founded on Eng. @Eng{fair}, @Ref{faire} (from
  Lat. {feria}).  For phonetics, cf. @Ref{paidhir} from {pair}, and
  @Ref{staidhir} from @Ref{stair}.
<faidseach>, lumpish (Sh.); @Ref<faidse>, lump of bread (M`A.):
<faigh>, get, Ir. @Ir{faghaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{fagbaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{ní fogbai}, non
  invenis, from {fo-gabim}, root {gab} of @Ref{gabh}, q.v.
<faighe>, begging, etc.; see @Ref{faoighe}.
<faighnich>, @Ref<foighnich>, ask: *{vo-gen-}, root {gen}, know, as in @Ref{aithne}.
  Cf. E.Ir. @EIr{imma foacht}, asked.  Windisch refers to {iar-faigim},
  {iarfacht}, I asked, = {iarmifoacht}, root {ag}, say.  {iarmi-fo-siag}
  (St. @ExtRef{R.C.;19;177}).
<fail.1>, @Ref<foil.1>, corrupt, putrefy, parboil; root {vel}, bubble, boil; Norse
  {vella}, boil, Eng. @Eng{well}, Ger. {wallen}, bubble.
<fail.2>, @Ref<foil.2>, a stye, Ir. @Ir{fail}, O.Ir. @OIr{foil}, {mucc-foil}, hara, {trét-foil}, W.
  {gwâl}, couch, *{vali-}, root {vel}, cover, encircle; Gr. @Gr{εἰλύω},
  envelop (*{velu-}), @Gr{εἶλαρ}, shelter; Skr. {valá}, cave, {vali}, projecting
  thatched roof.  In the sense of "encircling, rolling",
  add Lat. {volvo}, {volumen}, Eng. @Eng{volume}, {wallow}, etc.  Further
  allied is G. @Ref{olann}, wool, Eng. @Eng{wool}, Lat. {lâna}, etc.
<fail.3>, @Ref<fàil>, a ring, Ir. @Ir{fáil}, O.Ir. @OIr{foil}, g. @Ref{falach}, *{valex}; Gr. @Gr{ἑλιξ},
  a twist, spire, vine-tendril; root {vel}, "circle", as above in @Ref{fail.2}.
  Cf. for vowel @Ref{fàl.1}, dike; Br. @Br{gwalen}, "bague sans chaton".
  Also @Ref<failbhe>, Ir. @Ir{failge}, for @Ref<failghe>; from the stem @Ref{falach} or
  {falagh} condensed to {falgh}.
<failc>, bathe, lave, Ir. @Ir{folcadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{folcaim}, W. @W{golchi}, Br. @Br{goalc'hi},
  wash, *{volkô}; Lettic {wa'lks}, damp, {wa'lka}, flowing water,
  swampish place.  Further allied is G. @Ref{fliuch}, q.v.  Possibly
  here place {Volcae}, the Rhine Gauls, after whom the Teutons
  named the Celts; whence {Wales}, {Welsh}, etc.
<failcin>, pot-lid (Arran), @Ref<failceann> (Rob.); from @Ref{fail.3}, ring (Rob.).
<fàile>, smell, savour; see @Ref{àile}.
<fàileag>, dog-brier berry (= @Ref{mucag}):
<faileagan>, little lawns (Carm.): cf. @Ref{àilean}.
<faileas>, shadow, @Ref<aileas> (Dial.); from {fo-leus}? or allied to @Ref{ail.1},
  mark?
<failleagan>, @Ref<ailleagan>, @Ref<faillean>, root or hole of the ear, @Ref<faillean>,
  sucker of a tree: *{al-nio-}, root {al}, nourish?
<fàillig>, @Ref<fàilnich>, fail, @Ref<fàillinn>, failing, Ir. @Ir{faillighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{faill},
  failure, W. @W{gwall}, Br. @Br{goall}, *{valni-}; root {val} of @Ref{feall}, q.v.
  Borrowing from Eng. @Eng{fail}, from Lat. {fallo}, is however,
  possible in the modern languages.
<failm>, a helm; from the Norse {hjálm}, Eng. @Eng{helm}.
<failmean>, kneepan (M`A.); from @Ref{fail.3}, ring (Rob.).  See @Ref{falman}.
<fàilt>, @Ref<fàilte>, welcome, hail!  Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{fáilte}, *{vâletiâ}, root {vâl}, {vel},
  glow; W. @W{gwawl}, lumen; Gr. @Gr{ἀλέα}, warmth, sun's heat; Got.
--page 160
  {vulan}, be hot, O.H.G. {walm}, heat (Bez.).  Cf. Caesar's
  {Valetiacus}.  Borrowing from Lat. {valête} seems to be Zimmer's
  view (@ExtRef{Zeit.;30;28}).  Rhys suggests W. @W{gwell}; Hend., Eng.
  {wealth}.
<fainear>, under consideration, Ir. @Ir{fa deára}, remark, {fé ndeár}, {fé ndeara}
  (Munster).  Foley gives {tabhair fa d'aire} = "observe".
  "Thoir fainear" = observe, consider.  The above may be a
  fixed {fa d'aire} = {fa-deara}, with {n} from the plural @Ref{an.4}, their.
<fainleag>, @Ref<ainleag>, a swallow, Ir. @Ir{áinleóg}, O.Ir. @OIr{fannall}, W.
  {gwennol}, Corn. @Corn{guennol}, Br. @Br{gwenneli} *{vannello}.  Cf. Fr.
  {vanneau}, lapwing, Ital. {vannello}, Med.Lat. {vannellus}, which is
  usually referred to Lat. {vannus}, fan.   *{vat-n-allo-s} (Holden).
<fàinne>, a ring, Ir. @Ir{fáinne}, {áinne}, O.Ir. @OIr{ánne}, *{ânniâ}; Lat. {ânus},
  Eng. @Eng{annular}.

<fàireag>, a gland, swollen gland, Ir. @Ir{fáireóg} (Fol., O'R.); cf. W.
  {chwaren}, gland, blotch, root {sver}, hurt, Ger. {schwer}, difficult.
  The W. precludes comparison with Lat. {vărus}, pimple, {varix},
  dilated vein, Eng. @Eng{varicose}.
<fairge>, the ocean,Ir. {fairrge}, O.Ir. @OIr{fairgge}, Ptolemy's {Vergivios},
  the Irish Atlantic; from the same root as @Ref{fearg}.  In Sutherland
  {fairge} means the "ocean in storm".  Usually pronounced
  as if @Ref{fairce}.  W. @W{Môr Werydd}, the Atlantic.
<fairgneadh>, hacking, sacking:

<fairleas>, an object on the sky-line (H.S.D. from MSS.); *{f-air-leus};

<fairmeil>, noisy: allied to @Ref{seirm}.  See @Ref{foirm}?

<fàisne>, a pimple, weal (H.S.D., Dial.):

  *{fo-aith-tibim}, {tibiu}, I laugh, *{stebiô}; Lit. {stebiůs}, astonish.
<faiteach>, @Ref<fàiteach>, timorous, shy, Ir. @Ir{fáiteach}, {faitcheas}, fear
  (Keat.), O.Ir. @OIr{faitech}, cautus: *{f-ad-tech}, "home-keeping"?
<fàitheam>, a hem, Ir. @Ir{fáithim}, {fathfhuaim}; @Ref{fo} and @Ref{fuaim}.  See

<fàl.1>, turf, sods, dike, Ir. @Ir{fál}, hedge, fold, O.Ir. @OIr{fál}, saepes, W.
  {gwawl}, rampart, Pictish {fahel}, murus, *{vâlo-}; Lat. {vallum},

<fàl.2>, a spade, peat spade, Manx {faayl}, W. @W{pâl}, Corn. @Corn{pal}; from Lat.
  {pâla}.  Also "scythe" (Wh.).
<falach>, a hiding, covering, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{folach}, W., Br. @Br{golo}, *{vo-lugô},
  *{lugô}, hide, lie; Got. {liugan}, tell a lie, Eng. @Eng{lie} (Stokes).
  Ernault refers it to the root {legh}, @Ref{logh}, lie, as in G. {laighe}:
  "under-lie", in a causative sense.
<falachd>, spite, malice, treachery, Ir. @Ir{fala}.  See @Ref{fàillig}, @Ref{feall} for
  root.
<faladair>, orts (M`D.):
<fàladair.1>, a scythe, really "man who works the scythe", a turfer,
  from @Ref{fàl.1}: "scythe" properly is {iarunn fàladair}.
<fàladair.2>, bare pasture (H.S.D. for Heb.): "turf-land", from @Ref{fàl.1}.
<fala-dhà>, a jest, irony, fun; see @Ref{fealla-dhà}.
<falair>, an interment, funeral entertainment (Stew.) = {farair}?
<fàlaire>, an ambler, mare, Ir. @Ir{falaire}, ambling horse; seemingly
  founded on Eng. @Eng{palfrey}.  The form @Ref<àlaire>, exists, in the
  sese of "brood-mre" (M`Dougall's {Folk and Hero Tales}),
  leaning upon @Ref{àl}, brood, for meaning.  Ir. @Ir{falaradh}, to amble.
<falaisg>, heath-burning, Ir. @Ir{folosg} (do.), E.Ir. @EIr{foloiscim}, I burn
  slightly; from @Ref{fo} and {loisg}, q.v.
--page 162
<falamh>, empty, Ir. @Ir{folamh}, M.Ir. @MIr{folum}, E.Ir. @EIr{folom}, {folomm};
  cf. O.W. @OW{guollung}, M.Br. @MBr{gollo}, Br. @Br{goullo}.  Windisch derives
  the G. from @Ref{lom}, bare, but the modern aspiration of
  {folamh} makes this derivation doubtful.  Ernault refers the
  Br. to the root of Lat. {langueo}.
<falbh>, go @Ref<falbhan>, moving about, walking, waving, Ir. @Ir{foluamhain},
  bustling, running away, E.Ir. @EIr{folúamain}, flying; see @Ref{fo} and
  {luainech}.  O.Ir. @OIr{fulumain}, volubilis, allied to Lat. {volvo}, Eng.
  {wallow}, would suit the phonetics best, but it does not appear
  in the later dialects.  The verb {falbh} is made from @Ref{falbhan}.
  Hennessey referred the G. to @Ref{falamh}, empty.  Cf. E.Ir.
  @EIr{falmaigim}, empty, quit (Zim.).
<falbhair>, the young of live stock, a follower as a calf or foal; from
  the Sc. {follower}, a foal, Eng. @Eng{follower}.
<falcag>, common auk, @Ref<falc> (Heb.); from Norse {álka}, Eng. @Eng{auk}.
<fallaid>, dry meal put on cakes:
<fallain>, healthy, Ir. @Ir{falláin}, E.Ir. @EIr{follán}; for @Ref{fo}+@Ref{slàn}, q.v.
<fallsa>, false (M`D.), Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{fallsa}; from the Lat. {falsus}.
<falluing>, a mantle, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{fallaing}, Latinised form {phalingis}
  (Geraldus), dat.pl., W. @W{ffaling}; from Lat. @Ref{palla}, mantle,
  {pallium}.  Cf. O.Fr. {pallion}, M.Eng. {pallioun}.  M.E. {falding},
  sort of coarse cloth (Hend.).
<fallus>, sweat, Ir. @Ir{fallus}, {allus}, O.Ir. @OIr{allas}: *{jasl}, root {jas}, {jes},
  seethe, yeast, W. @W{jas}, what pervades, Br. @Br{goell} (= {vo-jes-l}),
  leaven; Eng. @Eng{yeast}, {zeal}; Gr. @Gr{ζέω}, boil.
<falmadair>, the tiller: "helm-worker", from @Ref<falm>, helm, from
  Norse {hjálm}, helm.  See @Ref{failm}.
<falmair>, a kind of fish (H.S.D. for Heb.), @Ref<falmaire>, herring hake:
<falman>, kneepan:
<falt>, hair, Ir. @Ir{folt}, O.Ir. @OIr{folt}, W. @W{gwallt}, Corn. @Corn{gols}, caesaries, O.Br.
  {guolt}, *{valto-s} (Stokes), root {vel}, cover; Lat. {vellus}, fleece,
  {lána}, wool, Gr. @Gr{λάσιος}, hairy (= {vlatios}); Eng. @Eng{wool}; Lit.
  {velti}, hairs, threads.  Stokes compares only Russ. {волотй},
  thread, Lit. {waltis}, yarn, Gr. @Gr{λάσιος}.  Same root as @Ref{olann},
  wool, *{vel}, *{vol}, *{ul}.
<faltan>, a tendon, snood; for {altan}, from @Ref{alt}.
<famh>, see @Ref{famh-thalmhainn}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<famhair>, a giant, Ir. @Ir{fomhor}, pirate, giant, E.Ir. @EIr{fomór}, {fomórach},
  a Fomorian, a mythic race of invaders of Ireland; *{fo-mór},
  "sub-magnus" (Zimmer).  Stokes refers the {-mor}, {-morach},
  to the same origin as {mare} of {nightmare}, Ger. {mahr}, nightmare.
  Rhys interprets the name as "sub-marini", taking
  {mor} from the root of @Ref{muir}, sea.  The {ó} of @Ref{mór}, if it is long
  (for it is rarely so marked) is against these last two derivations.
<famhsgal>, @Ref<fannsgal>, hurry, confusion (Arg.):
--page 163
<famh-thalmhainn>, @Ref<fath>, a mole, @Ref<fadhbh> (Lh.), W. @W{gwadd}, Corn.
  {god}, Br. @Br{goz}; M.Eng. {wont}, talpa.  Dialectic @Ref<ath-thalmhain>.
<fan>, stay, Ir. @Ir{fanaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{anaim}; root {an}, breathe, exist, as in
  @Ref{anam}, @Ref{anail}: "gabhail anail" = taking rest.  Stokes suggests
  {an} = {ṃn}, root {men}, remain, Lat. {maneo}, Gr. @Gr{μένω}, a phonetic
  change not yet proved for Gaelic.  W. @W{di-anod}, without delay.
<fanaid>, mockery, Ir. @Ir{fonomhad}, E.Ir. @EIr{fonomat}: *{vo-nom-anto-},
  root {nem}, take, for which see @Ref{nàmhad}.
<fanaigse>, dog violet (H.S.D. quoting O'R.), Ir. @Ir{fanaigse} (O'R.):
  from {pansy}?
<fànas>, a void space; from Lat. {vanus}.
<fang.1>, a sheep-pen, fank; from Sc. {fank}.
<fang.2>, a vulture, Ir. @Ir{fang}, raven.
<fann>, faint, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{fann}, W., Br. @Br{gwan}, Corn. @Corn{guan}, debilis,
  *{vanno-s}, root {vâ}, {ven}, spoil, wound; Got. {wunns}, affliction,
  {winnan}, to suffer, Eng. @Eng{wound}, {wan}; Gr. @Gr{ἄτε}, infatuation, etc.
  Others have connected it with Lat. {vannus} and with Eng. @Eng{want}.
  {fannan-feòir}, weak breeze (M`D.).
<fannadh>, fishing with a feathered hook (H.S.D. for Heb.):
<faob>, an excrescence, knob, piece, Ir. @Ir{fadhb} (Lh.†), O.Ir. @OIr{odb},
  obex, W. @W{oddf}: *{ud-bhv-o-}, "out-growth", root {bhu}, be (see
  @Ref{bu}).  Stokes gives a Celtic *{odbós}, from {eðgo-s}, {ozgo-s}(?),
  allied to Gr. @Gr{ὄσχη}, twig?  Lat. {obex}; or to Lit. {ůdega}, tail.
  Lidén equates Lat. {offa}, a ball. Stokes now @Gr{ὀσφύς}.
<faobh>, booty, Ir. @Ir{fadhbhaim}, I despoil, O.Ir. @OIr{fodb}, exuvias: *{vodvo-},
  from I.E. {vedh}, slay, thrust; Skr. {vadh}, slay; Gr. @Gr{ὠθέω}, push.
  The root may be {vedh}, pledge, Gr. @Gr{ἄεθλον}, war prize, Eng.
  {wager}.
<faobhag>, the common cuttle-fish (Heb.).
<faobhar>, edge, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{faebur}, O.Ir. @OIr{faibur}, machera,
  sword, *{vaibro-s}, Lat. {vibro}, vibrate, brandish, Lit. {wyburti},
  wag (Stokes).  Cf. further W. @W{gwaew}, pl. {gweywyr}, a lance.
<faoch.1>, @Ref<faochag>, a periwinkle, Ir. @Ir{faochóg}, M.Ir. @MIr{faechóg}; cf. W.
  {gwichiad}.
<faoch.2>, curve (Carm.):
<faochadh>, a favourable crisis in sickness, relief; see @Ref{faothaich}.
<faochainn>, entreat earnestly, strive, inf. @Ref<faochnadh> (M`A., Arg.):
<faochaire>, knave (Carm.):
<faod>, @Ref<feud>, may, Ir. @Ir{féadaim}, I can, E.Ir. @EIr{fétaim}, can, {sétar},
  {seitir}, potest, *{sventô}; Got. {swinþs}, strong, Ag.S. {swíð} (do.),
  Norse {svinnr}, clever, Ger. {geschwind}, swift (Stokes).
<faodail>, goods found by chance or lost, waif: "foundling", E.Ir.
  {étaim}, I find, *{pentô}, Eng. @Eng{find}.  See @Ref{eudail}.
<faodhail>,  ford, a narrow channel fordable at low water, a hollow
  in the sand retaining tide water: from N. {vaðill}, a shallow,
  a place where straits can be crossed, Shet {vaadle}, Eng. @Eng{wade}.

<faoghaid>, @Ref<faghaid>, @Ref<faodhailt>, starting of game, hunting:
<faoghar>, a sound; see rather @Ref{foghar}.
<faoighe>, @Ref<faighdhe>, begging, asking of aid in corn, etc., M.Ir.
  {faigde}, O.Ir. @OIr{foigde}, mendicatio, *{fo-guide}; from @Ref{fo} and
  @Ref{guidhe}, beg, q.v.
<faoilidh>, liberal, hospitable, Ir. @Ir{faoilidh}, joyful, O.Ir. @OIr{fáilidh},
  blithe, *{vâleti-s}, allied to {fáilt}, welcome (Stokes).  Hence
  @Ref<faoilte>, welcome, delight.  Root, *{vil}, Gr. @Gr{ἱλαρός}, gay?
<faoileag>, @Ref<faoileann>, a sea-gull, Ir. @Ir{faoileán}, O.Ir. @OIr{faoilenn}, W.
  {gwylan}, Br. @Br{gwelan}, whence Fr. {goëland} and Eng. @Eng{gull}.  For
  root, Stokes compares Eng. @Eng{wail}.
<faoilleach>, @Ref<faoillteach>, the month extending from the middle of
  January to the middle of February, Ir. @Ir{faoillidh} (do.),
  {faoilleach} (do.), holidays, Carnival.  The idea is "Carnival"
  or month of rejoicing; from @Ref{faoilidh}.  Usually referred to
  @Ref{faol}, wolf: "wolf-month".  Cf. @Ref{féill}.  February in Ir. = {mí
  na Féile Bríghde}.
<faoin>, vain, void, Ir. @Ir{faon}, M.Ir. @MIr{faen}, weak:
<faoisg>, unhusk, @Ref<faoisgeag>, a filbert, unhusked nut, O.Ir. @OIr{áesc},
  concha, {aesc}, classendix, Lat. {aesculus}? (Stokes).  Cf. W.
  {gweisgion}, husks, {gweisgioni}, to husk.
<faoisid>, @Ref<faosaid>, confession, Ir. @Ir{faoisdin}, O.Ir. @OIr{fóistiu}, *{vo-sestamtion-}

†<faol>, @Ref<faolchu>, a wolf, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{fáel}, {fael-chú}, W. @W{gweilgi}, the

<faolainn>, a stony beach (Heb.): "the beach", {vaðlinn}.

<far->, over; see @Ref{far.1}, upon, and @Ref{air} (b).  @Ref<far-ainm>, nick-name;

†<farradh>, company, vicinity, M.G. {na warri} (D.of L.), Ir.
  {farradh}, E.Ir. @EIr{farrad}, {i fharrad}, near, O.Ir. @OIr{in arrad}; from

<farral>, @Ref<farran>, anger, force, Ir. @Ir{farrán}, vexation, anger, {forrán},

<fàs.1>, grow, Ir. @Ir{fásaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{ásaim}, {fásaim}, root {aux}, {auℊ}, increase,
  Lat. {augeo}, Gr. @Gr{αὔξω}, Eng. @Eng{eke}, {wax}.  Stokes and Strachan
  refer {fás} to a stem {(p)ât-to-}, {pát}, {pat}, eat, feed, Gr. @Gr{πατέομαι},
  eat, Eng. @Eng{feed}, {food}.  Lat. {pasco}, {pastum}.
<fàs.2>, empty, waste, @Ref<fàsach>, a desert, Ir. @Ir{fás}, {fásach}, O.Ir. @OIr{fás}, {fáas},
  vanus, {fásach}, desert: *{vâsto-s}, a waste; Lat. {vastus}, vastare;
  Eng. @Eng{waste}, Ger. {wüste}.  Hence @Ref<fàsan>, refuse of grain:
  "waste".  {fásach}, desert, is neuter, see M`A. pref. VIII.
<fasair>, harness, girth-saddle; see @Ref{asair.1}.

<fasdadh>, hiring, binding, Ir. @Ir{fastogh}, hiring, see @Ref{foisteadh}.
<fasdail>, @Ref<astail.1>, a dwelling, E.Ir. @EIr{fastud}, holding fast, vb. {astaim},

  *{ex-sod-ijo}.  It is possible to refer {astaim} to *{ad-stâ-}, root
  {sta}, stand, Lat. {sto}; the {-asda} of @Ref{farasda}, "staid", seems
  from it (cf. @Ref{tairis.2}).
<fasgadh>, shelter, Ir. @Ir{fosgadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{foscad}, umbra: *{fo-scáth},
