<fathast>, yet, M.Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{fodesta}, {fodechtsa}, for {fo-fect-sa}, the {d}
  being otiose and caused by analogy (Zim., @ExtRef{Zeit.;30;21}).
  Atkinson suggests with a query {fo'nd(fh)echt-sa}.  The root
  word is {fecht}, time: "under this time, sub hoc tempus".
  See @Ref{feachd}, time.  Hence also @Ref<feasd> (= {i fecht-sa}).
<fathunn>, news, floating rumour, @Ref<fabhunn> (Dial.): *{vo-svon}, root
  {sven}, sound (see @Ref{tabhann}), or root {bon}, {ban}, Eng. @Eng{ban}, O.Ir.
  {atboind}, proclaims?
<fè>, @Ref<fèath>, (@Ref<fèith>, @Ref<fiath>), a calm, M.Ir. @MIr{feith}, E.Ir. @EIr{féth}, O.Ir. @OIr{féth},
  Gadelic root {vei}, *{ve-jo-}, root {ve}, {vê}, blow, Gr. @Gr{ἀήρ}, air, (whence
  Eng. @Eng{air}), Ger. {wehen}, to blow, Eng. @Eng{wind}, especially {weather}
  (root {vet}) for the G. sense.
<feabhas>, @Ref<feobhas>, goodness, "betterness", Ir. @Ir{feabhus}, O.Ir. @OIr{febas},
  superiority, {feib}, distincion, *{visus}, g. {vesv-iás} (Thur., @ExtRef{Zeit.;28;149},
  and Brug.), from {vesu-} or {vesv-}, as in @Ref{fiù}, q.v.  Stokes
  doubtfully compares Lat. {vigeo}, Eng. @Eng{vigour} (@ExtRef{Bez. Beit.;19;75}).
<feachd>, an army, host, expedition, Ir. @Ir{feachd}, an expedition, E.Ir.
  {fecht} ({ar fecht agus sluagad}), W. @W{gwaith}, action, work.  This
  Zimmer refers to O.Ir. @OIr{fichim}, I fight (Lat. {vinco}, Got. {veihan},
  root {viq}), as well as †<feachd>, time, Ir. @Ir{feachd}, E.Ir. @EIr{fecht},
  {oenfhecht}, once, W. @W{gwaith}, turn, {vicem}.  Stokes separates
  the latter (<feachd>, time, E.Ir. @EIr{fecht}, journey), giving as
  stem {vektâ}, root {vegh} (Lat. {veho}, Eng. @Eng{waggon}); for {fecht},
  campaign, hosting, he gives the Celtic {viktâ}, root {viq}, as
  Zimmer does.  The words seem, as Stokes has it, from two
  roots, but now they are indistinguishably mixed.  Osthoff
  regards {feachd}, time, as allied to Lat. {vices}; see @Ref{fiach.2}.
<fead>, a whistle, Ir. @Ir{fead}, M.Ir. @MIr{fet-}, {fetán}, a flute, a whistle, W.
  {chwythell}, a whistle, {chwyth}, a blast, breath, *{wviddo-}, *{svizdo-},
  Lat. {sibilus}, Eng. @Eng{sibilant}.  See further under @Ref{séid}.
<feadh>, length, extent, so Ir.; see @Ref{eadh.2}.
<feadhainn>, people, some people, troop, Ir. @Ir{feadhainn}, E.Ir. @EIr{fedain},
  company, {cobeden} conjugatio, W. @W{gwedd}, team, yoke, root {ved},
  I.E. {vedh}, Eng. @Eng{wed}, Lat. {vas}, {vadis}, surety, Skr. {vi-vadhá},
  shoulder-yoke.
--page 168
<fealan>, (M`A. @Ref<feallan>, itch, hives; it also means "worm" (see
  @Ref{fiolan}), M.Ir. @MIr{filún}, glandular disease, {fiolún saith}, anthrax,
  malignant struma, all which Stokes takes from L.Lat. {fello},
  strumae.
<feall>, treachery, Ir. @Ir{feall}, E.Ir. @EIr{fell} (*{velno-}), W. @W{gwall}, defect, Br.
  {goall} (do.), Corn. @Corn{gal}, malus, malum, Br. @Br{gwall} (do.), root {vel},
  cheat; Lit. {ap-vilti}, {vilióti}, cheat, Lett. {wilát}, deceitful;
  Norse {vél}, a deceit, wile, Eng. @Eng{wile}; Zend {vareta}, error.
  Stokes hesitates between the above and {vel} from {u(p)el}, Got.
  {ubils}, Eng. @Eng{evil}.
<fealla-dhà>, joking, irony: *{feall}+{dhà}, "double-dealing".
<feallsanach>, philosopher, Ir. @Ir{feallsamhnach}, {feallsamh}, philosopher,
  O.Ir. @OIr{felsub}; from Lat. {philosophus}.
<feamach>, groos, dirty (Sh., O'R.): from {feam}, tail, as in @Ref{feaman}.
<feamainn>, sea-weed, Ir. @Ir{feamuin}, E.Ir. @EIr{femnach}, W. @W{gwymon}, Fr.
  {goëmon}, *{vit-s-máni-}, root {vi}, {vei}, wind, as in @Ref{fèith}, vein?
  Stokes gives the stem as {vemmâni-} ({vembani-}?), which suggests
  *{veℊvo-}, root {veℊ}, as in @Ref{feur}.
<feaman>, a tail, Ir. @Ir{feam}, M.Ir. @MIr{feam}, mentula, Manx {famman};
  also G. @Ref<eaman>, *{engvo-}, Lat. {inguen}, groin.
<feann>, flay:
<feannadh>, skinning, excessive cold; see @Ref{fionnadh}.  The idea of
  "cold" is metaphorical.  E.Ir. @EIr{fennaim}, I skin, is referred
  by Stokes to the root of Eng. @Eng{wound}: he gives the stem as
  *{venvo-}.
<feannag.1>, hooded crow, Ir. @Ir{feannóg}, {fionnóg}: cf. @Ref{fionna}, pile, for
  root: "piled crow"?
<feannag.2>, a lazy-bed; older {fennoc}, trench: from @Ref{feann}, flay.
<fear>, a man, Ir. @Ir{fear}, O.Ir. @OIr{fer}, W. @W{gwr}, O.W. @OW{gur}, Corn. @Ref{gur}, Br.
  {gour}, *{viro-s} (Rhys thinks the Celtic start was {ver}: cf. W.
  {gwr} = {ver}, super, and G. {eadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{ed} = Lat. {id}, etc.): Lat.
  {vir}; Ag.S. {wer}, Norse {verr}, Eng. @Eng{werwolf}; Lit. {wýras}; Skr.
  {vîra}.
<fearann>, land, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ferand}, also {ferenn}, a girdle, garter,
  root {vera}, enclose, look after; Skr. {varaṇá}, well, dam, {vṛṇoti},
  cover, enclose; Gr. @Gr{ἐρυσθαι}, draw, keep; Ch.Sl. {vrêti},
  claudere: further Lat. {vereor}, Eng. @Eng{ware}.
<fearg>, wrath, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ferg}, O.Ir. @OIr{ferc}, {ferg}, *{vergâ}; Gr.
  @Gr{ὀργή}; root {vergo}, swell, be puffed up.  Hence @Ref<feargnadh>,
  provocation.
<feàrna>, alder tree, Ir. @Ir{fearn}, {fearnóg}, E.Ir. @EIr{fern}, {fernog}, W. @W{gwern},
  Corn. @Corn{gwernen}, Gaul. {verno-}, Fr. {verne}, *{verno-}; Gr. @Gr{ἐρνια}, wild
  figs (? Bez.).
<feàrr>, better, Ir. @Ir{feárr}, O.Ir. @OIr{ferr}, *{vers}, *{ver(i)s}, a comparative
  in {-is} from the prep. {ver} (= G. @Ref{far.1}, @Ref{for-}, super); now comparative
--page 169
  for @Ref{math.1}, but evidently once for {fern}, good, *{verno-s},
  Lat. {supernus} (cf. {-no-} of {magnus} disappearing in {major}, and
  {-ro-} of Celtic {mâros} in G. @Ref{mò}).  Stokes refers {ferr} to {vers},
  raise, *{uersos-}, height, top; Lat. {verruca}, steep place, Lit.
  {wirzùs}, top, Skr. {varshman-}, height, {várshîyas}, higher.  Cf.
  W. @W{goreu}, best (= Lat. {supremus}).
<feàrsaid>, a spindle, Ir. @Ir{fearrsaid}, M.Ir. @MIr{fersaid}, *{versatti-}, *{verttati-},
  W. @W{gwerthyd}, Corn. @Corn{gurthit}, O.Br. @OBr{guirtilon}, fusis, M.Br.
  {guerzit}, root {vert}, turn; Lat. {vertô}, {vortex}; Ger. {werden}, to be,
  Eng. @Eng{worth}, be, M.H.G. {wirtel}, spindle ring.  Skr. {vártate},
  turn, roll, {vartulâ}, spindle ball.
<fearsaideag>, thrift or sea gilly-flower; from ovs. @Ref<fearsad>, estuary,
  sand-bank, passage across at ebb-tide, whence place-name
  {Fersit}, and in Ireland {Belfast}; for root see @Ref{feart.3}.
<feart.1>, attention, notice; Br. @Br{gortos}, to attend, root {vert}, {vort};
  Ger. {warten}, attend, Eng. @Eng{ward}, from {ware}, Nor. {varða}, ward.
  An extension of root {ver}, watch, Lat. {vereor}, etc.
<feart.2>, a virtue, efficiency, deed, Ir. @Ir{feart}, O.Ir. @OIr{firt}, pl. {ferta}, W.
  {gwyrth}; from Lat. {virtus} (Windisch, Stokes).
†<feart.3>, a grave, Ir. @Ir{feart}, O.Ir. @OIr{fert}, tumulus, *{verto-}; root {ver},
  cover, enclose, which see under @Ref{fearann}.  Cf. Skr. {vṛti},
  enclosure, hedge.
<fearthuinn>, rain, Ir. @Ir{fearthuinn}, E.Ir. @EIr{ferthain}, inf. to {feraim},
  I pour, give, *{veraô}, rain: Lat. {ûrína}, urine, Gr. @Gr{οὗρον} (do.):
  Norse {úr}, a drizzle, Ag.S. {wär}, sea; Skr. {vā́ri}, water, Zend,
  {vâra}, rain.  See @Ref{dòirt}.
<feascradh>, shrivelling, so Ir. (O'R.):
<feasd>, @Ref<am feasd>, for ever, Ir. @Ir{feasda}, henceforward, E.Ir. @EIr{festa},
  {ifesta}, now, from this point forward, {i fecht-sa}; from @Ref{feachd} by
  metathesis of the {s}.  See @Ref{fathast}.
<feasgar>, evening, Ir. @Ir{feascar}, O.Ir. @OIr{fescor}, *{vesqero-}, W. @W{ucher},
  *{eksero-} for *{esqero-}; Lat. {vesper}; Gr. @Gr{ἑσπέρος}.
<feathachan>, slight breeze; see @Ref{feothachan}.
<féile.1>, generosity, hospitality, Ir. @Ir{féile}, E.Ir. @EIr{féle}; from @Ref{fial}, q.v.
†<féile.2>, charm, incantation, E.Ir. @EIr{éle}, {héle}, {mo fhele}; from Norse
  {heill}, auspice, omen, Eng. @Eng{hale}, etc.; allied to O.Ir. @OIr{cél},
  augurium, W. @W{coel}, omen, O.W. @OW{coil} (Zim., @ExtRef{Zeit.;33;147}).
  For G. {féile}, see @ExtRef{Inv. Gaelic Soc. Tr.;17;243}.  Stokes regards
  Zimmer's derivation from N. a failure, and compares W. @W{wylo},
  wail, weep, as Ir. @Ir{amor}, music = W. @W{afar}, grief, and G. {ceòl}
  = Ger. {heulen}, howl.  Rhys cfs. W. @W{eli}, oil, ointment.
<féile.3>, @Ref<féileadh>, a kilt, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{fíal}, velum: O.Ir. @OIr{ronfeladar},
  he might clothe us; from Lat. {vêlum}, a covering, {vêlare}, Eng.
  {veil}.  In Islay, Jura, etc., it is {an t-sibhleadh}.  McL. and D.
--page 170
  also give {éibhleadh}.  Hend. questions if Lat.  See {uanfebli}
  in Fled Br. 68.  Root {sveil} as in @Ref{fill}, {spaoil}, etc?
<féill>, a fair, feast, Ir. @Ir{féil}, festival, holiday, O.Ir. @OIr{féil}, W. @W{gwyl},
  festum, Br. @Br{goel}, *{vegli-}; Lat. {vigilia}, Fr. {veille}, a watch,
  vigil, Eng. @Eng{vigil}, {wake}.  The Celtic words are borrowed from
  Lat. (Windisch, Stokes).  Hence {féillire}, an almanack.
<féin>, self, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{féin}, *{sve-j-sin}, "self there", *{sve-j}, *{sve}, Pruss.
  {swaiss}, Ch.Sl. {svojĭ}; Lat. {suus}, {sē}; Gr. @Gr{ἕ}, @Gr{ὅς}.  Zeuss explains
  {féin}, as {bé-shin}, "quod sit hoc", {bé} being the verb to be.  This
  explanation is due to the divers forms of the O.Ir. word for
  "self, selves": {fésine} (= {bé-sin-é}, sit id hoc), {fésin}, {fadesin}
  (= {bad-é-sin}), {fodén}, etc.
<Féinn>, g. @Ref<Féinne>, the Fingalians, Ir. @Ir{Féinne}, @Ref{Fiann}, E.Ir. @EIr{fíann},
  *{veinnâ}, also E.Ir. @EIr{fían}, a hero, *{veino-s}, root {vein}, strive;
  Lat. {vênari}, hunt; Skr. {vénati}, go, move, desire.  Zimmer
  takes the word from Norse {fjándi}, an enemy (Eng. {fiend},
  which he supposes the Irish tropps called themselves after
  the Norsemen.
<feirm>, a farm, Ir. @Ir{feilm}; from m.Eng. {ferme}, Eng. @Eng{farm}.
<féisd>, @Ref<féis>, a feast; better @Ref{feusd}, q.v.
<feith>, wait, Ir. @Ir{feithim}, E.Ir. @EIr{fethim}, inf. {fethem} (= G. @Ref<feitheamh>),
  *{vetô}, root {vet}; Lat. {vetus}, old, Eng. @Eng{veteran}; Gr. @Gr{ἒτος}, year;
  Eng. @Eng{wether} ("yearling").
<féith>, a sinew, a vein, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{féith}, fibra, *{veiti-s}, root {vei}, {vi},
  wind, bend; Lat. {vînem}, with, {vîtis}, a vine; Gr. @Gr{ἰτέα} (long {ι}),
  willow; Eng. @Eng{withe}; Lit. {výtis}, willow-wand, Ch.Sl. {viti},
  res torta; Skr. {vayati}, weave, flecto.  The W. shows a stem
  *{vittâ}, vein, W. @W{gwythen}, Br. @Br{gwazen}, Corn. @Corn{guid-}; cf. Lat.
  {vitta}, fillet.  Hence <féith>, a bog channel (Ir. {féth}, a marsh,
  bog-stream), and @Ref<feithleag>, honeysuckle, M.Ir. @MIr{feithlend},
  woodbine, W. @W{gwyddfid} (do.).
<feitheid>, a bird or beast of prey (M`A.), Ir. @Ir{feithide}, Ir. @Ir{feithide}, a beast:
<feochadan>, corn-thistle, thistle (Arm., H.S.D.), Ir. @Ir{feochadan}
  (O'R.), {feóthadán} (O'B.), and {feóthán}.  Cf. @Ref{fobhannan}.
<feòcullan>, the pole-cat, Ir. @Ir{feochullan} (Fol., O'R. has {feocullan} like
  Sh.).  Cf. Sc. {fethok}, {fithowe}, pole-cat, M.Eng. {ficheu}, now
  {fitchew}.
<feobharan>, pith, puff (@Ref<feo'ran>) - Dial.; {feodharan}, root, *{vet}, {vetu-}?
<feobhas>, goodness; see @Ref{feabhas}.
<feòdar>, pewter, Ir. @Ir{péatar}, W. @W{ffeutar}; from the Eng. @Eng{pewter}.
<feodhaich>, decay, Ir. @Ir{feodhaim}, M.Ir. @MIr{feodaigim}, wither:

  {feugud}, W. @W{gwyw}, Lat. {vietus}; *{vivagatu}?
<feòil>, flesh, Ir. @Ir{feoil}, E.Ir. @EIr{feóil}, O.Ir. @OIr{feúil}, *{vepoli-s}; Skr.
  {vapâ}, fat, {vápus}, body, form?

<feòirlig>, a farthing land, @Ref<feòirling>; from Ag.S. {feorþling}, Eng.
  {farthing}.
<feòirne>, chess, Ir. @Ir{feoirne} (Sh., O'R., Fol.):
<feòrag>, a squirrel, Ir. @Ir{feoróg} (Sh., O'R., Fol.), W. @W{gwiwer}, Br.
  {gwiber}; Lit. {voverė}, Lettic {wâweris}, Pruss. {weware}; Lat.
  {viverra}, ferret (Pliny).
<feòraich>, inquire, @Ref<fiafraigh> (Kintyre Dial.), Ir. @Ir{fiafruighim}, O.Ir.
  {iarfaigim}: *{iar-fach}, prep. {iar} and {fach}, E.Ir. @EIr{faig}, dixit,
  *{vakô}, say; Lat. {vocô}, call, {vox}, voice; Skr. {vac}, say.  The {r}
  of G. and modern Ir. has shifted to behind the {f}, while a
  prothetic {f} is added.
<feòrlan>, a firlot; see @Ref{feòirling}.
<feothachan>, @Ref<feothan> (Arran), a little breeze; root {vet}, as in
  @Ref{onfhadh}.
<feuch>, @Ref<fiach.3>, behold, see, try, Ir. @Ir{feuch}, {féach}, E.Ir. @EIr{féchaim},
  {fégaim}, *{veikô}; Gr. @Gr{εἰκών}, image (Eng. {iconoclastic}), @Gr{εὄικα},
  I seem, @Gr{εἰκαζω}, conjecture; Skr. {viç}, appear, arrive.
<feud>, may, can; see @Ref{faod}.
<feudail>, cattle; usual spelling of @Ref{eudail}, q.v.
<feudar>, @Ref<'s fheudar>, it is necessary, M.Ir. @MIr{is eidir}, it is possible,
  for {is ed fhétir}, it is what is possible.  {feudar} is the pres.
  pass. of @Ref{feud}, may.  In G. the "may" has become "must".
  The negative, @Ref<cha 'n fheudar>, is common in E.Ir. as {ni fhétir},
  {ni étir}, cannot be.
<feum>, use, need, Ir. @Ir{feidhm}, pl. {feidhmeanna}, need, use, duty, need-service
  of a vassal, E.Ir. @EIr{feidm}, effort, *{védes-men-}, "need-service";
  root {ved}, as in @Ref{feadhainn}.  Hence @Ref<feumannach>, a
  steward: "a servitor".
<feun>, a waggon, wain, O.Ir. @OIr{fén}, W. @W{cywain}, vehere, *{vegno-}, root
  {vegh}, carry; Lat. {veho}, {vehiculum}, vehicle; Gr. @Gr{ὄχος}, chariot;
  Eng. @Eng{waggon}, {wain}; Skr. {vahati}, carry.
<feur>, @Ref<fiar>, grass, Ir. @Ir{feur}, O.Ir. @OIr{fér}, W. @W{gwair}, Corn. @Corn{gwyr}, *{vegro-},
  I.E. root {veℊ}, increase, be strong; Lat. {vegeo}, quicken,
  {vigor}, vigour, Eng. @Eng{vegetation}; Ag.S. {wacan}, nasci, Eng.
  {waken}.  Strachan and Stokes refer it to the root {veℊ}, {uℊ}, be
  wet, moist, Lat. {uvidus}, moist, Eng. @Eng{humour}, Gr. @Gr{ὑγρός}, wet,
  Norse {vökr}, moist; but judged by the Latin, the Celtic should
  be {vebro-}, which would not give W. @W{gwair}.
<feursa>, a canker, @Ref<veursann>, a worm in the hide of cattle:
<feusag>, @Ref<fiasag>, a beard, Ir. @Ir{féusóg}, {féasóg}, E.Ir. @EIr{fésóc}, beard, {fés},
  hair, *{vanso}, O.Pruss., {wanso}, first beard, Ch.Sl. {vasŭ},
  beard.
<feusd>, @Ref<feusda>, (@Ref<féisd>, @Ref<féis>), a feast, Ir. @Ir{féis}, @Ref{feusda}, E.Ir. @EIr{feiss};
  from Lat. {festia}, Eng. @Eng{feast}.

<fhuair>, found, invent, Ir. @Ir{fuair}, O.Ir. @OIr{fúar}, inveni, {frith}, inventus

<fiach.1>, value, worth; see @Ref{fiach.2}.

<fiadh>, a deer, Ir. @Ir{fiadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{fíad}, O.Ir. @OIr{fíadach}, venatio, W.
  {gwydd}, Br. @Br{guez}, {goez}, savage, *{veido-s}, wild; O.H.G. {weide},
  a hunt, Ger. {weide}, pasturage, Norse {veiðr}, hunting; further
  is G. @Ref{fiodh}, wood, Eng. @Eng{wood}.  Hence @Ref<fiadhaich>, wild.
<fiadhaich>, invite, welcome (Skye):
<fiadhair>, lay or fallow land; from the above root of @Ref{fiadh}.  Cf.
  Ger. {weide}, pasture.  Also G. @Ref<fiadhain>, wild, Ir. @Ir{fiadháin},
  wild, uncultivated.
<fial>, generous, Ir. @Ir{fial}, E.Ir. @EIr{fíal}, modest, W. @W{gwyl}.  Bez. suggests
  *{veiplo-}, Teutonic {vîba-}, Ger. {weib}, Eng. @Eng{wife}.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{fialus},
  relationship.  The underlying idea is "kindness, relationship".
<fiamh.1>, awe, reverence, Ir. @Ir{fiamh}, fear, reverence, ugly, horrible,
  E.Ir. @EIr{fiam}, horrible:
<fiamh.2>, aspect, appearance, trace, Ir. @Ir{fiamh}, track, trace, chain,
  {fíamh} (O'Cl.) = lorg, E.Ir. @EIr{fiam}, a chain, *{veimo-}, root {vei},
  wind, as in @Ref{féith}.  @Ref<fiamh ghàire>, @Ref<fèath ghaire> (Arg.), a
  slight smile, is in Ir. @Ir{fáetheadh an gháire}, appearance of a
  smile, E.Ir. @EIr{féth}, aspect.
<fianaidh>, peat cart; {carn-fianaidh} (Ross); see @Ref{feun}.
<Fiann>, the Fingalians; see @Ref{Féinn}.  This is the real nom. case.
<fiantag>, the black heath-berr; root {vein} as in @Ref{Fiann}.
<fianuis>, witness, a witness, Ir. @Ir{fiadhnuise}, {fiadhan}, a witness, O.Ir.

<fich>, an interjetion denoting "nasty"!  Eng. @Eng{fie}, Norse {fý}, Ger.

  rottenness ("Cha bhi fuidh ach far am bi fàile").
<fichead>, twenty, Ir. @Ir{fiche}, {ar fhichid}, O.Ir. @OIr{fiche}, g. {fichet}, W.

<fideadh>, a suggestion (H.S.D.): *{vid-dho-}, root {vid}, wit.
<fideag>, a small pipe, reed, flute, Ir. @Ir{fideóg}; for root, see @Ref{fead}.
  Shaw also gives the meaning "small worm".  M`L. has
  @Ref<fìdeag>.
<fidean>, a green islet or spit uncovered at high tide, web of sea-clam
  (Isles); from the N. {fit}, webbed foot of waterfowl,
  meadow land on the banks of firths or rivers, {fitja}, to web,
  Eng. @Eng{fit}.
<fìdhleir>, a fiddler; from {fiodhull}.  Ir. @Ir{fidiléir} is Eng. @Eng{fiddler}
  directly borrowed.  Hence G. @Ref<fidleireachd>, restlessness;
  "fiddling" about.
<fidir>, know, consider, Ir. @Ir{fidir}, knows, O.Ir. @OIr{fetar}, scio, {fitir}, novit,
  *{viddetor}, *{vid-dho-} (the {-dho-} as in @Ref{creid}, Windisch); root
  {vid}, see, as in @Ref{fios}.  Thurneysen explains it as *{videsar}
  (aorist stem {vides-}) becoming {vid-shar}, but {d-sh} does not
  produce {t} or {d} without an {n} before it.
<fige>, @Ref<figis>, a fig, Ir. @Ir{fíge}; from Lat. {fîcus}, Eng. @Eng{fig}.
<figh>, weave, Ir. @Ir{fighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{figim}, O.W. @OW{gueig}, testrix, W. @W{gweu},

  Ger {wickeln}, roll, wind, curl, {wieche}, wick, Eng. @Eng{wick}, Ag.S.
  {wecca} (Stokes).  Usually referred to the root {vei}, {vi}, wind.
<file>, @Ref<filidh>, a poet, Ir. @Ir{file}, g. @Ref{filidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{fili}, g. {filed}, *{velet-},
  "seer"; W. @W{gwelet}, to see, Br. @Br{guelet}, sight, *{velô}.  Cf. Norse

<fill>, fold, Ir. @Ir{fillim}, fold, return, O.Ir. @OIr{fillim}, flecto, *{velvô}; Lat.
  {volvo}, roll, {volumen}, Eng. @Eng{volume}; Gr. @Gr{εἰλύω}, envelop; Got.
  {af-valvjan}, roll away, Eng. @Eng{wallow}.  Cf. W. @W{olwyn}, a wheel
  (Stokes).  Windisch ({Curt. Et.}) suggests {vald} as root, allied
  to Norse {velta}, roll, Got. {valtjan}, Eng. @Eng{welter}, Ger. {walze}, roll,
  waltz.  See especially @Ref{till}.
<fillein>, a collop: a "roll"; from @Ref{fill}.

<flasg>, a flask, W. @W{fflasg}; from the Eng.
<flath>, a chief, prince, Ir. @Ir{flaith}, O.Ir. @OIr{flaith}, chief, dominion,
  {flaithem(an)}, chief (*{vlatimon-}), W. @W{gwlad}, region, M.W.
  {gulatic}, rex, Corn. @Corn{gulat}, patria, Br. @Br{gloat}, realm, Gaul. {vlatos},
  *{vlato-s}, *{vlati-s}, root {vala}, {vla}, be strong; Lat. {valere}, Eng.
  {valid}; Got. {valdan}, Ger. {walten}, rule, Eng. @Eng{weild}, Walter;
  Ch.Sl. {vladą}, rule, Russ. {владиете}, rule, O.Pruss. {waldnika-},
  king.  Also *{valo-s} as the final element of certain personal
  names - @Ref<Domhnall>, *{Dumno-valo-s} (see @Ref{domhan}), @Ref<Conall>,
  *{Kuno-valo-s} (*{kuno-s}, high, root {ku}, as in @Ref{curaidh}, q.v.,
  Teutonic {Hûn-}, Humbold, Humphrey, Hunwald, etc.), @Ref<Cathal>,
  *{Katu-valo-s} (see @Ref{cath}), etc.
<fleachdail>, flowing in ringlets (H.S.D., from MSS.); from Lat.
  {plecto}, plait.
<fleadh>, a feast, Ir. @Ir{fleadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{fled}, W. @W{gwledd}, O.W. @OW{guled},
  pompae, *{vḷdâ}, root {vel}, wish; Gr. @Gr{εἰλαπíνη}, feast, @Gr{ἔλδομαι},
  wish, {e@'lpís}, hope; Lat. {voluptas}; Eng. @Eng{will}, {well}.
<fleadhadh>, brandishing; Eng. @Eng{wield}; see @Ref{flath}.
<fleasg>, a rod, wreath, Ir. @Ir{fleasg}, garland, wand, sheaf, O.Ir. @OIr{flesc},
  rod, linea, *{vleska}, from *{vledska}, root {vḷd}; Ger. {wald}, wood,
  Eng. @Eng{wold}; Gr. @Gr{ἄλσος}, grove; Ch.Sl. {vladi}, hair.  From the
  Celtic comes the Fr. {flèche}, arrow, whence Eng. @Eng{Fletcher},
  arrow-maker.  See @Ref{fleisdear}.
<fleasgach>, young man, bachelor, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{flesgach}: "wand-bearer".
  From @Ref{fleasg}, above.  The Ir. @Ir{fleasgaigh ealadhna},
  itinerant medicine men, carried {fleasgan} to denote their profession.
<fleasgairt>, a barge or boat hung with festoons; from @Ref{fleasg}.
<fleisdear>, arrow-maker; from Sc. {fledgear}, M.Eng. {flecchere}, now
  {fletcher}, from O.Fr. {flechier}.  See @Ref{fleasg} further.
<fleodradh>, floating (Heb.), @Ref<fleodruinn>, a buoy; from Norse {fljóta},
  to float, Eng. @Eng{float}.
<fleogan>, an untidy, flabby person, a flat fish (Arms.), @Ref<fleoidhte>,
  flaccid (Sh.):
<fliodh>, chickweed, a wen, Ir. @Ir{fliodh}, {fligh}, chickweed, W. @W{gwlydd},
  chickweed, soft stems of plants, *{vḷdu-}.  Same root as in @Ref{fleasg}.
<fliuch>, wet, Ir., O.Ir., @OIr{fliuch}, W. @W{gwlyb}, O.W. @OW{gulip}, Corn. @Corn{glibor},
  humor, Br. @Br{gloeb}, wet, *{vḷqu-s}, wet; Lat. {liquidus} (= {fliquidus});
  Lit. {wa'lks}, wet, {wa'lka}, swampy place.  See @Ref{failc}.
<flò>, hallucination (H.S.D. for N.H.):
<flod>, a state of floating; from Eng. @Eng{float}, Norse {floti}, a raft.
<flodach>, lukewarm; see @Ref{plodadh}.
<flùr>, @Ref<plùr>, flower, Ir. @Ir{plúr}, M.Ir. @MIr{plúr}; from the M.Eng. {flour},
  O.Fr. {flour}, Lat. {florem}, G. <flùr> is from the Scotch.

<foghar>, harvest, Ir. @Ir{fóghmhar}, M.Ir. @MIr{fogamur}, autumn, E.Ir.

  idea is "sub hiemem".  Cf. W. @W{cynauaf}, harvest, O.W.

<fois>, rest, Ir. @Ir{fois}, O.Ir. @OIr{foss}, residence, remaining, rest, W. @W{ar-os};
  *{voss-}; root {ves}, be, rest; Gr. @Gr{ἄστυ}, city (*{vastus}); Skr. {vástu},
  place; Lat. {Vesta}; Eng. @Eng{was}, Ger. {wessen}, be, Got. {visa},
  remain.  So all etymologists till Windisch (1892) suggested
  the root {stâ}, tat is *{vo-sto-}.  Stokes still holds by old (1903).
  Hence @Ref<foisdin>, taciturnity, Ir. @Ir{foisdine}.

<fuaidne>, loose pins of warping stakes.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{fuat}.
<fuaigh>, stitch, @Ref<fuaigheal>, sewing, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{fúagaim}, {úagaim},
  O.Ir. @OIr{úaimm} (n.): {+out-s-men-}; root {poug}, {pug}, stitch,
  stick; Lat. {pungo}, Eng. @Eng{punch}.  Zimmer (in 1882), referred
  it to the root of @Ref{òigh}, the idea being "integrate", from
  {óg}, {uag}, "integer".  O.Ir. @OIr{óigthidi}, sartores.
<fuaim>, noise, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{fúaimm} (pl. {fuamand}).  Neither
  *{vog-s-men} (Strachan; root {vog} of Skr. {vagnú}, sound, Got.
  {vôpjan}, cry, Eng. @Eng{whoop}) nor *{voc-s-men} (Stokes; root {voq},
  voice, Lat. {voco}) can give @Ref{ua}, only {ŏ} or {ă}.
<fuaithne>, loom posts (Uist), Ir. @Ir{uaithne}, pillar, post, E.Ir. @EIr{úatne},
  a post (bed post).  So Henderson; {fùidne} (Wh.):
<fual>, urine, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{fúal}: *{voglo-} or *{voblo-}; root {voℊ}, {veℊ}, {uℊ},
  be wet; Gr. @Gr{ὑγρός}, wet, Eng. @Eng{hygrometer}; Lat. {humidus}, {uveo},
  (for {ugveo}), be moist, Eng. @Eng{humour}; Norse {vökva}, moisture.
<fuar>, cold, Ir. @Ir{fuar}, E.Ir. @EIr{uar}, W. @W{oer}, Corn. @Corn{oir}; *{ogro-}, root {ug},
  {aug}, of {fuacht}, q.v.  Stokes refers it to the root {veℊ}, {uℊ}, discussed
  under @Ref{fual}, especially Gr. @Gr{ὑγρός}, wet; a root which
  would rather be {vob} in Celtic (cf. Lat.), and this would not
  give W. @W{oer}.  Strachan suggests either Ch.Sl. {ognĭ}, fire (Lat.
  {ignis}), or Gr. @Gr{πάγος}, frost (root {pâg}, fix, fit).  Hence @Ref<fuaradh>,
  windward side, @Ref<fuaran>, a well, @Ref<fuarraidh>, damp, @Ref<fuarralanach>
  (Ir. {fuarálach}, chill), cold feeling, etc.; {fuar bhalla}, an outside
  wall; {fuar-shlat}, the rough strong hoop used to bend in
  staves at the end of casks (Wh.).
--page 183
<fuasgail>, loose, untie, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{fuaslaicim}; see @Ref{tuasgail}.
<fuath.1>, hatred, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{fúath}; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{uath}, awe, terror,
  terrible, and see @Ref{uath} for root.
<fuath.2>, a spectre, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{fúath}, figura, forma:
<fùcadh>, fulling cloth, M.G. {owkki^t} (D.of L.), Ir. @Ir{úcaire}, fuller; cf.
  @Ref{pùc}.
<fudag>, a shoe-strap (H.S.D. says Dial.):
<fudaidh>, mean, vile; from Sc. {footy}, {fouty}.
<fùdar>, powder, Ir. @Ir{púdar}; from the Eng.
<fùdraic>, smart, in good condition:
<fuidh>! an interjection.  See @Ref{fich}.
<fuidheall>, remainder, Ir. @Ir{fuigheall}, O.Ir. @OIr{fuidell}, W. @W{gweddill};
  also G. @Ref<fuidhleach>, remains, E.Ir. @EIr{fuidlech}: *{vodilo-}, {dîl},
  allied to Eng. @Eng{deal}, {dole}, Ger. {teil} (St. with query).
<fuidir>, a fool (Carm.):
<fùidreadh>, commixing, pulverising; from @Ref{fùdar}.  Dial. @Ref<fùdradh>,
  turning hay in the sunshine to dry it.
<fùidsidh>, craven; from Sc. {fugie}, one who flies from the fight.
<fuigheag>, a thrum, Ir. @Ir{fughóg}; from a short vowel form of root
  of @Ref{fuaigh}.
<fuil>, blood, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{fuil}, gen. {fola}, {folo}: *{voli-}, root {vol}, {vel},
  well; Eng. @Eng{well}.  Stokes agrees.
<fuilear>, @Ref<cha 'n fhuilear dhomh>, I need, must; for @Ref{furail}, O.Ir.
  {foráil}, excessive injunction, infliction, same root as @Ref{earail}.
<fuilig>, @Ref<fuiling>, @Ref<fulaing>, suffer (thou), Ir. @Ir{fulangaim}, E.Ir.
  {fulangim}, O.Ir. @OIr{fuloing}, sustinet, inf. @Ref{fulang}: "under-go";
  from @Ref{fo} and *{long}, going, root {leng}, spring, go, as in @Ref{leum},
  q.v.  Further allied is Ger. {verlangen}, desire, Eng. @Eng{long}, Lat.
  {longus}.
<fuin>, bake, Ir. @Ir{fuinim}, I knead, bake, boil, E.Ir. @EIr{fuinim}, bake,
  cook.  Zimmer takes the word to mean "to fire, bake", from
  the Norse {funi}, flame, fire, E.Ir. @EIr{oc-fune} = Norse {við funa},
  a-roasting; but unlikely.  Possibly *{voni-}, "dress", root {ven},
  {von}, Lat. {Venus}, Eng. @Eng{venerate}.
<fuirbidh>, a strong man, also @Ref<fuirbearnach>; compounds of @Ref{bì} and
  @Ref{beir}, with {for}, super.
<fuirearadh>, a parching of corn; see @Ref{eararadh}.
<fuirich>, stay, Ir. @Ir{fuirighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{fuirigim}, noun {fuirech}, O.Ir.
  {fuirset} ({s} future): *{vo-reg}; root {reg}, stretch, go; Lat. {porrigo},
  {rego}.  See @Ref{rach}.
<fuirm>, stools, a form, Ir. @Ir{fuirm}, W. @W{ffurf}; from Eng. @Eng{form}.
<fùirneis>, @Ref<fòirneis>, a furnace, Ir. @Ir{furnéis}; from the Eng.
<fuithein>, @Ref<fuifein>, a galling, taking off the skin by riding (M`D.):
  {fo-bian}?
<fulaing> (vb.), @Ref<fulang> (n.); see @Ref{fuilig}.

<fulaisg>, rock; from @Ref{fo}+@Ref{luaisg}, q.v.

<fulmair>, a species of petrel, fulmar; from Sc., Eng. @Eng{fulmar}.

<funntainn>, benumbment by cold; see @Ref{punntuinn}.  Sc. {fundy}.
<furadh>, parching corn (Carm.), also {furaradh}.  See @Ref{fuirearadh}.
<furail>, incitement, command, Ir. @Ir{furáil}, E.Ir. @EIr{uráil}, {furáil}, O.Ir.
  {iráil}; the same as @Ref{earail}, q.v.
<furan>, a welcome, Ir. @Ir{furán}, {foran} (Connaught); root {ver}, as in
  E.Ir. @EIr{feraim fáilti}, I welcome.  The root means in E.Ir.
  "give rain" (see @Ref{fearthuinn}).  The root of @Ref{fhuair} seems
  mixed with that of @Ref{fearthuinn}.  See @Ref{fearthuinn}.
<furas>, patience: *{f-air-asta}, {asta} (standing, staying) being for
  {ad-sta-}, @Ref{ad} and {sta}, stand.
<furasda> (@Ref<furas>), easy, easier, Ir. @Ir{furas}, {furasda}, E.Ir. @EIr{urusa}:
  *{air-usa}, from @Ref{usa}, easier, q.v.
<furbaidh>, wrath (Sh., O'R.), @Ref<furban> (H.S.D., from MSS); see
  @Ref{fuirbidh}.
<furbhailt>, @Ref<furailt>, courtesy, kindly reception; also @Ref<furmailt>.
  For the latter Armstrong gives "ceremony" as force, which
  may be from Eng. @Eng{formality}.  The words, otherwise, seem
  from {for-fàilte}.

<gal.1>, weeping, Ir. @Ir{gul}, E.Ir. @EIr{gol}, I.E. {ℊel}, pain; Ger. {qual}, pain,
  {quälen}, torment; Lit {gélti}, to smart.  Cf. @Ref{galar}.
†<gal.2>, valour, war, E.Ir. @EIr{gal}, O.Br. @OBr{gal}, puissance, *{galâ}, W. @W{gallu},
  posse, Br. @Br{galloet} (do.), Corn. @Corn{gallos}, might: *{galno-}; Lit.
  {galiu}, I can, Ch.Sl. {golemŭ}, great.  Hence the national name
  {Galatae}, Galatian, also {gallus}, a Gaul (but see @Ref{Gall}).
<galad>, good girl, brave girl, fem. for {laochan}, used in encouraging
  address: @Ref<a ghalad>.  Root is {gal} (*{galnat}), brave.
<galan>, a gallon, Ir. @Ir{galun}; from the Eng.
<galar>, a disease, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{galar}, W. @W{galar}, grief, Br. @Br{glar}, {glachar},
  (do.); *{galro-n}.  Bez. suggests as allied Norse {galli}, flaw,
  Umbr. {holtu}, Ch.Sl. {zŭlŭ}, bad, sore.  But cf. @Ref{gal.1}, weep.
<galc>, thicken cloth, fulling; from the Eng. @Eng{walk}, {waulk}.
<Gall>, a Lowlander, stranger, Ir. @Ir{Gall}, a stranger, Englishman,
  E.Ir. @EIr{gall}, foreigner; from {Gallus}, a Gaul, the Gauls being
  the first strangers to visit or be visited by the Irish in Pre-Roman
  and Roman times (Zimmer).  for derivation see @Ref{gal.2},
  valour.  Stokes takes a different view; he gives as basis for
  {gall}, stranger, *{gallo-s}, W. @W{gal}, enemy, foe: *{ghaslo-}? root
  {ghas}, Lat. {hos-tis}, Eng. @Eng{guest}.  Hence he derives {Gallus}, a
  Gaul, so named from some Celtic dialect.
<galla>, a bitch; cf. W. @W{gast}, a bitch.  G. is possibly for *{gas-liâ}.
  Pott has adduced Spanish {galgo}, greyhound, which, however,
  is founded on {canis Gallicus}.  See @Ref{gasradh} for root.
<gallan>, a branch, a youth (fig.): *{gas-lo-}, root {gas} of @Ref{gas}, q.v.
  Cf. W. @W{gelin}, a shoot.
<galluran>, wood angelica, so Ir.: {gal}+{flùran}.
<galuban>, a band put upon the dugs of mares to prevent the foal
  sucking (H.S.D., Dial.):
<gàmag>, a stride, Ir. @Ir{gámus}, proud gait or carriage: *{gang-mo-}(?);
  Sc. {gang}, Ger. {gang}, gait.  Cf. @Ref{gòmag}.

<gamhainn>, a year-old calf, a stirk, Ir. @Ir{gamhuin}, a calf, E.Ir.
  {gamuin}, pl.g. {gamna}, year-old calf; from {gam}, winter:
  "winter-old".  For root, see @Ref{geamhradh}.  Confirmed by the
  proverb: "Oidhche Shamhna, theirear gamhna ris na laoigh"
  - On Hallowe'en the calves are called stirks.  Similarly and
  from the same root are Norse {gymbr}, a year-old ewe lamb, Sc.
  {gimmer}, Gr. @Gr{χíμαρος}, a yearling goat (Dor.).  Hence
  @Ref<gamhnach>, farrow cow.

<gaoithean>, a fop, empty-headed fellow; from @Ref{gaoth}, wind.
<gaol>, love, Ir. @Ir{gaol}, kin, family, E.Ir. @EIr{gáel}, relationship: *{gailo-};
  Lit. {gailùs}, compassionate; Got. {gailjan}, gladden, Ger. {geil},
  wanton; Gr. @Gr{φíλος}, friendly.  Stokes and Strachan agree.
<gaorr>, fæces, ordure in the intestines, gore, Ir. @Ir{garr}, probably
  from Eng. @Eng{gore}, Ag.S. {gor}, dirt.  Hence @Ref<gaorran>, big belly,
  a glutton.  In Arg. pronounced with Northern {ao} sound; in
  North, pronounced with {ao} broad as in Arg.  Consider {skar}
  in sharn (Sc.); cf {gaoirnean} or {gaoirnean}.
<gaorsach>, a bawd, slut: "dirty wench"; from @Ref{gaorr} and the
  female termination {-sach}?  Cf. @Ref{siùrsach}.
<gaort>, @Ref<giort>, a saddle girth; from the Eng.
<gaoth>, wind, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{gaeth}, {goeth}, O.Ir. @OIr{gáith}: *{gaito-}, from
  root {gai}, I.E. {ghai}, {ghei}, {ghi}, drive, storm, as in G. @Ref{geamhradh},
  q.v.  Eng. @Eng{ghost} (I.E. {ghoizdo-s}) is allied.  Stokes
  refers it to the root of @Ref{gath} solely, which is {ghai} as above.
<gar.1>, warm, Ir. @Ir{goraim}, O.Ir. @OIr{gorim}, Br. @Br{gor}, burning, W. @W{gwrês},
  heat: *{gorô}, I warm; Gr. @Gr{θερος}, summer heat, @Gr{θερμός}, warm,
  Eng. @Eng{thermo-}meter; Lat. {furnus}, oven, furnace; Ch.Sl.
--page 189
  {gorêti}, burn; further Eng. @Eng{warm} (I.E. *{ℊh^uormo-}, Teut.
  {gwarm}.
<gar.2>, @Ref<gair.1>, @Ref<gaire>, near proximity, Ir. @Ir{gar}, near (adj. and adv.),
  M.Ir. @MIr{gar}, shortly, W. @W{ger}, {gar}, near.  See @Ref{goirid} for root.
<gar.3>, although (Dial.): *{ga-ro}.  For {ga}, see @Ref{ge.2}; @Ref{ro} is the verbal
  particle.
<gar.4>, cry, variant of @Ref{goir}. See @Ref{goir}, @Ref{gàrlach} and @Ref{garrag.2}.

<gàradh>, @Ref<gàrradh>, a garden, Ir. @Ir{gardhadh}, M.Ir. @MIr{garrda}; from the
  Norse {garðr}, a yard, M.Eng. {gard}, {garþ}, Eng. @Eng{yard}, {garden}.
<garadh>, @Ref<garaidh>, a den, copse, @Ref<garan>, thicket, Ir. @Ir{garán}, underwood,
  thicket, {garrán}, grove, root {gar}, bristle, be rough, I.E.
  {gher}, stand stiff, tear, scratch; Gr. @Gr{χάραξ}, a stake, @Gr{χαράδρα},
  ravine; Lat. {hir-sutus}, hirsute, {hēr}, hedge-hog, {furca}, a fork;
  Lit. {żeriù}, scrape, etc.  See @Ref{garbh}.
<garbh>, rough, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{garb}, W. @W{garw}, Br. @Br{garu}, hard, cruel:
  *{garvo-}; I.E. {gher}, scratchy, rough, tearing; Gr. @Gr{χήρ}, hedgehog,
  Lat. {hēr} (do.), hirsutus, hirsute, Skr. {gárshati}, be stiff.
  See @Ref{garadh} further.  Some join it with Lat. {gravis}, but as
  this is allied to Gr. @Gr{βαρύς}, heavy, the G. would rather be
  {barbh}.  Lat. {horreo}?
<garbhag>, sprat, garvie (Dial.); from the Sc. {garvie}.  In Arran,
  @Ref<garbhanach>, is the sea-bream, but this is from G. @Ref{garbh}.

<gàrcan>, a hen's complaint; onomatopoetic.  See @Ref{gràchdan}.

<gearran>, a gelding, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{gearrán}; from @Ref{geàrr.1}, cut.
<Gearran>, the 4 weeks dating from 15th March onwards (H.S.D.).
  This forms a part of the animal nomenclature given to the
  several periods of Spring-time: first the @Ref<Faoilleach>, explained
  as "Wolf-month"; then the @Ref<Feadag>, or Plover, a week's
  length; then the <Gearran>, or Gelding, variously estimated
  as to length and time; then came the @Ref<Cailleach>, or Old
  Woman, a week's time; then perhaps the three days of the
  @Ref<Oisgean>, or ewes.  See Nich. pp 412-414.
<geas>, spell, taboo, charm, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{geis}, taboo, {gessim} (vb.):
  *{gessô}, *{ged-to}, root {ged} of @Ref{guidhe}, q.v.

<geilt>, terror, fear, Ir. @Ir{geilt}, a distracted person, wild, M.Ir.
  {geltacht}, flying, E.Ir. @EIr{geilt}, mad by fear; Norse {verða at
  gjalti}, to turn mad with terror (borrowed from Celtic, Stokes,
  Thurneysen; borrowed into Celtic, Zimmer).  Stokes refers
  it to a root {ghel}, fly, suggested by Gr. @Gr{χελιδών}, a swallow.

<gith>, a shower, series (H.S.D.); cf. E.Ir. @EIr{gith}, way of motion,
  Skr. {hi}, set in motion, impel, {hiti}, impelling.
<githeilis>, running to and fro on trifling errands, trifling, E.Ir.
  @Ref{gith}, way, motion.  See @Ref{gith}.
<githir>, @Ref<gìr>, corn-reapers' wrist pain:
<giùd>, a wile:
<giugas>, refuse of fish left on shore:
<giùig>, a drooping of the head, languor:
<giùlan>, a carrying: *{gesu-lo-}, root {qes}, carry, Lat. {gero}, {gestum}.
<giulla>, @Ref<giullan>, a lad, boy, Ir. @Ir{giolla}, servant, footman.  From
  the same source as @Ref{gille}.
<giullaich>, prepare, manage well; from @Ref{giulla}, the idea being
  "serving"; cf. Ir. @Ir{giolla} above, and Ir. @Ir{giollas}, service.
<giùmsgal>, flattery:
<giùram>, complaining, mournful noise (H.S.D.); cf. I.E. {gevo-}, cry,
  as in @Ref{guth}, q.v.
<giùran.1>, gills of a fish, @Ref<garbhan>: *{gober-}, root of @Ref{gob}?
<giùran.2>, barnacle goose; see @Ref{giodhran}.
<giuthas>, fir, Ir. @Ir{giumhas}, E.Ir. @EIr{gius}: *{gis-usto}, root {gis}; Ger.
  {gien}, resinous wood, {kien-baum}, Scotch fir, {kiefer} ({kien-föhre}),
  pine, Ag.S. {cén}, fir-wood, *{ki-n} (Schräder).  Cf. root {gis} of
  {gaison}, O.Ir. @OIr{gae}.  Ag.S. {gyr}, abies.
<glac>, take, seize, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{glacaim}, {glaccad}, grasping, E.Ir.
  {glace}, hand, handful: *{glapko-}(?), Eng. clasp.  See @Ref{glas.1}.
<glag>, noise of anything falling, noise, horse-laugh, Ir. @Ir{glagaire}, a
  babbler, {glagan}, mill clapper: *{glag-ko-}; Gr. @Gr{γλαζω} (*{glagjô}),
  sing, noise; Eng. @Eng{clack}, M.Eng. {clacke}, mill clack, Norse
  {klaka}, chatter bird-like; aslo Eng. @Eng{clap}.  There is a degree
  of onomato-poesy about these words.  Cf. @Ref{clag}.
<glàib>, dirty water, puddle, Ir. @Ir{gláib}; cf. {láib}.
<glaim>, complaint, howling, Ir. @Ir{gláim}, M.Ir. @MIr{gláimm}: *{glag-s-mâ-};
  Ger. {klagen}, weep (Strachan, Stokes).

<glain>, see {glainne}.

<glainne>, @Ref<glaine>, a glass, Ir. @Ir{gloine}, E.Ir. @EIr{gloine}, @Ref{glaine}, W. @W{glain},
  a gem, what is pur; from @Ref{glan}, clean.
<glaiseach>, foam (M`A.), @Ref<glais-sheile>, water-brash, from obs. {glais},
  stream, E.Ir. @EIr{glaiss}, same root as @Ref{glas.2}.
<glaisleun>, lesser spear-wort (Sh.), Ir. @Ir{glaisleun}; from @Ref{glas.2} and
  {leun} or @Ref{lèan}, a swamp (Cameron).
<glaistig>, water imp; from {glas}, water.  So Carm.  Manx {glashtyn},
  kelpie, etc.
<glàm>, devour, Ir. @Ir{glámaim}, devour, gobble, {glámaire}, glutton:
  *{glad-s-mo-}; Ch.Sl. {gladu}, hunger.  Sc. {glam}.
<glamair>, a smith's vice; from the Norse {klömbr}, a smith's vice,
  Ger. {glemmem}, pinch, jam.
<glamhsa>, a snap as by a dog; for form, compare Ir. @Ir{glamhsan}, a
  murmur, which is an aspirated form of @Ref{glaim}, howling.  The
  G. is similarly from @Ref{glàm}, devour, with possibly a leaning on
  the idea of noise as in @Ref{glaim}.  H.S.D. has @Ref<glamhus>, open
  chops.  @Ref<glomhas>, open chasm (Wh.).
<glan>, clean, pure, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{glan}, W. @W{glain}, Br. @Br{glan}, Gaul. river
  name {Glana}: *{glano-s}, root {glê}, {gel}, {gla}, shine; Gr. @Gr{γλήνεα},
  shows, @Gr{γλήνη}, eyeball, @Gr{γελεῖν}, shine (Hes.), and @Gr{γλαινοí}, bright
  ornamentation (Hes.), from root {glai}, from which Eng. @Eng{clean}
  comes (thus: {glê}, {gla}: {glêi}, {glai}).
<glang>, a ringing noise; see @Ref{gliong}.
<glaodh.1>, a cry, call, Ir. @Ir{glaodh}, M.Ir. @MIr{gloed}, a shout; cf. O.Ir.
  {adgládur}, appello, Skr. {hrā́date}, sound, Gr. @Gr{γλῶσσα}, tongue
  (*@Gr{γλωθια}?), Ir. and G. would then be from an O.Ir. *{gláid},
  from *{glâdi-}.  Hence @Ref<glaodhar>, @Ref<glaoran>, a noise, prating.
  O.Ir. @OIr{gloidim}, ringo.
<glaodh.2>, glue, Ir. @Ir{glaodh}, M.Ir. @MIr{glóed}, E.Ir. @EIr{gláed}; *{gloi-do-}, from
  I.E. {gloi}, {glei}, be sticky; Gr. @Gr{γλοιά}, @Gr{γλíα}, @Gr{γλíνη}, glue: Lat.
  {gluten}; Ch.Sl. {glénu}, mucus; Eng. @Eng{clay}, Ger. {klei}, slime.
  W. @W{glud} and M.Br. @MBr{glut} are from the Lat.
<glaodhan>, pith of wood; from @Ref{glaodh.2} the idea being "resinous or
  gluey stuff".
<glaomar>, a foolish person (Dial.): "noisy one"; from @Ref{glaodh.1}.
<glaoran>, blossom of wood-sorrel: *{gloiro-}, "bright", root {glei} of
  @Ref{glé}?
<glas.1>, a lock, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{glas}: *{glapsâ}; Eng. @Eng{clasp}.
<glas.2>, grey, Ir. @Ir{glas}, green, pale, E.Ir. @EIr{glass}, W., O.W., Br. @Br{glas},
  green: *{glasto-}, green; Ger. {glast}, sheen (Bez.), root {glas}, to
  which Ger. {glass}, Eng. @Eng{glass}, are probably allied.
<glé>, very, Ir. @Ir{glé}, very, pure, O.Ir. @OIr{glé}, bright, W. @W{gloew}, bright,
  O.W. @OW{gloiu}, liquidum: *{gleivo-}, I.E. {ℊhlei-}, shine; Eng.
  {gleam}, {glimmer}, Ger. {glimmen}; Gr. @Gr{χλíω}, @Gr{χλιαρός}, warm
  (Kluge).  Bez. refers it to the root of Eng. @Eng{clean} (see @Ref{glan}).

<gleac>, a wrestle, fight, Ir. E.Ir. @EIr{gleic}: *{glekki-}, *{gleg-ko-}, I.E.

<gleadhraich>, @Ref<gleadhair>, noise, rattling, clang of arms, Ir. @Ir{gleaghrach},

  {glechrach} means "noisy", the stem is {glegar}, which also
  appears ({Mart. Gorman}, edited by Stokes).
<gleann>, a glen, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{glenn}, {glend}, W. @W{glan}, brink, shore,

<gleus>, order, trim, tune, Ir. @Ir{gleus}, E.Ir. @EIr{glés}; for root, see @Ref{glèidh}
  and @Ref{glé}.  Strachan adduces E.Ir. @EIr{glése}, brightness, and takes

  Cf. W. @W{glwys}, fair, pleasant.  Hence @Ref<gleusda>, diligent.

<gluc>, socket of the eye:
<glug>, noise of liquid in a vessel when moved, Ir. @Ir{glug} (do.), {glugal},
  clucking of a hen; Eng. @Eng{cluck}.  All are onomatopoetic.  See
  @Ref{gloc.1}.  Also @Ref<glugach>, stammering: "clucking".  Cf. Sc.
  {glugger}, to make a noise in the throat by swallowing any
  liquid. See @Ref{gloc.2}.
<gluig>, addled (of an egg); from the above word.  Cf. W. @W{clwc},
  soft, addled (of an egg).
<glumadh>, a great mouthful of liquid, @Ref<glumag>, a deep pool; allied
  to @Ref{glug} above.
<glumraidh>, hungriness, devouring (as sea waves) (Hend.):
<glùn>, the knee, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{glún}, W., Br. @Br{glin}: *{glûnos}.  Stokes
  compares Albanian {ǵu} ({ǵuri}, {ǵuni}), knee.  Possibly by dissimilation
  of the liquids for *{gnûnos}, from *{gnû}, *{gneu},
  allied to Eng. @Eng{knee}, Gr. @Gr{γνύξ}, on the knee.
<glupad>, dropsy in throat of cattle and sheep (Carm.):

<gnàth>, custom, usual, Ir. @Ir{gnáth}, O.Ir. @OIr{gnáth}, solitus, W. @W{gnawd},

<gnè>, nature, kind, Ir. @Ir{gné}, O.Ir. @OIr{gné}, gen. {gnée}, pl. {gnéthi} (neuter

<gnìomh>, a deed, Ir. @Ir{gníomh}, O.Ir. @OIr{gním}: *{gnêmu-}; root {gnê}, do,
  from {gen}, beget, as in @Ref{gin}.  Hence @Ref<dèan>, @Ref<nì.2>, @Ref<rinn.2>.

<gnoin>, shake and scold a person (M`A.):
<gnomh>, grunt of a pig (M`A.), for {gromh}, Ir. @Ir{grossachd}: an
  onomatopoetic word, allied to Lat. {grunnire}, grunt, Gr. @Gr{γρῦ},
  swine's grunt, Eng. @Eng{grunt}, {grumph}.  See @Ref{gnòsd}.
<gnòmhan>, groaning (of an animal), grunting; a long-vowel form
  of @Ref{gnomh}?
<gnos>, a snout (especially of a pig), Ir. @Ir{gros}, {grossach}, having a
  large snout: *{grupso-}; Gr. @Gr{γρύψ}, a griffin, "hook-nosed",
  @Gr{γρυπός}, bent, Ger. {krumm}.

<gnòsd>, @Ref<gnòsad>, @Ref<gnùsd>, low noise of a cow, Ir. @Ir{gnúsachd}; *{grum-so};
  see @Ref{gnomh}, grunt, and @Ref{gnòmhan}.  Aran Ir. @Ir{gnosacht}, grunt
  of pig.
<gnothach>, business, Ir. @Ir{gnòthuig} (pron. {gnathuigh}), {gnó} (pl.
  {gnóthaidhe}): *{gnavo-}, active, Lat. {gnavus}, active, Eng. @Eng{know}.
  See @Ref{gnìomh} and @Ref{gnàth}, for root.
<gnù>, @Ref<gnò>, surly, parsimonious, @Ref<gnùgach>, surly.  See @Ref{gnò} and @Ref{grùig}.
<gnùis>, the face, countenance, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{gnúis}, (fem. @Ref{i}-declension;
  *{gnûsti-}; root {gen}, know, Eng. @Eng{know}, etc.
<gnùth>, a frowning look; see @Ref{gnù}.
<gò>, a lie, fault, Ir. @Ir{gó}, lie, fraud, O.Ir. @OIr{gó}, {gáo}, {gáu}, W. @W{gau}, Br.
  {gau}, {gaou}: *{gavo-}.  Cf. Gr. @Gr{γαυσός}, crooked, @Gr{γαυσάδας}, a liar
  (Ernault).  Bezzenberger gives several alternatives; Lit.
  {pri-gáuti}, deceive, or Persian {zûr}, false, or Gr. @Gr{χαῦνος}, spongy,
  @Gr{χάος}, abyss.
<gob>, a beak, bill, Ir. @Ir{gob}, bill, mouth, E.Ir. @EIr{gop-chóel}, lean-jawed;
  *{gobbo}, root {gobh}, {gebh}; Gr. @Gr{γαμφηλαí}, @Gr{γαμφαí}, jaws; Ch.Sl.
  {ząbu}, tooth, {zobati}, eat; Skr. {jambhas}, a tooth.  Stokes
  compares it (*{gobh-nó-}) to Zend. {zafan}, mouth.  The relationship
  to Eng. @Eng{gobbet}, {gobble}, Fr. {gobet}, O.Fr. {gober}, devour, is
  not clear.  But cf. also Eng. @Eng{gab}, {gabble}, G. @Ref{gab}.
<gobha>, @Ref<gobhainn>, a smith, Ir. @Ir{gobha}, g. {gobhann}, O.Ir. @OIr{goba}, g.
  {gobann}, O.W. @OW{gob}, W. @W{gof}, pl. {gofion}, Corn. @Corn{gof}, Br. @Br{go}, Gaul.
  {Gobann-}: *{gobân}; root {gobh}, as in Gr. @Gr{γόμφος}, a bolt, Eng.
  {comb} (Windisch), for which see @Ref{gob}.  Lat. {faber} may, however,
  be allied, and the root then be {ghob}.  {gobha-uisge}, water
  ousel; aslo {gobha-dubh}.
<gobhal>, a fork, Ir. @Ir{gabhal}, fork, gable, O.Ir. @OIr{gabul}, W. @W{gafl}, Br.
  @Br{gaol}: *{gabulu-}; Eng. @Eng{gable}, Ger. {gabel}, fork; Gr. @Gr{κεφαλή},
  head.
<gobhar>, a goat, Ir. @Ir{gabhar}, O.Ir. @OIr{gabor}, W. @W{gafr}, Corn. @Corn{gauar}, Br.
  @Br{gabr}, @Br{gaffr}, Gaul. @Gaul{gabro-}: *{gabro-}; root {gab} of @Ref{gabh}, take, as
  Lat. {caper} is allied to {capio}, take (Loth)?  Stokes gives the
  stem as *{gam-ro}, root {gam} of @Ref{geamhradh}, winter, and
  {gamhuinn}, I.E. {ghim}; but {im} of {ghim} could not change to
  Gaul. @Ref{ab} in {gabro-}.
<goc>, a tap, cock; from the Eng. @Eng{cock}.
<gocaman>, an usher, attendant, sentinel, or look-out man; Martin's
  ({Western Isles}, p.103) {gockmin}, {cockman}; from Scandinavian
  {gok-man}, look-out man (Arms.; Mackinnon says it is Danish).
  For root, cf. Ger. {gucken}, peep.  Norse {gauksman}; {gauk maðr},
  cuckoo man.  Norse {gaukr}, cuckoo; Sc. {gawk}.
<gòdach>, giddy, coquettish (Sh., etc.); cf. @Ref{gabhd}.  {godadh nan ceann},
   tossing of one's head (Wh.).
--page 201
<godsag>, a titbit:
<gog>, a nod, tossing of the head, Ir. @Ir{gog}; from Eng. @Eng{cock}.  @Ref<godadh>
  (Arg.).
<gogaid>, a giddy female, Ir. @Ir{gogaide}; from Eng., Fr. {coquette}.
<gogail>, cackling, noise of liquor issuing from a cask, Ir. @Ir{gogallach};
  Eng. @Eng{cackle}.  The words are onomatopoetic.  Also @Ref<goglais>.
<gogan>, a wooden milk-pail, also @Ref<cogan>; from Sc. {cogue}, {cog},
  apparently allied to M.Eng. {cog}, ship, Norse {kuggi}, a small
  ship, Teutonic {kuggon-}, ship.
<goic>, a tossing of the head in disdain, a scoff, Ir. @Ir{goic}; founded on
  the Eng. @Eng{cock}, like @Ref{gog}, q.v.
<goid>, steal, Ir. @Ir{goidim}, E.Ir. @EIr{gataim}: *{gad-dô}, root {gad}, {ℊhad},
  {ℊhed}, seize; Gr. @Gr{χανδάνω}, @Gr{ἒχαδον}, hold, contain; Lat. {prehendo},
  seize; {praeda}, booty, {hedra}, ivy; Eng. @Eng{get}.  Thur. has
  compared the Lat. {hasta}, spear, giving a stem *{ghazdho-}.
<goigean>, a bit of fat meat, cluster, thread tangle or kink; cf.
  @Ref{gagan}: *{gaggo-}; cf. Gr. @Gr{γαγγλíον}, ganglion, a "knot", Eng.
  {kink}.
<goil>, boil, Ir. @Ir{gailim}, seethe, boil: *{gali-}; I.E. {ℊel}, well, Ger.
  {quellen}, gush.  See @Ref{goile}.
<goile>, a stomach, appetite, Ir. @Ir{goile}, @Ref{gaile}, stomach, appetite,
  throat, M.Ir. @MIr{gaile}; also O.Ir. @OIr{gelim}, I consume; Lat. {gula},
  throat (Eng. {gullet}), {glutire}, swallow (Eng. {glutton}); Skr.
  {gilati}, swallow; I.E. {ℊel}, allied to root of @Ref{goil}.
<gòileag>, a haycock, cole; from the Sc. {gole}, Eng. @Eng{coll}.
<goileam.1>, tattle, chattering, also @Ref<gothlam> ({l}=@Ref{le}); see @Ref{gothlam}.
<goileam.2>, fire (kindling) (Carm.):
<goill>, distorted face, angry face, grin, blubber lipl cf. Ir. @Ir{gailleóg},
  a blow on the cheek, G. @Ref{gailleag}.  Cf. for root Gr. @Gr{χεῖλος}, lip,
  *@Gr{χεσλος} = Skr. {ghas}, eat, swallow.
<goillir>, a Lewis bird of the size of the swallow, which comes to
  land in winter (Arms.):
<goimh>, anguish, pain, Ir. @Ir{goimh}: *{gomi-}, root {gom}, {gem}, press,
  Lat. {gemo}, groan, Ch.Sl. {żimą}, compress.
<goin>, @Ref<gointe>; see @Ref{gon}.
<goir>, call, cry, crow, Ir. @Ir{goirim}, E.Ir. @EIr{gairim}, O.Ir. @OIr{adgaur},
  convenio: *{garô}, speak, I.E. {ℊer}, cry; Gr. @Gr{γέρανος}, crane,
  @Gr{δειριᾶν}, abuse; Skr. {járate}, cry, crackle; further Lat. {garrio},
  chatter (*{gars-}); Eng. @Eng{garrulous}, Lit. {garsas}, noise; also root
  {gâr}, as in Gaelic @Ref{gàir.1}, Gr. @Gr{γῆρυς}, voice, etc.
<goireas>, convenience, apparatus; from @Ref{gar.2}, near, and @Ref{goirid}.
<goirid>, short, Ir. @Ir{gairid}, O.Ir. @OIr{garit}.  For root, see @Ref{geàrr.1} (Skr.
  {hrasva}, short, etc.), from which comes the comparative @Ref<giorra>.
  Also @Ref{gar.2}, near, q.v.
--page 202
<goirt>, sore, sour, Ir. @Ir{goirt}, sore, salt, E.Ir. @EIr{goirt}, bitter: *{gorti-},
  I.E. {gher}, be rough, as in @Ref{garbh}.

  *{gorto-}; Lat. {hortus}; Gr. @Gr{χόρτος}, straw-yard; Eng. @Eng{garden},
  {garth}, etc.
<goisean>, pl. of @Ref{goisear}.
<goisear> (pl. @Ref<goisean>), guisers, waits, singers about Christmas, etc.
  (Carm.):

<gread>, wound, whip, burn, Ir. @Ir{greadaim}; cf. W. @W{greidio}, scorch:

<greadan.1>, a considerable time with all one's might at anything

  means "griddle".  Eng. @Eng{griddle}, W. @W{greidell}, are allied.  Cf.

<grealach>, @Ref<greallach>, entrails: *{gre-lach}, root {gṛ}, I.E. {ghṛ}, gut;

  {hernia}, rupture.  Shaw has {greathlach}.  Hence
  @Ref<greallach>, dirty, Ir. @Ir{greallach}, clay, dirty.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{gore}.
<greallag>, a swingle-tree:
<greann>, hair, bristling of hair, surly look, also "cloth", "rough
  piled clothing", Ir. @Ir{greann}, beard, hair hair, E.Ir. @EIr{grend},
  beard, W., Br. @Br{grann}, eyelid, cilium: *{grendâ}; Ger. {granne},
  beard of corn or cat, Norse {grön}, moustache, Sp. {greña},
  tangled hair, Prov.Fr. {gren}, O.Fr. {grenon}, beard of cheek and
  lip; Albanian {krąnde}.  @Ref<greanndag>, rag, tatter.  Hence
  @Ref<greannar>.
<greas>, hasten, urge, Ir. @Ir{greasuighim}, M.Ir. @MIr{gressim}: *{gred-to-};
  I.E. {ℊhredh}, step out, go; Lat. {gradior}, {gradus}, step; Got.
  {grids}, a step; Ch.Sl. {grędą}, stride, come; Skr. {gṛdhyati}, step
  out.  The E.Ir. @EIr{grísaim}, I incite, is a different word, coming
  from {grís}, fire.
<greidil>, a gridiron, Ir. @Ir{greidil}, {greideal}, M.Ir. @MIr{in t-slissin gretli},
  Sean. Mor. {gretel}, W. @W{greidel}, {gradell}, O.W. @OW{gratell}; from
  Late Lat. {graticula}, from {cratis}, wicker-work, Eng. @Eng{crate},
  {grate}, {grill}, {hurdle}.  Eng. @Eng{griddle}, M.Eng. {gredel}, are the
  same as the Celtic words.  Skeat has suggested @Ref{gread} above
  as the orogin of the Celtic forms; cf. Ir. @Ir{greadóg}, a griddle.
  Hence @Ref<greidlean>, an instrument for turning the bannocks on
  the griddle.
<gréidh>, prepare, dress, Ir. @Ir{gréasaim}; see @Ref{gréis}.  {gréidhear}, {gré'ar},
  grieve (N.Gael.).
<greigh>, a stud of horses, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{groigh}, E.Ir. @EIr{graig}, W. @W{gre}:
  *{gragi-}; Lat. {grex}, flock; Gr. @Gr{γαργαρα}, heaps; O.H.G.
  {quarter}, herd.
<greim>, a hold, a morsel, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{greim}, {greimm}, a hold,
  strength, W. @W{grym}, force, strength: *{gredsmen-}; root {gher},
  hold, Gr. @Gr{χέιρ}, hand, Skr. {gáras}, grip.  Stokes separates
  {greim}, morsel, from {greim}, hold, strength.  {greim}, morsel, he
  refers to *{gresmen}, a bite, Skr. {grásati}, devour, Gr. @Gr{γράω},
  eat, Norse {krás}, a dainty.
<greis.1>, prowess, onset, slaughter, a champion, E.Ir. @EIr{gress}, {gréss},
  attack; from the root of @Ref{greas} above (Stokes).
<greis.2>, a shile, Ir. @Ir{do ghréas}, always, O.Ir. @OIr{do grés}, do {gress},
  semper, M.Ir. @MIr{do-gres}: *{grend-to-}, going on, root {grend}, {gred},
  I.E. {ghredh} as in @Ref{greas}.  Strachan gives *{grencs-}, and compares
  Norse {kringr}, round, Ger. {kring}.  See @Ref<treis>.
<gréis>, @Ref<greus>, embroidery, needle-work, Ir. @Ir{obair-ghréis}, from {gréas},
  E.Ir. @EIr{gréss}, any work of art or trade; see @Ref{greusaich}.

<grian>, sun, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{grían}: *{greinâ}, {ℊhr-einâ}, root {ℊher}, warm,
  as in @Ref{gar.1}.  Cf. Skr. {ghṛṇis}, sunshine, {ghramsa}, heat; W.

<grinneal>, bottom of the sea, gravel, Ir. @Ir{grinnioll}, channel, bed of
  a river, sand of the sea, sea bottom, M.Ir. @MIr{grinnell}: *{gris-ni-},
  root, {greis}, {gris}, gravel, E.Ir. @EIr{grían}, gravel (*{greisano-}), W.
  {graian}, gravel, {greienyn} a grain of gravel.  Rhys (Hib.Lect.,
  571) refers these words to the root of @Ref{grian}, sun, the particle of
  gravel being supposed to be "a shining thing".  This view is
  supported by @Ref<grioglachan> and @Ref<griogag>, q.v.

<grothlach>, a gravel pit, abounding in gravel (O'B., Sh., etc.), Ir.

<gruag>, hair of the head, a wig, Ir. @Ir{grúag}: *{grunkâ}, root {ℊru},

<gruaidh>, cheek, brow, Ir. @Ir{gruaidh}, cheek, E.Ir. @EIr{gruad}, W. @W{grudd},
  Corn. @Corn{grud}, maxilla: *{groudos}.  Bez. suggests the root {ghrud},
  {ghreud}, as in @Ref{grothlach}, above, the idea being "pounding,
  mashing" (Lit. {grústi}, bray, pound), and the original force
  "jaw": cf. Lat. {maxilla} and {macero}, macerate.  Stokes
  queries if it is from the root of Eng. @Eng{great}.  Eng. @Eng{proud}?

<grunnasg>, groundsel; formed on the Eng.

<gruth>, curds, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{gruth}: *{grutu-}; Eng. @Eng{curds}, M.Eng.

  Hence @Ref<gruitheam>, curds and butter: {gruth}+@Ref{ìm}.
<grùthan>, @Ref<grùan>, liver, Ir. @Ir{aeu. grúan} (Lh. {Comp.Voc.} sub "jecur"):
  *{grûso-}: root {ghru}, gritty, of @Ref{grothlach}.
<gu>, to, ad, Ir. @Ir{go}, {gu}, O.Ir. @OIr{co}, {cu}, W. @W{bw} in {bwy gilydd}, to its
  fellow: *{qos}; Ch.Sl. {kŭ}, to; cf. Lat. {usque} for *{quos-que}?
  (Bez.).  Used adverbially in {gu math}, {gu h-olc}.  Cf. Gr. @Gr{κας},
  @Gr{και}, Skr. {-ças}.
<guag.1>, a giddy, whimsical fellow, Ir. @Ir{gúag}, {guaigín}, folly, silly one;
  from M.Eng. {gowke}, {gōki}, a fool, Sc. {gowk}, Eng. @Eng{gawky}.

<guaigean>, thick, little and round: *{goug-go-}, root {ℊu}, bend.
<guailisg>, false, falsity (Carm.):
<guaillean>, a coal of fire; see @Ref{gual}.  Cf. @Ref{caoirean}, a peat, cinder,
  ember.
<guaillich>, go hand in hand: "shoulder to shoulder"; see @Ref{guala}.
<guaimeas>, quietness; see @Ref{guamach}.

  I.E. {ℊu}, bend, as in @Ref{guala}.

†<guais>, danger, @Ref<guaiseach>, dangerous, Ir. @Ir{guais}, O.Ir. @OIr{gúassacht}

  {quit}? {g-uait}?
<gual>, coal, Ir. @Ir{gual}: *{goulo-}, *{geulo-}; root {geul}, {gul}; Teutonic
  *{kola-}, Norse {kol}, coals, Ger. {kohle}, Eng. @Eng{coal}.  W. @W{glo}, Br.
  {glaou}, *{glôvo-} (Stokes), is allied to the Eng. @Eng{glow}.
<guala>, @Ref<gualann>, shoulder, Ir. @Ir{guala}, g. @Ref{gualann}, E.Ir. @EIr{gualu}, g.
  *{gualand}: *{goulôn}, root {ℊeu}, {ℊu}, @Ref{gu}, bend; Gr. @Gr{γυῖον}, limb,
  @Gr{γύαλον}, a hollow, @Gr{γύης}, ploughtree (Lat. {bura}); Old Bactrian
  = Zend, {gāo}, hand.  Strachan and Stokes give the root {gub},
  bend, stem *{gublôn-}, I.E. {gheubh}, bend, Gr. @Gr{κυφός} ({u} long),
  bent, stooping; Lettic {gubt}, stoop.
<guamach>, neat, snug, smirking; also "plentiful" (Sh., O'R.),

<gun>, without, Ir. @Ir{gan}, O.Ir. @OIr{cen}; Gr. @Gr{κενεός}, empty; root {keno-}.

<gu'n>, @Ref<gu'm>, that, Gr. @Gr{ὅτι}, Ir. @Ir{go}, O.Ir. @OIr{co}, {con}.  Windisch considers
  this the prep. {con}, with, and {co}, to; Zim. and Thur.
  regard it as from {co}, to (see @Ref{gu}).  The latter explains the {n}
  as the relative: *{co-sn}, a view supported by the verbal
  accent being on the first syllable and by the occasional form
  @Ref{conn}(?)  See @Ref{cha'n}.
<gùn>, gown, Ir. @Ir{gúna}; from the Eng. @Eng{gown}, from W. @W{gwn} (*{gwun}),
  from Celtic *{vo-ouno-}, root in Lat. {ex-uo}, doff, {ind-uo}, don,
  Lit. {aunù}, put on shoes, {áuti}.
<gunna>, a gun, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{gunna}; from M.Eng. {gunne}, Eng. @Eng{gun}.
<gur>, that, Ir. @Ir{gur}: *{co-ro}; see @Ref{gu'n} for {co}.  Uses are: {Gur
  cruaidh e} = O.Ir. @OIr{corrop cruaid é}; {corrop} is now Ir. @Ir{gurab},
  that is {co-ro-ba} ({ba}, verb "to be").  {gur} = {gun ro}, {con ro-}
  (St.).

<iad>, they, Ir. @Ir{iad}, E.Ir. @EIr{iat}, O.Ir. only in {olseat-som}, say they, W.
  {hwynt}: confusion of roots {ei} {sjo} with the 3rd plur. in {nt}.  Of
  E.Ir. @EIr{iat}, {siat}, Brugmann says:- "These have the ending of
  the 3rd plur. of the verb; later on {iat}, {siat} were detached,
  and began an independent existence".  Stokes similarly says
  they are {se} and {hwy} with the {nt} of the verbal 3rd pl. added.
<iadach>, jealousy, Ir. @Ir{éad}; see @Ref{eud}.
<iadh>, encompass, Ir. @Ir{iadhaim}, join, shut, surround, E.Ir. @EIr{iadaim}:
  *{eidâô}, *{ei-dho-}, root {ei}, go?  Stokes analyses it into *{ei-}
  {dâmô}, for {epi-dâmô}, Skr. {api-dā́nā}, a lock: for {epi}, see Gr.
  @Gr{ἐπí} under @Ref{iar.1}; and {dâmô} is from {dhô}, {dhê}, place, Gr. @Gr{τíθημι},
  Lat. {facio}.  It has also been correlated to Gr. @Gr{πιέζομαι}, press,
  Skr. {pîdayti}, press (*{pisdā}), from {pise}, stamp, press, Lat.
  {pistor}, etc.

<in->, @Ref<ion->, @Ref<ionn->, a prefix of like force as Lat. {in-}, used especially
  before medials, liquids, and {s} (@Ref{ionn-} only before {s}), Ir. @Ir{in-}, @Ref{ion-},

<innear>, dung, M.Ir. @MIr{indebar}: *{ind-ebar}; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{cann-ebor}
  (= @Ref{cac}, O'Cl.), on the analogy of which Stokes suggests that
--page 214
  {ind-} of {indebar} is for {find}, white, but G. is against this.
  O'Dav. has {find-ebor}, dung; so Meyer, but not O'Dav.!
<innil>, prepare, ready; see @Ref{inneal}.
<innis.1>, an island, Ir. @Ir{inis}, O.Ir. @OIr{inis}, W. @W{ynys}, Corn. @Corn{enys}, Br. @Br{enez},
  pl. {inisi}: *{inissî}, from {ṇss}, Lat. *{inssa}, {insula}, Gr. @Gr{νῆσος}
  (Dor. @Dor{νᾶασος}).  The connection of the Celtic, Lat., and Gr.
  is almost certain, though the phonetics are not clear.
  Strachan suggests for Celtic *{eni-stî}, "in-standing", that is,
  "standing or being in the sea".
<innis.2>, tell, Ir. @Ir{innisim}, E.Ir. @EIr{innisim}, {indisim}: *{ind-fiss-}, from
  {fiss}, now @Ref{fios}, knowledge; root {vid}.  Cf. {adfíadim}, narro
  (*{veidô}), {infíadim}.  {vet} (St.)?
<innleachd>, device, mechanism, Ir. @Ir{inntleachd}, device, ingenuity:
  *{ind-slig-tu-}, root {slig} of @Ref{slighe}, way?  Ascoli joins O.Ir.
  {intle}, insidiæ, {intledaigim}, insidior, and W. @W{annel}, a gin, Corn.
  {antell}, ruse, Br. @Br{antell}, stretch a snare or bow, and Ir. @Ir{innil}, a
  gin, snare.  The O.Ir. @OIr{intliucht}, intellectus (with {sliucht},
  cognitio), is considered by Zimmer to be a grammatical word
  from Lat. {intellectus}.  Stokes disagrees.  Hence @Ref<innlich>, aim,
  desire.
<innlinn>, provender, forage: "preparation", from @Ref{innil}, prepare.
<innsgin>, mind, courage (H.S.D. form MSS.), also in A.M`D.'s
  song, "{Am breacan uallach}"; {innsgineach}, sprightly (Sh.,
  O'R.):
<inntìnn>, mind, Ir. @Ir{inntinn}: *{ind-seni-}; root {sen} or {senn}, as in
  Ger. @Ref{sinn}, sense?  Kluge, however, gives *{sentno-} as the
  earliest form of the Ger.  Possibly it may be a plural from
  O.Ir. @OIr{inne}, sensus, meaning the "senses" originally.  The
  Gadelic words can scarcely be from a depraved pronunciation
  of Lat. {ingenium}.
<inntreadh>, @Ref<inntreachduinn>, a beginning, entering; from Eng.
  {entering}.
<iob>, a raw cake, lump of dough (H.S.D. for N.H.); also @Ref<uibe>,
  q.v.
<ioba>, pl. @Ref<iobannan>, tricks, incantations (Arg.); see @Ref{ubag}.
<iobairt>, an offering, sacrifice, Ir. @Ir{íodhbuirt}, M.Ir. @MIr{édpart}, O.Ir.
  {edpart}, {idpart}: *{aith-od-bart-}, root {bert}, {ber} of @Ref{beir}, q.v.  Cf.
  W. @W{aberth} (= {ad-bert}), a sacrifice.
<ioblag>, a victimised or despised female, a trollop (Glenmoriston):
<ìoc>, pay, remedy, @Ref<iocshlaint>, a cure, salve, remedy, Ir. @Ir{íocaim},

  Gr. @Gr{ἄκος}, a cure; Skr. {yaças}, grandeur.  The long vowel of

  the Gadelic forms is puzzling, and these have been referred

  refresh.
<iochd>, clemency, humanity, Ir. @Ir{iochd}, clemency, confidence, M.Ir.

  {pek}, {pak}, Lat. {pectus}, breast, {paciscor}, paction; allied to @Ref{uchd}.
  For {iochd}, progeny, cf. Norse {átt}, family (Rhys).  See @Ref{aicme}.
<ìochdar>, the lower part, bottom, Ir. @Ir{íochdar}, O.Ir. @OIr{íchtar}.  It is
  formed from @Ref{ìos}, {ís}, down, on the analogy of @Ref{uachdar}.  See
  @Ref{ìos}.

<iodhlann>, a cornyard, Ir. @Ir{iothlann}, granary, O.Ir. @OIr{ithla}, g. {ithland},

†<ionnas>, condition, status, @Ref<ionnas gu>, insomuch that, so that,

†<ìos>, down, Ir. †@Ref<íos>, in phrases @Ref<a nìos>, from below, @Ref<sìos>, to below,
  so Ir.; O.Ir. @OIr{ís}, {íss}, infra, W. @W{is}, comp. {isel}, sup. {isaf}, Br. @Br{is},
  {iz}, {isel}, comp. {iseloch}: *{enso} or *{endso}, from {en}, now @Ref{an.2}, in;
  Lat. {īmus}, lowest, from *{ins-mus}, from {in}.  Stokes cfs. rather
  Skr. {adhás}, under (ṇdhas), Eng. @Eng{under}, giving the prehistoric
  form as *{insô}; and there is much in favour of this view for
  the meaning's sake, though most philologists are on the side
  of {en} or {end}, now {an}, being root.  Lat. {imus} or {infimus} would
  then follow the Celtic.

<is.1>, is, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{is}, O.Ir. @OIr{iss}, O.W. @OW{iss}, {is} = Gr. @Gr{ἐστì}; Lat. {est}, is;

<is.2>, and, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{is}; seemingly an idiomatic use of @Ref{is.1}, is.  Consider
  the idiom; "Nì e sin is mise an so" - "He will do it
  and I here"; literally: "He will do it, I am here".  It is
  usually regarded as a curtailment of @Ref{agus}, and hence spelt
  variously as @Ref<a's>, @Ref<'us>.
<isbean>, a sausage; from Norse {íspen}, a sausage of lard and suet
  (= {í-spen}, from {speni}, a teat).
<isean>, a chicken, young of any bird, Ir. @Ir{iséan}, E. Ir. @Ir{essíne}, O.Ir.
  {isseniu}, pullo: *{ex(p)et-nio-}?  Root {pet}, fly; that is, *{ex-én-},
  {én} being @Ref{eun}, bird,
<isneach>, a rifle gun; from @Ref{oisinn}, corner?  Meyer suggests from
  @Ref{isean}, young of birds, comparing "fowling-piece".
--page 220
<ist!> whist! Eng. @Eng{whist!} {hist!} Lat. {st!}  Onomatopoetic.
<ite>, a feather, Ir. @Ir{iteóg}, O.Ir. @OIr{ette}: *{ettiâ}, *{pet-tiâ}, root {pet}, fly;
  Gr. @Gr{πέτομαι}, I fly; Lat. {penna}, a wing (*{pet-na}), Eng. @Eng{pen};
  Eng. @Eng{feather}, Ger. {fittich}; etc.  See @Ref{eun}.  W. @W{aden}, wing, is
  near related.  @Ref<iteachan>, a spool, weaver's bobbin.
<iteodha>, hemlok.  Cameron (29) suggests a derivation from @Ref<ite>,
  the idea being "feather-foliaged".
<ith>, eat, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ithim}: *{itô}, *{pitô}, I eat; Ch.Sl. {pi@'tati}, feed:
  Skr. {pitu}, nourishment, Zend {pitu}, food; further Gr. @Gr{πíτυς},
  pine.  Also †<ith>, †@Ref<ioth>, corn, as in @Ref{iodhlann}, q.v.
<iubhar>, yew, Ir. @Ir{iubhar}, E.Ir. @EIr{ibar}, Gaul. @Ref<Eburos>; Ger. {eberesche},
  service-tree (*{ebarisc}).  So Schräder.  It does not seem that
  Ir. @Ir{eó}, W. @W{yw}, Br. @Br{ivin}, *{ivo-}, Eng. @Eng{yew}, can be allied to
  {iubhar}.  Hence @Ref<iubrach>, a yew wood, stately woman, the
  mythic boat of Fergus Mac Ro in the Deirdre story.
  {Eboracum}?
<iùc>, corner, slit.  See @Ref{niùc}.
<iuchair.1>, a key, Ir. @Ir{eochair}, E.Ir. @EIr{eochuir}, Manx {ogher}, W. @W{egoriad},
  key, {egor}, {agor}, opening: *{ekûri-}; root stem {pecu-}, fastening,
  whence Lat. {pecu}, cattle, Eng. @Eng{fee}.  Cf. W. @W{ebill}, key, auger.
<iuchair.2>, the roe, spawn, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{iuchair}: *{jekvuri}, Lat. {jecur},
  liver?
<iuchar>, the dog-days:
<iugh>, a particular posture in which the dead are placed:
<iùl>, guidance, Ir. @Ir{iul}; cf. @Ref{eòlas}.
<iullag>, a sprightly female, @Ref<iullagach>, sprightly:
<iùnais>, want, E.Ir. @EIr{inguáis}, O.Ir. @OIr{ingnais}, absence: *{in-gnáth},
  from {gnáth}, known, custom; see @Ref{gnàth}.  Aslo @Ref<aonais>.
<iunnrais>, stormy sky:
<iunntas>, wealth:
<iurpais>, fidgeting, wrestling; cf. @Ref{farpuis}.
†<iursach>, suspensory (Oss. Ballads), applied to the mail-coat.
  From @Ref{iris}.  H.S.D. gives the meaning as "black, dark".
<iuthaidh>, @Ref<fiuthaidh>, @Ref<iùthaidh>, arrow, gun, etc.:
<iutharn>, hell; for *{ifhern}, a side-form of @Ref{ifrinn}.
<là>, @Ref<latha>, day, Ir. @Ir{lá}, g. {laoi}, O.Ir. @OIr{lathe}, {laithe}, {lae}, g. {lathi}, d.
  {lau}, {lóu}, {ló}: *{lasio-}, root {las}, shine; Skr. {lásati}, shines; Gr.
  @Gr{λάω}, behold.
<làban>, <làban>, mire, dirt, Ir. @Ir{lábán}; also @Ref<làib>.  Cf. for root
  @Ref{làthach} (*{làth-bo-}).
<labanach>, a day-labourer, plebeian, Ir. @Ir{labánach} (O'B., etc.; Sh.);
  from Lat. {labor}?

<labhair>, speak, Ir. @Ir{labhraim}, E.Ir. @EIr{labraim}, O.Ir. @OIr{labrur}, {labrathar},
  loquitur, W. @W{llafar}, vocalis, {lleferydd}, voice, Corn. @Corn{lauar},
  sermo, Br. @Br{lavar}, Gaul. river {Labarus}: *{labro-}, speak; Gr.
  @Gr{λάβρος}, furious, @Gr{λάβρεύομαι}, talk rashly.  Bez. prefers the
  root of Eng. @Eng{flap}.  Others have compared Lat. {labrum}, lip,
  which may be allied to bothe Celtic and Gr. (@Gr{λαβρεύομαι}).
  Hence G. and Ir. @Ref<labhar>, loud, O.Ir. @OIr{labar}, eloquens, W.
  {llafar}, loud, Gr. @Gr{λάβρος}.
<la-bhallan>, water shrew (Suth.), @Ref<la-mhalan> (Forbes):
<lach.1>, a wild duck, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lacha}; cf. the Lit. root {lak}, fly.
<lach.2>, reckoning, contribution per head; from the Sc. {laugh}, tavern
<lachan>, a laugh; from the Sc., Eng. @Eng{laugh}.
<lachduinn>, dun, grey, tawny, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{lachtna}, grey, dun; cf.
  Skr. {rakta}, coloured, reddened, {rañj}, dye, whence Eng. @Eng{lake},
  crimson.
<làd>, @Ref<lòd>, a load, Ir. @Ir{lád}; from the M.Eng. {laden}, to lade.
<lad>, a mill lead; from the Eng. @Eng{lead}, {lade}.  For the N.H. meaning
  of "puddle", see @Ref<lod>.
<ladar>, a ladle; from the Eng. @Eng{ladle} by dissimilation of the liquids.
<ladarna>, bold, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{latrand}, robber, W. pl. {lladron},
  theives; from Lat. {latro}, {latronis}, a thief.
<ladhar>, a hoof, fork, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ladar}, toes, fork, branch:
  *{plaðro-n}, root {pla}, extend.
<lag.1>, a hollow, Ir. @Ir{log}, a pit, hollow: *{luggo-}, root {luℊ}, bend; Gr.
  @Gr{λυγíζω}, bend; Lit. {lugnas}, pliant.  Stokes gives the basis as
  *{lonko-}, root {lek}, {lenk}, bend, Lit. {lànkas}, a curve, {lanka}, a
  mead, Ch.Sl. {lakŭ}, bent; but this would give {à} in G.; Ger.
  {lücke}, gap, blank.
<lag.2>, weak, Ir. @Ir{lag}, E.Ir. @EIr{lac}, M.Ir. @MIr{luice} (pl.), W. @W{llag}, sluggish:
  *{laggo-s}, root {lag}; Lat. {langueo}, Eng. @Eng{languid}; Gr. @Gr{λαγγάζω},
  slacken, @Gr{λαγαρός}, thin; Eng. @Eng{slack}, also {lag}, from Celtic.  Cf.
  @Gr{λάκκος}.
<làgan>, sowens: *{latag-ko-}?  Root {lat}, be wet, Gr. @Gr{λαταξ}, drop,
  Lat. {latex}.  See @Ref{làthach}.
<lagh>, law, Ir. @Ir{lagh} (obsolete, says Con.); from the Eng.  The
  phrase @Ref<iar lagh>, set in readiness for shooting (as of a bow) is
  hence also.
<laghach>, pretty, Ir. @Ir{lághach}, {laghach} (Donegal); cf. M.Ir. @MIr{lig},
  beauty, root {leg}, Lat. {lectus}, chosen, Eng. @Eng{election}?  Cf. O.W.
  {lin}, gratia.  Kluge says Eng. @Eng{like}.
<làidir>, strong, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{láidir}:
<laigh>, @Ref<luigh>, lie, Ir. @Ir{luigh}, E.Ir. @EIr{laigim}, O.Ir. @OIr{lige}, bed, W. @W{gwe-ly},

  {legô}, to lie, *{legos}, bed, I.E. root {leℊh}, lie; Gr. @Gr{λεχος}, bed,

<laimhrig>, landing place, harbour: from N. {hlað-hamarr}, pier or

<laimhsich>, handle, Ir. @Ir{laimhsighim}: *{lám-ast-ico-}, from *{lamas},

<laipheid>, an instrument for making horn-spoons:

<lairceach>, stout, short-legged, fat, @Ref<lairceag>, a short, fat woman:
<làirig>, a moor, sloping hill, a pass; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{laarg}, fork, leg and
  thigh, O.Ir. @OIr{loarcc}, furca.  Often in place names:
<laisde>, easy, in good circumstances; cf. Ir. @Ir{laisti}, a heavy, stupid

<laisgeanta>, fiery, fierce; from @Ref{las.2}, q.v.
<laithilt>, a weighing as with scales, Ir. @Ir{laithe}, scales: *{platio-}, root
  {plat}, {plet}, as in @Ref{leathan}.
<lamban>, milk curdled by rennet (Dial.); see @Ref{slaman}.
<lamh>, able, dare, Ir. @Ir{lamhaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{lamaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{-laimur}, audeo,
  W. @W{llafasu}, audere, Corn. @Corn{lavasy}, Br. @Br{lafuaez}: *{plamô}, a short-vowel
  form of the root of @Ref{làmh}, hand, the idea being "manage
  to, dare to"?  Stokes says it is probably from *{tlam}, dare,
  Gr. @Gr{τόλμα}, daring, Sc. {thole}; see @Ref{tlàth}.  Windisch has compared
  Lit. {lemiù}, {lemti}, fix, appoint.
<làmh>, hand, Ir. @Ir{lámh}, O.Ir. @OIr{lám}, W. @W{llaw}, Corn. @Corn{lof}, O.Br. @OBr{lau};
  *{lâmâ}, *{plâmâ}; Lat. {palma}, Eng. @Eng{palm}; Gr. @Gr{παλάμη}; Ag.S.
  {folm}, O.H.G. {folma}.  Hence @Ref<làmhainn>, glove, E.Ir. @EIr{lámind}.
  {làmh}, axe (Ross), {làmhaidh} (Suth.); {làmhag}, a small hatchet
  (Arg.), M.Ir. @MIr{laime}, axe; O.Slav. {lomifi}, break, *{lam}, Eng.
  lame (St.).
<lamhrag>, a slut, awkward woman, @Ref<lamhragan>, awkward handling;
  from {lámh}: "underhand".
<làn>, full, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{lán}, W. @W{llawn}, O.W. @OW{laun}, Corn. @Corn{leun}, {len}, Br.
  {leun}: *{lâno-}, *{plâno-}, or {pḹ-no-} (Brug.), root {pḹ}, {plâ}, {pel};
  Skr. {pûrṇás}, full; further Lat. {plênus}; Gr. @Gr{πλήρης}, @Gr{πολύς},
  many; Eng. @Eng{full}, etc.  See also @Ref{iol-}, @Ref{lìon.3}, {lìnn}.
<lànain>, a married couple, Ir. @Ir{lánamhain}, E.Ir. @EIr{lánamain}, O.Ir.
  {lánamnas}, conjugium: *{lag-no-}, root {log}, {leg}, lie, as in @Ref{laigh}?

<lànan>, rafter beam, from @Ref{lànain}.
<langa>, a ling; from Norse {langa}, Sc. {laing}, Eng. @Eng{ling}.

<langadar>, seaware with long leaves (Lewis):
<langaid.1>, a fetter, fetters (especially for horses), @Ref<langar>, Ir. @Ir{langfethir}
  (O'B.; Lh. has †{langphetir}), E.Ir. @EIr{langfiter} (Corm. Gr.,
  "English word this"), W. @W{llyfethar}, M.W. @MW{lawhethyr}; from

  {langivie} (Edmonston).

  seat".
<lann.1>, a blade, sword, Ir. @Ir{lann}, also "a scale, scale of a fish, disc"
  (Arg., M`A.): *{lag-s-na}?  Root {lag}, as in E.Ir. @EIr{laigen}, lance,
  W. @W{llain}, blade, Lat. {lanceo}, Gr. @Gr{λόγχη}, lance-point. Thur.
  ({Zeit. 28}) suggests *{plad-s-na}, "broad thing"; Gr. @Gr{πλαθάνη},
  Ger. {fladen}, flat cake, further G. {leathann}, broad, etc.  O.Ir.
  {lann}, squama, is referred by Stokes to *{lamna}, allied to Lat.
  {lamina}, {lamna}; which would produce rather O.Ir. *{lamn},
  Modern {lamhan}.  Ir. @Ir{lann}, gridiron, is doubtless allied to
  O.Ir. @OIr{lann}.
<lann.2>, an inclosure, land, Ir. @Ir{lann}, E.Ir. @EIr{land}, W. @W{llan}, O.W. @OW{lann},
  area, ecclesia, Br. @Br{lann}: *{landâ}; Teut. {land}, Eng. @Eng{land}.
  See @Ref{iodhlann}.
<lannsa>, a lance, Ir. @Ir{lannsa}; from the Eng.

  {lue}: *{loigo-s}, calf, "jumper", root {leíℊ}, skip, Got. {laikan},

  It is possible to refer it to root {leigh}, lick: "the licker".

<las.2>, kindle, @Ref<lasair>, flame, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lassaim}, {lassair}, W. @W{llachar},
  gleaming: *{laksar-}; Skr. {lakshati}, see, show, O.H.G. {luogên}

<lathailt>, a method, a mould (Wh.):
<làthair>, presence, Ir. @Ir{láthair}, O.Ir. @OIr{láthar}, {lathair}: *{latri-}, *{lâtro-},
  root {plât}, {plâ}, broad; Lettic {plât}, extend thinly; further in
  G. @Ref{làr} above.  Asc. refers it to the root of O.Ir. @OIr{láaim}, I
  send, which is allied to Gr. @Gr{ἐλαύνω}, I drive, etc.  Hence
  @Ref<làrach>.

<leadair>, mangle, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{letraim}, inf. {letrad}, hacking:

<leadan.2>, notes in music, Ir. @Ir{leadán}, musical notes, litany; from
  Lat. {litania}, litany.
<leag>, throw down, Ir. @Ir{leagaim}, inf. {leagadh} *{leggô}, from {leg}, root
  of @Ref{laigh}, lie (cf. Eng. @Eng{lay})?  The preserved {g} may be from
  the analogy of @Ref{leig}, let; and Ascoli refers the word to the
  O.Ir. root {leg}, {lig}, destruere, sternere: {foralaig}, straverat,
  {dolega}, qui destruit.
<leagarra>, self-satisfied, smug (Arg.):
<leagh>, melt, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{legaim}, {legad}, W. @W{llaith}, moist, {dad
  leithio}, melt, Br. @Br{leiz}: *{legô}; Eng. @Eng{leak}, Norse {leka}, drip,
  Ger. {lechzen}.
<leamh>, foolish, insipid, importunate, Ir. @Ir{leamh}; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{lem},
  W. @W{llefrith}, sweet milk, Corn. @Corn{leverid}, @Corn{liuriz}; O.Ir. @OIr{lemnact},
  sweet milk); consider root {lem}, break, as in Eng. @Eng{lame}, etc.
<leamhan>, elm, Ir. @Ir{leamhann}, @Ref{leamh}, M.Ir. @MIr{lem}: *{ḷmo-}; Lat. {ulmus},
  Eng. @Eng{elm}: *{elmo-}.  W. @W{llwyf} (*{leimá}) is different, with which
  is allied (by borrowing?) Eng. @Eng{lime} in {lime-tree}.
<leamnacht>, tormentil, Ir. @Ir{neamhain}:
<leamhnad>, @Ref<leamhragan>, stye in the eye, W. @W{llefrithen}, {llyfelyn}:
  *{limo-}, "ooze"?  Cf. Lat. {līmus}, mud, {lino}, smear, Eng. @Eng{loam}.
<lèan>, @Ref<lèana>, a lea, swampy plain, Ir. @Ir{léana} (do.): *{lekno-}?  Cf.
  Lit. {lëkns}, {lëkna}, depression, wet meadow (cf. Stokes on @Ref{lag.1}
  above); this is Mr Strachan's derivation.  The spelling
  seems against referring it, as Stokes does, to the root {lei}, Gr.
  @Gr{λειμών}, meadow, Lit. {léija}, a valley; though W. @W{llwyn}, grove,
  favours this.  Cf. W. @W{lleyn}, low strip of land.
<lean>, follow, Ir. @Ir{leanaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{lenim}, W. @W{can-lyn}, {dy-lyn}, sequi:
  *{linami}, I cling to; Skr. {linâmi}, cling to; Lat. {lino}, smear;
  Gr. @Gr{ἀλíνω} (do.); *{lipnâmi}, Lit. {lipti}, cleave to; root {lî}, {li},
  adhere.  Inf. is @Ref<leanmhuinn>.

<leanabh>, a child, Ir. @Ir{leanbh}, E.Ir. @EIr{leanab}: *{lenvo-}; from @Ref{lean}?
  Corm. gives also {lelap}, which, as to termination, agrees with
  G. @Ref<leanaban>.  Cf. @Gr{αλοφυρμοαι}.
<leann>, ale, see @Ref{lionn}.
<leannan>, a sweetheart, Ir. @Ir{leannán}, a concubine, E.Ir. @EIr{lennan},
  {lendan}, concubine, favourite: {lex-no-}, root {leg}, lie, as in @Ref{laigh}?
  From @Ref{lionn}; cf. @Ref{òlach}?
<lear>, the sea (poetical word), Ir. @Ir{lear}, E.Ir. @EIr{ler}, W. @W{llyr}: *{liro-},
  root {li}, flow, as in @Ref{lighe}, flood.  Stokes gives the Celtic as
  {lero-s}, but offers no further derivation.
<learag>, larch; from Sc. {larick}, Eng. @Eng{larch}, from Lat. {larix} (*{darix}),
  as in @Ref{darach}, q.v.).
<learg.1>, @Ref<leirg>, plain, hillside, Ir. @Ir{learg}, E.Ir. @EIr{lerg}, a plain; cf. Lat.
  {largus}, Eng. @Eng{large}.
<learg.2>, diver bird (Carm.):
<leas>, advantage, Ir. @Ir{leas}, O.Ir. @OIr{less}, W. @W{lles}, Corn. @Corn{les}, Br. @Br{laz}:
  *{lesso-}, root {pled}, fruit; Slav. {plodŭ}, fruit (Stokes, Bez.).
<leas->, nick-, step-, Ir. @Ir{leas-}, O.Ir. @OIr{less-}, W. @W{llys-} (W. {llysenw} = G.
  {leas-ainm}), Br. @Br{les-}; same as @Ref{leas} above: "additional".  Cf.
  Fr. use of {beau}, {belle} for {step-}.  Stokes suggests *{liss-}, blame,
  root {leid}, Gr. @Gr{λοιδορέω}, revile (Lat. {ludere}?); others compare
  {leas-} to Ger. {laster}, vice (see @Ref{lochd}); Bez. queries connection
  with Ag.S. {lesve}, false, Norse {lasinn}, half-broken.
<leasg>, @Ref<leisg>, lazy, Ir. @Ir{leasg}, O.Ir. @OIr{lesc}, W. @W{llesg}: *{lesko-s}; Norse
  {löskr}, weak, idle, O.H.G. {lescan}, become extinguished, Ger.
  {erloschen} (Stokes).  Brugmann and other give stem as *{led-sco-},
  comparing Got. {latz}, lazy, Eng. @Eng{late}, to which Norse
  {löskr} may be referred (*{latkwa-z}); root {lêd}, @Ref{lad}.  @Gr{ἐλιννυω},
  rest (@ExtRef{Zeit.;34;531}).
<leasraidh>, loins, Ir. @Ir{leasruigh}, pl. of {leasrach}; see @Ref{leis}.
<leathad>, declivity hillside; cf. Ir. @Ir{leathad}, breadth.  See @Ref{leud}.
<leathan>, broad, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{lethan}, W. @W{llydan}, O.W. @OW{litan}, Br.
  {ledan}, Gaul. {litano-s}: *{ḷtano-s}, Gr. @Gr{πλατύς}, broad; Skr.
  {práthas}, breadth; Lat. {planta}, sole of the foot, sprout: root
  {plet}, {plat}, extend.
<leathar>, leather, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lethar}, W. @W{lledr}, M.Br. @MBr{lezr}, Br. @Br{ler}:
  *{letro-}; Eng. @Eng{leather}, Ger. {leder}, Norse {leðr}.  To prove
  that the Teutons borrowed this word from the Celts, it is
  asserted that the original Celtic is *{(p)letro-}, root {pel} of
  Gr. @Gr{πελλα}, hide, Eng. @Eng{fell}.
<leatrom>, burden, weight, @Ref<leatromach> pregnant, Ir. @Ir{leathtrom}
  burden, pregnancy; from @Ref{leth} and @Ref{trom}.
<leibhidh.1>, race, generation (McIthich, 1685); from Eng. @Eng{levy}?
<leibhidh.2>, amount of stock (Carm.):
<leibid>, a trifle, dirt, @Ref<leibideach>, trifling, Ir. @Ir{libideach}, dirty,
  awkward.

<léideach>, strong, shaggy, Ir. @Ir{léidmheach}, strong (O'B.), O.Ir.

<leig> let Ir. @Ir{léigim}, O.Ir. @OIr{léiccim}, {lécim}: *{leingiô}; Lat. {linquo};
  Gr. @Gr{λεíπω}: Got. {leihvan}, Eng. @Eng{loan}.

  @Ref{lighiche}.
<léine>, a shirt, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{léne}, g. {lénith}, pl. {lénti}: *{leinet-}, from

  cloth @Gr{λíνον}, flax.  See @Ref{lìon.1}.  Strachan refers it, on the
  analogy of @Ref{deur} = {dakro-}, to {laknet-}, root {lak}, of Lat. {lacerna},
  cloak, {lacinia}, lappet.

  total, altogether: *{leiri-s}:
<léir.3>, torment, to pain: *{lakro-}, root {lak}, as in Lat. {lacero} lacerate?
<leirg>, a plain; see @Ref{learg.1}.
<leirist>, a foolish, senseless person slut (@Ref<leithrist>):

  Eng. @Eng{leg}, Gr. @Gr{λάξ}, kicking (St.).  Nigra connects it with

<leisg>, laziness, lazy, Ir. @Ir{leisg} (n.); see @Ref{leasg}.

<leithid>, the like, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lethet}; from @Ref{leth}, half, side.
<leithleag>, @Ref<léileag> print for frocks:

  *{lettrek-}.  It may be from *{leth-tír}, "country-side", or from
  {let} of @Ref{leathan}; cf. W. @W{lleth}, flattened, "broadened".
<leòb>, a piece, shred, Ir. @Ir{léab} a piece, {leadhb}, a patch of old leather.

<leòcach>, sneaking, low:
<leòdag>, a slut, prude, flirt:

<leogach>, hanging loosely, slovenly:

  @OBr{lammam}, salio: *{lengmen-}, O.Ir. vb. @OIr{lingim}, I spring, root

  forward, Eng. @Eng{light}, etc.  The O.Ir. perfect tense @OIr{leblaing}
  has made some give the root as {vleng}, {vleg}, Skr. {valg}, spring,
  Lat. {valgus}, awry, Eng. @Eng{walk}; and some give the root as
  {svleng}, from {svelg}.  It is difficult to see how the {v} or {sv} before
  {l} was lost before {l} in {leum}.
