<lompais>, niggardliness, Ir. @Ir{lompais}; from *{lommas}, from @Ref{lom}.
<lòn.1>, food, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{lón}, O.Ir. @OIr{lóon}, adeps, commeatus, O.Br. @OBr{lon},
  adeps: *{louno-}.  Strachan and Stokes cf. O.Sl. {plŭti}, caro,
  Lat. {plutà}, a crust, Lettic {pluta}, a bowel.  Bez. queries if it is
  allied to L.Ger. {flôm}, raw suet, O.H.G. {floum}.  It was usual
  to refer it to the same root as Gr. @Gr{πλοῦτος}, wealth; and
  Ernault has suggested connection with @Ref{blonag} (*{vlon}), which
  is unlikely.
<lòn.2>, marsh, mud, meadow (Arg.), water (Skye): *{lut-no-}, root {lut},
  muddy O.Ir. @OIr{loth}, mud, Lat. {lutum}; further root {lu}, {lou}, as
  in @Ref{lod}.  It may be from *{louno-}, with the same root; cf.
  M.Ir. @MIr{conluan}, hounds' excrement.
<lon.1>, @Ref<lon-dubh>, the blackbird, Ir., M.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{lon}.  Stokes refers
  it to *{lux-no-} (root {leuq}, light, Lat. {lux}, etc.), but this in the
  G. would give {lonn}.
<lon.2>, elk, M.G. {lon} (D.of L.), Ir. @Ir{lon}: *{lono-}; cf. O.Slav. {lani},
  hind, and, further, Celtic *{elanî}, roe (see @Ref{eilid}).
<lon.3>, a rope of raw hides (St Kilda): possibly a condensation of
  @Ref{lomhainn}
<lon.4>, @Ref<lon-chraois>, gluttony, M.Ir. @MIr{con cráis}.  Kuno Keyer, ({Vision
  of M`Conglinne}) translates {lon} separately as "demon".  For
  {craois} see @Ref{craos}.  {lon}, water (Carm.) + @Ref{craos}?
--page 233
<lon.5>, prattle, forwardness, Ir. @Ir{lonaigh}, a scoff, jest, W. @W{llon}, cheerful:
  *{luno-}, root {lu}, {lav}, enjoy, win, W. @W{llawen}, merry; Gr.
  @Gr{ἀπολαύω}, enjoy; Got. {laun}, reward.  See further under @Ref{luach}.
  {làn-aighear}, boisterous mirth (Wh.)?
<long>, a ship Ir. @Ir{long}, E.Ir. @EIr{long}, vessel (vas), ship W. @W{llong}, ship:
  *{longâ}; Norse {lung}, ship (Bez.); cf. Lat. {lagena}, flagon
  (Stokes).  Usually supposed to be borrowed from Lat. (navis)
  {longa}, war ship.  Cf. Ptolemy's River @Gr{Λόγγος}, the Norse
  {Skipafjörðr}, now Loch Long.  *{plugnâ}?  Eng. @Eng{fly}?
<longadh>, a diet, so Ir. E.Ir. @EIr{longad}, eating; a side form of @Ref{slug},
  which see for root.
<longphort>, harbour, camp, palace, Ir. @Ir{longphort} (do.); from @Ref{long} +
  @Ref{port.1}.  Hence @Ref<lùchairt>, palace; {longart}, {lunkart}, in placenames.
<lonn.1>, timber put under a boat for launching it; from Norse
  {hlunnr}, a roller for launching ships.
<lonn.2>, anger, fierce, strong, Ir. @Ir{lonn}, O.Ir. @OIr{lond}, wild.  Stokes
  (@ExtRef{Zeit.;30;557}) doubtfully suggests connection with Skr.
  {randhayati}, destroy, torment.
<lonnrach>, glittering, so Ir.; cf. {loinnir}.  {lònrach}, well fed (Hend.).
<lòpan>, soft, muddy place (Suth.): see @Ref<làban>.
<lorc>, shank (Carm.):
<lorg.1>, a staff, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lorg}, Corn. @Corn{lorc'h}, baculus, Br. @Br{lorc'hen},
  temo: *{lorgo-}, Norse {lurkr}, a cudgel (Bez., Cam.).
<lorg.2>, track, footstep, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lorg}, O.Ir. @OIr{lorc}, trames, {lorgarecht},
  indago, W. @W{llyr}, course duct, Corn. @Corn{lergh}, {lerch} Br. @Br{lerc'h},
  track: *{lorgo-}.  Bez. compares L.Ger. {lurken}, creep.  Rhys
  adds W. @W{llwrw}, direction (@ExtRef{Manx Pray.;2;127}).
<los>, purpose, sake, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{los} sake, behalf, part, M.Ir. @MIr{los},
  growth; {a los}, "about to" (Wh.); {in doghran losleathan},
  beaver (ooter of broad tail), Ir. @Ir{los}, tail, end (O'Cl), W. @W{llost},
  Br. @Br{lost}, *{losto-}, {lostâ}:
<losaid>, a kneading trough, Ir. @Ir{losad}, E.Ir. @EIr{lossat}: *{lossantâ},
  *{lok-s-}, root {lok}, {lek}; Gr. @Gr{λέκος}, a dish, pot; Lit {lekmenė},
  a puddle; Lat. {lanx}, dish.
<losgadh>, a burning, Ir. @Ir{loscadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{loscud}, W. @W{llosg}, urere, Corn.
  {losc} (n.) Br. @Br{losk}: *{loskô}, I burn, *{lopskô}, root, {lop}, {lap}; Gr.
  @Gr{λάμπω}, shine; O.Pruss. {lopis} flame, Lett. {lapa}, pine-torch
  (Stokes).  See @Ref{lasair}, to whose root it is usually referred.
<losgann>, a toad, Ir. @Ir{loscain}, E.Ir. @EIr{loscann}; from {losg} above, so
  named from the acrid secretions of its skin.
<lot.1>, wound, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lot}, damage, {loitim}, laedo: *{lottô}, *{lut-to-},
  root {lut}, {lu}, cut; Skr. {lû-}, cut; Gr. @Gr{λύω}, loose; Eng. @Eng{loss},
  {lose}; Pruss. {au-laut}, die.  Stokes refers it to a stem *{lud-nó-},
--page 234
  root {lud}, Teut. root {lut}, Eng. @Eng{lout}, {little}, Norse {lúta}, to lout,
  bow, Ag.S. {lot}, dolus, etc.
<lot.2>, share, etc., one's croft (Lewis):
<loth.1>, a colt, Manx {lhiy}, W. @W{llwdn}, young of deer, sheep, swine,
  hens, etc., Corn. @Corn{lodn} (do.), M.Br. @MBr{lozn}, beast, Br. @Br{loen}, animal:
  *{pluto-}, *{plutno-}; cf. Lat. {pullus}, foal, Eng. @Eng{filly}.
<loth.2>, marsh (Suth.), O.Ir. @OIr{loth}, mud; see further under @Ref{lòn.2}.
  Hence {Loth}, parish.
<lothail>, the plant brook-lime, Ir. @Ir{lothal} (O'B.), {lochal}:
<luach>, worth, value, Ir. @Ir{luach} O.Ir. @OIr{lóg}, {luach}: *{lougos}, root {lou},
  {lû}, gain; Lat. {lûcrum}, gain, {Laverna}, the thieves' goddess;
  Got. {laun}, a reward, Ag.S. {léan} (do.); O.Slav. {lovŭ}, catching.
<luachair>, rushes, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{luachair}: "light-maker", from {louk},
  light (Lat. {lux}, etc.), M.W. @MW{lleu babir}, rush-light.
<luadh>, fulling cloth; cf. Ir. @Ir{luadh}, motion, moving, root {ploud}
  (Lit. {plaudżu}, wash, Eng. @Eng{fleet}), a side-form of the root of
  @Ref{luath.2}.  But compare @Ref{dol}.
<luaidh.1>, mention, speaking, Ir. @Ir{luadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{luad}: *{laudo-}; Lat.
  {laus}, {laudis}, praise.  Hence @Ref<luaidh.3>, beloved one: "spoken
  or thought of one".
<luaidh.2>, lead, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{luaidhe}: *{loudiâ}; Eng. @Eng{lead}, Ag.S. {léad}
  (*{lauda-}), Ger. {loth}.
<luaidh.3>, beloved one. See @Ref{luaidh.1}.

<luaimear>, a prattler, Ir. @Ir{luaimearachd}, volubility; see @Ref{luaineach}.
<luaineach>, restless, Ir. @Ir{luaimneach}, E.Ir. @EIr{luamnech}, volatile (as
  birds), {lúamain}, flying; root {ploug}, fly; Eng. @Eng{fly}, Ger. {fliegen},
  Norse {fljúga}.
<luaireagan>, a grovelling person, a fire-fond child; from {luaith},
  ashes: "one in sackcloth and ashes"?
<luaisg>, move, wave, @Ref<luasgadh> (n.), Ir. @Ir{luasgaim}, M.Ir. @MIr{luascad},
  O.Br. @OBr{luscou}, oscilla, Br. @Br{luskella}, to rock: *{louskô}, *{ploud-sko-},
  root {ploud} or {plout}, {plou}, go, flow, move, as in @Ref{luath.2}, q.v.
  Bez. queries connection with Lit. {plúskát}, {plúkt}, pluck, tear.
<luan>, moon, Monday, so Ir.; M.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{luan}, moon, Monday:
  *{loukno-}, Lat. {lux}, {luceo}, {lûna}, moon.  The Gadelic is possibly
  borrowed from Lat.  Ir. @Ir{go lá an Luain}, till doomsday.
<luaran>, a dizziness, faint:
<luath.1>, ashes, Ir. @Ir{luaith}, E.Ir. @EIr{lúaith}, W. @W{lludw}, Corn. @Corn{lusu}, Br. @Br{ludu}:
  *{loutvi-}.  Bez. queries if it is allied to Ger. {lodern}, to flame.
<luath.2>, swift, Ir. @Ir{luath}, O.Ir. @OIr{lúath}: *{louto-}, root {plout}, {plou}, go,
  flow, be swift; Eng. @Eng{fleet}, Norse {fljótr}, swift (root {pleud}); Gr.
  @Gr{πλέω}, I sail; Lat. {pluit}, it rains; Skr. {plavate}, swim, fly.
<lùb>, bend, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{lúbaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{lúpaim} ({ro-lúpstair}, they bent,
  L.Leinster): {lúbbô}, root {leub}, {lub}; Eng. @Eng{loop}, M.Eng. {loupe},
  noose; @Gr{λυγíζω} see @Ref{lag.1}.  Skeat regards the Eng. as borrowed
  from the Celtic.  Hence @Ref<lùib>, a fold, creek, angle.
--page 235
<luch>, a mouse, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{luch}, g. {lochat}, W. @W{llyg}, {llygoden}, Corn.
  {logoden}, Br. @Br{logodenn}, pl. {logod}: *{lukot-}, *{pluko-}, "gray-one";
  Lit. {pilkas}, gray, {pele}, mouse; root {pel}, {pol}, gray, as under
  @Ref{liath}.  Stokes refers it to the Gadelic root {luko-}, dark (read
  {lauko-} or {louko-}), whence E.Ir. @EIr{loch} (read {lóch}), which he takes
  from I.E. {leuq}, shine (Lat. {lux}, etc.), comparing W. @W{llwg},
  vivid, blotchy, to which add W. @W{llug}, blotch, dawning.  From
  this obsolete G. word {lóch}, dark, comes the name of the rivers
  {Lòchaidh}, Adamnan's {Nigra Dea} or {Loch-dae}, which we may
  take as the G. form of it from another of his references.
<lùchairt>, a palace, castle; see @Ref{longphort}.
<luchd.1>, people, Ir. @Ir{luchd}, O.Ir. @OIr{lucht}, W. @W{llwyth}, tribe: *{lukto-},
  from {plug}, {pulg}, Eng. @Eng{folk}, Ger. {volk}, whence O.Slov. {pluku},
  a troop.
<luchd.2>, a burden, Ir. @Ir{luchd}, E.Ir. @EIr{lucht}, W. @W{llywth} a load: {lukto-}.
  The O.W. @OW{tluith} (or {maur-dluithruim}, multo vecte) has
  suggested *{tlukto-}, allied to Lat. {tollo}, raise (Stokes).  Eng.
  {flock}?
<lùdag.1>, the little finger, Ir. @Ir{lughadóg}, O.Ir. @OIr{lúta}, dat. {lútain}:
  *{lûddôn-}, root {lûd}, {lud}, Eng. @Eng{little}, Ag.S. {lýtel}, O.H.G. {luzil};
  root {lu}, {lû}, Eng. @Eng{loss}, {-less}, Gr. @Gr{λύω}, etc.
<lùdag.2>, @Ref<lùdan>, @Ref<lùdnan>, a hinge, @Ref<ludanan>, hinges, Ir. @Ir{lúdrach} (Fol.),
  {ludach} {ludann} (O'R.):
<ludair>, a slovenly person, @Ref<ludraig>, bespatter with mud, @Ref<luidir>,
  wallow Ir. @Ir{ludar} (n.), {ludair} (vb.); two words from @Ref{lod}, mud,
  and @Ref{luid}, rag.
<ludhaig>, permit, allow: from the Eng. @Eng{'lowing}, {allowing}.  {lughaic},
  stipulate for (Hend.).
<lùgach>, having crooked legs, @Ref<lùgan>, a deformed person, @Ref<lùigean>,
  a weakling: *{lûggo-}, root {leug}, {lug}, bend, Gr. @Gr{λυγíζω}, bend,
  Lit. {lugnas}, pliant.
<lugh.1>, swear, blaspheme, O.Ir. @OIr{luige}, oath, W. @W{llw}, Br. @Br{le}: *{lugio-n},
  oath, "binding"; Got. {liugan}, wed, O.H.G. {urliugi}, lawless
  condition, Ag.S. {orlege}, war.
<lugh.2>, a joint (M`A.), @Ref<luighean>, a tendon, ankle, Ir. @Ir{luthach}, joints,
  {luighéan}, a nave, M.Ir. @MIr{luíthech}, sinew.
<lugha>, less, Ir. @Ir{lugha}, O.Ir. @OIr{lugu}, {laigiu}, positive, {lau}, {lú}, little,
  W. @W{llai}, less, from {llei}, Br. @Br{lei}, from {lau}: *{legiôs}, from *{legu-s},
  little: Lat. {levis}; Gr. @Gr{ἐλαχύς}, little; Skr. {laghá-s}, light, Eng.
  {light}.
<luibh>, an herb, Ir. @Ir{luibh}, O.Ir. @OIr{luib}, {lubgort}, herb-garden, garden,
  W. @W{lluarth}, garden, Corn. @Corn{luvorth}, Br. @Br{liorz}, garden: *{lubi-},
  herb; Norse {lyf}, herb, Got. {lubja-leisei}, witchcraft, "herb-lore",
  O.H.G. {luppi}, poison, magic, Ag.S. {lyb} (do.).
--page 236
<luid>, @Ref<luideag>, a rag, a slut, Ir. @Ir{luid}: *{luddi}, root {lu}, cut, lose, as
  under @Ref{lot.1}.
<luidhear>, a vent, chimney, louvre, W. @W{llwfer}; from M.Eng.
  {louere}, {lover}, smoke-hole, O.Fr. {lover}.  The Norse {ljóri}, a
  louvre or roof-opening is from {ljós}, light.
<luidse>, a clumsy fellow; from the Sc. {lotch}, lout, {louching}, louting.
<lùigean>, a weak person; see @Ref{lùgach}.

<luigh>, lie; see @Ref{laigh}.
<luighean>, an ankle; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{lua}, foot, kick, O.Ir. @OIr{lue}, heel:
<luighe-siubhla>, see @Ref{luighe-siùbhladh}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<luighe-siùbhladh> (@Ref<laighe-siùbhladh>), child-bed, Ir. @Ir{luidhsiúbhail}
  (Fol.), M.Ir. @MIr{ben siuil}, parturient woman, {luige seola}, child-bed.
  Stokes refers {siuil} to M.Ir. @MIr{siul}, bed, and compares the
  Eng. phrase {to be brought a-bed}.  The G. and Ir. seem against
  this, for the idea of {luighe-siùbhladh} would then be "bed-lying";
  still worse is it when {leabaidh-shiùladh} is used.
  Consider @Ref{siubhal}, bearing.
<luigheachd>, requital, reward: *{lugi-}, root {lug}, {loug}, as in @Ref{luach}.
<luim>, a shift, contrivance:
<luimneach>, active (Smith's S.D.); cf. @Ref{luaineach}.
<luinneag>, a ditty, Ir. @Ir{luinnioc}, chorus, glee, M.Ir. @MIr{luindiuc},
  {luindig}, music-making; *{lundo-}, root {lud}, as in @Ref{laoidh}, Eng.
  {lay}?
<luinneanach>, tossing, floundering, paddling about; see @Ref{lunn.2}, a
  heaving billow.
<luinnse>, @Ref<luinnsear>, a sluggard, lazy vagrant, Ir. @Ir{lunnsaire}, idler,
  watcher; from Eng. @Eng{lungis} (obsolete), {lounger}.
<lùir>, torture, drub (M`A.); see @Ref{laoir}.
<lùireach>, a coat of mail, Ir. @Ir{lúireach}, E.Ir. @EIr{lúirech}, W. @W{llurig};
  from Lat. {lôrîca}, from {lôrum}, a thong.  Hence <lùireach>, a
  patched garment, an untidy female.
<luirist>, an untidy person, tall and pithless:
<lum>, part of the oar between the handle and blade; from N.
  {hlumr}, handle of an oar.
<luma-làn>, choke-full, also @Ref<lom-làn> and @Ref<lumha-lan> (Hend.); from
  @Ref{lom}+@Ref{làn}.
<luman>, a covering, great-coat, Ir. @Ir{lumain}, E.Ir. @EIr{lumman} (g. {lumne},
  M`Con.).  In some dialects it also means a "beating", that is
  a "dressing".
<lùnasd>, @Ref<lùnasdal>, @Ref<lùnasdainn>, Lammas, first August, Ir. @Ir{lughnas},
  August, E.Ir. @EIr{lúgnasad}, Lammas-day: "festival of Lug";
  from {Lug}, the sun-god of the Gael, whose name Stokes connects
  with Ger. {locken}, allure, Norse {lokka} (do.), and also
  {Loki}(?).  E.Ir. @EIr{nassad}, festival (?), is referred by Rhys to the
  same origin as Lat. {nexus}, and he translates {lúgnasad} as
  "Lug's wedding" ({Hib.Lect}, 416).
--page 237
<lunn.1>, a staff, oar-handle, lever; from Norse {hlunnr}, launching
  roller.  See @Ref{lonn.1}.  Dial. @Ref<lund>
<lunn.2>, a heaving billow (not broken); also @Ref<lonn.2>.  See @Ref{lonn.2}, anger.
<lunndair>, a sluggard; cf. Fr. {lendore}, an idle fellow, from M.H.G.
  {lentern}, go slow, Du. {lentern}.  Br. @Br{landar}, idle, is borrowed
  from the Fr.
<lunndan>, a smooth grassy plot (possibly "marshy spot", Rob.).
  Hence place-name {An Lunndan}.
<lunndraig>, thump, beat; from the Sc. {lounder}, beat, {loundering}, a
  drubbing.
<lur>, delight, @Ref<lurach>, lovely, @Ref<luran>, darling, a male child; *{luru-},
  root {lu}, {lau}, enjoy, as in @Ref{lon.5}.
<lurc>, a crease in cloth; from Sc. {lirk}, a crease, M.Eng. {lerke},
  wrinkle.
<lurcach>, lame in the feet; see @Ref{loirc.2}.
<lùrdan>, cunning, a sly fellow; from Sc. {lurdane}, worthless person,
  M.Eng. {lourdain}, lazy rascal, from O.Fr. {lourdein} (n.), {lourd},
  dirty, sottish, from Lat. {luridum}.
<lurg>, @Ref<lurgann>, a shank, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{lurgu} g. {lurgan}; W. @W{llorp},
  {llorf}, shank, shaft.
<lus>, an herb, plant, Ir. @Ir{lus} E.Ir. @EIr{luss}, pl. {lossa}, W. @W{llysiau} herbs,
  Corn. @Corn{les}, Br. @Br{louzaouen}: *{lussu-}, from *{lubsu-}, root {lub} of @Ref{luibh}.
<luspardan>, a pigmy sprite, Martin's {Lusbirdan}; from {lugh} little
  (see @Ref{lugha}), and @Ref{spiorad}.
<lùth> strength, pith, Ir. @Ir{lúth}, E.Ir. @EIr{lúth}; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{lúth}, velocity,
  motion, from the root {pleu}, {plu} of @Ref{luath.2}.  Or {tlúth}, from {tel}?
<ma>, if, Ir. @Ir{má}, O.Ir. @OIr{má}, @OIr{ma}, Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{ma} (also @Ref{mar}); cf. Skr.
  {sma}, {smâ}, an emphatic enclitic (= "indeed") used after
  pronouns etc., the {-sm-} which appears in the I.E. pronoun
  forms (Gr. @Gr{ἀμμε} = {ṇs-sme}, us).
<mab>, a tassel; a side-form of @Ref{pab}, q.v.
<màb>, abuse, vilify:
<mabach>, lisping, stammering; cf. M.Eng. {maflen}, Du. {maffeln}, to
  stammer.
<mac>, a son, Ir. @Ir{mac}, O.Ir. @OIr{macc}, W. @W{mab}, O.W. @OW{map}, Corn. @Corn{mab},
  Br. @Br{map}, {mab}, Ogam gen. {maqvi}: *{makko-s}, *{makvo-s}, son,
  root {mak}, rear, nutrire, W. @W{magu}, rear, nurse, Br. @Br{maguet}:
  I.E. {mak}, ability, production; Gr. @Gr{μακρός}, long, @Gr{μάκαρ},
  blessed; Zend {maçanh}, greatness; Lettic {mázu}, can, be
  able.  Kluge compares Got. {magaths}, maid, Ag.S. {magþ},
  Eng. @Eng{maid}, further Got. {magus}, boy, Norse {mögr}, which,
--page 238
  however, is allied to O.Ir. @OIr{mug} (pl. {mogi}), slave.  The Teut.
  words also originally come from a root denoting "might,
  increase", Gr. @Gr{μῆχος}, means, Skr. {mahas}, great.  Hence
  @Ref<macanta>, mild: "filial".
<macamh>, a youth, generous man, Ir. @Ir{macamh}, {macaomh}, a youth,
  E.Ir. @EIr{maccoem}: from @Ref{mac} and @Ref{caomh}.
<mach>, @Ref<a mach>, outside (motion to "out"), Ir. @Ir{amach}, E.Ir.
  {immach}; from {in} and @Ref{magh}, a field, {mach} being its accusative
  after the prep. {in}, into: "into the field".  Again @Ref<a muigh>,
  outside (rest), is for E.Ir. @EIr{immaig}, {in} with the dat. of @Ref{magh}:
  "in the field".  See @Ref{an.2}, @Ref{ann.2} and @Ref{magh}.
<machair>, a plain, level, arable land, Manx {magher}, Ir., M.Ir.
  {machaire}, {macha}; *{makarjo-}, a field; Lat. {mâceria}, an
  enclosure (whence W. @W{magwyr}, enclosure, Br. @Br{moger}, wall).
  So Stokes.  Usually referred to *{magh-thìr}, "plain-land",
  from @Ref{magh} and @Ref{tìr}.
<machlag>, matrix, uterus, Ir. @Ir{machlóg} (O'B., etc.), M.Ir. @MIr{macloc};
  cf. Ger. {magen}, Eng. @Eng{maw}.
<macnas>, sport, wantonness, Ir. @Ir{macnas} (do.), {macras}, sport,
  festivity; from @Ref{mac}.
<mactalla>, @Ref<macalla>, echo, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{macalla}; from @Ref{mac} and
  obsolete {all}, a cliff, g. {aille} (*{allos}), allied to Gr. @Gr{πέλλα},
  stone (Hes.), Norse {fjall}, hill, Eng. @Eng{fell}.  See also †@Ref<ail.2>,
  which is allied.
<mac-talla>, see @Ref{mactalla}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<madadh.1>, a dog, mastiff, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{madrad}: E.Ir. @EIr{matad}
  (McCon.), {maddad} (Fel.), W. @W{madog}, fox (cf. W. @W{madryn},
  reynard): *{maddo-}, *{mas-do-}, the {mas} possibly being for {mat-s},
  the {mat} of which is then the same as {math-} of @Ref{mathghamhuin},
  q.v.  Connection with Eng. @Eng{mastiff}, Fr. {mâtin}, O.F. {mestiff},
  from *{mansatinus}, "house-dog", would mean borrowing.
<madadh.2>, mussel:
<màdog>, @Ref<madog>, a mattock, W. @W{matog}; from M.Eng. {mattok}, now
  {mattock}, Ag.S. {mattuc}.
<màdar>, madder, Ir. @Ir{madar}, the plant madder; from the Eng.
<madhanta>, valiant, dexterous in arms, Ir. @Ir{madhanta}: "overthrowing",
  from the E.Ir. verb {maidim}, overthrow, break,
  from *{matô}, Ch.Sl. {motyka}, ligo, Polish {motyka}, hoe (Bez.).
<maduinn>, morning, Ir. @Ir{maidin}, O.Ir. @OIr{matin}, mane, {maten}; from
  Lat. {matutina}, early (day), Eng. @Eng{matin}.
<màg>, a paw, hand, lazy bed, ridge of arable land, E.Ir. @EIr{mác}:
  *{mankâ}, root {man}, hand, Lat. {manus}, Gr. @Gr{μάρη}, Norse {mund},
  hand.  Sc. {maig} is from Gaelic.
<magadh>, mocking, Ir. @Ir{magadh}, W. @W{mocio}; from the Eng. @Eng{mock}.
<magaid>, a whim; from Sc. {maggat}, {magget}.

  @Ref{mactalla}: {magar} = *{maggaro-}, root {mag}, {meg}, great, powerful,
  increase?  Cf., however, @Ref{mogul}.

<maith.1>, @Ref<math.1>, good, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{maith}, W. @W{mad}, Corn. @Corn{mas}, M.Br.
  {mat}: *{mati-s}, root {mat}, {met}, measure, I.E. {mê}, measure, as

  affabilis, Gr. @Gr{ματíς} (= @Gr{μέγας}, Hes.).

  @Ref{mainnir}.  Rhys regards the W. as borrowed from Ir.; if so,

  has also been referred to the root {mel}, grind.

<maois>, a large basket, hamper, @Ref<maois-eisg>, five hundred fish, Ir.

  Sc. {mese}, five hundred herring, Norse {meiss}, box, wicker
  basket, {meiss síld}, barrel-herrings, O.H.G. {meisa}, a basket
  for the back; Lit. {maiszas}, sack, Ch.Sl. {mėchŭ}.  The relationship,
  whether of affinity or borrowing, between Celtic and
  Teutonic, is doubtful.  The Brittonic might come from Lat.
  {mensa}, a table, and the Gadelic from the Norse.

<maol>, bald, Ir. @Ir{maol}, O.Ir. @OIr{máel}, {máil}, W. @W{moel}, Br. @Br{maol}: *{mailo-s};
  Lit. {mailus}, something small, smallness, Ch.Sl. {mėlŭkŭ}, small;
  further root {mei}, lessen (see @Ref{maoth}).  The Ir. @Ir{mug}, servant,
  has been suggested as the basis: *{mag(u)lo-}, servile, "short-haired,
  bald"; but this, though suitable to the W., would
  give in G. {mál}.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{mál}, prince, from *{maglo-}.  Hence
  <maol>, brow of a hill or rock, W. @W{mael}, a conical hill?

<mealbhan>, sea bent (Suth.), sand dunes with bent (W.Ross):
<mealg>, milt of fish; for *@Ref<fealg> = @Ref<sealg.2>?
<meall.1>, a lump, hill, Ir. @Ir{meall}, lump, knob, heap, E.Ir. @EIr{mell}, Br.
  {mell}, joint, knot, knuckle, Gaul. {Mello-dunum} (?), now {Melun}:
  *{mello-}, from *{melno-}; O.Slav. {iz-molêti}, just out, proturberate
  (Bez. with query); *{mḷso}; cf. Gr. @Gr{μέλος}, limb, part.
<meall.2>, deceive, entice, Ir. @Ir{meallaim}, M.Ir. @MIr{mellaim}, deceive, E.Ir.
  {mell}, error: {melsô} (Stokes), root {mel}, {mal}, bad; Lat. {malus};
  Lit. {mìlyti}, mistake, {mélas}, lie; Gr. @Gr{μέλεος}, useless; Arm.
  {meλ}, peccatum.  O.Ir. @OIr{meld}, pleasant (?), Gr. @Gr{ἀμαλός}, root
  {mela}, grind.
<meallan>, @Ref<clach-mheallain>, hail, Ir. @Ir{meallán} (Fol., O'R.); from
  @Ref{meall.1}, lump?
<meambrana>, parchments, Ir. @Ir{meamrum}, O.Ir. @OIr{membrum}; from
  Lat. {membrana}, skin, membrane, from {membrum}.
<meamhair>, @Ref<meomhair>, memory, Ir. @Ir{meamhair}, O.Ir. @OIr{mebuir}, W.
  {myfyr}; from Lat. {memoria}, Eng. @Eng{memory}.
<meamna>, @Ref<meanmna>, spirit, will, Ir. @Ir{meanma} (n.), {meanmnach} (adj.),
  O.Ir. @OIr{menme}, g. {menman}, mens; *{menmês}, g. {menmenos}, root
  {men}, mind, think; Skr. {mánman}, mind, thought, {manye},
  think; Lat. {memini}, remember, {mens}; Gr. @Gr{μέμονα}, think,
  @Gr{μνῆμα}, monument; Eng. @Eng{mean}, {mind}; etc.
<mean>, @Ref<meanbh>, small, E.Ir. @EIr{menbach}, small particle: *{mino-},
  *{minvo-}, root {min}; Lat. {minus}, Eng. @Eng{diminish}, Lat. {minor},
  {minutus}, minute; Gr. @Gr{μινύθω}, lessen; Got. {minus}, less: root
  @Ref{mi}, {mei}.  See @Ref{mi-}.  Stokes gives also an alternate root {men},
  Skr. {manâk}, a little, Lat. {mancus}, mamed, Lit. {mènkas}, little.
<meanachair>, small cattle, sheep or goats (Dial.); for @Ref<meanbh-chrodh>.
<mèanan>, a yawn, Ir. @Ir{méanfach}, E.Ir. @EIr{mén-scailim}, I yawn,
  "mouth-spread", {mén}, mouth, {ménogud}, hiatus; cf. W. @W{min},
  lip, edge, Corn. @Corn{min}, {meen}, Br. @Br{min}, snout.  Strachan and
  Stokes suggest the stem *{maknâ}, *{mekno-}, root {mak}; Ag.S.
  {maga}, stomach, Ger. {magen}, Eng. @Eng{maw}.
<meang.1>, guile, Ir. @Ir{meang}, E.Ir. @EIr{meng}: *{mengâ}; Gr. @Gr{μάγγανον},
  engine (Eng. {mangle}), @Gr{μαγγανεύω}, juggle; Lat. {mango}, a
  dealer who imposes.  Cf. N. {mang}, traffic, {monger}.
<meang.2>, whey; Dial. for @Ref{mèag}.
<meangan>, @Ref<meanglan>, a twig, Ir. @Ir{meangán}, {beangán}: *{mengo-},
  Celtic root {meg}, {mag}, increase; see under @Ref{maighdean}, @Ref{mac}.
  Cf. M.Ir. @MIr{maethain}, sprouts.
<meann>, a kid, Ir. @Ir{meannán}, {meann}, W. @W{myn}, Corn. @Corn{min}, Br. @Br{menn}:
  *{mendo-}, kid, "suckling"; Alban. {mεnt}, suck; O.H.G.
  {manzon}, ubera; perhaps Gr. @Gr{μαζός}, breast (Stokes, Strachan)

  It may be from the root {min}, small (*{minno-}), a form which
  suits the W. best.
<meannd>, mint; from the Eng.
<meantairig>, venture; from Eng. @Eng{venturing}.  W. @W{mentra}.
<mear>, merry, Ir. @Ir{mear}; cf. Eng. @Eng{merry}, Ag.S. {merge}, {myrige},
  O.H.G. {murg}, {murgi} (root {mṛgh}).  The E.Ir. @EIr{mer}, mad, is

<mearachd>, error, Ir. @Ir{mearaighim}, I err, {mearughadh}, a mistaking,
  erring, M.Ir. @MIr{merugud}, wandering, root {mer}, {mṛ}; Gr.

  {meraige}, a fool, O.Br. @OBr{mergidhaam}, I am silly, which Loth
  joins to Gr. @Gr{μάργος}, mad.

<mearganta>, brisk, lively, @Ref<meargadaich>, be impatient (Suth), Ir.

<meas.1>, fruit, Ir. @Ir{meas}, fruit, especially acorns, {measog}, acorn, E.Ir.

<meidh>, a balance, Ir. @Ir{meadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{med}, d. {meid}, W. @W{medd}, centre

<mèin.2>, @Ref<meinn>, disposition, Ir. @Ir{méin}, M.Ir. @MIr{mèin}, mind, disposition:
  "metal, mettle"; seemingly a metaphoric use of the foregoing
  word.  A root {mein}, mind, mean, appears to exist in

  compares Eng. @Eng{mien}.

<meirg>,  rust, Ir. @Ir{meirg}, O.Ir. @OIr{meirg}, @Ref{meirc}, Br. @Br{mergl}: *{mergi-},
  "red, dark"; Eng. @Eng{murk}, Ag.S. {mirce}, Norse {myrkr} (cf. G.
  @Ref{dearg} and Eng. @Eng{dark}).  Ernault compares Gr. @Gr{μάργος}, senseless;
  and it has been joined to O.W. @OW{mergid}, debilitas, O.Br.
  {mergidhehan}, evanesco, root {mar}, {mer}, fade, die.
<meirghe>, a banner, Ir. @Ir{meirge}, E.Ir. @EIr{mergge}; from the Norse
  {merki}, a banner, mark, Eng. @Eng{mark} (Zimmer).

  @Gr{ṇ-μερjω}, privative {ṇ} or {a} and root {mer} (@Gr{μέρος}, share).
<meirneal>, a kind of hawk; from the Eng. @Eng{merlin}.

<meuchd>, mixture (Dial.): *{meik-tu}, root {meik}, {mik}, as in @Ref{measg.2}.
<meud>, @Ref<miad>, size, Ir. @Ir{méid}, {méad}, W. @W{maint}, Corn. @Corn{myns}, Br. @Br{meñt}:
  *{mṇti-}, {ment}, "measure", a nasalised form of the root {met},
  measure, Lat. {mensus}, having measured, {mētior} (vb.), Gr.
  @Gr{μέτρον}, measure; etc.  Bez. queries its alliance only with
  Norse {munr}, importance.  Usually referred to the root {mag},
  {meg} (*{maganti-}), great, or to that of @Ref{minig}, q.v.
<meur>, @Ref<miar>, a finger, Ir. @Ir{meur}, O.Ir. @OIr{mér}.  Strachan suggests the
  stem *{makro-}, root {mak}, great, mighty, Gr. @Gr{μακρός}, long,
  Lat. {macer}, lean, {macte}, good luck, Zend. {maç}, great.  Brugmann
  has compared it to Gr. @Gr{μόκρωνα} (Hes.), sharp (Lat.
  {mucro}).
<mhàin>, @Ref<a mhàin>, only, Ir. @Ir{amháin}, E.Ir. @EIr{amáin}.  It has been
  divided into a prefix and root form: {a-máin}, the latter being
  parallel to Dor. Gr. @Dor{μῶνος}, Gr. @Gr{μόνος}, alone.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{nammá},
  tantum, "ut non sit magis" ({na-n-má}, Zeuss).
<mi>, I, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{mé}, W. @W{mi}, Corn. @Corn{my}, {me}, Br. @Br{me}: *{mê}, *{me}; Lat.
  {mê}; Gr. @Gr{με}; Eng. @Eng{me}; Skr. {mâ}.
<mi->, un-, mis-, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{mí-}, root {mî}, {mei}, @Ref{mi}, lessen; Gr. @Gr{μεíων},
  less; Lat. {minus}, less; Eng. @Eng{mis-}, Got. {missa-} (*{miþto-}).  See
  @Ref{maoth}, @Ref{mìn}.  Stokes makes {mí-} a comparative like @Gr{μεíων},
  and rejects the Teutonic words.

<miadan>, @Ref<miadar>, @Ref<miad>, a meadow, mead; from the Eng. @Eng{meadow}.

<mìlidh>, a champion, Ir. @Ir{mileadh}, {mílidh} (O'B.), E.Ir. @EIr{mílid}; from

<mill>, destroy, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{millim}: *{mel-ni-}, root {mele}, fail, miss;
  Lit. {mìlyti}, fail; Gr. @Gr{μέλεος}, useless, wretched, @Gr{ἀμβλíσκω},
  cause, miscarriage.  the root of Eng. @Eng{melt} (*{meld}, Gr.
  @Gr{ἀμαλδύνω}, destroy) has been suggested, the {mel} of which is
  the same as above.  It may be root {mel}, crush, mill.
<millteach>, mountain grass, good grass; Norse {melr}, bent grass.
<min>, meal, Ir. @Ir{min}, g. {mine}, O.Ir. @OIr{men}: *{miná}, root {min}, lessen.
  Strachan suggests two derivations; either allied to (1) Lit.
  {mìnti}, tread, Ch.Sl. {męti}, crush, Gr. @Gr{ματέω}, tread on, from
  root {men}, tread, or from (2) *{mecsn}, root {meq}, {menq}, grind,
--page 250
  Ch.Sl. {mąka}, meal, Gr. @Gr{μάσσω}, knead.  But {mexn-} would
  give G. {menn}.
<mìn>, soft, delicate, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{mín}, W. @W{mwyn}, gentle, Corn. @Corn{muin},
  gracilis, Br. @Br{moan}, fine: *{mîno-}, {meino-}, root {mei}, lessen; Gr.
  @Gr{μεíων}, less, @Gr{μινύθω}, lessen; Lat. {minor}, less, {minister}.  Hence
  @Ref<mìnich>, explain.  Stokes has apparently two derivations for
  {mìn} - the one above and *{mêno-}, allied to Gr. @Gr{μανός} ({a} long),
  thin.
<minidh>, an awl, Ir. @Ir{meanadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{menad}, W. @W{mynawyd}, Br.
  {minaoued}, M.Br. @MBr{menauet}: *{minaveto-}; Gr. @Gr{σμινύη}, mattock,
  @Gr{σμíλη} (@Ref{i} long), chiesel.
<minicionn>, mid's skin; from @Ref{meann} and *{cionn} (see @Ref{boicionn}).
<minig>, @Ref<minic>, often, Ir. @Ir{minic}, O.Ir. @OIr{menicc}, W. @W{mynych}, Corn.
  {menough}: *{menekki-s}; Got. {manags}, many, Ger. {manach}, Eng.
  {many}.
<minis>, degree, portion (M`A.), root of @Ref{mion}.
<ministear>, a minister, Ir. @Ir{mínistir}; from Lat. {minister}, servant,
  whence Eng. @Eng{minister}.
<miobhadh>, ill-usage, as by weather; from {mi-bhàidh}.
<mìobhail>, unmannerly (Arg.); @Ref{mi}+{modhail}.
<miodal>, flattery, Ir. @Ir{miodal}:
<miodhoir>, a churl, niggard one; see @Ref{miùghair}.
<mìog>, @Ref<miog>, (H.S.D.), a smile, sly look, Ir. @Ir{míog}: *{smincu-}, root
  {smi}, smile, Eng. @Eng{smile}, Gr. @Gr{μειδάω}, Skr. {smayate}, laughs.

  @Ref{miolasg}.
<miolasg>, flattery, fawning (as a dog), keen desire; from the root
  {smi}, smile?  See @Ref{mìog}.

<mion>, small, so Ir.; root {min}, Lat. {minor}, etc.  Also @Ref{mean},
  @Ref{meanbh}, q.v.
<mionach>, bowels, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{menach}; cf. W. @W{monoch}.
<mionaid>, a minute, Ir. @Ir{minuit} (dat.); from the Eng.
<mionn>, an oath, Ir. @Ir{mionn}, g. {mionna}, E.Ir. @EIr{mind}, oath, diadem;
  the {mind} was the "swearing reliques" of a saint, O.Ir. @OIr{mind},
  a diadem, insignia, O.W. @OW{minn}, sertum: *{menni-}; cf.
  O.H.G. {menni}, neck ornament, Ag.S. {mene}, neck chain, Lat.
  {monile}.  See @Ref{muineal} further.  Stokes gives the stem as
  *{mindi-}, but no etymology.  Windisch (@ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;5;}) equates
  {minn} with Lat. {mundus}, ornament, world.
<miontan>, a titmouse, Ir. @Ir{miontán}; from @Ref{mion}, small, *{minu-}, Lat.
  {minor}, etc., as under {mín}.
<mìorbhuil>, a miracle, Ir. @Ir{míorbhuil}, E.Ir. @EIr{mírbail}; from Lat.
  {mīrabile}, Eng. @Eng{marvel}.
<miortal>, myrtal, Ir. @Ir{miortal} (Fol.); from the English.  W. has
  {myrtwydd}, myrtle trees.
--page 251
<mìos>, a month, Ir. @Ir{mí}, {míos}, g. {míosa}, O.Ir. @OIr{mí}, g. {mís}, W. @W{mis},
  Corn. @Corn{mis}, Br. @Br{mis}, {miz}: *{mêns}, g. *{mensos}; Lat. {mensis}; Gr.
  @Gr{μέν}: Skr. {mâs}; further Eng. @Eng{month}.
<mios>, @Ref<miosa>, worse, Ir. @Ir{measa}, O.Ir. @OIr{messa}: *{missôs}; Got.
  O.H.G. {missa-}, mis-, Eng. @Eng{mis-}, {miss}.  See @Ref{mi-}.
<mìosach>, fairy flax, purging flax, Ir. @Ir{míosach}: "monthly"; from
  @Ref{mìos}, "from a medicinal virtue it was supposed to possess"
  (Cameron).
<miosar>, a measure (as of meal), Ir. @Ir{miosúr}, E.Ir. @EIr{messar}, phiala,
  O.Ir. @OIr{mesar}, modus, W. @W{mesur}; from the Lat. {mensura}, Eng.
  {measure}.
<miosgan>, butter kit, Ir. @Ir{míosgán}; from @Ref{mias}, a dish.
<miosguinn>, envy, malice, Ir. @Ir{mioscuis} ({míoscuis}, Con.), E.Ir. @EIr{miscen},
  hate, O.Ir. @OIr{miscuis}; Gr. @Gr{μῖσος} (= {mītos}); Lat. {miser},
  wretched (= {mit-s-ro-s}); root {mit}, @Ref{mi}.
<miotag>, a mitten, Ir. @Ir{miotóg}, {mitín}, mittens; from Eng. @Eng{mitten},
  O.Fr. {mitaine}.
<mìr>, a bit, piece, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{mír}, pl. {mírenn}: *{mêsren}, piece of
  flesh; Skr. {mâmsá}, flesh; Got. {mimz} (do.); Lit. {mėsà}, flesh
  (Stokes, Thur., Brug.).  Allied also is Lat. {membrum}, member;
  I.E. {mêmso-m}, flesh.
<mircean>, kind of sea-weed; cf. N. {máru-kjarni}, fucus vesiculosus
  (Lewis).
<mire>, pastime, Ir. @Ir{mire}, sport, madness, M.Ir. @MIr{mire}, madness; see
  @Ref{mear}.
<mirr>, myrrh, Ir. @Ir{miorr}, E.Ir. @EIr{mirr}, W. @W{myr}; from Lat. {myrrha},
  Eng. @Eng{myrrh}.
<mìs>, @Ref<mìseach>, @Ref<maoilseach>, goat, doe (Carm.) = @Ref{maoisleach}.
<misd>, the worse for, Ir. @Ir{misde}, {meisde}, M.Ir. @MIr{meste}, E.Ir. @EIr{mesai-die}
  = {messa-de}, "worse of"; from @Ref{mios} and @Ref{de}, of.
<misg>, drunkenness, Ir. @Ir{meisge}, {misge}, E.Ir. @EIr{mesce}, O.Ir. @OIr{mescc},
  drunk: *{mesko-}, *{meskjâ}, from *{med-sko-}, also E.Ir. @EIr{mid}, g.
  {meda}, mead, W. @W{medd}, hydromel, O.Corn. {med}, sicera, Br. @Br{mez},
  hydromel: *{medu-}; Gr. @Gr{μέθυ}, wine; Eng. @Eng{mead}; Ch.Sl.
  {medŭ}, honey, wine; Skr. {mádhu}, sweet, sweet drink, honey.
<misimean-dearg>, bog-mint, Ir. @Ir{misimín dearg}:
<mìslean>, a mountain grass, sweet meadow grass (Cameron); for
  {milsean}, from @Ref{milis}, sweet; cf. Ir. @Ir{milsean mara}, a sort of
  sea-weed; {mìsleach}, sweetness (Hend.).
<misneach>, @Ref<misneachd>, courage, Ir. @Ir{meisneach}, M.Ir. @MIr{mesnech}:
  *{med-s-}, root {med} of {meas}: "think, hope".
<mistear>, a cunning, designing person; from @Ref{misd}.
<mith>, an obscure or humble person; from the root {mi}, {mei} as in
  @Ref{mi-}, @Ref{miosa}.
--page 252
<mithear>, weak, crazy, Ir. @Ir{mithfir}, weak; see @Ref{mith}.
<mithich>, proper time, tempestivus, Ir. @Ir{mithid}, O.Ir. @OIr{mithich},
  tempestivus: *{meti-}, Lat. {māturus}, Eng. @Eng{mature}.
<mithlean>, sport, playfulness:
<miùghair>, niggardly; from @Ref{mi} and @Ref{fiù} or {fiù-mhor}? cf. @Ref{miodhoir}.
<mnathan>, wives, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{mná}, wives: *{bnâs}; see @Ref{bean.1}
<mo>, my, O.Ir. @OIr{mo}, @Ref{mu}, W. @W{fy}, M.W. @MW{my} (from {myn}), Corn., Br.
  @Ref{ma} (which aspirates): *{mou}, *{movo}: formed on the analogy
  of @Ref{do.3}, {du}, from the pronomial root {me} (see @Ref{mi}).  W. @W{myn} or
  {my n-} is allied to Zend. {mana}, Lit. {manè} (for {me-né}), Ch.Sl. {mene}.
<mò>, greater, Ir. @Ir{mó}, O.Ir. @OIr{móa}, {máo}, {máa}, {móo}, {mó}, W. @W{mwy},
  O.W. @OW{mui}, Corn. @Corn{moy}, Br. @Br{mui}: *{mâjôs}; Lat. {mâjor}, greater
  (Eng. {major}); Got. {mais}, more (adv.), {maiza}, greater, Eng.
  {more}: root {mâ} of @Ref{mór}, q.v.
<mobainn>, maltreating, handling roughly; see @Ref{moibean}.
<moch>, early, Ir. @Ir{moch}, early, O.Ir. @OIr{moch}, mane: *{moq-}; also O.Ir.
  {mos}, soon, W. @W{moch}, early, ready, Corn. @Corn{meugh}: *{moqsu};
  Lat. {mox}, soon; Zend. {moshu}, Skr. {mokshú}, soon: also Gr.
  @Gr{μάψ}, idly, rashly.  See @Ref{mus}.  Hence @Ref<mocheirigh>, early rising,
  @Ref<mochthrath>, early morning, M.Ir. @MIr{mochthrath}, O.Ir. @OIr{mochtratae},
  matutinus.
<mochd>, move, yield (Oss. Ballads); cf. M.Ir. @MIr{mocht}, gentle, weak,
  W. @W{mwytho}, soften, pamper, Eng. @Eng{meek}, Norse {mjukr}, soft,
  meek.
<mòd>, a court, trial, meeting; from the Norse {mót}, meeting, town-meeting,
  court of law, Ag.S. {mót}, {gemót}, Eng. @Eng{moot}, {meet}.
<modh>, manner, Ir. @Ir{modh}, O.Ir. @OIr{mod}, W. @W{modd}; from Lat. {modus}.
  Hence <modh>, respect, E.Ir. @EIr{mod}; cf. Eng. @Eng{manners} for sense.
<modhan>, the sound of a bagpipe or other musical instrument
  (H.S.D., also @Ref<moghun>):
<mòdhar>, soft, gentle (@Ref<modhar>, M`A.); from @Ref{modh}.
<mòg>, clumsy hand or foot; see @Ref{màg}, @Ref{smòg}.
<mogach>, shaggy, hairy:
<mogan.1>, a footless stocking; from the Sc. {moggan}, {moggans}.
<mogan.2>, spirits from oats (Uist):
<mogul>, a husk, mesh (of a net), Ir. @Ir{mogal}, cluster, mesh of a net,
  husk, apple of the eye, E.Ir. @EIr{mocoll} (do.), O.Ir. @OIr{mocul}, subtel:
  *{mozgu-}, I.E. {mozgho}, knot, mesh; Lit. {mázgas}, knot, mesh;
  O.H.G. {mascâ}, Ger. {masche}, Eng. @Eng{mesh}; Gr. @Gr{μόσχος}, sprout,
  calf.  Lat. {macula}, a mush, is not allied.  Dialect G.
  @Ref<mugairle>, bunch of nuts (Glenmoriston).
<mogur>, bulky, clumsy:
<moibean>, @Ref<moibeal>, a mop, broom, Ir. @Ir{moipal}; from Eng. @Eng{mop}.
--page 253
<moibleadh>, a gnawing, half-chewing: "making a mop of"; from
  @Ref{moibean}.
<móid>, a vow, Ir. @Ir{móid}, M.Ir. @MIr{móit}, E.Ir. @EIr{moit} (Corm.): *{monti-},
  W. @W{gofuno}, to vow, O.Br. @OBr{guomonian}, polliceri, which Bugge
  and Stokes connect with W. @W{mun}, hand (cf. Ag.S. {mund},
  Lat. {manus}).  But see @Ref{bóid}.  Stokes now says {votum}.
<mòid>, the greater, Ir. @Ir{móide}, more, M.Ir. @MIr{móti}: *{mò}+@Ref{de}.  Cf.
  @Ref{misd}.
<moighre>, robust, handsome:
<moil>, matted hair; see @Ref{molach} (*{mḷ-}).
<moilean>, a fat, plump child, a lump; cf. Ir. @Ir{moil}, {molan}, a heap.
  To this Lat. {môles} may be compared.
<mòin>, @Ref<mòine>, peat, moss, Ir. @Ir{móin}, g. {móna}, E.Ir. @EIr{móin}, pl. {móinte},
  W. @W{mawn}, peat, turf: *{mân-}; Lat. {mâno}, flow, Eng. @Eng{emanate}.
  Strachan takes it from *{mokni-}, root {mok}, {mak}, Ch.Sl.
  {mokrŭ}, wet, Lit. {makone}, puddle; Stokes agrees, giving Celtic
  as *{mâkni-}, {môkni-}.  It is doubtful if W. @W{k} would disappear
  before {n} (cf. @Ref{deur}).  W. has also a form {migen}, {mign}, a bog.
<moineis>, false delicacy (M`A.), @Ref<moinig>, vanity, boasting; from
  root {mon}, {men}, mind?
<moire>, @Ref<a more>, certainly, hercle, Ir. @Ir{iomorro}, indeed, however,
  O.Ir. @OIr{immurgu}, autem.
<moirear>, a lord, O.G. {mormær} (Book of Deer), M.G. {morbhair}
  (M`V.), M.Ir. @MIr{mormhaer} (Muireach Albanach), {murmor}
  (M`Firbis); from @Ref{mór} and @Ref{maor}, "great steward".
<mòirneas>, creat cascade, streams (Oss. Ballads); from @Ref{mór} and @Ref{eas}?
<moit>, pride, sulkiness, Ir. @Ir{moiteamhuil}, sulky, nice, pettish (Con.,
  O'R., M`F.); cf. E.Ir. @EIr{mochtae}, magnified, *{mog-tio-s}, root
  {mog}, {mag}, great.  O.Ir. @OIr{móidem}, boasting, praise.
<mol.1>, praise, advise, Ir. @Ir{molaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{molid}, laudat, W. @W{moli},
  {mawl}, laus, Br. @Br{meuli}: *{molô}, *{mâlo}, "magnify"; root {mōl},
  {mel}, be strong; Gr. @Gr{μάλα}, very; Lat. {melior}, better; Lit.
  {milns}, very many, Ch.Sl. {iz-molêti}, eminere (Stokes).
  Windisch has compared it to Ch.Sl. {moliti}, ask, Lit. {myleti},
  love, Gr. @Gr{μέλε}, friend, @Gr{μεíλιχος}, gentle.
<mol.2>, @Ref<mal>, a shingly beach; from Norse {möl}, g. {malar}, pebbles,
  bed of pebbles on the beach; root {mel}, grind.
<molach>, hairy, rough, Ir. @Ir{mothlach}, rough, bushy (O'R.), {muthalach},
  shaggy (Fol.).  If the Irish form is right, it cannot be allied
  to I.E. {mḷo-s}, wool, Gr. @Gr{μαλλός}, wool, tuft, Lit. {millas}, woolen
  stuff.
<moll>, chaff, Ir. @Ir{moll} (O'R.), W. @W{mwl}: *{muldo-}; Eng. @Eng{mould}, Got.
  {mulda}, dust, O.H.G. {molt}, dust, mould; root {mel}, grind.
  Borrowed from Welsh?
--page 254
<mollachd>, a curse; the Northern form of @Ref{mallachd}, q.v.
<mòlltair>, a mould; from Eng. @Eng{moulter}, {mould}.
<molltair>, miller's share of the grain or meal (Lewis) = {multure}:
<monadh>, a mountain range, W. @W{mynydd}, mons, Corn. @Corn{menit}, {meneth},
  O.Br. @OBr{-monid}, M.Br. @MBr{menez}, mountain: *{monijo-}, *{menijo-},
  root {men}, eminere, Eng. @Eng{eminent}.  Cf. Welsh inscription
  {Monedorigi}, "mountain-king"; also middle G. name of St
  Andrews - {Rig-monath} (Chronicles).  The Ir. @Ir{monadh} appears
  only in Lh.; O'Br. gives {mónadh}.  The G. word may have
  been borrowed from the Picts along with the place-names in
  which it appears: it is rare in Argyle topography.
<monaid>, heed:
<monais>, slowness, negligence; root {men}, stay, Gr. @Gr{μένω}.
<monar>, a diminutive person or thing, @Ref<monaran>, a mote; see @Ref{munar}.
<monasg>, chaff, dross; from the root of @Ref{monar}.
<monmhur>, @Ref<monaghar>, a murmuring noise, Ir. @Ir{monmhar}, {monbhar},
  murmuring, {monghair}, {monghar}, roaring: *{mon-mur}; cf.
  Lat. {murmur}.
<mór>, great, Ir. @Ir{mór}, O.Ir. @OIr{mór}, {már}, W. @W{mawr}, O.W., Corn. @Corn{maur},
  Br. @Br{meur}, Gaul. {-mârós}; Gr. @Gr{-μωρος}, great, famed (@Gr{ἐγχεσí-μωρος})
  in spear-throw; Got. {-mêrs}, famed, {mêrian},
  proclaim, O.H.G. {mâri}, famed, {-mar} in Germanic names
  Ger. {märchen}, a tale, Norse {mœrr}, famous; Slav. {-meru}
  ({Vladimir}, etc.); Lat. {merus}, Eng. @Eng{mere}.  A shorter form of
  the stem (*{mâro-}) appears in @Ref{mò}, greater ({mâ}), q.v.
<morbhach>, land liable to sea flooding, Ir. @Ir{murbhach}, M.Ir.
  {murmhagh}; from @Ref{muir} and @Ref{magh}.  Hence the locative
  {A' Mhor'oich}, the G. name of Lovat.  Aran Ir. @Ir{muirbheach},
  sandy soil by the seaside.
<morghath>, a fishing spear; "sea-spear", from @Ref{muir} and @Ref{gath}?  M.Ir.
  {murgai} (B.of Lis.).
<mòrnan>, a small timber dish, Ir. @Ir{mórnán}:
<mort>, murder, Ir. @Ir{mort}, M.Ir. @MIr{martad}, slaughtering; from Lat.
  {mort-} of {mors}, {mortis}, death.
<mortar>, mortar, Ir. @Ir{mortaoil}; from the Eng.

<mosach>, nasty, dirty; see @Ref{musach}.
<mosgail>, waken, arouse, Ir. @Ir{músguilim}, {músglaim}, M.Ir. @MIr{romuscail},

<mosradh>, coarse dalliance, @Ref<mosraiche>, smuttiness; from {mos} with
  suffix {radh}.  See @Ref{musach} for root.
<mothaich>, perceive, Ir. @Ir{mothuighim}, M.Ir. @MIr{mothaigim}, perceive,

<mothan>, bog violet:

<muc>, a pig, Ir. @Ir{muc}, O.Ir. @OIr{mucc}, W. @W{moch}, pigs, Br. @Br{moc'h}, pigs:
  *{mukku-}; Lat. {mûcus}, {muccus}, mucus; Gr. @Gr{μύξα}, phlegm,

<mucag>, a hip or hep, fruit of the dog-rose, M.Ir. @MIr{mucóra}; from
  @Ref{muc} above.  Cf. Gr. @Gr{μύκης}, a mushroom, from the same root.
<mùch>, smother, press down, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{múchaim}, also E.Ir. @EIr{múch},
  smoke, W. @W{mwg}, smoke, Corn. @Corn{mok}, {megi}, stifle, Br. @Br{mik}, suffocation,
  {miga}, be suffocated, {moguiet}, smoke: *{mûko-}, root
  {smûk}, {smûg}, ({smûgh}, {smaugh}), Eng. @Eng{smoke}, Gr. @Gr{σμύχω},
  smoulder ({v} long).  Stokes suggests old borrowing from the
  Ag.S.  Hence @Ref<mùchan>, a vent or chimney, Ir. @Ir{múchán} (O'B.).
<mùdan>, a covering, covering for a gun:
<mugha>, destruction, decay, Ir. @Ir{múgha}, a perishing, straying, M.Ir.
  {mugud}, slaying, {mogaim}, I slay:
<mugharn>, ankle, so Ir.; cf. W. @W{migwrn}, ankle, joint, Br. @Br{migorn},
  cartilage, which Stokes compares to Lat. {mucro}, point.
<muidhe>, a churn, E.Ir. @EIr{muide}, a vessel, {buide}, a churn, W. @W{buddai},
  churn.  Stokes compares {buide} and {buddai} to Gr. @Gr{πíθος}, jar,
  Lat. {fedelia}, pot, which is related to Eng. @Eng{body}.  The form
  {muidhe} has been compared to Lat. {modius}, a peck, Fr. {muid},
  hogshead.
<muidse>, a mutch; from the Sc. {mutch}, Ger. {mütze}.
<mùig>, @Ref<mùg>, cloudiness, gloom, surliness, Ir. @Ir{múig}: *{munki-}, root
  {muk}, smoke, as in @Ref{mùch}?  Or *{mūggi-}, allied to Eng. @Eng{muggy}?
<muigh>, @Ref<a muigh>, outside; see @Ref{mach}.
<muilceann>, fell-wort, Ir. @Ir{muilcheann}:
<muileach>, dear, beloved: *{molico-}, from @Ref{mol.1}, praise?
<muileag>, a cranberry:
<muileann>, a mill, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{mulenn}, {muilend}, W., Corn., Br.
  {melin}; from Lat. {molîna}, a mill, {molo}, grind (see @Ref{meil}).

<muileid>, a mukle, Ir. @Ir{múille}; from Lat. {mulus}.

<muillion>, a million, Ir. @Ir{milliun}; from the L.Lat. {millionem},

<muilteag>, a certain small red berry (Dial. H.S.D.).  See @Ref{muileag}.
<muime>, a step-mother, nurse, Ir. @Ir{buime}, {muime}, a nurse, E.Ir.
  {mumme}, nurse, stepmother: *{mud-s-mjâ}, nurse, "suckler",

  damp; Lit. {máudyti}, bath.  It has also been paralleled to
  Lat. {mamma}, Ger. {muhme}, mother's sister, stepmother.
<muin.1>, teach, instruct, Ir. @Ir{múinim}, O.Ir. @OIr{múnim}:
<muin.2>, the back, Ir. @Ir{muin}, E.Ir. @EIr{muin}, back, neck, W. @W{mwn}, neck:

  had also @Gr{μανιάκης}, collar or torque.
<mùin>, micturate, Ir. @Ir{mún}, urine, E.Ir. @EIr{mún}, root {meu} {mû}, befoul;
  Skr. {mū́tra} urine; possibly also Lat. {mûto}, {mutto}, penis,

<muineal>, the neck, Ir. @Ir{muineul}, E.Ir. @EIr{muinél}, W. @W{mwnwgl}:
  *{moniklo-}; from *{moni-} of @Ref{muin.2}, back, q.v.
<muineasach>, depressed (Glenmoriston):
<muing>, a name, Ir. @Ir{muing}, O.Ir. @OIr{mong}, W. @W{myng} (m.), M.Br. @MBr{móe},
  Br. @Br{moue}: *{mongâ}, *{mongo-}, root {mon} of @Ref{muin.2}, back, q.v.
  Further is Eng. @Eng{mane}, Norse {mön}, Ger. {mähne}; Sw. and
  Dan. {manke} is especially close to Gaelic.
<muinichill>, @Ref<muilichinn> (Arg.), a sleeve, Ir. @Ir{muinichille}, {muinchille},
  E.Ir. @EIr{munchille}; from Lat. {manicula}, {manica}, long sleeve,
  from {manus}, hand.
<muinighin>, confidence, trust, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{muinigin}; from *{moni-},
  love, desire, Norse {munr}, love, O.Sax. {munilîk}, lovable; root
  {men}, think (Lat. {mens}, Eng. @Eng{mind}, etc.).
<muinne>, stomach (Arg.).  Cf. @Ref{mionach}.
<muinnte>, @Ref<munnda>, beauteous; cf. Lat. {mundus}.
<mùinnteachd>, disposition (Dial.); for root see @Ref{muinighin}, and cf.
  O.Ir. @OIr{muiniur}, I think.
<muinntir>, household, people, Ir. @Ir{muinntir}, O.Ir. @OIr{muinter}, {muntar}.
  This is regarded by Stokes, Zimmer, and Güterbock as an
  early borrowing from the Lat. {monasterium}, monastery; the
  word {familia} is often applied to monasteries by Irish writers.
<muir>, the sea, Ir. @Ir{muir}, O.Ir. @OIr{muir}, gen. {mora}, W. @W{môr}, Corn.,
  Br. @Br{mor}, Gaul. {mor-}: *{mori-}, sea; Lat. {mare}; Eng. @Eng{mere},
  Ger. {meer}; Ch.Sl. {morje}.
<mùire>, leprosy; from @Ref{mùr.2}, a countless number, q.v.
<muirgheadh>, a fishing spear; see @Ref{morghath}.
<muirichinn>, children, family, Ir. @Ir{muiridhin}, a charge, family:

  memory; Gr. @Gr{μέριμνα}, care; Skr. {smarati}, think, mind,
  *{mori-gen-}.

<mùirn>, joy, affection, Ir. @Ir{múirn}, {múirnín} (Eng. {mavourneen},
  my darling), M.Ir. @MIr{múirn}, {muirn}: *{morni-}, root {mor}, {mer},
  {smer}, as in @Ref{muirichinn} above.
<mùiseag>, a threat, @Ref<muiseag> (Arm.); from @Ref{mus} of @Ref{musach}.
<muisean>, a mean, sordid fellow; see @Ref{musach} for the root.
<mùisean>, a primrose, Ir. @Ir{múiseán} (O'B.):

<muisginn>, an English pint, mutchkin; from the Sc. {mutchkin},

<mul.1>, a conical heap, mound, Ir. @Ir{mul}, @Ref{moil}, E.Ir. @EIr{mul-}, eminence:
  *{mulu-}; cf. Norse {múli}, jutting crag, "mull", Ger. {maul},
  snout.  Cf. Fr. {mulon}, little heap of dried grass.  {mul-conain},
  conical suppurating sore.
<mul.2>, axle, Ir. @Ir{mul}, {mol}, shaft; cf. Gr. @Gr{μελíη}, ash, spear.
<mulachag>, a cheese, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{mulchán}:
<mulad>, sadness; root {mu}, mutter?
<mulart>, dwarf elder, Ir. @Ir{mulabhúrd}, {malabhúr}, {mulart} (O'B.):
<mulc.1>, push, butt; cf. Lat. {mulceo}, {mulco}, stroke, beat.
<mulc.2>, a shapeless lump, lump; @Ref<mulcan>, a pustule; cf. @Ref{meall.1}:
<mullach>, the top, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{mullach}: *{muldâko-}, *{muldo-}, top,
  head; Ag.S. {molda}, crown of the head; Skr. {mûrdhán}, top,
  head.
<mult>, a wedder, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{molt}, W. @W{mollt}, Corn. @Corn{mols}, vervex, Br.
  {maout}, a sheep (mas.): *{molto-}, root {mel}, {mol}, crush, grind,
  "mutilate"; Russ. {молитй}, cut, cut up, O.H.G. {muljan},
  triturate.  Hence M.Lat. {multo}, whence Fr. {mouton}, a sheep,
  Eng. @Eng{mutton}.
<munar>, a trifle, a trifling person, @Ref<monar>, diminutive person or
  thing:
<munganachd>, bullying:
<mùnloch>, a puddle, Ir. @Ir{múnloch}, gen. {múnlocha}; from {mún} and @Ref{loch}.
<mur>, unless, Ir. @Ir{muna} (Donegal Ir. @Ir{mur}; Monaghan has {amur} =
  {acht muna}, unless), M.Ir. @MIr{mun}, {moni}, {mona}, E.Ir., O.Ir.
  {mani}; from @Ref{ma}, if, and @Ref{ni.1}, not: "if not".  The G. {r} for {n} is
  possibly due to the influence of @Ref{gur} and of the verbal particl
  {ro-} (in {robh}); {mun-robh} becoming {mur-robh}.
<mùr.1>, a wall, bulwark, palace, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{múr}, W. @W{mur}; from Lat.
  {mûrus}, a wall.
<mùr.2>, countless number (as of insects), E.Ir. @EIr{múr}, abundance; Gr.
  @Gr{μυρíος} ({υ} long), countless, ten thousand; Skr. {bhûri}, many.
  Stokes compares rather Gr. @Gr{-μυρα} of @Gr{πλήμυρα} ({υ} long),
  @Gr{πλημυρíς} ({υ} short or long), flood tide, flood.  <mùr>, leprosy =
  countless number. See @Ref{mùire}.
--page 258
<muran>, sea-bent, Ir. @Ir{muraineach}, bent grass; from @Ref{muir}, the sea.
  Norse has {mura}, goose-grass.
<murcach>, sorrowful, Ir. @Ir{murcach}, {múrcach}; cf. M.Br. @MBr{morchet},
  anxiety, now {morc'hed}, Corn. @Corn{moreth}, chagrin.  Eng. @Eng{murky},
  Norse {myrkr} could only be allied by borrowing.  Cf. Lat.
  {marceo}, droop.
<mùrla>, a coat of mail:
<murlach>, the king-fisher:
<murlag>, @Ref<murluinn>, a kind of basket, @Ref<murlach>, fishing basket
  (M`A.), Ir. @Ir{muirleog}, a rod basket for sand eels and wilks
  (Donegal).  Cf. Sc. {murlain}, a narrow-mouthed basket of a
  round form.
<murlan>, rough head of hair:
<murrach>, able, rich, {murrtha}, successful, M.Ir. @MIr{muire}, {muiredach},
  lord, Murdoch; Ag.S. {maere}, clarus, Norse {maerr}, famous
  (Stokes), same root as @Ref{mór}.
<murt>, murder; see @Ref{mort}.
<murtachd>, sultry heat, weariness produced by heat:
<mus>, before, ere; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{mos}, soon, mox, used as a verbal
  particle; it is allied to @Ref{moch}, being from *{moqsu}, Lat. {mox}.
<musach>, nasty, Ir. @Ir{mosach} (O'R., Sh.), W. @W{mws}, effluvia, stinking,
  Br. @Br{mous}, muck, {mouz}, crepitus ventris: *{musso-}, *{mud-so-},
  root {mud}, be foul or wet; Gr. @Gr{μύσος} (= @Gr{μύδ-σος}), defilement,
  @Gr{μύδος}, clamminess, decay; Lit. {mudas}, dirty sea-grass: root
  @Ref{mu} ({mū}), soil, befoul, G. @Ref{mùin}, Eng. @Eng{mud}, etc.
<musg>, a musket, Ir. @Ir{músgaid}, L.M.Ir. @MIr{muscaed} (F.M.); from the
  Eng.
<mùsg>, rheum about the eyes, gore of the eyes; from the root {mû},
  befoul, be wet, as discussed under @Ref{musach}, @Ref{mùin}.
<musgan>, dry-rot in wood, Ir. @Ir{musgan}, mustiness, mouldiness; Lat.
  {muscus}, moss; Eng. @Eng{moss}, {mushroom}; Lit. {musai} (pl.), mould.
  This word is not in H.S.D., but it is implied in Arm. and is
  in M`E.; also in common use.
<mùsgan.1>, pith of wood, porous part of a bone (H.S.D.).  Armstron
  gives also the meanings attached to @Ref<musgan>, above; the
  words are evidently the same.
<mùsgan.2>, the horse fish:
<mùsuinn>, confusion, tumult, Ir. @Ir{múisiún}, codlata, hazy state
  preceding sleep.  From Eng. @Eng{motion}?
<mutach>, short, E.Ir. @EIr{mut}, everything short: *{mutto-}, root {mut},
  dock; Lat. {mutilus}, maimed (Eng. {mutilate}), {muticus}, docked;
  Gr. @Gr{μíτυλος}, hornless.
<mùtan>, @Ref<mutan>, a muff, fingerless glove, also @Ref<mutag> (Arms.); from
  @Ref{miotag}, with a leaning on @Ref{mutach}, short.  Thurneysen takes
--page 259
  it from @Ref{mutach} without reference to @Ref{miotag}.  Ir. has {muthóg}
  (Con.).
<mùth>, change, M.W. @MW{mudaw}; from Lat. {mûto}, I change.
<n->, from, in @Ref<a nuas>, @Ref<a nìos>, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{an-}; see @Ref{a.5}.
<na.1>, not, ne, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{na}: used with the imperative mood solely.
  It is an ablaut and independent form of the neg. prefix {in}
  (see @Ref{ion-}, @Ref{an-}), an ablaut of I.E. {nê}, Lat. {nê}, Gr. @Gr{νη-}; shorter
  from Lat. {nĕ-}, Got. {ni}, Eng. @Eng{not} ({ne-á-wiht}), etc.; further I.E.
  {ṇ-}, Gr. @Gr{ἀν-}, Lat. @Ref{in-}, Eng. @Eng{un-}, Gaelic @Ref{an-}.  See @Ref{nach}, which is
  connected herewith as Gr. @Gr{οὐκ}, @Gr{οὐ}; the W. is {nac}, {nag}, with
  imperative, Br. @Br{na}.
<na.2>, or, vel, Ir. @Ir{ná}, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{nó}, W. @W{neu}: *{nev} (Stokes, who
  allies it to Lat. {nuo}, nod, Gr. @Gr{νεύω}, Skr. {návate}, go remove;
  but, in 1890, @ExtRef{Bez. Beit.;16;51}, he refers it to the root {nu},
  Eng. @Eng{now}).  It can hardly be separated from @Ref{neo}, otherwise,
  q.v.  Strachan agrees.
<na.3>, than, Ir. @Ir{ná}, M.Ir. @MIr{iná}, E.Ir. @EIr{inda}, {indás}, O.Ir. @OIr{ind as}, {indás},
  pl. {indate} (read {indáte}); from the prep. {in} and {tá}, to be
  (@ExtRef{Zeuss;2;716-7}, who refers to the other prepositional comparative
  conjunction {oldaas}, from {ol}, de).  The use of {in} in
  O.Ir. as the relative locative may also be compared.
<na.4>, what, that which, id quod, M.Ir. @MIr{ina}, {ana}, {inna n-}, E.Ir.
  {ana n-}; for {an a}, O.Ir. rel. {an} (really neuter of art.) and
  G. rel @Ref{a.3}, which see.  Descent from {ní} or {ni}, without any
  relative, is favoured by Book of Deer, as {do ni thíssad}, of
  what would come.  Possibly from both sources.
<'na>, @Ref<'na->, in his, in her, in (my); the prep. @Ref{an.2} with the possessive
  pronouns: @Ref<'nam>, @Ref<'nar>, @Ref<'nad> (also @Ref<ad>, E.Ir. @EIr{at}, {it}), @Ref<'nur>, <'na>,
  @Ref<'nan>.
<nàbaidh>, @Ref<nàbuidh>, a neighbour; from the Norse @Ref<nà-búi>, neighbour,
  "nigh-dweller", the same in roots as Eng. @Eng{neighbour}.
<nach>, not, that not (conj.), that not = quin (rel), noone?  Ir., E.Ir.
  {nach}, W. @W{nac}, {nag}, not, Br. @Br{na}: *{nako}, from @Ref{na.1}, not, which
  see above, and {ko} or {k} as in Gr. @Gr{οὐκ} against @Gr{οὐ} (Stokes).  The
  {ko} has been usually referred to the same pronominal origin
  as {-que} in Lat. {neque}; it does appear in @Ref{neach}.
<nàdur>, nature, Ir. @Ir{nádúr}, W. @W{natur}; from Lat. {natura}.
<naid>, a lamprey (Sh., O'B.), Ir. @Ir{naid}:
<naidheachd>, news, Ir. @Ir{núaidheachd}, W. @W{newyddion}; from @Ref{nuadh},
  new.
<nàile>, yea! an interjection:
--page 260
<nàird>, @Ref<a nàird>, upwards, Ir. @Ir{anáirde}, E.Ir. @EIr{i n-ardi}, {i n-airddi};
  prep. {in} (now @Ref{an.2}) into, and @Ref{àirde}, height: "into height".
  This adverb is similar in construction to {a bhàn}, {a mach}, {a steach},
  etc., for which see @Ref{a.6}.
<nàire>, shame, Ir. @Ir{náire}, E.Ir. @EIr{náre}: *{nagro-}, shameful, root {nagh},
  be sober, Gr. @Gr{νήφω} (do.), Ger. {nüchtern}, fasting, sober.
<nàisneach>, modest; compare @Ref{nàistinn}.
<nàistinn>, care, wariness; from Norse {njósn}, spying, looking out,
  Got. {niuhseini}, visitation (@Gr{ἐπισκοπή}), Ag.S. {neósan}, search out.
<naitheas>, harm, mischief:
<nall>, from over, to this side, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{annall}; from {an} (see @Ref{a.5})
  and {all} of @Ref{thall}, q.v.
<nàmhad>, see @Ref{nàmhaid}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<nàmhaid>, an enemy, Ir. @Ir{námhaid}, g. {namhad}, O.Ir. @OIr{náma}, g.
  {námat}, pl.n. {námait}: *{nâmant-}, root {nôm}, {nem}, seize, take;
  Gr. @Gr{νέμεσις}, wrath, nemesis, @Gr{νωμάω}, @Gr{νέμω}, distribute; O.H.G.
  {nâma}, rapine, Ger. {nehmen}, take, Eng. @Eng{nimble}; Zend. {nemanh},
  crime, Alban. {name}, a curse.  Cf. W., Corn., and Br. @Br{nam},
  blame.
<na'n>, ({na'm}), if (with false supposition), M.G. {dane}, {da n-}, {da m-}
  (D.of L.), Ir. @Ir{da}, {dá} (for {da n-}, eclipsing), E.Ir. @EIr{dá n-},
  {día n-}, O.Ir. @OIr{dian}: the prep. {di} or {de} and rel. {an}; Manx {dy}.
  The G. form with {n} for {d} is puzzling, though its descent from
  {da n-} seems undoubted.
<naoi>, nine, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{nói n-}, W., Corn. @Corn@W{naw}, Br. @Br{nao}: *{neuṇ};
  Lat. {novem}; Gr. @Gr{ἐν-νέα}; Eng. @Eng{nine}, Ger. {neun}; Skr. {návan}.
<naoidhean>, an infant, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{nóidiu}, gen. {nóiden}: *{ne-vid-},
  "non-witted"?  Cf. for force Gr. @Gr{νήπιος}, infant (= @Gr{νη-πιος},
  not-wise one), from @Gr{-πιφος}, wise, @Gr{πινυτός} (do.), root {qei} of @Ref{ciall},
---gjk (1.16) originally @Gr{-πιfος} 
  q.v.  So Stokes in @ExtRef{Celt.Ph.;2;}; now *{no-vidiôn} (@Ref{no} = {ne}); cf.

<naomh>, holy, Ir. @Ir{naomh}, E.Ir. @EIr{nóem}, {nóeb}, O.Ir. @OIr{nóib}: *{noibo-s};
  O.Pers. {naiba}, beautiful, Pers. {nîw} (do.).  Bez. suggests the
  alternative of Lettic {naigs}, quite beautiful.
<naosga>, a snipe, Ir. @Ir{naosga}: *{snoib-sko-}, root {sneib}, {snib} of Eng.
  {snipe}?
<nar>, negative particle of wishing: *{ni-air}, for not; @Ref{air} and @Ref{ni.1}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {nì}
<nàsag>, an empty shell:
<nasg>, a band, tieband, collar, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{nasc}: *{nasko-}; O.H.G.
  {nusca}, fibula, Norse {nist}, brooch: *{ṇdh-sko-}, root {ṇdh} (Brug.).
  The verg {nasg}, O.Ir. @OIr{-nascim}, appears in Br. as {naska}.  The
  root {nedh} is in Skr. {nahyati}.  Others make the root {negh} of
  Lat. {nexus}, etc., and the root {snet} of @Ref{snàth}, q.v., has been
  suggested.  See @Ref{snaim} further.
<nasgaidh>, gratis, free, Ir. @Ir{a n-aisge}, freely, {aisge}, a gift.  See
  @Ref{asgaidh}.
--page 261
<natar>, nitre; from Eng. @Eng{natron}, {nitre},
<nathair>, a serpent, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{nathir}, W. @W{neidr}, Corn. @Corn{nader},
  M.Br. @MBr{azr}: *{natrîx}; Lat. {natrix}, water snake; Got. {nadrs},
  Norse {naðr}, Eng. @Eng{adder}.  The Teutonic words are regarded
  by Kluge as scarcely connected with Lat. {natrix}, whose root
  is {nat}, swim.
<-ne>, emphatic participle added to the pl. of 1st pers. pron. {sin-ne},
  {ar n-athair-ne}, "our father"; O.Ir. @OIr{ni}, {-ni}, used independently
  (= {nos}) and as a suffix.  See further under {sinne}.
<neach>, anyone, Ir. @Ir{neach}, O.Ir. @OIr{nech}, aliquis, W., Corn., Br. @Br@Corn@W{nep}, @Br@Corn@W{neb},
  quisquam: *{neqo-}, {ne-qo-}; Lit. {nekàs}, something, {nekúrs},
  quidam, Lett. {ká ne ká}, anyhow.  Stokes takes the {ne} from
  the negative root {ne} (see @Ref{na.1}); the {qo} is the pronominal stem
  of the interrogative (cf. Lat. {-que}, {neque}).
<nead>, a nest, Ir. @Ir{nead}, E.Ir. @EIr{net}, W. @W{nyth}, Corn. @Corn{neid}, Br. @Br{nez}, {neiz}:
  *{nizdo-s}; Lat. {nîdus}; Eng. @Eng{nest}; Skr. {nîdas}.  Supposed to
  be from *{ni-sed-}, "sit down".
<nèamh>, heaven, Ir. @Ir{neamh}, O.Ir. @OIr{nem}, W., Corn. @Corn@W{nef}, M.Br. @MBr{neff},
  now {env}: *{nemos}; Skr. {námas}, bowing, reverence; Lat.
  {nemus}, grove; Gr. @Gr{νέμος}, pasture: root {nem}, distribute, Gr.
  @Gr{νέμω} (do.), Ger. {nehmen}, take.  Gaulish has @Gaul{νεμητον} or
  @Gaul{νεμετον}, O.Ir. @OIr{nemed}, sacellum.  Often, and lately (1895) by
  Prof. Rhys, referred to the root {nebh}, be cloudy, Gr. @Gr{νέφος},
  cloud, Lat. {nebula} (see @Ref{neul}); but the Gaelic nasalized {èa} is
  distinctly against this, as also is the Br. @Br{env} (Stokes).
<neamhnuid>, a pearl, Ir. @Ir{meamhunn}, M.Ir. @MIr{niamnuid}, pearl, E.Ir.
  {nemanda}, pearly, O.Ir. @OIr{ném}, onyx (for {nem}?); root {nem} of
  @Ref{nèamh}.
<neanntag>, nettle, Ir. @Ir{neantóg}, E.Ir. @EIr{nenntai}, nettles, {nenaid}.  See
  @Ref{deanntag}.
<neapaicin>, a napkin, Ir. @Ir{naipicín}; from Eng.
<nèarachd>, happiness, usually @Ref<mo nèarachd>, lucky to, Ir. @Ir{moigheanéar},
  happy is he (O'B.), {is meanar duit-se}, happy it is for you
  (O'Growney), M.Ir. @MIr{mo ghenar duit}, good luck to you (F.M.),
  {mongenar} (L.B.), E.Ir. @EIr{mogenar}.  The root seems to be {mag}
  (I.E. @Ref{magh}), increase (see @Ref{mac}); cf. Lat. {macte}, root, {mak},
  great.
<nearag>, a daughter (Oss. Ballads); if a word properly handed
  down, it is interesting to compare it with the root of
  @Ref{neart}.
<neart>, strength, Ir. @Ir{neart}, O.Ir. @OIr{nert}, W., Corn. @Corn@W{nerth}, Br. @Br{nerz},
  Gaul. {nerto-}, root {ner}; Skr. {nár}, man; Gr. @Gr{ἀνήρ} (root {ner});
  Lat. Umbr. {nerus}, viros, Sab. {Nero}, fortis; Teut. {Nerthus},
  Norse {Njörðr}; Lit. {norėti}, to will.
--page 262
<neas>, weazel; see @Ref{nios}.
<neasg>, @Ref<neasgaid>, a boil, Ir. @Ir{neascóid}, E.Ir. @EIr{nescoit}: *{ness-conti-},
  from E.Ir. @EIr{ness}, wound (*{snit-so-}, root {snit}, cut. Ger. {schneide},
  Sc. {sned}), and {-conti-} found in @Ref{urchoid}?  Stokes regards E.Ir.
  {ness}, wound, as from *{nesko-}, root {neg}.
<neimh>, poison, Ir. @Ir{nimh}, {neimh}, O.Ir. @OIr{nem}, pl. {neimi}: *{nemes-},
  "something given", root {nem-}, distribute (as in @Ref{nèamh})?
<nèip>, a turnip; from the Sc. {neep}, M.Eng. {nēpe}, from Lat. {nâpus}.
<neo>, @Ref<air neo>, otherwise, alioquin (conj.); see @Ref{neo-}.
<neo->, un-, Ir. @Ir{neamh-}, {neimh-}, M.Ir. @MIr{nem}, O.Ir. @OIr{neb-}, {neph-}: *{ne-bo-};
  the {ne} is the negative seen in @Ref{na.1}, @Ref{ni.1}, but the {bo} is doubtful.
  Zimmer suggests that {b} is what remains of the subj. of @Ref{bu},
  be: "be not".
<neòinean>, @Ref<neònan>, the daisy, Ir. @Ir{nóinin}: "noon-flower", from
  @Ref{nòin}, noon.  Cf. the Eng. @Eng{daisy} for force.
<neònach>, eccentric, curious: *{neo-gnàthach}, "unwont".
<neonagan>, a stye in the eye (Arg.); cf. @Ref{leamhnad}.  Also {steònagan};
  cf. Sc. {styen}.
<neoni>, nothing, a trifle, O.Ir. @OIr{nephní}; from @Ref{neo-} and @Ref{ni.2}, thing.
<neul>, @Ref<nial>, a cloud, Ir. @Ir{neul}, O.Ir. @OIr{nél}, pl.acc. {níula}, W. @W{niwl}, mist:
  *{neblo-s}; Lat. {nebula}; Gr. @Gr{νεφέλη}; Ger. {nebel}, mist; O.Slav.
  {nebo}, sky; Skr. {nabhas}, mist.
<ni.1>, not, Ir. @Ir{ní}, O.Ir. @OIr{ní}, {ni}, W. @W{ni}: *{nei}; O.Lat. {nei}, Lat. {ni-}, {nê};
  O.H.Ger. {ni}, Ger. {nein}; O.Slav. {ni}, neque; Zend {naê};
  Gr. @Gr{νη-}.  Thur. says *{ne-est} = *{nést}, Celtic {níst}, {nìs}, {ni h-}
  non-aspirating.
<ni.2>, a thing, Ir. @Ir{nidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{ní}, res, probably a curtailed form of
  O.Ir. @OIr{aní}, id quod, from the art.neut. and the pronominal
  suffix {ei}, which Zimmer compares to Got. {ei}, that (conj.),
  {sa-ei}, {that-ei}, which is either the locative of pronominal {o-}
  (Gr. @Gr{εἰ}, I.E. {ei-so}, this here), or the particle seen in Gr.
  @Gr{οὑτοσ-í} ({i} long), an instrumental of Lat. {is}, Gaelic {e}, he.
  Some have regarded {ni} as from *{gnithe}, factum, which see in
  @Ref{nì.2}, will do.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {ní}
<nì.1>, cattle; this is the same as @Ref{ni.2}, thing.
<nì.2>, will do, Ir. @Ir{gním}, I do, O.Ir. @OIr{dogní}, facit; see @Ref{dèan}, @Ref{gnìomh}.
<niata>, courageous, Ir. @Ir{nia}, gen. {niadh}, a champion, {niadhas}, valour,
  M.Ir. @MIr{forniatta}, brave, E.Ir. @EIr{nia}, g. {níath}, possibly Ogam
  {neta}, {netta} (*{nêta}?): *{neid-}, Gr. @Gr{ὀνειδος}, revile, Lit. {náids},
  hatred, Skr. {nind}, mock, or *{ni-sed-}, down-setter?  Rhys
  ({Lect.}) cfs. the Teut. {nanþ}, venture, strive; this would give
  Gaelic preserved {d}.
<nic>, female patronymic prefix, M.Gaelic {nee} (D.of L.), Ir. @Ir{ní},
  M.Ir. @MIr{iní}, an abbreviation of O.Ir. @OIr{ingen}, now @Ref{inghean} or
--page 263
  @Ref{nighean} and {ui}, nepotis (Stokes).  The G. {nic}, really "grand-daughter",
  stands for {inghean mhic} or {ní mhic}; we have
  recorded in 1566 {Ne V^c Kenze} (M`Leod Charters).
<nigh>, wash, Ir. @Ir{nighim}, E.Ir. @EIr{nigim}, O.Ir. @OIr{dofonuch}, lavo, {nesta},
  laveris: *{ligô}, I.E. {neiℊô}; Gr. @Gr{νíζω}, @Gr{νíπτω}; Eng. @Eng{nick}, {Auld Nick},
  a water power, Ger. {nix}; Skr. {nij}, clean.
<nighean>, a daughter; a corruption of @Ref{inghean}, q.v.
<nimh>, poison, Ir. @Ir{nimh}; see @Ref{neimh}.
<nior>, not (with perfect tense), Ir. @Ir{níor}, E.Ir. @EIr{nír} = {ní-ro}; @Ref{ro} is the
  sign of past tenses.
<nios>, @Ref<neas>, a weazel, Ir. @Ir{neas}, {eas(óg)}, O.Ir. @OIr{ness}:
<nìos>, from below, up, Ir. @Ir{aníos}, E.Ir. @EIr{anís}; from {an} (see @Ref{a.5})
  and @Ref{ìos}.
<nis>, now, Ir. @Ir{anois}, M.Ir. @MIr{anosa}, E.Ir. @EIr{innossai}, O.Ir. @OIr{indossa};
  {ind} (now {an}) of the article and G. @Ref{fois}, rest.  The word
  appears in @Ref<a bhos>, q.v.  The form {indorsa}, this hour (= now),
  is rejected by Ascoli as a misspelling for {indossa}.
<ni 's>, id quod, the usual classical Gaelic with the verb substantive
  to denote comparative state: @Ref<tha i ni's fheàrr>, she is better,
  Ir. @Ref{nios}, M.Ir. @MIr{ní is}: "thing that is", from @Ref{ni.2} and @Ref{is.1}.  The
  usual and true Gaelic form @Ref<na 's> is not a degraded form of
  Ir. @Ir{ni 's}.  The G. {na} of {na 's} is simply @Ref<na.4> = id quod (see @Ref<na.4>);
  the Ir. is some mediæval development with {ní}, for old {ana},
  id quod, was lost, the simple {a} (art.) being used now in its
  stead, as in O.Ir.  As it was impossible to use {a} in the
  comparative construction with clearness, recourse was had to
  {ní is}.  Thus Ir.: An tan do thógradh ní ba mó do dheunamh
  = G. An @Ref{tan} a thogradh e na bu mhò a dhèanamh.  Hence
  <ni 's> should never have been used in Sc. Gaelic.
<niùc>, a corner; from the Sc. {neuk}, M.Eng. {nōk}.  Dial. @Ref<iùc>.
  Skeat thinks the Eng. is the borrower.
<no>, or, vel, Ir. @Ir{ná}, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{nó}, W. @W{neu}; see @Ref{na.2}.
<nochd.1>, to-night, Ir. @Ir{anochd}, O.Ir. @OIr{innocht}, hac nocte: the art. and
  {nochd}, night, W. @W{henoeth}, Corn. @Corn{neihur}, Br. @Br{neyzor}, {nos}:
  *{nokti-}; Lat. {nox}, {noctis}; Gr. @Gr{νύξ}, @Gr{νυκτός}; Got. {nahts}, Eng.
  {night}; Lit. {naktìs}; Skr. {nákti}.
<nochd.2>, naked, Ir. @Ir{nochdadh}, manifestation, O.Ir. @OIr{nnocht}, W. @W{noeth},
  Corn. @Corn{noyth}, Br. @Br{noaz}: *{noqto-}; Got. {naqaþs}, O.H.G. {nacot},
  Eng. @Eng{naked}; further cf. Lat. {nûdus} (*{nogvidus}); Slav. {nagŭ};
  Skr. {nagná}.
<nodadh>, a nod, suggestion; from the Eng.
<nodha>, new; see @Ref{nuadh}.
<noig.1>, the anus:
<noig.2>, old-fashioned face; {noigeiseach}, snuffy; {noigeanach} (D.
  Bàn):
--page 264
<noigean>, a noggin, Ir. @Ir{noigin}; from the Eng. @Eng{noggin}.  Skeat
  thinks the Eng. are the borrowers; but this is unlikely.
<nòin>, noon, Ir. @Ir{nóin}, g. {nóna}, evening, noon, E.Ir. @EIr{nóin}, {nóna}, W.
  {nawn}; from the Lat. {nôna} hora, ninth hour of the day, or 3
  o'clock.
<noir>, the east, Ir. @Ir{anoir}, O.Ir. @OIr{anair}, "from before", if one looks at
  the morning sun; from {an} (see @Ref{a.5}) and @Ref{air}.
<nollaig>, Christmas, Ir. @Ir{nodlog}, E.Ir. @EIr{notlaic}, W. @W{nadolig}; from
  Lat. {natalicia}, the Nativity.
<norra>, a wink of sleep (Arran), @Ref<norradh> (M`Rury):
<nòs.1>, a custom, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{nós}, W. @W{naws}, M.Br. @MBr{neuz}: *{nomzo-}, Gr.
  @Gr{νομος}, law, Lat. {numerus}.  Thurneysen thinks the Gadelic
  words are borrowed from the Welsh {naws}, from {gnaws} (see
  @Ref{gnàth}).  Stokes gives *{nomso-} as stem for Gadelic alone; the
  W. he regards as from {gnâ}, as above.  The ideal stem would
  be *{nâsto-}, root {nâd}.
<nòs.2>, a cow's first milk, E.Ir. @EIr{nus}; from {nua}, new, and {ass}, milk.
<nòtair>, a notary, Ir. @Ir{nótadóir}, O.Ir. @OIr{notire}; from Lat. {notarius}.
<nothaist>, a foolish person:
<nuadarra>, angry, surly; see @Ref{nuarranta}.
<nuadh>, new, Ir. @Ir{núadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{nue}, {núide}, W. @W{newydd}, O.Br.
  {nouuid}, Br. @Br{neuez}, Gaul. {novio-}: *{novio-s}; Lat. {novus}, {Novius};
  Gr. @Gr{νέος}, young, new; Got. {niujis}, Eng. @Eng{new}; Lit. {naújas};
  Skr. {navya}.
<'nuair>, when, "the hour that", Ir. @Ir{anuair}, E.Ir. @EIr{innúair}: the art.
  and word @Ref{uair}, q.v.
<nuall>, @Ref<nuallan>, a howling, cry, Ir. @Ir{nuaill}, E.Ir. @EIr{núall}: *{nouslo-n};
  Skr. {nu}, cry, {navati}; Lettic {nauju}, cry; O.H.G. {niumo},
  praise, rejoicing.
<nuarranta>, sad, surly; cf. the Ir. interjection {mo nuar}, my woe,
  root {nu} as above.
<nuas>, down, from above, Ir. @Ir{anuas}; see @Ref{a.5} and {uas}.
---gjk (1.14) @Ref{uas} doesn't exist
<nuaig>, as far as, O.G. {gonice} (B. of Deer), Ir. @Ir{nuige}, {go nuige}, E.Ir.
  {connici}: *{con-do-icci}; see @Ref{thig}, come.
<nuimhir>, number, so Ir.; from Lat. {numerus}.  Usually {uimhir},
  q.v.
<'n uiridh>, last year, Ir. @Ref<'nuraidh>, E.Ir. @EIr{innuraid}; the art. and
  O.Ir. dat. {urid}.  See @Ref{uiridh}.
<null>, over, to beyond; for @Ref{nunn} on the analogy of @Ref{nall}, and for
  dissimilation of the {n}s.  See @Ref{nunn}, the only Argyllshire form.
<nunn>, over, beyond, Ir. @Ir{anonn}, O.L. {inunn}; from the prep. {an}
  (see @Ref{a.5}) and {sund}, here ("from here"), W. @W{hwnt}, Br. @Br{hont}:
  ({so-u-to-s}), this.  The pronominal forms beginning in {so} and
  {to}, or {s} and {t} without {o}, are all from the roots @Ref{so} and {to}
  ultimately.
--page 265
<o.1>, the interjection "O! oh!" Ir. @Ir{o}; see vocative @Ref{a.1}.
<o.2>, from, @Ref<ab>, Ir. @Ir{ó}, O.Ir. @OIr{ó}, @Ref{ua} ({hó}, {hua}): *{ava}; Skr. {áva}, away,
  off; Lat. {au-}, as in {aufero}, take away; Ch.Sl. {u-}, Pruss. {au-}.
  Also @Ref<bho>, q.v.
<o.3>, since, when, with the rel. as @Ref<o 'n>, Ir. @Ir{ó}, O.Ir. @OIr{ó}, ex quo; it is
  merely the prep. @Ref{o.2} used as a conjunction.
<ob>, refuse, Ir. @Ir{obaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{obbaim}, {obbad} (inf.); referred to {ud-bad},
  "out-speak", the prefix {ud-}, out (allied to Eng. @Eng{out}, Skr.
  @Ref{ud}, out, of) and {ba}, speak, I.E. {bha}, Lat. {fari}, Gr. @Gr{φα} in
  @Gr{φημí}.  Ascoli gives the root as {ben} (see @Ref{bean.1}), repellere.
<òb>, a creek; from Norse {hóp}, small land-locked bay, Sc. {hope},
  Ag.S. {hóp}, valley.
<obaidh>, a charm; see @Ref{ubag}.
<obair.1>, a work, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{opair}, {oper}, O.Ir. @OIr{opred}, operatio; from
  Lat. {opus} (g. {operis}), {opera}.
†<obair.2>, a confluence; the usual pronunciation of the {Aber-} in
  place names.  See @Ref{abar}.
<obann>, sudden, Ir. @Ir{obann}, E.Ir. @EIr{opond}: *{od-bond}, e vestigio, from
  @Ref{bonn.1}?  Stokes refers it to the root of Gr. @Gr{ἄφνω}, O.Slav. {abije},
  immediately, suggesting *{ob-nó-}.  W. @W{buan} also suggests itself.
<ocar>, interest on money, Ir. @Ir{ocar}, W. @W{ocr}; from Norse {okr}, usury,
  Ag.S. {wocer}, Got. {wokrs}, Ger. {wucher}; root {veℊ}.
<och>, an interjection, alas! Ir. @Ir{och}, {uch}, O.Ir. @OIr{uch}, vae, {ochfad},
  sighing: *{uk}; Got. {aúhjôn}, make a noise, Norse {ugla}, Eng.
  {owl}; Lett. {auka}, stormwind, Serb. {uka}, a cry.
<ochd>, eight, Ir. @Ir{ochd}, O.Ir. @OIr{ocht n-}, W. @W{wyth} (*{okti}), Br. @Br{eiz}: *{oktô};
  Lat. {octo}; Gr. @Gr{ὀκτώ}; Got. {ahtau}; Skr. {ashtaú}.
<ochòin>, alas, Ir. @Ir{och ón}; literally "alas this"!  From @Ref{och} and the
  old pronoun {ón}, discussed under @Ref{eadhon}.
<ocras>, hunger, Ir. @Ir{ocrus}, {ocarus}, E.Ir. @EIr{accorus}.  See @Ref{acras}.  The
  Lat. {careo}, want, may be suggested as allied; root {ker}, {kor}.
<od>, yonder, yon; see @Ref{ud}.
<oda.1>, tongue of land; {oddr}.
<oda.2>, horse-race (Uist), race, race-course (Carm.); cf. N. @Ref{at}, horse-fight.
<odhar>, dun, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{odar}: *{odro-s}, for *{odh-ro-}, shady, Lat.
  {umbra} (= *{o-n-dhra}), {âter}, dark, Umbrian {adro}, atra.  Bez.
  suggests, with query, *{jodras}, allied to Lit. {jůdas}, dark.
  Thurneysen has referred *{odro-s} to I.E. {udro-}, otter, hydra,
  watery, the idea being "otter-like" or "water-like" (Gr. @Gr{ὕδωρ},
  Eng. @Eng{water}).
--page 266
<ofrail>, an offering, Ir. @Ir{ofráil}, M.Ir. @MIr{offráil}, E.Ir. @EIr{oifrend}; from
  Lat. {offerendum}.
<òg>, young, Ir. @Ir{óg}, O.Ir. @OIr{óc}, {óac}, W. @W{ieuanc}, Corn. @Corn{iouenc}, Br.
  @Br{iaouank}, Gaul. {Jovinc-illos}: *{jovṇko-s}, comparative {jovôs};
  Lat. {juvenis}, {juvencus}; Eng. @Eng{young}, Got. {juggs}; Skr. {yuvaçá},
  juvenile, {júvan}, young.
<ogha>, grandchild, Ir. @Ir{ó}, @Ref{ua}, g. {ui}, a grandson, descendant, O.Ir.
  @Ref{ua}, {aue}, {haue}, g. {haui}: *{(p)avio-s}; Gr. @Gr{παíς}, for {pafís}, boy;
  further Lat. {puer}, for {pov-er}; W. @W{wyr}; root {pu}, {pav}, {pov},
  beget.  Brug. (@ExtRef{Grund.;2;122}) refers it to *{avio-s}, an adj. from
  {avo-s}, grandfather, etc., Lat. {avus}.  Eng. @Eng{eame}.
†<oghum>, the "Ogam" writing, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ogum}, {Ogma ma
  Elathan} (son of knowledge), the Hercules of the Gaelic gods,
  Gaul. {Ogmios}, the Gaul. Hercules and god of eloquence:
  *{Ogambio-s}.  Cf. Gr. @Gr{ὄγμος} (*@Gr{γ-μος}?), a furrow, line, Skr.
  {ájmas}, course, run, root {ag}: the comparison is very doubtful.
  See @Ref{oidheam}.
<òglach>, a youth, servant, Ir. @Ir{óglach}, O.Ir. @OIr{óclach}; from {óg} and
  suffix {-lach} (see @Ref{teaglach}).
<ogluidh>, gloomy, awful, bashful, Ir. @Ir{ogluidh}, bashful; from Norse
  {uggligr}, fearful, Eng. @Eng{ugly}.
<oich>, interjectionn of pain, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{uch}.  See @Ref{och}.
<oide>, foster-father, step-father, Ir. @Ir{oide}, O.Ir. @OIr{aite}: *{attio-s}; Gr.
  @Gr{ἄττα}, father; Got. {atta}, father; Ch.Sl. {otici}, father; Skr.
  {attâ}, mother.
<oidhche>, @Ref<oiche>, night, Ir. @Ir{oidhche}, O.Ir. @OIr{aidche}, later {oidche}, also
  {adaig}: *{ad-aqiâ}, *{ad-aqî}, root {aq}, dark; Lat. {aquilus}, dark;
  Lit. {aklas}, blind; Gr. @Gr{ἄκαρον}, blind (Hes.).  Skr. {andhas},
  darkness, with root {andh}, {adh}, Lat. {ater}, etc., have been
  suggested, the @Ref{ad} of *{ad-aqia} being made the root and not
  the {aq} (see @Ref{odhar}).
†<oidheadh>, tragical death, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{oided}, {aided}; root {pad},
  {ped}, fall, Lat. {pestis} (Stokes).  See @Ref{eas}.
<oidheam>, a secret meaning, inference, idea (M`A., M`E.), a book
  (M`F., H.S.D.).  Properly @Ref{oigheam}, the same as {ogham} above
  (zeuss, Rhys' {Hib.Lect.}).
<oidheirp>, @Ref<oirpe>, an attempt: *{ad-erb-}, root {erb} of @Ref{earb.1}, q.v.?
<oifig>, an office, Ir. @Ir{oifig}, M.Ir. @MIr{oifficc}; from Lat. {officium} (Eng.
  {office}).
<òigeach>, a stallion, young horse; from @Ref{òg} and @Ref{each}.  Commonly
  @Ref<àigeach>, q.v.
<òigh>, a virgin, Ir. @Ir{óigh}, E.Ir. O.Ir. @OIr{óg}, {uag}, integer: *{augi-}, root
  {auℊ}, increase; Lat. {augeo}; Got. {áukan}, increase; Lit. {áugu},
  (Brug.).  Bez. (in Stokes' {Urkel.Spr.}) suggests Czech {pouhý},

<oigheam>, obedience, homage; cf. {gaidhe}.

<oighre.1>, ice, Ir. @Ir{oidhir}, M.Ir. @MIr{óigred}, E.Ir. @EIr{aigred}, snow; see @Ref{deigh}.

<oighreag>, cloudberry; founded on Sc. {averin}.
<oil.1>, vexation, offence, Ir. †{oil}.  The E.Ir. @EIr{áil} has {a} long, and is

  from the root of @Ref{oillt}.
<oil.2>, rear, educate, Ir. @Ir{oilim}, O.Ir. @OIr{ailim}; root {al} as in @Ref{altrum}.

<oilean>, @Ref<eilean.2>, training, nurture, Ir. @Ir{oileamhuin}, nurture, M.Ir.

<oillt>, horror, disgust, Ir. @Ir{oilt}: *{aleti-}, root {pal}, strike, whence
  Lat. {palma}, palm, {palpo}, palpitate, etc.?
<oineach>, liberality, Ir. @Ir{oineach}, mercy, liberality.  See @Ref{eineach}.
<òinid>, a fool, Ir. @Ir{óinmhid}, E.Ir. @EIr{óinmit}, {onmit}; from {ón-}, foolish,
  and {ment}, mind.  See @Ref{òinnseach}.
<òinnseach>, a foolish woman, Ir. @Ir{óinseach}; from {ón}, foolish, and
  the feminine termination {-seach}.
<oir.1>, edge, border, Ir., E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{or}, W. @W{gor-or}, ora superior: *{oro-}.
  Cf. Lat. {ôra}, coast, from which Thur. regards it as borrowed;
  it is not allied to Ger. {ufer}, coast.
<oir.2>, for, O.Ir. @OIr{ar}, {air}; the prep. @Ref{air} (*{are}) used as a conj.  The
  Ir. @Ir{óir}, because, for, O.Ir. @OIr{óre}, {úare}, abl. of O.Ir. @OIr{uar}, {huar},
  is from Lat. {hôra}, Gaelic @Ref{uair}.
<oir->, prefix denoting "ad" or "on", Ir. @Ir{oir-}, O.Ir. @OIr{air-}, {ar-}; this is
  the prep. @Ref{air} (*{are}).  Hence @Ref<oirbheart>, a good deed, Ir. do.,
  from @Ref{beart}; @Ref<oirbheas>, act of charity, from @Ref{beus}, conduct, etc.
  Sometimes confused with @Ref<òr->, gold, as prefix; cf. {óirdheirc}.
<oircheas>, pity, charity, Ir. @Ir{oircheasachd}, need, charitableness; cf.
  O.Ir. @OIr{airchissecht}, gratia, indulgentia, vb. {airchissim}, parcit,
  indulget: @Ref{air}+{cess}; root of @Ref{cead}?
<òirde>, a piece or lump of anything; see @Ref{òrd.2}.

<òirdheirc>, glorious, Ir. @Ir{óirdhearc}, O.Ir. @OIr{airdirc}, {erdirc}; from @Ref{air}

<oirfeid>, music, Ir. @Ir{oirfid}, E.Ir. @EIr{air-fitiud}, playing, inf. to {arbeitim},

<oirthir.1>, the east, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{airther}; comparative of @Ref{air}, ante -

<oisinn>, a corner, Ir. @Ir{isinn}, the temple, {fán na hoisean}, along the

<oit>, an interjection to denote the sense of burning heat; cf. O.Ir.
  {uit mo chrob}, alas for my hand!
<oiteag>, a breeze, puff of wind, Ir. @Ir{oiteóg}: *{atti-}, root {at}, as in Gr.

<oitir>, a ridge or bank in the sea, a low promontory, Ir. @Ir{oitír}: *{ad-tír},
  from {tír}, land, "to-land".
<òl>, drink, drinking, Ir. @Ir{ól}, {ólaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{ól}, inf. to {ibim}, O.Ir. @OIr{oul},
  *{povolo} (St.), drinking: *{potlo-}, root {po}, {pô}, drink; Lat. {póto},

  borrowed from Norse {öl}, Eng. @Eng{ale}.  The root {pele}, {plê}, full,
  has also been suggested; but it is unlikely here.
<ola>, oil, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ola}, W. @W{olew}, O.W. @OW{oleu}, Br. @Br{eol}; from Lat.
  {oleum}, Eng. @Eng{oil}.
<òlach>, a hospitable person: "boon-companion"; from @Ref{òl}.
<olann>, wool, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{oland}, O.W. @OW{gulan}, W. @W{gwlan}, Corn.
