  {vḷnâ}, {vḹnâ}.
<olc>, bad, Ir. @Ir{olc}, O.Ir. @OIr{olcc}, {olc}; cf. Lat. {ulciscor}, revenge, {ulcus},
  wound, Eng. @Eng{ulcer}; Gr. @Gr{ἓλκος}, wound.  Bez. suggests O.H.G.
  {ilki}, hunger, Lit. {alkti}, Ch.Sl. {alkati}, hunger.
<ollabhar>, a great army (M`F.), Ir. @Ir{ollarbhar}: {oll}+@Ref{arbhar}.  For
  {oll}, see @Ref{ollamh}; E.Ir. @EIr{arbar}, a host, is from {ber} (see @Ref{beir}).
<ollamh>, a learned man, a doctor, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ollam}, g. {ollaman};
  from Ir. @Ir{oll}, great (root {pol}, {pel}, {plê}, full, fill).
<òmar>, amber, Ir. @Ir{omra}, W. @W{amfer}; from the Eng.
<omhail>, attention, heed, Ir. @Ir{úmhail}; cf. G. {umhal}, obedient.
<omhan>, @Ref<othan>, froth of milk or whey, whey whisked into froth
  (Carm.), Ir. @Ir{uan}, E.Ir. @EIr{úan}, froth, foam, W. @W{ewyn}, Br. @Br{eon}:
  *{eveno-}, *{poveno-}; Lit. {putà}, foam, Lettic {putas}.
<onagaid>, confusion, row (Dial.); cf. @Ref{aonagail}.
--page 269
<onfhadh>, a blast, storm, raging of the sea, Ir. @Ir{anfadh}, E.Ir.
  {anfud}, for {an-feth}, "excess-wind", {feth}, aura; root {vê}, {ven},
  blow; Skr. {vā́ta}, wind; Gr. @Gr{ἄημι}, blow, @Gr{ἀήρ}, Lat. {aer}, Eng.
  {air}; Lit. {vėjas}, wind; further Lat. {ventus} and Eng. @Eng{wind}.
<onnchon>, a standard (M`F., O'B.), so Ir., also Ir. @Ir{onchú}, leopard,
  E.Ir. @EIr{onchú}, banner, leopard; the idea of "leopard" is the
  primary one.  From Fr. {onceau}, {once}, Eng. @Eng{ounce}, leopard.
<onoir>, respect, honour, Ir. @Ir{onóir}, E.Ir. @EIr{onóir}, {onoir}: from Lat.
  {honor}.
<ònrachd>, solitude, Ir. @Ir{aonarachd}; from {aonar}, @Ref{aon}.
<òr>, gold, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ór}, W. @W{aur}, Corn. @Corn{our}, Br. @Br{aour}; from Lat.
  @Ref<aurum>.
<òr->, prefix @Ref{air}, @Ref{oir-}, confused often with the prefix <òr->, gold; e.g.
  @Ref<òrbheart>, good (golden!) deed, which is for @Ref{oirbheart} (see
  @Ref{oir-}).
<òrag>, sheaf of corn (H.S.D.), {orag} (M`F., Arm.):
<oragan>, an organ, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{orgán}, E.Ir. @EIr{organ}, W. @W{organ}; from
  Lat. {organum}, Eng. @Eng{organ}.
<òraid>, a speech, Ir. @Ir{óraid}, prayer, oration, E.Ir. @EIr{orait}, prayer,
  orate; from Lat. {orate}, pray ye, {oratio}, speech.
<òran>, a song; this is for *{auran}, from the correct and still existing
  form @Ref<amhran>, Ir. @Ir{amhrán}, M.Ir. @MIr{ambrán}, Manx {arrane};
  from {amb}, i.e. @Ref{mu}, about, and {rann}?  Ir. @Ir{amhar}, E.Ir. @EIr{amor},
  music.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{amhra}, eulogy, especially in verse.  Cf. {amra}
  (Cholumcille), panegyric.
<orair>, a porch (@Ref<orrar>, M`D.): "front", from {air-} or {ar-} and @Ref{air}, a
  reduplication really of @Ref{air}, "on-before".
<òrais>, a tumultuous noise (H.S.D. from MSS.):
<òrd.1>, a hammer, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{ord}, O.Ir. @OIr{ordd}, W. @W{gordd}, O.Corn.
  {ord}, Br. @Br{orz}, {horz}, Gallo.Brit. {Ordo-vices}(?): *{ordo-s}, *{urdo-s},
  root {verdh}, {urdh}, raise, increase, whence or allied are Gr.
  @Gr{ὀρθός}, Lat. {arduus}, G. @Ref{àrd}, etc.; especially Skr. {vardhate},
  raise, increase, grow.  See @Ref{òrdag}.  Thur. thinks it perhaps
  possible that Romance {urtare}, hit, thrust, Fr. {heurter}, Eng.
  {hurt}, are hence, and Ascoli that Fr. {ortail}, big toe ({orddu} =
  {ortu}), is from {òrd}, the basis of @Ref{òrdag}, q.v.
<òrd.2>, a mountain of rounded form (topographical only); from
  @Ref{òrd.1}.
<òrdag>, thumb, Ir. @Ir{ordóg}, O.Ir. @OIr{orddu}, g. {ordan}: *{ordôs}, *{urdôs};
  same root as @Ref{òrd.1} above.
<òrdugh>, order, Ir. @Ir{ord}, {ordughadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{ord}, {ordaad}, ordination,
  W. @W{urdd}, {urddawd}, ordaining, Br. @Br{urz}; from Lat. {ordo}.
<organ>, organ; see @Ref{oragan}.
--page 270
<orra>, @Ref<ortha>, @Ref<orr'>, @Ref<or>, a charm, incantation, Ir. @Ir{orrtha} ({órrtha},
  Con.), @Ref{ortha}, prayer, charm (in this last sense pronounced
  {arrtha}), E.Ir. @EIr{ortha}, acc. {orthain}, prayer (especially in verse);
  from Lat. {ôrâtionem}, Eng. @Eng{oration}.
<orrais>, squeamishness, nausea:
<os.1>, above, Ir. @Ir{os}, {ós}, {uas}, O.Ir. @OIr{os}, {uas}, W. @W{uch}, Br. @Br{a}, {us}; see @Ref{uasal}
  for root.
<os.2>, an elk, deer, Ir. @Ir{os} (O'B.), E.Ir. @EIr{os}, {oss}, W. @W{uch}, pl. {uchen}, bos,
  Corn. @Corn{ohan}, boves, Br. @Br{oc'hen} (do.), O.Br. @OBr{ohen}, boum: *{okso-s}
  (for G.), *{uksen-} (for Brittonic); Got. {auhsa(n)}, Eng. @Eng{ox}, {oxen};
  Skr. {ukshán}, bull.
<os.3>, quoth; for {ors'}, from {or}, {ar}, say; see @Ref{arsa}.
<òs>, mouth of a river, harbour bar; from Norse {ôss}, river mouth;
  Lat. {ostium}.
<osadh>, desisting, Ir. @Ir{osadh}, truce, E.Ir. @EIr{ossad} (do.): *{ud-sta-}
  "stand out"; root {sta}, stand.
<osag>, a blast, breeze: *{ut-sâ}, root {ut}, {vet}, {ve}, blow, as in @Ref{onfhadh}.
<osan>, a hose, stocking, Ir. @Ir{assan}, caliga, O.Ir. @OIr{ossa}, {assa}, soccus,
  W. @W{hosan}, Corn. @Corn{hos}; from Ag.S. {hosa}, g. {hosan}, now {hose},
  {hōsen}, Norse {hosa}.
<oscach>, eminent, superior (Sh., O'B.), Ir. @Ir{oscách}; from @Ref{os.1} and {cách}.
<oscarach>, @Ref<oscarra>, bold, fierce, Ir. @Ir{oscar}, champion; from the
  heroic name @Ref<Oscar>, son of @Ref<Oisian> (Ir. {Oisín}, little deer or @Ref{os.2},
  q.v.).  Possibly @Ref<Oscar> stands for *{ud-scaro-}, "out-cutter",
  root {scar} of @Ref{sgar}, q.v.  Zimmer derives it from Norse {Ásgeirr},
  spear of the Anses or gods, and @Ref{Oisian} from the Saxon
  {Óswine}, friend of the Anses; which should give respectively
  {Ásgar} and {Óisine}, but the initial vowels are both {o} short in
  @Ref{Oscar} and @Ref{Oisian}.  Doomsday Book has Osgar.
<òsd>, @Ref<òsda>, @Ref<tigh òsda>, an inn, Ir. @Ir{tigh ósda}; from M.Eng. {ooste},
  {hóst}, hotel, house, hospitium, through Fr. from Lat. {hospitium}.
  Stokes takes it direct from O.Fr. {oste}.
<osnadh>, a sigh, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{osnad}, W. @W{uchenaid}, {uch}, Br. @Br{huanad}.
  Zimmer has analysed this into @Ref{os.1}, up, and @Ref{an.5} (root of @Ref{anail}),
  breat: "up-breath"; cf. Lat. {suspirium}, from {sup-spírium},
  "up-breath".  But consider *{ok-s}, from {uk} of @Ref<och>.  Cf. E.Ir.
  {esnad}, M.Ir. @MIr{easnadh}, song, moaning.
<ospag>, @Ref<osmag>, a gasp, sob, sigh, pang, Ir. @Ir{ospóg}, {uspóg}, {osmóg}; cf.
  @Ref{osnadh}.  Also @Ref{uspag}, q.v.
<ospairn>, gasping quickly, sobbing, sighing; from @Ref{os.3} and {spairn},
  q.v.  Cf. @Ref{uspairn}.
<othail>, @Ref<odhail>, confusion, hubbub, also (Dial., where pronounced
  {ow-il}), rejoicing; spelt also @Ref<foghail.2>, @Ref<fòghail>; root {gal}, as in
  @Ref{gal.2}?  For @Ref{odhail}, rejoicing, cf. M.Ir. @MIr{odhach}, ceolmar, also
--page 271
  {uidheach}, @Ref{od}, music; root {ved}; Gr. @Gr{ύδέο}, sing, praise, Skr.
  {vadati}, sing, praise; Lit. {vadinu}, rufe, root {ved}, {vad}, @Ref{ud},
  rufen.
<othar>, ulcer, abscess, Ir. @Ir{othar}, sick: *{putro-}; Lat. {puter}, Eng.
  {putrid}; root {pû}, {pu}, Eng. @Eng{foul}, etc.
<òtrach>, dunghill, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{otrach}, dunghill, O.Ir. @OIr{ochtrach}
  (= {othrach}?), excrement: *{puttr-}, root {put}, {pu}, Lat. {pûteo},
  {puter}, as under @Ref{othar}.  Ir. @Ir{othrach}, dung, *{putr}.
<pab>, shag, refuse of flax, wooly hair, and (M`A.) tassel (= @Ref<bab>),
  M.Ir. @MIr{papp}, {popp}, sprig, tuft, E.Ir. @EIr{popp}, bunch, which
  Stokes refers to a Celtic *{bobbú-}, *{bhobh-nú-}, from *{bhobh},
  *{bhabh}, Lat. {faba}, bean, Gr. @Gr{πομφός}, blister, {pémfix}, bubble,
  Lettic {bamba}, ball, I.E. {bhembho-}, inflate.  Eng. @Eng{bob}, cluster,
  bunch, appears in the 14th century, and Sc. has {bob}, @Ref{bab}
  correspondingly; the Gadelic and Eng. are clearly connected,
  but which borrowed it is hard to say.  the meaning of <pab>
  as "shag, flax refuse" appears in the Sc. {pab}, {pob}.  Borrowing
  from Lat. {papula}, pimple, root {pap}, swell, has been suggested.
<pac>, a pack, Ir. @Ir{paca}; from Eng. @Eng{pack}.  Hence @Ref<pacarras>, a mass
  of confusion.
<pacaid>, a packet; from the Eng.
<padhadh>, thirst, Manx {paa}; seemingly formed by regressive
  analogy from the adjective @Ref<pàiteach>, thirsty, a side-form of
  @Ref<pòiteach>, drinking, bibulous, from @Ref<pòit>, Lat. {pôtus}, drunk.
  M.Ir. @MIr{paadh} is explained by Stokes as *{spasâtu-}, root {spas} or
  {spes}, Lat. {spiro}, breathe, W. @W{ffun}, breath, from *{sposnâ}.  For
  phonetics see @Ref{piuthar}.
<padhal>, ewer, Ir. @Ir{padhal}, ewer, pail, W. @W{padell}, pan; from Eng.
  {pail}; cf. @Ref{adhal}, @Ref{paidhir}, @Ref{staidhir}, @Ref{faidhir}, @Ref{rathad}.
<pàganach>, heathen, Ir. @Ir{páganach}, {págánta}, M.Ir. @MIr{pagánta}; from
  Lat. {paganus}, villager, pagan, whence Eng. @Eng{pagan}.
<pàidhneachas>, a penalty, pledge; from @Ref{pàigh}, with leaning on
  @Ref{peanas}.
<paidhir>, a pair; from English {pair}, M.Eng. {peire}, Fr. {paire}, from
  Lat. {par}.  Cf., for phonetics, @Ref{faidhir} (fair) and @Ref{staidhir} (stair).
<paidir>, the Lord's prayer, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{paiter}, O.Ir. @OIr{pater}, W.
  {pater}; from Lat. {pater} in {Pater noster}, etc., which begins the
  prayer.
<paidreag>, a patch, clout:
<paidrean>, a cluster of grapes, posy, string of beads, Ir. @Ir{paidrín},
  rosary, necklace; from @Ref{paidir}.
--page 272
<pàigh>, @Ref<pàidh>, pay, Ir. @Ir{paidhe}, payment; from Eng. @Eng{pay}.
<pail-chlach>, pavement, Ir. @Ir{páil-chlach}, stone pavement, {páil},
  {pabhail}, pavement; formed from the Eng. @Eng{pave}, {pavement}.
<pailleart>, a box on the ear, a blow with the palm: *{palm-bheart},
  "palm-action", from Lat. {palma}, palm; cf. W. @W{palfad}, stroke
  of the paw, Br. @Br{palfod}, blow on the cheek.
<pàilliun>, a tent, Ir. @Ir{pailliún}; from M.Eng. {pailyoun} (Barbour),
  {pavilon}, Fr. {pavillon}, from Lat. {papilionem}, a butterfuly -
  tents being called after the butterfly because spread out like
  its wings.  Stokes takes it direct from the Fr.
<pailm>, palm tree, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{pailm}; from Lat. {palma}, whence
  Eng. @Eng{palm}.
<pailt>, plentiful, @Ref<pailteas>, plenty, Manx {palchys}, Corn. @Corn{pals},
  plenteous, M.Br. @MBr{paout}, numerous, Br. @Br{paot}, many, much;
  the G. is in all likelihood a Pictish word - a root {qalt}, I.E.
  {qel}, company, collection, as in @Ref{clann}, q.v.
<paindeal>, a panther; founded on the Eng. @Eng{panther}, M.Eng.
  {pantere}.
<painneal>, a panel, Ir. @Ir{paineul}, W. @W{panel}; from the Eng., M.Eng.,
  Fr. {panel}.
<painnse>, a punch; from the Sc. {painch}, {pench}, Eng. @Eng{pauch}.
<painntear>, a snare, Ir. @Ir{painteur}, M.Ir. @MIr{painntér}; from M.Eng.
  {pantere}, snare for birds, O.Fr. {pantiere}.  Hence Eng. @Eng{painter},
  boat rope.
<pàipeir>, paper, Ir. @Ir{pâipeur}, W. @W{papyr}; from Lat. {papyrus}, whence
  Eng. @Eng{paper}.
<paipin>, poppy, Ir. @Ir{paipín}, W. @W{pabi}; from Lat. {popaver}, whence
  Eng. @Eng{poppy}.
<pàirc>, a park, Ir. @Ir{páirc}, W. @W{parc}, {parwg}; from M.Eng. {park},
  {parrok}, now {park}.
<pairilis>, palsy, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{pairilis}, W. @W{parlys}; from Lat. {paralysis},
  whence Eng. @Eng{palsy}.
<pàirt>, a share, part, Ir. @Ir{páirt}, E.Ir. @EIr{pairt}, W. @W{parth}; from Lat.
  {pars}, {partis}, a part, whence Eng. @Eng{part}.  M.Ir. @MIr{pars}, point of
  time less than a minute.
<pàisd>, a child, Ir. @Ir{páisde}; formed from M.Eng. {páge}, boy, Sc.
  {page}, boy, now Eng. @Eng{page}.
<paisean>, a fainting fit, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{páis}, E.Ir. @EIr{paiss}, passio, suffering;
  from Lat. {passionem}, {patior}, suffer.
<paisg>, wrap; see @Ref{pasgadh}.
<pait>, a hump, lump, Ir. @Ir{pait}, M.Ir. @MIr{pait}, mass; also Ir. @Ir{paiteóg},
  small lump of butter; from Eng. @Eng{pat}.  Skeat thinks the Eng.
  is from the Gaelic, but the {p} is fatal to the word being native
  Gadelic.
--page 273
<pàiteag>, a periwinkle (H.S.D., for Heb.):
<palla>, green shelf in a rock (Lewis); N. {pallr}, step, dais.
<palmair>, a rudder, Ir. @Ir{palmaire}; see @Ref{falmadair}.
<pàlas>, a palace, Ir. @Ir{pálas}, W. @W{palas}; from Lat. {palatium}, whence
  Eng. @Eng{palace}.
<panna>, a pan; from M.Eng. {panne}, now {pan}.
<pannal>, @Ref<pannan>, a band or company, also @Ref<bannal>, q.v.; from
  Eng. @Eng{band}.
<pàp>, the pope, Ir. @Ir{pápa}, O.Ir. @OIr{papa}, W., Br. @Br{pab}; from Lat. {papa},
  father, pope, Eng. @Eng{pope}.
<paracas>, a rhapsody (M`A.):
<paradh>, pushing, brandishing; cf. @Ref{purr}.
<pàrant>, a parent; from Eng. @Eng{parent}.
<pardag>, a pannier (Arm.):
<pàrlamaid>, parliament, Ir. @Ir{pairliméid}, M.Ir. @MIr{pairlimint}; from
  Eng. @Eng{parliament}.
<parraist>, a parish, Ir. @Ir{parraisde}; from Eng. @Eng{parish}, M.Eng.
  {parische}.
<pàrras>, paradise, Ir. @Ir{parrthas}, O.Ir. @OIr{pardus}, W. @W{paradwys}, Br.
  {baradoz}; from Lat. {aradisus}.
<partan>, a crab, @Ref<portan> (Skye), Ir. @Ir{partán}, {portán}, M.Ir. @MIr{partan};
  Sc. {partan}.  E.Ir. @EIr{partar}, {partaing}, ruby?
<pasgadh>, a wrapping, covering, @Ref<pasgan>, a bundle, @Ref<pasg>, a faggot;
  cf. Ir. @Ir{faisg}, a pen, W. @W{ffasg}, bundle, which last is certainly
  from Lat. {fasces}.
<pasmunn>, expiring pang (H.S.D.); from Eng. @Eng{spasm}?  H.S.D.
  gives also the meaning "cataclysm applied to the sores of a
  dying person".
<peabar>, @Ref<piobar>, pepper, Ir. @Ir{piobar}, W. @W{pubyr}; from Lat. {piper},
  Eng. @Eng{pepper}, Norse {piparr}.
<peacadh>, sin, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{peccad}, g. {pectho}, W. @W{pechod}, Br. @Br{pechet};
  from Lat. {peccatum}, {peco}, Eng. @Eng{peccant}.
<péa-chearc>, pea-hen: from the Eng. @Eng{pea}.  See @Ref{peucag}.
<peall>, skin, hide, E.Ir. @EIr{pell}; from Lat. {pellis}, hide, allied to Eng.
  {fell}.
<peallach>, shaggy, matted in the hair, from @Ref<peall>, mat, hairy skin;
  see @Ref{peall} above.
<peallaid>, sheepskin; from Scotch {pellet}, a woolless sheepskin,
  Eng. @Eng{pelt}, from Lat. {pellis} through Fr.
<peanas>, punishment, Ir. @Ir{píonús}; from Lat. {poena}, with possibly a
  leaning on the English {punish}.
<peann>, a pen, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{penn}, W. @W{pin}; from Lat. {penna}.
--page 274
<pearluinn>, fine linen, muslin; from Sc. {pearlin}, lace of silk or
  thread, Eng. @Eng{purl}, edgin of lace, from Fr. {pourfiler}, Lat.
  {filum}, thread.
<pearsa>, a person, Ir. @Ir{pearsa}, g. {pearsan}, O.Ir. @OIr{pearsa}, g. {persine};
  from Lat. {persona}, Eng. @Eng{person}.
<pearsail>, parsley, Ir. @Ir{pearsáil}; from M.Eng. {persil}, Eng. @Eng{parsley}.
<peasair>, pease, Ir. @Ir{pis}, a pea, pl. {piseanna}, W. @W{pys}, Br. pl. {piz};
  from Lat. {pisum}, Eng. @Eng{pease}.
<peasan>, impudent fellow, varlet; from Eng. @Eng{peasant}.
<peasg>, gash in skin, chapped gashes of hands, cranny, W. @W{pisg},
  blisters; G. is possibly of Pictish origin.  The Sc. {pisket}
  shrivelled has been compared.
<peata>, a pet, Ir. @Ir{peata}, E.Ir. @EIr{petta}; Eng. @Eng{pet}.  Both Eng. and
  Gadelic are formed on some cognate of Fr. {petit}, little, Eng.
  {petty} (Stokes).
<peic>, a peck, Ir. @Ir{peic}, W. @W{pec}; from Eng. @Eng{pec}.
<peighinn>, a penny, Ir. @Ir{pighin}, E.Ir. @EIr{pingin}; from Ag.S. {pennding},
  Norse {peningr}, now Eng. @Eng{penny}.
<peilig>, a porpoise; from Sc. {pellack}.
<peileasach>, frivolous; cf. Sc. {pell}, a soft, lazy person.
<peileid.1>, cod, husk, bag:
<peileid.2>, a slap on the head, the skull or crown of the head; in the
  last sense, cf. Sc. {pallet}, crown of the head, M.Eng. {palet},
  head-piece.  In the sense of "slap", cf Eng. @Eng{pelt}.
<peileir>, a bullet, Ir. @Ir{peileur}, L.M.Ir. @MIr{pelér}: from some French
  descendant of Lat. {pila}, ball, and allied to Eng. @Eng{pellet}, O.Fr.
  {pelote}, ball, Sp. {pelote}, connon ball.
<peilisteìr>, a quoit, flat stone; formed from @Ref{peileir} stem?
<peillic>, a covering of skins or coarse clothe, Ir. @Ir{peillic}, a booth
  whose roof is covered with skins, E.Ir. @EIr{pellec}, basket of
  untanned hide; from Lat. {pelliceus}, made of skins, from
  {pellis}.
<peinneag>, a chip of stone for filling crevices in wall; from Sc.
  {pinning}, {pinn} (do.), allied to Eng. @Eng{pin}.
<peinnteal>, a snare; another form of {paintear}, q.v.
<peirceall>, the jaw, lower part of the face, corer, Ir. @Ir{peircioll},
  cheekblade, corer: *{for-ciobhull}, "on-jaw"?  See @Ref{ciobhull}.
<peirigill>, deger, Ir. @Ir{peiriacul}; from Lat. {periculum}.
<péire>, the buttocks, Ir. @Ir{péire} (O'R.); cf. Corn. @Corn{pedren}, buttock, W.
  {pedrain}.  The word @Ref<peurs>, lente perdere (M`A.), is doubtless
  connected.
<peireid>, ferret (M`A.).
<péiris>, testiculi (H.S.D.); apparently from Fr. {pierre}.
--page 275
<peiteag>, waistcoat, short jacket; from Sc. {petycot}, a sleeveless
  tunic worn by men, Eng. @Eng{petticoat}.  Manx has {pettie}, flanel
  waistcoat, {peddee}, waistcoat.
<peithir.1>, a forester (@Ref<pethaire>, M`D.), @Ref<peithire>, a message boy
  (M`A.); cf. Sc. {peddir}, a pedlar, Eng. @Eng{pedlar}.
<peithir.2>, @Ref<beithir>, thunderbolt; a mythic and metaphoric use of
  @Ref{beithir}, q.v.
<peitseag>, a peach; Ir. @Ir{peitseóg}; from the Eng.
<peòdar>, pewtar, Ir. @Ir{péatar}, W. @W{ffeutar}; from Eng. @Eng{pewter}.  Also
  @Ref<feòdar>, q.v.
<peucag>, pea-hen, Ir. @Ir{pêacóg}, peacock (Fol.); from Eng. @Eng{peacock}.
<peur>, a pear, Ir. @Ir{piorra}, @Ref{péire} (O'R.), W. @W{peran}; from Eg. {pear}.
<peurda>, flake of wool off the cards in the first carding:
<peurdag>, @Ref<piartag>, a partridge, Ir. @Ir{pitrisg} (Fol.); G. is from Sc.
  {pertrik}, a side form of Eng. @Eng{partridge}, Lat. {perdic-em}.
<peursair>, perchman, shore herd (Carm.):
<pian>, pain, Ir. @Ir{pían}, poena, W. @W{poen}, pain, Corn. @Corn{peyn},
  Br. @Br{poan}; from Lat. {poena}, Eng. @Eng{pain}.
<pibhinn>, lapwing; from Sc. {peeweip}, Eng. @Eng{peewit}.  The true G. is
  @Ref<adharcan>, "horned one" (from @Ref{adharc}, because of the appearance
  of its head).
<pic>, pitch, Ir. @Ir{pic}, W. @W{pyg}; from M.Eng. {pik}, now {pitch}.
<pìc>, a pike, Ir. @Ir{pice}, W. @W{pig}, from the Eng.
<piceal>, pike, Ir. @Ir{picill} (Fol.); from the Eng.
<pigeadh>, @Ref<pigidh>, earthen jar, Ir. @Ir{pigín}, W. @W{picyn}; from Eng., Sc.
  {piggin}, {pig}, which is a metaphoric use of Eng. @Eng{pig}, sow.
<pighe>, @Ref<pigheann>, a pie, Ir. @Ir{píghe}; from the Eng.
<pigidh>, robin redbreast (H.S.D.); a confused use of Eng. @Eng{pigeon}?
<pilig>, peel, peeling (Dial.); from the Eng.  See @Ref{piol}.
<pill.1>, a sheet, cloth, the cloth or skin on which corn is winnowed;
  a particular use of the oblique form of @Ref{peall}, q.v.  M.Ir.
  {pill} or {pell} means "rug".
<pill.2>, turn, Ir. @Ir{pillim}, better {fillim} (O'B.); see @Ref{till} for discussion
  of the root.
<pill.3>,  return; see @Ref{till}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<pillean>, pack-saddle, pillion, Ir. @Ir{pillín}, W. @W{pilyn}; Eng. @Eng{pillion} is
  allied, if not borrowed, according to Skeat.  All are formed
  on Lat. {pellis} (see @Ref{peall}).  Sc. has {pillions} for "rags"; Br.
  {pill} (do.).
<pinne>, a pin, peg, Ir. @Ir{pionn} (Lh.), W. @W{pin}; from M.Eng. {pinne},
  now {pin}.
<pinnt>, a pint, Ir. @Ir{piúnt} (Fol.); from the Eng.
<pìob>, a pipe, a musical instrument, Ir. @Ir{píob}, E.Ir. @EIr{píp}, pl. {pipai}
  (Lib.Leinster), (music) pipe; from Med.Lat. {pîpa}, whence
  Ag.S. {pîpe}, Eng. @Eng{pipe}, Ger. {pfeife}, Norse {pípa}.  W., Corn.,
  and Br. have {pib}, pipe, similarly borrowed.
--page 276
<piobar>, pepper; see @Ref{peabar}.
<pìobull>, the bible (Dial.): see @Ref{bìobull}.
<pioc>, pick, Ir. @Ir{piocaim}; from Eng. @Eng{pick}.  Thur. thinks that W.
  {pigo} is ultimately from the Romance {picco} (point), Fr. {pique},
  or allied thereto.  Skeat takes the Eng. from Celtic; but see
  Bradley's {Stratmann}.
<piocach>, a saith, coalfish (Wh.):
<piocaid>, pickaxe, Ir. @Ir{piocóid}; from @Ref{pioc}, Eng. @Eng{pick}, a pickaxe, from
  Fr. @Ref{pic} (do.).  Whether the termination is Gadelic or the Fr.
  word {piquet}, little pickaxe, Eng. @Eng{picket}, was borrwed at once,
  it is hard to say.
<pìochan>, a wheezing, Manx {piaghane}, hoarseness, Ir. @Ir{spiochan};  Sc.
  {pech}, {pechin}, panting, {peught}, asthmatic.  Onomatopoetic
  Cf. Lat. {pipire}, chirp, pipe.  W. has {peuo}, pant.
<pioghaid>, @Ref<pigheid>, a magpie, Ir. @Ir{pioghaid} (Fol.), {pighead} (O'R.);
  from Sc. {pyat}, {pyet}, diminutive of {pie}, M.Eng. {pye}, now
  usually {mag-pie}.
<piol>, nibble, pluck; from Eng. @Eng{peel}, earlier, {pill}, {pyll}, peel, pluck,
  ultimately from Lat. {pellis}.  Also @Ref<spiol>, q.v.  W. has {pilio},
  peel, strip.
<piollach>,  (1) neat, trim (M`F., H.S.D., Arm.),  (2) hairy
  (= @Ref<peallach>, of which it is a side form, H.S.D., etc.), fretful,
  curious-looking (M`A.).  The second sense belongs to @Ref{peallach},
  the first to @Ref{piol}: "pilled".
<piollaiste>, trouble, vexation: "plucked" state, from @Ref{piol}?
<pioraid>, hat, cap; see @Ref{biorraid}.
<pìorbhuic>, @Ref<piorrabhuic>, periwig, Ir. @Ir{peireabhuic}; from the Eng.
<piorr>, scrape or dig (H.S.D.), stab, make a lunge at one (M`A.);
  the first sense seems from Sc., Eng. @Eng{pare}; for the second, see
  @Ref{purr}.
<piorradh>, a squall, blast; from L.M.Eng. {pirry}, whirlwind,
  blast, Sc. {pirr}, gentle breeze, Norse {byrr}, root {bir}, {pir}, of
  onomatopoetic origin (Skeat, sub {pirouette}, for Eng.).
<pìos.1>, a piece, Ir. @Ir{píosa}; from Eng. @Eng{piece}, Fr. {pièce}, Low Lat.
  {pettium}, from Gaulish *{pettium}, allied to G. {cuit}, Pictish {pet}
  (see @Ref{pit}).
<pìos.2>, a cup, Ir. @Ir{píosa}; from Lat. {pyxis}, box (Stokes).
<piostal>, a pistol, so Ir.; from Eng.
<pipheanaich>, giggling (M`D.):
<piseach>, prosperity, luck, Manx {bishagh}, Ir. @Ir{biseach}, M.Ir. @MIr{bisech}.
  Cf. Ir. @Ir{piseóg}, witchcraft, M.Ir. @MIr{pisóc}, charm, Manx {pishag},
  charm, Corn. @Corn{pystry}, witchcraft, M.Br. @MBr{pistri}, veneficium,
  which Bugge refers to Lat. {pyxis}, medicine box (see @Ref{pìos.2}).
<piseag>, a kitten, Ir. @Ir{puisín}; from Eng. @Eng{puss}.  Aran Ir. @Ir{piseóg},
  sea bream.
--page 277
<pit>, hollow or pit (Dict. only), @Gr{κύσθος}, M.G. {pit} (D.of L.), Manx
  {pitt}, Ir. @Ir{pit}; from Ag.S. {pyt}, pit, well, now {pit}, from Lat.
  {puteus}, well.  for force, cf. Br. @Br{fetan}, fountain, {fete}, @Gr{κύσθος}.
  The non-existent Dict. meaning is due to the supposed force
  of topographic {pit} discussed in @Ref{Pit-}.
<Pit->, prefix in farm and townland names in Pictland, meaning
  "farm, portion"; O.G. {pet}, {pett}, g. {pette} (B.of Deer), a
  Pictish word allied to W. @W{peth}, part, Gaelic @Ref{cuid}.  See further
  under @Ref{cuid} and @Ref{pìos.1}.
<piùg>, a plaintive note (H.S.D.); cf. W. @W{puch}, sigh.  Onomatopoetic?
<piuthar>, sister, Ir. @Ir{siur}, E.Ir. @EIr{siur}, {fiur}, g. {sethar}, {fethar}, O.Ir.
  {siur}, W. @W{chwaer}, Corn. @Corn{huir}, Br. @Br{hoar}: *{svesôr}, g. {svestros}
  (Stokes); Lat. {soror} (= {sosor}); Eng. @Eng{sister}; Lit. {sesu@ó}; Skr.
  {svâsar}.
<plab>, soft noise as of a body falling into water; from Sc. {plope},
  Dial. Eng. @Eng{plop}: onomatopoetic like {plump}.  Skeat compares
  Eng. @Eng{blab}.  See @Ref{plub.1}.
<placaid>, a wooden dish; through Sc. (?) from Fr. {plaquette},
  {plaque}, a plate, whence Eng. @Eng{placard}, Sc. {placad}.  M`A.
  gives also the meaning "flat, broad, good-natured female",
  which is a metaphoric use.
<plaibean>, a lump of raw flesh, a plump boy; founded on Sc.
  {plope}, as in @Ref{plab} above.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{plump}.
<plaide>, a blanket, Ir. @Ir{ploid}; Eng. @Eng{plaid}, Sc. {plaiden}, coarse
  woollen cloth, like flannel, but twilled: all are founded on
  Lat. {pellis}, but whether invented by Gadelic or English is at
  present doubtful.  Skeat says it is Celtic, a view which, as
  the case stands, has most to say for it; cf. G. @Ref<peallaid>,
  sheepskin.  Dunbar's "Hieland {Pladdis}".
<plàigh>, a plague, Ir. @Ir{pláigh}, E.Ir. @EIr{plág}, W. @W{pla}; from Lat. {plâga},
  disaster, M.Eng. {pláge}, Eg. {plague}.
<plais>, a splash; from Sc. {plash}, to strike water suddenly, Eng.
  {plash}, {splash}.
<plam>, anything curdled: cf. Br. @Br{plommein}, a clot, as of blood.
  See @Ref{slaman}.  M`A. gives it the meaning of "fat blubber
  cheek".  Arg. has "@Ref<bainne plumaichte>", curdled or soured
  mild.
<plang>, a plack - a Scots coin; from Sc. {plack}, a copper coin equal
  to four pennies Scots, which came with the Flemish, etc.,
  and is allied to Fr. {plaque}, used of coin, though really a
  "metal dish, etc.".  See @Ref{placaid}.
<plangaid>, a blanket; Ir. @Ir{plainceud} (Fol.); from the Eng.
<plannta>, a plant, Ir. @Ir{planda}; from Eng. @Eng{plant}, Lat. {planta}.
--page 278
<plaosg>, a husk, shell, Manx {pleayse}, Ir. @Ir{plaosg}, W. @W{plisg} (pl.), Br.
  {pluskenn}.  This Ernault considers borrowed from Romance -
  Fr. {peluche}, shag, plush, Eng. @Eng{plush}, from Lat. *{pilucius},
  hairy, {pilus}, hair: an unlikely derivation.  Seemingly
  @Ref<blaosg> is another form (Manx {bleayst}, M.Ir. @MIr{blaesc}, W. @W{blisg}):
  *{bhloid-sko-}, root {bhlōi}, {bhlē}, {bhel}, swell, etc.; Gr. @Gr{φλοιός}
  (*@Gr{βχλοvιο-}?), bark, shell, @Gr{φλέδων}, bladder.
<plàsd>, a plaster, Ir. @Ir{plasdruighim}; from the Eng.
<plàt>, a sort of cloth made of straw; from Sc. {plat}, plait, Eng.
  {plait}.  M`A. has the meaning "thrust, clap on", from Sc.
  {plat}, a stroke to the ground, blow with the fist, M.Eng.
  {platten}, strike, throw down, Ag.S. {plaettan}.
<plath>, @Ref<pladh>, a flash, glance, puff of wind; from *{svḷ-}, root {svel} of
  @Ref{solus}?
<pleadhag>, a dibble, paddle; also @Ref<bleaghan>, @Ref<spleadhan>, q.v.
<pleadhart>, a buffet, blow; from @Ref{pailleart}?
<pleasg.1>, a noise, crack, Ir. @Ir{pléasg} ({pleasg} Lh.) - an Ir. word (M`A.),
  Ir. @Ir{pleasgan} or {pléascán}, noise: cf. Sc. {pleesk}, {plesk}, plash,
  {pleesh-plash}, dabbling in water or mud.
<pleasg.2>, a string of beads:
<pleat>, a plait; from Sc. {plett}, Eng. @Eng{plait}.
<pleid>, solicitationn; see @Ref{bleid}.
<pleigh>, quarrel, fight, Ir. @Ir{pléidh}, debate; Sc. {pley}, quarrel, debate,
  all from M.Eng. {pleie}, {plege}, Ag.S. {plega}, game, fight, Eng.
  {play}.
<pleoisg>, @Ref<plodhaisg>, a booby, simpleton; cf. W. @W{bloesg}, a stammerer
  ({mlaisqo-}), Skr. {mlecchati}, talk barbarously, {mleccha},
  foreigner, Lat. {blaesus}, Gr. @Gr{βλαισός}.
<pleòdar>, pewter; from Eng. @Eng{spelter}, with leaning on @Ref{peòdar}.
<pliad> (H.S.D., Dial.), a plot of ground; of Scandinavian origin -
  Sw. {plaetti}, a plot of ground, Eng. @Eng{plot}, {plat} (Dr Cameron).
<pliadach>, flat, as of foot (Carm.):
<pliadh>, a splay foot; from Eng. @Eng{splay}.
<pliaram>, babbling (H.S.D.); for *{bliaram}; see @Ref{blialum}, from Sc.
  {blellum}.
<plionas>, a hypocritical smile (Wh.):
<pliotair> (@Ref<pliodaire>, M`A.), a fawner, cajoler; cf. Ir. @Ir{pleadail},
  pleading; from Eng. @Eng{plead}.
<pliut>, a clumsy foot; cf. Sc. {ploots}, the feet when bare (Shet.),
  {plootsacks}, feet.  Hence @Ref<pliutach>, a seal.  See @Ref{spliut}.
<ploc>, a roud mass, clod, block (rare), Ir. @Ir{bloc}, a block, W. @W{ploc},
  block, plug, Br. @Br{bloc'h}, block, mass: Gadelic and W. are from
  Eng. @Eng{block}, from Fr. {bloc}, of German origin - Ger. {block}, clod,
  lump, from the root of Eng. @Eng{balk}.
--page 279
<plod.1>, a clod; from Sc. {plod}, {ploud}, a green sod (Aberdeen).
<plod.2>, a fleet, Manx {plod}; from Norse {floti}, Eng. @Eng{fleet}, {float}, etc.
<plod.3>, a pool of standing water, Manx, Ir. @Ir{plod}; from M.Eng.
  {plodde}, a puddle, Eng. @Eng{plod}, originally "to wade through
  water", {ploude}, wade through water (Grose), Sc. {plout}, {plouter}
  (do.).
<plodadh>, parboiling; from Sc. {plot}, to scald or burn with boiling
  water, {plottie}, a rich and pleasant hot drink made of cinnamon,
  cloves, etc.  Also "floating" wood down river.
<ploic>, the mumps; see @Ref{pluic}.
<plosg>, palpitate, throb, Ir. @Ir{plosg} (O'R., Fol.), {blosgadh}, sounding,
  E.Ir. @EIr{blosc} ("ro clos blosc-béimnech a chride", the hitting
  sound of his heart).  See @Ref{blosg}.
<plub.1>, a plump, sudden fall into water; from Eng. @Eng{plump}. Cf.
  @Ref{plab}.  Hence @Ref<plubraich>, gurgling, plunging; etc.
<plub.2>, an unweildy mass or lump; from the Eng. @Eng{plump}.
<plubair>, a booby, one speaking indistinctly, blubberer; from Eng.
  {blubber}.
<pluc.1>, a lump, pimple, Manx {plucan}, pimple; seemingly a side
  form of @Ref{ploc}.  M.Ir. has {plucc}, club or mace.  Cf. Sc. {pluke},
  a pimple.
<pluc.2>, pluck, Manx {pluck}; from the Eng.
<plùc>, beat, thump; from M.Eng. {pluck}, a stroke.
<plucas>, the flux; founded on Lat. {fluxus}?
<plùch>, squeeze, compress, Ir. @Ir{pluchaim}, Manx {ploogh}, suffocation:
<pluic>, cheek, blub cheek, Ir. @Ir{pluc}: "puffed cheek"; from @Ref{ploc}.
<pluideach>, club-footed; see @Ref{pliut}.
<plùirean>, a flower, Ir. @Ir{plúr}; from M.Eng. {flour} (now {flower}),
  O.Fr. {flour} (now {fleur}).
<plum>, plunge into water; see @Ref{plumb}.
<plùm>, one who sits stock still, dead calm:
<pluma>, @Ref<plumba>, a plummet, Ir. @Ir{plumba}; from Eng. @Eng{plumb}, Fr.
  {plomb}, from Lat. {plumbum}, lead.
<plumb>, noise of fallinng into water, plunge; from Eng. @Eng{plump}.
<plumbas>, @Ref<plumbais>, a plum, Ir. @Ir{pluma}; from M.Eng. {ploume},
  now @Ref{plum}.
<plundrainn>, plunder, booty; from Eng. @Eng{plundering}.
<plùr>, flour, Ir. @Ir{flúr}; from M.Eng. {flour}; same as Eng. @Eng{flower},
  {flour} being for "flower of wheat".
<plutadh>, falling down, as of rain; from Sc. {plout}, Belg. {plotsen},
  Ger. {plotzlich}, sudden, from *{plotz}, "quickly falling blow".
<pobull>, people, Ir. @Ir{pobal}, O.Ir. @OIr{popul}, W., Br. @Br{pobl}, Corn. @Corn{pobel};
  from Lat. {populus}, whence Eng. @Eng{people}.
<poca>, a bag; from Sc. {pock}, Ag.S. {poca}, Norse {poki}, O.Fr. {poche}.
--page 280
<pòca>, @Ref<pòcaid>, pocket, pouch, Ir. @Ir{póca}, {pócait} (F.M.), bag, pouch;
  from M.Eng. {póke}, Ag.S. {poca}, as @Ref{poca}.  Eng. @Eng{pocket},
  M.Eng. {poket}, is a diminutive.  K.Meyer takes the Ir. from
  the Norse {poki}.
<pòg>, @Ref<pàg>, a kiss, Manx {paag}, Ir. @Ir{póg}, O.Ir. @OIr{póc}, {pócnat}, osculum,
  W. @W{póc}, Br. @Br{pok}; from Lat. {pâcem}, "the kiss of peace", which
  was part of the ritual for the Mass; hence in Church Lat.
  {dare pacem}, means "to give the kiss".  The old Celtic liturgies
  generally carry the rubric "Hic pax datur" immediately
  before the Communion.
<pòireagan>, rag, rags (M`D.):
<poit>, a pot, Ir. @Ir{pota}, W. @W{pot}, Br. @Br{pod}; from Eng. and Fr. {pot}, from
  Lat. {potare} ultimately.  See @Ref{pòit}.
<pòit>, drinking, tippling, Ir. @Ir{póit}: from Lat. {pôtus}, drunk (Eng.
  {potation}, {poison}, etc.).  See @Ref{òl}.
<poitean>, a small truss of hay or straw; see @Ref{boitean}.
<poll.1>, a pool, a hole, mud, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{poll}, W. @W{pwll}, Corn. @Corn{pol}, Br.
  {poull}; from Late Lat. {padulus}, pool, a metathesis of {palus},
  {paludis}, marsh (Gaidoz), whence Ital. {padula}, Sp. {paúl}.
  Teutonic has Ag.S. {pól}, Eng. @Eng{pool}, Du. {poel}, O.H.G. {pfuol},
  Ger. {pfuhl}.  Skeat considers that {poll} is from Low Lat.
  {padulis}, and that the Ag.S. {pól} was possibly borrowed from
  the British Latin or Latin remains seen in place-names having
  {port}, {street}, {-chester}, etc.  (@ExtRef{Principles;1;437}).
<poll.2>, @Ref<pollair>, nostril, Ir. @Ir{polláire}, {poll-sróna}; from @Ref{poll.1}.
<pollag>, the fish pollock or lythe - gadus pollachius, of the cod and
  whiting genus, Ir. @Ir{pullóg}; from @Ref{poll.1}?  Hence the Eng.
  name.  The Irish Eng. @Eng{pollan}, Sc. {powan}, is a different fish -
  of the salmon genus.
<pollairean>, the dunlin (Heb.), polidna alpina.  Mr Swainson
  ({Folklore of British Birds}) translates its Gaelic name as
  "bird of the mud pits (@Ref{poll.1})", an exact description, he says.
<ponach>, boy, lad (Dial.), @Ref<poinneach> (W.Ross); cf. Manx {ponniar},
  a boy, a small fish basket?  In ARg. @Ref<boinnean> (Wh.), from
  @Ref{boinne}.  Cf. use of @Ref<proitseach>.  The word is for {bonach}.
<pònaidh>, a pony; from the Sc. {pownie}, from O.Fr. {poulenet} ({l} lost
  as usual), little colt, now {poulain}, a colt, from Med.Lat.
  {pullanus}, from Lat. {pullus}, foal, Eng. @Eng{foal}, {filly}.
<pònair>, bean or beans, Ir. @Ir{pónaire}, M.Ir. @MIr{ponaire}; from Norse
  {baun}, O.H.G. {pôna}, Ger. {bohne}, Eng. @Eng{bean}, Du. {boon} (Stokes'
  {Celt. Dec.}).
<pong>, a point, note, @Ref<pongail>, punctual; see @Ref{punc}.
<pòr>, seed, spore, Ir. @Ir{pór}, seed, clan, W. @W{par}, germ; from Gr.
  @Gr{σπόρος}, seed, Eng. @Eng{spore}.
--page 281
<port.1>, harbour, port, Ir. @Ir{port}, harbour, fort, O.Ir. @OIr{port}, W., Corn.
  {porth}, Br. @Br{pors}, {porz}; from Lat. {portus}, Eng. @Eng{port}.
<port.2>, a tune, Ir. @Ir{port}, M.Ir. @MIr{ceudport}, rhyme, prelude: "carry =
  catch"; from Lat. {porto}, carry.  Sc. {port}, catch, tune, is
  from Gaelic.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{sport}, from Lat. {dis-port}.
<pòs>, marry, O.G. {pústa}, wedded (B.of Deer), M.Ir. @MIr{pósaim}; from
  Lat. {sponsus}, {sponsa}, betrothed, from {spondeo}, I promise (Eng.
  {spouse}, {respond}, etc.).
<post>, post, beam, pillar, Ir. @Ir{posda}, {posta}, W. @W{post}; from the Eng.
  {post}, from Lat. {postis}.  Pl. {puist}, slugs for shooting (Wh.).
<prab>, discompose, ravel ({pràb}, H.S.D.), @Ref<prabach>, dishevelled,
  ragged, blear-eyed, Ir. @Ir{prábach} (O'R.): "suddenly arrayed",
  from @Ref{prap}?
<pràbar>, @Ref<pràbal>, a rabble; from {pràb}, @Ref{prab}, discompose.  See
  @Ref{prab}.
<prac>, vicarage dues, small tithes, which were paid in kind (N.H.
  and Isles), @Ref<pracadair>, tithe collector; from Sc. {procutor}, Eng.
  {proctor}, {procurator}.
<pracas>, hotch-potch; cf. Sc., Eng. @Eng{fricasse}.
<pràcais>, idle talk; from Eng. @Eng{fracas}?
<pràdhainn>, press of business, flurry (M`A. for Islay), Ir. @Ir{praidhin},
  O.Ir. @OIr{brothad}, a moment; see @Ref{priobadh}.
<prainnseag>, mince collops, haggis; from {prann}, pound (M`A.), a
  side form of @Ref{pronn.3}, q.v.
<prais>, brass, pot-metal (Arm.), pot (M`A.), @Ref<pràis>, brass (H.S.D.,
  M`L., M`E.), Manx {prash}, Ir. @Ir{práis}, {prás}, W. @W{pres}; from
  M.Eng. {bras}, Ag.S. {bræs}.  Hence @Ref<praiseach>, bold woman,
  concubine, meretrix.
<praiseach>, broth, pottage, etc., Ir. @Ir{praiseach}, pottage, kale, M.Ir.
  {braissech}, W. @W{bresych}, cabbages; from Lat. {brassica}, cabbage.
<pràmh.1>, a slumber, slight sleep:
<pràmh.2>, @Ref<priam>, heaviness; properly "blear-eyed-ness"; cf. Ir.
  {srám}, eye-rheum.
<praonan>, an earthnut; see @Ref{braonan}.
<prap>, quick, sudden, Ir. @Ir{prab}, M.Ir. @MIr{prap}; see under @Ref{priobadh}.
<prasach>, a manger, crib, @Ref<frasach>, (M`Rury):
<prasgan>, @Ref<brasgan>, a group, flock; cf. Ir. @Ir{prosnán}, a troop, company
  (O'R.):
<prat>, a trick (Wh.); @Ref<pratail>, tricky; see protaig.
<preachan.1>, a crow, kite, moor-bittern, Ir. @Ir{preachan}, crow, kite,
  osprey (accordinng to the adj. applied), M.Ir. @MIr{prechan}, crow,
  raven:
--page 282
<preachan.2>, a mean orator (M`A.), Ir. @Ir{preachoine}, crier, M.Ir.
  {prechoineadha}, præcones; from the Lat. {praeco(n)}, crier,
  auctioneer.
<preas.1>, a bush, brier, W. @W{prys}, burshwood, covert: *{qṛst-}, root {qer}
  of @Ref{crann}?  The G., which is borrowed, is doubtless of Pictish
  origin.
<preas.2>, a press, cupboard, Manx {prest}; from the Eng. @Eng{press}.
<preas.3>, a wrinkle, fold; from the Eng. @Eng{press}.
<preathal>, confusion of mind, dizziness; see @Ref{breitheal}.
<prighig>, fry; from the Eng. @Eng{frying}.
<prìne>, a pin; from the Sc. {preen}, M.Eng. {prēon}, Ag.S. {préon},
  Norse {prjónn}, Ger. {pfriem}.
<priobadh>, winking, twinkling (of the eye), Ir. @Ir{prap} in {le prap na
  súl}, in the twinkling of the eyes (Keating), from @Ref{prap},
  sudden, {preaba} in {na bi preaba na sula muich} (B.of Moyra),
  M.Ir. @MIr{prapud}, brief space (as twinkling of the eyes), {la
  brafad súla}, older {friha brathad sula}, where we get the series
  {prapud}, {brafad}, {brathad} (g. {brotto}), O.Ir. @OIr{brothad}, moment.
  Stokes compares the similar Gothic phrase - {in brahva augins},
  where {brahv} might = a British *{brap}, borrowed into Irish.
  The form {frafad} could easily develop into {brap}; the difficulty
  is the passinng of {th} of {brothad} (which gives g. {brotto}) info {f} of
  {brafad} (but see @ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;10;57}).  The G. <priobadh> has its
  vowel influenced by @Ref<preabadh>, kicking, that is, {breabadh}, q.v.
  Zim. (@ExtRef{Zeit.;32;223}) cites {brofte}, momentary, and says {brafad}
  is made from {bro}, eyebrow, falsely.
<priobaid>, a trifle, @Ref<priobair>, a worthless fellow; from Sc. {bribour},
  low beggarly fellow, M.Eng. {bribour}, rascal, thief; from
  O.Fr. {bribeur}, beggar, vagabond, {briber}, to beg, {bribe}, morsel
  of bread, Eng. @Eng{bribe}.  Hence <priobaid> is from an early
  Northern form of Eng. @Eng{bribe}.  See @Ref{breaban} further.
<prìomh>, prime, chief, Ir. @Ir{príomh}, a principal, {primh}, prime, O.Ir.
  {prím}, W. @W{prif}; from Lat. {primus}, first, Eng. @Eng{prime}.
<prìonnsa>, a prince, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{prindsa}; from M.Eng. and Fr.
  {prince} (Stokes takes it from Fr. direct).
<prìosan>, prison, Ir. @Ir{príosún}, M.Ir. @MIr{prísún}; from M.Eng. {prisoun},
  from O.Fr. {prison} (Stokes takes it from O.Fr. {prisun}).
<prìs>, price, W. @W{pris}; from M.Eng. {prīs}, from O.Fr. {prīs}, Lat.
  {pretium}.
<probhaid>, profit; from the Eng.
<procach>, a year-old stag (Rob Donn):
<proghan>, dregs, lees:
<proinn>, a dinner, O.G. {proinn} (B.of Deer), Ir. @Ir{proinn}, O.Ir. @OIr{proind},
  {praind}; from Lat. {prandium}.
--page 283
<pròis>, pride, haughtiness; from Sc. {prossie}, {prowsie}, nice and particular,
  Dut. {prootsch}, {preutsch}, proud, Eng. @Eng{proud}.  The
  Arran Dial. has @Ref{pròtail} for {pròiseil}.
<proitseach>, a boy, stripling; cf. @Ref<brod balaich>, @Ref<brodan>, boy, from
  {brod}.  The termination is {-seach}, really a fem. one.  In Arg.
  @Ref<propanach>, a boy, from @Ref{prop}, also @Ref<geamht>.
---gjk (1.14) Probably same sense of @Ref{brod} ("good") that <brodan> refers to
<pronn.1>, food; see @Ref{proinn}.
<pronn.2>, bran, Manx {pronn}; see @Ref{pronn.3}.  Hence Sc. {pron}.
<pronn.3>, pound, bray, mash, Manx {pronney}, pouding; see, for root
  and form, @Ref{bronn}, distribute, from the root {bhrud}, break, which
  thus in G. means (1) distribute, (2) break or crush.  Hence
  @Ref<pronnag>, a crumb, Sc. {pronacks}.
<pronnasg>, brimstone; formed on Sc. {brunstane}, Norse {brenisteinn},
  Eng. @Eng{brimstone}.  Dial. of Badenoch has the form @Ref<pronnasdail>.
<pronndal>, muttering, murmering (Dial. @Ref<brundlais>):
<prop>, a prop, Ir. @Ir{propa}; from Eng. @Eng{prop}.
<propanach>, a boy (Wh.):
<prosnaich>, incite; see @Ref{brosnaich}.
<protaig>, a trick; from Sc. {prattick}, trick, stratagem, Ag.S. {prœtt},
  craft, {prœtig}, tricky, Eng. @Eng{pretty}, Norse {prettr}, a trick.
<prothaisd>, a provost; from the Eng.
<pubull>, a tet, Ir. @Ir{pupal}, g. {puible}, O.Ir. @OIr{pupall}, W. @W{pabell}, {pebyll};
  from Lat. {papilio}, butterfly, tent, Eg. {pavilion}.  See @Ref{pàilliun}.
<pùc>, push, jostle; from the Sc. {powk}, thrust, dig, M.Eng. {pukken},
  {pouken}, {póken}, to thrust, poke, Eng. @Eng{poke}, Ger. {pochen}, knock,
  Dial. @Ref<fùc>.
<pucaid>, a pimple; see @Ref{bucaid}.
<pudhar>, harm, injury, Ir. @Ir{púdhar} (O'B.), M.Ir. @MIr{pudar}, E.Ir. @EIr{púdar},
  {pudar}; from Lat. {pudor}, shame.  Usually taken as borrowed
  from Lat. {pûtor}, rottenness, Eng. @Eng{putrid}.
<pùic>, a bribe:
<puicean>, a veil, covering, Ir. @Ir{puicín}:
<puidse>, a pouch; from the Eng.
<puinneag>, sorrel:
<puinneanach>, beat, thump; from M.Eng. {pounen}, now {pound},
  Ag.S. {punian}.
<puinse>, punch, toddy; from Eng. @Eng{punch}.
<puinsean>, @Ref<puision>, poison; from the Eng.  Manx has {pyshoon}.
<pùirleag>, a crest, tuft, Ir. @Ir{puirleógach}, crested, tufted (O'B., Sh.),
  {puirleog} (O'R.) - an Irish word.  See @Ref{pùrlag}.
<pulag>, round stone, ball, pedestal, also <pulag>; from M.Eng.
  {boule}, a ball or bowl, now {bowl}, Fr. {boule}.
<pulaidh>, turkey cock: Fr. {poulet}.
--page 284
<pùlas>, pot-hook (Dial.); see @Ref{bùlas}.
<punc>, a point, note, Ir. @Ir{punc}, O.Ir. @OIr{ponc}, W. @W{pwnc}; from Lat.
  {punctum}, Eng. @Eng{point}.
<punnan>, a sheaf, Manx {bunney}, Ir. @Ir{punnann}, E.Ir. @EIr{punann},
  {pundand} (Corm.); from Norse {bundin}, a sheaf, bundle, Eng.
  {bundle}, {bind}.
<punnd.1>, a pound, Ir. @Ir{punta}, {punt}, M.Ir. @MIr{punt}; from the Eng.
<punnd.2>, a place for securing stray cattle, a pound; from the Eng.
  {pound}.
<punntainn>, @Ref<funntainn>, benumbment by cold or damp; cf. Eng.
  {swoon}, M.Eng. {swoghne}, *{swog-}.  Cf. Sc. {fundy}.
<punntuinn>, see @Ref{punntainn}.

<purgaid>, a purge, Ir. @Ir{purgóid}; from Lat. {purgatio}, Eng. @Eng{purgation},
  {purge}.
<purgadoir>, purgatory, Ir. @Ir{purgadóir}, E.Ir. @EIr{purgatoir}, Br. @Br{purgator};
  from Lat. {purgatorium}, Eng. @Eng{purgatory}.
<pùrlag>, a rag, tatter, fragment:
<purp>, @Ref<purpais>, sense, mental faculty; from Eng. @Eng{purpose}.
<purpaidh>, @Ref<purpur>, purple, Ir. @Ir{purpuir}, M.Ir. @MIr{purpuir}, W.
  {porphor}: from Lat. {purpura}, Eng. @Eng{purple}.  The old Gadelic
  form, borrowed through British, is @Ref{corcur}.
<purr>, thrust, push; from Sc. {porr}, thrust, stab, Du. {porren}, poke,
  thrust, Low.Ger. {purren}, poke about; further Eng. @Eng{pore}.
<pus>, a cat, Ir. @Ir{pus}; from the Eng.
<put.1>, the cheek (Stew., H.S.D.); from Eng. @Eng{pout}.
<put.2>, thrust, push; from Sc. {put}, push, thrust, M.Eng. {puten},
  push, now Eng. @Eng{put}.  Also G. @Ref<but>, @Ref<butadh>.
<pùt.1>, young of moorfowl; from Sc. {pout} (do.), Eng. @Eng{poult}, chicken,
  from Fr. {poulet}, from Lat. {pulla}, a hen, {pullus}, young fowl.
<pùt.2>, a large buoy, usually of inflated sheepskin; seemingly of
  Scand. origin - Swedish Dial. {puta}, be inflated; cf. Eng.
  {pudding}, W. @W{pwtyn}, a short round body, Corn. @Corn{pot}, bag,
  pudding.
<putadh>, see @Ref{put.2}.

<ràbach>, litigious, Ir. @Ir{rábach}, litigious, bullying:
<rabhadh>, a warning, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{robuth}, forewarning: @Ref{ro}+{buth},
  latter from *{buto-}, root {ℊu}, cry, Gr. @Gr{βοή}, shout, Skr. @Ref{gu}, be
  heard.  W. @W{rhybudd} is from the Root {qu} (Stokes, @ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;12;}).
<rabhairt>, @Ref<reothairt>, springtide, Manx {royart}, Ir. @Ir{romhairt},
  {rabharta}, M.Ir. @MIr{robarta}, O.Ir. @OIr{robarti}, malinas, (sing.
  *{robarte}), W. @W{fhyferth}: @Ref{ro}+{bertio-}, "pro-fero", root {bher} of
  @Ref{beir}.
<rabhan>, rhapsody, repetition, Ir. @Ir{rabhán}, repetition: from @Ref{ro} and

<rabhart>, upbraiding, senseless talk; from @Ref{ro} and {ber} of @Ref{abair}, say,
  q.v.
<rabhd>, idle talk: *{ro-bant}, root {ba}, speak, as in @Ref{rabhan}.
<rac>, the ring kepping the yard to the mast, the "traveller"; from
  Norse {rakki} (do.).
<ràc.1>, a rake, Ir. @Ir{ráca}, W. @W{rhacan}; from M.Eng. {rake}, Eng. @Eng{rake}.
<ràc.2>, a drake; from the Eng., earlier Eng. @Eng{endrake}.  The loss of {d}
  is due to the article.
<racadh>, tearing; see @Ref{sracadh}.
<racadal>, horse-radish (Sh., H.S.D., Arm.), @Ref<ràcadal> (M`E.), Ir.
  {rácadal}; see @Ref{rotacal}.
<racaid>, noise; cf. the Sc., Eng. @Eng{racket}.  Skeat takes the Eng. from
  the Gaelic, referring the G. to @Ref{rac}, to make a noise like geese
  or ducks.  See @Ref{ràcail}.
<ràcail>, noise of geese (H.S.D.); cf. Sc. {rackle}.  See @Ref{ràcain}.
<ràcain>, noise, riot, mischief, @Ref<ràcaireachd>, croaking, Ir. @Ir{racan}; cf.
  Br. @Br{rakat}, {rakal}, croak, {raklat}, cry as a hen; Lat. {raccare},
  cry as a tiger, Lit. {rėkti}, cry, root {rak}.  The words are greatly
  onomatopoetic.
<racan>, a bandy or crooked stick; cf. @Ref{rac}.
<racas>, sail hoop; see @Ref{rac}.
<rach>, go, Ir. @Ir{rachad}, I will go, E.Ir. @EIr{ragat}, ibo, O.Ir. @OIr{doreg},
  veniam; root {reg}, stretch.  See @Ref{éirich} for the root connections.
<rachd.1>, vexation, moan, Ir. @Ir{rachd}, a fit as of crying or tears: cf.
  @Ref{racaid}.
<rachd.2>, strength (Carm.):
<rachdan>, a tartan plaid worn mantle-wise:

<radan>, a rat; from Sc. {ratton}, M.Eng. {raton}, now {rat}.

<raip>, filth, foul mouth, @Ref<raipeas>, foul mouth, @Ref<rapach>, slovenly,

  seize.  The Ger. {raffen}, seize, snatch, has also been suggested.

  above ({rann}, stave, is mas. in E.Ir., the other {rann} is fem.).

  search a house, ransack, whence Eng. @Eng{ransack}.

<raog>, a rushing (H.S.D., Dial.); cf. @Ref{ruaig}.
<raoic>, @Ref<raoichd>, hoarse sound or cry, wild roaring, as of bull;
  @Ref<raibheic> (M`A.), pronounced {raoi'c}, roar: *{ro-beuc}.
<raoine>, a young barren cow that had calf; cf. Sc. {rhind}, as in
  {rhind mart}, Ger. {rind}, cattle, beeves.  In Suth. {reithneach}.
<raoir>, @Ref<an raoir>, last night, Ir. @Ir{a raoir}, {a réir}, O.Ir. @OIr{aréir}, *{pre-ri},
  root as in @Ref{riamh.2} (Asc., St.).  The Skr. {râtri}, night, has been
  compared, but the phonetics do not suit, and also Lat. {retro}.
  Cf. also @Ref{earar}, @Ref{uiridh}.
<raoit>, indecent mirth; from Sc. {riot} (do.), Eng. @Eng{riot}.
<raon>, a field, plain, road, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{roen}, road, O.Ir. @OIr{roe}, {rói},
  plain: *{roves-no-}, *{roves-jâ}?  Lat. {rus}, {rûris}; Eng. @Eng{room}.

  Gadelic *{roino-}.
<rapach>, dirty-mouthed; see @Ref{raip}.
<ràpach>, noisy, @Ref<ràpal>, noise, Ir. @Ir{rápal}, noise, bustle; founded on

<ras>, a shrub (M`F., not M`A. or M`E.), Ir. @Ir{ras} (O'B., etc.):
<ràsan>, harsh, grating noise, loquacity, @Ref<ràsanach>, discordant, Ir.
  {ráscach}, clamorous, talkative; cf. @Ref{ràn}, for ultimate root.
<ràsdail.1>, a rake, harrow, E.Ir. @EIr{rastal}; from Lat. {rastellus}, rake,

<ràsdail.2>, sound of frying meat; cf. {ròsd}.
<rath>, prosperity, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{rath}, gratia, W. @W{rhad}, grace, favour:
  *{rato-n}, root {râ}, give; Skr. {râti}, gift, {râs}, {rayis}, property,

<ràth.1>, a raft, Ir. @Ir{rathannaibh}, (on) rafts (F.M.); Lat. {ratis}.  The
  root is the same as that of @Ref{ràmh} (= {ret}, {rât} here).
<ràth.2>, @Ref<ràthan>, surety, vadimonium, Ir. @Ir{rath} (O'B., O'Cl.), O.Ir.
  {ráth}; cf. O.Br. @OBr{rad}, stipulationes, which Stokes equates with
  Ir. @Ir{rath}, and says that it is from Lat. {rătum} ({ratum facere} =
--page 288
  "ratify"), a derivation to which Loth objects.  Hibernian
  Lat. has {rata} for surety.  The Lat. and G. are ultimately
  from the same root in any case (see @Ref{ràdh}).
†<ràth.3>, a fortress, residence, Ir. @Ir{ráth}, E.Ir. @EIr{ráth}, {ráith}, g. {rátha},
  Gaul. {ratin}, {Argento-ratum}: *{râti-s}, *{râto-n}; cf. Lat. {prâtum},
  a mead.  W. @W{rhath}, cleared spot; borrowed from G.? (Rhys).
<rathad>, a road, Ir. @Ir{ráthad}, {ród}; from M.Eng. {roade}, road, Ag.S.
  {rád}; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{ramhad} (O'Cl.), E.Ir. @EIr{ramut} (Corm.).
<ré.1>, the moon, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ré}, luna: *{revi}, Skr. {ravi}, sun.
<ré.2>, time, space, Ir. @Ir{ré}, O.Ir. @OIr{ré}, g. {ree}, space: *{revesi-}, the {e} form
  of O.Ir. @OIr{rói}, *{rovesjâ}, discussed under @Ref{raon}, q.v.  Hence the
  prep. <ré>, during, which governs the genitive.
<reabh>, wile, trick, @Ref<reabhair>, subtle fellow, @Ref<reabhradh>, disporting,
  as boys (Badenoch), Ir. @Ir{reabh} (O'Cl.), {reabhach}, mountebank,
  the devil, @Ref{reabhradh}, E.Ir. @EIr{rebrad}, boys playing, sporting;
  root {reb}, play.  Bez. compares M.H.G. {reben}, move, stir,
  Swiss {räbeln}, to brawl, be noisy, to which add Eng. @Eng{rabble}.
  Cf. Zim. @ExtRef{Stud.;1;83,84}.
<reachd.1>, law, statute, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{recht}, W. @W{rhaith}, Br. @Br{reiz}, just:
  *{rektu-}, from the root {reg}; Lat. {rectum}, right, {rego}, rule;
  Eng. @Eng{right}.
<reachd.2>, a loud sob, keen sorrow, Ir. @Ir{rachd} (also G. @Ref<rachd.1>), E.Ir.
  {recht}; cf. Eng. @Eng{reck}.
<reamhar>, fat, Ir. @Ir{reamhar}, {ramhar}, E.Ir. @EIr{remor} ({remro-}), W. @W{rhef},
  thick; root {rem}, to be thick; Norse {ramr}, strong, stark.
  Stokes gives the alternatives of M.H.G. {fram}, {vrom}, sound,
  brave, O.Sax. @Ref{furm}, or Gr. @Gr{πρέμνον}, stem, thick end.
<reang.1>, a wrinkle in the face: "a rib"; see @Ref{reang.3}, boat-rib.
<reang.2>, a rank, series; from early Sc. {renk}, M.E. {reng}, now {rank};
  Ir. @Ir{ranc}, W. @W{rheng}, Br. @Br{renk}; O.Fr. {renc}.
<reang.3>, a boat-rib, @Ref<rangan> (Sutherland), {reang}, a bar, pole (Carm.);
  from Norse {röng}, g. {rangar}, a ship-rib.  See @Ref{rong.1}.
<reang.4>, kill, starve (M`F.), E.Ir. @EIr{ringim}, I tear, {reangadh}, to hang,
  {reng}, piercing or tearing.  See @Ref{tarruing}.
<reannach>, spotted, striped: "starred"; see @Ref{reannag}.
<reannag>, a star, Ir. @Ir{reannán}, O.Ir. @OIr{rind}, constellation, signum,
  sidus: *{rendi-}, root {red}, {ṛd}, order; Lit. {rinda}, row, order,

  Prellwitz).
<reasach>, talkative, prattling (H.S.D., Dial.), Ir. @Ir{réascach}, {ráscach};
  see @Ref{ràsan}.

<reasgach>, stubborn, irascible, restive:
<reic>, sell, Ir. @Ir{reic}, a sale, O.Ir. @OIr{recc}, a sale, {reccaim} (vb.), also
  {renim}, I sell: root {per}, through, over ("sell over sea"); Gr.
--page 289
  {peraw}, sell, pass through, @Gr{πιπράσκω}, @Gr{περνημι}, I sell; Lit.
  {pirkti}, {perkù}, buy.  The Gadelic and Lit. how a secondary
  root {perk}, {prek}, Gadelic *{(p)rek-kâ}, while O.Ir. @OIr{renim} and
  Gr. @Gr{περνημι} give a stem {pernā-}, {prenă-} (Ir.).
<réic>, roar, howl (H.S.D.):

<réim.1>, dominion, power, Ir. @Ir{réim}:
<réim.2>, course, order, Ir. @Ir{réim}, O.Ir. @OIr{réimm}, inf. to {rethim}, I run:
  *{reid-s-men-}, root {reid} of @Ref{réidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{riadaim}, I drive.
  Strachan suggests as alternates root {rengh}, spring, leap (cf.
  W. @W{rhamu}, soar), Gr. @Gr{ρíμφα}, quickly, Ger. {ge-ring}, light, Lit.
  {rengtis}, hurry; or root {ret}, run (see @Ref{ruith}), *{retmen}, or rather,
  *{ret-s-men}, which would only give {rĕmm}.

<réir>, @Ref<a réir>, according to, Ir. @Ir{a réir}, {do réir}; dat. of @Ref{riar}, q.v.
<réis.1>, a race; from the Eng. (H.S.D.).  Cf. {réise}, span, of E.Ir.
<réis.2>, a span, Ir. @Ir{réise}: *{prendsiâ}, from {sprend}, Lit. {spréstî}, to
  measure a span, root {sprend} (Strachan).
<reisimeid>, a regiment; from the Eng.
<réit>, @Ref<réite>, concord, conciliation, Ir. @Ir{réidhteach}; @Ref{réidh}, with
  terminal {-tio-}.
<reithe>, @Ref<reath>, a ram, Ir. @Ir{reithe}, E.Ir. @EIr{rethe}: *{retio-}; cf. Lat. {aries}
  (*{eriét-}), Umbrian {erietu} (from {eri-}), Gr. @Gr{ἒριοφος}, etc., as in

<reodh>, @Ref<reotha>, frost, Ir. @Ir{reó}, {reodhadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{reo}, {reod}, O.Ir. @OIr{reúd},
  W. @W{rhew}, Corn. @Corn{reu}, gelu, Br. @Br{reo}, {rev}.  Stokes gives the stem
  as *{regu-}, even suggesting that the Gadelic forms are borrowed
  from the Cymric; O.Ir. @OIr{réud} he refers to *{presatu-}.  I.E.
  {preus}, whence Lat. {pruina}, Eng. @Eng{freeze}, has been suggested,
  but the vowels do not immediatley suit ({preus} would give
  {rua-}, {ró-} or {ro-}, in G.); yet *{prevo-}, a longer form (with or
  without {s}) of {preu-s}, can account for the Celtic forms.
<reub>, @Ref<riab>, tear, wound, Ir. @Ir{reubaim}, {réabaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{rébaim}, {rép-gaeth},
  rending wind: *{reibbo-}, root {reib}, Eng. @Eng{reap}, {ripe}, and
  {rip}(?).  Stokes gives the stem as *{reip-nó-}, root {reip} of Gr.
  @Gr{ἐρεíπω}, dash down, Lat. {rîpa}, Eng. @Eng{rive}, {rift}, Norse {rifna},
  rumpi, {rífa}, break.  G. @Ref<reubainn>, rapine, leans for its form
  and force on Lat. {rapina}.  W. @W{rheibio}, seize, is from Lat.
  {rapio}.
--page 290
<reubal>, a rebel; from the Eng.
<reudan>, a timber moth; cf. O.Ir. @OIr{rétan}, recula, small thing, from
  {rét}, now @Ref{rud}, q.v.
<reul>, pl., @Ref<reultan>, star, Ir. @Ir{reult}, g. {réilte}, E.Ir. @EIr{retla}, g. {retland},
  {retglu}, g. {retgland} ("{rét glé}, bright thing", Corm.); perhaps
  {rét}, thing, and *{gland}, shining, Ger. {glanz} (see @Ref{gleus}).
<reumail>, constant (Arms.); from @Ref{réim.2}, course.
<reusan>, reason, Ir. @Ir{reusun}, M.Ir. @MIr{résún}, from M.Eng. {reisun}, now
  {reason}.
<reusbaid>, a beggar's brat (Arran), a rascal:
<ri>, to, against, Ir. @Ir{re}, O.Ir. @OIr{ri}, {fri}, in composition @Ref{frith-}, {fris-}, @Ref{fre-},
  W. @W{gwrth}, {wrth}, versus, contra, re-, Corn. @Corn{orth}, Br. @Br{ouz}; *{vṛti},
  root {vert}, turn; Lat. {versus}, against, to, {verto}, turn; Eng.

<riabhach>, brindled, greyish, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{riab}, a stripe: *{reibâko-},

  {roaban}, striped.
<riabhag>, a lark, Ir. @Ir{riabhóg}, "grey one", from @Ref{riabhach}.
<riach>, cut the surface, graze.  Although there is I.E. {reiko-},
  notch, break (Gr. @Gr{ἐρεíκω}, tear, Lit {raikýti}, draw a furrow,
  etc., Ger. {reihe}, row, Eng. @Eng{row}), yet it seems most probable
  that {riach} is a variant of @Ref{strìoch}, q.v.
<riachaid>, a distributing:
<riachlaid>, tattered garment (Suth.):
<riadh.1>, interest; from an older {ríad}, running, course (see @Ref{réidh} for
  root).  Cf. for force M.Ir. @MIr{rith}, interest: "running".
<riadh.2>, a drill (as of potatoes, Badenoch): "course, running", as in
  the case of @Ref{riadh.1} above.  See @Ref{riamh.1}.
<riadh.3>, a snare: *{reigo-}, root {rig} in @Ref{cuibhreach}?
<riaghailt>, a rule, Ir. @Ir{riaghail}, O.Ir. @OIr{riagul}, {riagol}; from Lat.
  {rêgula}, Eng. @Eng{rule}.  Hence also @Ref<riaghail> rule thou.
<riaghan>, a swing, swinging; cf. Ir. @Ir{riagh}, gallows, {riaghadh},
  hanging, gibbeting, O.Ir. @OIr{riag}, gibbet.  Cf. @Ref{riadh.3}, snare.
<riamh.1>, a drill (of potatoes, turnips, etc, M`A. for Skye); see
  @Ref{riadh.2}.  H.S.D. gives the meaning of "series, number", Ir.
  {ríomh}, O.Ir. @OIr{rím}, number, W. @W{rhif}, as in @Ref{àireamh}, q.v.
<riamh.2>, ever, before, Ir. @Ir{riamh}, O.Ir. @OIr{riam}, antea: *{reimo-},
  {preimo-}, I.E. {pri}, {prî}, belonging as a case to {pro}, before, and
  {per}; Lat. {pri-} (in {pris cus}, {primus}, etc.), Lit. {pri}, Got. {fri-},
  See @Ref{roimh}.
<rian>, order, mode, sobriety, Ir. @Ir{rian}, way or path, E.Ir. @EIr{rian}, way,
  manner: *{reino-}, root {rei}; Lat. {rîtus}, Eng. @Eng{rite} (Strachan).
<riar>, will, pleasure, Ir. @Ir{riar}, O.Ir. @OIr{riar}, voluntas: *{prîjarâ}
  (Stokes), root {prî}, love, please; Eng. @Eng{friend}, Got. {frijon}, to
--page 291
  love; Ch.Sl. {prijati}, be favourable; Skr. {prī́yate}, be gratified,
  {prîṇâti}, enjoy.
<riasail>, tear asunder, @Ref<riasladh>, mangling, tearing asunder: *{reik-so-},
  root {reik}, notch, break; Gr. @Gr{ἐρεíκω}, tear?  Cf. @Ref{riastradh} @Ref{riach};
  and @Ref{riaghan}, a swing.
<riasg>, dirk-grass, morass with sedge, land covered with sedge or
  dirk-grass, Manx {reeast}, wilderness, Ir. @Ir{riasg}, moor or fen,
  E.Ir. @EIr{riasc}, morass; *{reisko-}; cf. Lat. {rûscum} (*{roiscum}?),
  butcher's broom, Eng. @Eng{rush}.  Sc. {reesk}, coarse grass, marshy
  land, is from G.
<riasglach>, a mangled carcase (H.S.D., Dial.); from stem of
  @Ref{riasail}.
<riaspach>, @Ref<riasplach>, confused, disordered; see @Ref{riastradh}.
<riastradh>, turbulance, confusion, wandering, E.Ir. @EIr{ríastrad}, distortion.
  For root, cf. @Ref{riasail}.  W. @W{rhywstro}, obstruct (Hend.).
<riatach>, wanton, illegitimate; cf. Eng. @Eng{riot}.
<rib>, hair, snare, Ir. @Ir{ribe}, {ruibe}, hair, whisker.  See next words.
<ribeag>, rag, tassel, fringe, @Ref<ribean>, riband, Ir. @Ir{ribeóg}, rag, tassel,

<ribheid>, a reed, bagpipe reed, musical note, Ir. @Ir{ribheid}; from

<rìbhinn>, @Ref<rìoghann>, a nymph, young lady, quean, Ir. @Ir{ríoghan},
  queen, E.Ir. @EIr{rígan}, a derivative of @Ref{rìgh}, king.  Gaelic leans,
  by proper etymology, on {rìgh-bhean}.
<rideal>, a riddle; from the Eng.
<ridhe>, field, bottom of a valley (H.S.D.); better @Ref<righe>.  See

<ridir>, a knight, Ir. @Ir{ridire}, E.Ir. @EIr{ritire}, W. @W{rheidyr}; from Ag.S.

<rinn.1>, a point, promontory, Ir. @Ir{rind}, O.Ir. @OIr{rinnd}, {rind}, W. @W{rhyn},

<risteal>, a surface plough, used in the Hebrides, drawn by one
  horse and having a sickle-like coulter, Sc. {ristle}; from the
  Norse {ristill}, ploughshare, from {rísta}, cut.
<rithisd>, @Ref<rithis, <rìs>, @Ref<a rithisd>, etc., again, Ir. @Ir{arís}, O.Ir. @OIr{arithissi},
  {afrithissi}, rursus.  Ascoli suggests *{frith-éisse}, from @Ref{éis},
  vestigium (see @Ref{déis}).  Others have derived it from *{ar-fithis},
  O.Ir. @OIr{fithíssi}, absidas, {fithis}, a circle, orbit.  The {a} at the
  beginning is for {ar-}: *{ar-frithissi}, that is, @Ref{air}, by, on, q.v.
  The root may well be {sta}, stand, reduplicated to *{sistio-}:
  thus *{frith(sh)issi-}, "resistere, backness".
<ro>, very, Ir. @Ir{ró}, O.Ir. @OIr{ro-}, W. @W{rhy-}, Br. @Br{re}, O.Br. @OBr{ro-}, {ru-}, Gaul.
  {ro-} ({Ro-smerta}, {Ro-danos}, etc.): *{ro-}, *{pro-}, which is both a
  verbal and an intensive particle; Lat. {pro}; Gr. @Gr{πρό}, before;
  Eng. @Eng{fore}, {for}; Skr. {pra}, before.
<ròb>, coarse hair; founded on Eng. @Eng{rope}.
<robair>, a robber; from the Eng.  The Ir. has {robail} for "rob".
<robhas>, notification, information about anything lost; cf. @Ref<robhadh>

<robhd>, a runt; Eng. @Eng{rout?}
<roc.1>, a rock; from the Eng.  {roc}, a tempest covered rock (Heb.),
  so M`K., who derives from N. {rok}.
<roc.2>, a wrinkle, crease, Ir. @Ir{rocán}, {rug}; from the Norse {hrukka},
  wrinkle, fold, Eng. @Eng{ruck}, fold (Thurneysen).  See @Ref{rug.1}.
<ròc>, a hoarse voice; founded on the Norse {hrókr}, rook, croaker,
  G. @Ref{ròcas}, crow, Norse {hrókr}, rook.  W. has {rhoch}, grunt,
  groan, Br. @Br{roc'ha}, which Stokes refers to *{rokka}, Gr. @Gr{ρέγκω},
  snore.
<rocail>, tear, corrugate; in the latter sense, it is from @Ref{roc.2}, wrinkle,
  and, probably, the first meaning is of the same origin.  See,
  however, @Ref{racadh}.

<roghainn>, a choice, Ir. @Ir{rogha}, g. {roghan}, E.Ir. @EIr{rogain}, n.pl., O.Ir.

<roid.1>, bog myrtle, Ir. @Ir{rideog} (O'R.), M.Ir. @MIr{raidleog}, darnel, {raideog},

<roid.2>, a race before a leap, a bounce or spring: *{raddi-}, *{raz-di-},
  root {ras}, as in Eng. @Eng{race}?
<roilean>, snout of a sow; really the "rolled" up part of the snout,
  and so possibly from Eng. @Eng{roll}.
<roileasg>, a confused joy, @Ref<roille>, a fawning or too cordial reception;

  @Ref<roithleas>.
<roimh>, before, Ir. @Ir{roimh}, O.Ir. @OIr{rem-}: *{(p)ṛmo-} (Stokes), root {per},
  as in @Ref{ro} (= {pro}); in form, nearest allied to Eng. @Eng{from}, Got.
  {fruma}, Lit. {pirm}, before.  In the pronominal compounds,
  where {s} begins the pronoun, the {m} and {s} develop an intermediate
  {p} coincident with the eclipse of the {s}: {rompa} = *{rom-p-shu},
  where {su} = {sôs} (see @Ref{-sa}).
<ròin>, @Ref<ròineag> (also @Ref<ròinn>, @Ref<ròinneag>), Ir. @Ir{róine}, {róinne}, a hair,
  especially a horse hair, W. @W{rhawn}, coarse long hair, Corn. @Corn{ruen},
  Br. @Br{reun}, a hair, bristle, Skr. {roman}, hair, etc: *{râni-}; cf. Ir.
  {ruain}, hair of tail of cow or horse, {ruainne}, a hair.
<roinn>, division, share, Ir. @Ir{roinn}, M.Ir. @MIr{roinded}, divided: *{ranni-},
  an {i} stem from @Ref{rann.1}, q.v.

<ròisead>, rosin; from the Sc. {roset}, Eng. @Eng{rosin}.
<roiseag>, a small potato (M`D.):

<ròn>, the seal, Ir. @Ir{rón}, O.Ir. @OIr{rón} (before 900), W. @W{moelron}: *{râno-};
  Lettic {rohns}, seal (W.Meyer, @ExtRef{Zeit.;28;119}).  Stokes holds {rón}
  as an old borrow from Ag.S. {hron} or {hrón}, {hrán}, whale, while
  the Lit. {rùinis}, Lettic {rõnis}, seal, must be from Teutonic.
  Zimmer suggests Norse {hreinn}, reindeer, Ag.S. {hrán}.  Cf.

<rongair.1>, a lounger; cf. @Ref{rongair.2}.
<rongair.2>, @Ref<rong.3>, a lean person; from @Ref{rong.1}, rung: "like a ladder".
  The Sc. has {rung} in this sense: "an ugly, big-boned animal
  or person".
<ronn>, a slaver, a spittle, E.Ir. @EIr{ronna}, running of the nose: *{runno-};
  cf. Eng. @Eng{run}.
<ròp>, a rope, Ir. @Ir{rópa}; from M.Eng. {rope}, {roop}, Ag.S. {ráp}; now
  Eng. @Eng{rope}.

<ròram>, dealing extensively with a family in provisions, etc.;
  liberality (M`A.):
<ros.1>, seed, @Ref<ros lìn>, flax seed (Armstrong's only use for it), Ir. @Ir{ros},
  flax seed, M.Ir. @MIr{ros}, genealogy, E.Ir. @EIr{ross lín}, flax seed
--page 295
  (Corm.), @Ref{ros.1}, genealogy, to which Strachan compares Got.
  {frasts}, for {fra-sət-s}, from {pro-sto} (Stokes), a child.  A usual
  word for seed is @Ref<fras>, which also means a "shower", but both
  are ultimately from *{verso}, flow, whence Gr. @Gr{ἒρση}, @Gr{ἑρση}, dew,
  and @Gr{ἀρσην}, male.  Dr. Cameron compared Gr. @Gr{πράσον}, leek
  (*{pṛso}), Eng. @Eng{furze}.
<ros.2>, a promontory, Ir. @Ir{ros}, promontory (North Ireland), wood
  (South Ireland; its usual Ir. meaning), E.Ir. @EIr{ross}, promontory,
  wood; in the former sense from *{pro-sto-s}, "standing
  out before", root {sta}, stand, Lat. {sto}, Eng. @Eng{stand}, etc.;
  especially Skr. {prastha}, plateau.  In the sense of "wood", {ros}
  is generally regarded as the same word as {ros}, promontory,
  explained as "promontorium nemorosum", with which is
  compared W. @W{rhos}, a moor, waste, coarse highland, Br. @Br{ros}, a
  knoll.
<ròs.1>, rose, Ir. @Ir{rósa}, M.Ir. @MIr{rós}, W. @W{rhosyn}; from the M.Eng. {rose},
  Ag.S. {róse}, from Lat. {rŏsa}.  The word {ròs} has also the metaphoric
  meaning of "erysipelas".
<ròs.2>, knowledge (Carm.):
<rosad>, mischance, evil spell: *{pro-stanto-}, "standing before,
  obstruction", root {sta}.  Cf. @Ref{faosaid}.
<rosg.1>, an eye, eyelid, Ir. @Ir{rosg}, O.Ir. @OIr{rosc}, oculus: *{rog-sko-}, root
  {reg}, {rog}, see, Ir. @Ir{réil}, clear (*{regli-}); Lit. {regiù}, I see (Bez.
  apud Stokes).  See @Ref{dorch}.
<rosg.2>, aincitement (to battle), war ode, Ir. @Ir{rosg}, E.Ir. @EIr{rosc}: *{ro-sqo-},
  root {seq}, say, as in @Ref{sgeul}, {cosg}, q.v.
<rot>, a belch, bursting as of waves (H.S.D., Dial.); from Fr. {rot}.

<roth>, a wheel, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{roth}, W. @W{rhod} (f.), Br. @Br{rod}: *{roto-}, root
  {ret}, @Ref{rot}; Lat. {rota}, wheel; Ger. {rad}; Lat. {rátas}, Lett. {rats};

  @Ref<rotha>, a roll (of tobacco), @Ref<rothaich>, roll thou, swathe.

<rug.2>, caught, Ir. @Ir{rug}, E.Ir. @EIr{ruc}, {rucc}, tulit, O.Ir. @OIr{rouic}: *{ro+ucc-},
  where {ucc} = *{ud-gos-a}, root {ges}, carry, Lat. {gero}, {gestum}.  See
  @Ref{thug}.
<ruga>, rough cloth (M`A.); from Eng. @Eng{rug}, M.Eng. {ruggi}, hairy,
  Sw. {ruggig}.
<rugadh>, a greedy grasping of anything; from Sc. {rook}, deprive of,
  {rookit}, cleared out.
<rugaid>, a long neck (H.S.D.):
<rugair>, a drunkard (H.S.D. says Dial., M`A. says N.); from the
  Eng.  For phonetics, cf. @Ref{ràc.2}, drake.
<rugha>, a blush; see rather @Ref{rudha.2}, but {rucce} (Corm.) shame,
  reddening (O'Cl.).
<ruic>, undesirable fondness (M`D.):
<ruicean>, a pimple: *{rud-ki-}, from @Ref{rud}, {roud}, red, as in @Ref{ruadh}.
<ruidhil.1>, @Ref<ruidhle> (Arg.), a dance; see @Ref{ruithil}.
<ruidhil.2>, a yarn reel; from M.Eng. {reel}, {hréol}, Ag.S. {hréol}.
<ruidhleadh>, rolling; from @Ref{ruith}, @Ref{roth}.
<ruidhtear>, a glutton, riotous liver; from Eng. @Eng{rioter}.
<ruididh>, merry, frisky, Ir. @Ir{ruidéiseach}, from {ruidéis}, a sporting
  mood.  Cf. @Ref{ruidhtear}.
<ruig.1>, half castrated ram; from Eng. @Eng{rig}, {ridgeling}.
<ruig.2>, reach, arrive at, O.Ir. @OIr{riccim}, {riccu}; from @Ref{ro} and {iccim}, for
  which see @Ref{thig}.  Hence @Ref<gu ruig>, as far as, O.G. {gonice} (B.of Deer),
  E.Ir. @EIr{corrici}.
<ruighe.1>, an arm, forearm, Ir. @Ir{righ}, E.Ir. @EIr{rig}, forearm: *{regit-}, root
  {reg}, stretch, Lat. {rego}, etc.  See @Ref{ruigheachd}.
<ruighe.2>, the outstretched part or base of a mountain, shealing
  ground, E.Ir. @EIr{rige}, {rigid}, a reach, reaches; from the root {reg},
  stretch, as in the case of @Ref{ruig.2} and @Ref{ruighe.1}.
<ruigheachd>, @Ref<ruighinn>, reaching, arriving, Ir. @Ir{righim}, I reach, inf.
  {riachdain}, {rochdain}, E.Ir. @EIr{rigim}, porrigo: *{regô}; Lat. {rego},
  {erigo}, {porrigo}, I stretch; Gr. @Gr{ὀρέγω}, stretch; further is Eng.
  {right}, etc.  See @Ref{éirich}.
<ruighean>, wool-roll ready to spin; from the same root as @Ref{ruighe.1}.
<ruinn>, a point; see @Ref{rinn.1}.
<ruinnse.1>, a long stick or stake, an animal's tail, rump:
<ruinnse.2>, a rinsing, rinser; from Eng. @Eng{rinse}.
<ruis>, a rash; formed from the Eng.  Cf. Lit. {russus}, root {rud}.
<ruiteach>, ruddy, E.Ir. @EIr{rutech}: *{rud-tiko-}, from @Ref{rud}, {roud} of
  @Ref{ruadh}.  Stokes (@ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;8;366}) explained it as *{rudidech},
  but this would give G. {ruideach}.
<ruith>, run, Ir. @Ir{riothaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{rethim}, perf. {ráith}, inf. {rith}
  (d. {riuth}, W. @W{rhedu}, to run, {rhed}, race, Br. @Br{redek}, Gaul.
--page 298
  {petor-ritum}, four wheeler: *{retô}; Lit., Lett. {ritù}, I roll; Lat.
  {rota}, wheel, {rotula}, Eng. @Eng{roll}, Lat. {rotundus}, Eng. @Eng{round}.
  See @Ref{roth}.
<ruithil>, a reel, dance, also @Ref<righil>, @Ref<ruidhil.1>: *{retoli-}, root {ret}, run,
  wheel, as in @Ref{ruith}; Lat. {rotula}, little wheel, {rotulare}, revolve,
  Eng. @Eng{roll}.  Hence Eng. @Eng{reel} (Skeat).  The borrowing may be,
  however, the other way, and Eng. @Eng{reel}, dance, be the same as
  {reel}, a spindle or bobbin.  *{roteli}?
<rùm>, a room, Ir. @Ir{rúm}, M.Ir. @MIr{rúm}, floor (O'Cl.); from the Eng.
<rumach>, a marsh:
<rumpull>, the tail, rump; from the Sc. {rumple}, Eng. @Eng{rump}.
<rùn>, intention, love, secret, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{rún}, W. @W{rhin}: *{rûnes-}; Got.,
  O.H.G., Norse {rúnar}, Eng. @Eng{runes}; Gr. @Gr{ἐρευνάω}, seek out;
  root {revo}, search.
<rùsal>, search, turn over things, scrape, @Ref<rùsladh>, @Ref<rusleadh>, rusling,
  moving things about (Perth); from Eng. @Eng{rustle}; for ultimate
  root, see @Ref{rùn}.
<rùsg>, a fleece, skin, husk, bark, Ir. @Ir{rusg}, O.Ir. @OIr{rúsc}, cortex, W.
  {rhisg}, cortex, Corn. @Corn{rusc}, cortex, Br. @Br{rusgenn}, {rusk}, bark:
  *{rûsko-}; whence Fr. {ruche}, beehive (of bark), O.Fr. {rusche},
  {rusque}, Pied. {rusca}, bark.  Stokes thinks the Celtic is
  probably an old borrwo from the Teutonic - M.H.G. {rusche},
  rush, Eng. @Eng{rush}, rushes; but unlikely.  The Corn. and Br.
  vowel {u} does not tally with Gadelic {û}; this seems to imply
  borrowing among the Celts themseles.
<rùta>, a ram, ridglinng; from Norse {hrútr}, ram.
<rùtachd>, rutting: from the Eng.
<rutaidh>, surly (Carm.): {rut}, ram (Carm.).
<rùtan>, the hor of a roebuck:
<ruth>, desire (Carm.):
<rùthan> (better @Ref<rùghan>), a peat heap (= @Ref{dais.1}); from the Norse
  {hrúgi}, heap.
<rutharach>, quarrelsome, fighting (H.S.D. marks it obsolete;
  Arms.), Ir. @Ir{rútharach} (O'R.); from @Ref{ruathar}.
<-sa>, @Ref<-se>, @Ref<-san>, emphatic pronominal particle attached to personal
  pronouns and to nouns preceded by the possessive pronouns:
  @Ref<mi-se>, I myself, @Ref<thu-sa>, @Ref<sibh-se>, @Ref<i-se> (she), @Ref<e-san>, @Ref<iad-san>;
  @Ref<mo cheann-sa>, @Ref<a cheann-san>, his head.  So also modern Ir.,
  save that @Ref{esan} is {ésean}: O.Ir. @OIr{-sa}, @Ref{-se} (1st pers.), {su}, {-so}, pl.
  {-si} (2nd pers.), {-som}, {-sem} (3rd pers. {m.} and {n.}, sing., and pl.),
  {-si} (3rd pers. {f.}).  All are cases of the pronominal root {so-}, {-se};
  Gr. @Gr{ὁ}, the (= @Gr{σο}); Ag.S. {se}, the (m.), Eng. @Eng{she}.  See @Ref{so}, @Ref{sin}.
--page 299
<sabaid>, a brawl, fight; see @Ref{tabaid}:
<Sàbaid>, Sabbath, Ir. @Ir{Sabóid}, M.Ir. @MIr{sapoit}; from Lat. {sabbatum},
  whence Eng. @Eng{sabbath}; from Hebrew {shabbáth}.
<sabh.1>, sorrel, Ir. @Ir{samh}; better @Ref{samh.2}, q.v.
<sabh.2>, ointment, salve; from Sc. {saw}, Eng. @Eng{salve}.
<sàbh>, a saw, Ir. @Ir{sábh}; from the Eng.
<sàbhail>, save, Manx {sauail}, Ir. @Ir{sabhailim} ({sábhálaim}, O'B.); from
  Lat. {salvare}, to save.  Kuno Meyer says from Eng. @Eng{save}.
<sabhal>, a barn, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{saball}, Ir.Lat. {zabulum}; through
  Brittonic from Lat. {stabulum}, a stall, Eng. @Eng{stable}.  Cf. M.Ir.
  {stéferus} = zephyr.
<sabhd>, a lie, fable (H.S.D., Dial.), straying, lounging; cf. @Ref{saobh}.
<sabhs>, sauce, Ir. @Ir{sabhsa}; from the Eng.
<sabhsair>, a sausage; founded on the English word.
<sac.1>, a sack, Ir. @Ir{sac}, E.Ir. @EIr{sacc}, W. @W{sach}; from Ag.S. {sacc}, Eng.
  {sack}, Got. {sakkus}, Lat. {saccus}.
<sac.2>, a load, burden, Ir. @Ir{sacadh}, pressing into a sack or bag, Low Lat.
  {saccare} (do.); from Fr. {sac}, pillage, the same as Eng.
  {sack}, plunder, all borrowed from {saccus}, a sack or bag.
<sachasan>, sand-eel:
<sad.1>, dust shaken from anything by beating, a smart blow, @Ref<sadadh>,
  dusting, beating.
<sad.2>, aught (M`D.: Cha 'n' eil sad agam, I have naught):
<sagart>, a priest, Ir. @Ir{sagart}, O.Ir. @OIr{sacart}, {sacardd}; from Lat.
  {sacerdos}, whence Eng. @Eng{sacerdotal}.
<saidealta>, @Ref<soidealta>, shy, bashful, Ir. @Ir{soidialta}, rude, ignorant;
  from @Ref{sodal}, q.v.
<saidh.1>, an upright beam, prow of a ship, a handle or the part of a
  blade in the handle:
<saidh.2>, bitch; see @Ref{saigh}:
<saidh.3>, @Ref<saidhean>, the saith fish (Arg.); from N. {seiðr}, the gadus
  virens, now {sei}.
<saidhe>, hay; formed from the Eng. @Eng{hay} by the influence of the
  article ({an t-hay} becoming a supposed de-eclipsed {say}).
<saidse>, sound of a falling body, a crash, noise (Badenoch Dial.
  @Ref<doidse>, a dint):
<saigean>, a corpulent little man:
<saigh>, a bitch, Ir. @Ir{saith} (Con., Lane, etc.), {sagh}, {saighín} (O'Br.),
  M.Ir. @MIr{sogh}, {sodh}, E.Ir. @EIr{sod}, bitch, she-wolf:
<saighdear>, soldier, archer, Ir. @Ir{sáighdiur} (do.), M.Ir. @MIr{saigdeoir},
  sagittarius, W. @W{sawdwr}, soldier; from M.Eng. {soudiour},
  {sougeour}, Sc. {sodger}, now {soldier}, confused in Gadelic with an
  early borrow from Lat. {sagittarius}, archer.
<saighead>, an arrow, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{saiget}, W. @W{saeth}, Corn. @Corn{seth}, Br.
  {saez}; from Lat. {sagitta}.  For root see @Ref{ionnsuidh}.
--page 300
<sail>, a beam, Ir. @Ir{sail}: *{spali-}, allied to Ger. {spalten}, split, Eng.
  {spill}, {split}.
<sàil>, a heel, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{sál}, W. @W{sawdl}, Br. @Br{seuzl}: *{sâtlâ}.  Ascoli
  has lately revived the old derivatino from *{stâ-tlô-}, root {sta},
  stand; but {st} initial does not in native words become {s} in
  Gadelic.
<saill.1>, fat or fatness, Ir. @Ir{saill}, fat, bacon, pickle: *{saldi-}; Eng.
  {salt}, etc.; Lit. {saldùs}, sweet.  See @Ref{salann} further.
<saill.2>, salt thou, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{saillim}, condio, *{saldio}, salt: *{salni-};
  see @Ref{salann}.
<sailm>, a decoction, oak-bark decoction to staunch blood, a consumption
  pectoral; founded on M.Eng. {salfe}, now {salve}?
<sàimhe>, luxury, sensuality, Ir. @Ir{sáimhe}, peace, luxury, E.Ir. @EIr{sáim},
  pleasant: *{svadmi-}; Eng. @Eng{sweet}, Gr. @Gr{ἑδύς}, etc.  But cf.
  @Ref{sàmhach}.
<saimir>, the trefoil clover (A.M`D.), Ir. @Ir{seamar}; see @Ref{seamrag}.
<sainnseal>, a handsel, New Year's gift; from Sc. {handsel}, M.Eng.
  {hansell}, i.e. {hand-sellan}, deliver.
<saith>, the back bone, joint of the neck or backbone, Ir. @Ir{saith},
  joint of neck or backbone (Lh., O'B., etc.):
<sàl>, also @Ref<sàil>, @Ref<sàile>, sea, Ir. @Ir{sáile}, E.Ir. @EIr{sál}, {sáile}: *{svâlos}, root {sval},
  {svel}; Lat. {salum}, sea; Eng. @Eng{swell} (Stokes, who also refers
  Br. @Br{c'hoalen}, salt).  Shräder equates Gadelic with Gr. @Gr{ἅλς},
  salt, the sea, and Lat. {salum}, root {sal}.
<salach>, dirty, Ir., so O.Ir. @OIr{salach}, W. @W{halawg}, {halog}, Corn. @Corn{halou},
  stercora, O.Br. @OBr{haloc}, lugubri: *{salâko-s} (adj.), root {sal}, to
  dirty; Eng. @Eng{sallom}, O.H.G. {salo}, dusky, dirty.  {sal}, filth,
  is used.
<salann>, salt, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{salann}, W. @W{halen}, Corn. @Corn{haloin}, Br. @Br{halenn}
  (*{salên}): *{salanno-s}, salt; Lat. {sal}; Gr. @Gr{ἁλς}, salt, sea; Eng.
  {salt}, Ger. {salz}; Ch.Sl. {solĭ}.
<salldair>, a chalder; from Sc. {chalder}, Eng. @Eng{chalder}, {chaldron}, from
  O.Fr. {chaldron}, a caldron.
<salm>, a psalm, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{salm}, W. and Br. @Br{salm}; from Lat.
  {psalmus}, Eng. @Eng{psalm}.
<saltair>, trample, Ir. @Ir{saltairim}; from Lat. {saltare}, dance.
<samh.1>, the smell of the air in a close room, ill odour:
<samh.2>, sorrel, Ir. @Ir{samh}:
<samh.3>, a god, giant (Carm.):
<samh.4>, a clownish person; cf. Sc. {sow}, one who makes a dirty
  appearance, "a pig".
<samhach>, wooden haft, handle, Ir. @Ir{samhthach}, O.Ir. @OIr{samthach}; cf.
  O.Ir. @OIr{samaigim}, pono (which Ascoli refers to *{stam}, root {sta},
  stand).  Cf. {sam}, together, of @Ref{samhuinn}.
--page 301
<sàmhach>, quiet, Ir. @Ir{sámhach} (Coneys has @Ref{samhach}), still, pleasant,
  from {sámh}, ({samh}), pleasant, still, E.Ir. @EIr{sám}, {sáme}, rest, quiet,
  {sáim}, mild, quiet: *{sâmo-}.  Possibly allied to Eng. @Eng{soft},
  O.H.G. {samfto}, softly, Got. {samjan}, please; and the root {sam}
  of @Ref{samhradh}.  Stokes suggests connectino with Zend {hâma},
  like, Ch.Sl. {samŭ}, ipse, Norse {sömr}, {samr}, Eng. @Eng{same}; or
  Gr. @Gr{ἡμερος}, tame.  Cf. @Ref{sàimhe}.
<samhail>, @Ref<samhuil>, likeness, like, Ir. @Ir{samhail}, like, @Ref{samhuil}, likeness,
  simile, W. @W{hafal}, similis, O.W. @OW{amal}, Corn. @Corn{haval}, @Corn{avel},
  Br. @Br{haual}: *{samali-}; Gr. @Gr{ὁομαλός}, like; Lat. {similis}; Eng.
  {same}.
<samhainn>, see @Ref{samhuinn}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<samhan>, savin-bush, Ir. @Ir{samhán}; from Eng. @Eng{savin}, M.Eng. {saveine},
  Ag.S. {savine}, Lat. {sabina}.
<samhnan>, @Ref<samhnachan>, a large river trout (H.S.D., Dial.):
<samhradh>, summer, Ir. @Ir{samhradh}, {sámhradh}, E.Ir. @EIr{samrad}, {sam},
  W., Corn. @Corn@W{haf}, M.Br. @MBr{haff}, Br. @Br{hanv}: *{samo-}; Skr. {sámâ},
  year, Zend {hama}, summer, Arm. @Ref{ամ}, year; further Eng.
  {summer}, Gr. @Gr{ἡμέρα}, day.  The termination {rad} = {rado-n} (n.).
<samhuinn>, Hallow-tide, Ir. @Ir{samhain}, E.Ir. @EIr{samuin}, {samain}, {samfhuin}:
  usually regarded as for *{sam-fuin}, "summer-end",
  from {sam}, summer, and @Ref{fuin}, end, sunset, {fuinim}, I end, *{vo-nesô},
  root {nes}, as in @Ref{còmhnuidh}, q.v. (Stokes).  For @Ref{fuin}, Kluge
  suggests *{wen}, suffer (Got. {winnan}, suffer); Zimmer favours
  Skr. {van}, hurt (Eng. {wound}); and Ascoli analyses it into
  {fo-in-}.  Dr Stokes, however, takes {samain} from the root {som},
  same (Eng. {same}, Gr. @Gr{ὁμός}, like, Lat. {simul}, whence Eng.
  {assemble}; see @Ref{samhuil}), and makes *{samani-} mean "assembly"
  - the gathering at Tara on 1st November, while {Cét-shamain},
  our @Ref{Céitein}, was the "first feast", held on 1st May.
<samplair>, a copy, pattern, Ir. @Ir{samplair}, {sampla}; from Eng.
  {sampler}, {sample}.
<-san>, as in @Ref<esan>, ipse, @Ref<iadsan>; see @Ref{-sa}.
<sanas>, whisper, secret, Manx {sannish}, whisper, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sanas};
  *{sanastu-}, root {sven}; Lat. {sonare}, Eng. @Eng{sound}; Skr. {svánati},
  to sound.
<sannt>, desire, inclination, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{sant}, W. @W{chwant}, Corn. @Corn{whans},
  Br. @Br{c'hoant}: *{svandətâ}, desire, root {svand}, {svad}, desire, please:
  Gr. @Gr{ἁνδάνω}, please, @Gr{ἡδύς}, sweet; Skr. {svad}, relish; further
  Eng. @Eng{sweet}, etc.
<saobh>, erroneous, apt to err, dissimulation, Ir. @Ir{saobh} (adj.), O.Ir.
  {sáib}, {soib}, later {saeb}, falsus, pseudo-: *{svoibo-s}, turning aside,
  wavering, W. @W{chwifio}, turn, whirl; Eng. @Eng{sweep}, {swoop}.
<saobhaidh>, den of a wild beast, fox's den:
--page 302
<saod>, journey, intention, condition, good humour (Arg.), Ir. @Ir{saod},
  @Ref{seud}, journey, O.Ir. @OIr{sét}, way, journey, W. @W{hynt}, Br. @Br{hent},
  O.Br. @OBr{hint}: *{sento-s}; Got. {sinþs}, journey, way, O.H.G.
  {sind}, Eng. @Eng{send}.  Hence @Ref<saodaich>, drive cattle to pasture:
  Cf. {saod}, drive animals slowly (Shet.), N. {saeta}, waylay, {sát},
  ambush.
<saoghal>, the world, an age, life, Ir. @Ir{saoghal}, O.Ir. @OIr{saigul}, {saegul};
  from Lat. {saeculum}, race, age, from *{sai-tlom}, allied to W.
  {hoedl}, life.
<saoi>, @Ref<saoidh>, a good, generous man, a warrior, a scholar, Ir. @Ir{saoi},
  a worthy man, a scholar, pl. {saoithe}, E.Ir. @EIr{sái}, {sui}, a sage,
  g. {suad}: *{su-vid-s}, root {vid} of @Ref{fios} (Thurneysen).  Stokes
  ({Mart.Gorm.}) prefers {su-vet-}, root {vât}, say (see {fàith}).  Rhys
  agrees.

<saoibh>, foolish, perverse, Ir. @Ir{saobh} (do.); see @Ref{saobh}.

  *{su-adber}, from *{ad-beri-} (Lat. {adfero}), root {bher} of @Ref{beir},

<saoitear>, oversman, tutor (Suth.); see @Ref{taoitear}.

  man", free; from {su} (= @Ref{so-}) and {viro-s}, @Ref{fear}, q.v.
<saor.2>, a carpenter, Ir. @Ir{saor}, W. @W{saer}, Corn. @Corn{sair}: *{sairo-s}, from
  *{sapiro-s}, root {sap}, skill, Lat. {sapio}, {sapientia}, wisdom, Ag.S.
  {sefa}, understanding, sense (Stokes, who thinks the Brittonic
  may be borrowed).
<saothair>, labour, toil, Ir. @Ir{sothar}, E.Ir. @EIr{sáthar}, O.Ir. @OIr{sáithar}, g.

<sapair>, @Ref<sapheir>, sapphire, Ir. @Ir{saphír}; from Lat. {sapphirus}, whence
  Eng. also.
<sàr.1>, oppression, @Ref<sàraich>, oppress, Ir. @Ir{sáruighim}, O.Ir. @OIr{sáraigim},
  violo, contemno {sár}, outrage, contempt W. @W{sarhäed} contumelia:
  *{sâro-n}, *{spâro-n}, root {sper}, kick, spurn; Lat.
  {sperno}; Eng. @Eng{spurn}; Lit. {spìrti}, kick; Skr. {sphur}, jerk
  (Stokes).  The W. has the {a} pretonic short; is it borrowed
  from Ir. (Stokes)?
