<sàr.2>, excellent, Ir., E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{sár-}, W. @W{hoer}, positive, stubborn,
  assertion, Ogmic {Netta-sagru}, {Sgerettos}, {Sagrammi}: *{sagro-s},
  strong, root {seg}; Gr. @Gr{ὀχυρός}, strong, fast, @Gr{ἒχω}, have; Ger.
  {sieg}, victory; Skr. {sáhas}, might.
<sàrdail>, a sprat; from the Eng. @Eng{sardel} (Bailey), now {sardine}.
<sàs>, straits, restraint, hold, E.Ir. @EIr{sás}, a trap, fixing; from @Ref{sàth.2},
  transfix, q.v.
<sàsaich>, satisfy, Ir. @Ir{sásaighim}, O.Ir. @OIr{sásaim}; from @Ref{sàth.1}, q.v.
<sàth.1>, plenty, satiety, Ir. @Ir{sáth}, {sáith}, E.Ir. @EIr{sáith}: *{sâti-}; Got. {sóþ},
  satiety, Ger. {satt} (adj.); Lit. {sótis}; Lat. {sat}, enough, {satur},
  full, whence Eng. @Eng{satisfy}, etc.
<sàth.2>, thrust, transfix, Ir. @Ir{sáthadh}, a thrust, push, M.Ir. @MIr{sáthud},
  driving, thrusting, E.Ir. @EIr{sádim} (L.U.), O.Ir. @OIr{im-sadaim},
  jacio, W. @W{hodi}, shoot; possibly from {sô}, {sê}, hurl, as in @Ref{sìol}:
<sath>, @Ref<saith>, bad (Dial. {maith na saith, math na sath}), M.Ir. @MIr{sath}
  (Lecan Glossary), @Ref{saith}, O.Ir. @OIr{saich} ({cid saich no maith}):
  *{saki-s}, root {svak}, {svag}, weak, Ger. {schwach}.
<Sathairn>, @Ref<Di-sathairn>, Saturday; see under @Ref{di-}.
<sè>, @Ref<sèa>, @Ref<sia>, six, Ir. @Ir{sé}, O.Ir. @OIr{sé}, W. @W{chwech}, Corn. @Corn{wheh}, Br. @Br{c'houec'h}:
  {sveks}; Lat. {sex}; Gr. @Gr{ἕξ}; Got. {saíhs}, Eng. @Eng{six}; Skr. {shash}.
<seabh>, stray (M`A.): see @Ref{seabhaid}.
<seabhach>, trim, neat (H.S.D., Dial.):
<seabhag>, a hawk, Ir. @Ir{seabhac}, E.Ir. @EIr{sebac}, O.Ir. @OIr{sebocc}, W. @W{hebog},
  E.W. {hebauc}; from Ag.S. {heafoc}, now {hawk}, Ger. {habicht},
  Norse {haukr}, root {haf}, I.E. {qap}, Lat. {capus}, hawk, allied to
  {capio}.
<seabhaid>, an error, wandering, Ir. @Ir{seabhóid}, error, folly, wandering:
  *{sibo-}, a short form of the root of @Ref{saobh}?
<seac>, wither, Ir. @Ir{seacaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{seccaim}, {secc}, siccus, W. @W{sychu} to
  dry, {sych}, dry, Corn. @Corn{seygh}, Br. @Br{sec'h}, dry; from Lat. {siccus}.
  See further under @Ref{seasg}.
<seach>, by, past, Ir. @Ir{seach}, O.Ir. @OIr{sech}, ultra, praeter, W. @W{heb}, without,
  Corn. @Corn{heb}, Br. @Br{hep}, without: *{seqos}; Lat. {secus}, otherwise,
  by, {sequor}, I follow (Eng. {prosecute}, etc.); Gr. @Gr{ἑπομαι}, I follow,
  Skr has {sácâ}, with, together, Zend {haca}, out, for.  Hence G.
  and Ir. @Ref<seachad>, past, G. and Ir. @Ref<seachain>, avoid.
<seachd>, seven, Ir. @Ir{seachd}, O.Ir. @OIr{secht n-}, W. @W{saith}, Corn. @Corn{seyth}, Br.
  {seiz}: *{septṇ}; Lat. {septem}; Gr. @Gr{ἑπτά}; Got., O.H.G. {siban},

<seachduin>, a week, Ir. @Ir{seachdmhain}, O.Ir. @OIr{sechtman}, Corn. @Corn{seithum},
  Br. @Br{sizun}; from Lat. {septimana}, from {septem}.
<seachlach>, a heifer barren though of age to bear a calf; cf. O.Ir.
  {sechmal}, præteritio (= {sechm}, past, and {ell}, go, as in @Ref{tadhal.1}).
  Ir. @Ir{seachluighim}, lay aside.  H.S.D. suggests {seach-laogh},
  "past calf".  {seach-la}, surviving, still spared (Suth.).

<seachran>, wandering, error, Ir. @Ir{seachrán}, E.Ir. @EIr{sechrán}: *{sech-reth-an},
  from @Ref{seach} and @Ref{ruith}, run?
<seadh.1>, yes, it is, Ir. @Ir{'seadh}, for {is eadh}, it is; see @Ref{is.1} and @Ref{eadh.1}, it.
<seadh.2>, sense; usual spelling of @Ref{seagh}, q.v.
<seagal>, rye, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{secul}; from Lat. {secale}, whence also Br.
  {segal}.
<seagh>, sense, esteem, Ir. @Ir{seagh}, regard, esteem, strength, {seaghdha},
  learned (O'Cl.), M.Ir. @MIr{seg}, strength, Gaul. {sego-}: *{sego-},
  strength, pith; Norse {sigr}, victory, Ger. {sieg}; Skr. {sáhas},
  might; further Gr. @Gr{ἐχω}, have; I.E. {segh}, hold.
<seal>, a while, space, Ir. @Ir{seal}, O.Ir. @OIr{sel}, W. @W{chwyl}, versio, turning,
  Br. @Br{hoel}, "du moins", root {svel}, turn.  Bez. (apud Stokes)
  compares Lettic {swalstit}, move hither and thither; to which
  cf. Gr. @Gr{σαλεύω}, I toss.
<sealbh>, possession, cattle, luck, Ir. @Ir{sealbh}, E.Ir. @EIr{selb}, O.Ir. @OIr{selbad},
  W. @W{helw}, possession, ownership: *{selvâ}, possession, root {sel},
  take, E.Ir. @EIr{selaim}, I take, Gr. @Gr{ἑλεῖν}, take; Got. {saljan}, offer,
  Eng. @Eng{sell}.  Windisch has compared Got. {silba}, Eng. @Eng{self}
  (pronominal root {sve}).
<sealbhag>, sorrel, Ir. @Ir{sealbhóg}; usually regarded as for {searbhag},
  "bitter herb" (cf. Eng. @Eng{sorrel} from {sour}).  The change of {r} to
  {l} is a difficulty, but it may be due to the analogy of @Ref{mealbhag}.
<sealbhan>, the throat, throttle: *{svel-vo-}, Eng. @Eng{swallo} (*{svel-ko-})?
<sealg.1>, a hunt, Ir. @Ir{sealg}, O.Ir. @OIr{selg}, W. @W{hela}, {hel}, to hunt, O.W.
  {helghati}, venare, Corn. @Corn{helhia}, British {Selgovae}, now Solway:
  *{selgâ}, a hunt, root {sel}, capture (see @Ref{sealbh}).
<sealg.2>, milt, spleen, Ir. @Ir{sealg}, M.Ir. @MIr{selg}, Br. @Br{felc'h}: *{selgâ}, *{spelgâ};
  Gr. @Gr{σπλάγχνα}, the higher viscera, @Gr{σπλήν}, spleen (*{splghēn});
  Lat. {liēn}; Skr. {plîhán}, spleen; Ch.Sl. {slēzena}, Lit. {blużnis};
  also Eng. @Eng{lung}.
<seall>, look, E.Ir. @EIr{sellaim}, {sell}, eye, W. @W{syllu}, to gaze, view, Br.
  {sellet}; cf. @Ref{solus}.  Stokes gives the Celtic as *{stilnaô}, I see,
  comparing the Gr. @Gr{στιλπνός}.

<seamsan>, hesitation, quibbling, delay, sham; from the Eng. @Eng{sham},

<sean>, old, Ir. @Ir{sean}, O.Ir. @OIr{sen}, W., Corn., and O.Br. @OBr{hen}, Gaul.
  {Seno-}: *{seno-s}, old; Lat. {senex}, g. {senis}, old man; Gr. @Gr{ἑνος},
  old; Got. {sinista}, oldest, Eng. @Eng{seneschal}; Lit. {sénas}; Skr. {sánas}.
<seanachas>, conversation, story, Ir. @Ir{seanachas}, {seanchus}, tale,
  history, genealogy, O.Ir. @OIr{senchas}, vetus historia, lex, O.W.
  {hencass}, monimenta.  Stokes refers this to *{seno-kastu-}, "old story",
  from *{kastu-}, root {kans}, speak (see @Ref{cainnt} and Stokes'
  derivation of it).  Regarded by others as a pure derivative of
  *{seno-} or its longer stem *{seneko-} (Lat. {senex}, Got. {sineigo}, old,
  Skr. {sanakás}, old), that is *{senekastu-}.  Hence @Ref<seanachaidh>,
  a reciter of ancient lore, a historian, Ir. @Ir{seanchuidh}, a form
  which favours the second derivation.
<seanadh>, a senate, synod, Ir. @Ir{seanadh}, {seanaidh}, E.Ir. @EIr{senod}, W.
  @W{senedd}, Corn. @Corn{sened}, Br. @Br{senez}; from the Lat. {synodus}, now
  Eng. @Eng{synod}.
<seanagar>, old-fashioned, knowing; cf. Ir. @Ir{senfha}, W. @W{henwr}:
<seanair>, a grandfather, Ir. @Ir{seanathair}, M.Ir. @MIr{senathair}, literally
  "old father".
<seang>, slender, lean, Ir. @Ir{seang}, E.Ir. @EIr{seng}: *{svengo-s}; Norse

  it denotes {wet} or marsh land.

<seòl.2>, a sail Ir. @Ir{seól}, O.Ir. @OIr{séol}, {seól}, {seol}, g. {siúil}, W. @W{hwyl}, O.W.
  {huil}: usually referred to *{seghlo-} (root of @Ref{seagh}) or to
  Teutonic {seglo-}, sail (also from *{seghlo-}), borrowed into Celtic.
  In either case we should expect Ir. *{sél}, W. *{hail}, but we
  have neither.  Strachan suggests that {seól} is formed from
  g. {siúil} on the analogy of {ceól}, etc.; while W. @W{hwyl} may
  have been effected by a borrow from Lat. {vêlum} (Corn. {guil},
  Br. @Br{goel}).

  says the word belongs to the North Highlands; Arm. does
  not have it.  Ir. has {sgiot}, a dart, arrow: "something shot".

  charge.

  Br. @Br{skouîz}, {skuîz}: *{skîto-}, *{skîtto-} (Brittonic *{skvîtto-}, according

  says North):

  {sclaff}, a blow, Prov.Fr. {esclaffa}, to beat (Ducange), Med.Lat.
  {eclaffa}.

  see @Ref{glàm}.

<sian.1>, a scream, soft music (Carm.), Ir. @Ir{sian}, voice, shout, sound,
  E.Ir. @EIr{sian}: *{svêno-}, which Stokes (@ExtRef{Zeit.;28;59}) explains as
  *{sesveno-}, root {sven}, sound (see @Ref{seinn}).
<sian.2>, a pile of grass, beard of barley, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sion}, foxglove, W.
  {ffion}, digitalis, {ffuon}, foxglove, O.W. @OW{fionou}, roses, Br.
  {foeonnenn}, privet.  Stokes gives the Celtic as *{(p)êâno-}.
  Gadelic might be allied to Lat. {spîna}, thorn.
<sian.3>, a charm; see @Ref{seun.1}.
<sian.4>, storm, rain, Ir. @Ir{síon}, weather, season, storm, O.Ir. @OIr{sín},
  tempestas, W. @W{hin}, weather, M.Br. @MBr{hynon}, fair weather:
  *{sênâ}; root {sê} ({sêi}) as in @Ref{sìn}, @Ref{sìor}; Norse @Ref{seinn}, slow, late,
  M.H.G. {seine}, slowly, Eng. @Eng{sith}, {since}.
<sianan>, @Ref<breac-shianain>, freckles; from @Ref{sian.2}, foxglove?  See
  @Ref{seunan}.

<siar>, westward, aside, Ir. @Ir{siar}, O.Ir. @OIr{síar}; from {s-iar}, see @Ref{iar.2},
  west, and {s-} under @Ref{suas}.
<siaranachadh>, languishing, @Ref<siarachd>, melancholy (Dial.); from
  @Ref{siar}, "going backwards"?
<siasnadh>, wasting, dwining (Suth.):
<siatag>, rheumatism; from Lat. {sciatica}.
<sibh>, you, ye, Ir. @Ir{sibh}, O.Ir. @OIr{sib}, {si}, W. @W{chwi}, O.W. @OW{hui}, Corn. @Corn{why},
  Br. @Br{c'houi}: *{sves}, for {s-ves} (Brug.; Stokes has *{svês}); Gr.
  @Gr{σφῶï}, you two, Got. {izvis} ({iz-vis}); the {ves} is allied to Lat. {vos}.
  The form {sibh} is for *{svi-svi}.
<sic>, the prominence of the belly (H.S.D.), peritoneum (M`A.):
<sicear>, particle, grain (Carm.):
<sicir>, wise, steady; from Sc. {sicker}, M.Eng. {siker}, from Lat.
  {securus}, now Eng. @Eng{sure}.  W. @W{sicr} is from M.Eng.
<sìd>, weather, peasceful weather after storm, tide: *{sizdi-},
  "settling", root {sed}, sit?  Ir. has {síde} in the sense of "blast",
  from @Ref{séid}.  Also {tìd}, which suggests borrowing from N. {tíð},
  tide, time, Eng. @Eng{tide}.
<sil>, drop, distil, Ir. @Ir{silim}, perf. {siblais}, stillavit, Br. @Br{sila}, passez:
  *{sviliô}.  Stokes gives the root as {stil}, Lat. {stillo}, drop, Gr.
  @Gr{στíλη} (do.).  Hence @Ref<silt>, a drop.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{spill}; *{spild},
  destroy, spoil.
<sile>, spittle, saliva, Ir. @Ir{seile}, O.Ir. @OIr{saile}, W. @W{haliw}, Br. @Br{hal}, {halo}:
  *{salivâ} (Stokes); Lat. {saliva}.  Stokes says that they appear
  to be borrowed from Lat., while Wharton thinks the Lat. is
  borrowed from Gaulish.
<sìliche>, a lean, pithless creature: "seedy", from @Ref{sìol}?
<simid>, a mallet, beetle, Ir. @Ir{siomaide}:
<similear>, a chimney, Ir. @Ir{seimileur}, {simnear}, {simne}; from Eng., Sc.
  {chimley}, Eng. @Eng{chimney}.
<simleag>, a silly woman; from @Ref{simplidh}.
<simplidh>, simple, Ir. @Ir{simplidhe}, silly, simple; from Lat. {simplex},
  whence Eng. @Eng{simple}, W. @W{syml}.
<sin>, that, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{sin}, O.W. @OW{hinn}, W. @W{hyn}, @W{hwn}, @W{hon}, Corn. @Corn{hen},
  @Corn{hon} (fem.), Br. @Br{hen}, Gaul. {sosin} (= {so-sin}); from root {so} ({sjo}),
  as in @Ref{-sa}, @Ref{so}, q.v.
<sìn>, stretch, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{sínim}: *{sêno-}, root {sê}, mittere, let go; Lat.
  {sino}, {situs}; Gr. @Gr{ἱημι}, send.  Cf. {sìr} (from *{sêro-}, long).
  Allied is root {sêi}, {sei}, {si}, mittere, Norse {síðr}, long, @Ref{seinn}, slow,
  Lit. {seinyti}, reach.
<sine>, a teat, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sine}, {triphne}, tree-teated: *{svenio-} for
  *{spenio-}, root {spen} of Lit. {spėnýs}, udder teat, O.Pruss.
  {spenis}, teat, Norse {speni}, teat, Du. {speen}, udder, Sc. {spain}, wean.
<sineubhar>, gin, juniper tree (Suth.); Fr. {geniêvre}.
--page 323
<sinn>, we, us, Ir. @Ir{sinn}, E.Ir. @EIr{sinn}, {sinne}, O.Ir. @OIr{ni}, {sni}, {snisni}, {sninni},
  W. @W{ni}, {nyni}, Corn. @Corn{ny}, {nyni}, Br. @Br{ni}: *{nes} (Brug.; Stokes gives
  {nês}), accusative form, allied to Lat. {nôs}, Skr. {nas}, Gr. @Gr{νώ}.  The
  {s} of {sni} is due to analogy with the {s} of @Ref{sibh}, or else prothetic
  (cf. {is-sé}, he is).
<sinnsear>, ancestors, Ir. @Ir{sinnsear}, ancestors, an elder person, E.Ir.
  {sinser}, elder, ancestor: *{senistero-}, a double comparative form
  (like Lat. {minister}, {magister}) from @Ref{sean}, old, q.v.
<sìnte>, plough traces, from @Ref{sìn}.
<sìnteag>, a skip, pace; from @Ref{sìn}.
<sìob>, drift as snow (M`A.); see @Ref{siab}.
<siobag>, a blast of the mouth, puff, Ir. @Ir{siobóg}; cf. @Ref{siab}.
<sìoban>, foam on crest of waves; see @Ref{siaban}.

<sìth.1>, peace, Ir. @Ir{síth}, {síoth}, E.Ir. @EIr{síth}, O.Ir. @OIr{síd}: *{sêdos} (neut. {s}
  stem), root {sed} ({sêd}) of @Ref<suidhe>, q.v.; Lat. {sêdo}, settle; Lit.
  {sėdáti}, sit.  W. @W{hedd}, peace, is from {sĕd}.
<sìth.2>, a fairy, @Ref<sìthich> (do.), Ir. @Ir{sídh}, a fairy hill, {sígh}, a fairy,
  {sígheóg} (do.), O.Ir. @OIr{síde}, dei terreni, whose dwelling is called
  {síd}; in fact, {síde}, the fairy powers, is the pl. (ge. s. ?) of {síd},
  fairy dwelling or mound, while its gen. sing. appears in {mná síde},
  {fir síde}: *{sêdos}, g. {sêdesos}, as in the case of @Ref{sìth.1}, peace,
  which is its homonym (Stokes); root {se}, {sêd}, Gr. @Gr{ἑδος}, a
  temple or statue, literally an "abode" or "seat"; Lat. {noven-sides},
  {noven-siles}, the new gods imported to Rome.  Thurneysen
  has compared Lat. {sîdus}, a constellation, "dwelling of
  the gods".  Hence @Ref<sìthean>, a green knoll, fairy knoll.
<sithionn>, venison, Ir. @Ir{sídh}, and {sídheann} (O'R.), M.Ir. @MIr{sieng}, {sideng},

  deer: *{sedi-}, deer; to which is to be referred M.Ir. @MIr{segh}
  (= agh allaidh, O'Cl.), E.Ir. @EIr{ség} (= oss allaidh, Corm.).

<slad>, theft, Ir. @Ir{slad}, M.Ir. @MIr{slat}: *{sladdo-}.  Stokes gives the Celtic

  *{stḷ-ddo-}, allied to Eng. @Eng{steal}?

<slaod>, drag, trail, Ir. @Ir{slaodaim}, draw after, slide, {slaod}, a raft,

<slighe>, a way, Ir. @Ir{slighe}, E.Ir. @EIr{slige}, g. {sliged}: *{sleget-}, root {sleg} of

<slinn>, a weaver's sley or reed, Ir. @Ir{slinn}, a sley, M.Ir. @MIr{slind}, pecten,
  also @Ref{slige}, pecten, which suggests for {slinn} a stem: *{sleg-s-ni-},
  {sleg} being the same root as that of @Ref{slighe} and @Ref{slachd}.  Cf.
  Eng. @Eng{sley} allied to {slay}, smite.  Stokes refers both O.Ir.
  {slind}, tile and weaver's sley, to the root {splid}, {splind}, Eng.
  {split}, {splint}.  See @Ref{slinnean} and @Ref{sliseag} further.
<slinnean>, shoulder blade, shoulder, Ir. @Ir{slinneán}, M.Ir. @MIr{slindén}: cf.
  O.Ir. @OIr{slind}, imbrex, tile, Ir. @Ir{slinn}, slate, tile, also E.Ir. @EIr{slind-gér},
  smooth-sharp, slate-polished (?), {slinnd-glanait}, whetstone-cleaned:
  *{slindi-}, root {slid}, {sleid}, smooth, glide, Eng. @Eng{slide},
  Lit. {slidùs}, smooth.  Stokes refers {slind}, imbrex, to the root
  {splid}, {splind}, split, Eng. @Eng{split}, {splint}; see @Ref{sliseag}.
<slìob>, stroke, rub, lick, Ir. @Ir{sliobhaim}, polish, M.Ir. @MIr{slipthe},
  whettened, {slibad}, whetting, W. @W{yslipan}, burnish; from
  Norse or Ag.S. - Norse {slípa}, whet, make sleek, Ag.S.
  {slípan}, slip, glide, M.L.Ger. {slípen}, sharpen, M.Du. {slijpen},
  polish, sharpen.
<sliochd>, posterity, tribe, Ir. @Ir{sliochd}, M.Ir. @MIr{slicht}, trace, track,
  O.Ir. @OIr{slict}, vestigium: *{slektu-}, root {sleg} of @Ref{slighe} and @Ref{slachd}.
  For similar origin, cf. Ger. {geschlecht}, race, lineage.
<slìogach>, sly, Ir. @Ir{slíogach}, sleek, fawning, {slígthech}, sly; from
  Eng., Sc. {sleek}, Norse {slíkr}, smooth; I.E. {sleiℊ}, glide (see
  @Ref{sliabh}).
<slìom>, sleek, slippery, slim, the buttercup (Carm.), Ir. @Ir{slíomaim}
  flatter, smooth, gloss over; from Eng. @Eng{slim}, sly, crafty,
  slender, now "slim", Sc. {slim}, naughty, {slim o'er}, gloss over,
  O.Du. {slim}, awry, crafty, Ger. {schlimm}, bad, cunning.
  Hence G. @Ref<slìomaire>, weakling, craven.
<sliop>, a lip, blubber lip; from Eng. @Eng{lip}.
<slios>, the side of a man or beast, flank, Ir. @Ir{slios}, O.Ir. @OIr{sliss}, pl.
  {slessa}, W. @W{ystlis}: *{stlisti-}, root {stel}, extend, Lat. {stlâtus}, {lâtus},
  wide, Ch.Sl. {stelja}, spread.
<slis>, @Ref<sliseag>, a chip, Ir. @Ir{slis}, {sliseóg}, E.Ir. @EIr{sliss}: *{slissi-}, from
  *{splid-s-ti}, root {splid}. Eng. @Eng{split}, {splice}, {splint}, Ger. {spleissen},
  etc.  Eng. @Eng{slice} has been compared, Eng. @Eng{slit}, root {slid}, which
  could also produce the Gadelic forms.
<slisneach>, a plant like the {slan-lus} (Carm.):
<sloc>, a pit, slough, Ir. @Ir{sloc}: *{slukko-}, for *{slug-ko-}, root {slug},
  swallow, as in @Ref{slug}, q.v.  Skeat derives hence Ag.S. {slóh},
  Eng. @Eng{slough}.  Ger. {schlucht}, hollow, ravine, is referred by
  Kluge to the root {slup}, lubricus.

<slod>, a puddle, Ir. @Ir{slod}; see @Ref{lod}.
<slòcan>, sloke; from the Sc. or Eng. @Eng{sloke}.
<sloinn>, surname, Ir. @Ir{sloinnim}, I name, O.Ir. @OIr{slondim}, name,
  significo, {slond}, significatio, O.W. @OW{islinnit}, profatur, M.W.
  {cy-stlwn}, family and clan name, W. @W{ystlyned}, kindred, {ystlen},
  sex: *{stlondo-}, *{stlondiô}, I speak, name.
<sloisir>, dash, beat against sea-like, daub; from Sc. {slaister},
  bedaub, a wet liquid mass, to move clumsily through a miry
  road, also {slestir} (Badenoch Dial. @Ref<sleastair>, bedaub).
<sluagh>, people, Ir. @Ir{sluagh}, O.Ir. @OIr{sluag}, {slóg}, W. @W{llu}, Corn. @Corn{lu},
  Gaul. {slôgi}, in {Catu-slogi}: *{slougo-s}, cf. Slav. {sluga}, a servant,
  Lit. {slauginti}.
<sluaisreadh>, act of mixing (lime, etc.) with a shovel; see
  @Ref{sluasaid}.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{slubber}.
<sluasaid>, a shovel, Ir. @Ir{sluasad}, a paddle, a shovel:
<slug>, swallow, @Ref<slugadh> (inf.), Ir. @Ir{slugaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{slucim}, {slocim}:
  *{sluggô}, root {slug}, {lug}, swallow; Ger. {schlucken}, to swallow,
  M.H.G. {slucken}: Gr. @Gr{λύζω}, @Gr{λυγγαíνω}, have the hiccup.  W.
  {llwnc}, gullet, a gulp, {llyncu}, to swallow, O.Br. @OBr{ro-luncas},
  guturicavit, M.Br. @MBr{lloncaff} are allied to E.Ir. @EIr{longad}, now
  @Ref{longadh}, eating, which is a nasalised form of the root {slug},
  {lug}.
<smachd>, authority, correction, Ir. @Ir{smachd}, O.Ir. @OIr{smacht}, M.Ir.
  {smachtaigim}, I enjoin, {smacht}, fine for breaking the law:
  *{smaktu-}, from {s-mag}, root {mag}, I.E. @Ref{magh}, be strong; Eng.
  {may}, Got. {magan}, be able; Gr. @Gr{μῆχος}, means (see @Ref{mac}).
<smad>, a particle, jot: "spot, stain" (see @Ref{smod}).  From Sc. {smad},
  {smot}, a stain, Eng. @Eng{smut}.  Ir. has {smadán}, soot, smut.  Cf.
  also M.Ir. @MIr{smot}, a scrap, Ir. @Ir{smotán}, a block, W. @W{ysmot}, patch,
  spot.
<smàd>, threaten, intimidate, boast:
<smàg>, @Ref<smòg>, a paw; see @Ref{smòg}.
<smal>, dust, spot, blemish, Ir. @Ir{smál}, {smól}; root {smal}, @Ref{mal} ({smel},
  {mel}), Lit. {smálkas}, dust, {smėlynas}, sand field, {smelalis}, sand,
  Lettic {smelis}, water sand, Got. {málma}, sand, Norse {melr}, sand
  hill, Eng. @Eng{mole}.
<smàl>, snuff a candle, Ir. @Ir{smál}, embers, snuff of candle; cf.
  @Ref{smal}.
<smalag>, the young saith or cuddie:
<smaoin>, think; see @Ref{smuain}.
<smarach>, a lad, a growing youth (Badenoch); root {smar}, from
  @Ref{mar}, {mer}, Gr. @Gr{μεῖραζ}, boy, Skr. {maryakás}, a mannie, {máryas},
  young man, Lit. {marti}, bride; also W. @W{morwyn}, girl, {merch},
--page 330
  daughter, Br. @Br{merc'h}.  Cf. Aran Ir. @Ir{marlach}, child of two to
  five years, either sex.
<smarag>, an emerald, Ir. @Ir{smaragaid};  from Lat. {smaragdus}, whence
  through Fr. comes Eng. @Eng{emerald}.
<smeachan>, the chin, Ir. @Ir{smeach}, {smeachan}, E.Ir. @EIr{smech}: *{smekâ};
  Lit. {smakrà}, Lettic {smakrs}, chin, palate; Skr. {çmaçru}, moustache.
<smeadairneach>, a slumber, slight sleep:
<smeallach>, @Ref<smealach>, remains, offals, dainties:
<smèid>, beckon, nod, Ir. @Ir{sméidim}, beckon, nod, hiss: *{smeiddi-},
  root {smeid}, smile, Gr. @Gr{μειδάω}, smile, Pruss. {smaida}, a smile,
  Eng. @Eng{smile}.  W. @W{amneidio}, beckon, nod, O.W. @OW{enmeituou},
  nutus, O.Br. @OBr{enmetiam}, innuo, do not agree in vowel with
  Gadelic.
<smeileach>, pale, ghastly, @Ref<smeilean>, a pale, puny person; cf.
  {meileach}.
<smeòirn>, the end of an arrow next the bowstring, @Ref<smeorine>, back
  end of arrow head (Wh.), Ir. @Ir{smeirne}, a spit, broach (Sh.,
  O'R.):
<smeórach>, a thrush, Ir. @Ir{smólach}, {smól}, M.Ir. @MIr{smolach}; W.
  {mwyalch}, blackbird, Corn. @Corn{moelh}, Br. @Br{moualch}: *{smugal-},
  *{smugl-}, from {mug} (see @Ref{mùch})?  Stokes derives W. @W{mwyalch},
  blackbird, from *{meisalko-}, Ger. {meise}, Eng. @Eng{tit-mouse}.
<smeur.1>, @Ref<smiar>, anoint, smear, Ir. @Ir{sméaraim}, grease, smear; from
  the Eng.  For root see @Ref{smior}.

  Br. @Br{mouar} (pl.):
<smeuraich>, grope; from @Ref{meur}.
<smid>, a syllable, opening of the mouth, a word, Ir. @Ir{smid}: *{smiddi-},
  root {smid}, {smeid}, smile, laugh, as in {sméid}?
<smig>, the chin, Ir. @Ir{smig}, M.Ir. @MIr{smeice} (O'C.): *{smeggi-}, for
  *{smek-gi}, root {smek}, as in @Ref{smeachan}?
<smigeadh>, a smile, smiling, Ir. @Ir{smig}, {smigeadh}: *{smĭggi}, root
  {smi}, smile, for which see @Ref{smèid}.  Also @Ref{mìog}, q.v.
<smiodan>, spirit; from Sc. {smeddum}.
<smiolamus>, refuse of a feast (M'A.); see @Ref{smolamas}.
<smior>, @Ref<smear>, marrow, Ir. @Ir{smior}, E.Ir. @EIr{smir}, g. {smera}, W. @W{mer}:
  *{smeru-}; O.H.G. {smero}, grease, Ag.S. {smeoru}, lard, Eng.
  @Ref{smear}, Norse {smjŏrr}, butter.
<smiot>, throw in the air with one hand and strike with the other;
  formed on Eng. @Eng{smite}.
<smiotach>, crop-eared, short-chinned (R.D.), Ir. @Ir{smiot}, ear:
<smiùr>, smear; from the Sc. @Ref{smear}, Eng. @Eng{smear}.  See @Ref{smeur.1}.
<smod>, dirt, dust, also (according to M`A.) drizzling raid; from Sc.
  {smot}, Eng. @Eng{smut}.  See @Ref{smad}.

<smodal>, sweepings, crumbs, fragments, smattering, M.Ir. @MIr{smot}, a
  scrap; cf. @Ref{smod}.
<smòg>, @Ref<smàg>, a paw; cf. Norse {smjùga}, creep through a hole,
  Ag.S. {smúgan}, creep, Eng. @Eng{smuggle}.  For @Ref<smàg>, see also
  @Ref{màg}.
<smolamas>, trash, fragments of victuals; cf. @Ref{strolamas}, @Ref{brolamas}.
<smuain>, a thought, Ir. @Ir{smuaineadh}, M.Ir. @MIr{smuained}: *{smoudn-},
  root {smoud}, {moud}; Got. {gamaudjan}, remind, cause to
  remember; Ch.Sl. {myslĭ-}, thought (Strachan).  Cf. M.Ir.
  {muaidnig}, thought.
<smuairean>, grief, dejection: *{smoudro-}, root {smoud} of above?
<smuais.1>, marrow, juice of the bones, Ir. @Ir{smuais}, marrow, E.Ir.
  {smuas}:
<smuais.2>, smash, Ir. @Ir{smuais}, in shivers, in pieces; from Eng. @Eng{smash}.
<smùc>, a snivel, a nasal sound (@Ref<smùch>, M`A.); for root, see @Ref{smug}
  ({s-mûc-c}).
<smùcan>, smoke, drizzle; from Eng. @Eng{smoke}.
<smùdan.1>, a particle of dust; see @Ref{smod}.
<smùdan.2>, a small block of wood, Ir. @Ir{smotan}, stock, block, log:
<smùdan.3>, smoke; see @Ref{smùid}.
<smug>, snot, spittle, @Ref<smugaid>, spittle, Ir. @Ir{smug}, @Ref{smugaid}: *{smuggo-},
  root {smug}, {mug}, mucus; Lat. {emungo}, wipe the nose.  The
  root {muℊ} is a by-form of {muq}, mucus, seen in Lat. {mucus}, etc.;
  for which see @Ref{muc}.
<smùid>, smoke, Ir. @Ir{smúid}, E.Ir. @EIr{smúit}, {smútgur}, {smútcheo}:
  *{smúddi-}, root {smud}.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{smut}, Ger. {schmutz}, dirt;
  which Zem. thinks the Gadelic borrowed from, though the
  meaning makes this unlikely.  There are three allied roots
  on European ground denoting "smoke" -- {smûgh} (Gr. @Gr{σμῡ́χω},
  smoulder), {smúg}, or {smaug} (Eng. {smoke}) and {smûd} (G. {smùid}).
<smuig>, a snout, the face (in ridicule): from the Eng. @Eng{mug}, ugly
  face.
<smuilc>, glumness, dejection; M.Ir. @MIr{smuilcín}, a small snout:
  "snoutyness".
<smùrach>, dross, peat dross, @Ref<smùir>, dust, a particle of dust,
  @Ref<smùirnean>, a mote; cf. Sc. {smurach}, peat dross, {smore}, {smurr},
  a drizzling rain, M.Eng. {smóre}, dense smoke, Eng. @Eng{smother}
  (= {smorther}), O.Du. {smoor}.  O'R. has {smur} from Sh., and K.Meyer
  translates M.Ir. @MIr{smur-chimilt} as "grind to dust".
<smùsach>, extracting the juice from (Suth.):
<smut>, a bill, snout, Ir. @Ir{smut}, a large flat nose, snout:
<snag>, a little audible knock, a wood pecker (@Ref<snagan-daraich>), Ir.
  {snag}, hiccup; cf. Eng. @Eng{snock}, a knock, and @Ref{snagaireachd}.  Ir.
  {snag}, {snagardarach}, {snaghairdara}, a wood pecker, seems from
  @Ref{snaidh}.

<snagaireachd>, cutting or hacking wood with a knife; from Dial.Eng.
  {snagger}, a tool for {snagging} or cutting off {snags}, that is
  branches, knots, etc., Sc. {snagger-snee}, a large knife, snicker-snee,
  {sneg}, @Ref{snag}, cut off branches.
<snagarra>, active; from the above roots; cf. {snasmhor}.
<snaidh>, hew, chip, shape, Ir. @Ir{snoighim}, {snaidhim} (O'D.), E.Ir.
  {snaidim}, {snaisi}, peeled, W. @W{naddu}, hew, chip, cut. O.Corn.
  {nedim}, ascia (W. {neddyf}, {neddai}, adze, Br. @Br{eze}, {neze}), M.Br.
  {ezeff}: *{snadô}; Ger. {schnat}, border, {schnate}, a young twig,
  Swiss {schnätzen}, cut, Swab. {schnatte}, an incision in wood or
  flesh (Bez. apud Stokes).  Strachan suggests the root {sknad},
  Gr. @Gr{κναδάλλω}, scratch, @Gr{κνωδώνν}, tooth (see @Ref{cnàmh}).  Hence
  @Ref<snas>, regularity.
<snàig>, creep; from Sc. {snaik}, sneak in walking, etc., {snaikin},
  sneaking, Eng. @Eng{sneak}, {snake}.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{snaighim}, I creep.
<snaim>, a knot, Ir. @Ir{snaidhm}, E.Ir. @EIr{snaidm}, d. {snaidmaimm}, {naidm},
  bond, nexus: *{nadesmen}, root {ned}, bind, I.E. {nedh}; Skr.
  {nah}, tie, {naddha-s}, tied; Ger. {nestel}, lace, O.H.G. {nestila}, a
  band; Lat. {nôdus}, for {noz-dos}, a knot.  See @Ref{nasg}.
<snàmh>, swim, Ir. @Ir{snámhaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{snám} (inf.), {ro snó}, swam, W.
  {nawf}, natatio, {nofio} (vb.), M.Br. @MBr{neuff}, Br. @Br{neunv}: *{snâmu},
  (n.), {snâô}, I swim; Lat. {no}, {nâre}; Gr. @Gr{νάω}, flow; Skr. {snâti},
  bathe, float.
<snaodh>, head, chief; {ceann-snaodh}, head chief (Carm.):
<snaois>, a slice, piece; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{snaisse}, cut, caesus, from @Ref{snaidh}.
<snaoisean>, snuff, Ir. @Ir{snaoisín}, {snísín}; from Eng. @Eng{sneezing} in {sneesing powder},
  the old name for snuff, Sc. {sneeshin}, {sneezin}.
<snaomanach>, a strong, robust fellow, Ir. @Ir{snaománach}, stout, jolly
  fellow, hearty: "knotty", from *{snadm-} of @Ref{snaim}?
<snaoidh>, a bier, Ir. @Ir{snaoi}:
<snap>, the trigger of a gun; from the English {snap}.
<snas>, regularity, elegance, Ir. @Ir{snas}: "goot cut", from {snad} of
  @Ref{snaidh}; E.Ir. @EIr{snass}, a cut.
<snàth>, thread, Ir. @Ir{snáth}, O.Ir. @OIr{snáthe}, W. @W{ysnoden}, lace, fillet,
  {noden}, thread, Corn. @Corn{noden}, @Corn{snod}, vitta, Br. @Br{neudenn}: *{snâtio-},

<sneachd>, snow, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{snechta}, pl. {snechti}, nives, W. @W{nyf}:

  Eng. @Eng{snow}, Ger. {schnee}; Lat. {nix}, {nivis}; Gr. @Gr{νíφα} (acc.),

<snicean>, a stitch of clothing (Arg.):

<snìomh>, spin, wind, twist, Ir. @Ir{sníomhaim}, M.Ir. @MIr{snímaire}, a spindle.
  {sním}, spinning: *{snêmu-}, root, {snê}, {nê}; Gr. @Gr{νῆμα}, yarn.  See
  @Ref{snàth} further.  W. has {nyddu}, nere, Corn. @Corn{nethe}, Br. @Br{nezaff}.
  In the sense of "sadness", there is E.Ir. @EIr{sním}, distress, Br.
  {niff}, chagrin.

<snot>, smell, snuff the wind, turn up the nose in smelling; founded

<snuadh>, hue, appearance, beauty, Ir. @Ir{snuadh}, M.Ir. @MIr{snúad}; root
  {snu}, flow, as in E.Ir. @EIr{snuad}, hair, head of hair, Ir. @Ir{snuadh},

<so>, here, this, Ir. @Ir{so}, E.Ir., P.Ir. {seo}, {so}: *{sjo-} (beside *{so}, as in

<sobhrach>, @Ref<sòbhrach>, (M`L.), primrose, Ir. @Ir{sobhróg} (Fol.), {somharcin}

<soc>, forepart of anything, ploughshare, snout, Ir. @Ir{soc}, E.Ir. @EIr{socc},
  W. @W{swch} (f.), Corn. @Corn{soch}, Br. @Br{soc'h}, {souc'h} (m.): *{succo-}, snout,
  pig's snout, *{sukku-}, a pig, W. @W{hwch}, Corn. @Corn{hoch}, Br. @Br{houc'h}
  (Ag.S. {sugu}, Eng. @Eng{sow}, Lat. {sûs}, etc.).  So Thurneysen ({Rom.}, 112),
  who clinches his argument by E.Ir. @EIr{corr} being both
  "crane" and "beak".  Fr. {soc}, ploughshare, Eng. @Eng{sock} are
  from Celtic.  Stokes suggests the possibility of Celtic being
--page 334
  from Med.Lat. {soccus}, vomer, or allied to O.H.G. {seh}, vomer,
  Lat. {secare}.
<socair>, ease, easy, Ir. @Ir{socair}, easy, secure, M.Ir. @MIr{soccair}; opposite
  is @Ref<deacair>, O.Ir. @OIr{seccair}: *{di-acair}, *{so-acair}, from *{acar},
  convenience, root {cor}, place, as in @Ref{cuir}.  Hence @Ref{acarach}.
<sochair>, a benefit, emolument, Ir. @Ir{sochar}, emolument, wealth,
  ease, M.Ir. @MIr{sochor}, good contract ({Sench. Mór}); from @Ref{so-} and
  @Ref{cor}, q.v.
<sochar>, silliness, a yielding disposition, @Ref<socharach>, simple, compliant,
  Ir. @Ir{socharach}, obliging, easy, W. @W{hygar}, amiable, Br. @Br{hegar}, benignus;
  from @Ref{so-} and @Ref{càr}, dear.  The Ir. is also
  from {sochar}, ease.
<sochd>, silence, Ir. @Ir{sochd} (O'R., Sh.), M.Ir. @MIr{socht}: *{sop-tu-}, root {svop}
  of @Ref{suain} (Dr Cameron).
<sod.1>, noise of boiling water, steam of water in which meat is
  boiled, boiled meat, Ir. @Ir{sod}, boiled meat (O'B.); from Norse
  {soð}, broth or water in which meat has been boiled, Eng.
  {sodden}, {seethe}, {sod}, Sc. {sotter}, boil slowly, {sottle}, noise of
  boiling porridge, etc.
<sod.2>, an awkward person, a stout person; from Sc. {sod}, a heavy
  person, {sodick}, {soudie}, a clumsy heavy woman.
<sodag>, a pillion, clout; from Sc. {sodds}, a saddle made of cloth.
<sodal>, pride, flattery, Ir. @Ir{sodal}, {sotal}, {sutal}, O.Ir. @OIr{sotla}, pride,
  insolence, {sotli}, animositates; this has been adduced as the
  source of Eng. @Eng{sot}, Fr. {sot}.  According to Stokes *{sput-tlo-},
  W. @W{ffothyll}, pustula, Lat. {pustula}, Skr. {phutkar}, puff (Stokes).
<sodan>, caressing, joy, joyous reception:
<sodar>, trotting, a trotting horse (Sh., Lh., etc.), Ir. @Ir{sodar}, trotting:
<sog>, @Ref<sogan>, mirth, good humour, tipsiness; from *{sugg}, a short
  form of the root of @Ref{sùgradh}.
<sògh>, luxury, riot, Ir. @Ir{sógh}, M.Ir. @MIr{sodh}, E.Ir. @EIr{suaig}, prosperous:
  *{su-ag-}, root {ag} of @Ref{aghaidh}, @Ref{àgh}.
<soidealta>, bashful, ignorant; see @Ref{saidealta}.
<soidean>, a jolly-looking or stout person; see @Ref{sod.2}.
<soighne>, @Ref<soighneas>, pleasure, delight, Ir. @Ir{sóighneas}: {so-gne-},
  root {gen}.
<soileas>, officiousness, flattery, Ir. @Ir{soilíos}; from Lat. {sollicitus}?
<soilgheas>, wind, a fair wind:
<soilleir>, clear, visible, Ir. @Ir{soilléir}: from @Ref{so-} and @Ref{léir.1}.  The {ll} is
  due to the analogy of @Ref{soillse}.
<soillse>, brightness, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{soillse}, {soilse}: *{svelnestio-}; see
  @Ref{solus} for connections.
<soimeach>, prosperous, easy, easy circumstanced, good-natured,
  seems to combine O.Ir. @OIr{somme}, dives, and O.Ir. @OIr{soinmech},
--page 335
  lucky, good, Ir. @Ir{soinmheach}, fortunate, happy.  The former
  Stokes derives from {so-imbi-s}, for which see @Ref{iomadh}; the
  latter is {so-nem-ech}, root {nem}, under @Ref{nèamh}.  M.Ir.
  {somenmnach}, good-spirited, is from @Ref{meanmna}.
<soin>, esteem (n.), @Ref<soineil>, handsome; cf. @Ref{sònraich} for the root.
<soinionn>, @Ref<soineann>, fair weather, Ir. @Ir{soinean}, M.Ir. @MIr{soinend}, E.Ir.
  {sonend}; the opposite of {soinionn} is @Ref{doinionn}, for {su-sîn-enn},
  {du-sîn-enn}, from {sín}, now @Ref{sian.4}, weather, rain (Stokes).
<soir.1>, the east, Ir. @Ir{soir}, E.Ir. @EIr{sair}; from {s-} (see @Ref{suas}) and @Ref{air}
  (= *{are}), on, q.v.
<soir.2>, sack, vessel, bottle; cf. @Ref{searrag}.
<soirbh>, easy, gentle, @Ref<soirbheas>, success, wind, flatulence (Arg.),
  Ir. @Ir{soirbh}, O.Ir. @OIr{soirb}, facilis, opposed to {doirb}, difficilis, root
  {reb}, or @Ref{rib}, manare (Ascoli).  But compare Gaelic @Ref{reabh}.
<sois>, snug, fond of ease (M`A.); from Sc. {sosh}, snug, social.
<sòise>, a ball of fire in the sky, a portent (M`A.):
<soisgeul>, gospel, Ir. @Ir{soisgéal}, {soisgeul}, O.Ir. @OIr{soscéle}; from @Ref{so-} and
  @Ref{sgeul}.
<soisinn>, taste, decency, rest, stillness; from Sc. {sonsy}?
<soitheach>, a vessel, Ir. @Ir{soitheach}, M.Ir. @MIr{soithech}, {saithech}: *{satiko-}:
<soitheamh>, tame, docile, gentle: *{so-seimh}, from @Ref{sèimh}?  So
  Munro, who writes {soisheamh}.
<sol>, ere, before, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sul}; root {svel} of @Ref{seal}.
<sòlach>, highly delighted (M`A.; @Ref<sollach>, jolly, Arms.); founded
  on @Ref{sòlas}.  Arm.'s word seems from Eng. @Eng{jolly}.
<solar>, a provision, purveying, preparing, Ir. @Ir{soláthar}; from @Ref{so-}
  and @Ref{làthair}.
<sòlas>, joy, comfort, solace, Ir. @Ir{sólas}; from Lat. {sôlatium}, Eng. @Eng{solace}.
<sollain>, a welcome, rejoicing, Ir. @Ir{sollamhuin}, a solemnity, feast,
  rejoicing, E.Ir. @EIr{sollamain}; from Lat. {sollemne}, Eng. @Eng{solemnity}.
<solus>, light, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{solus}, E.Ir. @EIr{solus}, bright: *{svḷnestu-}, root
  {svel}; Ag.S. {svelan}, glow, Eng. @Eng{sultry}; Gr. @Gr{σέλας}, light,
  @Gr{σελήνη}, moon, @Gr{ἑλάνη}, torch; Skr. {svar}, sheen, sun.
<somalta>, bulky, large, placid; from M.Ir. @MIr{soma}, abundance, with
  adj. terminations {-ail} and @Ref{ta}.  See @Ref{soimeach} further.
<somh>, convert, upset (Carm.); cf. Ir. @Ir{sóm}.
<son>, sake, cause, @Ref<air son>, on account of, Ir. @Ir{son}, {ar son}, M.Ir. @MIr{son},
  {er son}; from E.Ir. @EIr{son}, word (root {sven} of @Ref{seinn})?
<sona>, happy, ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sona}, opposite of @Ref{dona}: *{so-gná-vo-s}, "well-doing";
  root {gna} of @Ref{gnìomh}.
<sonn.1>, a stout man, hero; from @Ref{sonn.2}, club, staff, M.Ir. @MIr{suinn catha},
  captains, "staves of battle".  Cf. N. {stafn-buar}, the {stem}
  men, or picked marines on the forecastle.  Cf. {Tàillear dubh
  na tuaighe} was "ursainn chatha nan Camshronach".  See @Ref{sonn.2}.
--page 336
<sonn.2>, a staff, cudgel, beam, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sonn}, W. @W{ffon}, O.W. @OW{fonn}:
  *{spondo-}, Gr. @Gr{σφενδόνη}, a sling, @Gr{σφεδανός}, vehement; Skr.
  {spand}, draw, move; Lat. {pendo}, hang (Rhys).  Stokes gives
  the stem *{spundo}, allied to Norse {spjót}, a lance, O.H.G.
  {spioz}, spit, spear.  Cf. M.Lat. {spnda}, trabecula, repagulum.
<sònraich>, appoint, ordain, Ir. @Ir{sonraighim}, {sonrach}, special, E.Ir.
  {sunnraid}, O.Ir. @OIr{sainriud}, especially, {sainred}, proprietas, {sain},
  singularis, proprius, O.W. @OW{han}, alium: *{sani-}, especially;
  Got. {sundrô}, privately, Eng. @Eng{sunder}; Lat. @Ref{sine}, without; Skr.
  {sanutár}, without.
<sop>, a wisp, Ir. @Ir{sop}, E.Ir. @EIr{sopp}, W. @W{sob}, {sopen}; from Eng. @Eng{sop},
  Norse {soppa}.  Zimmer takes the Ir. from Norse {svöppr},
  sponge, ball; Stokes derives it from Norse {sópr}, besom.  the
  W. @W{sob}, {sopen} favours and Eng. @Eng{source}.
<sòr>, hesitate, grudge, shun:
<soraidh>, a farewell, blessing, Ir. @Ir{soraidh}, happy, successful, M.Ir.
  {soraid}, E.Ir. @EIr{soreid}; from @Ref{so-} and @Ref{réidh}.
†<sorcha>, light, bright, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sorcha}; opposite of @Ref{dorch}, q.v
<sorchan>, rest or support, foot-stool, light stand, peer-man; from @Ref{sorcha}.
<sòrn>, a flue, vent, Ir. @Ir{sórn}, E.Ir. @EIr{sornn}, W. @W{ffwrn}, Corn. @Corn{forn}; from
  Lat. {furnus}, oven, whence Eng. @Eng{furnace}.
<sos>, a coarse mess or mixture; from Sc. {soss}.
<spad>, kill, fell, Ir. @Ir{spaidim}, benumb, @Ref{spaid}, {spad}, a clod (cf. @Ref{spairt}),
  a sluggard, eunuch; cf. W. @W{ysbaddu}, exhaust, geld, from Lat.
  {spado}, eunuch.  Hence @Ref<spadanta>, benumbed.
<spad->, flat, Ir. @Ir{spad-}; from *{spad} of @Ref{spaid}, spade?
<spadag>, a quarter or limb of an animal cut off; from L.Lat.
  {spatula}, a shoulder blade, {spatula prcina}, leg of pork, also
  {spadula}, a shoulder, {spadlaris}, a quarter of a beast.  Cf. W.
  {yspaud}, shoulder.
<spadair>, fop, braggart; cf. Norse {spjátra}, behave as a fop.  See
  @Ref{spaideil}.
<spadal>, a paddle, plough-staff, so Ir.; from M.Eng. {spaddle},
  paddle, dim. of {spade}.
<spadhadh>, a strong and quick pull, the utmost extent of the outstretched
  arms, the grass cut by one scythe-stroke, {spadh}, a
  scyth's stroke (Bad.); from Lat. {spatium}.  Meyer objects.
  If Stokes' theory were right {spadh} could be from root {spa},
  pull, span.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{swath}.
<spàg>, a claw or paw, limb of an animal, club-foot, @Ref<spàgach>, club-footed
  or awkward in the legs, Ir. @Ir{spág}, claw, club-foot,
  clumsy leg, W. @W{ysbach}, a claw; {spàga-da-ghlid}, a buffoon,
  tomfool (Wh.):
--page 337
<spagach>, uttering words indistinctly, @Ref<spagadh>, obliquity of the
  mouth, @Ref<spaig>, a wry mouth:
<spagluinn>, ostentation, conceit:
<spaid>, a spade, Ir. @Ir{spád}; from the Eng.
<spaideil>, foppish, well-dressed: "strutting", from Lat. {spatior}, as
  in @Ref{spaisdear} below?  Cf., however, @Ref{spadair}.
<spailp>, pride, conceit, @Ref<spailpean>, fop, Ir. @Ir{spailp}, {spailpín}, rascal,
  mean fellow, "spalpeen":
<spàin>, a spoon, Manx {spain}; from Norse {spánn}, {spónn}, spoon,
  chip, M.Eng. {spōn}, Ag.S. {spón}, chip.  Ir. @Ir{spúnóg}, spoon, is
  from the Eng.
<spàirn>, an effort, struggle, Ir. @Ir{spáirn}, {sbáirn}, wrestling, struggling;
  from the Norse {sporna}, kick with the feet, struggle, {sperna},
  kick, spurn, Eng. @Eng{spurn}.  Hennessey derived it from Eng.
  {sparring} ({Athenœum}, 15/8/71).
<spairiseach>, foppish, @Ref<spairis>, having the hands in the trousers'
  pockets (M`A.); founded on Sc. {spare}, opening of the fore
  part of the breeches.
<spairt>, a turf, clod, a splash, Ir. @Ir{spairt}; verb <spairt>, daub, plaster,
  splash, brain, Ir. @Ir{spairtim}: cf. N. {sparða}, pole-axe, whence
  M.Eng. {spert} or {spart}.
<spaisdear>, @Ref<spaidsear>, a saunterer, @Ref<spaisdeireachd>, sauntering, Ir.
  {spaisdeóireachd}, promenading, walking; Norse {spázera}, walk,
  Dan. {spadsere}, Ger. {spazieren}, from Ital. (13th Cent.), {spaziare}:
  all from Lat. {spatior}, walk, promenade.
<spàl>, a shuttle, Ir. @Ir{spól}; from Norse {spóla}, a weaver's shuttle, M.Eng.
  {spōle}, now {spool}, Ger. {spule}, bobbin, spool.  Hence
  {spàlag}, pea pod.
<spang>, thin plate of metal, spangle; from Norse {spo@'ng}, g. {spangar},
  a spangle, M.Eng. {spang}, now {spangle}, Ag.S. {spange}, a clasp,
  Ger. {spange}, buckle.
<spann.1>, sever, divide, wean (a child); from Sc. {spain}, {spane}, wean,
  prevent, confused with M.Eng. {spannen}, stretch, span.
<spann.2>, a hinge, hasp; from the Eng. @Eng{spang}, a spangle, Ag.S.
  @Ref{spang}, a hasp; or Ag.S. {spannan}, to clasp, Norse {spenna},
  {spennir}, grasper, Sc. {spenn}, to button.
<spaoill>, @Ref<speill>, wrap, swathe: *{svil}, *{sveil}, as in @Ref{till}, etc.
<spàrdan>, a roost, from @Ref{spàrr}.
<spàrr>, a joist, beam, roost, Ir. @Ir{sparra}, wedge, spear, E.Ir. @EIr{sparr},
  a beam, joist; from Norse {sparri}, a spar, Sw., Dan. {sparre},
  O.H.G. {sparro}, bar, balk, Ger. {sperren}, a spar, Eng. @Eng{spar}.
  Hence G. <spàrr>, drive as a nail or sedge, thrust, Ir. @Ir{sparraim};
  G. @Ref<sparrag>, a bridgle bit, "little bar".
<spathalt>, a limb, a clumsy libm; cf. @Ref{spoll}.
--page 338
<sparsan>, the dew-lap of a beast, Ir. @Ir{sparsan} (Lh., O'B); see
  @Ref{spursan}.
<speach.1>, a wasp, @Ref<connspeach>, for @Ref<conas-beach>, "wrangling or dog
  bee", from @Ref{beach}, bee?  The Ir. for "wasp" is {eircbheach}.
  @Ref{connspeach} is referred by Stokes (Dict. 302) to *{spekâ}, Gr.
  @Gr{σφήξ}; for phonetics cf. @Ref{padhadh}, @Ref{piuthar}, also @Ref{speir} and
  @Ref{speal}.
<speach.2>, a blow, thrust, stitch in the side, Ir. @Ir{speach}, a kick:
<speach.3>, door step (Carm.).
<spead>, a very small foot or leg (M`A.), @Ref<speadach>, sheepshanked
  (M`A.), kicking (Badenoch, where <spead> means a cow's or
  sheep's kick); cf. M.Ir. @MIr{spedudhud}, a musical instrument (?),
  Kuno Meyer's "King and Hermit".  Root {sped-do-}, {spend-}.
<speal>, a scythe, Ir. @Ir{speal}, scythe, reaping hook, M.Ir. @MIr{spel}:
  *{spelâ}, Gr. @Gr{ψαλíς}, shears, root {spal}, clip, pull, further Eng.
  {psalm} (so Stokes).
<spealg>, a splinter; from Sc. {spelk}, a splint attached to a fracture,
  M.E. {spelke}, a splinter, Norse {spjalk}, {spelkur}, splint, Du.
  {spalk}.
<spealt>, a splinter; from Teutonic - M.Eng. {spélde}, now a {spill},
  M.H.G. {spelte}, a splinter, Ger. {spalten}.
<spearrach>, a cow-fetter, a fetter for wild goats; see @Ref{speireach}.
<spéic>, a spike, Ir. @Ir{spéice}; from Norse {spík}, a spike, Eng. @Eng{spike},
  Ger. {speiche}.  W. has {ysbig}.
<speil>, cattle, herd, Ir. @Ir{speil}, herd of cattle or swine; *{speli-}, allied
  to Lat. {spolium} (Stokes).
<spéil>, slide, skate; from Sc. @Ref{speil}, play, {bonspel}, curling game,
  Ger. {spielen}, play.
<speir>, hoof or ham of cattle, claw talon, ankle and thereabouts of
  the human leg, Ir. @Ir{speirr}, hough, ham: *{s-peri-}; compare W.
  {ffer}, ankle, {ber}, leg, shank: Corn. @Corn{fer}, crus, E.Ir. @EIr{seir}, heel,
  {di pherid}: *{speret-}, Gr. @Gr{σφυρόν}, ankle, heel; root {sper}, Eng.
  {spur}, {spurn}, Lat. {sperno}, etc.
<speireach>, @Ref<spearrach>, cow-fetter, foot fetter; from @Ref{speir} and
  *{rich}, tie, for which last see @Ref{buarach}.
<spéiread>, strength, force, courage; founded on Lat. {spîritus}.
<speireag>, sparrow-hawk; from M.Eng. {sper-hauk}, Ag.S. {spear-hafoc},
  Norse {sparrhaukr}, from {sparrow} and {hawk}.
<spéis>, esteem, liking, Ir. @Ir{spéis}, M.Ir. @MIr{sbéis}; seemingly from M.Ir.
  {sbesailte}, special, from Lat. {species}, look (cf. Eng. @Eng{re-spect}).
<speuc>, @Ref<spiac>, diverge, divaricate, tear asunder, branch; from Sc.
  {spaik}, a spoke (in a wheel), Eng. @Eng{spoke}, Ag.S. {spáca}.
<speuclair>, spectacles, Ir. @Ir{speucláir}, a glass, spectacles; from the
  Latin.
--page 339
<speur>, the heaven, firmament, Ir. @Ir{speur}, {spéir}; from the L.Lat.
  {spera}, a hemisphere, circle (of each planet), celestial region,
  Lat. {sphaera}, a sphere (whence the Eng.), from Gr. @Gr{σφαῖπρα},
  globe.  Cf. Sc. {spere}, sphere, circle, "the @Ref{speir} of the moon".
<spìd.1>, spite, Ir. @Ir{spíd}; from the Eng.  Hence @Ref<spìdeig> or @Ref<spideag.3>,
  a taunt.
<spìd.2>, speed, haste; from Eng. @Eng{speed}.
<spideag.1>, nightingale (@Ref<spìdeag>, M.F.), Ir. @Ir{spideóg}, robin:
<spideag.2>, a delicate or slender creature (Arms. @Ref<spìdeag>); from Sc.
  {spit}, a little, hot-tempered person, {spitten}, a puny, mischievous

<spiorad>, a spirit, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{spiurt}, {spirut}; from Lat. {spiritus},

<spiris>, a hen-roost, hammock; from Norse {sperra}, a spar, rafter,

<spisniche>, pillar, support (Carm.):
<spitheag>, a chip, spelk, small bit of wood, bite, Ir. @Ir{spiothóg}, a
  finger stone for throwing at an object (Con., Sh.), {spitheóg}, a
  flake of snow; a borrowed word belonging to the Eng. group
  {spike}, {spigot}, but likely taken from Norse {spík}, sprig, spike.
<splang>, a sparkle, flash, Ir. @Ir{splanc}:
<splangaid>, a snot, mucus, Ir. @Ir{spleangaid} (O'R.); a side-form of
  @Ref{sglongaid}?

<spleadh.1>, a splay foot; from Eng. @Eng{splay}.

<spleadhan>, a sort of wooden paddle to dig up sand eels; see

<spleuchd>, @Ref<spliachd>, stare, squint, spread out by trampling:

<spolladach>, sottish:
<spòlt>, mangle, slaughter, hew down in battle, also (Dial. Badenoch)
  splutter; from the English.  Cf. M.Eng. {splatten}, cut open,
  Sc. {sploit}, squirt, spout.  {spoltadh}, drops flying out of a vessel
  when boiling or stirred carelessly.
<spong>, sponge, tinder, Ir. @Ir{sponc}, E.Ir. @EIr{sponge}, W. @W{ysbwng}, sponge,
  Corn. @Corn{spong}, Br. @Br{spone}, {sponeñk}; from Lat. {spongia}, sponge,
  from Gr. @Gr{σπογγιά}, allied to Lat. {fungus}.
<spor.1>, a spur, claw, talon, Ir. @Ir{spor}, M.Ir. @MIr{sbor}, a spur for a horse;
  from Norse {spori}, a spur, {spor}, foot trace, Dan. {spore}, Sw.
  {sporre}, Eng. @Eng{spur}, Ag.S. {spora}; root {sper} of @Ref{speir}, etc.
  Hence @Ref<sporadh>, inciting, scraping the earth (as a hen), Sc.
  {spur}.
<spor.2>, tinder, flint, gun-flint; from Eng. @Eng{spar}.
<sporan>, a purse, Ir. @Ir{sparán}, {sporán}, {sbarrán}, M.Ir. @MIr{sboran}, W.
  {ysbur}: *{s-burr-} from *{burs}, from L.Lat. {bursa}, a purse,
  whence Eng. @Eng{purse}, bursary; originally from Gr. @Gr{βυρση}, a
  hide.
<sporracan>, crumbs (M`F.):
<spors>, sport, Ir. @Ir{spórt} (Fol.); from the Eng.
<spot>, a spot; from the Eng.

<spoth>, geld, castrate, Ir. @Ir{spothaim}, M.Ir. @MIr{spochad} (n.), W. @W{dysbaddu},
  Br. @Br{spaza}; from Lat. {spado}, eunuch, whence Eng. @Eng{spay}.  The
  M.Ir. @MIr{spochad} is thought by Stokes to be from Br. @Br{spac'hein}
  (inf.).
<spracadh>, strength, sprightliness, Ir. @Ir{spracadh}; from Eng. @Eng{sprack},
  lively, Norse {spraekr}, lively, Sw. {spräker}; from Norse also
  comes Eng. @Eng{spark} - Norse {sparkr}.
<spraic>, a sever reprimand; see @Ref{spreig}.
<spraidh>, a loud blast, report of a gun; cf. Sc. {spraich}, a cry,
  Norse {spraki}, a report.
<spreadh>, burst, sound loudly while bursting, kill, Ir. @Ir{spréidhim},
  spread, burst ({spreighim}, O'B.), E.Ir. @EIr{sprédaire}, brush for
  sprinkling the holy water; from M.Eng. {spraeden}, now {spread}.
<spreangan>, a cloven stick for closing the wound of bled cattle;
  from Eng. @Eng{springe}, twig, rod, snare with flexible rod.
<spréidh>, cattle, Ir. @Ir{spré(idh)}, M.Ir. @MIr{spré}, {spreid}, W. @W{praidd}, flock,
  booty; from Lat. {praeda}, booty.  Hence Sc. {spreith}, booty.
<spreig>, blame, reprove, incite, Ir. @Ir{spreagaim}; founded on M.Eng.
  {spraechen}, now {speak}, Ger. {sprechen}.
<spreigh>, scatter, burst; see @Ref{spreadh}.
<spreill>, blubber lip: *{s-breill}, from @Ref{breall}?
<spreisneach>, the remains of a wreck:
<spreòchan>, weakness, weak person; from *{s-breòch-}, being the same
  in root as @Ref{breòclaid}?
<spreòd>, @Ref<spreod> (H.S.D.), a projecting beam, @Ref<crann spreòid>, a bow-sprit;
  from M.Eng. {sprēot}, a sprit, now {sprit}; Ag.S. {spréot},
  M.Du. {spriet}.  Hence <spreòd>, incite.
<sprochd>, dejection, sadness, Ir. @Ir{sprochd}: *{s-broc}, M.Ir. @MIr{broc},
  sorrow, anxiety (also {sbrog}).  Cf. @Ref{murcach} for root; or @Ref{bròn}?
<sprogan>, @Ref<sprogaill>, dewlap, bird's crop, Ir. @Ir{sprogaille}, {sbrogaill},
  also {sgroban}, {sgrogul}, neck: *{s-broggo-}.  See @Ref{bràghad}.
<spronnan>, a crumb; from @Ref{pronn.3}.
<sprot>, single stick (Lewis): N. {sproti}, stick.
<spruan>, brushwood, firewood, Ir. @Ir{spruán}: *{s-bruan}, from @Ref{bruan.2}.
  M`A. has {sprudhan}, fragments.
<sprùdan>, fingers, sprouts; from the Eng. @Eng{sprout}.
<spruileach>, @Ref<spruidhleach>, crumbs, fragments, Ir. @Ir{spruille(ach)},

  @Ref{spruan}.  M.Ir. has also {spuirech}, fragmentum, W. @W{ysbwrial},
  sweepings, {ysborion}, refuse of fodder.
<spruiseil>, spruce, neat, Ir. @Ir{sprúiseamhuil}; from the Eng. @Eng{spruce}.
<spruithean>, claw (as of eagle):
<spuaic>, crown of the head, a pinnacle, callosity, blister, Ir. @Ir{spuaic},

<spùidsear>, baling ladle (N.H.): cf. Eng. @Eng{spudge}.
<spùill>, spoil, plunder; from Sc. {spulye}, lay waste, plunder, Eng.
  {spoil}, Fr. {spolier}, Lat. {spoliare}.  W. has {ysbail}, a spoil.
<spùinn>, spoil, plunder, Ir. @Ir{spúinim}; another form of @Ref{spùill},
  borrowed directly from Lat. {spoliare}?
<spuirse>, spurge, milkweed, Ir. @Ir{spuirse}; from the Eng. @Eng{spurge},
  M.Eng. {sporge}.
<spùll>, nail of a cat, a clutch, @Ref<spùllach>, nailed, greedy (M`A.):
<spursan>, a gizzard, Ir. @Ir{spursán}; cf. @Ref{sparsan}, dewlap.
<spùt>, a spout; from the Sc. {spoot}, Eng. @Eng{spout}.
<sràbh.1>, a straw; from the Eng.:
<sràbh.2>, falling water (Carm.):
<srabhard>, strife (Suth. R.D.):
<srac>, tear, rend, rob, Ir. @Ir{sracaim}; G. has also @Ref<racadh>: *{srakko-},
  for {rap-ko-}, root {rap} of Lat. {rapio}?

---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<srad>, a spark of fire, Ir. @Ir{srad}: *{sraddâ}, from {strad} or {stṛ-d}, root
  {ster}, as in Eng. @Eng{star}, Gr. @Gr{ἀστήρ}.  M.Ir. has {srab-tine}, lightning,
  from the same root.
<sràid>, a street, Ir. @Ir{sráid}, E.Ir. @EIr{sráit}; from Lat. {strâtā} ({via}),
  whence Eng. @Eng{street}.  K.Meyer derives it from Norse {straeti},
  which itself comes from Lat.
<sraidean>, the plant shepherd's purse, Ir. @Ir{sraidín} ({sráidín}, O'B.);
  cf @Ref{srad}.
<sraigh>, the cartilage of the nose, sneeze (M`A.); cf. root of @Ref{sròn}.
<sramh>, a jet of milk from the cow's udder, Ir. @Ir{sramh} ({srámh}, O'R.);
  root {ster}, {stṛ}, strew.
<srann>, a snore, buzz, Ir. @Ir{srann}, E.Ir. @EIr{srand}, O.Ir. @OIr{srennim}, sterto:
  *{stre-s-no-}, root {ster}, {pster} of Lat. {sterto}, snore, {sternno}, sneeze
  (see @Ref{sreothart} further).  Stokes makes the Gadelic to be
  *{strenvô}, like Lat. {sternuo}.
<sraon>, stumble, make a false step, rush forward violently; cf. Ir.
  {sraoinim}, defeat, overthrow, scatter, M.Ir. @MIr{sráined}, dragging
  down, defeat, E.Ir. @EIr{sroenim}, hurl, drag, defeat: *{sroino-},
  root {ster}, strew, scatter (Eng. {strew}, etc.).
<sraonais>, a huff, snuffiness; M`A. has @Ref<sròin>, a huff: from @Ref{sròn},
  nose?
<srath>, a valey, strath, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{srath}, meadow land or holm
  along banks of a river or loch, often swampy (Joyce), O.Ir.
  {israth}, in gramine, W. @W{ystrad}, strath, E.W. {strat}, {istrat},
  planities: *{stratu-}, root {ster}, spread, scatter; Lat. {strâtus},
  from {sterno}, I strew; Gr. @Gr{στρωτός}, spread, @Gr{στορέννυμι}, scatter;
  Eng. @Eng{strew}, {strand} (?).
<srathair>, a pack-saddle, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{srathar}, W. @W{ystrodyr}; from
  Med.Lat. {stratura}, from {stratum}, {sterno}, spread.
--page 343
<sream>, rheum (M`A.), a wrinkle, @Ref<sreamach>, blear-eyed, Ir. @Ir{srám},
  eye rheum, {srámach}, blear-eyed, {sremach} (F.M.).  Stokes
  derives this from Ag.S. {streám}, Eng. @Eng{stream}.
<sreamadh>, curbing or checking by the nose:
<sreang>, a string, Ir. @Ir{srang}, {srang}, E.Ir. @EIr{sreng}: *{srengo-}, {strengo-},
  Gadelic root {streg}; immediately allied either to Eng. @Eng{string},
  Norse {strengr}, Ger. {strang} (I.E. {streℊh}, Gr. @Gr{στρέφω}, turn), or
  to Lat. {stringo}, bind, Ger. {strick}, string (I.E. {streℊ}).
  The I.E. roots {streℊ} and {streℊh} are allied ultimately.  {sraing},
  lie, embroidery (Hend.).
<sreath>, a row, series, Ir. @Ir{sreath}, O.Ir. @OIr{sreth}: *{srito-}, *{sṛ-to-}, root
  {ser}, order, join; Lat. {series}, row, {sors}, lot.
<sreathan>, filmy skin covering unborn calf (H.S.D., etc.).  When
  dried, it was used for covering vessels:
<sreothart>, a sneeze, Ir. @Ir{sraoth}, {sraothfurtach}, earlier {sreod}, W.
  {trew}, {ystrew}, a sneeze, {ystrewi} (vb.), Br. @Br{strefia}, {strevia} (vb.),
  root {streu}, {pstreu} (Stokes), further {ster}, {pster}, Lat. {sternuo},
  sneeze, Gr. @Gr{πτάρνυμαι} (do.)
<srian>, a bridle, Ir. @Ir{srian}, E.Ir. @EIr{srían}, W. @W{ffrwyn}; from Lat.
  {frênum} (through W.).
<srideag>, a drop, spark, @Ref<srideach>, white streaked with dark:
  *{sriddi}, root {sṛd} of @Ref{srad}.
<sringlean>, the strangles; founded on the English.
<sruit>, a torrent of quick words; founded on @Ref{sruth}.
<srobadh>, a push (Sh.), small quantity of liquor (A.M`D.); see
  @Ref{sruab}.
<sroghall>, a whip, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{sraigell}, O.Ir. @OIr{srogill} (gen.), W.
  {ffrowyll}; from Lat. {flagellum}.
<sról>, a streamer, banner, silk, Ir. @Ir{sról}, satin, byssus; from Lat.
  {stragulus}, coverlet, pall, whence Corn. @Corn{strail}, tapestry, W.
  {ystraill}, a mat.  Stokes ({Lismore}) has suggested a form
  *{fról}, *{flór}, Fr. {velours}, velvet, Br. @Br{flour}, velveted.
<sròn>, a nose, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{srón}, W. @W{ffroen}, Br. @Br{froan}: *{srognâ};
  *{sroknâ} (Stokes, Gr. @Gr{ρέγχω}, snore, snort, @Gr{ρέγκω}), *{sprognâ}
  (Strachan), to which Lat. {spargo} has been compared.  W. has
  also {trwyn} (*{trugno-} or {trogni-}), Corn. @Corn{trein}.
<sruab>, drink up with noise of the lips, pull hastily out of the
  water: *{sroubbo-}, root {sreub}?  Cf. @Ref{srùb}, and Lit. {sriaubiu},
  sup, lap up, Ch.Sl. {srŭbati}, swallow, Lat. {sorbeo}, Eng.
  {absorb}.
<sruan>, shortbread cake having five corners (M`A. for Islay):
<srùb>, a spout; from the Sc. {stroup}, spout, M.Eng. {strūpe}, throat,
  Norse {strjúpi}, the spouting trunk when the head is cut off,
  Sw. {strupe}, throat.  Hence @Ref<srùban>, a cockle.
--page 344
<sruth>, a stream, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{sruth}, g. {srotha}, W. @W{ffrwd}, Corn. @Corn{frot},
  alveus, Br. @Br{froud}: *{srutu-}, root {sreu}, flow; Gr. @Gr{ῥύσις}, a
  flowing, @Gr{ῥεῦμα}, a stream, @Gr{ῥέω}, flow; Eng. @Eng{stream}, Norse
  {straumr}; Lit. {sravju}, flow.  Some have referred the Celtic
  words to the root {spreut}, {spreu}, to well, Ger. {sprudel}, a well,
  {sprühen}, emit sparks, drizzle, further Eng. @Eng{spurt}, {spout}.
<sruthladh>, rinsing, half-washing, Ir. @Ir{sruthlaighim}; from @Ref{sruth}.
<stà>, advantage, use; from the Eng. - founded on {stay}?
<stàbhach>, wide, asunder, straddling, Ir. @Ir{stabhaighim}, straddle:
<stabhaic>, a wry neck, a sullen attitude of the head (M`A.); see
  @Ref{stùichd}.  Pronounced in Arg. @Ref<staoi'c>, @Ref<staghaic>.
<stàbull>, a stable, Ir. @Ir{stabla}; from Lat. {stabulum}, through the
  English.
<stac>, a precipice, steep hill, M.Ir. @MIr{stacc}, a stack (F.M.), {stacc}, a
  pile, piece; from Norse {stakkr}, a stack (of hay), {stakka}, a
  stump, Sw. {stack}, a stack, Sc. (Shetland, etc.) {stack}, a
  columnar isolated rock, Eng. @Eng{stack}.
<stad>, a stop, Ir. @Ir{stad}, E.Ir. @EIr{stad} (Cormac); founded on Lat. {status},
  position, {stat}, stands (Hennessey, Stokes).  Cf. Norse {staða}, a
  standing, a position.  Ascoli compares O.Ir. @OIr{astaim}, sisto
  (= {ad-sad-to-}, root {sed} of @Ref{suidhe}).
<stadh> (better @Ref<stagh>), a stay, a certain rope in ship's rigging; from
  Norse {stag} (do.), Eng. @Eng{stay}, Dan., Ger. {stag}.
<stadhadh>, a lurch, sudden bend:
<staid>, state, condition, Ir. @Ir{stáid}, M.Ir. @MIr{stait}; from Lat. {statio} (K.Meyer).
  W. has {ystâd}, from Lat. {status}.  Ir. @Ir{stáid} may be
  from the Eng.  See @Ref{stàideil}.
<stàideil>, stately, Ir. @Ir{stáideamhuil}; from Eng. @Eng{state}, {stately}.
<staidhir>, a stair, Ir. @Ir{staighre}, M.Ir. @MIr{staigre}; from the Eng., and
  Ag.S. {stáeger}.  The G. is possibly from Eng. @Eng{stair}, just as
  @Ref{paidhir} and @Ref{faidhir} are from {pair} and @Ref{fair} (Dr Cameron).
<stail>, a bandage, strap:
<stailc>, stubbornness, stop, stump, Ir. @Ir{stailc}; cf. @Ref{tailce}; cf. N. {stilkr},
  stalk.
<stàilinn>, steel; from Norse {stál}, steel, {stálin} weapons (pl.), Ger.
  {stahl}, Eng. @Eng{steel}.
<staing.1>, a peg, small pointed rock; from Norse {stöng}, g. {stangar}, a
  pole, Sc. and Eng. @Eng{stang}.
<staing.2>, a well-built person or animal (M`A.), @Ref<staingean>, obstinate
  boorish person, Ir. @Ir{stainc}, incivility; from @Ref{staing.1}.
<staipeal.1>, a stopple, Ir. @Ir{stapal} (O'R.); from the Sc. {stappil}, Eng.
  {stopple}.
<staipeal.2>, @Ref<stapull>, a staple, bar; from Eng. @Eng{staple}.

<stair>, a path over a bog, stepping stones in a river.  Dr Cameron
  has suggested connection with Du. {steiger}, waterside stairs,
  Eng. @Eng{stair}.  For {s-tar}, from *{tar}, cross (see @Ref{thar})?
<stairirich>, a rattling, a rumbling noise; also @Ref<dairireach>, q.v.
  For {s-dairirich}.
<stàirn.1>, a particle, small quantity (Perth); from Sc. {starn}, particle,
  grain, star, from {star}.
<stàirn.2>, noise (as the tread of horses), a violent push: *{s-tairn};
  see @Ref{tàirneanach} for root.  Cf. Ir. @Ir{stathruim}, clatter, din.

<stalan>, a stallion, Ir. @Ir{stail}; from the English.

  gives <stalc> as meaning "dash one's foot against (Islay),
  thread a hook, thump, stare."  In the meaning of "stalk",
  the word is from the Eng.

<stràc>, a stroke, ship or boat plank; from Sc. {strake}, Eng. @Eng{stroke};
  from Sc. {straik}, strait-edge for measuring corn, comes G.
  <stràc> (do.).  Similarly G. <stràc>, mower's whetstone, is from
  {strake}; all are from the root of Eng. @Eng{stroke}, strike.

<stuaic> (M`A., Arm.), @Ref<stuaichd> (H.S.D.), a little hill, round
  promontory, Ir. @Ir{stuaic}: *{s-tuag-c}, from @Ref{stuadh} above.  M`A.
  has the meaning "wry-neck" and sullen countenance, extreme
  boorishness", which is usually represented by @Ref{stùic}.  Stokes
  gives the Celtic as *{stoukki-}, Br. @Br{stuchyaff}, to feather, Lit.
  {stúgti}, set on high, Eng. @Eng{steep}.
<stuaim>, modesty, Ir. @Ir{stuaim}, device, mien, modesty: *{s-tuamm-},
  *{tous-men}, root {tus}, {teus} of @Ref{tosd}, silence.
<stùc>, @Ref<stùchd>, a little hill jutting out from a greater, a horn, Ir.
  {stucán},a small conical hill, {stucach}, horned; from Teutonic
  - N. {stúka}, wing of a building; Sc., Eng. @Eng{stook}, M.Eng.
  {stouke}, a shock of corn (12 sheaves), {stooks}, small horns, Low Ger.
  {stūke} (properly a projection), a bundle, bunch.  But
  cf. @Ref{stuaic}.
--page 350
<stùic>, @Ref<stùichd>, a projecting crag, an angry or threatening aspect;
  from @Ref<stùc> above.
<stuidearra>, studious, steady, glum, Ir. @Ir{stuideurach}, {stuideur}, a
  study.
<stuig>, incite, spur on dogs; from Eng. @Eng{stick}.
<stuird>, huffiness, pride, Ir. @Ir{stuirteamhlachd} (Con.); from M.Eng.
  {sturte}, impetuosity, {sturten}, impetuous, quarrelsome, Sc. {sturt},
  vexation, anger, a side form of {start}.
<stùirt>, vertigo, a disease in sheep caused by water in the head,
  drunkenness; from Sc. {sturdy}, from O.F. {estourdi}, dizzy-headed,
  now {êtourdi}, giddy-headed; from Lat. {extorpidire}.
  From Fr. comes Eng. @Eng{sturdy}.
<stùr>, dust; from Sc. {stour}, M.Eng. {stour}, tumult.
<stùrr>, the rugged point of a rock or hill, @Ref<sturrach>, rugged:
  *{s-tùrr}, from {turr} = @Ref{tòrr}, q.v.?  Cf. N. {staurr}.
<stuth>, stuff, metal; founded on the Eng. @Eng{stuff}.
<stuthaig>, dress with starch, starch (vb. and n.); from Sc. {stiffing},
  starch, Eng. @Eng{stiff}.  Perthshire has @Ref<stifinn>.
<suabag>, a sweeping blow (Suth.  R.D.):
<suacan>, a pot (M`F.), earthen furnace (Arm.), a basket hung in
  the chimney containing wood to dry (Dial.), anything
  wrought together awkwardly, as clay (M`A.), Ir. @Ir{suachgan}
  (Lh.), an earthen pot; from @Ref{suath}?
<suaicean>, a bundle of straw or hay twisted together, a deformed
  person; see @Ref{sùgan}.
<suaicheantas>, ensign, escutcheon, Ir. @Ir{suaitheantas}, a streamer,
  standard, escutcheon, {su-aichintus}, ensigns, colours (K.Meyer),
  O.Ir. @OIr{suaichnid}, clear, demonstratio, for {su-aithne}, "easily
  known", from @Ref{aithne}, knowledge.
<suail>, small, inconsiderable (M`F.), Ir. @Ir{suaill}, E.Ir. @EIr{suail}, a trifle:
<suaimhneach>, genial, secure, Ir. @Ir{suaimhneach}, peaceful, gentle,
  peaceable: *{su-menmnach}?  See @Ref{meamna}.
<suain>, sleep, Ir. @Ir{suan}, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{súan}, W. @W{hun}, Br. @Br{hun}:
  *{supno-s}, developing into *{sofno-}, *{sovno}, *{souno-}; I.E. root
  {svop}, {svep}, sleep; Lat. {sopor}, sleep; Skr. {svápnas}.
<suaineadh>, twisting, rope-twisting anything, a line for twisting
  round anything, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{súanem}, g. {suaneman}, funis:
  *{sognemon-}, root {sug}, {soug}, Br. @Br{sug}, trace, W. @W{syg}, chain,
  trace; Romance {soga}, rope, Ital. {soga}, rope, leather band, Sp.
  {soga}, a linear measure, Port. {soga}, rush rope, Churwälsch
  {saga}.  Stokes finally refers {súanem} to a stem-root *{sogno-}
  beside {segno-} (whence E.Ir. @EIr{sén}, a net for catching birds, gin,
  root {segh}, hold, Eng. @Eng{sail}), Lit. {segù}, fasten, {saga}, sledge.
--page 351
  This divorces {suaineadh} from G. @Ref{suaicean} and @Ref{sùgan}, q.v.
  Cf. W. @W{hwynyn}, {hoenyn}, a hair from a horse's tail, gin.
<suaip.1>, a faint resemblance; from Sc. {swaup}, {swap}, cast or lineaments
  of the countenance, Norse {svipr}, likeness, look, a swoop
  or flash.
<suaip.2>, exchange, swop; from the Sc. {swap}, Eng. @Eng{swop}.
<suairc>, civil, meek, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{suarc(c)}; opposed to @Ref{duairc}:
  *{su-arci-}:
<suaiteachan>, wagging (tails) (Suth.); from @Ref{suath}?
<suanach>, a hide, skin, fleece, coarse garment, "plough rein"
  (Suth.); cf. Ir. @Ir{sunach}, a kind of plaid:
<suarach>, insignificant, careless, Ir. @Ir{suarach}: *{svogro-}, root {sveg},
  {sug}, Ger. {schwach}, weak, {siech}, sick, Eng. @Eng{sick}.  Cf. Eng.
  {sour}, Ger. {sauer}, *{sûra}.
<suas>, up, upwards, Ir. @Ir{suas}, O.Ir. @OIr{súas}: *{s-uas}, from {uas}, as in
  @Ref{uasal}, and the prefix {s-}, allied to the final {s} of Lat. {abs}, {ex},
  Gr. @Gr{ἒξ}, @Gr{πρός}, etc., and the initial {s} of Lat. {sub}, {super}; possibly
  for *{ens}, Gr. @Gr{εἰς}, from {en}, and meaning "into", "to" (Rhys'
  @ExtRef{M. Pray.;2;156}).
<suath>, rub, mix, knead, Ir. @Ir{suathaim}, knead, mix, M.Ir. @MIr{súathaim}
  (do.), E.Ir. @EIr{suata}, polished down, root {sout}, {sut}, mix; cf.
  Eng. @Eng{seethe}, Norse {sjóða}, cook, seethe, Got. {suaths}, a burnt
  offering.
<sùbailte>, supple; from the Eng.
<sùbh>, @Ref<sùbhag> (@Ref<suibheag> or @Ref<sui'eag>, Dial.) a raspberry, @Ref<subh>,
  fruit generally (Arg.), Ir. @Ir{suibh}, a strawberry, {sughog}, raspberry
  (Fol.), O.Ir. @OIr{subi}, fragae, W. @W{syfi}, strawberry, Br. @Br{sivi};
  a side form to root {suℊ} as in @Ref{sùgh.1}.  Cf. Gr. @Gr{ὕφεαρ}, a kind of
  mistletoe.
<subhach>, merry, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{subach}, O.Ir. @OIr{sube}, joy; opposite of
  @Ref{dubhach}: *{so-bv-io-}, "well-being", from root {bu}, be (see @Ref{bu},
  etc.).
<subhailc>, virtue, Ir. @Ir{subhailce} ({súbhailc}, Con.), O.Ir. @OIr{sualig},
  virtus, {sualchi} (pl.): *{su-alich} (Asc., @ExtRef{Zim.;1;54}), root {al} of
  {altram} (Dr Cameron).
<suchd>, sake, account (M`A.):
<sud> (Dial. @Ref<sid>), yon, Ir. @Ir{súd}, E.Ir. @EIr{sút}, @EIr{siut}, illud, illic, W. @W{hwnt}
  ({h-wnt}), other, yonder, Br. @Br{hont}; from the root of @Ref{so}; {sud} =
  {s-út} (Rhys).  Also @Ref{ud}.
<sùdh>, a seam between the planks of a ship; from Norse {súð},
  a suture (only used for the clinching of a ship's boards), from
  {sýja}, sow, Eng. @Eng{sew}, {suture}.
<sùg.1>, @Ref<sùgradh>, mirth, Ir. @Ir{súgadh}, {súgradh}, E.Ir. @EIr{sucach}:
<sùg.2>, suck, imbibe; from Sc. {souk}, {sook}, Eng. @Eng{suck}, Ag.S. {súcan}.
  See @Ref{sùgh.1}.

<sugan>, @Ref<corra-shugain>, the reflection of rays of light from any
  moving luminous body from the roof or wall of a house:
<sùgan>, a rope of twisted straw, Ir. @Ir{súgán}, {suagan}, straw or hay
  rope, {suag}, a rope (O'R.): *{souggo-}, root {soug} of @Ref{suaineadh},
  q.v.  Hence @Ref<suigean>, a cirle of straw ropes in which grain
  is kept in a barn.
<sùgh.1>, juice, sap, also (as vb.) drain, suck up, Ir. @Ir{súgh}, {súghaim},
  E.Ir. @EIr{súgim}: *{sûgô}, suck, *{sûgo-}, juice; Lat. {sûgô}, suck;

  {súg}, {súch}, W. @W{sug}, from Lat. {sucus} (Stokes).
<sùgh.2>, a wave (A.M`D.), motion of the waves (H.S.D.); root {sup},
  swing, Lit. {sùpti}, swing, Lat. {dissipo}, scatter?
<sùicean>, a gag for a calf; founded on {sùg}, Sc. {sook}.
<suidh>, sit, @Ref<suidhe>, a seat, sitting, Ir. @Ir{suidhim}, E.Ir. @EIr{suidim},
  {sudim}, O.Ir. @OIr{suidigur}, {suide}, a seat: *{sodeiô}, *{sodio-n}, root

<sùil>, eye, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{súil}: *{sûli-s}, allied to *{sâvali-s}, sun, W. @W{haul},

<suilbh>, cheer, hospitality, geniality: *{su-lubi-}, root {lubh}, please,
  love, Lat. {libet}, Eng. @Eng{love}.  It influences the meaning of
  @Ref<suilbhir>, originally "eloquent".
<suilbhir>, cheerful, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{suilbir}, O.Ir. @OIr{sulbir}, eloquence,

<suipeir>, a supper, Ir. @Ir{suipéir}; from the Eng.

  courtship?  Teh word is doubtful Gaelic; H.S.D. finds only

<suiridhe>, a courting, @Ref<suiridheach> (better @Ref<suirtheach> or @Ref<suireach>,

<sùith>, soot, Ir. @Ir{súithche}, M.Ir. @MIr{suithe}, O.Ir. @OIr{suidi}, fuligine, W.

<ta>, @Ref<tha>, is, Ir. @Ir{tá}, E.Ir. @EIr{tá}, is, {táim}, I am, O.Ir. @OIr{táu}, {tó}, sum, {tá},

<tac>, a lease, tack; from Sc. {tack}.

<tachair>, meet, happen, Manx {taghyrt}, to happen, an accident, Ir.

<tàcharan>, a ghost, yelling of a ghost, an orphan, Ir. @Ir{tacharán}:

<tachd>, choke, Ir. @Ir{tachdaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{tachtad}, angens.  Stokes gives
  the root as {tak} and refers to it also W. @W{tagu} (and {ystagu}),
  choke, Corn., Br. @Br@Corn{taga}.  Brugmann and Ascoli analyse {tachd}
  into {to-acht}, root {angh}, Lat. {ango}, choke, Gr. @Gr{ἀγχω}, Eng.
  {anger}.  Root {tak} as in Lat. {tacere} (Prellwitz).
<tachras>, winding yarn, Ir. @Ir{tocharais}, {tochardadh}, M.Ir. @MIr{tochartagh}:
  *{to-cert-}, root {qert}, wind, as in @Ref{ceirtle}.

  *{to-ad-ell}, form *{elnô} (Stokes), go, M.W. @MW{elwyfi}, iero, Corn.

<taibhs>, @Ref<taibhse>, an apparition, ghost, Ir. @Ir{taibhse}, vision, ghost,

<taibid>, a taunt; see @Ref{teabaid}.
<taibse>, propriety of speech: "precision", E.Ir. @EIr{tepe}, cutting; see

<taic>, support, proximity, Ir. @Ir{taca}, prop, surety, fastening, {toice},
  prop, wealth, {tacamhuil}, firm, @Ref{aice.1}, support, food, near, M.Ir.
  {aicc}, a bond, E.Ir. @EIr{aicce}, relationship: *{akki-}, *{pakki-}, root
  {pak}, bind; Lat. {paciscor}, agree, {pax}, peace; Eng. @Eng{fang}, Got.
  {fahan}, seize: Zend {paç}, bind.  The root is a triplet -- {pak},
  {pag}, {pagh} (Gr. @Gr{πήγνυμι}, make fast, Lat. {pango}, Eng. @Eng{page},
  etc.).  Zimmer refers E.Ir. @EIr{aicce} to the root of @Ref{agus}, @Ref{aig}.
<taidhe>, attention, heed, Ir. @Ir{uidh}, O.Ir. @OIr{oid}, {óid}, {con-ói}, servat:
  *{audi-}, root {av}, watch, Lat. {aveo}, desire, {audeo}, dare, Skr. {av},
  favour (see @Ref{àill} further).  The {t} of G. is due to the phrase
  "Thoir taidhe" (= {thoir do aidhe}) - Take thy heed: a phrase
  to which the word is practically restricted, and which
  accounts for the short vowel of the G. and Ir., the sentence
  accent being on the verb.
<taidheam>, meaning, import; see @Ref{oidheam}.
<taifeid>, a bow-string:
<taig>, attachment, custom; cf. @Ref{aig}, at.
<taigeis>, haggis; from Sc. {haggis}, O.Fr. {hachis}, Eng. @Eng{hash}, from

<taighlich>, chattels (Heb.); a side form of @Ref{teaghlach}.

  {tal}, {tel}, take, hold; Gr. @Gr{τάλαντον}, a talent, Eng. @Eng{talent}, @Gr{τελος},

<tailce>, strength, Ir. @Ir{talcánta}, strong, E.Ir. @EIr{talce}, {tailce}: *{t-alkiâ},

  @Ref{tail}.
<tàille.2>, @Ref<tàilleabh> (M`A.), consequence, @Ref<air tàille>, on account of;
  cf. M.Ir. @MIr{a haithle}, after, {as a haithle sin}, thereafter, O.G.
  {as á áthle}, thereafter (B.of Deer), {aithle}, remnant.
<tàillear>, a tailor, Ir. @Ir{tailiur}, W. @W{teiliwr}; from the Eng., M.Eng.
  {tailor}, {taylor}, from Fr. {tailleur}.
<tailm>, a tool, sling, noose, Ir. @Ir{tailmh}, a sling, E.Ir. @EIr{tailm} (do.),
  W. @W{telm}, laqueus, Br. @Br{talm}, sling: *{talksmi} (Stokes); Ch.Sl.
  {tlŭką}, strike.
<tailmrich>, bustle, noise; for *{tairmrith}, E.Ir. @EIr{tairmrith}, transcursus,
  from {tairm-}, cross, trans (see @Ref{thar}), and @Ref{ruith}, run.
<tailp>, a bundle, bunch (Sh., O'R.):
<tàimh>, death, mortality, Ir. @Ir{táimh}, E.Ir. @EIr{tám}, plague: *{tâmo-},
  death; cf. Skr. {támyati}, choke, Ch.Sl. {tomiti}, vexare.  Cf.,
  however, @Ref{tàmh}, rest.
<taimhlisg>, traduce (Carm.):
<tàin>, cattle, drove, Ir. @Ir{táin}, cattle, spoil, E.Ir. @EIr{táin}: *{to-ag-ni},
  root {ag}, drive, Lat. {ago}, etc.
<taing>, thanks; from the Eng. @Eng{thank}.
<tainneamh>, thaw (Arran), Manx {tennue}, Ir. @Ir{tionadh}, O.Ir. @OIr{tinaid},
  evanescit, root {ten} as in @Ref{tana}.  See @Ref{aiteamh}.
<taip>, a mass, Ir. @Ir{taip}; see @Ref{tap}.
<tàir.1>, contempt, Ir. @Ir{táir}, E.Ir. @EIr{tár}; for *{to-shár}; see @Ref{sàr.1}.
<tàir.2>, get, obtain, come, Ir. @Ir{tair}, come thou, E.Ir. @EIr{tair} (do.), {tair},
  venies; from {tairicim}, I arrive at, come, catch, for *{to-air-ic},
  root {ic} of @Ref{thig}, q.v.
<tairbeart>, an isthmus, peninsula: *{tar-bertâ}, from {tar} (see @Ref{thar},
  cross) and {ber} of @Ref{beir}: "cross-bringing, portage".
<tairbhe>, profit, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{torbe}: *{to-for-be}, where {-be} comes from
  *{bv-iâ}, root {bu}, be (see @Ref{bu}).
--page 357
<tairbheartach>, profitable, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tairbert}, yielding, giving
  up: *{to-air-ber-}, from the berb @Ref{beir}, bring.
<tairbhein>, surfeit, bloody flux (Carm.):
<tairg>, offer, @Ref<tairgse>, an offer, Ir. @Ir{tairgim}, {tairgsin}, E.Ir. @EIr{tairgim},
  {tharscin} (dat.): *{to-air-ges-}, root {ges}, carry (Lat. {gero}, as in
  @Ref{agus}?  Ascoli compares O.Ir. @OIr{taircim}, affero, {tairciud},
  oblatio, tribuere, from {to-ad-ro-ic}, root {ic} of @Ref{thig}.
<tairgneachd>, @Ref<tailgneachd>, @Ref<tairgire>, prophecy, Ir. @Ir{tairrgire}, @Ref{tairgire},
  prophecy, promise, O.Ir. @OIr{tairngire}, promissio: *{to-air-ind-gar-iâ},
  root {gar} as in @Ref{goir}.
<tairiosg>, a saw; see @Ref{tuireasg}.
<tairis.1>, the dairymaid's cry to calm a cow: cf. O.Ir. @OIr{tairissim}, sto,
  *{to-air-sess}, from {sess} as in @Ref{seas}, q.v.
<tairis.2>, kind, loving, Ir. @Ir{tairis}, loyal, E.Ir. @EIr{tairisse}, true, loyal:
  "stable", from {to-air-sess}, from {sess}, stop, stand, as in @Ref{seas}, q.v.
<tairisgein>, peat-spade; see @Ref{toirsgian}.
<tairleas>, @Ref<turlas>, cupboard or aumrie (Perth): Sc. {tirless}, lattice,
  wicket, Fr. {trellis}.
<tairm>, necromancy (Sh., O.R.); see @Ref{taghairm}.
<tàirneanach>, thunder, Ir. @Ir{tóirneach}, {tóirn}; see @Ref{torrunn} for root, etc.
<tàirng>, @Ref<tarrang>, a nail, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tairnge}; from @Ref{tarruing}?
<tais>, soft, Ir. @Ir{tais}, E.Ir. @EIr{taise}, {tasse}, weakness: *{taxi-}, soft (Gaul.
  {Taxi-magulus}?), root {tak}, weak, melting, Gr. @Gr{τακερός} (do.),
  @Gr{τήκω}, melt; further Lat. {tabes}, Eng. @Eng{thaw}.  Bezzenberger
  suggests Gr. @Gr{τάγηνον}, a melting pot, saucepan.
<taisbean>, reveal, Ir. @Ir{taisbeanaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{taispenim}, {taissfenim},
  O.Ir. @OIr{asfenimm}, testificor, {doairfenus}, exploravi; the old
  Gaelic root is {fen}, {ben}, which may be cognate to Gr. @Gr{φαíνω}
  (see @Ref{taibhse}).  Zeuss regarded the {s} as put before the {b} by
  metathesis, the word being of the same origin as @Ref{taibhse}.
<taisdeal>, a journey, {taisdil} (Cars.), journey (v.imp.) Ir. @Ir{taisdiol}:
  *{to-asdel}, *{ad-sod-}, root {sod-}, as in @Ref{astar}.
<tàisealan>, @Ref<taisealan> (M`E.), saints' relics, E.Ir. @EIr{taisse}:
<taisg>, deposit, store away, @Ref<tasgaidh>, depository, Ir. @Ir{taisgim}, E.Ir.
  {taiscim}, {doroisecht-sa}, id deposui: *{to-ad-sec-}, root {seq}, follow,
  beside, as in @Ref{seach}, past; the idea of the verb being "put
  past".  (Ernault Zeit. @ExtRef{Celt.;2;384}. {segh}).
<taisgeal>, finding of anything, @Ref<taisgealach>, a spy, Ir. @Ir{taiscealladh},
  spying, betraying, M.Ir. @MIr{taiscelad}, O.Ir. @OIr{taiscelaid}, explorator,
  pl. {taisceltai}, {do-scéulaim}, experior; from {to-scél-}, from @Ref{sgeul},
  story (Windisch).  Hence @Ref<taisgealadh>, news.
<taitheasg>, a repartee, Ir. @Ir{taitheasg}, {aitheasg} (O'Br., etc.), O.Ir.
  {taithesc}, answer, {aithesc}, admonitio, W. @W{ateb}, a reply: *{ati-seq},
  root {seq}, say, as in @Ref{sgeul}.
--page 358
<taitinn>, pleasing, Ir. @Ir{taithneamhach}, M.Ir. @MIr{taitnemach}, bright,
  shining, E.Ir. @EIr{taitnim}, I shine, {taitnemach}, shining, O.Ir.
  {taitnem}, lucina, light: *{taith-tennim}, {to-aith-tenn}, root {ten} of
  @Ref{teine}, fire (Windisch).  Stokes (@ExtRef{Bez.Beit.;18;112}), divides
  {taitnem} into {tait-} and {nem}, Pictish {namet}, albus.
<tàl>, adze, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tál}: *{to-aglo-} (rather {t-aglo-}?), Got. {aqisi}, axe,
  Eng. @Eng{axe} (Strachan).  Stokes gives a pre-Gaelic *{tâkslo}, root
  {tek}, Ch.Sl. {tesla}, axe, Lat. {gelum} (= {tex-lum}), weapon, Gr.
  @Gr{τέκτων}, carpenter; but {tek} does not appear to have a side
  form {tâk}, and {tâkslo-} would produce {táll} ({tôkslo}, Foy).  But
  cf. Lat. {pâla}, spade, for root, and for phonetics G. @Ref{torc.1} and
  Lat. {porcus}.
<talach>, complaining, Ir. @Ir{talach}, dispraise, reproach:
<tàladh>, enticing, hushing, caressing; from Norse {tál}, allurement,
  bait, trap, Ag.S. {tál}, calumny, root {dâl}, {del}, Lat. {dolus},
  guile, @Gr{δηλέομαι}, hurt (Dor. @Dor{δᾱλέομαι}).
<talainte>, a partition or dividing wall; from Sc. {halland}, {hallon}.
  Dial. G. has also @Ref<tallaid>.
<talamh>, earth, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{talam}, g. {talman}: *{talmon-}, for
  {tḷ-mon}, root {tel}; Lat. {tellus}, earth (for {tēlṓs}), *{têl}, flat; Gr.
  @Gr{τηλíα}, a board; Ag.S. {thelu}, board (root {tēl}); Skr. {talas},
  level ground; Ch.Sl. {tĭlo}, pavement (root {tḷ}).  Stokes joins
  here Celtic {talo-s}, brow, Gaul.  {Dubno-talos}, {Argio-talos}
  (Pictish {Talorgan}), W. @W{tâl}, brow, Corn. @Corn{tâl}, Br. @Br{tal}.
<tàlan>, feats of arms, chivalry, Ir. @Ir{talan} (O'B., Sh., etc.); see
  @Ref{tàlann} for origin.
<tàlann>, a talent, Ir. @Ir{tallann}, O.Ir. @OIr{talland}; from Lat. {talentum},
  Eng. @Eng{talent}.
<tàlfuinn>, a hoe; from @Ref{tàl} and @Ref{fonn.1}.
<talla>, a hall, Ir. @Ir{alla}, M.Ir. @MIr{all}; from Norse {hall}, {höll}, Eng. @Eng{hall}:
  allied to G. @Ref{ceall}, q.v.
<talmaich>, honour (Carm.):
<tàmailt>, an insult, offence, Ir. @Ir{támailt}, Br. @Br{tamall}, reproach, root
  {stemb}, abuse, I.E. {stenℊo}, stamp, Gr. @Gr{στέμβω}, shake, misuse,
  abuse, @Gr{στόβεω}, scold, Eng. @Eng{stamp} (Stokes, Jubainville @ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;16;365}.
<tàmh>, rest, Ir. @Ir{támh}, E.Ir. @EIr{tám}: *{tâmo-}, root {stâm}, {sta}, stand,
  Eng. @Eng{stand}, {station}, {stamina}; see @Ref{seas}.  Usually {tàmh}, rest,
  and @Ref{tàimh}, death, are referred to the same root.
<tamhasg>, blockhead, brownie; see @Ref{amhas}.  For termination, cf.
  @Ref{ùruisg}, @Ref{tannasg}.
<tamhladh>, a gulping movement (M`D.):
<tamull>, a while, space of time, Ir. @Ir{tamall}: *{to-ad-melno-}, from
  {melno-}, linger, Gr. @Gr{μέλλω}, linger (Stokes).  See @Ref{mall}.

<tan>, time, @Ref<an tan>, when, Ir. @Ir{tan}, {an tan}, O.Ir. @OIr{tan}, {intain}, {intan},
  quum, quando: *{tanâ}, time; Skr. {tan}, duration, {tanâ}, continually.
  root {tan}, {ten}, extend, as in @Ref{tana}, q.v.
<tana>, thin, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tana}, Corn. @Corn{tanow}, Br. @Br{tanaw}, but W. @W{teneu}:
  *{tanavo-}, thin; Lat. {tenuis}, thin, {tendo}, stretch; Gr. @Gr{ταναός}
  @Gr{τανυ-}, long, stretched, @Gr{τεíνω}, stretch; Eng. @Eng{thin}, Ger. {dünn};
  Ch.Sl. {tĭnŭkŭ}; Skr. {tanú}.
<tànaiste>, next heir, tanist, anything second, Ir. @Ir{tánaiste}, lieutenant,
  second in command, heir apparent, O.Ir. @OIr{tánaise},
  secundus, {imthanu}, alternation, {innimthána}, talionem:
  *{to-atn-}, root {at} of @Ref{ath.1}, "re", Skr. @Ref{at}, also *{at-s-men}, of @Ref{àm},
  time, q.v. (Strachan).  Rhys (@ExtRef{Celt.Br.;2;308}) suggests connection with
  W. @W{tan}, till, Lat. {tenus}, root {ten} (no root {tân}?).
<tancard>, a tankard, Ir. @Ir{tancárd}; from Eng.
<tannas>, @Ref<tannasg>, an apparition, ghost; from the root of @Ref{tana}?
<taobh>, a side, Ir. @Ir{taobh}, E.Ir. @EIr{tóeb}, {táib}, O.Ir. @OIr{tóib}, W., Corn., Br.

<taom.1>, pour out, empty (vb.), a jet, torrent (n.), @Ref<taoim>, bilge-water,

  out (= {to-ess-sem-im}).  Borrowing from Norse {tómr}, empty,
  Eng. @Eng{toom}, is not to be thought of.
<taom.2>, a fit of rage, Ir. @Ir{taom} (O'B., etc.), M.Ir. @MIr{taem}:

<taosnadh>, horseplay (R.D.):

<taplach>, a wallet, repository, Ir. @Ir{taplaigh}; for {tap-lach}, from @Ref{tap},
  tow, etc.
<tarachair>, augur, so Ir.; for {tarathar}.  See @Ref{tora}.
<taraid>, truncheon or staff of authority (Hend.):
<taran>, the ghost of an unbaptised infant (Sh., O'R.); for {tacharan}?
<tarbh>, a bull, Ir. @Ir{tarbh}, E.Ir. @EIr{tarbh}, W. @W{tarw}, Corn. @Corn{tarow}, Br.
  @Br{taro}, @Br{tarv}, Gaul. {tarvos}: *{tarvos}; Lat. {taurus}; Gr. @Gr{γαῦρος}
  (= @Gr{τάρφος}); Pruss. {tauris}, buffalo, Ch.Sl. {turŭ}, auroch.
  Prellwitz thinks the Celtic not allied to Gr. @Gr{ταῦρος}, etc.,
  which he refers to the root {tau}, @Ref{tu} ({stû} gives Eng. @Eng{steer}).
<tarcuis>, also @Ref<talcuis>, contempt.  Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{tarcuisne}, E.Ir.
  {tarcusul}:
<targadh>, ruling, governing, assembly (Lh., etc.), Ir. @Ir{targadh}:
