<tàrladh>, it happened; see @Ref{thàrladh}.
<tàrlaid>, a slave, thrall; from Eng. @Eng{varlet}?
<tàrmachadh>, producing, originating, source, dwelling, Ir. @Ir{tórmach},
  an increasing, a growing ripe for bearing, magnifying, O.Ir.
  {tórmach}, an increase: *{to-for-mach}, root {mag}, power (Eng.
  {may}, {might}, etc.).
<tàrmachan>, a ptarmigan, Ir. @Ir{tarmochan}; Eng. @Eng{ptarmigan} is hence
  (Skeat).  Also {tarman}, from {tarm}, murmur (Carm.):
<tarmachan-dé>, white butterfly (Carm.):
<tàrmus>, dislike of food: *{to-air-meas}; see @Ref{meas.1}.
<tàrnach>, thunder-clap; see @Ref{tàirneanach}.
<tàrnadair>, inn-keeper; from L.Lat. {tabernator}, tavern-keeper,
  Lat. {taberna}, Eng. @Eng{tabern}.
<tarp>, a clod, lump (Sh., O'B., etc.), Ir. @Ir{tarp}, {tarpán}; from Norse
  {torf}, a turf, sod, Eng. @Eng{turf}.
<tàrr>, lower part of the belly, tail, breast, Ir. @Ir{tárr}, belly, lower part
  of the belly, E.Ir. @EIr{tarr}, W. @W{tor}, Br. @Br{tor}, O.Br. @OBr{tar}: *{tarsâ},
  {tarmsâ}; Sc. {thairm}, belly, gut, Eng. @Eng{tharm}, Ger. {darm},
  bowels; Gr. @Gr{τράμις}, tail, entrail, hip joint.  Stokes gives the
  Celtic *{targsâ}, allied to Lat. {terbus}, back.
<tarrag>, a nail; see @Ref{tàirng}.
<tarruing>, pull, draw, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tairrngim}: *{to-air-rengim}, from
  E.Ir. @EIr{ringim}, hang, tear, from {reng}, a nasalised form of {reg},
  stretch (see @Ref{ruighe.1} and @Ref{ruighe.2}).
<tarraid>, also @Ref<tèarraid>, sheriff officer, tipstaff (Dial.); see @Ref{earraid}.
--page 361
<tarsuinn>, transverse, across, Ir. @Ir{tarsna}, {tarsa}, {trasna}, M.Ir., E.Ir.
  {tarsnu}, across; from {tar}, across (see @Ref{thar}), and {sainn} of
  @Ref{ursainn}, q.v.
<tart>, thirst, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tart}: *{tar(s)to-}; Eng. @Eng{thurst}, Ger. {durst},
  Gr. @Gr{τέρσομαι}, become dry; Lat. {torreo}, burn, {tostum} (*{torstum}),
  Eng. @Eng{toast}; Skr. {tarsh}, thirst, Zd. {taresh}; I.E. {ters}, dry.
<tartan>, tartan; from Eng., Sc. {tartan}, from Fr. {tiretain}, linsie-wolsie.
<tartar>, noise; reduplication of root {tar}, {tor} in {tòirneanach}.
<tàsan>, tedious discourse or scolding, Ir. @Ir{tasanach}, tedious, slow
  (Lh. marks it obsolete and queries meaning):
<tasdan>, a shilling; from Sc. {testan}, {testoon}, a silver coin of the
  16th century with Mary's head ({teste}) on it, the "inglis
  testane" being worth 8 shillings Scots, Eng. @Eng{tester}, worth 6d;
  originally so called from the coins of Louse XII. (1500) with
  his head ({teste}, Fr. {tête}, head) on them.
<tasgaidh>, depository, a treasure: "A thasgaidh" - Thou treasure;
  see @Ref{taisg}.
<tataidh>, attract, attach one to oneself, @Ref<tadadh> (inf.), @Ref<taiteadh>
  (Perth), tame: *{tad-dam}, root {dam} of @Ref{aidich}.
<tàth>, cement, join (M`F., Lh.), Ir. @Ir{táthaim}, {táth}, solder or glue,
  W. @W{todi}, construc, join: *{táto-}, *{stâto-}, constitute, root {sta},
  stand?
<tathaich>, visit, frequent, tendency to vomit (Hend.), Ir. @Ir{tathuighim},
  M.Ir. @MIr{aithigim}; formed form the prep. @Ref{aith}, back, rather
  than a compound of {tiagaim} as in {imthich}, our @Ref{imich} (that is,
  *{ati-tig-}, go back again).  Stokes prefers root {at}, go, formerly
  discussed under @Ref{tànaiste}.
<tathunn>, barking; see @Ref{tabhunn}.
<té>, a woman, female, she, Ir. @Ir{an tí}, she who, {an té}, he who
  (O'Donovan says either means "he or she who" or "person
  who"), O.Ir. @OIr{intí} is(qui), {indí} ea(quae), {aní} id(quod): the
  article and the enclitic particle {-í}, for which see @Ref{nì.1}, and cf. @Ref{tì.1},
  he who.
<tè>, @Ref<tèa>, insipid, slightly fermented; from root of @Ref{teas}; cf. {tepid}.
<teabaid>, a taunt, repartee (Dial.), @Ref<teab>, a flippant person's mout
  (M`A.), @Ref<teibidh>, smart: "cutting", E.Ir. @EIr{tepe} ({to-aith-be},
  Stokes), a cutting, O.Ir. @OIr{taipe}, concisio, brevitas: *{tad-be}
  (= {to-ad-be}), reduced root {be}, cut, {imdibe}, circumcisio, etc.,
  root {bi}, {bin}, as in @Ref{bean.2}, touch, q.v.
<teach>, a house, Ir. @Ir{teach}, O.Ir. @OIr{tech}, {teg}, g. {tige}, W. @W{ty}, Corn. @Corn{ti},
  O.Br. @OBr{teg}, {tig}, {ti}, now {ti}: *{tegos}, g. {teges-os}; Gr. @Gr{τέγος}, roof,
  @Gr{στέγω}, cover; Lat. {tego}, cover, {tectum}, house; Eng. @Eng{thatch},
--page 362
  Ger. {dach}; Lit. {stë́ giu}, cover; Skr. {sthagati}, cover.  See @Ref{tigh}
  for usual nom. case.
<teachd.1>, coming, arrival, Ir. @Ir{teachd}, O.Ir. @OIr{techt}, aditus, itio, W.
  {taith}, iter, Br. @Br{tiz}, diligence, haste: *{tiktâ}, root {stig}, {teig}, as
  in @Ref{tighinn}, q.v.  Some derive it from @Ref{thig} or {tig}, q.v.  Hence
  @Ref<teachdaire>, messenger.
<teachd.2>, legal, lawful, M.Ir. @MIr{teachta}, {téchta}, O.Ir. @OIr{téchte}, fitting,
  legalis, lex: *{tenctio-}, root, {tenq}, become, chance, produce,
  Eng. @Eng{thing}, Lit. {tenkù}, chance, befaull, Lat. {tempus}.  Dial.
  form @Ref<deic>, @Ref<cha deic>, q.v.
<tèachd>, @Ref<teuchd>, silly boasting (Arg.).
<teacht>, see @Ref{teachd.1}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<teadalach>, slow, dilatory:
<teadhair>, a tether; from Sc., Eng. @Eng{tether}, {tedder}, Norse {tjóðr}, {tjor},
  Sw. {tjuder}.
<teagair>, collect, provide, shelter, Ir. @Ir{teagar}, provision, shelter,
  {teagarach}, warm, snug, {teagairim}, store, provide; cf. @Ref{eagar}.
<teagamh>, doubt, suspense; see @Ref{theagamh}.
<teagasg>, teaching, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tecosc}: *{to-aith-cosc-}, for which see
  @Ref{caisg}.
<teaghlach>, family, household, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{teglach}, W. @W{teulu}, O.W.
  @OW{telu}, Corn. @Corn{teilu}, familia: *{tego-slougo-}, from the stems of @Ref{tigh}
  and @Ref{sluagh}.  The terminations {-lach} from *{slougo-s} makes
  abstract collective nouns, which are used for single objects or
  persons; as @Ref{òglach}, young man, really "youth", or "young-people",
  just as "youth" is also used in Eng. as a concrete
  noun - "a youth".
<teaglach>, see @Ref{teaghlach}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<teallach>, hearth, forge, Ir. @Ir{teallach}, E.Ir. @EIr{tenlach}, {tellach}: *{tene-lach},
  from @Ref{teine}, fire, and terminal {-lach} (see @Ref{teaghlach}).
<teallaid>, a lust or bunchu woman (M`F.):
<teamhaidh>, pleasant, Ir. @Ir{teamhair}, pleasant, Tara, E.Ir. @EIr{temair},
  delightful, omnis locus conspicuus: *{stem-ri-}?
<teamhair>, time (Suth.): Lat.?
<teamhall>, slight swoon or stun, Ir. @Ir{teimheal}, darkness, O.Ir.
  {temel} (do.), Skr. {támas}, Lit. {tamsa}, Lat. {tenebrae}, {temere},
  rashly.
<teampull>, temple, church, Ir. @Ir{teampoll}, O.Ir. @OIr{tempul}, W. @W{teml},
  Corn. @Corn{tempel}; from Lat. {templum}.
<teanacadh>, deliverance, succour, @Ref<teanacas>, healing: *{tind-ioc},
  from @Ref{ìoc}, heal.
<teanchair>, pincers, smith's thongs, Ir. @Ir{teanchoir}, tongs, pincers,
  O.Ir. @OIr{tenchor}, forceps: *{ten-cor}, "fire-putter", from the stem
  of @Ref{teine}, fire, and @Ref{cor}, seen in @Ref{cuir}, put.
<teanga>, @Ref<teangadh>, a tongue, Ir. @Ir{teanga}, O.Ir. @OIr{tenge}, gen. {tengad}:
  *{tengot-}, from {stenℊh}, sting (Eng. {sting}, Ger. {stengal}, stalk),
--page 363
  which is from {zdṇℊh}, from {dṇℊh}, whence Lat. {dingua}, Eng.
  {tongue}?  Stokes ({Academy}, Oct 1891) has compared Lat. {tango}
  (so Windisch, {Scot.Celt.Rev.}, 34).  Rhys has considered the
  probabilities of alliance with W. @W{tafod}, Corn. @Corn{tavot}, Br. @Br{toed},
  older {teaut} (*{tebâto-}) in @ExtRef{Manx Pray.;2;136-7}.
<teann>, tight, tense, near to, Ir. @Ir{teann}, O.Ir. @OIr{tend}, W. @W{tyn}, tight,
  stretched: *{tendo-}; Lat. {tendo}, I stretch, {tentus}, stretched
  (Stokes, @ExtRef{Rev.Celt.;13;12f}); in any case from root {ten} of @Ref{tana}.
  Foy gives {sten}; N. {stinnr}, rough, hard.  Cf. Gr. @Gr{στενός}.
<tearb>, separate, Ir. @Ir{tearbadh} (O'Cl.), severance, M.Ir. @MIr{terpúd}, E.Ir.
  {terbaim}, {terbud}: *{ter-be-}, Gadelic reduced root {be}, cut, for
  which see @Ref{teabaid}?
<tearc>, scarce, rare, Ir. @Ir{tearc}, E.Ir. @EIr{terc}: *{ter(s)qo-s}, rare, root {ters},
  dry (as in @Ref{tart}); Lat. {tesqua} (= {tersquo-s}), deserts.
<tearmann>, a sanctuary, protection, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{termain}, {termonn},
  W. @W{terfyn}; from Lat. {termo(n)}, {terminus}, end, "end of race
  for life by reaching church lands" or {Termon landes} (Ducange).
<tearr>, tar, Ir. @Ir{tearr}; from M.Eng. {terve}, Norse {tjara}.
<tèaruinn>, save, escape, @Ref<tèarnadh> (inf.), Ir. @Ir{tearnaim}, E.Ir.
  {térnaim}, {ternam}, an escape, {érnaim}, I escape: *{es-rn-}, root {ṛn},
  Eng. @Eng{run}?
<teas>, heat, Ir. @Ir{teas}, O.Ir. @OIr{tess}, g. {tesa}, W., Corn. @Corn@W{tes}, Br. @Br{tez}: *{testu-},
  for *{tepstu-}, root {tep}, burn, heat; Lat. {tepeo}, be warm, Eng.
  {tepid}; Ch.Sl. {teplo}, hotly; Skr. @Ref{tap}, be hot, Zd. @Ref{tap}, burn.
  See, also from {tep}, @Ref<teine>, @Ref<teth>.  Hence @Ref<teasach>, fever.
<teasairg>, save, deliver, Ir. @Ir{teasargaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{tessurc}, servo,
  {dumesurcsa}, defendo me: *{to-ess-arc}, root {ark}, defend: Lat.
  {arceo}, ward off; Gr. @Gr{ἀρκέω} (do.).  See @Ref{adharc}.
<teasd>, die, Ir. @Ir{teasdaighim}, die, fail, M.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{testa}, deest, fails;
  *{to-ess-tá}, from {tá}, I am.  Cf., for force, Lat. {desum}.
<teasdam>, I preserve, help (Carm.):
<teasg>, cut, cut off, Ir. @Ir{teasgaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{tescaim}: *{to-ess-sc}, root {sec},
  cut, Lat. {seco}, Eng. @Eng{saw}.
<teibideach>, irresolute: "halting, failing"; cf. Ir. @Ir{tebim}, disappoint,
  fail, for which see @Ref{theab}.
<teich>, flee, Ir. @Ir{teithim}, E.Ir. @EIr{techim}, O.Ir. @OIr{teichthech}, vitabundus,
  W. @W{techu}, skulk, M.Br. @MBr{techet}, flee: *{tekô}, *{tekkô}, flee, I.E.
  root {teq-}, flow, run; Ch.Sl. {teku}, a run, Lit. {tekù}, flow; Skr.
  {taki}, runs, Zd. {taka-}, course.
<teididh>, wild, fierce (H.S.D.), wild fire (M`A.):
<teilg>, a fishing line: "a cast", from @Ref{tilg}, cast, Ir. @Ir{teilgean}, casting?
<teilinn>, msical instrument, @Ref<teilig>, a chord (Carm.), W. @W{telu} or
  {telyn}, harp.  Cf. @Ref{seillean}.
<teilleach>, a blub-cheeked fellow (Dial.); cf. @Ref{meilleach}.
--page 364
<teine>, fire, Ir. @Ir{teine}, O.Ir. @OIr{tene}, g. {tened}, pl. {tenti}, W. @W{tân}, Corn., Br.
  @Ref{tan} (in proper names also {tanet}): *{tenet-}, *{tenos}, Celtic root
  {te}, from {tep}, hot, as in @Ref{teas}, q.v.  Not for *{te(p)ne-}, as usually
  said, which would give {téine} now, nor *{tepsne-}, which would
  produce {tenne} now; @Ref{teine-sionnachain}, phosphorescence, {teine-fionn},
  will o' the wisp (Suth.).
<teinn>, calamity, strait; an abstract nounn from @Ref{teann}.
<teirig>, fail, be spent, die, @Ref<teireachduinn> (inf.), Ir. @Ir{teiricim} (O'B.),
  E.Ir. @EIr{tarnic}, it ended, from *{tar-ic}, transire ({tar}, across, and
  @Ref{ic} or @Ref{nic} of @Ref{thig}, {thanig}).  Atkinson joins it with {tairicim},
  arrive (= {to-air-ic-}), as in @Ref{tàir.2}, but the meanings scarcely suit.
<teiric>, hake, herring hake (Carm.):
<teirinn>, @Ref<tèarn>, descend, Ir. @Ir{tearnaim}, {túrnaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{tairnim}, O.Ir.
  {tairnnud}, dejectio (= {to-air-innud}), from *{endô}, go, root {end},
  {ed}, I.E. {ped}, go (Eng. {foot}, Lat. {pes}, etc., G. @Ref{uidhe}, q.v.).
<teirisi>! the dairymaid's cry to calm a cow; see @Ref{tairis.1}.
<teirm>, a term, Ir. @Ir{tearma}, earlier, {térma} (F.M.); from M.Eng.
  {terme}, from Lat. {terminus} through Fr.
<tearmasg>, @Ref<tiormasg>, a mistake, mischance; cf. @Ref{eirmis}.  Here {te}
  may be for @Ref{de}, on the analogy of {to}, @Ref{do.2}.
<téis>, a musical air; see @Ref{séist} for derivation.
<teismeid>, last will and testament; from Lat. {testamentum}.
<teis-meadhon>, the exact or very middle; {teis} = {to-ess}, as in @Ref{teasairg}.
<teist>, testimony, Ir. @Ir{teisd}, {teist}, O.Ir. @OIr{teist}, W. @W{tyst}, Br. @Br{test}; from
  Lat. {testis}, Eng. @Eng{test}, etc.
<teó>, @Ref<teódh>, make warm; from @Ref{teò-}, q.v.  The Ir. verb is {teighim},
  inf. {téaghadh}.
<teò->, warm, @Ref<teò-chridheach>, warm-hearted; *{tepu-}, Skr. {tapus},
  hot, root {tep} as in @Ref{teth}.  Cf. Keating's ({Three Shafts}, 282),
  {teó-ghrádhuigheas}, qui ardentius amat, where Atkinson considers
  @Ref{teó} a comparative.
<teòm>, a doel (Carm.):
<teòma>, skilful, expert, @Ref<teòm>, cunning (Carm.):
<teth>, hot, Ir. @Ir{teith}, comp. @Ref<teotha> (G. and Ir.), M.Ir. @MIr{te}, comp. {teou}:
  *{teps} (?), root {tep}, hot, as in @Ref{teas}.  The O.Ir. is {tee}, @Ref{té},
  fervidus, pl. {téit}, from *{tepents}, g. *{tepentos}, Lat. {tepens}.
<teuchd>, congeal, be parched, Ir. @Ir{teuchdaim}, curdle, coagulate,
  M.Ir. @MIr{téchtaige}, frozen, O.Ir. @OIr{coiteichtea}, concretionis:
  *{tenkto-}, from I.E. {tenq}, firm, fast; Eng. @Eng{tight}, Ger. {dicht},
  close.
<teud>, a string, Ir. @Ir{teud}, {téad}, O.Ir. @OIr{tét}, fidis, W. @W{tant}: {tṇtâ}, chord;
  Skr. {tântu}, {tánti}, cord: root {ten}, stretch, thin, as in @Ref{tana}.
<teugmhail>, battle, contest, disease, Ir. @Ir{teagmháil}, a meeting,
  retribution: *{to-ex-com-dháil}, see @Ref{còmhdhail}.  In the sense of
  "disease", see @Ref{eugail}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {comhdhail}
--page 365
<teum>, a bite, sudden snatch, wound, E.Ir. @EIr{temm}, W. @W{tam}, a bite
  Corn. @Corn{tam}, pl. {tymmyn}, Br. @Br{tamm}: *{tendmen}, root {tend}, cut;
  Lat. {tondeo}, shear, {tineo}, a worm; Gr. @Gr{τένδω}, gnaw; Ch.Sl.
  {tęti}, caedere.
<thà>, is; see @Ref{tà}.  The aspiration is due to the use of {tà} in relative
  sentences, where the {t} is intervocalic.
<thàinig>, came, Ir. @Ir{thánaic}, {tháinig}, vēnit, O.Ir. @OIr{tánic}, {ránic}, vēnit,
  {tânac}, vēni: *{ananka}, I have come - a reduplicated perfect;
  Skr. {ânamca}, has reached; Gr. @Gr{ἤνεγκε}, brought: root {enk},
  {nak} ({nank}), attain, bring, for which see @Ref{thig}.  The aspiration
  is due to the analogy of other perfects which follow @Ref{do.2}.
<thairis>, over, across, Ir. @Ir{tairis}, E.Ir. @EIr{tairis}, over it, him; from {tar}
  (@Ref{thar}) and {sé} or {é}, he, it.  The aspiration is, due to a suppressed,
  or supposed suppressed, @Ref{do.2} or @Ref{a.7}.
<thall>, over, beyond, Ir. @Ir{thall}, O.Ir. @OIr{thall}, {tall}: *{t-all}, O.Ir. @OIr{ol},
  quam, {indoll}, {altarach}, ultra, {al}, ultra; root {ol}, {el}, {ol}, Lat.
  {ille} (= {olle}), {alius}.  Also @Ref<eile>, other, which see.  The form
  @Ref<thallad> stands for {thall-ud}.
<thalla>, come, come along, "age", @Ref<thallaibh> (pl.), E.Ir. @EIr{tallaim},
  take away, *{talnô}, root {tel}, bear (see @Ref{tlàth}, @Ref{tail}, etc.).  Also
  interjection: @Ref<thalla! thalla!> well! well!
<thar>, across, Ir. @Ir{tar}, O.Ir. @OIr{tar}, @Ref{dar}, W. @W{tra-}, over, {trach}, beyond,
  root {ter}, through, past, Lat. {trans}, {terminus}; Skr. {tar-}, pass;
  I.E. {ter}, pass through, bore.  See @Ref{tora}, @Ref{troimh}.
<thàrladh>, accidit, Ir. @Ir{tarla}, E.Ir. @EIr{dorala}, {dorla}, O.Ir. @OIr{tarla}:
  *{to-ro-la}, the {la} being the remains of root {plu}, as in @Ref{dol}
  (Ascoli).
<theab>, nearly did (with inf.), Ir. @Ir{do theib sé}, he failed (O'B.):
  "grazed" it, from *{tebb}, graze, cut, as in @Ref{teabaid}?
<theagamh>, mayhap, perhaps, O.Ir. @OIr{tecmaing}, accidit, {tecmang},
  eventus, {do-é-cm-aingim}, accido, for *{to-ex-com-ang}, root {ang},
  near, as in @Ref{cumhang}, q.v.  Meyer takes O.Ir. @OIr{ecmaing} from
  {ad-com-bangim}, {bang} root of @Ref{buain}.  It has also been referred
  to root {mang}, {mag}, Eng. @Eng{may}, etc.
<théid>, will go, Ir. @Ir{téid}, goes, O.Ir. @OIr{téit}, venit, it: *{to-éit}, *{entô},
  *{pentô}, go, reach, root {pet}, {pent}, go, fly, fall; Lat. {pet}, seek,
  "fall on"; Gr. @Gr{πíπτω}, fall; Got. {finþan}, Eng. @Eng{find}.
<their>, will say; see @Ref{deir}.
<thig>, will come, Ir. @Ir{tigim}, come, E.Ir. @EIr{tic}, {ticc}, venit, O.Ir. @OIr{ticfa},
  veniet: *{tó-icc}, from {icc}, *{enkô}, come, reach, root {enk}, {nak},
  {nank}, attain, bring; Gr. @Gr{ἤνεγκα}, brought (= G. @Ref<thàinig>), a
  reduplicated perf. from @Gr{εγκ}; Skr. {ānamça}, attained; further
  {nank} of @Ref{adhlac} and Lat. {nanciscor}.
--page 366
<thoir>, give, G., Ir. @Ref<tabhair>, give thou, q.v.  The G. is for {toir}, a
  crushed form of @Ref{tabhair}, and this is aspirated on the analogy
  of @Ref{bheir}, @Ref{gheibh}, and especially of @Ref{thug}, its past tense.
<thud>, an interjection of dislike or impatience: Sc. {hoot}, hoot-hoot,
  Sw. {hut}, whence Eng. @Eng{hoot}.  The G. is borrowed.
<thug>, bave, brought, Ir. @Ir{thug}, {thugas} (1st pers.), E.Ir. @EIr{tuc}, {tucas},
  {do-fuc}, from {uc}, {ucc}, *{ud-ge}, from {s-} aorist *{e-ges-s-t}, *{e-ges-s-m},
  root {ges}, carry, Lat. {gero}, {gessi} (Zimmer, @ExtRef{Zeit.;30;156-7});
  whence also W. @W{dug}, he bore, Corn. @Corn{duk}, Br. @Br{dougas}.
<thugad>, @Ref<thugaibh>, @Ref<thuige>, etc., to thee, to you, to him; for
  @Ref{chugad}, etc., q.v.  Similarly @Ref<thun> is for @Ref<chun>, @Ref<gun>, @Ref<gu>, q.v
  @Ref<thun> with gen. is for @Ref{chum}.
<tì.1>, any one, person, Ir. @Ir{tí}, person, {an tí}, {an té}; see @Ref{té}, @Ref{nì.1}.
<tì.2>, intention, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tí}; {ar ti} = intends (Glenmassan MS.):
<tiachair>, perverse, ill-disposed, sick, a dwarf, Ir. @Ir{tiachair}, perverse
  (O'Cl., Lh., O'B.), M.Ir. @MIr{tiachair}, troublesome, E.Ir. @EIr{tiachaire},
  affliction, peevishness:
<tiadhan>, a little hill, small stone, Ir. @Ir{tíadhan}, a stone, testicle:
<tiamhaidh>, gloomy, lonesome, Ir. @Ir{tiamdha}, dark (O'Cl.), E.Ir.
  {tiamda}, dark, afraid:
<tiarmail>, prudent; cf. @Ref{tìorail}.
<tibirt>, fountains (Uist; Hend.); see @Ref{tiobart}.
<tìde>, time; from Icel. {tíð}, Sc., Eng. @Eng{tide}, Ag.S. {tíd}, Ger. {zeit}.
<tigh> (for @Ref<taigh>), a house, Ir. @Ir{tigh}, O.Ir. @OIr{teg}, {tech}; see @Ref{teach}.
<tighearn>, @Ref<tighearna>, lord, master, Ir. @Ir{tighearna}, O.Ir. @OIr{tigerne}, W.
  {teyrn}, O.W. @OW{-tigern}, Corn. @Corn{teern}, O.British {tigernus}: *{tegerno-s},
  {tegernio-s}, root {teg} of @Ref{tigh}, q.v.
<tighil>, call when passing (M`A.); the {t} being as in @Ref{tigh}, the word
  seems a variant of @Ref{tadhal.1}.
<tighinn>, coming, Ir. @Ir{tighim}, I come, E.Ir. @EIr{tiagaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{tiagu},
  {tíchtu} ({tíchtin}), adventus: *{tigô}, *{teigô}, from root {steiℊh}, {stiℊh},
  go; Gr. @Gr{στεíχω}, walk; Got. {steigan}, ascend, Ger. {steigen},
  Eng. @Eng{stair}: Skr. {stighnute}, stride.
<tilg>, cast, cast out, vomit, Ir. @Ir{teilgim}, O.Ir. @OIr{teilcim}: {to-es-leic},
  "let out", from the original of G. @Ref<leig>, let, q.v.
<till>, @Ref<pill.3>, return, Ir. @Ir{tillim} (Keating), {fillim}, {pillim} (O'B.) (Ulster
  has {till}): *{svelni-}, turn round, W. @W{chwylo}, turn, revolve,
  {chwyl}, a turn, course, while (for which see G. @Ref<seal>).  Cf. @Ref{fill}.
<tìm>, time; from the Eng.
<timchioll>, around, a circuit, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{timchell}: *{to-imm-cell},
  from I.E. {qel}, move, go; Lat. {colo}, tend, {celer}, swift; Gr.
  @Gr{πελομαι}, go, be, @Gr{ἀμφíπολος}, attendant; Skr. {cárâmi}, move,
  go.  See @Ref{buachaill}.

<tinn>, sick, Ir. @Ir{tinn}, E.Ir. @EIr{tind}: *{tenni-}, root {ten} of @Ref{tana}, @Ref{teann},
  @Ref{teinn}.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{tinaim}, evanesco, Lat. {attenuo}, Eng.
  {attenuate}.
<tinne>, a chain, link, piece of a column, M.Ir. @MIr{tinne}, flitch, E.Ir.
  {tinde}, ring, link, bar, O.Ir. @OIr{tinne}, chalybs; from the root {ten}
  of @Ref{tana}.  Cf. Norse {þind}, diaphragm.
<tioba>, a heap (Arg.); from Eng. @Eng{heap} or G. @Ref{iob}?
†<tiobart>, a well, O.G. {tiprat} (gen., B.of Deer), Ir. @Ir{tiobar},
  {tiobrad}, E.Ir. @EIr{tipra}, d. {tiprait}, *{to-aith-brevant-}, Celtic verb
  *{bervô}, seethe, boil; Gr. @Gr{φρέαρ}, @Gr{φρέατος}, a well; Ger. {brunnen},
  Eng. @Eng{burn}.  See @Ref{tobar}.
<tiodhlac>, a gift, Ir. @Ir{tiodhlacadh}, E.Ir. @EIr{tidnacul}, O.Ir. @OIr{tindnacul},
  traditio, {do-ind-naich}, distribuit: {to-ind-nank-}, root {nank},
  bring, get, Lat. {nanciscor}, obtain; also root {enk} as in @Ref{thig},
  q.v.  Hence also @Ref<tiodhlaic>, bury, and @Ref<adhlac>, q.v.
<tiolam>, a short space, a snatch:
<tiolp>, snatch, grasp eagerly, Ir. @Ir{tiolpaim}:
<tìom>, soft, timid, G. {tioma}, tenderness, Ir. @Ir{time}, fear, E.Ir. @EIr{tim},
  soft, timid, {timme}, fear: *{temmi-}, root {tem}, faint, Lat. {timeo},
  fear, Eng. @Eng{timid}; Skr. {tam}, to faint, Zd. {tam}, perish.
<tiomnadh>, a will or testament, Ir. @Ir{tiomna}, O.Ir. @OIr{timne}: *{to-imm-ne},
  the {n} of {ne} being the remains of {-ân-}, mandare, mittere
  (Ascoli); cf. O.Ir. @OIr{adroni}, deposuit, {immeráni}, delegavit, G.
  @Ref<àithne>, command, q.v.
<tiompan>, a musical instrument - a cymbal, Ir. @Ir{tiompán}, tabor,
  cymbal, drum, E.Ir. @EIr{tiompan}, a small stringed instrument;
  from Lat. {tympanum}, a timbrel, drum (Windisch).  The
  difference of meaning between E.Ir. and Lat. has caused some
  to doubt the connection; and Stokes gives the Celtic root as
  {temppu-}, a chord or string, Lit. {tempiù}, stretch, Ch.Sl. {tęetiva},
  chorda.
<tiomsach>, collecting, bringing together, Ir. @Ir{tiomsughadh}, E.Ir.
  {timmsugud}: *{to-imm-sag-}, root {sag} as in {tionnsuidh}, q.v.
<tionail>, gather, Ir. @Ir{tionólaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{tinólaim}, {tinolaim}, {do-in-ola},
  applicat: *{to-in-ōla-im}, where {ōla} is referred by Stokes to
  *{oklo-}, *{polko-}, joining, uniting, Ger {fügen}, to fit, {füge}, joint;
  Lat. {paciscor}, bargain, bind; Skr. {pā́ças}, a knot, Zd. {paç}, bind.
  Ascoli regards it as *{to-in-od-lu}, root {lu}, {plu} of @Ref{dol}, but *{od-lu-}
  would rather mean "go out", "go off".  W. @W{cynull}, gathering,
  Corn.  {cuntell}, O.Br. @OBr{contullet}, are, according to Ernault,
  borrowed from Lat. {contuli}.
<tionnail>, likeness of any person or thing: *{t-ionnail}, from {ionnan},
  like.
<tionndadh>, turning, Ir. @Ir{tiontodh}, O.Ir. @OIr{tintuith}, g. {tintuda}
  {tintathigh}, interpretes: *{to-ind-sout-}, root {su} of @Ref{iompaidh}, q.v.
--page 368
<tionnscainn>, a beginning, devising, @Ref<tionnsgal>, ingenuity, Ir.
  {tionnscnadh}, a beginning, device, plotting, {tionsgiodal}, managing,
  industry, O.Ir. @OIr{tinscnaim} (= {to-ind-scannaim}), I begin,
  {tindscetal}, a beginning, root {sqend}, start, spring, Lat. {scando},
  ascend, Skr. {skandati}, hurry, spring.  The W. has {cy-chwyn},
  ortus (*{sqenô}).  The form {-scetal} is for {sqen-t-} (?).
<tiop>, pilfer (M`A.); cf. @Ref{tiolp}.
<tìor>, dry (as corn), kiln-dry, Ir. @Ir{tiortha}, kiln-dried (Con.), M.Ir.
  {tírad}, kiln-drying, E.Ir. @EIr{tír}, to dry; from the root of @Ref{tioram}
  (O.Ir. @OIr{tírim}).
<tìorail>, warm, cosy, sheltered, Ir. @Ir{tíoramhuil}, cosy; W. @W{tirion},
  pleasant, a familiar abject; cf. Ir. @Ir{tíoramhuil}, {tíorthamhuil},
  homely, national, from {tír}.  Dr Cameron regarded it as
  taken from the root of @Ref{tioram}, which is ultimatley the
  same as that of @Ref{tìr}.  Borrowing from Eng. @Eng{cheerful} is
  unlikely.
<tioram>, dry, Ir. @Ir{tirim}, M.Ir. @MIr{tirimm}, O.Ir. @OIr{tírim}, {tír} (vb.):
  *{tersmi-}, root {ters}, dry, as in @Ref<tart>, q.v.  See also @Ref{tìr} for
  phonetics.
<tiorc>, save, deliver from peril: *{t-erc-}, *{to-arki-}, root {ark} of
  @Ref{teasairg}, q.v.
<tiort>, an accident:
<tiosan>, water-gruel; from Eng. @Eng{ptisan}, Lat. {ptisana}, barley water,
  from Gr. @Gr{πτισάνη}.
<tiot>, @Ref<tiota>, @Ref<tiotan>, a moment, while; cf. Ir. @Ir{giota}, something
  small, jot, appendage, from Lat. {iota}, whence Eng. @Eng{jot}.
  Gaelic is {t-iot}.
<tìr>, land, earth, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tír}, W., Corn., Br. @Br{tir}, tellus, la terre:
  *{têros} (*{têres-}); Lat. {terra} (*{tersâ}), Oscan {teerum}, territorium.
  The further root is {ters}, be dry, as in @Ref{tart}; the idea
  of {tír}, {terrâ}, is "dry land" opposed to sea.
<tit>, an interjection expressive of wet being perceived suddenly
  (H.S.D.): Eng. @Eng{chut}?
<tiugainn>, come, let us go; from deaspirated {thugainn}, "to us",
  for {chugainn}, q.v.
<tiugh>, thick, Ir. @Ir{tiugh}, E.Ir. @EIr{tiug}, W. @W{tew}, O.W. @OW{teu}, obtuso, Corn.
  {tew}, Br. @Br{teu}: *{tegu-}, thick; Eng. @Eng{thick}, Norse {þykkr}, Ger.
  {dick}; Gr. @Gr{στεγνός}, fast, tight.
<tiurr>, a beach out of reach of the sea; for {an t-iurr}, from Norse
  {eyrr}, a gravelly bank by a river or a promontory, Sw. {ör},
  Dan. {örr}.  @Ref<tiur>, mark of sea on shor, tear, stamp (Carm.).
<tlachd>, pleasure, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{tlacht}: {tḷ-ko-}, "willing", from @Ref{toil},
  will, q.v.  O.Ir. @OIr{todlugud}, petitio, {tothlaigim}, I desire, is from
  *{tloq-}, of @Ref{altach}.
--page 369
<tlàm>, teaze (wool), handful of wool.  Strachan and Stokes give
  the stem as *{tlagm} (read {tlâg-s-m-}) allied to Ger. {flocke}, flock
  of wool, Eng. @Eng{flock}.
<tlàth>, mild, smooth, Ir. @Ir{tlaith} ({tláith}, O'B.), {tlath}, E.Ir. @EIr{tlaith}, W.
  {tlawd}: *{tlâti-}, "long-suffering", from {tel}, bear, endure; Gr.
  @Gr{τλητός}, {tláw}, endure; Lat. {tollo}, raise, {tuli}, {lâtus} (for *{tlâtus}),
  borne; Eng., Sc. {thole}.
<tlìgheachd>, liquid, spume: {t-lighe}?
<tlus>, pity, tenderness, M.Ir. @MIr{tlusach}, wealthy, W. @W{tlws}, jewel
  (Stokes), E.Ir. @EIr{tlus} (S.n.R.); from root {tḷ}, {tel} of @Ref{tlàth}, q.v.
<tnùth>, envy, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tnúth}; from the root {ten}, stretch:
  "grasping"?
<to->, @Ref<do-.2>, verbal prefix = to, ad, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{to-}, {do-}.  Stokes compares
  Gothic {du-} to, from {þu} (?).  W. has {du-}, {dy-}, {y}, Corn. @Corn{dhi}, Br.
  {do}, {da}.
<tòbairt>, flux, diarrhœa spasms: {to-fo-od-ber-t}, root {ber} of @Ref{beir}.
<toban>, wreath of wool or flax on a distaff; from Sc. {tappin}.
<tobar>, a well, Ir. @Ir{tobar}, O.Ir. @OIr{topur}, fons: *{to-od-bur}, root {bhur},
  {bhru}, to well, boil; Gr. @Gr{φύρω}, mix; Lat. {ferveo}, well, Eng.
  {fervid}; Skr. @Ref{bhur}, move quickly: further see root {bhru} in
  @Ref<bruith>, and {bhrev} in @Ref<tiobar>.  Some have referred <tobar> to
  the root {ber} of @Ref{inbhir}, @Ref{abar} (@Ref{obair.2}).
<tobha>, a rope, from Sc. {tow}, rope, Eng. @Eng{tow}, pull, Norse @Ref{tog}, rope,
  Lat. {duco}.
<tobhta.1>, @Ref<tota>, turf, roofless walls, knoll; from Norse {toft}, {topt}, a
  clearing, a space enclosed by roofless walls, Eng. @Eng{toft}, {tuft},
  and {top}.
<tobhta.2>, @Ref<tota>, a rower's bend; from Norse {þopta}.
<toch>, hough or thigh of an animal: *{t-hoch}, from the Sc. {hough}.
<tochail>, dig, Ir. @Ir{tochuilim}, {tochlaim}: *{to-cladh}; see @Ref{cladh}.
<tochar>, @Ref<tochradh>, dowry, Ir. @Ir{tochar}, M.Ir. @MIr{tocra}, (acc.); cf. O.Ir.
  {tochur}, placing, from @Ref{cuir}, put.  The idea is "something
  assigned to one".  Hence Sc. {tocher}.
<tòchd.1>, @Ref<tòch>, an unpleasant smell, @Ref<tòchar> or @Ref<tàchar>, dense volume
  of smoke (Arg.); root {stou}, as in @Ref{toth}.
<tòchd.2>, a disease of the eye in cattle; cf. Sc. {hock} (H.S.D.).
†<tochmharc>, a wooing, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tochmarc}: *{to-com-arc}; see
  for root @Ref{iomchorc}.
<tocsaid>, a hogshead; from the Eng.

<todhar>, manure, a bleaching, seaweed for manure, Ir. @Ir{tuar}, a
  bleach-green, {tuarachan}, a bleacher:

<toigh>, agreeable, cordi (mihi est), @Ref<docha>, preferable, @Ref<is docha leam>,

<toit>, smoke, fume, Ir. @Ir{tóit}, M.Ir. @MIr{tutt}, smoke: *{tutto-}, root {tu}, {stu},

<tonn.1>, a wave, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr@Ir{tond}, O.Ir. @OIr{tonn}, W., Corn. @Corn@W{ton}, Br. @Br{tonn}:
  *{tunnâ}, root {tu}, swell; Lit. {tvanas}, a flood, {tvinti}, swell;

  Celtic as *{tundâ}, Ag.S. {þeótan}, howl, Norse {þjóta}, whistle
  (as the wind, etc.).  Some have correlated it with Lat. {tundo},
  beat, root {tund}, {tud}, Skr. {tud-}, push.

<tre>, through, Ir. @Ir{tré}, {tre}, E.Ir. @EIr{tré}, @EIr{tria}, @EIr{tri}, O.Ir. @OIr{tri}, @OIr{trí}, @OIr{tre},

<treabh>, plough, till, Ir. @Ir{treabhaim}, E.Ir. @EIr{trebaim}, inhabit, cultivate,

<trèan-ri-trèan>, corn-crake, Ir. @Ir{traona}:
<treann>, cut (Carm.):
<treas.1>, third, Ir. @Ir{treas}, O.Ir. @OIr{tress}: *{tristo-}, from {tris}, thrice, Gr.
  @Gr{τρíς}, Skr. {tris}, root {tri} of @Ref{tri}, three.  W. @W{trydydd}, third, is for
  *{tritijo-s}.
--page 375
†<treas.2>, battle, skirmish, Ir. @Ir{treas}, E.Ir. @EIr{tress}.  For root, cf.
  @Ref{treasa}.  W. has {trîn}, battle, bustle, {treis}, violence.
<treasa>, stronger, Ir. @Ir{treas}, strong, {treise}, stronger, O.Ir. @OIr{tressa}, W.
  {trech}, fortior, Br. @Br{trec'h}: *{treksjôs}, fortior, root {treg}, {streg},
  {sterg}, strong, Eng. @Eng{stark}, Lit. {strėgti}, stiffen, Pers. {suturg}
  (*{stṛg}), strong.  Stokes refers it to the root {treg}, {trag}, draw,
  leap, as in @Ref{troigh}, @Ref{traogh}.  See @Ref{treun} further; {treasa} is its
  comparative really.
<treasdach>, thorough-paced (of a horse); cf. Ir. @Ir{trosdán}, a pace,
  jump; root {treg}, draw, walk, as in @Ref{troigh}.
<treasg>, refuse of brewed malt, groats, Ir. @Ir{treasúmha}, dross, copper
  dross, {treascach}, draffy, M.Ir. @MIr{tresc}, refuse, offal: *{tre-sco}?
<treibhireach> (@Ref<treibhdhireach>, Dictionaries), prudent, upright,
  O.Ir. @OIr{trebar}, prudent, M.Ir. @MIr{trebaire}, prudence; from {treb} of
  @Ref{treabh}, q.v.
<tréig>, forsake, Ir. @Ir{tréigim}, E.Ir. @EIr{trécim}, W. @W{trancu}, perish:
  *{trankjô}, abandon, root {trak}, push, press, as in @Ref<dùrachd>
  (Stokes).
<treis>, a while, space, also @Ref<greis.2>, Ir. @Ir{treibhse}, {dreibhse} (O'B.),
  {treimhse} (Con.); see @Ref{greis.2}.
<treisg>, @Ref<treisginn>, weaver's paste, trash (M`A., Arg.), Ir. @Ir{treisgin}
  (con., etc.), {dreislinn} (Monaghan); cf. Sc. {dressing}.
<treodhair>, a smith's nail mould, Ir. @Ir{treóir}, {treoir}; from @Ref{tre}, {trem},
  through?
<treòir>, strength, Ir. @Ir{treóir}, conduct, strength, M.Ir. @MIr{treorach},
  strong, E.Ir. @EIr{treóir}, vigour: *{treg-ri-}, root {treg} of @Ref{treasa}.
<treòraich>, guide, Ir. @Ir{treóruighim}, M.Ir. @MIr{treoraigim}: *{trag-ri-}, root
  {trag} of @Ref{troigh}?
<treubh>, a tribe; from Lat. {trĭbus}, a tribe.  See @Ref{treabh}.
<treubhach>, valorous, strenuous, @Ref<treubhantas>, bravery; for
  *{treuntas}, from which {treubhach} is deduced.  M`Kinnon
  (@ExtRef{Gael.Soc.Tr.;13;341}) refers it to @Ref{treubh}, tribe.
<treud>, flock, herd, Ir. @Ir{tréad}, {treud}, E.Ir. @EIr{trét}: *{trento-}, root {trem},
  Lat. {turma}, troop, Ag.S. {þruma}, heap, company (Strachan,
  Stokes).  Windisch has compared Gr. @Gr{στρατός} (*{strṇtos}) to
  {treud}.
<treun>, brave, Ir. @Ir{treun}, O.Ir. @OIr{trén}, fortis, W. @W{tren}, strenuous,
  force: *{tregno-}, root {treg} of @Ref{treasa}, q.v.  Stokes gives the
  Celtic as *{treksno-}, which would produce *{tresno-}, modern
  @Ref{treann}.
<tri>, three, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{treí}, W. @W{tri}, Corn. @Corn{try}, Br. @Br{tri}: *{treis}; Lat. {três}
  (*{trei-es}); Gr. @Gr{τρεῖς}; Got. {þreis}, Eng. @Eng{three}; Lit. {trýs}; Skr.
  {tráyas}.
<triall>, going, journey, Ir. @Ir{tríall}, E.Ir. @EIr{triall}: *{tri-all}, "go-through",
  root {ell} of @Ref{tadhal.1}?
--page 376
<trian>, third part, a third, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{trían}, W. @W{traian}: *{treisano-};
  see @Ref{treas.1}, @Ref{tri}.
<triath>, lord, chief, E.Ir. @EIr{tríath}: *{treito-s}.  Stokes compares Lat.
  {trîtavus}, {strîtavus}, ancestor in the 6th degree.
<tric>, frequent, often, Ir. @Ir{tric}, E.Ir. @EIr{trice}: *{trekki-}, root {treg} of
  @Ref{troigh} (Stokes, Strachan).
<trid>, @Ref<trìd>, through, by, Ir. @Ir{tríd}, E.Ir. @EIr{trít}, per eum, id: *{trei-t},
  from root {trei} of @Ref{tre}, through; the final {-t} is the demonstrative
  pron. {to} (Eng. {that}, Gr. @Gr{το}); a pron. *{em-ti}, *{en-ti}
  (Stokes).
<trìd>, rag, clout, stitch; "Cha'n 'eil trìd air":
<trileanta>, thrilling, quavering; cf. E.Ir. @EIr{trílech}, song, O.Ir.
  {trírech}, song of birds.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{trill}, Ital. {trillare}, Sp. {trinar}:
  an initiative word, Eng. @Eng{thrill} is from the root {tre}, {ter} (see
  @Ref{tora}), "piercing", which may also be the ultimate origin of
  the G. words.
†<trilis>, locks of hair, Ir. @Ir{trilis} (obs.), E.Ir. @EIr{triliss}; cf. Eng. @Eng{tress},
  from Lat. {tricia}, {trica}, plait, Gr. @Gr{τρíχα}, in three parts, root
  @Ref{tri}, three.
<trill>, sand plover (Heb., Miss Freer):
<trìlleachan>, @Ref<trìleachan> (@Ref<drilleachan>, M`A.), the pied oyster-catcher,
  sea-piet:
<trillsean> (@Ref<drillsean>, M`A.), lantern, rush-light, a glimmer, Ir.
  {triliseán}, torch, lantern, earlier {trilsen}, facula, {trillsech}, sparkling:
  "piercing", from @Ref{tre}, {ter}, as in @Ref{trileanta}?
<trinnseir>, a plate, trencher, Ir. @Ir{trinsiur}; from Eng. @Eng{trencher}.
<trioblaid>, trouble, tribulation, Ir. @Ir{trioblóid}, E.Ir. @EIr{tréblait}; from
  Lat. {tribulatio}, Eng. @Eng{tribulation}.
<triobuail>, vibrate, quiver; from Eng. @Eng{tremble}?
<trionaid>, a trinity, Ir. @Ir{tríonóid}, {tríonoid}, E.Ir. @EIr{trínóit}, O.Ir. @OIr{trindóit};
  from Lat. {trinitât-}, {trinitas}, a trinity, from {tres}, three.
  The Gadelic is developed from *{trin(i)tâti-}.
<treubhas>, trews, trousers, Ir. @Ir{triús}, M.Ir. @MIr{tribus}, O.Ir. @OIr{trebus},
  breeches, L.Lat. {tubrucus} (Isidor), {tribuces} (Du Cange),
  "thigh breeches" (D' Arbois); from Sc. {trews}, Eng. @Eng{trooze},
  {trouses}, now {trousers}, trunkhose.
<triùcair>, a rascal; from Sc. {truker}, {trukier}, a deceitful person,
  from O.Fr. {tricher}, to trick, allied to Eng. @Eng{trick}.
<triuchan>, a stripe of distinguishing colours in tartan:
<triuthach>, @Ref<triuth> (M`F.), hooping cough, @Ref<triogh> (M`A.), a fit of
  laughing or coughing, Ir. @Ir{triuch}, {trioch}: root {pster} of
  @Ref{sreothart}?
<trobhad>, come thou hither to me; opposite of @Ref<thugad>: *{to-ro'-ad},
  *{to-romh-t}, "to before you"?

<tròcair>, mercy, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{trócaire}, W. @W{trugaredd}, Corn. @Corn{tregereth},

  "loving of the wretched", from the roots of @Ref{truagh} and @Ref{car},
  love.
<trod>, a quarrel, scolding, Ir. @Ir{troid}, M.Ir. @MIr{trot}, quarrel, combat,
  {trottach}, quarrelsome: *{truddo-}, root {trud}, distress, bother;
  Eng. @Eng{threat}, Norse {þrjóta}, fail, lack; Lat. {trûdo}, push, Eng.
  {obtrude}; Ch.Sl. {trudŭ}, difficulty.
<trog.1>, raise, @Ref<trogail>, raising, Manx {troggal}, earlier {trogell}: {to-ro-od-gab},
  that is to say, @Ref<tog> with the prep. @Ref{ro} inserted.  See @Ref{tog}.
  Rhys (@ExtRef{Manx Pray.;2;138}) compares E.Ir. @EIr{turcbál}, a rising (as
  of the sun): *{to-for-gab-}.
<trog.2>, trash (Dial.), busy dealing, @Ref<tròg>, busy dealing, from Sc.
  {troke}, to bargain, barter, {trog}, old clothes, {troggin}, pedlar's
  wares, Eng. @Eng{truck}, from Fr. {troquer}, barter, truck.
<trogbhoil>, grumbling (M`A.), @Ref<trògbhail>, quarrel (Nich., {trogbhail},Arm., Sh., O'R.):
<troich>, a dwarf; see @Ref{droich}.
<tròidht>, cataplasm, rags, shapeless worn shoe (Skye); see @Ref{trait}.
<troigh>, misspelt @Ref<troidh>, a foot, Ir. @Ir{troigh}, O.Ir. @OIr{traig}, g. {traiged},
  W. @W{traed}, O.Corn. {truit}, pes, M.Br. @MBr{troat}: *{traget-} (*{troget-}?),
  foot, root {trag}, leap, draw, Gaul. {vertragos}, greyhound; I.E.
  {tragh}; Got. @Got{þragjan}, run, Ag.S. {þrah}, course; Lat. {traho},
  draw.
<troileis>, any trifling thing; founded on Eng. @Eng{trifles}?
<troimh>, through, O.Ir. @OIr{tremi-}, trans-, super-: *{trimo-}, from @Ref{tri} of
  @Ref{tre}.  For the @Ref{mi} or {mh}, cf. @Ref{roimh}, @Ref{comh-}.
<trom>, heavy, Ir. @Ir{trom}, O.Ir. @OIr{tromm}, W. @W{trwm}, Corn. @Corn{trom}, Br.
  {troum}: {trud-s-mo-s}, "oppressive", from {trud}, oppress, distress;
  Got. {us-þriutan}, oppress, Eng. @Eng{threat}; Lat. {trûdo}, push.  See
  @Ref{trod} further.  For other views, see Rhys' @ExtRef{Lect.;2;114}, Zimmer
  @ExtRef{Zeit.;24;208}.
<troman>, dwarf, elder, Ir. @Ir{tromán}, O.Ir. @OIr{tromm}, g. {truimm}; also
  G. @Ref<droman> (M`A.):

  Fr. {trompe}.

<troraid>, a spire, steeple (M`F.); founded on Eng. @Eng{turret}.
<trosdail>, dull, seriously inclined, Ir. @Ir{trosdamhuil}, serious, confident.

  {trostan}, long slender pole.  See @Ref{trasd} for root.

<trosg>, a codfish, Ir. @Ir{trosg}; from Norse {þroskr}, Dan. {torsk}, Ger.

<trot>, trot, @Ref<trotan>, trotting; from the Eng.
<truacantas>, compassion, Ir. @Ir{truacánta} (O'B.): *{troug-can-},
  "expressing pity", from @Ref{truagh} and @Ref{can}, say.
<truagh>, wretched, pitiful, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{trúag}, O.Ir. @OIr{tróg}, W. @W{tru},
  Corn. @Corn{troc}, miser, Br. @Br{tru}, Gaul. {Trôgos}: *{trougo-}, miser, root
  {streug}, rub, wear; Gr. @Gr{στρεύγομαι}, am worn out, distressed;
  Ch.Sl. {strugati}, scratch, distress, Lit. {strugas}, carving instrument;
  Norse {strjúka}, to stroke, Ger. {straucheln}, stumble
  (Windisch, Prellwitz).  Stokes refers it to the root of Norse
  {þrúga}, press, {þrúgan}, compulsion, O.H.G. {drûh}, compes.
  From Celtic comes Eng. @Eng{truant}.
<truaill.1>, a sheath, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{trúaill}: *{troud-s-li-}, root {treud},
  {trud}, push; Eng. @Eng{thrust}, Lat. {trûdo}.  See further @Ref{trod}, @Ref{trom}.
<truaill.2>, pollute, violate, Ir. @Ir{trúaillim}, E.Ir. @EIr{trúalnim}, O.Ir.
  {druáilnithe}, corruptus, {œllned}, inquinatio, illuvies, {élnithid},
  violator, from {éln-}, O.Ir. @OIr{as-lenaimm}, pollue, G. root {len} ({lēn},
  Ascoli), fœdare (Lat. {lino}, smear, as in @Ref{lean}?).  Ascoli
  analyses {truaill} into {der-uad-lēn} ({der-} intensive), while
  Thurneysen refers the {tru-}, {dru-} to the root of Lat. {trux},
  {trucis}.  {dru-es-lén} (Stokes).  E.Ir. @EIr{trú}, wretched, Eng. @Eng{throe}
  (Stokes).
<trudair>, a stammerer, a dirty or obscene person, Ir. @Ir{trudaire}, a
  stammerer (Lh., O'B., Con.).  In the first sense, the word is
  Ir.; in the second sense, it is G. only, and likely of the same
  origin as @Ref{trusdar}.  Norse {þrjótr}, knave, bad debtor, has been
  adduced as its origin.
<truilleach>, a dirty or base person, filthy food: *{trus-lic-}, root {trus}
  as in @Ref{trusdar}?  Or from Sc. {trolie}, a person of slovenly
  habits, {trollop}?
<truis>, tear, snatch, truss; from Sc. {truss}, to eat in a slovenly,
  scattering fashion (Ork.), Icel. {tros}, Eng. @Eng{trash}.  In the sense
  of "truss", the G. is from Eng. @Eng{truss}.  Hence the cry to dogs
  to get out - @Ref<truis!>
<trùp>, a troop; from the Eng.
<trus>, truss or bundle, collect, Ir. @Ir{trusdalaim}, truss up, girdle, W.
  {trwsa}, a truss; from Eng. @Eng{truss}, O.Fr. {trusser}, from L.Lat.
  {tortiare}, {tortus}, twisted.  See also {triubhas}.
<trusdar>, a filthy fellow, filth; cf. Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{trist}, curse, profligacy,
  L.Lat. {tristus}, improbus.
<trusgan>, clothes, apparel, Ir. @Ir{truscán}, {trosgán}, clothes, furniture;
  founded on @Ref<trus>.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{trousseau} from the same origin.
<truthair>, a traitor, villain; from Sc. {trucker}, deceiver, trickster?
  Or from Eng. @Eng{traitor}?  Cf. @Ref{trudair}.
--page 379
<tu>, @Ref<thu>, thou, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tú}, W. @W{ti}, Corn. @Corn{ty}, @Corn{te}, Br. @Br{te}: *{tû}; Lat.
  {tû}; Gr. @Gr{σύ}; Eng. @Eng{thou}; Pruss. {tou}; Zd. {tû}.
<tuagh>, axe, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{tuag}, E.Ir. @EIr{túagach}, hitting: *{tougâ}
  root {teuℊh}, {tuq}, hit, strie; Gr. @Gr{τεύχω}, fashion, @Gr{τύκος},
  hammer, @Gr{τυκάνη}, flail; Ch.Sl. {tŭalo}, cuspis.  Stokes prefers
  comparison with Skr. {tuj}, hit (*{tug}).
<tuaicheal>, dizziness, @Ref<tuachioll> (Sh.), winding, eddying, moving

  Ir. @Ir{tuachail}, going, confused with *{tuath-cell}, "left (north)

<tuaileas>, reproach, scandal, so Ir. (Lh., O'B., etc.): *{to-fo-less};
  from *{lisso-}, blame, discussed under @Ref{leas-}?
<tuailt>, @Ref<tubhailt>, a towel; Ir. @Ir{tudhoille}; from the Eng.

<tuaiream>, a guess, aim, vicinity, Ir. @Ir{tuairim}; also @Ref<tuairmse>:
  *{to-for-med-}, root {med} of @Ref{meas.2}.

<tuasaid>, a quarrel, fight, Ir. @Ir{fuasaoid}, animosity, spite, E.Ir.
  {fúasait}, "entwickelung", development: {to-fo-ad-sedd-}, G.

  root {sedd} from {sizd}, {si-sed}, set, "set-to" being the idea?

<tuasgail>, loose, untie, Ir. @Ir{tuaslagadh}, releasing, E.Ir. @EIr{tuaslaicim}:
  *{to-fo-as-léc-im}, from {lēc} of @Ref{leig}, let, q.v.
<tuath.1>, people, tenantry, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{túath}, populus, W. @W{tud},
  country, nation, Corn. @Corn{tus}, Br. @Br{tud}, Gaul. {Tout-}, {Teuto-}: *{toutâ},
  people; Lat. Umbr. {toto}, state, Oscan {túvtú}, populus, Lat.
  {tôtus}, all; Got. {þiuda}, people, {Teutonic}, {Deutsch}, German,
  {Dutch}; Lettic {táuta}, people, O.Pruss. {tauto}, land.
<tuath.2>, north, Ir. @Ir{tuath}, {tuaith}, O.Ir. @OIr{túath}, left, north: *{toutâ},
  *{touto-s} (adj.), left hand, left, "good", Got. {þiuþ}, good; cf.
  Gr. @Gr{εὐώνυμος}, left hand, "good-omened".  Rhys (@ExtRef{Manx Pray.;2;62})
  suggests that the root is {su}, turn (see @Ref{iompaidh}):
  *{do-hūth} (*{to-su-}), "turning to"; W. @W{aswy} or {aseu}, left hand,
  being also hence - *{ad-sou-i-}.
<tuba>, a tub; from the Eng.

  Ir. @Ir{tubaiste}:

<tughag>, a patch:
<tuig>, understand, Ir. @Ir{tuigim}, O.Ir. @OIr{tuiccim}, {tuiccim}, {tuccim}: *{to-od-ges-}
  root {ges} of @Ref{tug}.  some have given the stem as *{to-od-cesi}, root
  {qes} of @Ref{chì}; but this would give G. {tuic}.  O.Ir. @OIr{tuicse}, electus:
  *{to-od-gus-}, root {gus}, taste, Eng. @Eng{gusto}.
<tuil>, a flood, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tuile}: *{tuliâ}, root {tu}, swell; Gr. @Gr{τύλος},
  knob, weal; Skr. {tûla}, tuft, Eng. @Eng{thumb}, {tumid}, etc.  (See
  @Ref{tulach}).  So Stokes @ExtRef{Zeit.;31;235}.  The O.Ir. root {ōl}, to flood,
  abound, gives {tólam}, a flood, {imról}, {foróil}, abundance, etc.
  The root {pol}, {pel} has also been suggested, as in @Ref{iol-}.
<tuilis>, overloading stomach (Carm.):
<tuille>, @Ref<tuilleadh>, more (n.), Ir. @Ir{tuille}, {tuilleadh}, addition, {tuilleamh},
  wages, addition, E.Ir. @EIr{tuilled}, {tuillem}, addition, inf. to {tuillim},
  enhance, deserve, as in G. @Ref<toill>.  Two words are mixed:
  {to-eln-}, deserve, and {to-oln}, much, more, E.Ir. @EIr{oll}, great,
  {huilliu}, plus, *{olniôs}, root {pol}, {pel}, many, Gr. @Gr{πολύς}, Lat. {plus}
--page 381
  etc. (see @Ref{iol-}).  Stokes equates the O.Ir. @OIr{uilliu}, {oll}, with Lat.
  {pollere}, which is from *{pol-no-}, root {pol} as above (Wharton).
  The G. syntax of {tuille} shows its comparative force in {tuille na}
  (more than) as well as {tuille agus}, Ir. @Ir{tuilleadh agus}
  (addition and).
<tuimhseadh>, beating, thumping, @Ref<tuinnse>, a blow (@ExtRef{Gael.Soc.Tr.;15;260),
  M.Ir. @MIr{tuinsim}, calco, {tuinsem}, bruising, *{to-ud-nessim}
  (Str.); founded on Lat. {tundo}, beat.  Stokes queries if cognate.
<tuineadh>, an abode, possession, Ir. @Ir{tuinidhe}, possession (O'Cl.),
  E.Ir. @EIr{tunide}; also <tuineadh> (Ir. and G.): *{to-nes-}, root
  {nes} as in {comhnuidh}, q.v.
<tuinneasach>, deathful, Ir. @Ir{tuinneamh}, {tuineamh}, death:
<tuinnidh>, firm hard, Ir. @Ir{tuinnidhe} (O'B., Sh.), immovable, {clocha tuinnidhe};
  from @Ref{tuineadh}, the idea being "settled, fixed".
<tuir>, relate, @Ref<tuireadh>, relating, Ir. @Ir{tuirtheachda}, relation, rehearsal,
  E.Ir. @EIr{turthiud}, pl. {tuirtheta}, tale, from {ret}, run (as in @Ref{ruith}).
  Cf. @Ref{aithris}, E.Ir. @EIr{tuirem}, reciting, is from *{to-rím}, root {rīm},
---JTM: text has E.I.
  number (as in @Ref{àireamh}).
<tuireadh>, a dirge, lamentation, Ir. @Ir{tuireamh}, dirge, elegy; for root
  see @Ref{tuirse}.
<tuireann>, a spark of fire from an anvil, Ir. @Ir{tuireann} (O'B., etc.),
  E.Ir. @EIr{turend} (?): *{to-rind}?  For rind, see @Ref{reannag}.
<tuireasg>, a saw, Ir. @Ir{tuiriosg}, E.Ir. @EIr{turesc}: *{tar-thesc}, from @Ref{teasg},
  cut, q.v.
<tuirl>, @Ref<tuirling>, descend, Ir. @Ir{tuirlingim}, E.Ir. @EIr{tairlingim}, O.Ir.
  {doarblaing}, desilit *{to-air-ling-}; for {ling}, jump, see @Ref{leum}.
<tuirse>, sadness, Ir. @Ir{tuirse}, M.Ir. @MIr{tor}, sad, E.Ir. @EIr{toirsi}, {torsi}, O.Ir.
  {toris}, {toirsech}, tristis; root {tor}, {ter}, @Ref{tre}, Lat. {tristis}, sad.
<tùis>, incense, Ir., M.Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{túis}; from Lat. {tūs}, Gr. @Gr{θύος}.
<tuisleadh>, a stumbling, fall, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{tuisled}, prolapsio, {tuisel},
  casus, {dofuislim}, labo: *{to-fo-ess-sal-im}, root {sal}, spring; Lat.
  {salio}, leap, dance, Eng. @Eng{insult}; Gr. @Gr{ἅλλομαι}, leap; cf. Lit.
  {selė́ti}, glide, creep.  Ascoli analyses it into *{to-fo-isl-}, where
  {isl} is what remains of {ísel} or @Ref{ìosal}, low.
<tuit>, fall, Ir. @Ir{tuitim}, O.Ir. @OIr{tuitim}, inf. {tutimm}, acc.pl. {totman}, also
  {tothimm}, *{tod-tim}, Gadelic root {-tim-}, W. @W{codwm}, a fall (cf. Ir.
  {cudaim}), {codymu}, cadere, Corn. @Corn{codha}; cf. Eng. @Eng{tumble}, Fr. {tomber},
  fall.  Usually explained as *{to-fo-thét-}, from @Ref{théid}, which would
  naturally be {tuid} in G., even granting that the crasis of
  {-ofothé-} simply landed in {-ui-}, not to mention the inf. in preserved
  {m} (@Ref<tuiteam>).  Root {tud} (Thur.); {to-ud} = {think}.
<tul.1>, entirely, Ir. @Ir{tul} (i.e. {tuile}, O'Cl.), increase, flood: an adverbial
  use of the root form of @Ref{tuil}, flood?  Cf. Ir. @Ir{tola}, superfluity.
<tul.2>, fire, hearth, heap (Carm.):
--page 382
<tulach>, a hillock, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tulach}; root {tu}, swell; Gr. @Gr{τύλος},
  knob, @Gr{τùλη} ({u} long), swelling, weal; Lat. {tumor}, {tūber}, a
  swelling; Eng. @Eng{thumb}.
<tulag>, the fish whiting, Ir. @Ir{tullóg}, the pollock; cf. @Ref{pollag}.
<tulchann>, @Ref<tulchainn>, a gable, posterior, Ir. @Ir{tulchán}, hillock; from
  @Ref{tulach}?
<tulchuiseach>, plucky (Hend.):
<tum>, dip, @Ref<tumadh>, dipping, so Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tummim}: *{tumbô}; Lat.
  {tinguo}, {tingo}, wet, Eng. @Eng{tinge}, {tincture}; O.H.G. {duncôn}, dip,
  Ger. {tunken}, dip, steep.
<tunna>, a tun, ton, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{tunna}; Ag.S. {tunne}, M.Eng. {tonne},
  Norse {tunna}, Ger. {tonne}; all from Lat. {tunna}, a cask.  Stokes
  (@ExtRef{Bez.Beit.;18;}), suggests borrowing from the Norse; Kluge
  regards the words as of Celtic origin.  On this see †@Ref<tonn.2>.
<tunnachadh>, beating, dashing; see @Ref{tuimhseadh}.
<tunnag>, a duck, Ir. @Ir{tonnóg}?
<tunnsgadh>, upheaval (R.D.):
<tur>, @Ref<gu tur>, entirely, Ir. @Ir{tura}, plenty ({tura namhad}, plenty of
  enemies), E.Ir. @EIr{tor}, a crowd (dat. {tur}); see @Ref{tòrr}.
<tùr.1>, a tower, Ir. @Ir{túr}; from M.Eng. {tour}, {tūr}, from O.Fr. @Ref{tur}, Lat.
  {turris}.
<tùr.2>, understanding; cf. M.Ir. @MIr{túr}, research, examination, O.Ir.
  {túirim}, {rotuirset}, scrutati sunt, for {to-fo-shirim}, from @Ref{sir}, search.
<turadh>, dry weather, @Ref<tur>, dry (without condiment), so Ir., E.Ir.
  {turud}, {terad}, adj. @Ref{tur}, dry, {tair}: root {tor}, {ter} of @Ref{tioram}?
<turag>, a trifling illness (as of a child) - Arg.:
<turaman>, rocking, nodding; see @Ref{turraban}.
<turcais>, tweezers (M`A.), pincers; see @Ref{durcaisd}.
<turguin>, destruction (H.S.D. from MSS.), M.Ir. @MIr{tuarcain}, smiting,
  E.Ir. @EIr{tuarcaim} (dat.), hitting: *{to-fo-argim}, root {org}, O.Ir.
  {orgun}, {orcun}, occisio, O.Br. @OBr{orgiat}, Cæsar's Gaul. {Orgeto-rix}:
  *{urg-}, root {vṛg}, {verg}, press, Lat. {urgeo}.  Stokes suggests
  connection with Gr. @Gr{ἐρέχθω}, tear; Bezzenberger gives Zend
  {areza}, battle, fight; Brugmann compares Skr. {ṛghāyati}, raves,
  rages, O.H.G. {arg}, what is vile or bad.
<turlach.1>, a large fire: *{t-ur-lach}, from Ir. @Ir{ur}, {úr}, fire, Gr. @Gr{πῦρ}, Eng.
  {fire}.
<turlach.2>, a bulky, squat person; see @Ref{tòrr}, @Ref{turadh}.  Cf. W. @W{twrllach},
  a rounnd lump.
<turlas>, small cupboard (Perth); see @Ref{tairleas}.
<turloch>, a lake that dries in summer, Ir. @Ir{turloch}; from @Ref{tur} and
  @Ref{loch}.
<tùrn>,a turn, job; from the Eng.
--page 383
<turraban>, @Ref<turraman>, rocking of the body, nodding, grief (@Ref<turadan>,
  Sh.).  Hence @Ref<turra-chadal>, a slumbering drowsiness,
  "nodding sleep":
<turrag>, an accident:
<turradh>, a surprise, taking unnawares (Skye):
<turraig>, @Ref<air do thurraig>, at stool (M`A.):
<turram>, a soft sound, murmur; onnomatopoetic.  But cf. @Ref{toirm},
  @Ref{torrunn}.
<turtur>, a turtle, so Ir., W. @W{turtur}; from Lat. {turtur}.
<turus>, a journey, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{turus}, O.Ir. @OIr{tururas}, incursus, {aururas},
  properatio: *{to-reth-s-tu}, root {ret}, run (see @Ref{ruith}).
<tùs>, the beginning, Ir. @Ir{tús}, O.Ir. @OIr{túus}, {tús}, W. @W{tywys}, leading; see
  @Ref{tòiseach}.
<tut>, interjection of cold or impatience; from Eng. @Eng{tut}.  See @Ref{thud}.
<tùt>, a quiet breaking of wind, stench, Ir. @Ir{tút}, M.Ir. @MIr{tútt}, stench:
  allied to @Ref{toit}, q.v.  Cf. Keating's {tútmhar}, smoky.
<tuthan>, a slut (Arm., M`L.), Ir. @Ir{túthan}; from the root of the
  above word.
<ua>, @Ref<o.2>, from, Ir. @Ir{ua}, {ó}, O.Ir. @OIr{ua}, {hua}, {ó}: *{ava}, ab; Skr. {áva}, ab,
  off; Lat. {au-} ({au-fero}), away; Ch.Sl. {u-}, ab, away.  See @Ref{o.2}.
<uabairt>, expulsion: *{od-bert-}, prefixed by @Ref{ua}? from the root {ber}
  (in @Ref{beir}).
<uabhar>, pride, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{úabar}, vainglory, W. @W{ofer}, waste, vain
  (Ascoli): *{oubro-}, root {euℊ}, rise, Gr. @Gr{ὕβρις}, insolence (see
  @Ref{uasal}).  It has also been analysed into *{ua-ber} like @Ref{uabairt} =
  "e-latio", elation.
<uachdar>, surface, summit, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{uachtar}, {ochtar}: *{ouktero-},
  root {euℊ}, {veℊ}, rise, be vigorous, as in @Ref{uasal}, q.v.  Cf. W. @W{uthr},
  admirandus.
<uadh-> in @Ref<uadh-bheist>, monster, @Ref<uadh-chrith>, terror; see @Ref{uath}
  below.
<uaigh>, a grave, Ir. @Ir{uaigh}, M.Ir. @MIr{uag}, E.Ir. @EIr{uag}, *{augâ}, allied to
  Got. {augo}, eye, Eng. @Eng{eye}.  See for force {dearc}.  So Stokes,
  and rightly.
---gjk (1.14) review: ref to which sense of {dearc}?
<uaigneach>, secret, lonesome, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{uagnech}: *{uath-gen-},
  "lonesome-kind", from @Ref{uath}, lonesome, single; Norse {auðr},
  empty, Got. {auþs}, waste, desert; Lat. {ôtium}, rest.
<uaill>, pride, Ir. @Ir{uaill}, E.Ir. @EIr{úaill}, O.Ir. @OIr{uall}: *{oukslâ}, root {euℊ},
  {veℊ} of @Ref{uasal}.
<uaimh>, a cave, den, Ir. @Ir{uaimh}, g. {uamha}, M.Ir. @MIr{uaim}, g. {uama},
  O.Ir. @OIr{huam}, specus (also {huád}, specu): *{oumâ}.  Bezzenberger
  suggests *{poumâ}, allied to Gr. @Gr{πῶμα}, a lid (*@Gr{πωυμα}); Strachan
--page 384
  compares Gr. @Gr{εὐνή}, bed (Ger. {wohnen}, dwell).  W. @W{ogof}, cave,
  den is correlated by Ascoli.
<uaine>, green, Ir. @Ir{uainne}, {uaithne}, E.Ir. @EIr{úane}.  Strachan suggets
  the possibility of a Gadelic *{ugnio-}, root {veℊ}, be wet, Gr.
  {u@`grós}, wet (see @Ref{feur}).
<uainneart>, bustle, wallowing, Ir. @Ir{únfuirt}, wallowing, tumbling;
  also G. @Ref<aonairt>, @Ref<aonagail>:
<uair>, an hour, Ir. @Ir{uair}, O.Ir. @OIr{huar}, @Ref{uar}, g. {hóre}, W. @W{awr}, Corn. @Corn{our},
  O.Br. @OBr{aor}, Br. @Br{eur}, {heur}; from Lat. {hora}, Eng. @Eng{hour}.  Hence
  @Ref<uaireadair>, a watch, time-piece, Ir. @Ir{uaireadóir} (*{horatorium}?).
<uaisle>, pride, nobility, so Ir.; from @Ref{uasal}, q.v.
<uallach.1>, a burden, Ir. @Ir{ualach}: *{podl-}; O.H.G. {fazza}, a bundle,
  Ger. {fassen}, hold (Strachan).  Also G. @Ref<eallach.1>, q.v.
<uallach.2>, gay, proud, so Ir.; from @Ref{uaill}.
<uamhag>, sheep-louse:
<uamharr>, dreadful, Ir. @Ir{uathmhar}, E.Ir. @EIr{úathmar}; from @Ref{uath}, fear,
  q.v.  Used adverbially, like Eng. @Eng{awfully}, to denote excess.
  Dial. @Ref<uarraidh>.
<uamhas>, dread, horror, @Ref<uathbhas>, Ir. @Ir{uathbhás}, E.Ir. @EIr{úathbhás}:
  *{uath-bás}, "dread death"; see @Ref{uath} and @Ref{bàs}.
<uamhunn>, horror, Ir. @Ir{uamhan}, awe, horror, E.Ir. @EIr{uamun}, {hóman},
  O.Ir. @OIr{omun}, {homon}, rarely, {ómun}, fear, W. @W{ofn}, fear, awe,
  Corn. @Corn{own}, Br. @Br{aoun}, Gaul. {-obnos}, {Ex-obnus}, Fearless: *{obno-s},
  fear.  Bez. cfs. Got. {bi-abrjan}, be astounded (but {abrs} means
  "powerful"), and Gr. @Gr{ἄφνω}, suddenly.
<uan>, a lamb, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{uan}, W. @W{oen}, pl. {wyn}, Corn. @Corn{oin}, Br. @Br{oan}:
  *{ogno-s}; Lat. {agnus}; Gr. @Gr{άμνός} (for @Gr{ἀβνός}); Ch.Sl. {jagne};
  Also Ag.S. {éanian}, to yean or lamb (*{aunōn}).
<uar>, waterfall, heavy shower, confluence (Sutherland Dial.), Ir.,
  E.Ir. @EIr{úarán}, fresh spring; see @Ref{fuaran}.  Arm. has @Ref<uaran>,
  fresh water.
<uarach>, hourly, temporary (H.S.D.), homely (M`L.); from @Ref{uair}.
<uasal>, noble, proud, Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{uasal}, W. @W{uchel}, Br. @Br{uhel}, {huel},
  Gaul. {uxello-}: *{oukselo-}, high, root {euℊ}, {veℊ}, rise, increase;
  Gr. @Gr{ὑψηλός}, high, @Gr{αὐξω}, increase; Lat. {augeo}, increase, {vigeo},
  be strong; Eng. @Eng{up}, Ger. {auf}; Lit. {áuksztas}, high.
†<uath>, dread, Ir. @Ir{uath}, O.Ir. @OIr{úath}, Corn. @Corn{uth}, Br. @Br{eus}, {heuz}, horror;
  *{pouto-}, root {pu}, foul; Lat. {putris}, Eng. @Eng{putrid}, {foul}?
<ub!> @Ref<ubub!> interjection of contempt or aversion, O.Ir. @OIr{upp}.
<ubag>, @Ref<ubaidh>, a charm, Ir. @Ir{uptha}, {upadh}, sorcerer, O.Ir. @OIr{upta},
  fascinatio, {uptha}, Manx {obbee}, sorcery: *{od-ba-t-}, from {ba},
  speak (see @Ref{ob}, refuse).  Zimmer refers it to root {ben} of @Ref{bean.2},
  hurt, touch.
<ubairt>, rummaging amoung heavy articles, bustle (Dial.); see
  @Ref{ùbraid}.
--page 385
<ubh! ubh!> interjection of disgust or amazement; cf. Eng. @Eng{phew}.
<ubh>, an egg, Ir. @Ir{ubh}, {ugh}, O.Ir. @OIr{og}, {ub} (?), W. @W{wy}, pl. {wyan}, Corn.
  {uy}, {oy}, Br. @Br{u}, {vi}: *{ogos}; Gr. @Gr{ὤβεον}, egg, further @Gr{ὠόν}, Lat.
  {ovum}, Eng. @Eng{egg}.  The phonetics as between Celtic and the
  other languages is somewhat difficult; but the connection
  is indisputable.
<ubhal>, apple, Ir. @Ir{ubhall}, E.Ir. @EIr{uball}, {ubull}, O.Ir. @OIr{aball}, W. @W{afal},
  Corn. @Corn{auallen}, Br. @Br{avallen}: *{aballo-}, *{aballôn}; Eng. @Eng{apple},
  Ger. {apfel}; Lit. {obůlys}.  Stokes now queries Ger. {obst}, fruit,
  O.H.G. {obaz}, Ag.S. {ofet}, fruit.
<ùbhla>, a fine, penalty:
<ùbraid>, confusion, dispute, also @Ref<ùprait>: *{ud-bert-}, from {ber} of
  @Ref{beir}.
<ucas>, @Ref<ugsa>, coal-fish, stenlock:
<uchd>, the breast, so Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{ucht}: *{poktu-}; Lat. {pectus}?  Stokes
  and Bezzenberger give *{puptu-}, Lettic {pups}, woman's breast,
  Lit. {pápas}, breast (Eng. {pap} from Lat. {pappa}).  St. now
  gives {poktus}, allied to {pectus}.  See @Ref{iochd}.
<ud>, yon, yonder, Ir. @Ir{úd}, E.Ir. @EIr{út}; for @Ref{sud} ({sút}), q.v.  For loss of
  {s}, cf. the article.
<udabac>, outhouse, porch, back-house (@Ref<ùdabac>, Uist); from Norse
  {úti-bak}, "out-back"?
<udail>, cause to shake, waver, remove, Ir. @Ir{udmhall}, quick, stirring
  (O'Cl.), O.Ir. @OIr{utmall}, unsteady, {utmaille}, instability: {út} of
  @Ref{sud} + {tamall} (Rhys).
<ùdail>, inhospitable, churlish, @Ref<ùdlaidh>, gloomy; cf. Norse {útlagi},
  an outlaw, {útlagð}, outlawry.
<udalan>, a swivel, Ir. @Ir{udalán} (Fol., O'R.); from @Ref{udail}.  Cf. {ludnan}.
<udhar>, a boil, ulcer; also @Ref<othar>, q.v.
<ùdlaiche>, a stag, old hart (Arm.):
<ùdrathad>, @Ref<ùtraid>, free egress and regress to common pasture;
  from the Norse - cf. {útreið}, an expedition, "out-road".
<ugan>, the upper part of the breast, Ir. @Ir{ugán}, craw of a fowl,
  {ugannn}, fish gill (Heb.):
<ùghdair>, author, Ir. @Ir{úghdar}, E.Ir. @EIr{ugtar}, O.Ir. @OIr{augtor}; from Lat.
  {auctor}.
<ugsa>, coal-fish; see @Ref{ucas}.
<uibe>, a mass, lump (as of dough), @Ref<iob>; cf. @Ref{faob}: *{ud-bio-}, "out-being".
  But cf. Lat. {offa}, ball.
<uibhir>, a number, quantity, Ir. @Ir{uibhir}, {uimhir}, E.Ir. @EIr{numir},
  number; from Lat. {numerus}, Eng. @Eng{number}.
<ùidh.1> (@Ref<uidh>), care, heed, Ir. @Ir{uidh} (obs.), O.Ir. @OIr{oid}; see @Ref{taidhe}.
<ùidh.2>, a ford, that part of a stream leaving a lake before breaking
  into a current; also an isthmus (M`Kinnon), @Ref{uidh}, {aoi}); from
--page 386
  Norse {eið}, an isthmus, neck of land.  Hence {Eye} or {Ui} near
  Stornoway, older {Ey}, {Huy}, {Eie}.
<uidh>, @Ref<uidhe>, a journey, distance, Ir. @Ir{uidhe}, E.Ir. @EIr{ude}, O.Ir. @OIr{huide},
  profectio: *{odio-n}, root {pod}, {ped}, go; Lat. {pes}, {pedis}, foot;
  Gr. @Gr{πούς}, @Gr{ποδός}, foot; Eng. @Eng{foot}; Skr. {padyâ}, footstep.
<uidheam>, accoutrements, apparatus, Ir. @Ir{ughaim}, harness, trappings,
  O.Ir. @OIr{aidmi}, armamenta, W. @W{iau}, jugum, O.Corn. {iou},
  Br. @Br{geo}, {ieo}, *{yougo-}, yoke; Eng. @Eng{yoke}, Ger. {joch}; Gr. @Gr{ζυγόν};
  Lat. {jugum}; Lit. {jungas}.  The Gadelic requires a form
  *{ad-jung-mi}.  Cf. O.Ir. @OIr{adim}, instrumentum, pl.n. {admi}.
<ùig>, a nook, cove; from Norse {vík}, bay, creek, Eng. @Eng{wick}, {-wich}.
  Hence the place name {Uig} (Skye, Lewis).  Hence @Ref<ùigean>, a
  fugitive, wanderer.
<uigheil>, pleasant, careful; from @Ref{aoigh.2} in the first meaning and
  from @Ref{ùidh.1} in the second.
<uile>, all, the whole, Ir. @Ir{uile}, O.Ir. @OIr{uile}, {huile}: *{polio-s}, root {pol},
  {pel}, full, many, Gr. @Gr{πολλός} (= @Gr{πολιος}), much, many; see @Ref{iol-}.
  Stokes and most philologists refer it to *{oljo-s}, Eng. @Eng{all}, Ger.
  {all}, Got. {alls} (*{olnó-s}, Mayhew).  Some have derived it from
  *{soli-}, Lat. {sollus}, whole, Gr. @Gr{ὁλος}, whence Stokes deduces the
  Brittonic words - W. @W{oll}, all, Corn. @Corn{hol}, Br. @Br{holl}, {oll} (see @Ref{slàn}).
<uileann>, elbow, Ir. @Ir{uille}, g. @Ref{uilleann}, M.Ir. @MIr{uille}, pl.acc. {uillinn},
  O.Ir. @OIr{uilin} (acc.), W., Corn. @Corn@W{elin}, Br. @Br{ilin}, {elin}: *{olên-}; Gr.
  @Gr{ὠλήν}, @Gr{ὠλένη}; Lat. {ulna}; Ag.S. {eln}, Eng. @Eng{ell}, {elbow}.
<uilear>, enough, etc.; see @Ref{fuilear}.
<uill> ({ùill}, H.S.D.), oil thou, <uilleadh>, oil (n.); see @Ref{ola}.
<uilleann>, honeysuckle, so Ir. (O'B.), M.Ir. @MIr{feithlend}, woodbine;
  see under @Ref{feith}.
<uilm>, coffer (Carm.):
<uim->, circum, Ir. @Ir{uim-}, O.Ir. @OIr{imm-}; a composition form of @Ref{mu},
  q.v.  Hence @Ref<uime>, about him, it, Ir. @Ir{uime}, O.Ir. @OIr{uimbi};
  @Ref<uimpe>, about her (= {imb-sì} or {imb-shi}).
<ùin>, @Ref<ùine>, time, Ir. @Ir{uain}, time, opportunity, E.Ir. @EIr{úine}, O.Ir.
  {úain}, leisure, time: *{ut-nio-}, root {ut}, {vet} of @Ref{feith}, wait.
  Strachan gives *{ucn-} as a reduced form, from {euq}, Skr. {ókas},
  comfort, @Gr{εὔκηλος}, free from care, at ease.
<ùinich>, bustle, tumultus; see @Ref{uainneart}.
<uinicionn>, lambskin (Carm.); for {uainicionn}.
<uinneag>, a window, M.G. {fuinneóg}, M.Ir. @MIr{fuindeog}, {fuindeoc};
  from Norse {windauga}, Sc. {winnock}, Eng. @Eng{window} (= {wind-eye}).
  From Ag.S. {windaége} (Stokes, {Lis.}).
<uinnean.1>, an onion, Ir. @Ir{uinniun}, M.Ir. @MIr{uinneamain}, {uindiun}, W.
  {wynwynyn}; from Lat. {union-em}, O.Fr. {oignon}, Eng. @Eng{onion},
  from {unus}, one.
--page 387
<uinnean.2>, ankle:
<uinnseann>, ash, Ir. @Ir{uinseann}, M.Ir. @MIr{fuindseog}, ash-tree, O.Ir.
  {ind-huinnius}, W. @W{on}, {onen}, earlier {onn}, {onnen}, Br. @Br{ounnenn}.
  Corn. @Corn{onnen}: *{osnâ}, *{osnestu-}; Lat. {ornus} (*{osinos}); Lit. {ůsis},
  ash, Russ. {ясенй}.  Cf. Eng. @Eng{ash}.
<uipear>, unhandy craftsman, bungler:
<uipinn>, a treasure, hoard; cf. @Ref{uibe}.
<ùir>, mould, dust, earth, Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{úir}, E.Ir. @EIr{úr}, g. {úire}: *{ûrâ};
  Norse {aurr}, loam, wet clay, mud, Ag.S. {eár}, humus.  Stokes
  hesitates between *{ûrâ} and *{ugrâ}, Gr. @Gr{ὑγρός}, wet.
<uircean>, a young pig, Ir. @Ir{uircín}, M.Ir. @MIr{orcán}, porcellus, {oircnín}
  (do.), {orc}, porcus; *{porko-s}; Lat. {porcus}; Eng. @Eng{farrow}, {pork};
  Lit. {pàrszas}, boar.
<uiread>, as much, amount, Ir. @Ir{oiread}, O.Ir. @OIr{erat}, {airet}, length of
  time, distance, {cia eret}, quamdiu: *{are-vet-to-}, root {vet} of
  @Ref{feith}.
<uireas>, below, down; see @Ref{ioras}.
<uireasbhuidh>, need, poverty, so Ir., M.Ir. @MIr{auresbadh}; from @Ref{air}
  and @Ref{easbhuidh}, q.v.
<uirghioll>, faculty of speech, speech, Ir. @Ir{uirghíol}, a command
  (O'B.), {uraghall}, {uradhall}, speech (Keat.), E.Ir. @EIr{uirgill},
  for {ur-fhuigell}, M.Ir. @MIr{urfhoighill}:
<uiridh>, @Ref<an uiridh>, last year, Ir. @Ir{annuraidh}, E.Ir. @EIr{inn uraid}, O.Ir.
  {urid}: *{peruti}; Skr. {parut}, last year; Gr. @Gr{πέρυσι}, Dor.
  @Dor{πέρυτι}; root {vet} of @Ref{feith}.
<uirigh>, a couch, bed: *{air-sed-}, root {sed} of @Ref{suidhe}?
<uiriollach>, a precipice (H.S.D. from MSS.): *{air-ailech}, from @Ref{ail.2},
  rock, q.v.
<uirisg>, offspring of fairy and mortal (M`F.); see @Ref{ùruisg}.
<ùirlios>, a walled garden, Ir. @Ir{uirlios} (O'B., etc.); from @Ref{air} and @Ref{lios}.
<ùirneis.1>, a furnace, Ir. @Ir{uirnéis}, {fúirnéis} (O'B.), M.Ir. @MIr{forneis}; from
  Eng. and O.Fr. {fornaise}, Lat. {fornacem}, {fornax}, oven.
<ùirneis.2>, tools, implements, Ir. @Ir{úirnéis} (Fol., O'R.), {úirlis} (Con.);
  see @Ref{airneis}.
<uirsgeil>, a spreading (as of dung or hay to dry); from @Ref{air} and
  @Ref{sgoil}.
<uirsgeul>, a fable, romance, so Ir.; from @Ref{air} and @Ref{sgeul}.
<ùis>, use, utility; from the Eng. @Eng{use}, Lat. {ûsus}.
<uiseag>, a lark, Ir. @Ir{uiseóg}, {fuiseóg}, W. @W{uchedydd}, Br. @Br{ec'houedez}, also
  W. @W{ucheda}, to soar; from *{ux}, up, as in {uas}, @Ref{uasal}?
<uisg>, @Ref<uisge>, water, Ir. @Ir{uisge}, O.Ir. @OIr{uisce}, {usce}: *{ud-s-kio}, root {ud},
  {ved}; Gr. @Gr{ὕδωρ}, @Gr{ὑδος}; Eng. @Eng{water}, etc.; Skr. {udán}; further
  Lat. {unda}, wave.  Stokes suggests the possibility of @Ref{uisge}
  being for *{uskio-}, and allied to Eng. @Eng{wash}.
--page 388
<uisliginn>, disturbance, fury:
<uislinn>, sport, diversion, Ir. @Ir{uslainn} (Lh., etc.):
<uist>, hist! whist! Lat. {st!} Eng. @Eng{hist!}
<ula>, @Ref<ulachan> (pl.), beard, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{ulcha}, g. {ulchain}: *{ulukon-};
  *{pulu-}, beard; Skr. {pula}, {pulaka}, horripilation; Gr. @Gr{πύλιγγες},
  hair of chairs (Hes.).  Hence {Ulaid}, Ulster.  It may be root
  {ul}, {vel}, cover (see @Ref{olann}).
<ulag.1>, block, pulley, "sonwball" (Wh.); from Eng. @Eng{pulley}, L.Lat.
  {polanus}?
<ulag.2>, oatmeal and water mixed:
<ulaidh>, a treasure, Ir. @Ir{uladh}, charnel-house, E.Ir. @EIr{ulud}, stone
  tomb; root {ul}, {vel}, cover?  A Gadelic *{alvet0}, allied to Lat.
  {alvus}, a belly, {alveus}, channel, has been suggested.
<ulbh>, you brute! (Sutherland); from Norse {úlfr}, wolf.
<ulbhach> (@Ref<ul'ach>), ashes, W. @W{ulw}, pl. {ulwyn}: *{polviko-}, *{pôlven-};
  Lat. {pulvis}, dust, {pollen}, pollen.
<ulartaich>, @Ref<ulfhartaich>, howling; from *{ul}, bark (Gr. @Gr{ὑλάω}, bark,
  Lat. {ulula}, owl, etc.), and {art} of @Ref{comhart}, q.v.
<ullachadh>, preparation, preparing, Ir. @Ir{ullmhuighim}, I prepare;
  from @Ref{ullamh}, ready.
<ullag>, a mouthful of meal (Sh.); cf. @Ref{ulag.2}.
<ullamh>, ready, Ir. @Ir{ullamh}, for {urlamh}, E.Ir. @EIr{erlam}, paratus; from
  @Ref{air} and {lam}, the latter being from @Ref{làmh}, hand: "to hand,
  handy".  Usually referred to root {las}, desire, Lat. {lascivus},
  Eng. @Eng{lascivious}.
<ultach>, a lapful, armful, Ir. @Ir{ullthach} (O'B.), M.Ir. @MIr{utlach}, lapful,
  {urtlach}, lap: *{ar-tḷ-ac-}; root {tol}, {tel}, lift (see @Ref{toil}, @Ref{tlàth}).  G.
  {ulathach}, burden in one's arms = {ultach} (Wh.).
<ùmaidh>, dolt, blockhead; see @Ref{umpaidh}.
<umha>, copper, brass, Ir. @Ir{umha}, O.Ir. @OIr{humæ}, {ume}, copper, brass,
  {umaide}, {humide}, aeneus, W. @W{efydd}, O.W. @OW{emid}, aere; *{umâjo-}
  (Stokes), *{omja} (Ascoli), *{um-ajo-}, {-ajo-} = {aes} (Bez.).
<umhail>, heed, attention, Ir. @Ir{umhail}, {úmhail} (O'B., Con.); cf.
  @Ref{ùmhal}.
<ùmhal>, obedient (@Ref<umhailt>, Dial.), Ir. @Ir{umhal}, E.Ir., O.Ir. @OIr@Ir{umal},
  W. @W{ufyll}, Corn. @Corn{huvel}, Br. @Br{vuel}; from Lat. {humilis}, Eng.
  {humble}.
<ùmlagh>, a fine, @Ref<unlagh> (Arg.); from Sc. {unlaw}, {unlach}, a fine,
  transgression, {un-law}.
<umpaidh>, a boor, clown, idiot (Sh., O'R.); see @Ref{ùmaidh}.
<ung>, anoint, Ir. @Ir{ungaim}, O.Ir. @OIr{ongim}; from Lat. {ungue}.  W. has
  {enenio} from *{o^inj-}.
<unnsa>, an ounce, Ir. @Ir{únsa}, W. @W{wns}; from Eng.  The O.Ir. is
  {unga}, from Lat. {uncia}.
--page 389
<unradh>, adversity (Campbell's Tales, II. Mac-a-rusgaich); a form
  of {an-rath}?
<ùp>, push, @Ref<ùpag>, a push; cf. W. @W{hwp}, a push, effort.  Cf. @Ref{pùc}.
  Onomatopoetic.
<ùr>, fresh, new, Ir., E.Ir. @EIr{úr}, O.Ir. @OIr{húrde}, vividarium, W. @W{ir},
  fresh, green: *{ûro-s}, *{pûro-s}; Lat. {pûros}, Eng. @Eng{pure}.
  Usually referred to *{ugro-s}, Gr. @Gr{ὑγρός}, wet, Lat. {uvidus},
  moist, root {veℊ}.
<urcag>, thole pin (N.Lochaber).  Cf. {àrcan}, a cork.
<urchair>, a shot, cast, Ir. @Ir{urchur}, E.Ir. @EIr{urchur}, {aurchor}, {erchor}, W.
  {ergyr}, O.Br. @OBr{ercor}, ictum: *{are-koru-}, a cast; from @Ref{cuir},
---JTM: changed single occurrence of O.B. to O.Br.
  send, q.v.
<urchall>, fetters, shackles, so Ir. (Lh., etc.): *{are-col-}, root {col}, {cel}
  of @Ref{timchioll}?
<urchasg>, physic, antidote, Ir. @Ir{urchosg}, preservative, antidote:
  *{air-chosg}, from {cosg}, {casg}, stop, q.v.
<urchoid>, hurt, mischief, Ir. @Ir{urchóid}, O.Ir. @OIr{erchoit}: *{are-kkonti-}, Gr.
  @Gr{κεντέω}, stick, prick, @Gr{καíνω}, kill.  Stokes prefers *{skonti-}, as
  stem, allied to Eng. @Eng{scathe}.
<urla>, face, hair, breast, Ir. @Ir{urla}, lock of hair, long hair of the
  head, E.Ir. @EIr{urla}, {irla}: *{air-la-}, where {la} is for {vla}, root {vel}
  of @Ref{falt}?
<ùrlabhairt>, eloquence, Ir. @Ir{urlabhair}, elocution, E.Ir. @EIr{erlabra}:
  *{air-labhair}; see @Ref{labhair}.
<ùrlach>, stag (R.D.):
<ùrlaich>, turn from in disgust (Arg.):
<ùrlaim>, readiness (M`F.), Ir. @Ir{úrlamh}, ready; see @Ref<ullamh>.  Hence
  also @Ref<ùrlaimh>, expert, O.Ir. @OIr{erlam}, {irlam}.
<ùrlamhas>, possession, Ir. @Ir{úrlámhus}, {forlamhus}; from {for}, super,
  and @Ref{làmh}, hand: "upper-handed-ness".
<ùrlann>, a staff, Ir. @Ir{úrlann}, a staff, spear staff, M.Ir. @MIr{urlannn}, staff
  of a spear: *{air-lann}, from @Ref{lann.1}: also E.Ir. @EIr{irlond}, hinder
  end of a spear or ship.
<ùrlar>, a floor, lowest part, Ir. @Ir{urlár}: *{air-lár}, from @Ref{làr}, floor, q.v.
<ùrnuigh>, a prayer, Ir. @Ir{urnuighe}, O.G. {ernacde} (B.of Deer), O.Ir.
  {irnigde}, {irnichte}: *{are-nakô}, I strive for, root {nak}, {enk}, as in
  @Ref{thig}?  Zimmer gives the root {iℊh}, desire, Gr. @Gr{ἰχανᾶν}, desire,
  Lit. {igiju}, strive after, Skr. {îh}, long for, dividing it into *{air-con-ig}
  (*{air-in-ig}?).  O.?Ir. @OIr{arnigim}: {ig} = Gr. @Gr{ἰχαρ}; {arn} =
---gjk (1.16) O.?Ir. is in original
  *{paran}, Gr. @Gr{παρά} (St.Zeit. 36).
<urra>, a person, infant; cf. @Ref{urradh}.
<urradh>, @Ref<urrainn.2>, authority, guarantee, author, Ir. @Ir{urra(dh)},
  surety, author, defendant, {urrain}, stay, prop, M.Ir. @MIr{errudus},
  responsibility; from @Ref{ràth.2}, @Ref{ràthan}, surety.  {Urradha} were a
  chief's "gentlemen" paying rent or servic (Sil.Gad.).
--page 390
<urrainn.1>, power, @Ref<is urrainn>, can; Ir. @Ir{urra}, power, {urrain}, stay.
  See @Ref{urradh}, @Ref{urrainn.2}.
<urrainn.2>, authority, guarantee, author; see @Ref{urradh}.
---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<urrail>, forward, bold, @Ref<urranta>, Ir. @Ir{urránta}, bold, confident in one's
  might; from @Ref{urradh}.
<urram>, honour, respect, Ir. @Ir{urram}, {urraim}, honour, deference,
  submission, M.Ir. @MIr{urraim}, homage: *{air-réim}?
<urras>, surety, guarantee, Ir. @Ir{urrúdhas}, {urrús}; from @Ref{urradh}.
<ursainn>, a door-post, Ir. @Ir{ursa}, g. {ursann}, E.Ir. @EIr{ursa}, {aursa}, {irsa},
  d. {ursaind}, W. @W{gorsin}: *{are-stan-}, root {sta}, stand.
<ùruisg>, a Brownie; from @Ref{uisge}, @Ref{air}+@Ref{uisg}.
<us>, impudence (M`A.):
<usa>, easier, Ir. @Ir{usa}, O.Ir. @OIr{assu}, facilius, {asse}, facilis; cf. W. @W{haws},
  from {hawdd}, easy; further Fr. {aisé}, Eng. @Eng{easy}, Got. {azets},
  easy.
<usaid>, querulousness (M`A. and Wh.):
<usga>, holy, sacred (Carm.):

<usgar.1>, a jewel, bell on liquor:

---gjk (1.14) inserted entry
<uspag>, a push, pang, Ir. @Ir{uspóg}; cf. @Ref{ospag}.
<uspair>, an ugly or lumpish fellow, Ir. @Ir{uspán}, a shapeless lump,
  chaos, clumsy fellow.  See @Ref{uspan}.
<uspairn>, strife, Ir. @Ir{uspairneachd}: *{ud-spairn}, from @Ref{spàirn}.
<uspan>, a shapeless mass, Ir. @Ir{uspán}: also @Ref<usp> (@Ref<ùsp>); cf. @Ref{uibe},
  *{uibs-}?
<ut! ut!> interjection of disapprobation, Eng. @Eng{tut}, {hoot}, W. @W{hwt}, etc.
<utag>, @Ref<ùtag> (Arg.), strife, confusion; also "push, jostle", @Ref<ut>, push.
  Cf. @Ref{put.2}, {putag}.
---gjk (1.14) review: ref to which sense of {putag}?
<ùtan>, a knuckle (Sh., O'R.), better {utan}:
<ùth>, an udder, E.Ir. @EIr{uth}.  Stokes gives the stem as *{(p)utu-}, Lit.
  {suputimas}, a swelling, {putlùs}, swollen.  Lat. {ûber}, Gr. @Gr{οὖθαρ},
  Eng. @Eng{udder} have been compared, but the Gadelic lacks the
  terminal {-er}, and the consonant is {t} rather than {d} or {dh}.  Cf.
  Lat. {uter}, skin-bag.
<uthard>, above, on high, Ir. @Ir{ós}, {árd}.  Gaelic is for *{for-ard}, "on high";
  see @Ref{air} and @Ref{àrd}.
<utraid>, district road (Carm.); see @Ref{ùdrathad}.
---gjk (1.13) originally ref to {udrathad}
<ùtrais>, a confused mass of anything, a fidgeting.
